Title: Colin Powell Criticizes Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton in Leaked Emails

Article:

Former Secretary of State Colin Powell, in a series of leaked emails, has criticized both Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump and Democratic candidate Hillary Clinton. The emails, obtained by the website DCLeaks.com and first reported by Buzzfeed News, reportedly have ties to Russian intelligence services, according to a federal law official.

In a June 17 email to a former aide, Powell called Trump a "national disgrace" and an "international pariah," stating that the Republican presidential contender was "in the process of destroying himself, no need for Dems to attack him."

In an Aug. 21 email to the same former aide, Powell criticized Trump for spurring the "racist" so-called "birther" movement, a consistently debunked rumor that President Barack Obama was born in another country.

Powell also dismissed Trump's stated overtures to African-American voters, writing, "There is nothing he can say that will sway black voters so he might as well say it to white folks."

In the same day's email to former Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice, Powell called the ongoing investigations into the 2012 attack on the U.S. consulate and another facility in Libya that left four Americans dead, including U.S. ambassador Chris Stevens, a "stupid witch hunt."

Powell, in a 2015 email to Rice, also criticized Clinton, stating, "Basic fault falls on a courageous ambassador who thought Libyans now love me and I am ok in this very vulnerable place. But blame also rests on his leaders and supporters back here. Pat Kennedy, Intel community, DS and yes, HRC."

The House Select Committee on Benghazi report released in June found an array of bureaucratic miscues and inter-agency blunders but does not specifically blame Clinton.

The revelations mark the latest in a string of headlines around Powell's email correspondence. His online activity has figured heavily in the controversy around Clinton's use of a private email server.

Powell expressed frustration about his name being linked to Clinton's email issues, writing in another leaked email, "I have told Hilleary’s [sic] minions repeatedly that they are making a mistake trying to drag me in, yet they still try."

In July of 2015, Powell complained to his broker at Merrill Lynch that questions raised about Clinton’s email and speaking fees impacted his life, stating, "I had a gig cancelled because the client, a public university, caught hell from overpaying HRC."

"HRC is the gift that keeps on taking," Powell wrote in the July 1, 2015 email, according to the leaked documents.

In a 2014 email, Powell, not referring to Clinton by name, described her as having "unbridled ambition, greedy, not transformational" along with some colorful references to her husband's rumored philandering, rumors he attributed to the New York Post.

While Powell has described himself as a lifelong Republican, he twice endorsed Obama, a Democrat, for president.

Title: Bipartisan Opposition to ObamaCare-Tied Medical Device Tax Prompts Calls for Delay

Article:

A group of U.S. senators, including Democrats and Republicans, have expressed concerns about a 2.3 percent tax on medical devices that is set to take effect on January 1, 2013, as part of the Affordable Care Act. The tax aims to raise nearly $30 billion over the next decade.

The senators, led by Minnesota Democratic Sen. Amy Klobuchar and North Carolina Democratic Sen. Kay Hagan, wrote a letter to Senate Democratic Leader Harry Reid on Monday, urging a delay in the implementation of the tax. They argue that the tax could harm the medical technology industry, which directly employs over 400,000 people in the United States and is responsible for 2 million high-skilled manufacturing jobs.

The lawmakers contend that the tax could cause significant uncertainty and confusion for businesses, and they urge Reid to support a delay in enactment in a fiscally responsible manner. They also argue that the tax could hurt the U.S.'s global leadership position in the medical technology industry and potentially lead to job losses.

It is unclear whether any changes to the planned tax could be included as part of a broader deal to avert the looming fiscal crisis. The Republican-controlled House already voted to repeal the tax over the summer, but the Senate has not taken it up.

Republican Georgia Rep. Tom Price has also called for the tax to be repealed, stating that it could serve as a common ground for both parties in efforts to serve the American people. Stephen J. Ubl, president of the Advanced Medical Technology Association, has also expressed concerns, stating that the tax could cost thousands of jobs and hinder the ability of medical technology companies to find tomorrow's treatments and cures.

The tax would apply to a broad range of devices, including X-ray machines, ultrasound equipment, and pacemakers. Equipment makers argue that the tax, which is based on gross sales, could end up being much higher than 2.3 percent. One industry spokesman with Indiana-based Cook Medical estimated earlier this year that the actual impact on earnings is more like 15 percent. Cook Medical also announced earlier this year that it was scrapping plans to open five new plants due to the tax.

Dozens of other CEOs have issued similar warnings, stating that the looming tax could put whole companies out of business. However, the administration has defended the provision, arguing that the medical device companies could benefit from the law due to the increased demand for equipment from the millions of new health care customers insured as a result of the law.

Title: Trump's Rhetoric and Media Bias: A Neutral Analysis of the Relationship Between President Trump and the Media

Article:

In a recent rally in Phoenix, President Donald Trump deviated from his prepared remarks, launching into a 30-minute tirade against journalists. The President's rhetoric during this rant drew comparisons to the character Joe Pesci portrayed in the movie "Goodfellas," with some noting similarities to a Queens-born "wise guy" rather than a dignified occupant of the Oval Office.

The comparison between Trump and Pesci is not an assertion of the President's criminality but rather a reflection of the impassioned, sometimes combative tone in Trump's speeches.

The author, a former journalist at CBS News for 28 years, notes that he has witnessed liberal bias and elitism in the media during his career, but he never saw anything resembling the "fake news" that Trump frequently decries. He emphasizes that he never encountered journalists fabricating stories out of thin air.

During the Phoenix rally, Trump accused journalists of attributing stories to unnamed sources that do not exist. While there have been instances of journalists making up quotes from nonexistent sources, such occurrences are extremely rare. Trump's characterization of "fake news" as news he dislikes has been a recurring theme in his criticism of the media.

The author also addresses several high-profile media errors since Trump took office, such as CNN's erroneous report in early June that former FBI Director James Comey would contradict the President's assertion that Comey had informed him he was not under investigation. The story was retracted, and three of CNN's top investigative reporters resigned.

In late June, CNN published a story alleging ties between Trump adviser Anthony Scaramucci and a Russian investment fund under investigation by the United States Senate. The story was later retracted, and the network's top investigative reporters resigned. The New York Times reported that the incident was an "embarrassing episode" for CNN, particularly given the widespread mistrust in the media and Trump's regular attacks on the press.

The author argues that while the CNN journalists did not fabricate the story, their biases may have contributed to mistakes. He suggests that introspection and acknowledging biases are not strong suits among journalists, who often circle the wagons rather than examining their biases and their impact on news coverage.

The author concludes by emphasizing the importance of objective journalism in a free country, where people rely on reporters to be honest brokers of information and to hold powerful individuals accountable. He calls for both Trump and the media to exercise greater fairness in their dealings with each other, acknowledging that both parties have shortcomings.

The author also criticizes the media for abandoning their role as objective observers and taking on the role of anti-Trump activists, which he argues undermines public trust in the media. He suggests that shouting about "fake news" is no way to deal with a press that Trump dislikes, and that proclaiming "fake innocence" is no way to deal with a president that reporters dislike.

Title: U.S. Forces Korea Leads the Way in Addressing Racism in the Military

Article:

U.S. Forces Korea, led by Army Gen. Robert B. Abrams, has taken a leading role in combating racial injustice and discrimination within the American military. The command has allowed at least two major demonstrations on military bases, banned Confederate flags, and initiated listening sessions, social media events, and question-and-answer forums to hear service members' experiences with discrimination.

The steps began shortly after the death of George Floyd, a Black man who died while in Minneapolis police custody last month. By June 15, Gen. Abrams issued guidance banning the Confederate flag, stating it "has the power to inflame feelings of racial division" and must be outlawed.

Gen. Abrams' actions have been praised by numerous specialists and retired military officials for addressing the issue swiftly, a concern the Pentagon has often been slow to address. The military, they say, will be stronger for this.

Top leaders at the Pentagon, including Defense Secretary Mark Esper and Joint Chiefs of Staff Chairman Gen. Mark A. Milley, have also been outspoken on the issue, launching reviews and directing internal investigations into promotion practices and other areas where Blacks could face discrimination.

However, lasting change must take root at lower levels of the military, according to specialists. Leadership from officials such as Gen. Abrams is crucial in setting a standard that all are equal and suppressing any racist tendencies.

Retired Army Lt. Col. Daniel L. Davis, who served as a U.S. adviser to the Second Republic of Korea Army, commended Gen. Abrams, stating, "It sets a standard that we are all equal here... We all have to pull together, work together as a team. It has a suppressive effect on anybody who may harbor these racist tendencies."

Title: Romney's Potential Reaction to Supreme Court's Decision on Obamacare

Article:

Republican presidential candidate Mitt Romney, who previously implemented a state-level health care law similar to the Affordable Care Act (Obamacare), may have a different reaction to the Supreme Court's decision on the federal law compared to other Republicans. There is concern among some GOP circles that if the court strikes down Obamacare, Romney may lose a key issue to rally conservative voters, who have been difficult to inspire.

Representative Patrick McHenry (R-N.C.) stated, "Clearly, the Supreme Court overturning Obamacare is the best thing for the country, but it’s an open question what’s better for November’s election. If the law is upheld, it might drive our people out to the polls."

As the justices prepare to rule this month, both political parties are strategizing on how to position their candidates following the decision. House Republican leaders have been planning a unified GOP response, regardless of the outcome. The White House, with both President Obama's political standing and his signature achievement at risk, is hoping for the law to be upheld in its entirety.

However, Republicans are considering the possibility that a significant blow to the law could energize Obama's base and diminish the urgency of their own activists. A conservative operative involved in the campaign stated, "Obamacare is the one permanent and potentially irreversible [effect] that Obama will have on the country, and if it is overturned, it makes the election, by default, less important."

A CBS/New York Times poll released Thursday found that more than two-thirds of respondents believe the law should be struck down in whole or in part. A ruling against Obamacare could provide Romney, who has campaigned to repeal the law, with a clearer contrast with Obama on health care. On Thursday, Romney stated, "As president, I will work from my first day in office to dismantle Barack Obama’s federal health care takeover and replace it with real reform that strengthens our health care system and puts patients first."

Republicans on Capitol Hill have been discussing the potential outcomes and their effects on the November election, with several lawmakers debating the political implications. Representative Patrick Tiberi (R-Ohio) stated, "I could argue it both ways, and I have argued it both ways. I could see the president, if the mandate is thrown out, using it to rev up his troops."

Title: Network Personalities Adapt to Social Distancing Measures Amid Coronavirus Outbreak

Article:

In response to the ongoing coronavirus outbreak, network personalities are adapting their filming arrangements to practice social distancing. This includes remote work or filming from different parts of the same studio.

One of the top-rated morning shows on cable news, Fox & Friends, has seen changes in the interplay between co-hosts Steve Doocy, Ainsley Earhardt, and Brian Kilmeade, who usually sit on a "curvy couch" in a studio in Manhattan. On Tuesday, only Doocy sat on the couch, while his co-hosts sat in other parts of the same studio, one level down.

Kilmeade explained, "To be responsible, to show social distancing, all three of us are apart." Doocy added, "We're doing exactly the same thing people all across America are trying to do, and that is: Stay away from each other, because you don't want to get infected, and you don't want to spread infections."

Similar adjustments have been made on other networks. On MSNBC, Morning Joe personalities Joe Scarborough, Mika Brzezinski, and Willie Geist beamed in from different locations on Tuesday. On CNN, New Day co-hosts Alisyn Camerota and John Berman sat at the same desk, but several feet apart, in line with the recommended six feet of separation guideline.

Representatives for Fox News, MSNBC, and CNN have all confirmed that their on-air staffers are practicing social distancing. At MSNBC, guests who come to the network's 30 Rock headquarters in New York for on-camera appearances will do so from a "separate location," the network said. On-air staffers who sit at the same desk will always be at least six feet apart.

On Monday, MSNBC anchor Joshua Johnson highlighted the distance between himself and the other people on his panel. "You may have noticed if you've been watching these specials for the last few days that we've been all at this one table," he said. "We're not doing that anymore."

Across the television news industry, shows have cut out live audiences. At least one prominent host, The View co-host Joy Behar, has taken a temporary leave from her perch out of concern about potentially contracting the illness.

On Tuesday morning, Today show host Al Roker beamed in live from his kitchen after he and fellow host Craig Melvin went into self-quarantine after a staffer on the third hour of the show's franchise tested positive for the virus. "I didn't have to commute in, so I did sleep in," he said.

Title: Speaker Paul D. Ryan Announces Retirement from House of Representatives

Article:

Speaker of the House Paul D. Ryan (R-WI) announced on Wednesday that he will retire from Congress at the end of this year, marking the conclusion of a two-decade political career. The announcement was made at a press conference in the morning following a private disclosure to colleagues during the weekly House Republican meeting.

Ryan cited family commitments as the primary reason for his decision, stating, "If I am here for one more term, my kids will only have ever known me as a weekend dad. I just can't let that happen. So I will be setting new priorities in my life."

Despite speculation that the GOP may face a challenging midterm election in November, Ryan expressed confidence in the party's ability to maintain control of the House, citing a strong economy and significant legislative achievements. He also emphasized his intention to remain active as a lame-duck speaker, stating, "I'm not done yet. I intend to run through the tape."

Rumors of Ryan's departure had circulated for months, and he and his aides had consistently denied them. Several lawmakers are expected to compete for Ryan's succession, including House Majority Leader Kevin McCarthy (R-CA) and House Whip Steve Scalise (R-LA).

Ryan has served as speaker for a little over two years and has overseen a turbulent period, facing down conservative rebellions and securing a large tax cut, but failing to repeal Obamacare. His efforts to rewrite the federal budget to bring more accountability to social spending programs have also faced opposition, even from within his own party.

In the past, Ryan has been a prominent critic of President Trump during the 2016 campaign, but he has since become the president's most effective ally on Capitol Hill, helping to push the White House agenda. President Trump tweeted after the news broke, "Speaker Paul Ryan is a truly good man, and while he will not be seeking re-election, he will leave a legacy of achievement that nobody can question. We are with you Paul!"

Democrats expressed hope that Ryan, now free from having to face voters, would turn on President Trump and his colleagues. Senate Minority Leader Charles E. Schumer (D-NY) stated, "With his newfound political freedom, I hope the Speaker uses his remaining time in Congress to break free from the hard-right factions of his caucus that have kept Congress from getting real things done."

Republicans, however, expressed doubt that Ryan's retirement would significantly alter the political landscape. Representative Kevin Brady (R-TX), who succeeded Ryan as chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, stated, "We're going to continue to rally behind him. I think the main reason for this is his family. He's never been a lifer."

Ryan faced a tougher-than-usual election fight back home in Wisconsin this year, with several Democrats vying to challenge him. Kyle Kondik, of the University of Virginia's Center for Politics, stated that the announcement gives Democrats a much better shot of picking up the seat, which Ryan has held since 1999.

Ryan faced a challenge for the seat from Paul Nehlen, a man with white supremacist ties who was severed by the state party in 2018 and had his Twitter account suspended for anti-Semitism.

Title: Trump's Meeting with Evangelical Leaders May Signify a Shift in Voting Tendencies

Article:

In a strategic move to secure the evangelical voting bloc, former President Donald Trump met with hundreds of evangelical leaders in Times Square, New York, on Tuesday. This demographic is crucial for Trump's presidential aspirations.

During the meeting, Trump expressed his commitment to defending religious liberty, including his intention to repeal IRS restrictions that limit political discourse from the pulpit. He stated that a repeal could potentially be his "biggest contribution to Christianity."

Among the 900 or so evangelical leaders, some who were initially not in favor of Trump seemed to change their stance after the meeting. Matt Barber, founder and editor-in-chief of BarbWire.com, stated, "The ball has moved forward a little bit. And I appreciate Mr. Trump's willingness to reach out to the evangelical community."

Trump contrasted his Supreme Court picks with those that Hillary Clinton might nominate, emphasizing that his choices would be more aligned with the evangelical community's values. Trump also spoke about the need for evangelicals to unite as their rights and values are under attack.

Attendees praised Trump for his lack of major mistakes or missteps during the meeting. Gary Bauer, president of American Values, recalled, "I can't remember any time during the several hours this morning that his answer disappointed or that there was chagrin about it."

Mike Huckabee, former Governor of Arkansas, commended Trump for his openness and interaction with the leaders, stating, "He did something that most Republican nominees in the past have refused to do and that's walk into this room and be willing to sit down, take their questions, and really interact with them in a very big way."

With some evangelicals still expressing reservations, Trump will need to continue outreach efforts. Rev. Samuel Rodriguez, president of the National Hispanic Christian Leadership Conference, predicted, "As it pertains to the evangelical vote and the candidacy of Donald J. Trump, today's meeting may very well be a tipping point."

Rodriguez noted that he knew many pastors who were initially skeptical but changed their views after the meeting. "After hearing his commitment, his very well-defined, articulated commitment to religious liberty and life, the Supreme Court especially, I think you saw a number of the same pastors walk out going, 'that's what I needed to hear,'" Rodriguez said.

The meeting comes after a series of challenging weeks for the Trump campaign. It will be essential for them to capitalize on any progress made by encouraging evangelicals to actively support Trump within their congregations. Trump also announced the formation of an Evangelical Executive Advisory Board.

Title: Ann Romney's Prime-Time Speech at the GOP Convention Emphasizes Struggles and Family Ties

Article:

Ann Romney, the wife of Republican presidential nominee Mitt Romney, delivered a heartfelt and personal speech during the GOP convention on Tuesday, focusing on their shared struggles, family life, and her own health challenges.

In her much-anticipated prime-time address, Ann Romney spoke candidly about their "real marriage," rather than a "storybook marriage," and shared her experiences with breast cancer and multiple sclerosis, as well as the trials of raising five children.

Barbara Bair, a delegate from York, Pennsylvania, praised Ann Romney's speech, stating, "I was so glad she had this opportunity to talk to the women of America, to have them hear about the trials they went through. And to hear that her husband is a man that stands behind her, supporting her through breast cancer. There is nothing scarier for families than cancer."

The speech was intended to humanize Mitt Romney, but it primarily served to humanize Ann Romney, a woman of great attractiveness and expensive polish, and, by extension, her husband. The aim was to help Mitt Romney appeal more to women who may have been wary of the Republican Party's positions on reproductive and workplace rights.

Kitty Dunn, a 65-year-old delegate from Utah who has met the Romneys, commented, "She may have privilege, but she understands."

Although Ann Romney began her speech with the statement, "I want to talk to you about love," she later shifted to a tougher, more strident defense of her husband, his unheralded good works, and his business success. She defended Bain Capital, the investment firm her husband co-founded, as a company that "has helped so many others lead better lives."

Despite the more assertive tone, Ann Romney's softer, personal approach, including her exclamation of "I love you women!" and her connection made talking about her own struggles, was effective.

Greg Treat, a 34-year-old delegate and state senator from Oklahoma, commented, "I think Ann Romney will make a difference. Michelle Obama is a huge positive for the president, and Mrs. Romney will be for her husband as well."

Title: Google Bans Far-Right Websites ZeroHedge and The Federalist from Ad Platform Over Policy Violations

Article:

Google has banned the far-right websites ZeroHedge and The Federalist from its advertising platform due to policy violations related to content about recent Black Lives Matter protests. The company issued a warning to The Federalist on Tuesday over comments on articles related to the protests, but ZeroHedge was banned last week.

Google's spokesperson stated in an email that the websites violated its policies on content related to race, promoting derogatory content that promotes hatred, intolerance, violence, or discrimination based on race. The spokesperson added that when a page or site violates its policies, it removes the ability to monetize with Google.

After publication of this story, Google clarified on Tuesday that The Federalist had been warned about policy violations but still had time to address them. On Wednesday morning, Google stated that The Federalist had removed the comments that violated its policies, and it would take no further action.

The Center for Countering Digital Hate, a British nonprofit that combats online hate and misinformation, found that 10 U.S.-based websites, including ZeroHedge and The Federalist, published what they say are racist articles about the protests. The Center for Countering Digital Hate also found advertisements for many companies that had otherwise made public statements supporting Black Lives Matter and the recent protests running on the websites.

Imran Ahmed, CEO of the Center for Countering Digital Hate, said they found content outright racist in defense of white supremacism and containing conspiracy theories about George Floyd and the Black Lives Matter movement on the websites.

Google has banned various websites from its advertising platform in recent years, mostly targeting fake news operations. ZeroHedge and The Federalist have become well known in recent years for publishing far-right articles on a variety of subjects.

As the Black Lives Matter protests unfolded over recent weeks, hundreds of corporations have lent their support. This includes Google, which said it has donated $12 million in funding to organizations working to address racial inequities.

There are other similar websites that continue to generate revenue through Google, causing continued concern for civil rights advocates. In its research, the Center for Countering Digital Hate pointed to examples of articles on other far-right websites that carried advertisements by well-known brands while disseminating false narratives about the protest movement.

Caroline McCarthy, vice president of communications and content at TrueX, a digital advertising company, said companies need to hold Google and other digital advertising companies responsible for where their ads run. "The reality is that they [brands] have to start by asking questions," McCarthy said. "They have to say, what is my brand content going to be running against? And if the other person on the other side of the conversation can’t give them a straight answer, then that’s a problem."

"The pressure on the tech companies is only going to come from dollars actually, literally getting pulled," she added.

Title: Jeb Bush's Use of Term "Anchor Babies" Sparks Controversy Among Latinos

Article:

In a recent exchange with reporters in New Hampshire, former Governor Jeb Bush used the term "anchor babies" to refer to the U.S.-born children of undocumented immigrants. The term has sparked controversy, with many in the Latino community finding it offensive and inaccurate.

Raul A. Reyes, an attorney and member of the USA Today board of contributors, has criticized Bush's use of the term, stating that it is a "disgusting slur." Reyes, who is active on Twitter (@RaulAReyes), emphasizes that the term is dehumanizing to Latinos, immigrants, and children who are as American as anyone else.

The term "anchor baby" is often associated with the belief that having an American-born child can protect undocumented individuals from deportation. The child, in this line of thought, "anchors" a family in the United States and allows them to gain citizenship. However, having a citizen child does not provide protection from possible deportation. In the first six months of 2011, parents with U.S.-citizen children accounted for 22% of deportees. Between 2010 and 2012, the United States deported nearly 205,000 parents of citizen kids, and in 2013, over 72,000 were deported, according to The Huffington Post.

Another misconception surrounding "anchor babies" is that people from foreign countries are rushing to the United States to have children. While there has been a phenomenon known as "birth tourism" among Asian mothers who temporarily relocate to the United States to have a child, their numbers are statistically small. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention estimates that 7,955 children were born to foreign residents in 2012. Research has shown that the overwhelming majority of undocumented immigrants come to the United States to work.

Title: Google Fires Employee Over Controversial Memo on Gender Dynamics in Tech Industry

Article:

Google terminated the employment of software engineer James Damore on Monday, following the publication of a 10-page memo he authored that criticized the company's approach to hiring women and suggested biological differences between men and women could contribute to the underrepresentation of women in the tech industry.

Damore's memo, which argued that men, on average, may be biologically more suited to coding jobs than women, sparked a heated debate on social media and within the tech industry. Some found his views offensive and destructive, while others embraced him as a brave truth-teller.

The incident echoes past examples of the wide gulf between U.S. conservative activists and the tech sector. In 2014, Brendan Eich was forced out as Mozilla's chief executive after his opposition to gay marriage became public. Tech companies often gave benefits to same-sex couples well before gay marriage was legalized.

Andrew Torba, chief executive of the social network Gab, which is popular among conservatives, offered Damore a job, stating that "censorship is for losers." WikiLeaks publisher Julian Assange also extended a job offer to Damore, writing on Twitter that "censorship is for losers."

Aaron Ginn, co-founder of the Lincoln Network, a group of libertarian-leaning tech workers and investors, criticized Google's decision to fire Damore, stating that the company should have put him through training instead. "You're going to make him a martyr," Ginn said. "In this hyper-tribal political day we are in, I think you'd want to try to avoid making him a martyr."

Intense political feelings have recently divided two board members of Facebook Inc, according to a report by the New York Times. Last August, Reed Hastings, chief executive of Netflix Inc, warned investor Peter Thiel in an email that Thiel's support for Republican U.S. President Donald Trump showed "catastrophically bad judgment." The outcome of that dispute is not known. Hastings and Thiel remain on Facebook's board.

Google, which has used the motto "Don't be evil," received accolades from many quarters for treating Damore's memo as a threat to its corporate culture. However, critics argue that the memo is toxic to the tech community and that it categorizes women as weak or incompetent.

Damore, who could not be reached for comment on Tuesday, said in an email to ███ on Monday that he was exploring a possible legal challenge to his dismissal. His case would likely be weak, employment lawyers said, and some lawyers said Google could have faced lawsuits if it had not acted against him.

Google said it could not discuss individual employee cases. Damore's title at Google was software engineer, and he had worked at the company since December 2013, according to a profile on LinkedIn. The LinkedIn page also states that Damore received a Master's degree in systems biology from Harvard University in 2013, not a PhD, as previously reported.

Industry experts note that in the early days of tech, it was mostly women who held the then-unglamorous jobs of coding. However, as the value of top-notch programming became clear, men came to dominate the field.

Other tech companies on Tuesday were closely watching the controversy at Google unfold, and grateful they were not the ones caught in another debate over gender and diversity. "Every large organization has a James Damore - but at tech companies, they're more liberated to share their personal views," an executive at one major Silicon Valley firm said, speaking on condition of anonymity. "Tech firms have an abundance of smart, confident people who think they have an obligation to share their wisdom with their coworkers."

Title: "Democratic Loss in North Carolina's 9th District Highlights Shift in Minority Voting Patterns"

Article:

Last week, the special election in North Carolina's 9th District was touted as the first major contest of the 2020 cycle, with Democrat Dan McCready expected to win a traditionally Republican seat. However, Republican Dan Bishop emerged victorious on Tuesday, with a "thin margin of victory." The focus has since shifted to the voting patterns that may have contributed to Bishop's win, particularly the significant decrease in Democratic votes in counties with a high minority population.

One of the most concerning examples for the Democrats is rural Robeson County, where the ethnic makeup is 38.6% Native American, 25.7% White, 24% Black, 8.52% Hispanic, 2.15% Two or More Races, 0.66% Asian, and 0.275% Other. In the 2018 election, McCready won Robeson County by 15.31 points. On Tuesday, he received a fraction of the votes, winning by only 1.11 points, a significant decrease from his 2018 performance. In 2012, President Obama carried Robeson County by 17 points.

Robeson County has a population of approximately 143,000, and 74% of these residents are not the "racist rednecks" the Democrats might suggest make up most of the Trump/GOP base. The shift away from McCready was due to disenchantment among minority voters with the Democrat.

Similar trends were observed in other ethnically diverse counties, such as Cumberland County, where nearly 60% of the approximately 333,000 residents are Black, Hispanic, or a member of some other minority group. McCready won Cumberland County in 2018, but Dan Bishop won it on Tuesday.

The only place where the Democrat improved on his 2018 performance was in the affluent white areas of Mecklenburg County. Bishop only flipped two new counties from blue to red, but he turned several from dark blue to pale blue, reducing McCready's margins in enough ethnically diverse rural counties to win.

The reasons for this shift in voting patterns are clear. Despite the Democrats' attempts to scare minorities with evidence-free claims that the economy is faltering, a majority of Blacks (53%) and Hispanics (54%) answered that the U.S. economy is "strong" in a Harvard-Harris poll released in early September. These are far higher marks than any GOP president has received, particularly from Blacks.

The unemployment rate among Black Americans hit 5.5% in August, the lowest rate on record. Breitbart points out a secondary effect of this record-low unemployment rate often overlooked by the media: the persistent gap between white and black unemployment also narrowed to its smallest on record. The unemployment ratio has averaged around 2 to 1 or so for decades, meaning the black unemployment rate is typically twice the white unemployment rate. In good times, the unemployment rate of whites and blacks falls, but the gap remains. However, in the current economic climate, the decline in employment inequality is the best on record because it comes in the context of falling unemployment.

President Trump acknowledged the positive economic impact of his policies during his North Carolina rally on Monday, explaining that he needs the help of people like Dan Bishop to keep the economy strong and create jobs for all Americans. He also criticized "the other Dan" (McCready) for supporting Nancy Pelosi on higher taxes, sanctuary cities, and radical abortion policies.

In his victory speech, Dan Bishop thanked President Trump and expressed his support for the President's values. He emphasized the need for a congressman with a backbone to represent the 9th District in Washington, D.C. The voters of North Carolina's 9th District agreed, electing Dan Bishop to the House of Representatives. However, it was not racist rednecks or people who wallow in "white privilege" who elected Bishop. The voters who elected Bishop are the people who work for a living in places like Cumberland, Richmond, and Robeson counties. They are by no means all white, and they remember all too well what it was like during the Obama years and how it felt to go hat in hand to the unemployment office. This should frighten the Democrats badly.

Title: Special Counsel Adds Charges Against Paul Manafort and Indicts Top Aide

Article:

Special Counsel Robert Mueller has added new charges against Paul Manafort, the former chairman of the Trump 2016 campaign, and indicted a top aide, Konstantin Kilimnik. Mr. Manafort is accused of conspiring with Mr. Kilimnik to obstruct justice, in addition to charges of witness tampering, money laundering, illegal foreign lobbying, and lying to federal officials. The new charges, known as a superseding indictment, allege that they sought to tamper with witnesses ahead of Mr. Manafort's trial next month.

The charges were filed in Washington DC on Friday and came days after Mr. Mueller asked a judge to revoke Mr. Manafort's $10 million bail, which has allowed him to remain under house arrest at his Virginia home, over the witness-tampering accusations. Mr. Kilimnik, a Russian citizen, was a longtime employee of Mr. Manafort's political-consulting firm and had done extensive lobbying work for him in Ukraine on behalf of the country's then pro-Russian president Viktor Yanukovych. He has denied allegations that he has ties to Russian intelligence.

The legal pressure on Paul Manafort is growing, and now one of his top deputies is joining him in the prosecutorial crosshairs. For the moment, Mr. Manafort is one of the few targets of Mueller's Russia probe to push toward a criminal trial, rather than cooperate with the investigation. The special counsel's team may be hoping the prospect of pre-trial incarceration could help change Mr. Manafort's mind.

Perhaps more important is that an alleged line from the Russian government to the Trump campaign could be getting clearer. Konstintin Kilimnik, a Soviet-born former translator from Ukraine, is reported, by the New York Times and others, to be the "Person A" described in a previous Mueller court filing as having "ties to a Russian intelligence service" up to and including in 2016, when his boss, Mr. Manafort, worked as the chair of Donald Trump's presidential campaign.

Mr. Mueller has yet to assert that Mr. Manafort's Ukraine and Russian connections resulted in any election-meddling. The skeleton for future allegations, however, can now be discerned. Mr. Kilimnik appears unlikely to face these new charges in court. His whereabouts are currently unknown, although Mr. Mueller, in a December 2017 court filing, says a Manafort "colleague" widely considered to be Kilimnik is "currently based in Russia."

Mr. Mueller is investigating whether there was any collusion between the Trump campaign and Russia during the 2016 election, and whether the president unlawfully tried to obstruct the inquiry after the election. Mr. Mueller was appointed after US President Donald Trump fired FBI director James Comey last May. On Tuesday, he asked that Mr. Manafort be detained in jail, claiming that he had been using encrypted communication to try to coach two potential witnesses' testimonies. On Friday, Mr. Trump denied that he was considering pardoning Mr. Manafort. "It's far too early to be thinking about it," Mr. Trump told reporters before traveling to the G7 summit in Canada. "They have not been convicted of anything. There's nothing to pardon."

Title: Democratic Presidential Candidates Face Opportunity to Criticize Obama Administration's Record

Article:

Democratic presidential hopefuls have been cautious about criticizing former Vice President Joe Biden's eight-year tenure with President Barack Obama, but voters in early primary states see this as an opportunity for candidates brave enough to challenge the Obama orthodoxy. While the Democratic base still holds immense goodwill towards the country's first black president, some early state voters argue that Obama failed to deliver on many of his promises, leaving the political landscape largely unchanged a decade after his historic presidency.

"We saw what happened with Obama. There's no change yet," said Democratic voter Derryl Mitchell II, 27, who owns a media marketing firm in Charleston, South Carolina. "We had a chance in 2008 and not much came from it. We're still here—same issues."

Biden, who is running on a platform of restoring Obama-era values and stability to the country, currently holds a commanding lead in the crowded primary race. He has primarily directed his political attacks at President Trump, while his nearly two dozen rivals have largely refrained from criticizing the former vice president.

This dynamic is expected to change at the first Democratic presidential primary debate next week in Miami, where Biden will be a primary target. The challenge will be to criticize the Obama administration's record without directly criticizing Obama himself.

"I actually think there is probably a good bit of room to go after Obama policies without mentioning Obama by name," said Brent Nelsen, a political science professor at Furman University in Greenville, South Carolina. "There is still an afterglow from the Obama presidency and I would say most candidates aren't going to go out and criticize Barack Obama personally or the administration directly, but you already hear them taking on things like health care."

Indeed, liberal activists have argued that Obama's signature achievement, the Affordable Care Act, didn't go far enough and that his administration's record on the deportation of immigrants was abysmal. Biden is also vulnerable to criticism for suddenly championing policies that didn't receive significant push from the Obama White House, such as a $15 minimum wage or free tuition at community colleges.

Republican strategist and pollster John Couvillon said Biden is vulnerable on the Obama front and will eventually face criticism from his competitors.

"With President Obama fading further and further into the rearview mirror, those aspects of President Obama's record could be challenged by competitors," he said.

Speaking at a fundraiser in New York on Tuesday, Biden acknowledged the target on his back. "There's a target on my back," he said.

Some White House hopefuls have been cautious about criticism of the Obama legacy. Former Rep. Beto O'Rourke told MSNBC last week that Biden represents a return to the past.

"You can not go back to the end of the Obama administration and think that that's good enough," he said. "We can not return to the past."

However, when pressed to explain his comment, Mr. O'Rourke tried to thread the needle, praising Obama as the "greatest president of my lifetime" while reiterating his argument that it is time for a new generation of leadership.

"I think some of the appeal of the vice president's candidacy is a return to an earlier era," he said. "And while we are grateful for that era, and certainly for the service of President Obama, I think we need to be focused on the future, because, even before Donald Trump, we had challenges in this country."

The Democratic hopefuls are understandably skittish about criticizing Obama. Just look at what happened to Sen. Bernie Sanders of Vermont, whose far-left campaign has made him a top 2020 Democratic contender.

Last year, on the 50th anniversary of the assassination of Martin Luther King Jr., Mr. Sanders dared to question the accomplishments of Obama.

"The business model, if you like, of the Democratic Party for the last 15 years or so has been a failure," he said at an event in Jackson, Mississippi. "People sometimes don't see that because there was a charismatic individual named Barack Obama. He was obviously an extraordinary candidate, brilliant guy. But beyond that reality, over the last 10 years, Democrats have lost about 1,000 seats in state legislatures all across this country."

The retribution by Democratic Party faithful was swift and severe. Mr. Sanders was even called "deplorable."

Steffen Schmidt, a political science professor at Iowa State University, said going after the Obama years was too risky. He suggested Biden's rivals focus on what they consider blemishes from the three-plus decades Biden spent representing Delaware in the Senate.

"Obama went out of two terms with high approval especially among Democrats, so the candidates will need to stick with age, support for tough police action against gangs, his original position on abortion, and other issues Democrats hold against him," he said.

On the campaign trail, Biden gets lots of mileage out of his Obama ties. During a campaign swing through Iowa last week, Biden said he was proud to have served as Obama's right-hand man. He touted the role the administration played in passing the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act in response to the 2008 recession, which he credited with stopping the country from slipping into an economic depression.

"As a point of personal privilege, I want to say something we don't say often enough to our party and to our nation: Barack Obama was a president of extraordinary character and decency," he said in Davenport, eliciting his biggest applause of the evening.

Title: Obama Administration Signals Iran Nuclear Deal Nears Completion, Midterm Elections Could Influence Outcome

Article:

The Obama administration has signaled that a nuclear deal with Iran is close, with negotiations ongoing between the Islamic Republic and the Permanent members of the United Nations Security Council, as well as Germany. The negotiations have reportedly been met with apprehension from the U.S. political team regarding the potential reception of the deal in the U.S. Congress and the American public.

The Obama administration is reportedly working to avoid scrutiny from the Senate, with one senior White House official telling the New York Times that they would not seek congressional legislation in any comprehensive agreement for years. The Democrats controlling the Senate are said to be content to follow the president's lead, with members of the president's own political party reportedly silent and ineffective in challenging the administration's policies on Syria, Russian aggression in Eastern Europe, and responses to ISIS and other terrorist acts.

The foreign policy and political team is working to finalize the Iran deal in secret, with career State Department foreign service officials reportedly excluded from the real negotiation process. The political appointees working with former Democratic presidential nominee and current Secretary of State John Kerry have allegedly outmaneuvered any dissenting expert voices critical of the deal.

Undersecretary of State for Political Affairs Wendy Sherman, who was appointed by Hillary Clinton and previously served as the Executive Director of the pro-choice political group Emily's List, has reportedly ignored signs that the Iranians are not serious about making concessions. Sherman, who led unsuccessful negotiations to end North Korea's nuclear weapons and ballistic missile programs in the Clinton administration, has been criticized for being duped by North Korean officials throughout the process.

The proposed deal from the Obama administration is reportedly weaker than the UN's previous five resolutions demanding Iran stop enriching all uranium. The only chance of stopping the deal, according to the article, is to elect a Republican-controlled Senate willing to fight the president on the issue. Pro-Israel voters, including evangelical Christians and Jewish voters in several states, are urged to vote in the midterm elections to flip the Senate to the Republicans and potentially prevent a disastrous Iran deal. Eastern European Americans concerned about the rise of Russia and the weak American response in Ukraine are also encouraged to vote for the president's opposition in the Senate.

If Iran obtains the pending Obama deal, the article suggests, a nuclear weapon for the Islamic Republic will likely follow. The midterm elections are presented as the last chance to stop this calamitous outcome. Richard Grenell, a former spokesman for four United States Ambassadors to the United Nations, including Ambassador Zal Khalilzad, is the author of the article.

Title: Republicans Unveil Final Tax Bill, Aim for Vote Next Week

Article:

Republicans have unveiled their final tax bill on Friday, moving closer to a vote in the following week and potentially signing it into law by the end of the year. The bill, which has been a campaign promise, is expected to lower the corporate tax rate from 35% to 21%, repeal the corporate alternative minimum tax, nearly double the standard deduction for individuals, and restructure the way pass-through businesses are taxed.

The bill keeps seven personal income tax brackets and lowers the tax rates for most brackets, including dropping the top rate to 37% from 39.6%. The child tax credit under the bill will be $2,000, and the credit is refundable up to $1,400.

The conference report allows individuals to deduct up to $10,000 in state and local taxes. Individuals can either elect to deduct up to $10,000 in state and local income and property taxes or state and local property and sales taxes. The student loan interest deduction remains untouched, and the mortgage interest deduction cap has been lowered.

Unlike previous versions of the bill, the conference committee version leaves the estate tax untouched, doubling the estate tax exemption instead. The bill also repeals the corporate alternative minimum tax and makes changes to the individual alternative minimum tax.

Republican leaders are confident they have enough support to pass their legislation next week. The bill appears to be gathering momentum, as key holdouts in the Senate, where Republicans have a slim two-vote majority, have signaled their support for the bill.

One of the key items Republicans have had to keep a close eye on is how much their bill costs. Under the Senate rules, the bill can not cost more than $1.5 trillion over 10 years and it can not add to the deficit after that. The bill sunsets the individual tax breaks at the end of 2025 and repeals the individual mandate to help finance the bill.

This story will continue to update with additional developments.

Title: Key Tax Reform Issues Remain Unresolved as Republicans Strive for Permanent, Revenue-Neutral Legislation

Article:

The Trump administration and congressional Republicans are working towards unifying around a single tax-reform bill, aiming to pass the legislation this year. However, there are still key differences between the priorities of the White House, the House, and the Senate that need to be resolved.

Five tax reform issues that Republicans need to address include the permanence of the changes, the budget window, tax rates for individuals and businesses, the border-adjustment tax (BAT), and business investment language.

House GOP leaders are pushing for the changes to be permanent, but some senators and administration officials have expressed openness to temporary tax changes. If Republicans want to pass a tax-reform bill under "reconciliation" to bypass a Democratic filibuster in the Senate, the legislation must be revenue-neutral or make the tax cuts temporary.

Republicans agree on lowering tax rates, but there is a disagreement on how low to set tax rates for both individuals and businesses. The Trump administration's tax plan proposes individual tax brackets of 35 percent, 25 percent, and 10 percent, as well as a 15 percent rate for corporations and small businesses. Meanwhile, the House Republicans' blueprint would establish individual tax rates of 33 percent, 25 percent, and 12 percent, with a corporate tax rate of 20 percent and a maximum rate of 25 percent for pass-through businesses.

The biggest fight over tax reform so far this year has centered on the House GOP's BAT proposal. Under the proposal, imports would be subject to a 20 percent tax that wouldn't apply to exports. However, the proposal's fate doesn't look promising, as GOP senators, administration officials, and even some House Republicans have expressed concerns about its impact on consumers.

Without the BAT, lawmakers will have to find other ways to raise revenue and prevent corporations from shifting profits overseas. The GOP tax plan's language about business investment may be its next most hotly debated provision. The plan would eliminate the deduction for businesses' net interest expenses, instead allowing companies to immediately write off the full costs of their investments.

House GOP leaders believe that "full expensing" is a policy that would provide more of an incentive for businesses to invest. However, the interest deduction has its defenders, who say that debt financing is important to industries such as real estate, private equity, telecommunications, and agriculture.

The tax plans from House Republicans and the White House do not include infrastructure. However, linking taxes and transportation may not be off the table, as Trump and some lawmakers have floated the idea. After the BAT, the GOP tax plan's language about business investment may be its next most hotly debated provision.

Title: Presidential Candidate Bernie Sanders Sues Democratic National Committee Over Voter File Access Suspension

Article:

Presidential candidate Bernie Sanders filed a lawsuit against the Democratic National Committee (DNC) on Friday, seeking access to the party's voter files following the suspension of his campaign's access due to alleged unauthorized access to Hillary Clinton's campaign files. The incident has become a source of controversy for both Sanders and the DNC.

The DNC accused Sanders' campaign of playing dirty, while Sanders claimed the DNC is attempting to undermine his campaign to benefit Clinton. Clinton, in turn, has remained silent on the matter, with her campaign manager, Robby Mook, stating that Sanders' staff "stole data from our campaign."

The DNC's voter data file, which contains detailed demographic, voting history, and personal information of tens of millions of Americans, was suspended from Sanders' access after the DNC detected over two dozen breaches where Sanders employees accessed Clinton data and attempted to download it.

Sanders' campaign manager, Jeff Weaver, stated that one staffer has been terminated, and others are being questioned for acting "irresponsibly." However, the campaign also argues that the DNC had no legal right to suspend their access, and claims Democratic Party leaders are trying to aid Clinton's campaign.

DNC Chairwoman Debbie Wasserman Schultz, speaking on CNN, defended the decision to suspend Sanders' access, stating it was a fair move because he broke the terms of the access agreement. The third Democratic presidential debate is scheduled for the following day, with Sanders, Clinton, and former Maryland Governor Martin O'Malley participating.

Clinton currently maintains a wide lead in national polls and is ahead in Iowa, but Sanders leads in New Hampshire. Mook, Clinton's campaign manager, expressed surprise that Sanders was fundraising off the incident, stating, "Their staff stole data from our campaign, and they are now fundraising off of it. I'll leave it to voters what that says or doesn't say."

Mook called for an independent monitor to ensure the data has been expunged by the Sanders campaign. The incident marks the latest in a series of computer-related problems that have plagued the Democrats this year. In a separate incident, Clinton's use of a private email server during her tenure as Secretary of State has been a point of controversy.

Clinton's spokesman, Brian Fallon, stated that the Sanders breach of voter files was not an accident, and Sanders staffers not only looked at the data but at one point tried—apparently unsuccessfully—to download data into a spreadsheet for storage and use later. Sanders is paying $10,000 a month for access to the files, but in his court documents, he stated that losing access to the files and his campaign's work on them is costing his operation over $600,000 a day in value because he cannot access mailing lists he has used to raise money.

Title: White House Signs Bipartisan TRACED Act to Combat Unwanted Robocalls

Article:

The White House announced on Monday that President Trump had signed the Pallone-Thune TRACED Act, a bipartisan legislation aimed at preventing criminal robocalls. The new law will provide American consumers with increased protection against unwanted robocalls.

The TRACED Act updates existing laws and regulations to strengthen penalties, increase transparency, and enhance government collaboration to stop unwanted solicitation. President Donald J. Trump expressed pride in working with Congress to get this legislation to his desk and signing it into law.

According to the Federal Trade Commission, a robocall attempting to sell a product or service is illegal unless a company has the consumer's written permission. The TRACED Act takes several significant steps in the fight against illegal robocalls, including requiring phone carriers to authenticate the legitimacy of calls and blocking unverified robocalls at no cost to consumers.

The bill is a bipartisan effort, with near-unanimous support in Congress. It is a significant win for consumers across the country, officially putting illegal robocallers on notice. While no process is perfect, the TRACED Act represents an important legislative compromise that will begin to address the issue of illegal robocalls.

Senator Thune, who partnered with the President on this consumer protection issue, expressed gratitude for the Senate's action. He hopes the President will quickly sign the bill into law, allowing families to enjoy a new year of family calls instead of robocalls.

Title: Biden, Buttigieg Warn of Difficulties in Winning Elections with Democratic Socialist Nominee

Article:

Former Vice President Joe Biden and Presidential contender Pete Buttigieg have expressed concerns about the potential impact of a Democratic socialist nominee on the party and the country.

In an interview on ABC News' "This Week," Biden stated that nominating a progressive candidate, such as Sen. Bernie Sanders (Vt.), for president would make it harder for Democrats to win elections across the board. Biden suggested that voters in Mid-Western and Southern states would not be as willing to vote for Democratic candidates if the presidential nominee supports democratic socialistic policies.

However, Biden vowed to "work like hell" to help Sanders win the election if he won the nomination. He also warned that President Donald Trump is desperate to pin the democratic socialist label on all Democratic candidates to use as a foil, and nominating Sanders would help him do that.

Similarly, Buttigieg expressed concern about the potential impact of a democratic socialist nominee, not just on the Democratic Party, but on the country as a whole. He stated that a democratic socialist label could further divide the country and that most people do not see themselves fitting into the "revolution or status quo" picture presented by some campaigns.

The concerns expressed by Biden and Buttigieg come after a disappointing fourth-place finish by Sanders in the Iowa Caucus last week. Sanders has consistently identified as a democratic socialist and has been a leading voice in the progressive wing of the Democratic Party.

Title: Dan Coats Steps Down as US Director of National Intelligence, John Ratcliffe Nominated as Successor

Article:

The United States Director of National Intelligence, Dan Coats, has announced his resignation, making him the latest high-profile figure to leave the Trump administration. President Donald Trump tweeted that Coats would step down in mid-August, with Texas Congressman John Ratcliffe set to replace him.

Coats and Trump have often been at odds, particularly on issues related to Russia, North Korea, and the Iran nuclear deal. As Director of National Intelligence, Coats oversaw all 17 US intelligence agencies, including the CIA and NSA. However, throughout his tenure, Coats' assessments were frequently contradicted by the president, who has been critical of intelligence agencies.

In January, the president called his intelligence chiefs "passive and naive" in their assessment of the threat posed by Iran. Coats is the latest in a string of Trump administration officials to leave the White House, including former Defense Secretary James Mattis and Secretary of State Rex Tillerson.

In his resignation letter to the president, Coats said America's intelligence community had become "stronger than ever" during his two-and-a-half-year tenure. "As a result, I now believe it is time for me to move on to the next chapter of my life," he wrote.

Coats and Trump's differences on foreign policy appeared irreconcilable at times, particularly on Russian interference in US elections, the Iran nuclear deal, and Trump's attempts at rapprochement with North Korea. Citing a former senior intelligence official, the Washington Post reported that Coats came to see his departure as inevitable given his troubled relationship with Trump.

Last year, the intelligence chief admitted that Trump did not brief him about his behind-closed-doors meeting with Russian President Vladimir Putin in Helsinki. "If he had asked me how that ought to be conducted, I would have suggested a different way," Coats said of their summit.

Coats' views also diverged from the president's on North Korea. In January, Coats told Congress North Korea was unlikely to give up its nuclear weapons, contradicting a statement by Trump that Pyongyang no longer posed a threat.

Dan Coats has served as Director of National Intelligence since March 2017, succeeding James Clapper. Born in Jackson, Michigan, Coats graduated from two universities with degrees in political science and law in the 1960s. He served two terms as a Republican senator for Indiana, from 1989 to 1999 and again from 2011 to 2017. Coats also served as the US ambassador to Germany from 2001 to 2005 in between his terms in the Senate.

A prominent supporter of the president and his policies, John Ratcliffe has served as the congressman for Texas' 4th District since 2015. Providing his nomination is approved, Ratcliffe's views are expected to chime with Trump's more often in his new role. Last Wednesday, Ratcliffe defended the president during the testimony of former special counsel Robert Mueller, who led a two-year investigation into Russian meddling in the 2016 election.

Senate Democratic leader Chuck Schumer criticized Ratcliffe's appointment, stating, "it's clear that Rep Ratcliffe was selected because he exhibited blind loyalty to President Trump with his demagogic questioning of... Mueller."

Title: Indictment of Former Trump Campaign Officials: A Look at the Current Case and Historical Precedents

Article:

The recent guilty plea by former Trump campaign officials, specifically Paul Manafort and Rick Gates, has raised questions about their involvement in the 2016 presidential campaign and potential ties to Russia. The fact that Gates pleaded guilty to only two relatively lower-level charges suggests that he may have valuable information for Special Counsel Robert Mueller, according to legal experts.

Manafort's participation in a June 2016 meeting with Donald Trump Jr., the candidate's son, and Jared Kushner, his son-in-law, with a Russian lawyer under the promise of receiving incriminating information about Hillary Clinton on behalf of Russia's government, has been a point of interest. Additionally, Manafort reportedly offered to give "private briefings" to Oleg V. Deripaska, a Russian oligarch allied with President Vladimir V. Putin, whom Manafort allegedly owed $19 million. Prosecutors are interested in learning about the watering down of a Republican convention platform plank on Russia's intervention in Ukraine.

Gates' credibility as a witness may be questioned due to his guilty plea to lying to the FBI during his plea negotiations. However, Ty Cobb, the White House special counsel, has stated that Manafort has no damaging information against President Trump. Manafort reiterated his innocence and his intention to fight the "untrue piled up charges" on Friday.

President Trump's argument that the ongoing investigations have no connection to him resonates with many of his supporters. However, historical precedents suggest that being surrounded by prosecuted individuals can cause political damage, even if the president is not directly implicated. For instance, President Jimmy Carter faced significant political damage when his confidant and budget director, Bert Lance, was accused of banking irregularities. Presidents Ronald Reagan and Bill Clinton also faced investigations of their aides unrelated to them.

In the current case, the targets include not just a "coffee boy," as Manafort's former campaign adviser described George Papadopoulos, but the president's top two campaign officials and national security adviser. While Trump has dismissed the relevance of allegations against Manafort due to their involvement in business dealings before the campaign, the latest indictment claims that Manafort was scheming to defraud banks while serving as Trump's campaign chairman.

Title: Questions Remain Over British Ex-Spy's Unverified Anti-Trump Dossier and FBI's Handling of It

Article:

Thursday's testimony by James Comey focused on his discussions with President Trump, but the former FBI director still faces questions regarding the links between the bureau and a British ex-spy's mysterious and unverified anti-Trump dossier. Sen. Richard Burr, R-N.C., asked Comey about the dossier, prepared by former British spy Christopher Steele, during Thursday's morning testimony. However, Comey declined to discuss the issue in open session, citing the sensitivity of the material in the report.

Sen. Charles Grassley, R-Iowa, has yet to receive a response from Comey in the matter of Steele and his London-based company, Orbis Business Intelligence Ltd. Steele's firm was hired by Fusion GPS, a Washington, D.C. firm, to collect opposition research on then-candidate Donald Trump during the 2016 campaign.

For months, Grassley has criticized Comey for the bureau's failure to provide documents requested and answer questions about Steele. Grassley also called out Fusion GPS this week for allegedly not cooperating with his committee, sending a June 7 letter seeking "all responsive documents and information" by June 14 and warning that he could consider a "compulsory process" if necessary.

Comey considered the unverified dossier prepared by Steele to be so important that he insisted it be included in January's final intelligence community report on Russian meddling in the election. The FBI offered Steele $50,000 to corroborate the dossier, according to published reports, though the bureau has denied making any payments.

The Steele dossier was part of the evidence the FBI used to obtain a FISA warrant for Carter Page, a peripheral adviser in the Trump campaign the dossier named as a figure in Trump campaign dealings with Russia. In interviews with Fox News, Page repeatedly denied he was the Trump campaign's point person for Moscow, and said he believes he was a target of unmasking efforts by the Obama administration.

Questions remain over how the unverified dossier was passed around on both sides of the Atlantic, particularly between June and December 2016, as it was shown in parts to a variety of politicians, journalists, and intelligence agencies before being brought officially to the FBI by Sen. John McCain on Dec. 9.

The person who brought the dossier to the attention of McCain last fall, former British Ambassador Sir Andrew Wood, now emphasizes to Fox News that "Intelligence always needs evaluating of course...It is always foolish to put yourself in a position to pretend to knowledge that you do not have."

In an email exchange, Wood said while he told McCain about the material, he "had not read and could not vouch for" it. Still, he said, the material was "produced by responsible persons."

"I understood that its general contents were known to others in the United States. The Senator then arranged for the papers to be brought to him," he wrote, adding: "It was up to the Senator to decide what action if any he took throughout the whole process. He is known to me as to many others as a courageous patriot. I have no doubt that he acted as he thought fit in that capacity."

Serving as Britain's ambassador to Moscow from 1995-2000, Wood's name and his relationship with Steele emerged in British Court documents obtained and reviewed by Fox News as part of Steele's defense in a lawsuit brought against him by Russian technology guru Aleksej Gubarev. Gubarev—whose companies are mentioned in the dossier—has also filed a lawsuit in Fort Lauderdale, Florida against Buzzfeed for publishing the unverified 35-page dossier in full.

The April 2017 documents identify Wood as "an Associate of Orbis" and say he was "aware of the Second Defendant's" [Steele's] intelligence gathering for the pre-election memoranda. However, in email exchanges with Fox News on June 6, Wood told a different story.

"I have had no professional relationship with Orbis," he wrote. "You refer to me as an ‘Associate’ (capital A) and draw some conclusions as to my role, which go beyond what it has been, that of a friend to Christopher Steele and a person among others with whom I have from time to time discussed Russian affairs."

When asked about the role of Fusion GPS in Washington D.C., Wood wrote that "I do not know Fusion apart from the fact that it exists."

McCain's office has not responded to Fox News' latest request for comment on the dossier. In a Jan. 11 press release, McCain stated, "Late last year, I received sensitive information that has since been made public. Upon examination of the contents, and unable to make a judgment about their accuracy, I delivered the information to the Director of the FBI."

Title: Clinton Faces Tight Race Despite Advantages in White House Bid

Article:

Hillary Clinton, the Democratic presidential nominee, is facing a tight race against Republican opponent Donald Trump, despite several advantages in the race for the White House. Clinton has a larger staff, a favorable Electoral College map, and demographic trends moving in her favor. She is running to succeed a popular president and the economy is strengthening. However, Trump has divided the Republican Party and alienated large groups of Americans.

As of August 27, Clinton had a more than 6-point lead over Trump in the RealClearPolitics national average of polls. However, by Tuesday, her lead had narrowed to 2.4 percentage points. Polls have shown Trump ahead in the swing states of Florida and Ohio, and he has a fighting chance in all other battleground states, including purple states such as Nevada and Virginia, as well as Pennsylvania and Wisconsin, states a Republican hasn't won in decades.

Clinton's team believes her strong performance in Monday's debate will translate into a wider lead going into the second and third contests next month. "The debate buoys her to the next big thing and the next debate," said one Clinton surrogate. They also argue that it is Trump who faces some pressure, with the next presidential debate on Oct. 9 in St. Louis potentially being a must-win situation for the Republican.

However, Clinton and her supporters acknowledge they are in a close race that could still go either way. "I'm afraid that since Trump is backed into a corner, he'll come out swinging for the gutter," said Democratic strategist and Clinton surrogate Jim Manley. "There's still a long way to go between now and the election in November. There's still lots of ups and downs and many twists to go."

If Clinton loses, the gains her party made in the Obama years could be turned back, from the Affordable Care Act and Wall Street reform to regulatory actions on climate change and immigration. Clinton would also go down as the Democrat who lost to Trump, a status she clearly does not want.

Clinton's campaign has been sidelined at times by storylines like the controversy over her use of a private email server at the State Department, which overshadowed her campaign and fed into the narrative that Clinton is dishonest and secretive. "I think a lot of people have wondered why we don't have a commanding lead in the final stretch, and I think she's going to have to spend some time sealing the deal for a lot of folks," said a surrogate.

If Clinton is feeling the pressure, it is not evident. On Tuesday, she said she was up for the challenge. "You should know by now, when I set my mind on something, I keep going," she told reporters on her plane just weeks after a bout of pneumonia forced her off the campaign trail briefly. "I don't quit, whatever the static, whatever the incoming is, and that's what I'll do for the American people."

However, Clinton has wondered why she doesn't have a bigger lead against Trump with less than 40 days to go until Election Day. Last week, during a videoconference with the Laborers International Union of North America, she vocalized it: "Why aren't I 50 points ahead, you might ask?" The comment was an acknowledgement of a question her supporters ask—and of their frustration. Earlier this week, the Trump campaign put out an ad criticizing Clinton for the remark and accusing her of becoming "more and more frustrated with how out of touch she is" with voters.

Clinton allies say they hoped their candidate's performance on Monday night stopped Trump's momentum so they can begin building a lead again. "I think her base may be stronger than ever, and motivated," one longtime Clinton adviser said. But, at the same time, the adviser cautioned that "there should be no resting on laurels."

Title: Facebook's Claimed Competition: A Closer Look at the Top Social Apps

Article:

In a recent testimony before Congress, Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg stated that the company faces competition from at least eight major apps. However, it is worth noting that Facebook owns or has a version of each of these apps that supposedly threaten them.

According to TechCrunch, Zuckerberg's defense against accusations of Facebook having a monopoly has been to claim that the average American internet user regularly uses eight other social apps, not just Facebook's platform. However, data from mobile app insight service App Annie suggests a different picture.

In the United States, Zuckerberg's company owns three of the top 10 apps. Instagram, which is owned by Facebook, is number four, Facebook Messenger is number 6, and the Facebook app itself is number 8. The top three apps are games, but for all other apps, Facebook has or is working on a cloned version or features of those apps.

For instance, the YouTube app sits at number 5, and Facebook is currently attempting to build its "Watch Video" section to take on YouTube. The Silicon Valley giant has already adopted the "Stories" idea from the seventh most popular app, Snapchat. Facebook also owns the 19th most popular app, WhatsApp.

If one selects the "Social Media" category on App Annie and sorts by the "most popular" apps, Facebook owns the top three apps listed. This contradicts Zuckerberg's statement that users have a variety of choices when it comes to social media networks outside of Facebook.

In summary, while Zuckerberg claims that users regularly use eight different communication and social apps, Facebook's ownership or cloning of several top apps in the United States suggests a different reality. This raises questions about the level of competition in the social media market and the extent to which Facebook dominates this space.

Title: Trump Faces Calls for Staff Changes Amidst Ongoing White House Turmoil

Article:

The White House is facing calls for staff changes following the controversial firing of FBI Director James Comey. Former aides, GOP strategists, and sources close to the White House have expressed concern over President Trump's handling of the situation, which they believe has undermined his staff.

Changes seemed imminent late last week, as the president expressed anger over the rollout of Comey's firing. However, with Trump set to begin his first foreign trip as president on Friday, many think the threat of staff changes has temporarily subsided.

The repeated rumors of a shakeup have damaged morale, with aides acknowledging that the turmoil surrounding Comey's firing is the worst to hit the White House yet. Allies close to the administration want to see Trump act decisively or move on, rather than keep his staff in limbo under threat of change.

The rumors have touched nearly every corner of the West Wing, including senior advisers such as Chief of Staff Reince Priebus and strategist Stephen Bannon. The most intense speculation in recent days has centered on the press operation and embattled press secretary Sean Spicer.

Trump's communications team was kept in the dark ahead of firing Comey, leading to a chaotic rollout that produced conflicting stories about the reasoning behind the decision. The turmoil led Trump to publicly question the performance of his media relations staff.

While Trump praised Spicer as a "nice man," he declined to definitively say if he would keep his current post. "He's doing a good job, but he gets beat up," Trump said. Pressed on whether he'd keep Spicer at the lectern, Trump said, "He's been there at the beginning."

A subdued Spicer returned to the James S. Brady Press Briefing Room on Monday, where he faced another barrage of questions over Trump's decision to fire Comey. White House spokespeople did not respond to requests for comment for this story.

Those who have worked for Trump say it is common knowledge that, with the exception of family, staff members live on thin ice. Confusion over the division of responsibilities on the team of rivals Trump has assembled has created a White House where leaks have become the norm.

Trump's allies say he is frustrated by the leaks, which they say are coming from advisers who either don't believe in Trump's message, refuse to buy into the way he does business, or are so obsessed by the Washington power game that they'd risk harming the administration to boost their own image.

A sweeping reshuffle would bring its own set of difficulties. Trump's thirst for personal loyalty could narrow the universe of Republicans he might consider hiring, given that many top GOP aides were deeply critical of him during the 2016 campaign. It's a problem the White House has encountered as it struggles to fill posts across the federal government.
