At the same time, the ally stressed that whoever is brought in would have to have enough gravitas to carry out major changes, saying, "He's going to have to bring in a real, real political pro to fix this thing."

Others say Trump has brought these problems upon himself by shutting out many of his top aides and advisers or contradicting them in public. "The problem is not Spicer or [White House communications director Michael] Dubke if you tell them 45 minutes in advance that you're firing Jim Comey," said one former adviser. "If you lack confidence in your communications team, go find people you have confidence in."

Republican strategist John Feehery, who is also a columnist for ███, made a similar point. "The White House is actually doing pretty well when the president doesn't screw up," he said. "They needed to have a better system of controlling his anger."

In past administrations, the chief of staff has taken on the role of gatekeeper to the president, controlling who meets with him and what information he receives. In Trump's White House, rival factions exist in competition for Trump's ear.

Former Trump aides and GOP operatives with close ties to the White House say Trump has not given Priebus enough responsibility. "The leaks shows a total lack of discipline, and that starts with the chief of staff," said a former Trump adviser. "The only way to be effective here is for the chief of staff to grab the loudest, most inveterate opponents inside the White House and to fire them. If the president hasn't empowered him to do that, then he needs to walk."

Insiders who spoke to ███ believe that, despite recent reports, Bannon is probably safe. He represents Trump's core economic nationalist vision, and it is believed that Trump's base would flee if the president narrowed his inner circle to Trump's son-in-law, Jared Kushner, and economic adviser Gary Cohn, who are viewed as liberals by many grassroots conservatives.

"There would be tremendous base flight if Bannon were gone," said one former adviser. Bannon's allies believe Kushner is pushing his father-in-law to clean house.

Political watchers say the appearance of chaos and the backdrop of uncertainty has undercut Trump's credibility on the global stage as he prepares to make his first overseas trip, which includes stops in Saudi Arabia and Israel as well as summit meetings with major U.S. allies.

"Trump's credibility abroad is taking severe hits," said Ian Bremmer, the president of the Eurasia Group, in a dispatch to clients. "On the back of Emmanuel Macron's win in France, continental European leaders together view Trump as a dangerous buffoon, one to be increasingly strategized against, rather than with."

Title: The Legitimacy of Not Voting: Debunking Common Myths Surrounding Abstention

Article:

The act of not voting has long been a contentious topic, often met with disapproval and a sense of civic duty. However, it is essential to examine the underlying assumptions and myths that surround this choice. Here are four common myths about not voting, debunked.

1. A single vote can significantly impact election outcomes:
A comprehensive review by economists Casey Mulligan and Charles Hunter found that only one federal election in more than a century has been decided by a single vote. In reality, a voter's individual impact on an election is minimal.

2. Not voting disenfranchises underrepresented groups:
While it is true that only about half of the voting-age population participates in elections, the act of voting does not equate to being a good citizen. Social and cultural change often occur outside the political sphere, and individuals can contribute to the American experiment in various ways, such as tweeting, blogging, donating, or activating.

3. Not voting is unpatriotic:
The right to vote, as well as the right to abstain, has been fought for by generations of brave Americans. In fact, choosing not to vote can be an expression of love for one's country, as it allows individuals to focus their time and resources on more impactful activities.

4. Lack of knowledge disqualifies one from not voting:
Even well-informed voters cannot predict a candidate's actions in office, and the two-party system may not represent the interests of some individuals. In such cases, abstaining from voting can be a principled choice.

Ultimately, the decision to vote or not to vote is a personal one, and individuals should feel empowered to make choices that align with their values and beliefs. Whether one chooses to vote or not, it is crucial to engage in informed, thoughtful discourse and to recognize the legitimacy of all perspectives.

Title: President Obama Apologizes for Health Insurance Plan Losses, Senate Introduces Bill to Delay Individual Mandate of Obamacare

Article:

President Barack Obama expressed his apologies on Thursday for Americans losing health insurance plans they were assured they could keep, as a bipartisan bill was introduced in the Senate to delay the individual mandate of Obamacare by one year. The proposed legislation aims to avoid a $95 penalty for not having health insurance, which is set to take effect next year.

In an interview with NBC News, Obama stated, "I am sorry that they are finding themselves in this situation based on assurances they got from me. We've got to work hard to make sure that they know we hear them and we are going to do everything we can to deal with folks who find themselves in a tough position as a consequence of this."

The White House, while defending the health care law and vowing to address the website issues, has not explicitly ruled out the possibility of delaying the individual mandate. House Speaker John Boehner responded to Obama's apology, stating, "An apology is certainly in order, but what Americans want to hear is that the president is going to keep his promise."

The bill, introduced by Senators Joe Manchin (D-W.Va.) and Mark Kirk (R-Ill.), aims to delay the individual mandate to provide Americans more time to explore their health insurance options. The legislation also acknowledges the positive components of the Affordable Care Act but recognizes the need for "commonsense reforms" to address the issues with the federal healthcare exchanges.

Senator Manchin stated, "We need to start working together to fix this law and make it work so that all Americans have access to affordable and reliable health care coverage." The bill suggests a one-year delay of the individual mandate to eliminate penalty fees if individuals choose not to enroll for a health care plan in 2014.

The bill also notes that delaying the entire implementation of Obamacare would not be "responsible," but Congress should take action to make "commonsense reforms" to the law. Senator Kirk added, "Healthcare should not be a burden on consumers, which is why we must delay the penalty for individuals."

The legislation emphasizes the need to maintain the positive aspects of the Affordable Care Act while addressing the issues with the federal healthcare exchanges. The bill concludes by stating, "Healthcare should not be a burden on consumers, which is why we must delay the penalty for individuals."

Title: India Implements World's Largest Lockdown to Combat COVID-19 Outbreak

Article:

India will institute the world's largest lockdown starting Wednesday, as announced by Prime Minister Narendra Modi in a televised address. The 21-day lockdown aims to contain the spread of the novel coronavirus, with Modi warning citizens to stay indoors or risk inviting the pandemic into their homes. The move affects nearly one-fifth of the world's population.

As of Tuesday, Indian health officials have reported 469 active cases of COVID-19, the disease caused by the virus, and 10 deaths. The government has invoked a British Raj-era epidemic act, granting it sweeping powers to manage the disease. The cases have been growing rapidly, with Modi stating they have the potential to "spread like wildfire."

In recent days, India has been gradually implementing stay-at-home orders and has banned international and domestic flights, as well as passenger service on its extensive rail system. Essential service providers, including hospitals, police, and media, had been exempted from the stay-in-place orders, with many grocery stores and pharmacies remaining open.

Modi referred to the lockdown as a "total lockdown" but did not specify whether any service providers would be exempt. He stated that "all steps have been taken by central and state government to ensure supply of essential items." However, it remains unclear how this will affect the approximately 300 million Indians who, according to official data, live below the poverty line.

Indian Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman announced that a comprehensive relief package would be unveiled soon. Indian virologist Dr. T. Jacob John stated before the lockdown was announced that India was being forced to take extreme containment measures after failing to mitigate the problem earlier, when the caseload was light.

"There would have been time because the wolf was not yet at the door. Now today the wolf's inside the door and India's supposed to calmly respond with a wolf in the corner," he said.

Title: Pompeo's Secret Meeting with Kim Jong Un Highlights Administration's Foreign Policy Fractures

Article:

In the heart of Washington D.C., the revelation of a clandestine meeting between Mike Pompeo, the outgoing Central Intelligence Agency (C.I.A.) director, and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un at the end of last month has stirred discussions about the Trump administration's foreign policy strategies. The unusual choice of a C.I.A. director, with little diplomatic experience, to lead the U.S. delegation for such a high-stakes meeting has exposed critical fractures within an administration that has reportedly sidelined the State Department's diplomatic corps.

The meeting, which took place under unusual circumstances, has boosted Pompeo, who is currently awaiting Senate confirmation to take over the State Department from the unceremoniously dismissed Rex Tillerson. However, among veteran foreign-policy hands, the C.I.A. director's advance-man trip has highlighted the administration's reliance on non-traditional channels for diplomacy.

According to a senior administration official, Tillerson was dismissed just days after President Donald Trump agreed to meet with Kim, leaving Pompeo, nominated by Trump to be Tillerson's successor, to take the lead on the administration's negotiations with Pyongyang. The meeting was facilitated through a back channel between the C.I.A. and its North Korean intelligence counterpart, the Reconnaissance General Bureau.

During his visit to North Korea over Easter, Pompeo was reportedly accompanied by a small group of C.I.A. officials, but no one from the White House or the State Department. The decision to send Pompeo to meet with Kim was less about his role as spy chief than his close personal relationship with the former Tea Party lawmaker, according to an administration official.

The larger question hanging over the upcoming North Korea summit, tentatively planned for late May or early June, is whether Pompeo continues to take point as he navigates the administration's foreign policy decisions alongside Trump's equally ambitious national security adviser, John Bolton, a notorious war hawk who has advocated for a pre-emptive military strike.

Suzanne DiMaggio, a senior fellow at the New America Foundation who has engaged North Korean officials in unofficial discussions, expressed concerns about Bolton's outlook on North Korea and his potential impact on the diplomatic process. "I think [given] Bolton's outlook on North Korea, which is well-known because he has written about it extensively, it wouldn't be surprising if his lack of enthusiasm about a diplomatic solution to the North Korea problem doesn't get in the way of this process going forward," DiMaggio said. "It does beg to question whether he's the right person to be the president's national security adviser at this time."

The circumstances of the Pompeo-Kim meeting were primarily a function of timing. The lack of a permanent secretary of state and the administration's reliance on non-traditional channels for diplomacy have raised questions about the Trump administration's foreign policy strategies. The larger question, however, remains whether these strategies will lead to a successful resolution of the North Korea issue.

Title: Twitter Censors President Trump's Tweet Regarding Minneapolis Riots, Citing Violence Glorification

Article:

Twitter has censored a tweet from President Donald Trump on Thursday night, in which the president expressed anger at rioters in Minneapolis who were "dishonoring the memory of George Floyd" and warned that "when the looting starts, the shooting starts." Twitter stated that the president's remarks were "glorifying violence" based on the historical context of the last line, its connection to violence, and the risk it could inspire similar actions today.

In the tweet, Trump wrote, "I can’t stand back & watch this happen to a great American City, Minneapolis. A total lack of leadership. Either the very weak Radical Left Mayor, Jacob Frey, get his act together and bring the City under control, or I will send in the National Guard & get the job done right." He continued, "These THUGS are dishonoring the memory of George Floyd, and I won’t let that happen. Just spoke to Governor Tim Walz and told him that the Military is with him all the way. Any difficulty and we will assume control but, when the looting starts, the shooting starts. Thank you!"

When the tweet is embedded in a post, it does not show the censorship label that Twitter applied. However, a screenshot of the tweet on Twitter's platform shows the censorship label that Twitter applied.

In a statement, Twitter Comms said, "This Tweet violates our policies regarding the glorification of violence based on the historical context of the last line, its connection to violence, and the risk it could inspire similar actions today." Twitter added, "We’ve taken action in the interest of preventing others from being inspired to commit violent acts, but have kept the Tweet on Twitter because it is important that the public still be able to see the Tweet given its relevance to ongoing matters of public importance." Twitter noted that engagements with the Tweet will be limited, and people will be able to Retweet with Comment but will not be able to Like, Reply, or Retweet it.

Twitter's actions against the president come after Trump signed an executive order on Thursday that took action against social media companies for repeatedly discriminating against and censoring conservatives. The executive order was issued after Twitter started applying controversial labels to Trump's tweets while largely ignoring false statements from Democrats and the Chinese Communist Party (CCP).

Twitter took no action against numerous tweets that appeared to encourage rioting, destruction of property, or fighting against law enforcement. The following controversial tweets, which Twitter did not take any action against, are from public figures or they are tweets that went viral on the platform and garnered tens of thousands of retweets:

* Twitter CEO Jack Dorsey has ties to Black Lives Matter and his company "painted # blacklivesmatter on a wall at its San Francisco headquarters, placing the company squarely into the national debate about excessive force used by police with blacks," USA Today reported in 2014.
* In 2018, Twitter CEO Jack Dorsey promoted an article on his Twitter account and said it was "great." The article essentially called for turning the entire United States into California and completely eliminating the Republican Party.
* The Daily Caller reported that the article, titled "The Great Lesson of California in America's New Civil War," called for a complete marginalization of the Republican Party and its voters since they only care "about rule by and for billionaires at the expense of working people" and not "average citizens." California, despite its mass wealth inequality, growing lack of social cohesion, poverty, and soaring housing costs, "provides a model for America as a whole," according to the authors. Yet, they do not call for Democrats to try to understand their political adversaries. Instead, they proposed Americans "take the Republican Party down for a generation or two" in order to save the country.

███, headed by bestselling author and popular podcast host Ben Shapiro, is a leading provider of conservative news, cutting through the mainstream media's rhetoric to provide readers the most important, relevant, and engaging stories of the day. Get inside access to ███ by becoming a member.

Title: North Korea Announces Disarmament Ceremony at Nuclear Test Site Ahead of U.S.-DPRK Summit

Article:

North Korea has announced plans to dismantle its nuclear testing site, located in the northeastern part of the country, from May 23-25. The dismantlement ceremony is part of the Hermit Kingdom's pledge to discontinue nuclear tests.

According to North Korea's Foreign Ministry, all tunnels at the Punggye-ri testing ground will be destroyed by explosion, and observation and research facilities, as well as ground-based testing units, will be removed. The announcement, made on Saturday, stated that the Nuclear Weapon Institute and other concerned institutions are taking technical measures for dismantling the northern nuclear test ground of the Democratic People's Republic of Korea (DPRK).

The North has also invited journalists from the United States, South Korea, China, Russia, and Britain to inspect the dismantling process. Analysts suggest that the closure of the site is mostly symbolic and does not represent a material step toward denuclearization.

The announcement follows U.S. President Donald Trump's plans for a summit with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un in Singapore on June 12, marking the first meeting ever between a sitting U.S. president and the leader of North Korea. Kim had previously revealed plans to shut down the nuclear test site during his summit with South Korean President Moon Jae-in last month.

Following the Moon-Kim summit, Moon's office stated that Kim was willing to disclose the process to international experts, but the North's statement on Saturday did not include any mention about allowing experts on the site.

U.S. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo, on Friday, stated that North Korea can look forward to "a future brimming with peace and prosperity" if it agrees to quickly give up its nuclear weapons.

North Korea had already announced, at a ruling party meeting last month, that it has suspended all tests of nuclear devices and intercontinental ballistic missiles (ICBMs) and the plan to close the nuclear testing ground.

The closure of the site could be a useful precedent for Washington and Seoul as they proceed with nuclear negotiations with Pyongyang, analysts say. Adam Mount, a senior defense analyst at the Federation of American Scientists, stated, "Now that North Korea has accepted in principle that agreements should be verified, U.S. negotiators should hold them to this standard for any subsequent agreement." Mount further added, "It will make it more difficult for Kim Jong Un to deny inspections now that he has placed them on the table."

North Korea's six known nuclear tests have taken place at the Punggye-ri site, where a system of tunnels has been dug under Mount Mantap, according to Reuters.

Title: U.S. and Russia Reach Agreement on Securing Syria's Chemical Weapons Stockpile, Averting U.S. Military Action

Article:

In a significant diplomatic development, the United States and Russia have reached an agreement on securing Syria's chemical weapons stockpile, effectively removing the threat of U.S. military action. The agreement, announced on Saturday, follows over two weeks of tense rhetoric and an unsuccessful attempt by President Obama to gain congressional and public support for a limited military strike.

The agreement, brokered in a last-minute diplomatic push led by the Russians, will see Syria's chemical weapons stockpile removed or destroyed by 2014. International inspections will begin by November, and the Syrians will offer full disclosure of their chemical weapons arsenal within a week. Any potential violations by the Syrian regime will be taken to the United Nations Security Council for response.

President Obama, in a Saturday afternoon statement, acknowledged the progress made but emphasized that "much more work remains to be done." Secretary of State John Kerry, who negotiated the agreement with his Russian counterpart, Sergey Lavrov, in Geneva, was more direct, stating, "We have committed to a standard that says verify and verify."

The deal's implementation will be closely scrutinized by a Congress that is wary of Russian President Vladimir Putin and Syrian President Bashar Assad. President Obama's relationship with Putin is strained, with the two leaders often at odds over Syria policy and Putin's decision to grant temporary asylum to former NSA contractor Edward Snowden.

The deal's success hinges on Syria's commitment to the agreed-upon timeline and disclosure of its chemical weapons. Sen. Bob Corker, the top Republican on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, expressed skepticism, stating that Syria's willingness to follow through is "very much an open question."

The agreement offers President Obama a way out of his unpopular call for military action, but it may make it more difficult to hold the Assad regime accountable for the August 21 chemical attack that killed over 1,400 Syrian civilians. The deal's implementation will be closely watched, and its success will determine whether it meets President Obama's goal of denying the Assad regime the ability to conduct another chemical attack.

Title: Chelsea Manning Released from Prison After 62-Day Contempt of Court Detention

Article:

Former US intelligence analyst Chelsea Manning has been released from prison after a 62-day confinement for refusing to testify before a grand jury investigating Wikileaks. Manning, 31, was held in custody following a Virginia judge's order in March. However, she will have to appear again before the grand jury on May 16.

Manning was found guilty in 2013 of charges including espionage for leaking secret military files to Wikileaks, but her sentence was later commuted. She has refused to answer further questions about Wikileaks from investigators, citing that she has already presented her testimony during her 2013 trial.

In a statement, her lawyers announced, "Today marked the expiration of the term of the grand jury, and so, after 62 days of confinement, Chelsea was released from the Alexandria Detention Center earlier today." The statement further added, "Unfortunately, even prior to her release, Chelsea was served with another subpoena. It is therefore conceivable that she will once again be held in contempt of court and be returned [to custody]."

When Manning refused to testify in March, her lawyers reportedly asked for her to be confined at home due to medical issues, but the judge said US Marshals would address her care needs.

US prosecutors have been investigating Wikileaks for years, and in November, prosecutors inadvertently revealed possible charges against Wikileaks founder Julian Assange in court documents from a separate case. Manning was arrested in Iraq in 2010 for disclosing more than 700,000 confidential documents, videos, and diplomatic cables to the anti-secrecy website.

While Manning said she only did so to spark debates about foreign policy, US officials said the leak put lives at risk. She was sentenced to 35 years after being found guilty of 20 charges related to the leak, but then-President Barack Obama commuted her sentence in 2017. Her sentence was the longest given for a leak in US history. President Obama said it was "disproportionate" to her crimes.

Title: Obama's Speech on National Security Agency Reforms: Former NSA Director Expects Few Changes, Emphasis on Reassurance

Article:

In anticipation of President Barack Obama's upcoming speech on changes to the National Security Agency (NSA), former NSA Director Michael Hayden has stated that he does not expect any significant alterations in the way the government collects intelligence.

During an interview on MSNBC's "Morning Joe," Hayden expressed his belief that the speech would focus on reassuring the public rather than implementing transformative changes. He suggested that the language of the speech would emphasize transparency, checks and balances, and reform, but the substance would primarily involve maintaining the status quo.

Hayden also indicated that the NSA's data collection practices are unlikely to change in the near future. Shortly after his appearance on MSNBC, news broke that Obama would propose the NSA to relinquish control over the phone data it collects, but no alternative collector was specified.

According to Hayden, the primary task for Obama in his speech is to reassure the public about the intelligence agencies' activities. He stated, "His mission here, I don't think, is to change what we’re doing. His mission here is to make people more comfortable about what it is that the intelligence agencies are doing."

Hayden identified two key questions that Obama will need to address in the NSA's phone data collection: where the data is stored and how it can be queried. He anticipates that the president will delegate the first question to Congress, while the NSA will continue to hold the data.

Regarding the second question, Hayden expressed concern about requiring intelligence agencies to seek a judge's approval every time they want to query data. He noted that, as the director of the NSA prior to 9/11, such a requirement would feel like a pre-9/11 mindset and make him uncomfortable.

The president's 11 a.m. speech is the culmination of a months-long review of the surveillance programs made public last summer by leaker Edward Snowden. Prior to Hayden's interview, the White House had not confirmed the specific changes Obama would propose.

Title: Democratic Presidential Candidates' Performance and Critiques in the Debate

Article:

The first Democratic presidential debate of 2020 saw Senators Elizabeth Warren and Cory Booker receive praise for their performances, while facing critiques on certain aspects.

Senator Elizabeth Warren presented a consistent message on domestic politics, emphasizing her goal to make government work for the majority of Americans. She shared her personal story, highlighting her humble beginnings and the impact of government-funded education on her life. Warren expressed her ambition to provide the same opportunities to every American, believing that America can still offer such opportunities with a united movement.

Warren's policy proposals were commended for their simplicity and directness, a quality that is not commonly found in senators. However, her Medicare for All plan drew criticism for its potential to replace all private health insurance, which could alienate a significant portion of potential supporters.

Senator Cory Booker delivered a compelling speech on a variety of issues, including immigration and healthcare. He called for a return to a sense of common purpose in the country, aiming to beat President Trump in the election. Booker's performance served as a reminder of his political skills and potential to play a significant role in the race.

Critics noted that the candidates, including Warren, seemed to dodge questions regarding GOP obstruction, particularly Mitch McConnell's efforts to block Democratic initiatives. The candidates' responses suggested that their proposals would remain unimplemented without a Democratic president, House, and Senate in 2021.

The debate questions received mixed reviews, with some praising the moderators for not dedicating much time to foreign policy. However, the lightning round format, in which candidates were asked to name the "greatest geopolitical threat" in one word, was criticized for its lack of nuance and its assumption that the best way to assess a potential president's foreign policy is by finding out what they fear most. This format was seen as promoting a simplistic and potentially dangerous view of the world.

Title: California Bishop Calls for Tighter Gun Control in Letter to U.S. Senators

Article:

In a written petition to U.S. senators, Bishop Stephen Blair, chairman of the bishops' Committee on Domestic Justice and Human Development in California, has called for stricter gun control measures. The Catholic News Agency reported that the bishop believes such measures would help build a "culture of life" and reduce gun violence.

In his letter, Bishop Blair referenced the Safe Communities, Safe Schools Act of 2013, stating it as a positive step towards addressing the issue of gun violence. The bill, if enacted, would implement restrictions and regulations aimed at reducing gun violence and saving lives.

The bishop specifically advocated for the federal government to restrict civilian access to high-capacity ammunition magazines and to ban all assault-type weapons.

While some members of the U.S. Conference of Catholic Bishops have expressed support for stronger gun controls, the Catholic Church has not adopted a political policy on the issue. Pope John Paul II, in his Evangelium Vitae in 1995, stated that guns can be used in self-defense, aligning with church teachings.

Bishop Blair's call for tighter gun control comes as President Obama continues to push for stricter gun control measures. The Senate is expected to discuss gun control issues on Thursday, following a deal brokered by Senators Pat Toomey (Pennsylvania Republican) and Joe Manchin (West Virginia Democrat) on background checks.

Title: California Experiences Historic Drought as NASA Images Reveal Decrease in Water Storage

Article:

Images captured by NASA satellites reveal a significant decrease in California's water storage since 2002, with the entire state currently experiencing a historic drought. The three images, taken in June 2002, June 2008, and June 2014, depict the state's water loss, with orange and red colors indicating greater water loss.

The Sacramento and San Joaquin River basins, which encompass the Central Valley, have suffered the most significant losses. Between 2011 and 2014, these river basins lost approximately 4 trillion gallons of water each year, which is more than California's 38 million residents use in cities and homes annually.

As of Thursday, 100% of California was in a drought, according to the U.S. Drought Monitor. Over 58% of the state is in "exceptional" drought, the worst level. Record warmth has contributed to the drought, as the state experiences its hottest year since records began in 1895, according to data from the National Climatic Data Center.

California Governor Jerry Brown declared a statewide drought emergency earlier this year. Since then, reservoir storage levels have continued to fall, and as of Thursday, they were down to about 52% of the historical average. Regulations restricting outdoor water use were implemented in late July for the entire state. People are not allowed to hose down driveways or sidewalks, nor are they allowed to water lawns and landscapes (if there is excess runoff). There are reports of wells running dry in central California.

Additionally, about 1,000 more wildfires than usual have affected the state, including some unusual ones in the spring.

Title: North Korean Leader's Hotel Choice Sparks Last-Minute Relocation of White House Press Corps

Article:

In a surprising turn of events, North Korean leader Kim Jong Un chose to stay at the same hotel as the White House press corps during his meeting with U.S. President Donald Trump in Hanoi, Vietnam. This decision, initially hailed by South Korean media and experts as a strategic move to expose himself to the American press, led to a last-minute relocation of the White House press pool.

Before Kim's arrival, the Melia Hotel was expected to host the press center for hundreds of visiting American journalists. However, minutes after Kim arrived at a Vietnamese border station on Tuesday, the Vietnamese foreign ministry announced that the Melia Hanoi Hotel would no longer serve as the press center.

The White House press pool was instead relocated to a shared working space set up for visiting journalists at the Viet Xo Friendship Cultural Labour Palace, a large Soviet-era building a few blocks from the Melia. The fate of the journalists who had booked to stay in the Melia remains unclear.

During Kim's first summit with Trump in Singapore last year, reporters and other guests at the hotel were herded back and ordered to pocket phones and cameras when Kim moved through the hotel. Some guests who took photographs of the leader had their photos deleted.

Kim and Trump will meet in Hanoi on Wednesday and Thursday to discuss a North Korean pledge to give up its nuclear weapons program. The Melia had been widely expected to host Kim during his stay in Hanoi. Sources told media outlets last week that the North Korean leader would stay there, and Kim's foreign minister, Ri Yong Ho, based himself in the hotel during a visit to Vietnam in November last year.

Kim's close aide Kim Chang Son also inspected the hotel before the summit. On Monday, a member of staff at the hotel told media outlets that the White House press center had been set up on the third floor, and an entire ballroom had been reserved for the North Korean delegation. Despite these signs, the Melia was still considered a potential location for the White House press until Kim set foot off his train. A reporter from a certain media outlet was evicted from the Melia hotel lobby before Kim arrived.

Cheong Seong-chang, a North Korea expert at the Sejong Institute, commented after Kim arrived at the hotel, "It was hard to understand in the first place."

Title: Trump's Tariffs Harm U.S. Economy Due to Impact on Intermediate Goods, According to Tax Theory

Article:

Noah Smith, a former assistant professor of finance at Stony Brook University and opinion columnist, argues that President Donald Trump's tariffs are a detrimental move for the U.S. economy due to their impact on intermediate goods. According to Smith, tax theory suggests that intermediate goods, such as steel for cars or transistors for computer chips, should not be taxed because taxing inputs causes companies to produce less, resulting in a smaller economic pie to divide among consumers.

Chad Brown of the Peterson Institute for International Economics provides data that most of the $50 billion worth of Chinese products Trump is threatening to impose tariffs on are intermediate goods or capital goods. This, according to Smith, will negatively affect a large number of U.S. companies, particularly manufacturers.

Smith suggests that if Trump wants to boost American manufacturing, he should not use taxes to restrict the materials and equipment U.S. factories need. Instead, he proposes focusing tariffs on consumer goods or implementing a Value-Added Tax (VAT) in the U.S. VATs, which let companies deduct the cost of their intermediate goods when paying taxes, are a highly efficient form of taxation.

Smith also suggests using the VAT to fund health care, housing subsidies, and other services for poor Americans, addressing the concern that VATs tend to hit the poor harder than the rich. He notes that a VAT might satisfy Trump's desire for a trade war, as he seems to view VATs as a kind of tariff on imported goods, although this is not accurate.

This column does not necessarily reflect the opinion of the editorial board or the owners of ███ LP.

Title: Former FBI Deputy Director McCabe Expresses Concern Over Reputation Amidst Ongoing Public Attacks from President Trump

Article:

In a statement, former FBI Deputy Director Andrew McCabe, who served a 21-year career with the bureau, expressed concern over the impact of President Trump's public attacks on his reputation. McCabe stated that the real damage is being inflicted on the FBI, law enforcement, and the special counsel.

During one of the most tumultuous periods in the FBI's history, McCabe served as the second in command and oversaw investigations into both the Trump campaign and Hillary Clinton's use of a private email server. He assumed the role of acting FBI director following the sudden firing of his predecessor, James Comey, and publicly contradicted the White House on national television regarding the support of rank-and-file FBI agents for Comey.

President Trump has repeatedly singled out McCabe for public criticism, suggesting that he helped protect Clinton from prosecution during the 2016 presidential campaign. The president cited the fact that McCabe's wife, Jill, ran as a Democrat for a State Senate seat in Virginia and received hundreds of thousands of dollars from a political committee run by Terry McAuliffe, a longtime ally of the Clintons, as evidence of bias.

As recently as Thursday, the White House press secretary, Sarah Huckabee Sanders, stated that McCabe had "troubling behavior" and was a "bad actor." McCabe's lawyer, Michael R. Bromwich, described these comments as "vile and defamatory" and claimed they were intended to put pressure on the Department of Justice.

Mrs. McCabe lost her race, and McCabe was later promoted to deputy director, where he oversaw the investigation into Clinton. No charges were filed in that case, and Trump has pointed to the donations to Mrs. McCabe's campaign as evidence of FBI bias.

Title: McConnell Assures No Default on Debt as Congressional Focus Shifts to Borrowing Limit and Tax Reform

Article:

Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.) has stated that there is "zero chance" Congress will allow the U.S. to default on its debts by failing to increase the borrowing limit. McConnell made these comments during a joint appearance in Kentucky with U.S. Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin on Monday.

The event marked one of McConnell's first public appearances since President Donald Trump publicly criticized him for failing to pass a repeal and replacement of former President Barack Obama's health care law. McConnell did not mention Trump in his remarks and did not take questions from reporters after the event.

When asked about his news sources, McConnell said he reads a variety of outlets, including The New York Times. In response to a question about where he gets his news, McConnell said, "My view is most news is not fake. I try not to fall in love with any particular source."

The U.S. government currently has enough money to pay its bills until Sept. 29. After that date, Congress would need to grant permission for the government to borrow more money to meet its obligations, including Social Security and interest payments.

McConnell sought to reassure a crowd of nervous business leaders by interjecting at the end of Mnuchin's answer to a question about what would happen if lawmakers did not increase the borrowing limit. "Let me just add, there is zero chance, no chance, we won't raise the debt ceiling," McConnell said. "America is not going to default."

As the most pressing issue when lawmakers return to Washington following their August recess, addressing the country's borrowing limit will take center stage. After that, Republicans are expected to turn their attention to overhauling the nation's tax code.

McConnell also addressed the likelihood of repealing a pair of Obama-era laws most disliked by conservatives. While negotiations about health care are ongoing, McConnell said the path forward is "somewhat murky." He also stated that it would be "challenging" to lift the restrictions placed on banks following the 2008 financial crisis, known as "Dodd-Frank."

On tax reform, McConnell said the only things lawmakers won't consider eliminating are deductions on mortgage interest and charitable deductions. The specifics of tax reform have yet to be determined.

Title: Hillary Clinton Officially Announces 2016 Presidential Bid

Article:

Former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton has officially announced her intention to seek the 2016 Democratic nomination for president on Sunday afternoon, ending years of speculation over her plans to pursue the Oval Office. According to sources familiar with the campaign plan, Clinton will make the announcement via a video and social media, although the exact method has not been confirmed.

At this point, Mrs. Clinton faces minimal competition for the Democratic nomination. Polls barely register former Maryland Governor Martin O'Malley or former Virginia Senator Jim Webb. One potential heavyweight, Vice President Joe Biden, has expressed interest in a campaign but has taken few apparent steps to prepare. On Thursday, former Rhode Island Governor Lincoln Chafee surprisingly joined the field and offered a critical critique from the left of Mrs. Clinton's record on foreign policy. "The biggest question will be: What exactly did you accomplish in your four years as secretary of state?" he said in an interview. "There was a lot of dust in the air. Not many concrete accomplishments."

Announcing now gives Clinton an edge, as she lost a bitter contest to then-Senator Barack Obama for her party's nomination in 2008. The early announcement would provide her fundraising team more time to generate the hundreds of millions of dollars typically necessary to mount a successful presidential bid.

Following the Sunday announcement, Clinton is expected to travel to the first-in-the-nation caucus state of Iowa early next week for campaign events. Democratic strategists and advisers spoke on condition of anonymity because Clinton has not yet finalized all aspects of her announcement plan, according to The Washington Post. NPR's Mara Liasson reports that Clinton is expected to stay in Iowa for at least a month of small, unscripted events with small groups of voters.

Title: Chicago Mayor Rahm Emanuel Condemns Rep. Ilhan Omar's Anti-Semitic Comments in The Atlantic Op-Ed

Article:

In an opinion piece published in The Atlantic on Thursday, former Obama Chief of Staff and current Chicago Mayor Rahm Emanuel criticized Representative Ilhan Omar's recent anti-Semitic comments. Emanuel's stance differs from other Democrats who view Omar's comments as criticism of Israel rather than anti-Semitic remarks.

Emanuel stated unequivocally, "Her remarks are not anti-Israel; they are anti-Semitic." He argued that Omar's comments perpetuate age-old stereotypes about Jews, such as the trope of dual loyalty, which has been used by anti-Semites throughout history.

Emanuel, who has faced questions of dual loyalty in his political career, noted that this trope has been aimed at Jews in various countries for centuries. By embracing this trope, Omar, according to Emanuel, is associating herself with historical events such as the Spanish Inquisition, Russian pogroms, and the Holocaust.

However, Emanuel clarified that a politician can be critical of Israel without being anti-Semitic. He emphasized the strong relationship between the United States and Israel, highlighting their shared values and national interests. Jewish Americans who support Israel, he said, do so because of the commonality of their values and interests.

Emanuel also acknowledged that Omar, as a Muslim in Congress, faces adversities, but he argued that these circumstances should not excuse her from the consequences of her anti-Semitic remarks. He concluded by praising Emanuel for his courage in calling out Omar's anti-Semitism.

Title: The Role of Individuals in America's Reopening Amidst the COVID-19 Pandemic

Article:

In the ongoing debate between governors and President Trump over who holds the authority to reopen America, it is crucial to recognize that the power to reopen lies not with politicians, but with individuals, families, businesses, and religious congregations. Politicians can facilitate the process by lifting lockdown orders and school closures, but the decision to resume normal activities ultimately rests with the individuals and groups mentioned above.

Nate Silver, a renowned data analyst and pandemic guide, aptly stated, "people will vote with their feet." The desire for social interaction, the need for economic activity, and the religious inclinations of Americans will drive the reopening process, not top-down orders from politicians.

The desire for family reunions, the need for businesses to operate, and the religious needs of Americans are strong motivators. Businesses, having invested resources in their establishments, will reopen when they can do so safely and profitably. The first business to reopen, if it does so safely, will likely attract a crowd of paying customers.

Religious institutions also play a significant role in the reopening process. The New Boston Post, in an editorial, emphasized the importance of churches in tending to people's spiritual needs. Church leaders should devise plans for reopening their churches, setting a specific date for resuming services. The editorial argues that governors cannot order churches to close, as the role of government in religious matters is limited by the U.S. Constitution.

Timothy P. Carney, writing for The Washington Examiner, suggests that churches could reopen with social distancing measures in place, making worship services safer than shopping at a store like Home Depot, which remains open.

However, the primary motivators in this situation are the desire to stay alive and to avoid infecting others. Each individual decision carries potential risks, and the consequences of one person's actions can affect others. But this is not a new concept in American life, and it has not previously led to nationwide or statewide lockdowns.

The best approach to reopening America is one that aligns with American values, emphasizing freedom, competition, choice, and diversity, rather than a one-size-fits-all approach or authoritarianism. The role of government is to protect the natural or God-given freedoms of individuals, families, businesses, and religions, rather than controlling their activities, even in the name of public health.

Title: Local Governments Urged to Mobilize Resources During COVID-19 Crisis

Article:

The COVID-19 pandemic is posing a significant challenge to society, comparable to the Great Depression and World War II. The baby boomer generation is currently facing the first major societal challenge in their lifetime, and the response to this virus will determine the impact of its spread.

During the Great Depression, President Franklin Roosevelt utilized the federal government to create jobs and stimulate the economy. Automobile companies shifted production from cars to military equipment, and millions of people joined the military to support the war efforts. This generation, often referred to as the Greatest Generation, made significant sacrifices to preserve America's freedom and democracy.

Now, local governments are being called upon to take action during this crisis. With many people losing jobs and struggling to pay for basic necessities, local governments are being asked to provide essential services such as housing, food, and childcare.

Cary Bozeman, a commissioner for the Port of Bremerton and former mayor of Bremerton, has urged local governments in Kitsap County, including Bremerton, Poulsbo, Port Orchard, Bainbridge Island, and the school districts, to take action to support their citizens during this difficult time. Bozeman believes that local governments have the ability to quickly and efficiently deliver services to their communities.

Bozeman suggests that local governments should work together to ensure that people do not lose their housing and have access to food and childcare for working parents. He believes that local governments should tap into their reserves or even borrow money at low interest rates to provide the necessary resources.

Bozeman emphasizes that local governments cannot rely solely on federal or state assistance and that local leaders must step forward, develop a plan, and support those most in need during this challenging time. Bozeman's call to action is a reminder that, as a community, we have the ability to mobilize and support each other during this difficult period in our lives.

Title: Hugo Chavez: A Controversial Leader of Venezuela

Article:

Hugo Chavez, a charismatic and divisive figure, served as the President of Venezuela from 1999 until his death in 2013. Known for his leftist ideology and fervent opposition to the United States, Chavez sought to transform Venezuela into a socialist state. His presidency was marked by economic struggles, political polarization, and international controversy.

Born in a poor family in 1954 in the Great Savannah, Chavez joined the military as a youth and attempted to overthrow Venezuela's government in 1992. After his release from prison, he was mentored by Luis Miquilena, a prominent Venezuelan leftist leader. Miquilena convinced Chavez to abandon plans for a violent overthrow and pursue democratic means to rise to power.

Chavez won the presidency in a landslide election in 1998, capitalizing on the Venezuelan people's growing discontent with the traditional political parties. He was inaugurated the following year. During his years in power, Chavez was omnipresent, with his face on billboards and his voice dominating the airwaves. His main platform was a Sunday TV show, "Hello Mr. President," where he railed against American leaders and built a connection with poor Venezuelans.

Chavez's greatest success, according to former Vice President Jose Vicente Rangel, was making those who had been marginalized feel part of something bigger. Chavez used his political capital and a powerful base to launch what he called 21st Century Socialism, nationalizing companies, seizing farmland, and forming alliances with like-minded leaders who opposed the United States.

Chavez's policies and alliances, however, were not without controversy. He provided subsidized oil to Communist Cuba, irking Washington, and supported a violent guerrilla movement in neighboring Colombia, according to internal Colombian government documents and interviews with former Colombian guerrillas. Some of his closest allies included controversial leaders such as Iran's Mahmoud Ahmadinejad and Syrian President Bashar Assad.

At home, Chavez jailed some opponents and labeled his critics as degenerates and squealing pigs. Michael Shifter, president of the Washington-based Inter-American Dialogue policy group, stated that despite the elections Chavez won, his government was far from democratic. "He, over time, concentrated power in his own hands. There were very few checks and constraints on his authority. He made all the decisions. No one else. Institutions like the judiciary were completely controlled by Chavez," Shifter said. "So in the end, he really was an autocrat and despot."

Despite the economic struggles and political polarization, Chavez maintained fervent supporters throughout his rule. His charisma, folksy humor, and connection with the poor resonated with millions of Venezuelans. He was enthralling to an international left yearning for a magnetic leader, as evidenced by director Oliver Stone's glowing documentary, "South of the Border." However, the rosy gloss often did not align with reality.

Title: Marine Shoots, Kills Two Fellow Service Members at Virginia Base, Then Apparent Suicide

Article:

A Marine shot and killed two of his fellow service members at Marine Corps Base Quantico on Thursday night, and then apparently killed himself, base officials said. The incident took place at the Marine Corps Base Quantico, where the shooter gunned down a man and a woman, the spokesmen said. All are Marines - permanent personnel assigned to the officer candidate school.

Authorities did not disclose a motive and were investigating the incident. The identities of the victims were not immediately disclosed as authorities worked to notify next of kin.

The incident shocked the military community. It comes as the Corps grieves over another tragedy: the deaths of seven U.S. Marines in a training exercise in Nevada on Monday.

Secretary of Defense Chuck Hagel "was saddened to learn of the shootings at Marine Corps Base Quantico," Pentagon spokesman George Little said Friday. "This tragedy, as well as the tragedy in Nevada earlier this week, took the lives of Marines who volunteered to serve their nation. His heart and his prayers are with them and their families. He believes that the legendary strength of the United States Marine Corps will ensure that they are forever remembered," Little said.

Early Marine accounts said the notification of the shooting came late Thursday when authorities found one dead victim. Using a public address system, police announced a lockdown at the base and surrounded the building where the suspect was believed to be barricaded. They ordered everyone to stay in their homes, doors locked, they said.

Authorities from the base and Prince William County, Virginia, surrounded the shooter, who was in a barracks not far from where the first shooting occurred. Law enforcement officials entered the barracks two hours later and discovered the shooter dead, apparently of a self-inflicted wound. The female victim was in the room with him, fatally shot.

The lockdown ended early Friday, a few hours after it started. As dawn rose over the base, Maxwell told reporters that there were no barricades or a standoff but did not elaborate. The incident was confined to a single barracks at the candidate school.

He said "quick" police reaction helped resolve the situation, first reported at 10:30 p.m. via an emergency call. Soon, security was heightened, and a mass notification was issued throughout the base. Base restrictions were lifted a few hours later. Others in the officer candidate school were "accounted for and safe."

"As we take care of our Marines and their families that are dealing with this tragedy, I'd also ask for the support of our neighbors, the community, and their thoughts and prayers as well for our Marines who have lost their comrades-in-arms," Maxwell said.

Visitors to the base will see a grand statue: the Iwo Jima Monument. It gives all who enter pause about the important role the base has played in training generations of Marines in forging military doctrine and fighting America's wars.

The statue depicts the historic flag-raising on Mount Suribachi, on the Japanese island of Iwo Jima, during the famous World War II battle there. The Quantico base, started during World War I, has been integral in training, education, and forging military doctrine for America's battles.

Early on, amphibious warfare was, the corps said, "conceived and perfected" there. The Marines there came up with the idea "of carrying troops from ship to shore by helicopter." Now, it's home to the Marine Corps Warfighting Laboratory, which conducts experiments in modern warfare.

"This is perhaps the only command whose mission touches the farthest reaches of the Corps; decisions made here impact Marines aboard ship, fighting in the Global War on Terrorism, on guard duty at embassies across the globe, and reserve duty throughout the United States," the Marines said. Federal agencies, such as the Drug Enforcement Administration and the FBI, share training facilities there. The base also has a reputation across popular culture as a key national security training location. Jack Ryan, writer Tom Clancy's well-known character in novels and films, for example, took officer training there.

Title: White House Physician Confirms President Trump's Health and Cognitive Ability

Article:

During a news conference on Tuesday, the White House physician, Navy Rear Adm. Dr. Ronny Jackson, presented the results of his examination of President Trump last week, confirming the President's physical and mental health and fitness for office.

The detailed description of the President's health provided by Dr. Jackson indicates that, for a 71-year-old male, President Trump is in excellent health and likely will remain so for years to come. The liberal media, in their follow-up questions, were reportedly attempting to find any flaws in Dr. Jackson's report, questioning not only normal findings but also alleging that the White House doctor may not be telling the whole truth.

President Trump passed the cognitive test with a perfect score of 30 out of 30. This impressive result was corroborated by the medical team, reinforcing their personal impression of the President's normal and healthy cognitive abilities. Aside from the well-known fact that the President has a history of high cholesterol and takes a small dose of cholesterol-lowering medication, there appear to be no other medical findings of concern.

The cognitive ability tests, which are psychometric assessments designed to measure general intelligence, were administered to the President. These tests evaluate a person's cognitive ability in areas such as numerical, verbal, abstract, spatial, and mechanical reasoning. This helps to measure normal brain health and can detect declines in function, as well as conditions like Alzheimer's or age-related dementia.

The President's perfect score on the cognitive test has put to rest any speculation about the President's mental fitness. This press conference was transparent, and the amount of information disclosed was commendable. The medical team at the White House is believed to have done President Trump justice, and the recommendations of diet and exercise are the only prescriptions necessary.

Title: French Authorities Conduct Raid on Paris Suburb, Detain Eight and Thwart Potential Attacks

Article:

French authorities conducted a raid on a suspected hideout of the alleged mastermind behind the deadly Paris attacks on Wednesday, resulting in eight detentions, two deaths, and potentially thwarted further bloodshed. The operation took place in the northern Paris suburb of Saint-Denis.

According to Paris prosecutor Francois Molins, the suspected ringleader, Abdelhamid Abaaoud, may have been present in the apartment building during the raid, but this is unclear. Residents in the area reported seeing Abaaoud in the neighborhood and at a local mosque.

Investigators zeroed in on the building after intercepting phone conversations indicating that a relative of Abaaoud might be there. The raid was met with resistance, including an armored door, a woman who detonated a suicide vest, and gunfire exchanged for approximately an hour. The French police used powerful munitions, causing one floor of the building to collapse.

The violence resulted in body parts, which are being tested through DNA analysis. Neither Abaaoud nor suspect Salah Abdeslam, who has been sought since the attacks, were among those detained in the operation, according to Molins.

French President Francois Hollande described the intense standoff as further proof that "we are at war" with ISIS. He stated, "What the terrorists were targeting was what France represents. This is what was attacked on the night of November 13."

ISIS has drawn international attention for taking over large areas of Iraq and Syria, leaving a trail of violence and destruction in its wake. This month alone, ISIS has claimed responsibility for the Paris attacks, the downing of a Russian passenger jet in Egypt, and a pair of suicide bombings in Beirut.

France had already been part of the U.S.-led coalition fighting ISIS with airstrikes. In response to the series of shootings and explosions in Paris last week, which killed 129 people, France has stepped up its efforts against ISIS. President Hollande has proposed extending France's state of emergency for three more months, giving authorities greater powers in conducting searches, holding people, and dissolving certain groups.

To combat the Islamist extremist group, President Hollande also plans to appeal to world leaders, including meeting next week with U.S. President Barack Obama and Russian President Vladimir Putin, who have been at odds on what to do in Syria.

Whoever was inside the Saint-Denis apartment on Wednesday appeared to be "prepared to act" in possibly another attack, according to Molins. The operation involved 110 police, who swarmed a diverse, working-class area that is home to the Stade de France sports stadium, where three suicide bombings took place days earlier.

The raid led authorities to another apartment on the same street. Molins described the operation as complex, with almost an hour of uninterrupted gunfire as police tried to gain entry. The violent standoff left residents in the area, already shaken by last week's attacks, startled and scared.

Three people in the Saint-Denis building, including one with a bullet wound in the arm, are among the eight detained, according to Molins. The others include the person who loaned the apartment to the suspected terrorists and his friend. Two of the eight held were hospitalized, according to Interior Ministry spokesman Pierre-Henry Brandet.

Residents in the area were shocked by the events unfolding in their neighborhood. Saadana Aymen, a 29-year-old who lives one street down, expressed his surprise, stating, "When you think of Saint-Denis, you don't think of terrorists."

Authorities conducted further raids in other locations on Tuesday night into Wednesday, resulting in the detention of at least 25 people, the confiscation of 34 weapons, and the discovery of illicit drugs in 16 instances. The authorities have not provided details about the arrests or said what connection they could have to Friday's attacks.

Investigators are working to piece together the movements and contacts of the terrorists in the days and hours leading up to the attacks. They have found at least one piece of evidence that could help them in their search: one of the attacker's cell phones was found in a trash bin outside the Bataclan theater, where most of Friday's victims were gunned down. A message on the phone, according to Molins, said, "Here we go, it's starting."

Authorities are trying to determine who the message was sent to and whether the suspected ringleader in the attack is still on the run or whether his remains were found in the rubble.

Title: "Unfavorable Voters Could Impact 2020 Presidential Election, New Poll Suggests"

Article:

A new Morning Consult poll suggests that voters who hold unfavorable views of both President Donald Trump and presumptive Democratic nominee Joe Biden could play a significant role in the 2020 presidential election. Unlike in 2016, this group might not favor Trump, who previously benefited from such voters due to their perceived lesser dislike of him compared to Hillary Clinton.

In 2016, exit polling showed that voters who did not like either major party candidate favored Trump over Clinton by a 17-point margin. However, the new Morning Consult poll indicates that Biden has a 29-point lead with the same group, with a 19-point advantage when undecided voters are forced to make a choice.

The poll also reveals that this group holds more negative views of Trump, with 66 percent saying they have very unfavorable views of the president, compared to 40 percent for Biden. This data is based on voters who express unfavorable views of both candidates.

The impact of the so-called "haters demographic" on the election depends on several factors. Geographic limitations due to the Electoral College, polling inaccuracies, and the role of third parties are among these factors.

The geographic limitation arises from the Electoral College system, which restricts the influence of voter anger in states that are traditionally blue or red. For instance, a Californian's dislike for Joe Biden will not change California's blue status.

The poll's accuracy can be questionable, as it categorizes individuals based on their responses. Some voters might dislike both candidates but have already made up their minds. For example, many conservatives might have voted for Trump in 2016 not because they particularly liked him but because they wanted a Republican president to appoint judges.

The role of third parties is another factor. The abysmal approval ratings for Trump and Clinton in 2016 likely contributed to the record-shattering number of votes received by former New Mexico Gov. Gary Johnson, the Libertarian Party's presidential nominee.

This year's Libertarian ticket, led by Jo Jorgensen, is not expected to match Johnson's performance. The Morning Consult poll did not include any third-party candidates, so it may overlook whether members of the "haters demographic" might refuse to vote for both Trump and Biden, opting instead to stay home or support an alternative candidate they like.

With negative partisanship driving much of American politics, it is not surprising that voters with a negative view of both Trump and Biden are likely to decide the election. With more than 100 days until the polls close, both candidates will have ample opportunities to address this demographic.

Title: Mitt Romney Announces Senate Bid in Utah, Seeking Political Comeback

Article:

Mitt Romney, the 2012 Republican presidential nominee, announced on Friday his intention to run for the U.S. Senate in Utah to succeed the retiring Orrin Hatch. In a tweet, Romney stated, "I am running for United States Senate to serve the people of Utah and bring Utah's values to Washington."

Romney, who is considered a heavy favorite for the Senate seat, has emerged as a prominent critic of President Trump. If he wins, he could potentially cause challenges for the administration from across Pennsylvania Avenue.

Born in Michigan, Romney has deep ties to Utah. He attended Brigham Young University in Provo and played a significant role in turning around the scandal-plagued 2002 Winter Olympics in Salt Lake City, moving to the state after losing the 2012 presidential race.

A video message posted on Twitter on Friday highlights Romney's Olympics background and offers voters an early look at his platform. In the video, Romney emphasizes fiscal responsibility, job creation, and a moderate approach on immigration, which appears to be a critique of Trump's policies.

"Utah has a lot to teach the politicians in Washington," Romney says in the video. "Utah has balanced its budgets. Washington is buried in debt. Utah exports more abroad than it imports. Washington has that backwards. Utah welcomes legal immigrants from around the world. Washington sends immigrants a message of exclusion."

The announcement was widely anticipated, although it was delayed following Wednesday's mass shooting at a Florida high school. Utah Republican Party Chairman Rob Anderson earlier this week criticized Romney, stating, "Mitt Romney does not live here, his kids were not born here, he does not shop here." Anderson later apologized for his comments, acknowledging that they came across as disparaging or unsupportive.

Despite Romney's past criticism of President Trump, Democrats attempted to portray the two as ideologically aligned. Democratic National Committee spokesperson Vedant Patel said in a statement, "While Mitt Romney desperately wants to separate himself from the extremism of the current administration, the basic policies of Trump's GOP – whether it's tax cuts for the rich or reversing the progress of the ACA – were his before they were Donald Trump's." Patel continued, "Utah deserves a Senator who will expand opportunities and fight to improve the lives of everyone, not another multi-millionaire looking out for himself, his rich neighbors, and the special interests."

Romney reportedly reached out to Anderson regarding his comments and accepted the apology. As Chairman of the Utah Republican Party, Anderson pledged to treat all candidates equally to ensure a fair path to the Party nomination.

Title: Pressure to Close Guantanamo Bay Prison Mounts as Funding and Housing Issues Persist

Article:

The United States' Guantanamo Bay Naval Station, colloquially known as Gitmo, remains a contentious issue, with calls to close the aging and deteriorating prison growing louder. Despite President Barack Obama's pledge to shut down Gitmo and an executive order signed in 2009 aiming for closure within a year, the prison continues to house 149 prisoners, with approximately 50 considered too dangerous for release.

The prison's infrastructure has reportedly deteriorated significantly, prompting the Southern Command to request $200 million in improvements last year. However, this request was denied by the Pentagon. General John F. Kelly, head of the U.S. Southern Command, which includes Joint Task Force Guantanamo, stated to The New York Times that the prison is "a long way from being closed."

The main obstacle to closing Gitmo lies in the funding aspect. If funds are allocated for facility upgrades in anticipation of the prison's closure, those funds would be wasted if the prison remains open. Conversely, if the prison continues to operate without necessary improvements, critical issues persist.

The House of Representatives has voted to prohibit the transfer of prisoners, citing the Obama administration's alleged violation of law when five Taliban prisoners were released in exchange for Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl in May without sufficient notification to Congress. Rep. Howard "Buck" McKeon, California Republican and chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, stated to The New York Times that there is no support in the House for relaxing current restrictions or backing off the ban in light of the president's recent legal violations.

An attempt to transfer six detainees to Uruguay fell through at the last minute when Uruguayan President Jose Mujica withdrew from the deal.

In addition to political hurdles, the prison faces practical challenges. Leaking ceilings, buckling floors, and inadequate medical facilities cause constant problems at the aging prison. Approximately 6,000 service members and staff work at the prison complex, with taxpayer expense estimated at about $413 million in 2014, or approximately $3 million per prisoner per year. If the prisoners were housed in a U.S. federal penitentiary, costs would drop to about $30,280 per prisoner per year.

Rear Adm. Kyle Kozad, who heads the prison task force, told The New York Times, "We are forced to at least forecast so that we're prepared if this detention facility is open two years from now, 12 years from now, 22 years from now, so that we're prepared to be able to continue to do the mission."

Title: Supreme Court's Actions on Death Penalty: A Legal Trivia or Constitutional Issue?

Article:

The ongoing debates surrounding the death penalty at the U.S. Supreme Court are not, as some headlines suggest, a matter of open feuding or sniping among justices. Instead, the court is addressing minor aspects of the death penalty's application, according to Damon Root, author of Overruled: The Long War for Control of the U.S. Supreme Court.

Current Supreme Court actions regarding the death penalty primarily revolve around specific, technical issues such as the presence of religious figures in the death chamber and the pain experienced by individuals with rare diseases during lethal injection. These cases, while significant in their own right, do not challenge the constitutionality of the death penalty as a whole.

The Constitution, as written, supports capital punishment. The Fifth Amendment specifies certain limitations on the conditions in which a person may be "deprived of life," and the Eighth Amendment's prohibition of "cruel and unusual punishment" does not necessarily rule out capital punishment. The drafters of the Constitution did not believe that the Eighth Amendment prohibited capital punishment.

Arguments against the death penalty, such as the irreversibility of the punishment or the uneven application of the law, are often based on assumptions that may not stand up to scrutiny. These arguments are more appropriately directed towards procedural reform rather than the death penalty itself.

The Supreme Court's role is to interpret the Constitution, not to decide on the morality or acceptability of capital punishment. The more substantial arguments against the death penalty, such as its potential to add more violence and horror to society, are better suited for Congress and the states, which have the power to end the practice of capital punishment if they so choose.

In conclusion, the current debates surrounding the death penalty at the U.S. Supreme Court are primarily focused on technical, procedural issues rather than the constitutionality of capital punishment itself. The more substantial arguments against the death penalty are better addressed through procedural reform or legislative action.

Title: Defense Secretary Mattis Labels North Korea a "Clear and Present Danger," Criticizes China's Actions in South China Sea

Article:

Defense Secretary Jim Mattis, in a speech at the Shangri-La Dialogue in Singapore, labeled North Korea as a "clear and present danger" and criticized China for its actions in the South China Sea. Mattis expressed hope for cooperation with China in ridding North Korea of its nuclear weapons, but was critical of North Korea's nuclear and missile programs.

In his speech, Mattis emphasized the Trump administration's efforts to exhaust all possible alternatives to avert a nuclear arms race with North Korea, in violation of United Nations restrictions on its activities. He also criticized China for its disregard for international law by its "indisputable militarization" of artificial islands in disputed areas of the South China Sea.

Mattis called North Korea an "urgent military threat" and expressed concern about the possibility of a pre-emptive attack without warning South Korea in advance. He also highlighted the U.S. commitment to working with its global partners in the Asia-Pacific region.

Rep. Mac Thornberry, a Republican from Texas and chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, praised Mattis for effectively stressing the U.S. commitment to allies in the region.

Overall, Mattis' speech struck a positive and hopeful tone for cooperation and peace in the Asia-Pacific region, where the U.S. has made it a priority to nurture and strengthen alliances and partnerships. Mattis also acknowledged the competition between the U.S. and China, the world's two largest economies, but emphasized that conflict is not inevitable.

The U.S. has about 28,500 troops permanently based in South Korea, a defense treaty ally.

Title: Understanding National Debt: Factors, Implications, and Differences Between Developed and Developing Countries

Article:

National debt, a measure of a government's borrowing, is a significant indicator of a country's fiscal health. The critical factor to consider alongside national debt is a country's gross domestic product (GDP). According to Jeffrey Frankel, an economics professor at Harvard Kennedy School, the stability of a country's debt depends on whether it is decreasing as a share of GDP.

The amount of debt a country can handle safely depends on various factors. Rising debt can cause economic strain, as a larger portion of government expenditures is allocated for interest payments. However, in some cases, more borrowing may be justified, such as during economic stagnation, when the government may want to increase spending as a stimulus, investing in big infrastructure projects.

The levels of national debt differ significantly between developed and developing countries. Nicolas Véron of the Peterson Institute for International Economics explains that this disparity is due to "market discipline," as investors are less inclined to lend to emerging markets, where they perceive greater risk. Véron further states, "The more creditworthy you are, the more you can borrow. It's true of individuals; it's true of countries."

Regarding the United States' national debt, it has been surging since the 1980s, currently close to $20 trillion, with an increasing percentage of GDP. While it is impossible to predict with certainty, most analysts expect significant tax cuts and spending increases under President Trump, which would likely result in a rising national debt.

National debt played a significant role in Europe's recent financial struggles. Some analysts question whether too much austerity was imposed during the 2009 crisis or whether it was imposed at the wrong time. Greece, considered an advanced economy, had "lots of features of emerging markets," according to Véron, and its debt levels before the crisis were far higher than they should have been. Frankel agrees, stating that Greece needed austerity before 2008 but did not have it; then, when the economy was already struggling, austerity was imposed. Frankel refers to renowned British economist John Maynard Keynes, stating that it's in the boom times that governments should cut back.

Title: Colorado Pioneers Healthcare Price Transparency, Aiming to Simplify Cost Comparisons

Article:

Colorado is leading the way in making healthcare prices more transparent, with the ultimate goal of making it as easy for consumers to compare prices as shopping for a coffee maker. The state's efforts, spearheaded by a nonprofit organization called the Colorado Health Institute (CIVHC), aim to provide consumers with the information they need to make informed decisions about their healthcare services and costs.

Edie Sonn, the CEO of CIVHC, explains that the organization's mission is to "give you that information, so you can become an empowered consumer." The organization has been working to make health care prices publicly available in Colorado, and they have made significant progress in recent years.

One of the key tools CIVHC has used is an "all-payer claims database," which collects a copy of every receipt for a health care service in a given state. This database aims to provide a comprehensive view of healthcare prices in Colorado. However, gathering and organizing this data has been a complex and time-consuming process.

"Claims data is dirty," says Sonn. "It's really dirty. It takes a lot of scrubbing to make sense of it. It's complicated, time-consuming, and expensive."

The state has received funding for this effort from private grants, but those are now drying up. To continue making basic price information accessible to the public for free, the state is considering selling more complex, custom data reports to businesses within the health industry.

Dr. David Ehrenberger, the chief medical officer for Avista Adventist Hospital, outside Denver, is one such business that is interested in these reports. He would like to see reports that show not just how much his competitors are charging, but also their complication rates. This information would give him better negotiating power with big insurance companies.

However, there is a glitch in the system. In order to create the reports that healthcare providers want, they need to include price information from all payers, and one of the biggest payers is Medicare. At the moment, CIVHC cannot use Medicare data in any of the custom reports they want to sell.

"Current federal law restricts what we can do with that Medicare data," says Sonn. "The only thing you can use their data for is public reporting."

CIVHC and other organizations like it have found support on Capitol Hill to allow them to sell Medicare data.
