A measure that would make that change is now part of a larger Medicare bill working its way through Congress. If it passes, Colorado will be one step closer to making shopping for healthcare as easy as shopping for a coffee maker.

This story is part of a partnership between NPR and Kaiser Health News.

Title: Young Adult Uninsured Rate Drops Significantly in 2011, Attributed to Affordable Care Act Provision

Article:

A new report released on Monday by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) indicates a significant decrease in the number of young adults without health insurance in 2011. The report, based on a federal survey of approximately 35,000 households, shows a 22% drop in the uninsured rate among young adults, marking the largest annual decline for any age group since the CDC began collecting data in 1997.

The study's author, Matthew Broaddus, a research analyst at the liberal Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, attributes the increased coverage for young people to a provision in the Affordable Care Act (ACA) that allows children to remain on their parents' insurance policies until they turn 26. Joseph Antos, a health care policy expert at the conservative American Enterprise Institute, concurs, stating that the ACA provision is the only plausible explanation for the increase.

According to the data from the federal study, known as the National Health Interview Survey, the share of people aged 19 to 25 who lacked health insurance fell to 27.9%, down from 33.9% in 2010. This represents about 1.6 million fewer uninsured individuals in this age group. For the next age group, those aged 26 to 35, the share of the uninsured rose, further indicating that the health care law may be driving the decline among the younger group.

The dependents' provision of the health care law took effect in September 2010, and the number of uninsured young adults decreased that year as well, though by a smaller amount. Obama administration officials have pointed to this drop as evidence that the law, which was broadly opposed by Republicans, is having an effect.

Title: Democratic Candidates Criticize Profit-Driven Enterprises During Debates

Article:

During the opening round of the Democratic presidential debates, several candidates expressed criticism towards profit-making enterprises, viewing them as a significant threat to the United States. Here is a compilation of instances where profit was demonized during the debates:

1. "We've had an industrial policy in the United States for decades now, and it's basically been let giant corporations do whatever they want to do. Giant corporations have exactly one loyalty, and that is to profits. And if they can save a nickel by moving a job to Mexico or to Asia or to Canada, they're going to do it."

2. "Health care—it's not just a human right, it should be an American right. And I believe the best way to get there is Medicare for All. But I have an urgency about this. When I am president of the United States, I'm not going to wait. We have to do the things immediately that are going to provide better care. And on this debate, I'm sorry. There are too many people profiteering off of the pain of people in America, from pharmaceutical companies to insurers."

3. "The insurance companies last year alone sucked $23 billion in profits out of the health care system, $23 billion. And that does not count the money that was paid to executives, the money that was spent lobbying Washington."

4. "I have been to some of the largest private prisons, which are repugnant to me that people are profiting off incarceration, and their immigration lockups."

5. "The debate we're having in our party right now is confusing, because the truth is there's a big difference between capitalism on the one hand and greed on the other. And so all the things that we're trying to change is when companies care more about profits when they do about people."

6. "I believe we need to get to universal health care as a right and not a privilege to single payer. The quickest way you get there is you create competition with the insurers. God bless the insurers, if they want to compete, they can certainly try, but they've never put people over their profits, and I doubt they ever will."

7. "Let's be clear. Let us be very clear. The function of health care today from the insurance and drug company perspective is not to provide quality care to all in a cost-effective way. The function of the health care system today is to make billions in profits for the insurance companies."

8. "We will have Medicare for all when tens of millions of people are prepared to stand up and tell the insurance companies and the drug companies that their day is gone, that health care is a human right, not something to make huge profits off of."

Title: Democrats' Reactions to Trump's Policies Compared to Obama's Executive Actions

Article:

The article discusses the contrasting reactions of the Democratic party to the policies of President Donald Trump and his predecessor, President Barack Obama. The author argues that Democrats have shown a tendency to forget or downplay Obama's executive actions, particularly in areas such as immigration, foreign policy, and congressional subpoenas, while criticizing similar actions taken by President Trump.

The article cites examples of this phenomenon, such as the Democrats' criticism of Trump's immigration policies, which they claim are draconian, despite the fact that Obama deported more immigrants during his presidency. The article also mentions the construction of cages on the southern border, which the Democrats attribute to Trump, but were actually built during Obama's administration.

In terms of congressional subpoenas, the article points out that Obama's Attorney General, Eric Holder, was held in contempt of Congress for defying subpoenas, while Democrats have criticized Trump for doing the same. The article also mentions at least eight other instances of Obama's administration defying congressional oversight.

The article also compares the reactions of the two parties to the assassination of Iranian military leader Qassem Soleimani. While Democrats have criticized Trump for authorizing the drone strike without their notification or consent, the article notes that Obama authorized at least 2,800 drone strikes in Iraq and Syria without congressional approval.

The article concludes by stating that the Democrats' reactions to Trump's policies will likely cost them in the upcoming election, both in terms of foreign policy and the economy. The author also notes that the Democrats' reactions to Trump's actions are in stark contrast to their praise of Obama's policies in the past, such as the killing of Osama bin Laden.

The article does not express an opinion on the merits of the policies in question, but rather presents the contrasting reactions of the two parties as a phenomenon worth noting. The author does not take a side in the political debate, but rather presents the facts as they are.

Title: Moms Demand Action Calls for Removal of Billboard Depicting Firearms as American Symbols

Article:

Moms Demand Action for Gun Sense, a gun-control advocacy group funded by New York City billionaire Mike Bloomberg, has called for the removal of a billboard in several cities, including Chicago, that depicts "assault rifles" as being as American as apple pie and baseball. The ad, for firearms parts manufacturer Slide Fire, based in Texas, features the slogan "Pure American" under three photos of a baseball glove, a pie, and an AR-type rifle.

Nicole Chen, the head of the gun-control group's Illinois chapter, expressed her disapproval, stating, "I was shocked that the ad removes'mom' from the idiom 'as American as baseball, apple pie, and mom,' and replaces it with an assault rifle." She added, "It's particularly upsetting that children in Chicago, a city that has struggled horribly with gun violence, are being exposed to such a harmful message."

Slide Fire deliberately chose Chicago for one of its billboards due to the city's high crime rate and extremely restrictive gun-control laws. Laura Shackelford, the chief executive manager of Slide Fire, explained, "Chicago is the number one place in the country that shows gun laws don't work." She continued, "We specifically put the ad up there to show that a firearm is normal Americana. We have to stop allowing a small group of anti-gun people to dictate how we think about guns."

The term "assault rifle" is often misused by anti-gun groups to describe any rifle with certain ergonomic features. In this context, the term refers to a fully automatic weapon that shoots ammunition as long as the trigger is pulled. However, the ad in question depicts a modern sporting rifle, which is not an "assault rifle" by definition.

Slide Fire manufactures the Slide Stock, a replacement stock on a rifle that allows for faster shooting through a technique known as "bump firing." The feature has been controversial due to claims that it converts a semi-automatic gun into an automatic one. However, the gun owner must still pull the trigger each time to release one round and use a complicated physical technique to shoot faster. The ATF has approved the feature for manufacture and sale.

Ms. Shackelford emphasized that the "Pure American" campaign is about promoting Second Amendment rights more than their product. She stated, "We are all law-abiding citizens who are sick of being told that it's abnormal or scary to own a firearm. These gun-control groups are not making anyone safer, but just stoking irrational fears of the unknown."

She further pointed out that guns are older than either baseball or apple pies as symbols of America. "Firearms are the reason we are American citizens today," she said. "And it's why the Constitution includes the Second Amendment."

Lawrence Keane, general counsel of the National Shooting Sports Foundation, which represents firearms manufacturers, also weighed in, stating, "The modern sporting rifle depicted is by definition not an 'assault rifle.' We wish anti-gun groups wouldn't purposely mislead the public when they exercise their right to free speech."

Emily Miller, senior editor of opinion for The ███ and author of "Emily Gets Her Gun" (Regnery, 2013), added her perspective on the matter.

Title: Military Rights Group Calls for Removal of Nazi Symbols from German POW Graves in U.S. National Cemetery

Article:

A nonprofit organization, the Military Religious Freedom Foundation (MRFF), has requested the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) to remove marble headstones inscribed with Nazi iconography and a phrase honoring Adolf Hitler at the graves of two German prisoners of war (POWs) in the Fort Sam Houston National Cemetery in San Antonio. The headstones bear the soldiers' names, dates of birth and death, a swastika within an iron cross - an award for valor - and the phrase, "He died far from his home for the Führer, people and fatherland."

Mikey Weinstein, chair of the MRFF, was informed about the headstones by a former active duty senior officer in the U.S. military. Weinstein, who is Jewish, shared photographs of the headstones with the media and wrote a letter to Secretary of Veterans Affairs Robert Wilkie, demanding that the department "immediately replace the gravestones of all German military personnel interred in V.A. National Cemeteries" and ensure that no Nazi-era symbols remain in U.S. military graveyards.

The Fort Sam Houston National Cemetery, which houses 133,154 American veterans, spouses, or their children, has 140 POWs from World War II buried in its "Section Z," with 132 being German. By the end of World War II, nearly half a million Axis prisoners of war were transferred to about 700 camps in the U.S., with the majority being repatriated at the end of the war. POWs who died in the U.S. were often buried at their prisons and reinterred in national cemeteries when camps shut down.

It is unclear why the remains of these two POWs, who died in 1943, were not repatriated nor why their gravestones were inscribed with Nazi iconography and given military distinction. The VA routinely changes out headstones if appropriately requested, such as for errors in spelling or dates. The military also keeps a registry of Available Emblems of Belief for Placement on Government Headstones and Markers, and neither the iron cross nor the swastika appear on the official list.

The former military officer who shared the photos, who is Jewish, saw the headstones when he was paying respects to his grandfather, an ambulance driver who fought against the Germans in World War II. His father was also enlisted, and his uncle and aunt are both buried at the same cemetery. "There are Nazis here today, and they could gather around these symbols. You know, 'Here are the martyrs that died for our cause,'" he told the media. "It's an outrage."

The VA National Cemetery Administration (NCA) has stated that it will continue to preserve these headstones, like every past administration has. It is not immediately clear whether any past administration has fielded a similar call to remove the headstones. The VA did not respond to requests for comment.

Historical records show that the POWs were buried in Section Z starting in 1947, according to a 2012 article about the cemetery in a local San Antonio publication. The cemetery is also home to four Italian, three Japanese, and one Austrian POWs. The remains of these POWs were buried in Section Z, which was as far from the active part of the cemetery as possible when they were first buried, but as the cemetery expanded, their graves are now in the geographic center.

The VA has not issued a statement regarding the removal of the headstones or an apology for their presence in the cemetery. The MRFF is now calling on the VA to apologize and explain why it has used taxpayer money to maintain the gravestones.

Title: Millennials' Economic Struggles and the American Dream: A Look at Work, Investment, and Wealth

Article:

Recent polling indicates a significant majority of Americans believe it will be more challenging for millennials to achieve the American Dream of economic advancement. This article examines the early indicators of young people's economic status and their financial habits.

One concerning trend is the declining labor force participation rate among individuals aged 18 to 24. The current rate is near a 50-year low, at 65 percent. This means that if you are 22 and not working, you are dependent, not independent. Moreover, over half of 18- to 23-year-olds live with their parents, leading to questions about when they might leave home.

Another troubling trend is the low rate of stock market participation among young people. According to the latest data from the Federal Reserve, only 7 percent of households headed by those under 35 years old directly own stock. This is a significant decrease compared to the 30 percent recorded in 1963 when the survey was first conducted.

The decline in stock market participation is not unique to the younger generation, as it has fallen for nearly every age group over the past decade. However, this is ironic given that since 2008, the stock market indexes have more than doubled. Many sold during the 2008 panic and have yet to re-enter the market.

Investing should be a long-term strategy for young people, as the dollar invested at a young age is likely to be worth significantly more after accounting for inflation by the time one reaches retirement age. The average real rate of return of stocks since the late-19th century has been 6 percent, which would make $1 invested at age 18 worth more than $15 at age 65. With a real return of 9 percent per year, each $1 grows to more than $50 during those 47 years.

There are several reasons for the low investment rates among young people. One reason is the lingering psychological trauma of the 2001 tech and 2008 broad market collapses. Another issue is the high levels of student loan debt, which leaves many young people unable to save and only able to pay off their debts.

Perhaps the most significant problem for young workers is the Federal Insurance Contributions Act (FICA) payroll tax, which intercepts more than 12 percent of their paychecks. After paying these taxes, many young workers have little disposable income left to invest after covering necessities. Worse, the young do not receive a return on this money, as the government spends it as soon as it is received.

Economist Peter Ferrara of the Heartland Institute argues in his new book, "Power to the People," that the average-income young American would have a nest egg of well over $1 million if they invested their payroll tax dollars in an index fund of all stocks. This would eliminate the retirement crisis for millennials and create a retirement bonanza instead.

According to Ferrara, the average two-earner household earns about 1 percent per year on the FICA taxes they pay given the benefits they are scheduled to receive. A lifetime single worker, however, gets a significantly lower return of less than 0.5 percent. These workers would be nearly better off stashing their payroll tax dollars under a mattress.

America should aim to give every worker a piece of the economic pie and allow them to share in the returns to capital. The left's new narrative is that equity returns rise faster than wages. If this is true, it is essential to allow more poor and middle-class workers to own more equities.

If only the wealthiest top 10 percent of Americans own stock directly, the wealth gap between rich and poor is likely to widen. Economist David Malpass points out in a recent wealth analysis that the value of all U.S. household assets is $99 trillion, up more than 5 percent over the last year. However, he also finds that "most of this wealth is concentrated with the wealthy," and this is in part because the middle class and young have dropped out of the market.

In conclusion, it is crucial for millennials to start investing early and regularly to build wealth and capital over time. The wise ones will get started immediately by setting aside $100 a month for investing in their and America's future.

Title: Trump Transition Team Accuses Special Counsel of Unlawfully Obtaining Emails

Article:

WASHINGTON - The organization responsible for U.S. President Donald Trump's transition to the White House, Trump for America, Inc. (TFA), has accused the Special Counsel Robert Mueller's team of unlawfully obtaining tens of thousands of emails during the investigation into allegations of Russian meddling in the 2016 election.

In a letter to congressional committees, Kory Langhofer, counsel to TFA, stated that career staff members at the General Services Administration (GSA), a government agency, had unlawfully produced TFA's private materials, including privileged communications, to Mueller's office.

The materials, according to the letter, included "tens of thousands of emails." The Trump team used facilities of the GSA, which helps manage the U.S. government bureaucracy, during the period between Trump's November presidential election victory and his inauguration in January.

The Trump team's accusation adds to the growing friction between the president's supporters and Mueller's office as it investigates whether Russia interfered in the election and if Trump or anyone on his team colluded with Moscow.

White House spokeswoman Sarah Sanders said, "We continue to cooperate fully with the special counsel and expect this process to wrap up soon."

The special counsel's office dismissed the transition team's complaint. "When we have obtained emails in the course of our ongoing criminal investigation, we have secured either the account owner's consent or appropriate criminal process," said Peter Carr, spokesman for the special counsel's office.

The GSA did not respond immediately to a request for comment.

Democrats say there is a wide-ranging effort by the president's allies on Capitol Hill and in some media outlets to discredit Mueller's investigation. Trump himself has declared Mueller's effort a waste of time, stating, "There is absolutely no collusion. That has been proven."

On Friday, Representative Adam Schiff, the top Democrat on the House of Representatives Intelligence Committee, expressed concerns that the committee's Republican majority intends to prematurely close its investigation of the topic. Some Republicans have argued that Mueller is biased against Trump and should be fired.

Langhofer's letter was sent to the U.S. Senate Committee on Homeland Security and Government Affairs, and the U.S. House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform. It asked Congress to act immediately "to protect future presidential transitions from having their private records misappropriated by government agencies, particularly in the context of sensitive investigations intersecting with political motives."

The letter stated that Mueller's office obtained the emails despite the fact that it was aware the GSA did not own or control the records. It also said the special counsel's office has "extensively used the materials in question, including portions that are susceptible to claims of privilege" without notifying the Trump for America team.

The transition team included a number of aides who were later caught up in Mueller's investigation, such as former national security adviser Michael Flynn, who pleaded guilty this month to lying to the FBI about his contacts with Russia.

Langhofer, the Trump transition team lawyer, wrote in his letter that the GSA's transfer of materials was discovered on Dec. 12 and 13. The FBI had requested the materials from GSA staff on Aug. 23, asking for copies of the emails, laptops, cell phones, and other materials associated with nine members of the Trump transition team responsible for national security and policy matters, the letter said. The FBI requested materials of four additional senior members of the Trump transition team on Aug. 30, it added.

Langhofer argued that, while such transition teams are involved in executive functions, they are considered private, non-profit organizations whose records are private and not subject to presidential records laws.

Title: Nevada and Idaho Halt Same-sex Marriage Licenses Amid Conflicting Court Decisions

Article:

County clerks in Nevada and Idaho declined to issue marriage licenses to same-sex couples on Wednesday, following a series of conflicting court decisions. A U.S. Supreme Court ruling temporarily blocked partners in Idaho from obtaining marriage licenses, while a 9th Circuit Court ruling cleared the way for Idaho and Nevada to issue such licenses. However, a stay by Justice Anthony Kennedy halted the process in both states.

In Nevada, couples gathered at courthouses early in anticipation of receiving marriage licenses, but were ultimately turned away. Mary Baranovich, a plaintiff in a Nevada court challenge to the state's gay marriage ban, expressed disappointment, stating, "I think I have whiplash."

In Idaho, hopeful couples also gathered at courthouses, but were informed that they would not be issuing same-sex marriage licenses that day. Amber Beierle, one of the disappointed couples, shared her experience, "We were past the metal detectors, we were just a few feet away from the clerk, and then our attorney was handed a one-page document. Apparently, it was Justice Kennedy telling us, No."

In South Carolina, a judge issued a license for a handful of gay couples, but no marriages took place due to a state attorney general's request for a stay from the Supreme Court.

In Las Vegas, wedding chapels prepared for same-sex weddings, with photographers and Elvis impersonators on standby. However, no marriages occurred, as Clark County Clerk Diana Alba announced that no marriage licenses would be issued in Nevada on Wednesday, and she was uncertain when they might begin.

Tara Traynor and her fiancée, Cathy Grimes, were among the couples waiting for a legal approval to obtain a marriage license in Nevada. They had been together for eight years and were among the first couples to register as domestic partners in the state. "It's kind of disheartening," Traynor said. "We wait and wait, and we're hopeful."

The Supreme Court's Monday decision effectively made gay marriage legal in about 30 states, but the how and when that would happen remains uncertain.

Title: Andrew Gillum Concedes Florida Governor Race to Ron DeSantis

Article:

Andrew Gillum, the Democratic candidate for Florida governor, officially conceded the race to Republican Ron DeSantis on Saturday night in a video posted to his Facebook page. Gillum, the mayor of Tallahassee, stood with his wife R. Jai and thanked his supporters.

"R. Jai and I wanted to take a moment to congratulate Mr. DeSantis on becoming the next governor of the great state of Florida," Gillum said.

The race went to a legally required recount, but after an initial machine recount, DeSantis still led Gillum by more than 30,000 votes. More than 8 million ballots went to a machine recount that ended Thursday afternoon. The final tally was 4,075,445 for DeSantis and 4,041,762 for Gillum.

Gillum said he and his wife wanted to ensure every vote had been counted, including those that were undervotes and overvotes.

"We wanted to make sure that every vote, including those that were undervotes and overvotes—as long as it was a legally cast vote—we wanted those votes to be counted," he said.

Losing the race for the governor's mansion does not mean Gillum will stop working on behalf of Florida voters. He will end his four-year term as Tallahassee mayor later this month but said he would fight to update the state election system and advocate for the issues that matter to him and the more than 4 million people who voted for him.

"We also want you to know that even though this election may be beyond us, that this—although nobody wanted to be governor more than me—this was not just about an election cycle," he said. "This was about creating the kind of change in this state that really allows for the voices of everyday people to show up again in our government, our state, and our communities."

President Donald Trump offered praise on Twitter for Gillum, whom he had frequently attacked leading up to Election Day.

"Congratulations to Andrew Gillum on having run a really tough and competitive race for Governor of the Great State of Florida," Trump tweeted. "He will be a strong Democrat warrior long into the future—a force to reckon with!"

Gillum said he has no plans of stepping out of the spotlight completely.

"Stay tuned. There is more to come," he said. "The fight for Florida continues."

Contributing: The Associated Press. Follow Ashley White on Twitter: @AshleyyDi.

Title: Crossroads GPS Releases "ObamaCareNado" Video Criticizing Affordable Care Act

Article:

In a move that combines political criticism with popular culture, the Karl Rove-backed Crossroads GPS has released a new online attack video titled "ObamaCareNado." The video, which parodies the SyFy network's television series "Sharknado," portrays the Affordable Care Act as a destructive tornado.

The 47-second video, described as a "trailer," features scenes of tornadoes ripping through scenery and people, with the faces of Crossroads GPS's primary targets, including House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi, Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid, and President Barack Obama, interspersed throughout. The video's narrator warns, "Just when you thought it was safe to go to the doctor, a rising tide of health care costs."

Crossroads GPS, one of the largest conservative political groups, has been known for its aggressive approach to political issues, including immigration reform and student loans. The organization spent $176 million in the 2012 federal elections, according to OpenSecrets.org.

Meanwhile, Republicans in the House of Representatives have also been actively criticizing Obamacare, passing two bills on Wednesday night that aim to postpone the individual and business mandates of the Affordable Care Act. However, these bills are not expected to progress in the Democratic-controlled Senate.

The release of the "ObamaCareNado" video coincides with President Obama's Thursday morning speech, where he highlighted the success of the Affordable Care Act. He stated, "Affordable health care is not some privilege just for the few. It's a basic right that everybody should be able to enjoy so we're going to keep fighting to secure that right to make sure that every American gets the care that they need when they need it at a price they can afford."

On Wednesday, a study was released predicting a 50% drop in health care prices for New York residents when the health care law takes effect next year.

Title: "Public Response to Jesse Jackson Jr.'s Corruption Case Mixed: Morning Joe Expresses Sorrow, Sparking Debate"

Article:

The fallout from the corruption case involving former Congressman Jesse Jackson Jr. has sparked a debate, with some expressing sympathy and others condemnation. In a segment on the political talk show 'Morning Joe,' the hosts expressed sadness over Jackson Jr.'s downfall, a sentiment that has been met with criticism from some observers.

Jazz Shaw, a political commentator, summarized the criticism in a post on his website:

"At what point did this become a'sad story' exactly?" Shaw wrote. "The criminal was caught and brought to justice. The system worked. Aren't we generally happy about that?"

Jackson Jr. was found guilty of misusing over $750,000 in campaign funds for personal expenses, including luxury items such as a $43,000 Rolex watch. The former congressman represented a district with a significant number of residents living below the poverty level.

Shaw continued, "This guy stole nearly a million dollars from the people of his district. Was anybody'sad' when Bernie Madoff got caught? Was anyone praying for 'a new chapter' in Madoff's life where he would 'turn things around?'"

The hosts of 'Morning Joe' argued that Jackson Jr. deserved sympathy due to his struggles with bipolar disorder and the impact his conviction would have on his family. However, Shaw and others argue that Jackson Jr.'s actions were a betrayal of the public trust and that Americans should be celebrating his conviction, not lamenting his downfall.

Alexander Hamilton, in The Federalist Papers, wrote that "a dangerous ambition more often lurks behind the specious mask of zeal for the rights of the people than under the forbidding appearance of zeal for the firmness and efficiency of government." In other words, corrupt politicians like Jesse Jackson Jr. will always exist in public life, and it is the responsibility of citizens to hold them accountable.

The controversy surrounding Jackson Jr.'s case highlights the ongoing challenge of maintaining trust in government and the importance of holding elected officials accountable for their actions.

Title: North Carolina Primary Highlights Establishment vs. Tea Party, American Idol Runner-up's Bid, and Other Key Races

Article:

The primary season is in full swing as North Carolina, Ohio, and Indiana hold primaries today. Twenty-five states will hold primaries in the next six weeks, with today's key race taking place in North Carolina, where the establishment GOP and the Tea Party are engaged in a fierce battle. This contest is seen as a potential 2016 proxy fight between Jeb Bush, Rand Paul, and Mike Huckabee.

Several colorful candidates are on the ballot today. In North Carolina, the Republican Senate primary pits Thom Tillis, the establishment candidate backed by Jeb Bush and Mitt Romney, against Greg Brannon, a Tea Party and libertarian favorite. Mark Harris, an Evangelical candidate who has galvanized social conservatives, is also in the race, having been backed by Mike Huckabee. Candidates must receive 40 percent of the vote to avoid a July 15 run-off. Polls show Tillis leading with Brannon in second, but with Tillis just barely clearing the 40 percent mark.

In the Democratic primary, American Idol 2003 runner-up Clay Aiken is facing off against businessman Keith Crisco and Toni Morris. There has been no public polling in this race, making it difficult to predict the outcome. Aiken has been outspent by Crisco and has run only one television ad compared to Crisco's four.

In the 3rd Congressional District of North Carolina, Rep. Walter Jones is being challenged from the right by GOP consultant and former aide to President George W. Bush and the McCain campaign, Taylor Griffin. Jones is well known for voting for the Iraq war and becoming one of the most vocal members of the GOP against it. Griffin is seen as more conservative than Jones due to his foreign policy views, while Jones has tried to portray Griffin as a "Washington insider."

House Speaker John Boehner is facing two challengers, despite being heavily favored to win. He is facing Eric Gurr, a computer consultant, and J.D. Winteregg, a high school French teacher. Boehner will win, but he is facing challengers and some outside money being thrown at him. Winteregg has gained publicity for himself by releasing an online parody video in the style of the drug Cialis. The video was a not-so-subtle spin on the speaker's first name and claimed Winteregg offers the remedy for "electile dysfunction" personified by Boehner. Winteregg was dismissed from an adjunct teaching position at Cedarville University, a Christian college, after the suggestive video aired. The Tea Party Leadership Fund has spent about $325,000 on behalf of Winteregg and against Boehner.

In Indiana, there are no exciting races this time around, as neither of the state's senators are on the ballot, and all nine House incumbents are seeking re-election, making it a relatively uneventful primary.

Today's primary election in North Carolina will be the first time voters go to the polls since the state's new voting law was passed in August by the state's GOP governor and legislature. Today may not prove to be a true test of the law because turnout is usually low in primary contests and the highest-profile requirement of the new law, having to show government-issued ID at the polls, does not go into effect until 2016. However, voting rights advocates will still be keeping an eye on some of the law's provisions, such as a ban on same-day registration and restrictions on early voting.

Title: Media's Decline: A Look at the Shift in Information Landscape

Article:

The current media landscape is experiencing a significant shift, as traditional media outlets are facing a decline in relevance and influence. This change is attributed to two primary factors: the growing public disillusionment with the media elite and the advent of technology that allows individuals to bypass traditional media gatekeepers.

The disillusionment stems from the public's perception of media outlets as biased and unreliable. Many individuals feel that traditional media outlets have been lying to them and distorting the news, leading to a loss of trust and a desire for alternative sources of information.

The technology revolution has provided an avenue for bypassing traditional media outlets. Social media platforms, online news sources, and other digital mediums have emerged as viable alternatives, offering unfiltered news and information directly to the public. This shift has led to a decline in the influence and power of traditional media outlets, as they are increasingly being ignored by the public.

The decline in relevance is particularly evident in the case of Donald Trump. Despite the media's efforts to discredit him, Trump remains popular, and his opponents, including Hillary Clinton, have not been able to match his appeal. This has led to a sense of frustration and desperation among media outlets, as they struggle to maintain their influence and control the narrative.

Traditional media outlets have also been criticized for their lack of objectivity. In the past, they claimed to be impartial, but many individuals feel that they have abandoned this pretense in favor of promoting their own ideologies. This shift has further eroded public trust in traditional media outlets, as they are seen as biased and unreliable.

The decline in the influence and power of traditional media outlets is a significant shift in the information landscape. As technology continues to evolve, it is likely that this trend will continue, with individuals increasingly turning to alternative sources of information and bypassing traditional media gatekeepers. This shift has far-reaching implications for the future of journalism and the role of media in society.

Title: The Impact of Election Outcomes on Policy Agenda: A Look at the 1964 and 2016 Elections

Article:

A divide among some American progressive groups, particularly those associated with labor unions and economic populism, is growing as the 2016 presidential election approaches. The concern is that Donald Trump, due to his perceived vulnerabilities, may prompt Hillary Clinton to run a campaign that focuses primarily on policy matters minimally, instead opting for a landslide victory that would carry no mandate.

Conversely, David Frum, a center-right Republican dissident writing in The Atlantic, expresses a contrasting worry. He suggests that Clinton faces a challenge similar to neither Johnson nor Nixon in 1964 or 1972, the challenge of a divided party that may push her to lean left to retain the support of Bernie Sanders' supporters.

Frum cites Lyndon B. Johnson's 1964 convention speech as an example of the rhetoric Clinton should, but likely cannot, employ. Johnson's speech emphasized the Democratic Party as a unifying force for all Americans, eschewing partisan politics and prejudice.

The 1964 election, however, demonstrates that this choice may be a false one. Johnson attempted to run a campaign focused on portraying his opponent, Barry Goldwater, as an unacceptable outlier, but the election resulted in a landslide victory for Johnson and historic majorities for the Democrats in the House and Senate. This, in turn, led to a burst of progressive legislation in 1965-'66 that is considered one of the biggest legislative leaps forward in American history.

The reality is that the amount of progressive legislation a candidate can enact is largely dependent on the shape of Congress rather than the content of their platform. Clinton does not have a realistic chance of securing large Democratic majorities. The House districts are heavily tilted, making a narrow majority a steep uphill fight, and any Democratic majority would rely heavily on relatively moderate members holding Republican-leaning districts.

Even a small Democratic majority reliant on moderate legislators would pass more progressive legislation, such as raising the minimum wage, increasing taxes, and expanding Medicaid funding, than a Republican majority. The success of Democrats in securing such a majority will be a significant factor in determining policy outcomes, rather than whatever liberal causes Clinton may pay lip service to.

The shape of House districts, therefore, suggests that Democrats' hopes of securing such a majority depend on either swinging Republicans over to their side or else demoralizing Republicans and getting them to stay home altogether. This, in turn, reinforces the pattern established by Lyndon B. Johnson in 1964: The choice between reassuring the center and laying the groundwork for policy on issues is a false one.

Title: House Republican Leaders Unveil Tax-Increase Proposal, Drawing Mixed Reactions from Conservatives

Article:

In a move that breaks with traditional Republican orthodoxy, House Republican leaders have proposed a deficit reduction package that includes increased taxes for wealthier Americans as part of an effort to avoid the fiscal cliff. The proposal, which is part of a $2.2 trillion deficit reduction package, has drawn criticism from some conservative lawmakers, but top Senate Republicans have been cautious in their response.

The tax-increase proposal aims to raise new revenue by eliminating unspecified deductions and other loopholes from the tax code. While it does not call for an increase in tax rates, it has been met with criticism from conservatives like Sen. Jim DeMint (R-South Carolina), who described it as an $800 billion tax hike that would destroy jobs and allow for more spending in Washington. Sen. Rand Paul (R-Kentucky) also voiced opposition, stating that raising taxes would "cripple the economy."

Senate Republican Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Kentucky) declined to endorse the plan directly when asked about it at a press conference, instead commending the House Republican leadership for moving the process along and expressing hope that a real discussion could take place. Sen. John Thune (R-South Dakota) and Sen. Roy Blunt (R-Missouri) also expressed support for the plan as a good faith effort that should be taken seriously by the White House.

Sen. Charles Grassley (R-Iowa), a senior Republican on the Finance Committee, was one of the few GOP senators who expressed support for the plan, but only if there is a "willingness on the part of Democrats to accept spending cuts that are three to one or four to one."

Conservative groups like Americans for Prosperity and Heritage Action for America have also criticized the plan, with the latter urging supporters to contact their members of Congress and oppose the compromise.

House Republican aides argue that the criticism from the right demonstrates that the proposal is a serious and credible offer, and that the president is not meeting the same level of criticism because he is proposing a "Christmas list for the left." The aides also believe that if the White House does not show movement, it indicates that the president agrees with liberals that going off the fiscal cliff is not a significant concern.

The entire House GOP leadership team, including House Speaker John Boehner and House Budget Committee Chairman Paul Ryan, signed onto the Republican counter offer on Monday. Freshman Georgia Republican Rep. Austin Scott praised the show of unity and expressed a desire to see a deal that reduces the debt more, but still needs to see the final cost of the House Republican plan.

Despite the criticism from some conservatives, House GOP aides recognize that they are likely to lose votes from conservatives if they are able to reach a final deal with the White House, but are working closely to keep their message consistent. They are also pressing the administration to engage and show what kind of cuts to entitlement programs Obama could accept.

Title: Former Rhode Island Governor Lincoln Chafee Ends Long-Shot Presidential Bid

Article:

Former Rhode Island Governor Lincoln Chafee, a Democrat, announced the end of his presidential bid on Friday at the Democratic National Committee Women's Leadership Forum. Chafee, who was a Republican, independent, and then a Democrat, is the second candidate to withdraw from the race this week, following former Virginia Senator Jim Webb's announcement on Tuesday.

Chafee, a member of a prominent political family in Rhode Island, had struggled to make any significant impact in the race. He raised only $8,300 from 10 major donors during the last quarter, and his few supporters told NPR this week they appreciated the positive attitude he brought to the race.

Chafee's performance in last week's presidential debate was unremarkable, speaking for just nine minutes during the two-hour faceoff. He emphasized his anti-war stance, contrasting it with front-runner Hillary Clinton's controversial 2002 vote in favor of the Iraq War.

In his withdrawal announcement, Chafee reiterated his peace-focused platform, stating, "The United States of America is so strong militarily, economically, and culturally that we can take chances for peace. In fact, as a strong mature world leader, we must take chances for peace."

Chafee's campaign had been marked by several missteps, including his response to a question about his vote to repeal banking regulations known as the Glass-Steagall Act, which many saw as evidence of his unpreparedness. His sparsely attended announcement in June, during which he advocated for the U.S. to switch to the metric system, was also widely panned.

Before entering politics, Chafee had an interesting life. He attended an exclusive Northeastern prep school, where he was a classmate of former Florida Governor Jeb Bush. After graduating from Brown University, he went on to learn to be a farrier, someone who shoes horses, and traveled around the U.S. working at racetracks.

Title: New Hampshire Senator Kelly Ayotte Defends Vote Against Expanded Background Checks, Faces Criticism

Article:

New Hampshire Senator Kelly Ayotte, a Republican, has come under fire for voting against a bill aimed at expanding background checks on gun purchases. In response, Ayotte published an op-ed on Monday to clarify her stance on the issue.

In the op-ed, Ayotte stated that outside groups are running false advertisements against her, accusing her of not supporting measures to prevent gun-related violence. Ayotte affirmed her support for effective background checks, citing her recent vote to improve the National Instant Criminal Background Check System (NICS).

The controversy stems from Ayotte's vote against a compromise bill proposed by Senators Joe Manchin (D-W.Va.) and Pat Toomey (R-Pa.). This proposal would have mandated background checks for sales at gun shows and online transactions. Instead, Ayotte supported an alternative measure, written by Sen. Chuck Grassley (R-Iowa), which focused on encouraging states to submit mental health information to the background check database, without addressing gun shows and online sales.

Ayotte's poll numbers have dropped, and she has faced criticism from various groups, including Michael Bloomberg's Mayors Against Illegal Guns and former Rep. Gabrielle Giffords' Americans for Responsible Solutions, who have run ads in New Hampshire attacking her. The daughter of the principal at Sandy Hook Elementary School also confronted Ayotte at a town hall, an incident that garnered national media attention.

In response to Ayotte's op-ed, John Feinblatt, Chairman of Mayors Against Illegal Guns, stated, "In her op-ed, Senator Ayotte says that she voted to improve the existing background check system, but the bill she voted for (Grassley-Cruz) did just the opposite by narrowing the categories of mentally ill people who would be prohibited gun purchasers and potentially calling into question millions of names already in the system." Feinblatt further noted that the current background check system has blocked over two million dangerous people from buying guns.

Title: Emory University Hospital's Ebola Treatment: A 12-Year Preparation and a 3-Month Response

Article:

Atlanta's Emory University Hospital received the first call at the end of July, reporting an American doctor who had contracted Ebola while treating patients in Liberia. In just 72 hours, Dr. Kent Brantly would be admitted to Emory's doors, and almost immediately, the hospital learned that a second Ebola patient was also on the way.

The true cure for the Ebola virus is keeping the patient alive long enough to develop the antibodies that will help them recover from the infection. In the three months since, Emory has treated four Ebola patients, all of whom have survived. The most recent patient, Dallas nurse Amber Vinson, spent more than a week in a special treatment unit at Emory before being discharged in good health and spirits on Tuesday.

Dr. Bruce Ribner, who heads Emory's Ebola team, told reporters at a news conference Tuesday that the general dogma in the industry in July was that if patients became severely ill and required dialysis or ventilator support, such interventions would be ineffective, as the patients would invariably die. Emory, however, proved that aggressive treatment of the illness can be effective.

Emory's plan to treat patients with infectious diseases like Ebola began 12 years ago, when the Atlanta-based Centers for Disease Control and Prevention started working with the hospital to create a special isolation unit. Since then, a core team of health workers has trained yearly and held practice drills every six months to stay prepared for any infectious disease that may come their way.

In July, with two Ebola patients on the way, it quickly became clear that Emory's specially trained team was too small, says Nancye Feistritzer, the hospital's chief of nursing. Critical care nurses volunteered to help fill in the gaps but were not part of the core group that had long practiced for this day. The expanded team had to quickly train, and not everyone made the cut.

Once all the team members were in place, they focused on supportive care of these patients, administering IV fluids and preventing infections. "The true cure for Ebola virus is keeping the patient alive long enough to develop the antibodies that will cause them to get over the infection," Dr. Jay Varkey says.

Emory learned lessons, big and small, from each case. For example, increasing the amount of working space around patients sick with Ebola helped a lot, as did having a hand sanitizer dispenser available that wouldn't require a gloved hand to be touched. In Emory's experience, nurses on the Ebola unit, who started out on eight-hour shifts, preferred 12-hour rotations instead. Caring for the emotional health of patients in isolation is as important as promoting physical well-being, the staff learned.

Team members worked hard to coordinate their efforts, from top administrators to waste management crews, to pharmacists and lab technicians—every department played a role. "Every morning the team meets to discuss what worked well, what might be refined," Feistritzer says, looking for lessons that might be put into practice the next shift or the next day.

The Emory team does not claim to have all the right answers, Varkey says. But what they do know, they're sharing. "Our entire 84-page document, in terms of our protocols," he says, "is now available to any person who wants to access that on the Web." Those protocols went live a week ago. So far, more than 11,300 people have registered to get access to them.

This story is part of a reporting partnership between NPR, WABE, and Kaiser Health News.

Title: Houston Struggles with Looting, Curfew as Tropical Storm Harvey Causes Mass Evacuation and Billions in Damage

Article:

Houston, the fourth-largest city in the United States, is grappling with the aftermath of Tropical Storm Harvey, which made landfall near Corpus Christi on Friday. The storm, the most powerful to hit Texas in over 50 years, has resulted in at least 25 deaths, forced 30,000 people to seek shelter, and caused an estimated tens of billions of dollars in damage.

In response to the crisis, the Houston City Council has allocated $20 million from a rainy day fund for storm recovery efforts. However, officials anticipate that far more resources will be needed. Texas Governor Greg Abbott has suggested that the state may require federal relief totaling over $125 billion, surpassing the aid provided to Hurricane Katrina victims in 2005.

As of Wednesday morning, close to 49,000 homes in Texas have suffered flood damage, with over 1,000 destroyed. Thousands of other homes are threatened by two reservoirs swollen by as much as 52 inches (132 cm) of rain in some areas. Officials have ordered evacuations in several areas around levees or dams, but opted against calling for a mass evacuation to avoid potential chaos during the storm.

Looting and armed robberies have been reported in Houston, prompting a midnight to 5 a.m. curfew. At least 40 people have been arrested for looting, including one individual who allegedly drove a sport utility vehicle into a cash machine. Harris County District Attorney Kim Ogg has vowed to vigorously prosecute looters.

The George R. Brown Convention Center, which initially planned to house 5,000 people, has seen its population double due to the influx of evacuees from areas south and west of Houston. At least one man was arrested in the convention center for attempting to steal a cot and insulting police officers.

Two additional "mega" centers, the Toyota Center and NRG Park, were opened late Tuesday to accommodate more evacuees. As of Wednesday afternoon, about 8,000 people were taking shelter at the Houston convention center, with the population fluctuating as other centers open and some evacuees move on.

A long-term solution for the evacuees has yet to be formulated. "Right now we're just working in 12-hour increments," said Tom McCasland, director of Houston's housing and community development department and head of the convention center shelter.

Some have criticized the decision not to order a mass evacuation, but officials noted that a 2005 evacuation ahead of Hurricane Rita turned into a nightmare for many in Texas and Louisiana who became trapped in vehicles that ran out of fuel on congested roadways.

Area churches and aid organizations have donated clothing, bedding, and food for the evacuees. The Red Cross has brought at least 1,000 volunteers to staff the convention center and provided cots, blankets, and food for 34,000 across the region.

Houston Mayor Sylvester Turner has called on the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) to send cots, food, and other supplies, as well as to deploy staff directly into damaged communities, not just into shelters. "I can't think of one district where there are not tremendous needs," said Turner. "People are looking for results."

Title: Marco Rubio and Ted Cruz Release Tax Returns, Increasing Pressure on Donald Trump to Follow Suit

Article:

Republican presidential candidates Marco Rubio and Ted Cruz have released their tax returns, increasing pressure on rival Donald Trump to do the same. Rubio's tax returns, dating back to 2000, show his family's adjusted gross income was $335,561 in 2014, with a 19.3% tax rate. Cruz released 2010-2014 tax returns, reporting an adjusted gross income of $1.2 million in 2014, with a 32.22% tax rate.

Rubio's tax returns, available on his campaign website, indicate a significant increase in income from previous years. In 2012, the Rubios reported nearly $1 million in income. In 2000, their largest monthly expense was a payment to Sallie Mae, and they paid bills by mail, hoping payments wouldn't arrive before the next paycheck. Today, their only debt is their mortgage on their house.

Cruz, who previously released 2006-2010 tax returns during his Senate campaign, called for Trump to release his returns, stating, "It is time to stop the excuses." Cruz's statement continued, "Donald Trump owes it to the American people to be fully vetted, and that includes releasing his tax returns so the voters can see the full financial picture."

Trump faced criticism at Thursday's debate for not releasing his tax returns. When asked about the issue, Trump responded, "I will absolutely give my return, but I'm being audited now for two or three years, so I can't do it until the audit is finished, obviously."

An NPR fact check found that there is no law barring Trump from releasing his returns while being audited, though an accountant or lawyer may have advised him otherwise. The information regarding Trump's tax returns and any potential advice from his accountant or lawyer was not available in the provided source text.

Title: The Impact of Automation on American Jobs and Education

Article:

The ongoing debate about economic recovery in the United States has led to growing frustration among Americans, with good-paying jobs remaining scarce and family incomes down by approximately $1,650 during President Obama's tenure. This trend has been compared to the economic recovery periods under former presidents Ronald Reagan and Bill Clinton, where the annual growth of Gross Domestic Product (GDP) was 4.6 and 3.7 percent, respectively, compared to the current 2.2 percent under President Obama.

However, the article suggests that the lack of workers adequately trained for a more technologically demanding workplace is slowing growth, not the other way around. The article argues that automation has been a persistent theme throughout American history, with machines replacing workers in various industries, pushing them into more highly paid professions or less well-paid occupations.

The article points to the increasing role of robots in the workforce, with machines taking over tasks requiring subtle manual dexterity and complex cognitive processes. By 2030, it is predicted that 90 percent of jobs could be replaced by smart machines. The real challenge, according to the article, is training most Americans to engage in intellectually demanding and creative work, or risk being relegated to low-paying jobs better suited for androids.

The article also criticizes the state of education in the United States, with less than 40 percent of 12th graders being ready for college-level reading and math, and four in ten college graduates lacking the complex reasoning skills needed for white-collar work. The article suggests that the focus on sexism in education and the workplace, as well as the opposition to universal standards for more academic rigor like the Common Core, is misguided and detrimental to the future prosperity of the country.

The article is written by Peter Morici, an economist and business professor at the University of Maryland, and a national columnist. The article calls for a shift in focus from anger about false injustice or an omnipresent state to building and teaching the machines that will do the work that has burdened humanity since the first branch was shaped into a hunting implement. The article concludes by warning that without young people trained and encouraged to do sophisticated work, the locus of prosperity will permanently shift from America to Asia.

Title: Senate Leaders Prepare for Showdown Over Presidential Nominations

Article:

In a developing political standoff, the top Democrat in the Senate, Harry Reid, has vowed to proceed with a series of votes this week that could potentially alter Senate rules to expedite the confirmation of President Obama's executive branch and independent agency nominees. This move, known as the "nuclear option," could end the bipartisan cooperation that is crucial to the Senate's operations.

Sen. Reid aims to amend the rules to prevent Republicans from filibustering when President Obama nominates individuals for executive branch or independent agency positions, while maintaining the filibuster for judicial nominees. In an interview on NBC's "Meet the Press," Sen. Reid defended the proposed rule change, stating, "The changes we're making are very, very minimal. What we're doing is saying, 'Look, shouldn't President Obama have someone working for him that he wants?'"

Under this scenario, Sen. Reid would leverage the Democrats' majority in the Senate to overturn decades of precedent, effectively changing the rules when it comes to parliamentary procedure. This would establish that nonjudicial nominees are not subject to the same level of debate as bills.

Sen. Mitch McConnell, the Republican leader, countered that Democrats are seeking a fight where there is none. He argued that Senate Republicans have confirmed President Obama's picks at a faster rate than President George W. Bush's at the same point during his term, and that Republicans have not defeated any of the president's major executive nominees.

The tension between the two leaders is palpable, as they did not appear together during their interviews on NBC. Sen. Reid has scheduled seven potential filibuster votes for Tuesday morning, including nominations for the Labor Department secretary, Environmental Protection Agency administrator, three members of the National Labor Relations Board, president of the Export-Import Bank, and director of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau.

The question remains whether Sen. Reid would force a rules change if Republicans filibuster only some of these nominees. He has scheduled the three most controversial votes—for the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau and two of the NLRB picks—to be first, suggesting he is trying to pressure Republicans to relent.

Sen. McConnell stated that Republicans would allow most of the nominees, including those to whom they strongly object, such as Thomas E. Perez, the Labor secretary pick. However, the three main fights over the NLRB and CFPB nominees are more complex. When these nominees faced potential Republican blockades early last year, President Obama used his recess appointment powers to name them to their positions, but he did so at a time when the Senate did not consider itself in recess.

A federal appeals court has ruled that President Obama exceeded his authority with the NLRB appointment and invalidated one of the board's rulings, calling the rest into question. The Supreme Court is set to take up the case. Republicans argue that Sen. Reid is risking significant damage to the Senate institution in an attempt to save the NLRB from its precarious position.

Ahead of the showdown, each side has presented numbers to support their arguments. Republicans claim they have confirmed an exceptional number of President Obama's nominees, including every executive branch appointment that has reached the Senate floor. They assert that they have obstructed only a few judges who were outside of mainstream legal thought.

Democrats, on the other hand, argue that Republicans have used nominations as a means to attack President Obama's policies and the role of government. Sen. Reid stated, "They have nothing against the qualifications. They don't like the jobs these people have."

The filibuster is not part of Senate rules. It is a term applied when a single senator or group of senators wishes to prolong debate on an issue indefinitely. Some issues and motions, such as bringing a budget to the Senate floor, are considered nondebatable and cannot be filibustered, but most regular motions are debatable. It takes 60 votes to end debate, and a failed vote to cut off debate is considered a filibuster.

Title: White House Faces Controversies in Second Term, but Agenda Remains Focus

Article:

The White House is currently embroiled in several controversies, with some comparing the situation to previous presidents' scandals during their second terms. The past week has seen headlines of potential scandals, including the secret subpoena of journalists' phone records, the IRS targeting of conservative groups, misleading statements about the Benghazi terrorist attack, and others.

However, a rocky start to a second term does not necessarily mean the derailment of a president's goals or agenda. According to Howard Kurtz, the host of CNN's "Reliable Sources," presidents such as Ronald Reagan and Bill Clinton signed major fiscal legislation during their lame-duck terms.

White House spokesman Jay Carney insisted Tuesday that the controversies have little connection to President Barack Obama's second-term agenda. He stated that the president is focused on issues such as economic growth, expanded opportunities for the middle class, and immigration reform, as per the campaign promises made during his re-election last November.

One of the controversies in question is the secret subpoena of AP phone records. The Republican National Committee has called for Obama to demand Attorney General Eric Holder's resignation over the matter. If not, said RNC Chairman Reince Priebus, it will show that "the president of the United States believes his administration is above the Constitution and does not respect the role of a free press."

Another issue is the IRS political targeting, with Republican senators characterizing it as a broad abuse of power by the administration. The embattled Holder, who was cited for contempt of Congress during Obama's first term over the botched "Fast and Furious" gun walking program, also confirmed that he recused himself last year from his department's investigation of classified leaks that led to the recent secret subpoenas of telephone logs of The Associated Press.

The Benghazi issue has renewed GOP criticism of former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton, considered the likely Democratic frontrunner if she decides to run for president in 2016. The GOP accuses the administration of not bolstering security prior to the attack, of botching the response to it, and of misleading the public in its slow-to-evolve explanation of events less than two months before the November election.

Despite these controversies, the full details remain unknown, and they are certain to continue to dominate Washington in coming days. Carney spoke as Attorney General Eric Holder announced a Justice Department investigation of whether any laws were broken in the IRS political targeting. Congress is also looking into the matter, with a House committee hearing scheduled for Friday.

Title: House Passes Clean Debt Ceiling Bill, Relying on Democratic Support

Article:

In a 221-201 vote, the House of Representatives has passed a bill to lift the debt ceiling until March 2015, removing the threat of a default until after the November midterm election. The bill was supported by 193 Democrats and just 28 Republicans.

The bill's passage marks a reversal for Speaker John Boehner (R-Ohio), who, in 2011, stated that when Congress raises the debt limit, it should also enact budget cuts of equal or greater magnitude. The vote also signifies the House Republican Conference's inability to move beyond fiscal fights and highlights the leadership's inability or unwillingness to corral votes for their priorities.

All Republican leadership, including Boehner, Majority Leader Eric Cantor (R-Va.), and Majority Whip Kevin McCarthy (R-Calif.), voted for the bill. Other notable Republican supporters include Reps. Dave Camp (R-Mich.), Darrell Issa (R-Calif.), Peter King (R-N.Y.), Buck McKeon (R-Calif.), Devin Nunes (R-Calif.), and Peter Roskam (R-Ill.).

However, Rep. Paul Ryan (R-Wis.), a potential 2016 presidential candidate, voted against the bill. House Republican Conference Chairman Cathy McMorris Rodgers (R-Wash.), GOP Policy Chairman James Lankford (R-Okla.), and Rep. Greg Walden (R-Ore.), the chairman of the party's political arm, also voted against the bill.

The Senate could vote on the debt limit bill as early as Wednesday. Once the Senate clears the bill, Congress will not face a major fiscal decision until government funding runs dry on September 30.

White House Press Secretary Jay Carney called the House vote a "positive step in moving away from political brinkmanship."

Tuesday's vote was the culmination of a series of fits and starts over the last few weeks. Republicans considered attaching various policy provisions to the debt limit increase, such as changes to Obamacare, the Keystone XL pipeline, updates to the Medicare reimbursement rate, and reversals to recent military pension cuts. However, each time leadership floated a new policy, the rank and file rejected it.

On Tuesday morning, Boehner announced during a meeting at the Capitol Hill Club that he would seek to pass a clean debt limit increase. Boehner denied that it was a result of having less leverage after the October 2013 government shutdown.

"No, it's the fact that we don't have 218 votes," Boehner said. "And when you don't have 218 votes, you have nothing. We've seen that before, we see it again."

There was rancor within the rank and file and in leadership, where many wanted to dispense with the issue, especially since the GOP is gaining political momentum due to troubles with Obamacare. However, outside conservative groups, including the Club for Growth, called on Republicans to oppose the bill.

Boehner blamed President Barack Obama for the divisions within the House Republican Conference.

"You've all known that our members are not crazy about voting to increase the debt ceiling," Boehner said Tuesday morning. "Our members are also very upset with the president. He won't negotiate. He won't deal with our long-term spending problems without us raising taxes. He won't even sit down and discuss these issues. He's the one driving up the debt, and the question they're asking is, why should I deal with his debt limit?"

Title: U.S.-Germany Tensions Escalate over Alleged Surveillance of World Leaders

Article:

Tensions between the United States government and its allies, including Germany, have escalated following reports that the National Security Agency (NSA) may have monitored the phone calls of 35 world leaders, including German Chancellor Angela Merkel. The latest report in The Guardian suggests a secret memo reveals that the NSA encouraged top departments to share their contact lists to keep numbers for top foreign leaders in their surveillance systems. The document reportedly states that an official handed over 200 numbers, some of which covered 35 world leaders, though their identities remain unnamed.

Germany's government has already expressed outrage over the allegations that Merkel's cellphone may have been targeted. White House Press Secretary Jay Carney, while stating that the U.S. "is not monitoring and will not monitor" Merkel's communications, did not deny that such surveillance may have occurred in the past.

On Thursday, the German Foreign Ministry summoned U.S. Ambassador John B. Emerson for a meeting with Foreign Minister Guido Westerwelle. In a written statement, Westerwelle said he told the ambassador "it is unacceptable that the mobile phone of our Federal Chancellor may have been subject to surveillance activities by our American partners."

"For us, spying on close friends and partners is totally unacceptable. This undermines trust, and this can harm our friendship," the foreign minister said. "We need the truth now."

The latest incident is the latest in a series of flare-ups over reported surveillance that has involved France, Mexico, and Brazil. More damaging information could be on the horizon, as The Washington Post reported Friday that U.S. officials are telling some foreign intelligence agencies that NSA leaker Edward Snowden has documents detailing their cooperation with the United States.

France demanded explanations over a report that the U.S. swept up millions of French phone records and also summoned the American ambassador to demand an explanation. Germany, which has Europe's biggest economy, has been one of Washington's closest allies in Europe. The United States was West Germany's protector during the Cold War, and the country is still home to thousands of U.S. troops.

Carney said Wednesday that President Obama assured Merkel that "the United States is not monitoring and will not monitor the communications of the chancellor." The German government did not comment on Merkel's response to Obama's statement, but a prominent lawmaker with her party who heads Parliament's domestic affairs committee criticized Carney's statement.

"I think we are all outraged, across party lines," Wolfgang Bosbach told Deutschlandfunk radio. "And that also goes for the response that the chancellor's cellphone is not being monitored - because this sentence says nothing about whether the chancellor was monitored in the past."

"This can not be justified from any point of view by the fight against international terrorism or by averting danger," Bosbach said.

Merkel had previously raised concerns over allegations of mass electronic eavesdropping when Obama visited Germany in June, demanded answers from the U.S. government, and backed calls for greater European data protection. Her government is striking a markedly sharper tone now, and signaling frustration over the answers provided so far by the U.S. government.

Title: Supreme Court to Consider Same-sex Marriage Cases from Five States

Article:

The Supreme Court has scheduled same-sex marriage cases from Utah, Oklahoma, Virginia, Indiana, and Wisconsin for consideration at its private conference on Monday, indicating a willingness to engage in the ongoing national debate. The justices have the option to consider some or none of these cases, preferring to delay their decision until later in the fall.

By listing all five cases for consideration simultaneously, the justices have given equal consideration to the Indiana and Wisconsin cases, which were decided last month by the U.S. Court of Appeals for the 7th Circuit. The 10th and 4th Circuits previously ruled in the other cases.

The court could choose to hear one or more cases this winter, deny them all, or delay its decision for a while. In all five states, federal district and appellate judges have agreed that state bans on same-sex marriage should be struck down as unconstitutional. However, these decisions are on hold pending the Supreme Court's review.

Additional same-sex marriage cases could be added to the justices' list soon. A ruling is expected from the U.S. Court of Appeals for the 6th Circuit on cases from Ohio, Michigan, Kentucky, and Tennessee. The 9th Circuit heard oral arguments earlier this month in cases stemming from Idaho and Nevada. Cases from Texas and Florida remain at the appellate court level.

In June 2013, the Supreme Court ruled 5-4 that the federal government must recognize same-sex marriages legally performed in states that allow them. Since then, the number of states allowing same-sex marriage has grown to 19, along with the District of Columbia. The court also refused to overrule a California court's decision striking down that state's ban.

Thirty-one states continue to prohibit gays and lesbians from marrying, including all the states with cases pending before the Supreme Court. The justices are widely expected to rule this term on whether such bans are constitutional.

Title: Florida First Lady Casey DeSantis Skips Women for Trump Event Due to Scheduled Execution

Article:

Florida First Lady Casey DeSantis will not attend the Women for Trump event in Tampa, scheduled for Thursday, due to a conflict with a planned execution, according to the governor's office. The event, titled "An Evening to Empower," is centered around the 99th anniversary of the ratification of the 19th Amendment, which granted women the right to vote.

The event, which is being billed as a get-out-the-vote rally, is also set to feature notable Republican women such as Kellyanne Conway and former Attorney General Pam Bondi, according to an email announcement. However, Casey DeSantis, the wife of Governor Ron DeSantis, will not be in attendance due to scheduling conflicts.

The execution of Gary Ray Bowles, a serial killer who targeted gay men, is the main reason for Casey DeSantis' absence, according to Alex Garcia, who is overseeing Trump re-election campaign efforts in Florida. Garcia stated that an announcement advertising the event was a "tad premature."

The celebration event is planned at roughly the same time as the execution of Gary Ray Bowles, for whom Governor Ron DeSantis signed a death warrant earlier this summer. Department of Corrections officials usually maintain constant contact with the governor's office during executions in case questions arise. The governor is informed when an execution has been carried out.

Helen Aguirre Ferré, a spokesperson for the governor, stated that, though the first lady is not an elected official, "out of protocol, the executive office of the governor does not participate in any public event" while an execution is carried out.

In 2013, Pam Bondi, who is also scheduled to speak at the event, came under heavy criticism after she asked then-Governor Rick Scott to move the date of an execution because it conflicted with a kickoff fundraiser for her re-election. She later stated she should not have requested the date change.

Title: Final Republican Debate of 2015: Seven Observations from the CNN/Salem Radio Debate at The Venetian Las Vegas

Article:

The final Republican debate of 2015 took place on Tuesday, December 16, 2014, at The Venetian Las Vegas. This debate, hosted by CNN and Salem Radio, featured nine candidates, a decrease from the previous gathering at the Reagan Presidential Library in September. The debate was truncated, lasting 40 minutes less than the three-hour debate in September.

Here are seven observations from the debate:

1. No One Trumped Trump: The candidates attempted to challenge Donald Trump, the front-runner, on various issues, but their efforts did not significantly impact his position. Kentucky Sen. Rand Paul criticized Trump on Internet policy, and former Florida Gov. Jeb Bush expressed disapproval of Trump's approach. However, Trump's position on the stage was not earned through profound thinking or refined elegance, making it challenging for his rivals to make a lasting impression.

2. The Cage Match: Candidates such as Sen. Marco Rubio, Sen. Ted Cruz, and Gov. Chris Christie engaged in verbal exchanges, with Rand Paul taking swings at Trump, Rubio, and Christie. The media-desired confrontation between Trump and Cruz did not occur, as both candidates were too smart to take the bait.

3. Executive Order: The debate focused on national security and leadership skills, providing an opportunity for governors Chris Christie and John Kasich to showcase their qualifications. However, both candidates faced challenges. Christie struggled to stand out in a round-robin style of Q&A, while Kasich's rhetorical substance abuse, reciting a long Washington biography, did not resonate with the Republican base.

4. Auld Lang Syne: The debate marked the end of the GOP's debate circuit for 2015. The next debate is scheduled for January 14, 2016, in North Charleston, S.C., hosted by the Fox Business Network.

5. Exam Vibe: The debate had a tired atmosphere, with candidates seeming weary of sharing the same oxygen. Tempers were short, giving the debate a sense of being the last exam before an extended break.

6. Debate Winners: Trump and Cruz were considered the winners of the debate, as they played error-free ball.

7. Debate Losers: Anyone who missed the "Star Wars" premiere by staying home to watch the debate was considered a loser, as the debate was mostly uneventful.

Title: Major U.S. Stock Markets Close at Record Highs on Renewed Trade Hopes and Strong Earnings

Article:

The Dow Jones Industrial Average, S&P 500, and Nasdaq all closed at record highs on Monday, as renewed trade hopes and strong earnings propelled stocks higher. The Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 114 points, or 0.42 percent, to book its first record close since July 23. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq finished in record territory for a second straight day.

The record-setting day came after the Chinese Foreign Ministry stated that U.S. President Donald Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping have remained in contact while negotiators craft the final language for the "phase one" of the trade agreement between the two economic powers.

McDonald's shares were lower after the company parted ways with CEO Steve Easterbrook over his consensual relationship with an employee. Easterbrook was instrumental in the company's turnaround, emphasizing a technological shift that included third-party delivery through apps and the installation of kiosks that let customers customize their orders.

Under Armour was sharply lower after confirming the Department of Justice and Securities and Exchange Commission are probing its accounting practices.
