The athletic-apparel maker reported better-than-expected third-quarter results on Monday morning but cut its sales outlook for the remainder of the year.

Ford gained after the United Auto Workers union approved the tentative labor deal that was reached last week.

Earnings reports continued to exceed Wall Street estimates, with over 70 percent of S&P 500 companies reporting, about 76 percent have topped earnings-per-share estimates and 59 percent have beat on revenue, according to Refinitiv.

The Warren Buffett-led Berkshire Hathaway reported a 14 percent increase in third-quarter profit versus a year ago to $7.86 billion, as its cash pile swelled to a record $128.1 billion.

Elsewhere, the luxury automaker Ferrari beat on both the top and bottom lines, sending shares higher.

Commodities gained with West Texas Intermediate crude oil up 0.57 percent at $56.52 a barrel and gold ended little changed near $1,510 an ounce. Treasurys were lower as selling ran the yield on the 10-year note up 5.8 basis points to 1.786 percent.

Global stock markets followed Wall Street higher on Monday after the unexpectedly strong U.S. jobs data helped to soothe investor worries. On Friday, the Labor Department said American employers added 128,000 jobs in October, better than the 89,000 forecast.

In Europe on Monday, Germany's DAX all gained 1.35 percent to pace the advance. In Asia, the Shanghai Composite Index added 0.6 percent and Hong Kong's Hang Seng advanced 1.7 percent. Japan's markets were closed for a holiday.

FOX Business' Ken Martin and the Associated Press contributed to this article.

Title: Pope Francis' Comments on Free Speech Spark Controversy

Article:

Pope Francis, a prominent figure in the Catholic Church, has faced criticism following lighthearted comments that included a pretend punch to a colleague during a flight to the Philippines. The comments were made in an attempt to emphasize the need for limits on free speech, including the right to insult another's faith.

While speaking to reporters on the plane, the Pope gestured as if he were punching someone, stating, "If someone were to say a swear word against my mother, this is what I would do." The Vatican later clarified that the Pope's words were "spoken colloquially" and consistent with his "free style of speech."

The Pope's comments have raised concerns about his stance on free speech, particularly regarding religion. He stated, "One cannot provoke, one cannot insult other people's faith, one cannot make fun of faith. There is a limit. Every religion has its dignity... In freedom of expression, there are limits."

The Pope's comments were made in response to a general question about the balance between religious liberty and free expression, and they appear to reference the massacre of journalists at Charlie Hebdo magazine in Paris. Although the Pope did not directly blame the slain cartoonists for the attack, his comments could be interpreted as implying that such criticism of religion is problematic.

Notable Catholic figures, such as Bill Donahue, president of the New York-based Catholic League, have also raised similar concerns. Donahue stated, "Charlie Hebdo's Stephane Charbonnier didn't understand the role he played in his own death."

In contrast, Jim Wallis, president of Sojourners, a progressive, evangelical community and publication, suggested a different approach to responding to religious attacks. Wallis wrote, "Loving your enemies certainly includes supporting the foundational commitment to free speech, and defending the right of free speech, even, or especially, for those who offend you."

In the United States, the Supreme Court outlawed blasphemy laws in 1952. It is hoped that the Pope's comments were intended as counsel for his followers rather than an advocacy for any legal position. As the article concludes, "No one has the right not to be offended. Even the Pope."

Title: CNN and MSNBC Inject Analysis into Chyrons During 2016 Presidential Race

Article:

Television news networks, such as CNN and MSNBC, have historically used graphics, known as chyrons, to identify people and places in their news stories. However, during the 2016 presidential race, these networks have begun to incorporate analysis into their chyrons during their news reporting.

The practice started in June when Donald Trump denied having said Japan should have nuclear weapons. CNN inserted a snarky line in their chyron: "TRUMP: I NEVER SAID JAPAN SHOULD HAVE NUKES (HE DID)". Last week, when Eric Trump claimed his father had apologized to the Khan family over remarks he made about them after they spoke at the Democratic National Convention, CNN went with: "Last week, Trump claimed his father had apologized to the Khan family".

MSNBC followed suit, using parentheses to add analysis to Trump's statements. When Trump claimed he had seen video of $400 million being sent to Iran by the Obama administration around the time they were releasing American hostages, MSNBC put out: "TRUMP SAYS HE WATCHED (NONEXISTENT) VIDEO OF IRAN RECEIVING CASH".

On Thursday, after Trump described Obama and Hillary Clinton as founders and co-founders of ISIS – similar to remarks President Obama made in 2015, when he laid the rise of ISIS at the feet of President Bush – CNN wrote on its graphic: "OH CNN, YOU SO SNARKY".

While fact-checking may or may not be a legitimate new use of the chyron, what is noticeable is a distinct absence of chyron fact-checking for various claims made by Clinton. For instance, Clinton recently told Fox News' Chris Wallace that FBI Director James Comey had called her answers about her private email use as secretary of state “truthful” – he did not make such a sweeping statement. Last month, she claimed GOP vice presidential nominee Mike Pence had “slashed” education spending as governor of Indiana – he had not. For these statements, Clinton received a "false" rating from Politifact. The CNN and MSNBC chyrons, however, did not deploy their parentheses for those statements.

Outlets like Mediaite and The Daily Caller have also raised questions about a double-standard with the chyrons.

Title: Senate Democrats Secure Necessary Votes to Maintain Iran Nuclear Deal

Article:

Senate Democrats have garnered the 34 votes required to maintain the Iran nuclear deal in Congress, marking a significant foreign policy victory for President Barack Obama. Senator Barbara Mikulski of Maryland provided the crucial 34th vote on Wednesday, stating that the agreement is the most effective means to curb Iran's nuclear ambitions.

Congress is set to vote later this month on a resolution disapproving the deal, which is universally opposed by Republicans, who label it a risky concession to Iran. Obama has pledged to veto the resolution if it passes, and with 34 votes in hand, Democrats now have the necessary support to uphold his veto.

The agreement, signed by Iran, the U.S., and five other world powers, aims to dismantle Iran's nuclear program in exchange for billions of dollars in sanctions relief. Secretary of State John Kerry is sending a letter to all members of Congress outlining U.S. security commitments to Israel and Gulf Arab states in light of the nuclear deal.

In a nationally broadcast interview on Wednesday, Kerry stated, "I really believe the fastest way to a genuine arms race in the Middle East is to not have this agreement. Because if you don't have this agreement, Iran has already made clear what its direction is."

With opposition to the agreement failing to gain traction among Democrats, supporters may even be able to muster the 41 votes needed to block the resolution from passing in the first place, sparing Obama from having to use his veto pen. This would require eight of the 11 remaining undeclared senators to support the deal.

Senators Bob Casey of Pennsylvania and Chris Coons of Delaware announced their support for the deal on Tuesday, bringing the total number of Senate supporters to 33. In statements, both senators expressed their belief that the agreement will significantly constrain Iran's nuclear program and is the best option available at this time.

Republicans in Congress and presidential candidates unanimously oppose the deal, which aims to curb Iran's nuclear program in exchange for sanctions relief. The Israeli government is strongly against it, contending that concessions made to Iran could empower that country, which has sworn to destroy Israel. However, critics have failed to turn the tide against the agreement during the summer recess, despite a multimillion-dollar lobbying campaign funded by the American Israel Public Affairs Committee (AIPAC).

Only two Democratic senators have come out against the deal—Chuck Schumer of New York and Robert Menendez of New Jersey—while in recent weeks undeclared Democratic senators, even from red states, have been breaking in favor of the deal one after another.

Even if Congress were able to pass the disapproval resolution, it would not prevent the deal, which was agreed to among Iran, the United States, Britain, France, Germany, Russia, and China. In July, the U.N. Security Council unanimously endorsed the nuclear deal, approving a resolution that would lift international sanctions on Iran in 90 days.

Title: House Homeland Security Committee Seeks Information on Extremist Involvement in George Floyd Protests

Article:

The House Homeland Security Committee has requested more information from administration officials regarding alleged extremist involvement in protests over the death of George Floyd. The Democratic members of the committee, led by Chairman Bennie Thompson (D-Miss.), addressed a letter to FBI Director Christopher Wray and acting Secretary of Homeland Security Chad Wolf.

The committee expressed "serious concerns" about the "Constitutional implications" of officials' statements that left-wing and right-wing extremists are instigating violence at Floyd protests. The committee seeks to understand the truth and evidence behind reports of extremist involvement in protests, as well as how the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) and the FBI are responding to these issues while ensuring the protection of Americans' civil rights and civil liberties.

The committee has requested all documents from January 1 to the present related to intelligence on ongoing protests, including information given to law enforcement partners, the designation of groups as domestic terrorist organizations, the deployment of DHS employees at demonstrations, and the surveillance of protesters. The deadline to deliver the documents is June 19, and the committee will be briefed by the DHS and the FBI by June 12.

The letter follows reports that right-wing and left-wing anti-government groups have been involved in the Floyd protests within Minnesota and across the country. President Trump announced on Monday that the U.S. plans to designate anti-fascist activists, known as antifa, as a terrorist organization, although federal authorities are unable to label domestic groups as terrorist organizations.

Attorney General William Barr also called out the decentralized group on Sunday, stating, "The violence instigated and carried out by Antifa and other similar groups in connection with the rioting is domestic terrorism and will be treated accordingly."

Title: Hope Hicks Returns to White House as Senior Advisor

Article:

Washington — Hope Hicks, a former top White House aide and longtime confidante to President Donald Trump, is rejoining the administration approximately two years after her departure. A White House official confirmed that Hicks will work closely with Trump's son-in-law and senior adviser, Jared Kushner, and political director Brian Jack. She will not be part of the communications department.

Hicks, 31, previously served as a top communications aide before leaving the White House in 2018 to take a position at the Fox Corporation in California. The announcement of Hicks' departure came a day after she testified before the House Judiciary Committee during the Mueller investigation. Hicks is expected to begin her new role in early March, although the exact timeline remains uncertain.

"There is no one more devoted to implementing President Trump's agenda than Hope Hicks. We are excited to have her back on the team," Kushner said in a statement.

White House press secretary Stephanie Grisham added, "Hope Hicks is one of the most talented and savvy individuals I have come across. She has always impressed me with her quiet confidence, loyalty, and expertise, and I am beyond thrilled to welcome Hope back to the White House."

Prior to her tenure at the White House, Hicks had minimal experience in politics, joining the Trump campaign in its earliest days. Hicks became one of the president's closest advisers, leaving a significant void when she departed. The end of Hicks' tenure at the White House was marked by controversy, as then-White House staff secretary Rob Porter was accused of abuse by his two ex-wives. Porter eventually resigned.

During congressional testimony, Hicks admitted to telling some "white lies" to defend the president.

Hicks' return to the White House follows the formal conclusion of two significant investigations into the president—the Russia investigation and the impeachment saga.

According to a source close to Hicks, she is returning out of a sense of duty and purpose. While she enjoyed her life in the corporate world, outside the White House, she is returning partly due to a sense of duty to this president and this administration. The former model had been considering a return over the past few months.

Title: PG&E to Plead Guilty to 84 Counts of Involuntary Manslaughter in Connection with 2018 California Wildfire

Article:

Pacific Gas & Electric (PG&E) has announced it will plead guilty to 84 counts of involuntary manslaughter in connection with the 2018 Camp Fire in Northern California that resulted in the deaths of 84 people and the destruction of three towns. The plea agreement, announced on Monday, resolves the charges facing PG&E as part of a previously sealed indictment in Butte County.

The plea agreement marks the second time this decade that the company's negligence has resulted in a criminal conviction. In 2010, PG&E was convicted of six felony counts for falsifying records and other safety violations following a natural gas explosion in San Bruno, California, which killed eight people. As with its prior criminal conviction, no one from PG&E will go to prison for the company's felony crimes. Instead, its plea agreement with the Butte County District Attorney's office calls for PG&E to pay a $4 million fine, the maximum allowed.

PG&E will also help pay for efforts to restore access to water for residents affected by the loss of a canal destroyed by the Camp Fire. "We can not replace all that the fire destroyed, but our hope is that this plea agreement, along with our rebuilding efforts, will help the community move forward from this tragic incident," PG&E Corp. CEO Bill Johnson said.

Butte County District Attorney Mike Ramsey said he hopes the plea agreement will bring "a bit of a sense of justice done" for the fire. However, some survivors and victims' families are outraged with the outcome. "It's a crime against society," said Camp Fire survivor Lisa Williams. "A fine doesn't change their behavior. They pay it and repeat bad behavior."

Jay Downer, whose wheelchair-using brother died in the fire, also expressed dismay at the price PG&E will pay for its lethal negligence. "If I fell asleep at the wheel of a car and killed one person, I would be charged with manslaughter and I would be spending time in jail," Downer said.

PG&E is scheduled to enter its plea and face sentencing at a court hearing scheduled for April 24. The Nov. 8, 2018, Camp Fire was fanned by strong winds, forcing thousands of people to quickly flee in their cars as flames ripped through the narrow canyon communities. Butte County officials have pegged the 2018 wildfire's death toll at 85, but Ramsey disclosed Monday that further evidence cast doubt about whether one of the deaths was directly caused by the blaze.

The Camp Fire followed a series of 2017 blazes that tore through Northern California and killed 44 people. Although state investigators didn't find PG&E culpable for those fires, the company is accepting responsibility for them in its bankruptcy case as part of a $13.5 billion settlement that will pay the victims of the 2017 and 2018 fires.

Less than three months after the Butte County fires, PG&E filed for bankruptcy in early 2019 to help shield the utility from more than $50 billion in claimed losses stemming from a badly outdated electrical grid. PG&E has settled those claims for $25.5 billion, including the fund set up for the wildfire victims. Since the bankruptcy filing, PG&E hired Johnson as its new leader to shape up its culture as the company steps up its efforts to improve the safety and reliability of its power lines.

Johnson hailed the plea agreement as a sign that PG&E is "working to create a better future for all concerned. We want wildfire victims, our customers, our regulators, and leaders to know that the lessons we learned from the Camp Fire remain a driving force for us to transform this company." Johnson has previously acknowledged that it will take many years to pull that off while PG&E pours an estimated $40 billion into badly needed upgrades.

In the meantime, PG&E plans to periodically turn off the power during extremely windy and dry conditions to minimize fire risks in parts of a sprawling service territory that provides electricity to 16 million people. By its own admission, PG&E bungled the deliberate blackouts it imposed last autumn to the exasperation of customers and community leaders who complained about not being told about the outages.

California Gov. Gavin Newsom had previously expressed doubts about whether the company has made enough changes to reform its ways, and he had been threatening to block PG&E's plan to get out of bankruptcy this summer. PG&E's chief regulator, the California Public Utilities Commission, still must approve the company's bankruptcy plan, a decision that's expected within the next few weeks. Last week, Newsom dropped his objections amid the coronavirus outbreak that prompted him to order everyone in the state to remain in their homes as much as possible to reduce the spread of COVID-19.

California holds unusual leverage over PG&E's fate in bankruptcy because the company needs state approval of its plan to qualify for coverage from a wildfire insurance fund that the state created last summer. Newsom backpedaled in a Friday bankruptcy court filing, saying he now believes PG&E's plan qualifies it for the coverage. As part of his deal with PG&E, the Democratic governor is still reserving the right to pursue a government-financed takeover of the company if it doesn't emerge from bankruptcy by a June 30 deadline.

Title: All Members of President's Committee on the Arts and Humanities Resign in Protest of Trump's Remarks

Article:

The entire 17-member President's Committee on the Arts and Humanities (PCAH) has resigned in response to President Donald Trump's controversial remarks regarding a white supremacist rally in Charlottesville, Virginia. The resignation follows Trump's disbanding of the American Manufacturing Council and the Strategy and Policy Forum after several business leaders resigned from these groups in protest over his remarks.

In a tweet on Friday morning, committee member Kal Penn shared a letter of resignation, stating that the committee's reproach and censure are necessary following Trump's support of the hate groups and terrorists who caused harm in Charlottesville. The letter, which includes an acrostic spelling out "RESIST," has become associated with protests against the Trump administration.

The White House issued a statement on Friday afternoon claiming that the president had intended to disband the council anyway. This mirrors Trump's previous claim that he was disbanding the Strategy and Policy Forum after all its members had made the decision to disband it on their own.

The PCAH is a federal agency, unlike the other advisory councils Trump has recently disbanded. It is responsible for education and cultural ambassadorship for the arts and is headed by Melania Trump as honorary chair. Its members were appointed by President Obama and include such cultural figureheads as author Jhumpa Lahiri and writer-director George C. Wolfe.

In the resignation letter, the committee condemned the administration's refusal to quickly and unequivocally condemn hatred and noted the importance of the arts in creating empathy and love, and the humanities in supporting a vibrant free press. The letter also criticized Trump for his actions and words that the committee deemed as attacking civil liberties, including the elimination of arts and culture agencies, threatening nuclear war, and withdrawing from the Paris agreement, among other actions.

All 17 members of the committee signed the letter, including Wolfe, who added his signature after Penn's tweet featuring the initial 16 signatories. Though the committee had not met under Trump's administration, Politico reports that it had continued to do some of its basic work, which includes overseeing educational programs and diplomatic functions. The resignation of the full committee makes the PCAH the first White House agency to officially dissolve under President Trump.

"Supremacy, discrimination, and vitriol are not American values," the letter concluded. "We must be better than this."

Title: Trump Prepares to Expand Travel Ban, Considering Additional Countries for Restrictions

Article:

President Donald Trump is reportedly planning to extend his travel ban executive order to include more countries, with potential penalties such as enhanced screening for travelers from these nations. Homeland Security Secretary Elaine Duke has submitted recommendations for countries that should face travel restrictions or additional screening, though the specific countries under consideration have not been disclosed.

The current travel ban, which temporarily halts some admissions from six countries with terrorist connections, is set to expire on Sunday. Administration officials, including White House, Homeland Security, and State Department officials, have stated that they are looking to update the ban.

The Trump administration went through a months-long, two-tier review of other countries' information-sharing with the U.S. Countries deemed "inadequate" were given a 50-day notice that if they did not comply, they could face restrictions. According to Miles Taylor, counselor to Ms. Duke, some countries were "still unable or worse yet, deliberately unwilling to comply," and will face new restrictions.

The new standards suggested by Ms. Duke are conditions-based, rather than the time-based 90-day approach taken in the initial executive order. Critics of the travel ban have accused the administration of using religious animus as a driving force behind the policy.

The original travel ban, which grew out of then-candidate Trump's demand for "extreme vetting" of travelers, particularly from Muslim countries, was met with resistance in the courts. The Supreme Court had been set to hear oral arguments on the current version of the travel ban, but may find the case moot if substantial changes are made to the policy tied to the end of the 90-day pause.

Officials briefing reporters Friday said they cannot predict how the updates will affect the court case since Trump has not announced a final decision yet. The Justice Department has been consulted throughout the process. Under the current ban, the administration is free to block some travel, but must admit refugees worldwide and visitors from the six targeted countries if they prove they have "bona fide" ties. The Supreme Court has delivered a mixed verdict on the current ban, ruling that Trump does have important national security powers that must be respected, but also finding that visitors with "bona fide" ties to a person or institution in the U.S. have rights that must be respected.

Title: Colorado Baker Files Lawsuit Against State Over Refusal to Make Cake for Transgender Woman

Article:

Jack Phillips, the Colorado baker who won a narrow Supreme Court victory over his refusal to make a wedding cake for a gay couple, has filed a lawsuit against the state after it launched another case against him for declining to create a cake for a transgender woman. The lawsuit, filed in U.S. District Court in Denver on Tuesday, alleges that Colorado's Civil Rights Commission has violated Phillips' constitutional rights to free speech, freedom of religion, equal protection, and due process.

The lawsuit names Governor John Hickenlooper, Cynthia Coffman, the state attorney general, and the Colorado Civil Rights Commission as defendants. Phillips seeks permanent injunctions against the state from taking any enforcement action against him, who the lawsuit says was "vindicated" by the Supreme Court ruling.

In June, the Supreme Court ruled that the Colorado's civil rights commission was hostile toward Phillips' Christian beliefs when it cited him for refusing to bake a wedding cake for a same-sex couple in 2012. However, the ruling did not rule on whether he violated Colorado's public accommodation statute.

The lawsuit stems from a complaint filed by Denver attorney Autumn Scardina with the civil rights commission in 2017, in which she claims that Phillips refused to bake a cake that "celebrates my transition from male to female." Scardina did not immediately return a phone message left at her law office.

The director of the state's Civil Rights Division, Aubrey Elenis, ruled in June that Phillips discriminated against Scardina. "The evidence thus demonstrates that the refusal to provide service to (Scardina) was based on (her) transgender status," Elenis wrote in a probable cause determination. The finding by Elenis requires both sides to resolve the issue through "compulsory mediation," the document said.

Phillips is also seeking $100,000 in punitive damages against Elenis "for her unconstitutional actions," according to the lawsuit. Daniel Ramos, executive director of One Colorado, a group that advocates for the LGBTQ community, blasted the Alliance Defending Freedom (ADF), the conservative Christian group whose lawyers represent Phillips.

"We have seen the ADF launch similar lawsuits across the country that target nondiscrimination laws and civil rights agencies, and this broad lawsuit they filed on behalf of Jack Phillips reads as more of the same," Ramos said. The Colorado Civil Rights Commission declined to comment on Phillips' lawsuit.

Title: Study Indicates Bias in Mainstream Economic News Coverage Favoring Democratic Presidents

Article:

A new study published in the journal American Politics Research suggests that mainstream economic news coverage tends to be biased in favor of Democratic presidents. The research, conducted by Eric Merkley, a Ph.D. candidate at the University of British Columbia, provides evidence that the media is more charitable to Democrats than Republicans.

Merkley used automated content analysis software to evaluate the tone of 400,000 news articles related to unemployment and inflation, published between 1985 and 2013 by 23 high-circulating American newspapers and the Associated Press. The study excluded editorials and opinion pieces.

Merkley found that the tone of economic news coverage was more positive during Democratic presidencies, even after controlling for the economic performance. "Journalists broadly lean to the political left and this has become increasingly true over time," Merkley told a media outlet.

However, Merkley emphasized that the findings do not suggest that mainstream media deliberately manufactures false or misleading content to harm Republican presidents. Instead, the findings are consistent with confirmation bias, where journalists appropriately reduce tone in economic news in response to worsening economic conditions under Republican presidents, but are problematically more charitable during Democratic administrations.

The study includes some limitations, and the current research is no exception. Merkley noted that the findings only apply to economic news content and may vary across broader issue types. He also acknowledged that his methodology cannot address the growing conservative echo chamber, such as Fox News, Breitbart News, and Town Hall, and that more work should be done on this issue.

Merkley's study adds to the mixed academic research on media bias, with some studies finding that media outlets present topics in a largely nonpartisan manner, while others suggest patterns of bias vary across issue types. The study's findings highlight the importance of objectivity and impartiality in journalism, particularly during economic news coverage.

Title: Grand Jury to Decide Fate of Ahmaud Arbery's Accused Killers

Article:

Ahmaud Arbery, a 25-year-old black man, was shot and killed in February in a neighborhood outside Brunswick, Georgia. The shooting occurred in the Satilla Shores neighborhood, where Arbery did not reside, according to his father. His family stated that he was jogging when the shooting took place.

Arbery's friend, Akeem Baker, told The Atlanta Constitution-Journal that Arbery was a frequent runner. A Facebook page and GoFundMe campaign called "I Run With Maud" were started to raise awareness about Arbery's killing. As of Wednesday, the GoFundMe had raised over $14,000, and the page had over 21,000 followers. A dedication run is planned for Friday.

No arrests or charges have been made in the case, according to prosecutor Tom Durden, who stated that a grand jury will hear the evidence in the shooting, but a hearing will not occur until mid-June at the earliest when Georgia courts reopen from coronavirus restrictions.

On Tuesday, Durden requested the Georgia Bureau of Investigation (GBI) to look into the case. GBI Director Vic Reynolds issued a statement Wednesday, stating that his team would operate the investigation out of its headquarters and "bring to bear every resource and experience this agency has in resolving this matter."

According to a police report, Arbery was shot after two men saw him running in their neighborhood and armed themselves with guns before getting in a truck to pursue him. Gregory McMichael, one of the men, told police he was in his front yard when he saw "the suspect from the break-ins" running. McMichael and his adult son, Travis, grabbed guns because they "did not know if the male was armed or not."

McMichael and his son chased Arbery, with Travis getting out of the truck with a shotgun. Arbery "began to violently attack" Travis, and the two men then started fighting over the shotgun, according to the police report. Travis fired two shots, and Arbery was shot multiple times.

Video footage of the event has been posted online, showing a black man jogging on a road in daylight. A white truck is parked in the road ahead of him; a man stands in the pickup bed, and another is beside the open driver's-side door. The runner passes the pickup on the passenger side. There is shouting, then a gunshot, and the video shows the runner grappling with a man in the street over what appears to be a shotgun or rifle. A second shot goes off, and the runner punches the man. A third shot is fired at point-blank range. The runner staggers a few feet and falls face down.

A statement released by S. Lee Merritt, an attorney representing Arbery's mother, Wanda Cooper, stated that a "false narrative" had been created that the video disproved. "Mr. Arbery had not committed any crime, and there was no reason for these men to believe they had the right to stop him with weapons or to use deadly force in furtherance of their unlawful attempted stop. This is murder," Merritt said.

Georgia Governor Brian Kemp, who had not addressed the shooting until this week, tweeted Tuesday that "Georgians deserve answers." Georgia Attorney General Chris Carr stated on Twitter late Tuesday that he is "deeply concerned with the events surrounding the shooting of Ahmaud Arbery" and expects "justice to be carried out as swiftly as possible."

Dozens of demonstrators walked through Brunswick Tuesday, holding signs that said, "Justice for Ahmaud Arbery" and "I run with Maud." More demonstrators walked around the state Capitol in Atlanta on Wednesday, demanding justice. The Georgia NAACP is to hold a protest with Arbery's family at the Glynn County Courthouse on Friday.

Several lawmakers have spoken out, including Democratic presidential candidate Joe Biden, who tweeted late Tuesday that Arbery was "killed in cold blood." Former Georgia Democratic gubernatorial candidate Stacey Abrams stated, "Our systems of law enforcement and justice must be held to the highest standards." She called for a "full investigation, appropriate charges, and an unbiased prosecution." Senator Kamala Harris, D-Calif., a former Democratic presidential candidate, stated on Twitter the video "sickens me to my core." "Exercising while Black should not be a death sentence," she said.

Title: Former Senator Jeff Flake Predicts Republican Challenge to President Trump in 2020

Article:

Former Senator Jeff Flake (R-AZ), a known critic of President Donald Trump, has predicted that a Republican will challenge the incumbent in the 2020 presidential election. Flake, who has had a contentious relationship with Trump, expressed his belief that a Republican contender will emerge, and he also suggested the possibility of an independent candidate.

During an interview, Flake stated, "I do think the president will have a challenge from the Republican Party. I think there should be. I also think that there will be an independent challenge, particularly if the Democrats insist on putting somebody up from the far left of the party."

Flake's comments come as President Trump has announced his intention to run for re-election in 2020, citing his accomplishments in his first year, such as tax reform, a record number of judicial appointments, and the appointment of a new conservative justice to the Supreme Court.

Flake's potential rival, Ohio's Republican Governor John Kasich, has been mentioned as a possible contender for the White House. When asked about his own presidential aspirations, Flake did not rule out the possibility of an independent run.

Throughout the past year, Flake and Trump have clashed on various issues. In July 2017, Flake published a book titled "Conscience of a Conservative," in which he criticized Trump for leading the Republican Party to compromise its principles. Trump responded to Flake's book during a rally in Arizona in August 2017, labeling him and Senator John McCain as "weak" on border issues.

In the fall of 2018, Flake announced his retirement from the Senate. During his farewell speech, he compared Trump's rhetoric to that of Soviet dictator Joseph Stalin's, stating, "I do not think that we should be using a phrase that's been rejected as too loaded by a Soviet dictator."

If Flake decides to challenge Trump in 2020, the debates between the two would likely be a highly anticipated event.

Title: False Claims Act in Healthcare: A Study on Its Impact and Misuse

Article:

A new working paper from the Independence Institute, penned by attorneys Mark W. Pearlstein and Laura McLane, discusses the use and misuse of the False Claims Act (FCA) in the healthcare sector. The FCA, enacted in 1863 to combat fraudulent billing during the Civil War, has become a tool for private individuals to sue entities suspected of defrauding the federal government.

Between 2009 and June 2016, over 4,700 FCA actions were filed, with awards ranging from $11,000 to $22,000 per detected fraud, and treble damages. The Act's spoils are divided among the person alleging the fraud, their attorneys, and the federal government. In 2014, the Department of Justice reported that FCA "recoveries" totaled $5.79 billion, with health care lawsuits accounting for $2.3 billion of that amount.

The federal government investigates every FCA case, with the initial investigation conducted under seal. Defendants may be unaware of the investigation until their business documents are subpoenaed. An individual alleging fraud can proceed with a case even if the government decides against it.

The FCA's original intent was to prosecute fraud cases involving contractors billing the U.S. government for nonexistent or worthless goods, not to prosecute contractors for failing to adhere to specific manufacturing standards or minor differences of opinion. However, the paper suggests that the FCA is increasingly used as a blunt instrument to extract large sums from businesses, leading to lawsuits against nursing homes, hospitals, doctors, insurers, clinical laboratories, pharmaceutical manufacturers, software providers, managed care organizations, and universities funded by federal grants.

Plaintiffs allege various issues, including too little care, too much care, billing errors, record-keeping violations, and differences in opinion about medical necessity. The Department of Health and Human Services certifies provider performance using various methods and has administrative enforcement tools to influence contractor behavior.

In 2015, the Fourth Circuit upheld a $237 million FCA verdict in United States ex rel. Drakeford v. Tuomey. The case involved a business entity related to Tuomey Regional Medical Center, which had part-time employment agreements with 19 surgeons and gastroenterologists. The physicians had agreed to use Tuomey facilities when they performed procedures on their private patients. Plaintiffs argued that the contract violated the Stark Law because physicians who performed more procedures earned more.

After 10 years of litigation, Tuomey settled with the federal government, agreeing to pay $72.4 million and sell itself to another health system. Many FCA defendants settle because they cannot afford to prove their innocence. The government often requires signing a Corporate Integrity Agreement as part of the settlement terms, giving it control of the defendant's business activities for many years.

A judge in the Tuomey case wrote that the hospital was caught in "a n impenetrably complex set of laws and regulations that will result in a likely death sentence for a community hospital in an already medically underserved area." He concluded that "even for well-intentioned health care providers, the Stark Law has become a booby trap rigged with strict liability and potentially ruinous exposure—especially when coupled with the False Claims Act."

Pearlstein and McLaine argue that the aggressive use of the FCA in healthcare cases goes beyond the traditional understanding of fraud. Unless Congress revises the statute, it will continue to harm patients by allowing routine second-guessing of physician decisions, raise costs by encouraging meritless whistle-blowing for money, and impair access to care as risk-averse participants bow out.

Linda Gorman, director of the Health Care Policy Center at the Independence Institute, a free-market think tank in Denver, notes the impact of the FCA on healthcare.

Title: Obama's West Coast Fundraising Tour Aims to Bolster Democratic Party Committee Coffers

Article:

President Barack Obama embarked on a three-day fundraising tour in the West Coast to support the Democratic Party committees for the 2014 election cycle. The tour comes at a time when the political climate has become challenging for Democratic candidates, particularly in the Senate, due to the flawed rollout of the Affordable Care Act's federal insurance marketplace and the ongoing debate over the law's implementation.

The fundraising tour is a critical obligation for Obama, who can now focus on this task after having built a billion-dollar war chest for his own re-election. Jim Manley, a former aide to Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid and a Democratic strategist with QGA Public Affairs, stated, "It's kind of better late than never." He added, "There are a whole bunch of Democrats on the Hill who wish he had done more in years past."

The Affordable Care Act's implementation issues and the controversy surrounding whether Obama knowingly misled the public about insurance coverage have caused concern among Democrats across the country about the law's future. Vulnerable red state Democrats, such as Sen. Mary Landrieu (R-La.), and challengers, like Michelle Nunn, who is running for Senate in Georgia, have proposed various solutions, including delaying the individual mandate and allowing Americans to keep their health insurance coverage indefinitely.

Obama's job approval and favorability ratings have declined, according to a recent ███/Washington Post poll. These sentiments could negatively impact Democrats running for re-election in 2014. Bill Galston, a former policy adviser to President Bill Clinton and chair of the Brookings Institute's Governance Studies program, noted, "If the president is way down in the public's esteem, that's going to create a big headwind for Democrats running for re-election."

However, Obama is not the first (nor will he be the last) president to face criticism within his own party. Poll numbers can be volatile, and the government shutdown, which seemed to leave Republicans in a weakened position weeks ago, has since energized the GOP due to the health care law's early troubles. If Democrats can shift the focus away from the broken website and onto economic issues, they may perform well in 2014, according to top Democratic pollster Joel Benenson.

Obama is also facing criticism from Democratic activists who are frustrated with the lack of progress on other issues, such as immigration reform. Despite the support of Silicon Valley CEOs, who have donated tens of thousands of their own money to boost Obama and advocate for immigration reform, the prospects of an immigration bill passing through the House of Representatives are slim.

The timing of Obama's fundraising swing has been criticized, with some suggesting it could not have been worse for the president and his political team. Tickets to one of Obama's fundraisers were reportedly discounted, and at an event on immigration reform in San Francisco, he was heckled by pro-immigration reform activists.

Republicans are capitalizing on the health care law's troubles, viewing its implementation as their greatest political advantage. They are unlikely to shift their focus away from the health care law and onto other issues like immigration reform or gun control. Even news of a potential deal on Iran's nuclear program has not deterred Republicans from viewing the health care law as a political asset.

It remains to be seen whether Obama's numbers will improve and whether 2014 will prompt a full-scale revolt among vulnerable or even potentially vulnerable Democrats running. However, in the meantime, Galston suggested that Obama's primary focus should be on extending a lifeline to his fellow Democrats, as he is, to some extent, responsible for their current predicament. Galston stated, "The president's position now has to be that he will be inclined to do almost everything that the party asks him to do to get them out of a tough spot."

Title: Democrat Governors Criticize President Trump's Handling of Reopening Protests

Article:

In a joint response, Governors J.B. Pritzker of Illinois and Gretchen Whitmer of Michigan have criticized President Donald Trump for his support of protests demanding the reopening of businesses in their respective states. The governors claim that Trump's stance is spreading fear and potentially endangering the public.

Governor Pritzker, speaking to Washington Post reporter Robert Costa, stated, "I know what he's trying to do. It's a political maneuver in the middle of a national emergency, and he should stop it. What could it mean? It could mean terrible things. You could end up with violence."

Pritzker also expressed concern that large gatherings of protesters could lead to the spread of the coronavirus, potentially causing illness and death among the population. "People gathering in large crowds will be giving each other coronavirus, and people, unfortunately, will get sick and some people may die as a result of the president’s rhetoric that has brought them out to protest," he said.

Governor Whitmer, in an interview with The Associated Press, criticized Trump's call to suspend immigration during the coronavirus crisis, stating it was part of a series of "inconsistent messages" designed to spread fear and put the public at greater risk. Instead, she emphasized the need for resources to increase coronavirus testing, stating, "This is what we need right now, not additional new things to be upset about, fearful of or mad about."

Whitmer also denied that her comments against Trump's actions were an attempt to position herself as a potential running mate for presumptive Democrat nominee Joe Biden. Instead, she stated her focus is on managing the coronavirus crisis in her state. However, her strict rules, including bans on certain purchases or travel to property owned in the state, have led to protests at the state capital, including from people who want to return to work as Michigan's unemployment rates soar. More than 1 million people in her state are unemployed due to closures under the governor's office or job losses since the outbreak began.

Title: Trump Praises Pakistani Prime Minister in Phone Call, Expresses Willingness to Play Role in Addressing Outstanding Issues

Article:

President-elect Donald Trump expressed praise for Pakistani Prime Minister Muhammad Nawaz Sharif during a phone call on Wednesday, according to a readout provided by the Pakistani government. The conversation provided a glimpse into Trump's diplomatic strategy.

Trump stated, "You are a terrific guy. You are doing amazing work which is visible in every way," during the call, according to the readout. He also expressed his readiness to play any role that Prime Minister Sharif wants him to play in addressing and finding solutions to outstanding issues.

The call, which included Sharif's congratulations on Trump's election victory and an invitation for Trump to visit Pakistan, showcased Trump's penchant for hyperbole, a trait he often exhibited during his off-the-cuff campaign speeches.

Trump further stated, "Please convey to the Pakistani people that they are amazing and all Pakistanis I have known are exceptional people."

The full readout of the call, according to the Pakistani government, is as follows:

"Prime Minister Muhammad Nawaz Sharif called President-elect USA Donald Trump and felicitated him on his victory. President Trump said Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif, you have a very good reputation. You are a terrific guy. You are doing amazing work which is visible in every way. I am looking forward to see you soon. As I am talking to you Prime Minister, I feel I am talking to a person I have known for long. Your country is amazing with tremendous opportunities. Pakistanis are one of the most intelligent people. I am ready and willing to play any role that you want me to play to address and find solutions to the outstanding problems. It will be an honor and I will personally do it. Feel free to call me any time even before 20th January that is before I assume my office."

On being invited to visit Pakistan, Trump said, "I would love to come to a fantastic country, a fantastic place of fantastic people." He also expressed, "Please convey to the Pakistani people that they are amazing and all Pakistanis I have known are exceptional people."

The transition team of Trump has not released a readout of the call.

Title: Federal Court's Interpretation of Trump's Travel Ban Challenged for Alleged Misinterpretation of Precedent

Article:

The Fourth Circuit Court of Appeals has upheld a nationwide injunction on President Donald Trump's temporary halt on immigration from six majority-Muslim countries, sparking controversy and allegations of misinterpretation of existing precedent. This new interpretation, coined as "Trumplaw," has been criticized for its potential impact on national security and disregard for established legal principles.

The court's ruling hinges on two main points: first, that Trump's campaign statements were so offensive that they granted a Muslim resident standing to challenge an executive order that did not apply to him; second, that the harm caused to the plaintiff's feelings and potential delayed entry of his wife into the United States outweighs the government's asserted national-security interest in pausing immigration from hostile and war-torn countries.

Critics argue that Trumplaw is difficult to reconcile with existing precedent, as it often requires courts to yank laws out of context, misinterpret them, and rewrite them to reach a desired outcome. One example is the Fourth Circuit's reading of the Supreme Court case, Kleindienst v. Mandel. In this case, the Supreme Court ruled against a Belgian journalist seeking a non-immigrant visa due to his advocacy of Marxist doctrines, despite the First Amendment's protection of such activities.

The Fourth Circuit, however, interpreted Mandel to argue that the Court looked only at the face of the document to determine whether its supporting reasons were legitimate, not whether they were "bona fide." This interpretation, according to critics, would have altered the outcome in Mandel and other key Supreme Court cases, and goes against the Court's refusal to look behind notices and documents to explore the subjective motivations of relevant government officials.

The dissent, led by Judge Paul Niemeyer, argues that this approach grants the court the power to conduct an extratextual search for evidence suggesting bad faith, which is prohibited by three Supreme Court opinions. The dissent asserts that the majority's interpretation rejects clear holdings in Mandel, Fiallo, and Din, and favors a politically desired outcome.

The controversy surrounding the travel ban and the interpretation of Trumplaw is ongoing, with critics arguing that the court's decision risks national security and sets a dangerous precedent for future administrations. The principle established by the Fourth Circuit's decision is that a judge's dislike of a politician's campaign statements can taint actions that clearly contradict those statements, potentially allowing for the manipulation of legal interpretations for political purposes.

Title: Wind Energy Helps Texas and Other States Weather Extreme Cold Weather, Highlighting U.S. Grid Vulnerability

Article:

On Tuesday, Texas set a new winter record for power usage due to frigid temperatures. However, the state managed to avoid major power outages, in part due to increased output from West Texas wind farms. This is not the first time wind energy has helped Texas avoid power outages in extreme weather; in 2011, high wind outputs during peak demand helped Texas's grid weather 100-plus temperatures.

Similarly, wind energy is aiding other states in dealing with the ongoing Polar Vortex. According to the American Wind Energy Association (AWEA), when the temperatures began dropping in the Upper Midwest, wind generated enough energy to power 6 million average homes. The Mid-Atlantic region also saw high wind energy output, which helped bolster the grid after some power plants failed unexpectedly due to the weather.

However, this week's Polar Vortex has put the vulnerability of the U.S. energy grid in focus. On Tuesday, electricity demand in parts of the Southeast U.S. was the second-highest it's been in winter since the 1920s, according to the Tennessee Valley Authority. Parts of Tennessee lost power during the night, and parts of South Carolina instituted rolling blackouts to manage the electricity demand. Earlier this week, 40,000 people in Indiana lost power, and people across the country were urged to conserve power to help the grid deal with the spike in demand.

Severe weather is the number one cause of power outages in the U.S., meaning that as extreme events become more common, the U.S. power grid will be put more and more at risk. Between 2003 and 2012, extreme weather caused over 675 power outages and cost the U.S. between $18 billion to $33 billion per year, according to a report by the President's Council of Economic Advisers and the Department of Energy. The report, released in August, states that transmission line construction in the U.S. has slowed from 10,000 miles built per year in the late 1960s to just 1,000 miles per year in the mid-2000s. This slowdown means about 70 percent of U.S. transmission lines and power transformers are over 25 years old.

Massoud Amin, an electrical engineering professor at the University of Minnesota, estimates that updating the country to Smart Grid technology would cost $21 billion per year for the next two decades, but would ultimately result in savings of between $79 and $94 billion per year.

"As a nation, we must take action to improve our electric grid if we want to meet the power needs of a pervasively digital society," Amin wrote in Forbes in 2012. "Americans should not accept or learn to cope with increasing blackouts."

Title: Conservative Groups Launch Ad Campaign, Town Hall Meetings to Defund Obamacare

Article:

Conservative political advocacy groups, including Heritage Action for America, ForAmerica, and Tea Party Patriots, are escalating their efforts to defund President Barack Obama's Affordable Care Act (Obamacare) by launching new online ad campaigns and town hall meetings starting this week.

Heritage Action for America, a leading conservative advocacy group, announced on Monday that it would spend over half a million dollars to run online ads in the districts of 100 House Republican lawmakers who have not joined the push to defund the healthcare law. Last month, Heritage Action joined 49 other conservative groups in demanding the House GOP leadership pass a bill to fund the government but not allow any money for Obamacare.

In a statement, Heritage Action CEO Michael A. Needham said, "The American people may have been locked out of the legislative process that gave us Obamacare, but they will be the force behind stopping this unworkable, unaffordable law. Congress should seize the moment and defund the entire law."

On the same day, two other conservative groups, ForAmerica and Tea Party Patriots, also launched an online ad campaign targeting GOP senators and House Speaker John Boehner in an effort to persuade them to defund Obamacare.

Some conservative lawmakers, including Senators Ted Cruz of Texas, Marco Rubio of Florida, and Mike Lee of Utah, are using upcoming budget battles as leverage, vowing to oppose any measure that provides funding for the federal government that includes funding for the health care law. The measure funding the federal government expires on September 30, setting up another Capitol Hill budget battle between congressional Republicans and the White House.

However, so far, only slightly more than a dozen fellow Republican senators have signed up to support the cause, leaving it up to outside conservative groups to rally the base.

The announcement of internet ads by Heritage Action, which is a sister organization of the Heritage Foundation, one of the oldest and largest conservative think tanks, comes on the same day the group is launching a nine-stop "Defund Obamacare Tour." Joining the series of townhalls, which kick off on Monday in Fayetteville, Arkansas, are former Sen. Jim DeMint, the Heritage Foundation president, and Rafael Cruz, the father of Sen. Cruz. The senator from Texas will join DeMint and his father at the second town hall on Tuesday in Dallas.

Two progressive groups, Americans United for Change and Protect Your Care, plan counter-protests outside the townhalls. "Pro-Health Reform advocates are going to meet the repealers and defunders on the battlefield and confront them directly and aggressively," says Brad Woodhouse, president of Americans United for Change. "A strong majority of the American people want the Affordable Care Act implemented and fixed if necessary – they do not want it repealed – which is the only plan for health care Republicans have."

Americans appear divided on whether they want the law, which passed in 2010 along party lines when the Democrats controlled both houses of Congress. In one of the most recent surveys on the law, conducted last month for CBS News, nearly four in ten called for the entire law to be repealed, with 18% saying that just the measure's controversial individual mandate should be repealed. Thirty-six percent of those questioned said that the law should be kept as is, or expanded.

Title: Majority of Americans Support Universal Background Checks for Gun Purchases, Despite Opposition from Gun Lobby

Article:

In a recent poll, 91% of Americans expressed support for universal background checks for gun purchases, with only 8% opposing the measure. This overwhelming majority was consistent across households with guns, with 88% in favor and 11% against.

The National Rifle Association (NRA), a powerful lobbying group known for its advocacy of gun rights, has been identified as a key opponent of universal background checks. The NRA, with approximately 4.5 million members, has been accused of being influenced by gun manufacturers who prioritize profits over public safety.

The poll suggests that the NRA's efforts to portray universal background checks as a potential precursor to gun confiscation have been successful, with 48% of respondents believing that such checks would lead to the government confiscating legally owned guns. However, this belief is widely considered to be unfounded, as the poll indicates that only 8% of the population opposes the checks.

The opposition to universal background checks primarily stems from concerns about the potential impact on profits for gun manufacturers. Background checks would close a loophole in the current system, preventing sales to felons and the mentally ill, which would reduce the market for guns and, consequently, profits.

The poll also revealed that some gun owners are concerned about additional gun regulations, while others fear that background checks could expose them to potential tyranny from their own government or foreign powers. However, these concerns seem unfounded, as universal background checks would not infringe on the constitutional right to bear arms or lead to gun confiscation.

Despite the opposition from the gun lobby, the poll suggests that a majority of Americans support measures to keep guns out of the hands of criminals and the mentally ill. The poll also found that many other countries, with similar requirements and lower rates of gun violence, have successfully implemented similar measures.

In conclusion, the poll indicates that a significant majority of Americans support universal background checks for gun purchases. Despite the opposition from the gun lobby, the poll suggests that the public is largely in favor of measures to keep guns out of the hands of those who should not possess them.

Title: Trump, Pence, and Rubio Unveil New Cuba Policy in Miami

Article:

Senator Marco Rubio (R-FL) joined Vice President Mike Pence and President Donald Trump in Miami, Florida on Friday to announce the White House's new Cuba policy. Rubio praised the president for his compassion towards the Cuban people, who continue to face challenges under the dictatorial leadership of Raul Castro.

In multiple conversations since the election, Rubio shared that Trump had frequently asked, "What are we going to do about Cuba?"

President Trump outlined some of the ways he intends to empower the people of Cuba, starting by canceling many of the provisions in the Obama administration's "one-sided" deal with the Castro regime.

"The Cuban American community has so much love," Trump said, acknowledging the warm welcome he received upon his arrival. He commended the community for building a vibrant culture in Miami, noting it as "a testament to what a free Cuba can be."

"With God's help, a free Cuba is what we will soon achieve," he added.

President Trump, in contrast to his predecessor, pledged to expose communism as a failed system. He promised, "Now that I am president, we will expose the crimes of the Castro regime."

The president outlined several demands his administration will be making of Castro. These include not lifting sanctions until all political prisoners are free, all parties are legalized, and free elections are scheduled. He also plans to restrict U.S. dollars going to a military that is the cause of the Castro regime, enforce the ban on tourism and embargo, and ensure that investments flow directly to the people so they can open private businesses.

Furthermore, Trump demanded that Castro stop harboring fugitives and criminals like Joanne Chesimard, who escaped from prison in 1979 and has been hiding in Cuba since gaining political asylum in 1984.

Trump concluded his remarks and proceeded to sign the new policy document. "America will expose the crimes of the Castro regime and stand with the Cuban people in their struggle for freedom," he said.

Title: World Leaders Adopt Flattery Strategy in Dealing with President Trump

Article:

Diplomacy, a complex art, requires an understanding of other cultures to avoid potential faux pas during diplomatic visits. Saudi Arabia's King Salman bin Abdulaziz has demonstrated a unique approach in dealing with U.S. President Donald Trump, employing a strategy of flattery that has been adopted by various world leaders since Trump took office.

During Trump's visit to Saudi Arabia on Sunday, King Salman greeted him with a grand ceremony that included a military flyover, cannons, an elaborate cardamom coffee service, and the presentation of a gold medal. This level of adulation was not extended to the last American president, Barack Obama, during his visit in 2009.

The New York Times recently published a checklist of dos and don'ts for leaders meeting with President Trump. The advice includes being concise, offering numerous compliments, and avoiding lengthy monologues. Leaders are also advised to acknowledge Trump's Electoral College victory, contrast him favorably with his predecessor, and maintain regular contact.

British Prime Minister Theresa May, during her January visit, called Trump's election win "stunning." Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu referenced Trump's book, The Art of the Deal. Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe complimented Trump's golf swing.

However, Trump's efforts at statecraft on his first day in Saudi Arabia were not as overt as those of other leaders. First Lady Melania and daughter Ivanka, who accompanied the president, opted not to wear headscarves, despite Trump's own deep knowledge of Middle Eastern manners. Trump, however, did thank King Salman for the medal by dipping what appeared to be a tiny curtsey.

Title: ISIS Militants Attack Kirkuk in Northern Iraq, Clashes Continue in Other Regions

Article:

ISIS militants have launched an attack on the strategically important city of Kirkuk in northern Iraq, a move that could potentially be an attempt to capture the oil-rich city or to divert Kurdish troops engaged in the fight to capture ISIS' stronghold of Mosul. The city, located on top of some of Iraq's largest oil reserves, has not fallen to ISIS, unlike many other notable cities in northern Iraq.

For months, ISIS has been clashing with the Peshmerga, armed fighters who protect Iraqi Kurdistan, to the west of Kirkuk. The militants have moved into areas on Kirkuk's outskirts but not the central city. On Friday, heavily armed militants attacked an abandoned hotel in central Kirkuk that local police had used as their headquarters. Peshmerga and Kurdish anti-terror units later regained control of the hotel, killing three militants and two suicide bombers.

In addition to the attack on Kirkuk, ISIS militants took over Maktab Khalid, an area about 12 miles southwest of Kirkuk, after heavy clashes with the Peshmerga. Among those killed was Brig. Gen. Shirko Fateh, the highest-ranking operational commander of the Peshmerga brigade located in Kirkuk. Photos posted by ISIS purportedly show the group's militants in control of parts of south and southwest Kirkuk, burning tents that had been used by Peshmerga troops.

The U.S. military said Friday that an ISIS chemical weapons expert was killed during a coalition strike late last week. Abu Malik worked in Saddam Hussein's chemical weapons program before joining al Qaeda in 2005, U.S. Central Command said. "His death is expected to temporarily degrade and disrupt the terrorist network and diminish (ISIS's) ability to potentially produce and use chemical weapons against innocent people," the military said.

There is no public evidence that ISIS has a dedicated weapons of mass destruction program. However, U.S. Central Command said: "His past training and experience provided the terrorist group with expertise to pursue a chemical weapons capability."

Kirkuk is one of the few notable cities, apart from the region of Kurdistan and its capital, Erbil, that have not fallen to ISIS. The Kurds and the central Iraqi government in Baghdad have long disputed control of Kirkuk's oil reserves, with each side wanting to keep hold of them. ISIS, which relies heavily on revenue from oil smuggling to fund its operations, has also been coveting them.

Peshmerga forces took over the Kirkuk area in June when the Iraqi army crumbled in the face of ISIS' advances and have played a vital role in defending it from ISIS since. In December, ISIS claimed responsibility for a suicide car bomb attack there that killed at least 17 people and injured more than 20. The attack, according to ISIS, was meant to send a message to the Kurdish people and Peshmerga fighters.

Still, Kirkuk is hardly the only place that has seen recent fighting. The group has been fending off an offensive from Peshmerga fighters around Mosul, Iraq's second-largest city and a focal point for all sides in the conflict, that has left the Sunni extremist group on its heels. The city of 1.5 million people on the Tigris River has been held by ISIS since June. ISIS has invested heavily in governing the city. Its leader, Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, pronounced his leadership of the caliphate at the Grand Mosque there in July.

Kurdish officials say that as long as ISIS holds Mosul, it threatens Kurdistan. Likewise, neither the government in Baghdad nor its coalition partners can rest while terrorists occupy Iraq's second-largest city. Peshmerga forces have made steady progress against ISIS north and west of Mosul over the past two months. They have taken some 3,000 square kilometers (1,160 square miles) of the Sinjar area, as well as the area around the Mosul Dam, choking off access routes and threatening ISIS' main resupply routes.

There's little doubt that ISIS remains a very real force and threat in much of Iraq. The group, which calls itself the Islamic State, still controls a vast swath of that Middle Eastern nation and neighboring Syria. Its goal is to have a vast caliphate under its strict version of Sharia law, with its followers proving they will stop at nothing—having been blamed for the large-scale killings of civilians, mass kidnappings, and forcing women and girls to become sex slaves—during its quest. That violent campaign continued Friday, and not just in Kirkuk.

Dozens of gunmen believed to be from ISIS faced off Friday morning about 175 miles (285 kilometers) away in central Ramadi, police and health officials in that city said. Several hours later, that onslaught had been foiled, and 20 gunmen were dead, according to the officials. Elsewhere in Ramadi, a suicide car bomb explosion at an Iraqi army checkpoint killed one soldier and wounded six others. Violence flared in other parts of Iraq as well, further proof of the country's unsettled state. Six explosions went off Friday around Baghdad, leaving at least seven dead and 23 wounded, according to police officials. The deadliest such blast was in Bab Al Sharji, a busy commercial area in central Baghdad, leaving three dead and 10 hurt.

Title: Progressives and Historical Figures: A Dilemma of Moral Judgment and Selective Memory

Article:

The ongoing debate surrounding the removal of historical figures with controversial pasts, such as Confederate generals and other racially insensitive individuals, has sparked a discussion about the proper rules of exemption for progressives when waging war against the past. The question arises: do progressives erase the history of their racist heroes or only their racist enemies?

In some cases, the condemnation of figures from the past may be warranted, such as Confederate general Nathan Bedford Forrest, a founding member of the Ku Klux Klan, or Supreme Court Justice Roger B. Taney, who wrote the majority opinion in the racist Dred Scott decision. However, the wide liberal search for more enemies of the past may lead progressives down a hypocritical path, as they may have to disassociate themselves from historical figures who were once considered progressive icons, such as Margaret Sanger, the founder of Planned Parenthood, who was an unapologetic racist and eugenicist.

The issue of selective memory and moral judgment is further complicated by the fact that many historical figures, such as Ruth Bader Ginsburg, Susan B. Anthony, Earl Warren, President Woodrow Wilson, and Supreme Court Justice Hugo Black, have been associated with racist or discriminatory actions or statements. The question then becomes: what are the proper rules of exemption for progressives when waging war against the dead?

Some argue that the rules should be based on a tally of the dead's good and bad behaviors, with a 51 percent "good progressive" cutoff that exempts them from condemnation. Others argue that reactionary sins may cancel out all the progressive good, at least in the eyes of self-styled moral superiors.

The debate also raises questions about the ultimate purpose of progressives condemning the past. Does toppling a statue or renaming a building improve racial relations or reduce unemployment in the inner city? Does it make us feel better about doing something symbolic when we can't do something substantive? Or is it a sign of raw power and ego when activists force authorities to cave to their threats and remove images and names in the dead of night?

The debate over historical figures with controversial pasts is a complex one, with no easy answers. It raises questions about moral judgment, selective memory, and the role of historical figures in shaping our society. As the debate continues, it is important to approach the issue with a nuanced and thoughtful perspective, recognizing the complexities and nuances of history and the role that historical figures have played in shaping our society.

Title: Analysis of Trump Derangement Syndrome and Its Implications

Article:

The concept of Trump Derangement Syndrome, a term coined over a decade ago, has resurfaced in recent times, characterized by intense criticism and perceived psychological issues towards President Donald Trump. This syndrome is not just general outrage towards the president, but also the inability to discern legitimate policy differences from signs of mental instability.

One example of this is Trump's decision regarding climate change and the Paris Agreement. The response to his withdrawal was met with hyperbolic language, such as "America just resigned as leader of the free world." However, the Paris Agreement, according to the author, was a failure due to its lack of uniform commitments and enforcement provisions. Critics argue that developing countries like China and India should be given leeway due to a two-century head start in industrialization.

The author argues that the Paris Agreement was "hot air" and withdrawing was a reasonable policy choice. The subsequent attacks on Trump were deemed unhinged due to the president's other behavior providing ample opportunity for shock and dismay.

The article also discusses Trump's tweets, which the author suggests serve as a direct conduit from the president's unconscious mind. The president's tweets have been criticized for their inappropriate and insensitive content, particularly during times of crisis.

Examples of this include Trump's tweets mocking the mayor of London after a terror attack, using the atrocity to renew an old feud with a foreign official, and undermining the case for his travel ban as it goes to the Supreme Court. The author also criticizes Trump's tweets about the administration's "extreme vetting" process, which contradicts the purpose of the travel ban.

The article concludes by questioning the sustainability of Trump's behavior, quoting economist Herb Stein's statement, "If something can not go on forever, it will stop." However, the author expresses doubt about what, other than a smoking gun produced by the Russia inquiry, could actually stop Trump's behavior.

The article does not take a political stance but instead provides a critical analysis of Trump's behavior and the concept of Trump Derangement Syndrome. It is important to note that the author's opinions and interpretations are presented as such, and readers are encouraged to form their own conclusions based on the information provided.

Title: First Lady Michelle Obama Discusses Alleged Racial Experiences in Interview

Article:

In an exclusive interview with People magazine, First Lady Michelle Obama discussed her experiences with alleged racism. The interview, published this week, details an incident at a Target store where she felt she was treated as a subservient.

According to the interview, Mrs. Obama recounted an incident where a woman asked her for help reaching an item on a shelf. She described this as a "challenge" for the country to overcome, stating that such incidents are "the regular course of life" for African-Americans.

However, it is important to note that the specific details of the incident, as well as the broader context of the experiences Mrs. Obama described, have been met with skepticism by some. Critics argue that the incident at Target, as described, is not an example of racism but rather a common act of courtesy between equals.

In the past, Mrs. Obama has shared a similar anecdote, but in a different context. In 2012, she recounted the same incident on David Letterman's show, presenting it as a feel-good story demonstrating her relatability.

The first lady's discussion of her experiences has sparked debate, with some arguing that her narrative is a calculated attempt to pander to America's aggrieved leftists. Critics point to her past statements and actions, such as her senior thesis at Princeton University, titled "Princeton-Educated Blacks and the Black Community," which decried her racial otherness and accused her university of pushing her towards "assimilation into a white cultural and social structure."

Despite these criticisms, it is important to approach such discussions with a nuanced and balanced perspective, recognizing the complexities and nuances of race relations in America.

Title: Senate Votes to Proceed with Impeachment Trial Without Additional Witnesses or Evidence

Article:

The United States Senate voted 51-49 on Friday to set rules for the impeachment trial of President Donald Trump that do not allow for any more witnesses or motions. The vote ensures that the trial will proceed without additional testimony or evidence, and a final vote is set for Wednesday at 4 p.m., where Trump is expected to be acquitted.

The decision to proceed without witnesses was met with criticism from Democrats, who argued that a trial without witnesses and evidence would not be legitimate. Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer (D-NY) said, "To not allow a witness, a document, no witnesses, no documents, in an impeachment trial is a perfidy. It's a grand tragedy."

Republicans countered that Democrats bungled the impeachment in the House, denying Trump fair rights and delivering two articles that were fatally flawed. One White House official said Speaker Nancy Pelosi's (D-CA) move to hold onto the articles for weeks, saying she wanted to try to dictate the terms of the Senate's trial, helped build GOP unity against the impeachment effort.

One of the most significant mistakes made by Democrats was Sen. Elizabeth Warren's (D-MA) attempt to drag Supreme Court Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. into the political fray. In a question to the chief justice, Warren asked, "At a time when large majorities of Americans have lost faith in government, does the fact that the chief justice is presiding over an impeachment trial in which Republican senators have thus far refused to allow witnesses or evidence contribute to the loss of legitimacy of the chief justice, the Supreme Court, and the Constitution?"

Republican senators say no such threats had been made, and for Warren to suggest it irked key GOP lawmakers. Sen. Lisa Murkowski (R-AK) said it had "become clear some of my colleagues intend to further politicize this process, and drag the Supreme Court into the fray, while attacking the chief justice."

In the final days of last week, Democrats made several other efforts to try to rope the chief justice into the political fray, including offering a proposal to have the Senate outsource key decisions over witnesses and evidence to him.

With Sen. Murkowski firmly in the GOP corner, the Senate was able to avoid a tie-breaking vote by the chief justice, preserving his independence. Chief Justice Roberts made clear he would have declined to cast a vote anyway.

The handful of Republicans sympathetic to the Democrats' complaints about the president didn't go as far as Schumer in criticizing the Democrats' handling of the impeachment trial. Sen. Lamar Alexander (R-TN) called Trump's demand for Ukraine to investigate a political opponent "inappropriate," but said the answer was to let voters decide, not remove the president by Senate conviction.

Alexander was the 50th vote against witnesses, and Sen. Murkowski was the crucial 51st. In the case of a 50-50 tie, the chief justice would have been under pressure to cast a tie-breaking vote. With Murkowski in board, the GOP was able to avoid that and preserve the chief justice's independence.

Title: Transgender Employee Fired After Allegedly Harassing Conservative Customer at Cultiva Espresso & Crepes

Article:

A transgender employee of Cultiva Espresso & Crepes in Lincoln, Nebraska, was fired after reportedly verbally abusing a conservative customer. The incident, which occurred on Wednesday, involved Marilyn Synek, a communications specialist who was identified as a former volunteer for Republican U.S. Senator Ben Sasse and a supporter of the Nebraska Family Alliance, a conservative policy organization.

According to the Washington Examiner, Synek, 23, told the paper that an employee approached her, called her by name, and began yelling profanities at her. The employee allegedly asked Synek to leave and informed her that she would be denied service due to her "bigoted" views.

Synek, who stated she frequents the coffee shop weekly, also told the Examiner that the employee declared, "You are f*cking bigoted trash, and we do not want you in our restaurant."
