The employee reportedly added, "Over 80 percent of the people who work here are queer. You are not f*cking wanted in our restaurant, so get out and don't come back!"

The employee, Natalie Weiss, wrote on Facebook that "when this person was leaving the store, I told them in no uncertain terms, and admittedly vulgar ones, that they were not welcome to come back." Weiss added that the Nebraska Family Alliance "really is a bigoted anti-LGBT2QIA+ organization who lobbies every year for legalized discrimination against my community in my state" and that "apparently Cultiva would like their LGBT2QIA+ staff to understand they must serve our literal societal oppressors with a smile."

Cultiva Espresso & Crepes management wrote on Facebook that the employee in question was "fired almost immediately" following the incident. The management stated, "We're proudly liberal personally, and believe in human rights and diversity to the fullest degree. Let it be known that we would * never * condone treating a customer this way."

The management further explained, "We're running a business, and we try to instill professionalism in our staff, usually successfully." They added, "We're more than happy to have people sit in our stores and discuss politics with civility, as has been a tradition in coffee shops for centuries. When the heat rises to this level, it's not good for anybody."

The management continued, "We'd like everyone to know that * anyone * is welcome in our stores anytime, as long as they're not harassing customers or staff members, committing crimes, damaging property, etc. Whatever your race, religion, gender identity, or general political beliefs, we just want you to enjoy our food and coffee, and have a good time, and tell other people you had a good time."

Weiss, in a subsequent Facebook post, noted, "Cultiva Espresso & Crepes, you just let neo-conservative Trump allies drive out a trans employee." She added, "So, for those keeping track, in Nebraska, you can be fired or lose your home because you identify in the LGBT2QIA+ umbrella, and you can also be fired for telling people who fight for that status quo to get lost."

According to the Lincoln Journal Star, Synek said that while she believes Americans can disagree politically, she hopes the incident demonstrates the need for civility. Synek also noted that the coffee shop's owners apologized to her personally and asked her to return, the paper said.

"I've always enjoyed their coffee and crepes, and I accept their apology," Synek added, according to the Journal Star.

Title: Former Senator John Edwards Acquitted on One Count, Mistrial Declared in Corruption Case

Article:

John Edwards, the former Democratic presidential candidate, walked out of a federal courthouse in North Carolina on Thursday afternoon following a mistrial declaration in his high-profile corruption case. The jury found him not guilty on one count of accepting illegal campaign contributions but were deadlocked on the remaining five counts, leading to the mistrial decision by Judge Catherine Eagles.

The former senator was on trial for allegedly skirting campaign finance law by using contributions to keep secret his extramarital affair during the 2008 campaign. Prosecutors argued he knowingly had nearly $1 million in donations channeled to his mistress to keep her silent and prevent the affair from derailing his presidential bid. The defense argued he was merely trying to keep the secret from his wife.

The one count on which Edwards was acquitted was a charge that he received campaign contributions from wealthy donor Rachel "Bunny" Mellon in excess of the legal limit in 2008. Other counts were similar, though the jury could not come to an agreement.

The mistrial announcement followed a day marked by confusion and miscommunication at the North Carolina courthouse. The judge initially indicated the jury was ready to announce a verdict on all counts by mid-afternoon Thursday. However, the jury had only reached a verdict on one count. In response, the defense argued for a mistrial. But Eagles initially granted the prosecution's request to urge the jurors to resume deliberations. She later apologized for calling them into the courtroom and then sending them back for more discussions.

Edwards, a former U.S. senator, had faced a maximum sentence of 30 years in prison. In his emotional statement on the courthouse steps, Edwards spoke of his love for his daughter, Frances Quinn Hunter, whom he fathered out of wedlock with his mistress Rielle Hunter. He also expressed his desire to continue helping children in need.

"I really believe (God) thinks there's still some good things I can do," Edwards said. "Whatever happens with this legal stuff going forward, what I'm hopeful about is all those kids that I've seen, you know, in the poorest parts of this country and in some of the poorest places in the world, that I can help them, in whatever way I'm still capable of helping them."

The trial brought out lurid testimony from a succession of witnesses who described the behind-the-scenes drama involving Edwards' family and his staff as they began to learn of his affair. It is unclear whether federal prosecutors will seek to retry Edwards. A Justice Department spokeswoman had no immediate comment on the next step. A law enforcement official later told Fox News that it is unlikely the Justice Department would retry Edwards.

Title: June Jobs Report Shatters Expectations, Media Outlets Question Report's Legitimacy Amidst Rising COVID-19 Cases

Article:

The June jobs report, released on Thursday, surpassed expectations with a gain of 4.8 million jobs and an unemployment rate of 11.1 percent. However, several broadcast network evening newscasts questioned the report's legitimacy due to the recent surge in coronavirus cases across the country.

ABC, CBS, and NBC collectively presented a "reality check" due to the report being based on data collected before the recent spike in coronavirus cases. They suggested that the economy could face another setback as a result of the ongoing pandemic.

CBS Evening News anchor Margaret Brennan stated, "The President celebrates as the economy adds nearly five million jobs, but will that work dry up as businesses are forced to shut down again?" During two segments totaling over three minutes, Brennan emphasized that the good news came with a "big catch."

Correspondent Adriana Diaz warned that the positive numbers were taken before many states experienced a resurgence in coronavirus cases. She also noted that the unemployment rates for Black and Hispanic workers were significantly higher than the national average, at 14.5 percent and 15.4 percent, respectively.

White House correspondent Weijia Jiang, known for her critical stance towards the Trump administration, further questioned the report's legitimacy and praised Joe Biden for his criticism of the President's optimism.

NBC Nightly News anchor Lester Holt also expressed skepticism, stating that the record number of jobs added was "not telling the whole story." White House correspondent Peter Alexander echoed this sentiment, suggesting that while Americans were returning to work faster than expected, many of the jobs added were not new positions but rather furloughed workers returning to their previous jobs.

ABC's World News Tonight ran a chyron during the opening teases stating, "Recovery Reality Check." Weekend anchor Tom Llamas warned that while the jobs report was "good news," critics were "cautious" due to 19 states either reversing course on reopening or pausing their reopening plans.

Chief business correspondent Rebecca Jarvis was slightly more balanced in her reporting, acknowledging both the record rehiring and the ongoing layoffs. She also noted that analysts expect the White House will allow the $600 weekly unemployment benefit to expire at the end of the month, although some additional stimulus may be necessary due to persistent layoffs and high unemployment rates.

These dismissals of the June jobs report were made possible by advertisers such as IBM (on ABC), Capital One (on CBS), and Liberty Mutual (on NBC). The relevant contact information can be found in the hyperlinks.

Title: Senate Democrats and Republicans Disagree on Timing of Supreme Court Justice Scalia's Replacement

Article:

The passing of Supreme Court Justice Antonin Scalia, a conservative justice who died on Saturday in Texas, has sparked a dispute between Senate Democrats and Republicans over the timing of his replacement. The vacancy, which arises in an election year, has led to a disagreement over whether the Constitution compels President Obama to act or if the court should function with eight members until a new president is elected.

Senate Democrats argue that there is no constitutional clause that prevents President Obama from nominating a replacement, while Republicans contend that the high court can function with eight members, allowing voters to shape its future. Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, a Kentucky Republican, has already ruled out a vote this year, stating that the American people should have a voice in the selection of their next Supreme Court justice.

Justice Scalia, who was 79, was found dead in his room at a West Texas resort early Saturday after he did not come out for breakfast. Known for his outspoken and often humorous demeanor, he endeared himself to conservatives during his three decades on the bench while vexing liberals who frequently disagreed with him yet admired his candor.

The debate over Justice Scalia's replacement adds a remarkable wrinkle to an already challenging year on Capitol Hill. Republicans in charge of both chambers say there are few opportunities for bipartisan agreement, though mental health care reform could be one. Instead, House Speaker Paul D. Ryan, a Wisconsin Republican, wants to put forth an agenda of "ideas," offering voters a clear contrast to President Obama's agenda. Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell wants to get back to basics by passing a budget and all twelve appropriation bills in a legislative year shortened by this summer's nominating conventions and November's general elections.

The standoff has already spilled onto the campaign trail, with Senate candidates discussing the issue. Texas Senator and presidential candidate Ted Cruz said his chief rival, businessman Donald Trump, could not be trusted to nominate a worthy replacement. Cruz argued that Americans' right to bear arms and other "basic liberties" would be at risk if President Obama is able to tilt the court toward a liberal majority.

Other candidates, such as Senators Marco Rubio of Florida and Bernie Sanders of Vermont, have also weighed in on the issue, expressing their opinions on the constitutional process for filling a Supreme Court vacancy. The debate is expected to continue as both parties jockey for position ahead of the 2016 elections.

Title: Congress Frustrated as Obama Delays Request for Authorization for Use of Military Force Against ISIS

Article:

The ongoing war against the Islamic State (ISIS) has sparked frustration among members of Congress, as President Barack Obama has yet to formally request an Authorization for Use of Military Force (AUMF). The Washington Times reports that Sen. Lindsey Graham (R-S.C.) expressed his discontent, stating, "The process should come from him. He’s the commander in chief. If he feels he needs this authority, he wants this authority, then he should be the leader. He should write down what he’s looking for in terms of authority and let us debate it."

Sen. Robert Menendez (D-N.J.) also voiced his concern, stating, "I have always felt that we should be continuing on an AUMF, but it’s a little difficult when the administration doesn’t produce any witnesses. So either they want an AUMF or they don’t."

Fox News Channel host Bill O'Reilly, commenting on the recent beheading of Peter Kassig, 26, of Indiana by ISIS, said, "The bad guys are winning and the president seems hesitant to do what's necessary to turn things around. He can talk all he wants. Meantime, Americans are being murdered."

Robert Gates, Obama's former defense secretary, expressed his belief that Iraqi troops need U.S. special operations troops on the ground to defeat ISIS. The Washington Post reported Gates' statement, "When you deny the military the authorities they require to achieve the objective, you leave them with a great sense of frustration."

Bernadette Meehan of the National Security Council told the Times that "the administration continues to have conversations with members of both parties regarding an AUMF to suit the current fight and our current strategy against ISIS." However, Graham insists a written request is needed. "I think he doesn't want to make that hard decision," he told the Times. "He doesn't want to write down on a piece of paper what he would like Congress to do because he's afraid of the left."

The Washington Post commented that "Mr. Obama appears to recognize the severity of the threat posed by the Islamic State (ISIS) and appears to be focused on the job of leading the fight against it. But if he continues to allow his ideological resistance to steps such as the deployment of ground forces to constrain the campaign, he will ensure its failure."

Obama has stated that a final resolution on the approach to the campaign against ISIS "may carry over into the next Congress," according to The Washington Times. The New York Times argues that instead of waiting on Obama to act, Congress should take action immediately on its own. "Increasingly, it seems as if the current lame-duck Congress will leave the issue to the next one," the Times wrote. "The priority in the lame-duck session should be to pass a new and separate authorization for the war against ISIS."

Title: Trump's Decision on Obamacare Subsidies Leaves Health Insurance Market in Limbo

Article:

President Donald Trump's recent reversals on maintaining Obamacare subsidies to insurers have created uncertainty about the availability and cost of health insurance for consumers when enrollment for 2018 begins in two weeks.

Last week, Trump announced his administration would stop paying billions of dollars in subsidies that help insurers provide discounts to low-income households, one of several moves to dismantle the Affordable Care Act (ACA), also known as Obamacare. However, Trump has since shown support and dismissed an effort by Republican and Democratic senators to reinstate the subsidies for two years, until a broader replacement for the 2010 ACA can be negotiated.

Bryna Koch, special projects coordinator at the Arizona Center for Rural Health, expressed concern that consumers on Obamacare plans may be confused by the back-and-forth and proposed policy changes, which could lead them to not seek assistance.

Trump, who campaigned on repealing and replacing Obamacare, has called the subsidies a "bailout" for insurance companies. By law, health insurers must still offer the discounts on deductibles, co-pays, and other out-of-pocket costs, even if the government stops reimbursing them. Insurers say they do not profit from the subsidies.

In anticipation of Trump's move, insurers proposed higher premiums for 2018 to recoup the lost funding. In all but a handful of states, they submitted two sets of premium rates—a lower rate to use if the subsidies remained, and a higher rate to use if the funding was cut.

The fate of the subsidies remained uncertain on Thursday. A senior White House aide stated that Trump would demand steps toward repealing Obamacare in any healthcare legislation, casting doubt on the prospects for the bipartisan effort to shore up insurance markets.

A California court is expected to consider on Monday a request by Democratic attorneys general to keep the subsidies flowing until a legal challenge to Trump's decision is resolved. If the funding is not restored when 2018 enrollment opens on Nov. 1, many consumers will see premium rates that are on average 20 percent higher than they would have been otherwise.

Even before Trump's decision on the subsidies, the Congressional Budget Office (CBO) predicted that the Republican president's policies to roll back Obamacare enrollment efforts would lead to 4 million fewer people signing up for insurance in 2018 than previously forecast. The CBO still expects 11 million people to sign up for next year—an increase from this year's enrollment of 10 million.

The federal government has already halted a subsidy payment to the insurance industry for October. However, leading insurers are not yet sure whether that is the last word. Anthem Inc. Chief Executive Officer Joseph Swedish told ███ he could not yet predict how ending the subsidies or restoring them through "potential congressional action" would affect pricing next year. Anthem has submitted premium rates that account for the subsidies being cut.

Should the subsidies be restored at any time after Nov. 1, insurers may be able to revert to the lower monthly premium rates or provide rebates for consumers. "A midyear change in premiums would be highly unusual, but this would be the right thing to do," said Marc Harrison, CEO of Intermountain Healthcare, a Utah-based health plan and hospital chain. "Intermountain Healthcare would pursue this."

Washington state's insurance regulator said it would allow insurers to change rates as soon as practical—even the next month—if lawmakers reinstate the funding, an approach backed by the National Association of Insurance Commissioners. However, this could run up against federal government objections, as the Affordable Care Act does not allow for changes to premium rates after they have been finalized. The administration is working to approve higher rates in several states that did not take into account Trump's cut in subsidies for 2018.

Title: Hungary Declares State of Emergency, Deploys Military to Border Amid Migration Crisis

Article:

Hungary has declared a state of emergency in two of its southeastern counties, a move that enables the deployment of the military to the border with Serbia in an attempt to stem the flow of migrants entering the country. The state of emergency grants authorities increased powers to manage the crisis, allowing them to close roads, limit the functioning of public institutions, and expedite court processes for asylum-seekers.

The state of emergency, which requires parliamentary approval for the military deployment, has already seen heavily armed military personnel, vehicles, and dogs at the border in recent days, according to Associated Press reporters.

The declaration comes as Hungary enacted tougher laws on Tuesday aimed at preventing asylum-seekers from entering the country. The legislation criminalizes attempts to breach the razor-wire fence along the border with Serbia and includes longer prison terms for convicted human traffickers.

Two of seven border crossings with Serbia were closed Tuesday morning, and a boxcar covered with razor wire was used to close a key border crossing along a railroad track, which had been the main entry point for migrants.

Chaotic scenes were reported at the main border crossing near Roszke, Hungary, as Hungarian authorities opened a temporary office to process people on the edge of no man's land, and crowds tried to enter. A small group of about 20 managed to enter, but thousands remained outside.

A group of migrants also blocked the main highway connecting Serbia and Hungary, stating they would refuse food and water until they are allowed to cross into Hungary. The sit-in protest is happening on the no man's land between Roszke and Horgos, Serbia, the main border crossing between the two countries.

Those who made it into Hungary the day before were boarding buses, with a Hungarian police officer confirming they were being sent directly to Austria.

In recent days, people have rushed to enter Hungary, hoping to reach Western Europe before it was too late. A record 9,380 migrants entered Hungary on Monday, surpassing the previous record of 5,809 set just a day earlier.

As of 2015, approximately 200,000 migrants have entered Hungary, with almost all entering by foot across the southern border with Serbia. However, most migrants simply transit Hungary on their way to Germany or other Western European nations.

Under the new laws, most migrants entering Hungary from Serbia can be turned away because Serbia is considered a safe country and could theoretically provide asylum. The new law also makes it a crime to damage the 4-meter razor-wire fence that Hungary has built on the 110-mile border with Serbia, giving police the power to detain anyone trying to breach it.

The state of emergency allows the government to mobilize the army, pending parliamentary approval next week, to assist police with border control. Courts are also required to prioritize cases involving migrants caught entering Hungary illegally. Police can enter and search homes where migrants who entered Hungary illegally are believed to be hiding.

Germany's interior minister, Thomas de Maiziere, on Tuesday expressed support for the idea of cutting European Union funding to countries that refuse to share the burden of hosting refugees. Several EU countries, particularly those in the former Eastern bloc, have rejected calls from Germany and the EU's executive Commission for mandatory quotas to distribute refugees among the 28-nation bloc.

De Maiziere suggested that there should be discussions on how to exert pressure, stating that countries rejecting quotas often receive significant amounts of EU funding. He also mentioned that Commission chief Jean-Claude Juncker has suggested reducing funding from the structural funds for such countries.

Title: Local Politicians Adopt Bipartisan Approach Amid Federal Government Shutdown

Article:

Across the United States, local politicians are adopting a bipartisan approach in the face of the ongoing federal government shutdown. From New Jersey to California, Republican and Democratic officials are emulating each other's strategies to ensure the delivery of essential services to their constituents.

Indiana's Republican Governor, Mike Pence, announced on Tuesday that the state will fund food stamps and welfare checks during the shutdown. In Wisconsin, Republican Governor Scott Walker, known for his battles with public sector labor unions, has removed barriers to a federally supported boat launch on the Mississippi and has stated that the state will fund state parks that were ordered shut down due to their reliance on federal funds.

In California, Democratic Governor Jerry Brown, who has been reluctant to announce plans to help those affected by the shutdown, is being praised for his fiscal conservatism. As the shutdown continues, David McCuan, political science professor at Sonoma State University in Rohnert Park, California, predicts that there will be more and more "purple ground" at the local level.

"It's no longer the suburbs versus the cities; it's delivery of services to the people," McCuan says, referencing an old adage that there are no Democratic or Republican streets, only American streets. Over the long term, if the shutdown persists, McCuan anticipates this tone will rise to the national level as well, with increasing calls for moderates in both parties to find common ground.

Politicians' decisions are influenced by politics, notes government policy attorney Leonard Wolfe of Dykema in Lansing, Michigan. "Politicians who are up for reelection want to show that they are in control of their state," he says, explaining that the average voter does not differentiate between the source of their government services.

"People want to know why they can't get into their parks or get their benefits check," Wolfe says, adding that they are not interested in partisanship. "They expect their local politicians to be able to help," he says. Consequently, politicians are making gestures that signal, "I am in control here."

Republican Governor Chris Christie of New Jersey has released a campaign ad with the slogan, "Compromise is not a dirty word." However, there are limits to how much local politicians can "bail out" the federal government, even when they are inclined to do so, points out Christine Kelleher-Palus, associate professor and chair of Villanova University's Department of Public Administration in Philadelphia.

The recent economic downturn has left states in a difficult position, and they are struggling in many areas due to the shutdown, Kelleher-Palus says via email. "States are doing a lot of analyses and contingency planning – trying to figure out how individual programs are affected, and for how long they can be sustained," she says.

Political analyst Barbara O'Connor, director emeritus of the Institute for the Study of Politics and Media at California State University, Sacramento, notes that New Jersey's Governor Christie has been unpredictable and that he terrifies Republicans because they can't count on him to toe the party line. However, with the safety net being threatened for an ever-widening group of constituents, O'Connor expects more politicians to be willing to do the "helpful thing."

In California, Governor Brown has also been a source of unexpected moves, a trend O'Connor expects to continue. "Remember that he is a Jesuit who lived with Mother Teresa," she says, referring to Brown's religious background, "yet he has held the line on expenses and been touted for his frugality."

The bigger question, O'Connor says, is how more extreme politicians will respond as the shared pain spreads among constituents. "It's an interesting drama, and we don't know how it will play out," she concludes.

Title: Former Massachusetts Governor Michael Dukakis Discusses Democratic Presidential Candidates' Challenges

Article:

In a recent statement, former Massachusetts Governor Michael S. Dukakis, the Democratic presidential nominee in 1988, expressed concerns about the current state of the U.S. tax system and its impact on the Democratic party. He stated, "When you have a tax system that is so horribly skewed and loaded with loopholes as ours has become, and big companies don't have significant taxes to pay, you're seeing a lot of Democrats asking what their party is going to do about it."

During his statement, Dukakis also mentioned his support for Hillary Clinton, stating, "The vast majority of people should be doing better in this economic recovery." He further commented on the struggles of both Clinton and Bernie Sanders, the current Democratic presidential candidates, to convincingly sell a vision to majorities of voters in Iowa and New Hampshire, despite months of trying.

Sanders, who has been criticized for his tax plans and lack of foreign policy experience, has raised concerns among some Democrats that he would focus on the economy at the expense of a strong American role in the world. For his supporters, however, Sanders' vision for the party is inspiring, with Erin Bilbray, a Nevada Democrat who ran for Congress in 2014, stating that she was willing to pay more in taxes to guarantee health insurance for her children.

Clinton, on the other hand, faces negative feelings among some voters who see her as too close to Wall Street and too hawkish on foreign policy. In a recent poll, 55 percent of likely Democratic primary voters in New Hampshire called Clinton the least honest candidate in the party's field, compared with 46 percent in December.

Title: White House and Democrats Respond to Contempt Proceedings Against Attorney General Eric Holder

Article:

In a series of statements on Thursday, Democrats, including House Speaker Nancy Pelosi and White House Press Secretary Jay Carney, responded to the contempt proceedings against Attorney General Eric Holder. The proceedings, initiated by Republicans, are in response to the Department of Justice's (DOJ) crackdown on state voter ID laws and the ongoing investigation into Operation Fast and Furious.

Republicans, who have voted in favor of contempt at the committee level, are seeking more than 70,000 additional documents to answer questions on Fast and Furious. The White House, through Carney, described the contempt case as a "fishing expedition," while Pelosi accused Republicans of targeting Holder due to his efforts to overturn voter suppression in the states.

Carney, when asked about Pelosi's claim, could not "divine" Republicans' motivation for pursuing the contempt case against Holder. However, he defended both Holder and President Obama for asserting executive privilege over the documents Republicans are seeking. The documents in question, according to Carney, are "internal Executive Branch documents."

The executive privilege claim, which has been invoked 24 times since the presidency of Ronald Reagan, does not necessarily imply the president or White House staff were involved in the Fast and Furious discussions, according to Justice Department officials. They argued that any "deliberative communications" among officials in the Executive Branch could be covered by the privilege assertion.

Meanwhile, House Speaker John Boehner suggested that the White House's decision to invoke executive privilege implies White House officials were involved in decisions that misled Congress and covered up the truth regarding Fast and Furious. Sen. Marco Rubio, R-Fla., also added his name to the list of lawmakers calling for Holder's resignation.

The White House and Justice Department downplayed the potential implications of the executive privilege claim, with Justice Department officials noting that the privilege assertion does not have to pertain to communications involving the president or White House staff. Any "deliberative communications" among officials in the Executive Branch, they said, could be covered.

Title: Lawyers for Trump Seek to Halt Release of Book Containing Allegations About Administration

Article:

Lawyers for U.S. President Donald Trump are attempting to prevent the release of a book containing damaging allegations about his administration. The book, "Fire and Fury: Inside the Trump White House," cites former top aide Steve Bannon as describing a meeting with a group of Russians as "treasonous." The book also portrays Mr. Trump as being surprised at winning the presidency.

Despite the legal threat, the book's publishers have brought its release forward. Initially scheduled for Tuesday, the book's author, Michael Wolff, announced that it would now be available for purchase on Friday. The White House has disputed the book's accuracy. Mr. Trump earlier stated that Mr. Bannon, who was dismissed in August, had "lost his mind" after losing his White House position.

Among a number of explosive statements, Mr. Bannon reportedly said, referring to a Trump Tower meeting between top campaign officials and Russia, "They're going to crack Don Junior like an egg on national TV." The meeting, which involved Mr. Trump's eldest child Donald Trump Jr., is being investigated by Special Counsel Robert Mueller as part of his inquiry into possible collusion between Trump campaign officials and Russia to win the election.

On his Breitbart radio show on Wednesday, Mr. Bannon responded to the president's criticism by saying he was a "great man" and that he supported him "day in and day out." After the president met Republican senators in the Oval Office to discuss immigration on Thursday, a reporter asked Mr. Trump if his former strategist had betrayed him. He responded, "I don't know, he called me a great man last night so he obviously changed his tune pretty quick."

The legal notice, which has been published by the Washington Post, demands that author Michael Wolff and the book's publisher "immediately cease and desist from any further publication, release or dissemination of the book." It accuses Wolff of making "numerous false and/or baseless statements" about Mr. Trump and says lawyers are considering pursuing libel charges.

The lawyers base their notice on excerpts of the book published in publications including New York Magazine and ask for a full copy of the book to be sent to them. The letter says the book "appears to cite to [sic] no sources for many of its most damaging statements about Mr. Trump" and that many claims are made without citing sources. Neither Wolff nor the publisher, Henry Holt and Co Inc, have yet responded.

The attorney who wrote the letter, Charles J. Harder, has been called Hollywood's favorite lawyer. He represents Jared Kushner, and represented wrestler Hulk Hogan in his case against now-defunct news website Gawker. Mr. Harder also briefly represented disgraced film producer Harvey Weinstein. He sent a cease-and-desist letter to Mr. Bannon on Wednesday, saying he had violated a non-disclosure agreement.

The book is reportedly based on more than 200 interviews, but some of the book's excerpts have already been criticized and questioned. Still, even if only half of what the book contains is true, it paints a damning portrait of a paranoid president and a chaotic White House, according to BBC North America editor Jon Sopel.

Donald Trump might want to familiarize himself with the so-called Streisand Effect. The lesson, most prominently learned by singer Barbra Streisand when she tried to quash photographs of her home that appeared on an obscure website, is that the more you fight against undesirable news, the more you call attention to it.

Thanks to his lawyer's "cease and desist" letter, Mr. Trump is giving Michael Wolff and his explosive book the kind of massive publicity boost money alone can't buy. The highly critical allegations are leading every news program and newspaper front page (and burying the latest round of glowing U.S. economic news that might otherwise garner attention).

Threatening lawsuits is a common tactic for Mr. Trump, dating back to his days as a New York real estate mogul. Very seldom does he follow up with actual court action. In this case, such a move would be particularly risky. To meet the "actual malice" requirement of U.S. libel law, the president would open himself up to investigation from opposing lawyers seeking to prove that Wolff's allegations had substance—or, at the very least, that he had reason to believe they did.

"Steve Bannon has nothing to do with me or my presidency," Mr. Trump said in a statement on Wednesday. Press secretary Sarah Sanders dismissed the book as a "trashy tabloid fiction" that she said was "filled with false and misleading accounts from individuals who have no access or influence with the White House."

A spokesperson for Melania Trump said the First Lady had encouraged her husband's presidential bid. "She was confident he would win and was very happy when he did," she said on Wednesday. On Thursday, the White House said it was banning personal devices, including mobile phones, from the West Wing, citing security concerns.

In researching the book, Wolff said he had been able to take up "something like a semi-permanent seat on a couch in the West Wing" following the president's inauguration.

Title: National Security Advisor McMaster Allegedly Linked to George Soros, According to Multiple Intelligence Sources

Article:

Three separate domestic and foreign intelligence sources have reported that National Security Advisor H.R. McMaster is an active operative of globalist billionaire George Soros. The allegations suggest that McMaster is a foreign intelligence agent for a multi-national combine controlled by Soros, which may explain his perceived efforts to obstruct President Trump's agenda.

Roger Stone, a correspondent for ███, reported that he has received confirmation from sources within the White House, the Israeli government, and Israeli intelligence that General McMaster has been communicating with George Soros, providing him with information about what is happening inside the White House. Stone claims to have verified this information with two different high-level sources within Israeli intelligence, and expects the Israeli ambassador to the US to confirm it.

The implication of this allegation is that McMaster is a primary leaker, given Soros' extensive ties to the mainstream media. It is already known that McMaster was a member of the International Institute for Strategic Studies, an organization that was funded by Soros' Open Society Foundation and another Soros-financed group.

Last month, Israel publicly accused Soros of undermining democratically-elected governments. The Israeli Ministry of Foreign Affairs criticized Soros when it spoke out against the vandalism of anti-Soros posters in Hungary, which were defaced with anti-Semitic graffiti. The Ministry stated that it deplores any expression of anti-Semitism in any country and stands with Jewish communities everywhere in confronting this hatred. However, the statement also criticized Soros for continuously undermining Israel's democratically elected governments by funding organizations that defame the Jewish state and seek to deny it the right to defend itself.

Soros began infiltrating the National Security Council as early as May when his operative Fiona Hill, a member of the Council on Foreign Relations and the Soros-funded Eurasia Foundation, joined its staff. Stone reported that Soros has planted a mole in the National Security apparatus in the form of Fiona Hill, who has a Harvard background and has been on the Soros payroll and the payroll of the Open Society Institute.

Hill has been associated with the Soros-founded Central European University (CEU) in Hungary, which has tried to influence the Hungarian government, which has defiantly refused EU migrant quotas and Soros' meddling in its affairs. CEU's rector, Michael Ignatieff, stated that they received unequivocal support from Hill's team at the National Security Council. Ignatieff also noted that there is a tiny ledge of commonality between Republicans and Democrats, and academic freedom is one issue that unites them both.

However, it is unlikely that "academic freedom" exists at CEU, given that it was founded by Soros, a globalist socialist known for bankrolling institutions that promote his political agenda. It is also no secret that academic institutions are routinely used to steer government policies as part of the interconnected, globalist network of academia, technology, government, and media.

Title: Potential Executive Actions on Gun Control by Obama Administration

Article:

The Obama administration has hinted at taking executive actions on gun control and gun-related violence, prompting questions about the specific measures they might implement without Congressional approval.

According to The New York Times, one potential action could involve strengthening the FBI's background check database. Currently, federal agencies that do not contribute to the database, such as the Social Security Administration, have access to mental competence information about prospective gun buyers, or details about failed drug tests and other issues that might prevent a sale to the wrong person. The president could also demand that states share more information from their crime and mental-health databases.

The Hill reports that the specific executive orders Obama is considering are unclear, but a Democratic aide familiar with the discussions suggests that the president could bypass Congress and bolster federally funded mental-health programs.

The coalition of Mayors Against Illegal Guns, led by New York Mayor Michael Bloomberg, has called for Obama to consider several measures that they claim can be implemented without congressional approval. These include stepping up prosecution by the Justice Department of felons and others prohibited from buying weapons when they attempt to do so, requiring federal agencies to report records to the National Instant Criminal Background Check System, and appointing an ATF director. The federal agency charged with enforcing gun laws has been without a confirmed director for six years.

The Times adds that most changes to the current system, which allows easy access to weapons with hugely destructive power, will likely require legislation.

Following the Dec. 14 mass shooting at Sandy Hook Elementary School in Newtown, Conn., Vice President Biden was tasked with presenting "concrete proposals" on reducing gun violence this month. Among the groups he is due to meet with today is the National Rifle Association.

Update at 12:35 p.m. ET: Biden Sees Recommendations Coming On Universal Background Checks And High-Capacity Magazines:

At the White House a short time ago, Biden stated that there has been broad agreement among the groups he has met with so far that a system of "universal background checks" for gun purchasers needs to be established. Additionally, he said, there has been broad agreement for controls on high-capacity ammunition magazines. Based on past statements from NRA leaders, it is unlikely they are among those Biden is speaking about when he talks of agreement on these issues.

Title: Pete Buttigieg Launches Bid for Democratic Presidential Nomination

Article:

Pete Buttigieg, the former mayor of South Bend, Indiana, has officially entered the race for the Democratic Party's nomination for the 2020 presidential election. At his launch event in South Bend, Buttigieg outlined his vision for a "re-imagined future" and differentiated himself from President Donald Trump's politics.

Should Buttigieg secure the nomination, he would become the first openly gay U.S. president. At 37, he is the youngest candidate in a crowded field that includes Vermont Senator Bernie Sanders (77) and Massachusetts Senator Elizabeth Warren (69). Despite his relative inexperience, the former Rhodes Scholar has gained momentum in recent weeks, moving from the margins to the front of the pack.

In his campaign, Buttigieg has focused on gun control, climate change, LGBT rights, and other progressive issues he hopes will appeal to millennial voters. His tenure as mayor of South Bend, during which the city's economy has improved, has also earned him praise. Since announcing his presidential run in January, Buttigieg has raised over $7 million in funds in the first quarter of 2019.

Opinion polls in Iowa and New Hampshire last week placed Buttigieg third in both states, behind Bernie Sanders and former Vice-President Joe Biden. Sanders launched his campaign last month, while Biden, who has faced allegations of inappropriate touching by several women, has yet to announce his candidacy.

At the rally, Buttigieg sought to differentiate himself from his rivals as a candidate taking the "long view," especially on issues such as climate change. "I recognize the audacity of doing this as a Midwestern millennial mayor," he said. "More than a little bold… But we live in a moment that compels us each to act. The forces changing our country today are tectonic."

More than a dozen candidates are running to be the Democratic Party's candidate for the presidential election in November 2020. The process of selecting a nominee will begin early next year.

Born in South Bend in 1982, Buttigieg studied at Harvard and Oxford, graduating from the latter in 2007 with first-class honors in philosophy, politics, and economics. He worked as a consultant at McKinsey & Company between 2007 and 2010 and served for seven months in Afghanistan as a Navy reservist in 2014. At 29, he was elected mayor of South Bend, taking office in January 2012.

Despite an unsuccessful run for chairman of the Democratic National Committee in 2017, former President Barack Obama name-checked Buttigieg as a rising star. The video announcing he will run for president focuses on his role in South Bend's redevelopment and takes aim at corruption and infighting in Washington.

Buttigieg came out as gay in 2015 and married Chasten Glezman, a middle school teacher, last year. In his rally speech, Buttigieg positioned himself as the voice of millennials. Critics say his campaign has so far emphasized values and his personal story rather than a distinctive policy agenda.

Tougher action on climate change, including the so-called "Green New Deal" proposals, and passing the Federal Equality Act, legislation that would give federal non-discrimination protections to LGBT people, are among Buttigieg's key policy priorities. The race to stop Donald Trump's re-election is underway, and many other candidates are vying for the Democratic Party's nomination.

Title: Trump's Misleading Statements at Coronavirus Briefing

Article:

President Donald Trump continued his pattern of false and misleading claims during a coronavirus briefing on Friday, as the number of confirmed cases in the United States surpassed 100,000. Here is a developing roundup of some of the President's statements and their factual inaccuracies:

1. The real state of the stock market 22 days ago
Trump claimed that 22 days ago, "everything was going beautifully" before the US was hit by the coronavirus. He said, "22 days ago we had the greatest economy in the world, everything was going beautifully, the stock market hit an all-time high."

Facts First: While the market had previously set all-time records under Trump, on March 5, 22 days before Trump's comments, the Dow dropped 3.6% or 970 points, then its fifth-worst single-day point drop on record, adding to a 3,000-point drop since its peak on February 12.

2. The current situation is unprecedented and unforeseen
Throughout Friday's press briefing, the President claimed the current situation was unprecedented and unforeseen. He said, "In all fairness to all of the former presidents, none of them ever thought a thing like this could happen."

Facts First: This is false. The US intelligence community and public health experts had warned for years that the country was at risk from a pandemic.

3. Suggesting General Motors should manufacture ventilators
As he did on Twitter earlier on Friday, Trump suggested at the briefing that General Motors should manufacture ventilators at its plant in Lordstown, Ohio.

4. Calling the coronavirus a germ, flu, or virus
Trump said, "You can call it a germ, you can call it a flu, you can call it a virus, you know you can call it many different names. I'm not sure anybody even knows what it is."

Facts First: Dr. Anthony Fauci, director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, said Thursday that the coronavirus is "very much more transmissible than flu and more importantly, it's significantly more serious" with a mortality rate approximately 10 times higher than the 0.1% for the flu.

5. Claiming thousands of ventilators were sent to New York and they were unaware
Trump said, "We sent thousands of ventilators to New York and they did not know about it at the time, they were complaining." Trump also said at the briefing that New York had been unaware of thousands of ventilators sitting in "a warehouse."

Facts First: There is no evidence that New York did not know ventilators had arrived from the federal government when Gov. Andrew Cuomo was demanding additional ventilators.

6. Claiming China pays 25% interest on $250 billion worth of product that they send in
Trump said, "China pays 25% interest on $250 billion worth of product that they send in."

Facts First: Trump was inaccurately describing his 25% tariff on $250 billion worth of Chinese products. A tariff is not the same as "interest." It is a tax paid by the importer, not a charge paid by an entity that has borrowed money.

Title: President Obama Clarifies Red Line Statement on Syria

Article:

In a press conference in Stockholm on Wednesday, President Barack Obama clarified his statement regarding a "red line" on the use of chemical weapons by Syrian President Bashar Assad.

"First of all, I did not set a red line," the President said. "The world set a red line." He explained that the world set a red line when governments representing 98% of the world's population condemned the use of chemical weapons and passed a treaty forbidding their use, even during war.

Congress, according to Obama, also set a red line by ratifying the treaty and passing the Syria Accountability Act, which indicated that certain atrocities happening in Syria needed to be addressed.

The President further clarified that the international community's credibility, as well as America and Congress's credibility, is at stake in the Syria vote. He stated, "My credibility is not on the line. The international community's credibility is on the line. And America and Congress's credibility is on the line because we give lip service to the notion that these international norms are important."

The President's comments come as the Senate Foreign Relations Committee passed a Syria use-of-force resolution on Wednesday, but only by a close 10-7 vote. President Obama lost two Democrats and five Republicans, including Senators John Barrasso of Wyoming and Marco Rubio of Florida, who are not typically considered isolationists.

The President's comments suggest that he believes America is the enforcer of world order, and that there is no substitute for the President of the United States. However, he has yet to fully grasp, according to the article, that he must lead and cannot default to the international community or Congress. If he loses on Syria, it will be because he has not led effectively.

Title: California's SB 50 Fails for Third Time in State Senate Amidst Opposition from NIMBYs and Housing Justice Advocates

Article:

California's contentious housing bill, SB 50, failed to pass out of the state Senate for the third time on Thursday, falling three votes short. The bill, which aimed to revolutionize land use and housing in the state, has been a subject of debate in the state legislature for several years. The opposition, primarily from lawmakers representing the Los Angeles area, was a significant factor in the bill's failure.

While many attribute the bill's defeat to the NIMBYs (Not In My Back Yard) who opposed top-down control and intrusion into their neighborhoods, the opposition was more complex. Housing justice groups, concerned about the bill's potential impact on low-income residents and its lack of protection for them, emerged as a significant and deeply entrenched opposition.

It is crucial to recognize that the NIMBYs and housing justice advocates, despite sharing common ground in their opposition to SB 50, have different goals and motivations. While NIMBYs aim to prevent major development and sometimes low-income housing in their neighborhoods, housing justice advocates focus on addressing the displacement of low-income communities and communities of color in the development process.

This distinction is important as California lawmakers prepare to reintroduce housing production legislation. While NIMBYs may remain resistant to development near them, resistant housing justice advocates might cooperate if they feel the policy will help and not hurt vulnerable communities. Conflating the two factions overlooks the real concerns about the widening wealth and affordability gap in the state.

Following the SB 50 vote, Senate President pro Tempore Toni Atkins, bill author Senator Scott Wiener, and Governor Gavin Newsom have affirmed their intention to reintroduce housing production legislation. Senator Wiener has already introduced two housing policy spot bills on Thursday, and the Assembly is currently considering legislation that guarantees a legal right to housing for families and children.

Senator Atkins, who supported SB 50, challenged the bill's critics to put forward their own legislation on Thursday, stating, "The opponents of SB 50 have real concerns, but have offered no substantive alternative with the same kind of scope of SB 50." The housing crisis in California is not going away and will remain a legislative focus over the next year and beyond.

Title: Silicon Valley-Backed Political Advocacy Group FWD.us Launches, Focuses on Immigration Reform

Article:

In a move that has been anticipated for weeks, the political advocacy group FWD.us, backed by Facebook founder Mark Zuckerberg, officially launched on Thursday. The group, whose name stands for Forward U.S., has a list of top Silicon Valley CEOs and a team of strategists.

The 11 founders of FWD.us include Reid Hoffman, co-founder of LinkedIn, and John Doerr, the venture capitalist who has backed Google and Amazon.com. Notable contributors include Marissa Mayer, Yahoo's chief executive, and Eric Schmidt, Google's executive chairman.

The group has enlisted political players from both sides of the aisle, including Rob Jesmer, a former executive director of the National Republican Senatorial Committee; Dan Senor, who also served as Rep. Paul Ryan's chief adviser during his vice presidential run; and Joe Lockhart, former White House press secretary for President Bill Clinton. Jef Pollock, the Democratic pollster, and Alida Garcia, former Latino vote deputy director for the Obama 2012 campaign, are also part of the team.

In an op-ed in The Washington Post on Thursday, Zuckerberg wrote about meeting a middle school student who is an undocumented immigrant and uncertain about his ability to attend college due to his immigration status. He expressed his concern about the current immigration policy, stating, "We have a strange immigration policy for a nation of immigrants, and it's a policy unfit for today's world."

The group's exact actions are yet to be determined, but they may include ads, campaign support, public communications, and grass-roots organizing, according to a source familiar with the organization. The group's website features testimonials from its members.

Last week, the group's co-founder and president, Joe Green, issued an apology after a leaked prospectus listed as members the names of executives who had not committed to the effort. The prospectus also included phrases that were criticized, such as "Human Capital" and an assessment that the group's members control "massive distribution channels." Green expressed regret over some of the document's phrases.

With its official unveiling, FWD.us will focus its initial efforts on the passage of comprehensive immigration reform. Tech companies are pushing for an increase in the number of H-1B temporary visas for high-skilled foreign workers and a reduction in green card wait times for their workers.

Title: Congressional Republicans Unveil $1.4 Trillion Tax-Cut Plan

Article:

Congressional Republicans have officially unveiled their final $1.4 trillion-plus tax-cut plan, which includes significant reductions in corporate and individual tax rates, the winding down of certain credits and exemptions, and the imposition of new international tax rules. The plan, which is the result of months of work and negotiations among Republicans, aims for quick passage next week.

The plan, known as the conference report, lowers the corporate tax rate from 35 percent to 21 percent, effective January 1, 2018. This reduction is being billed as the biggest corporate tax rate reduction in U.S. history. The plan preserves the existing number of individual tax rates at seven, not counting the zero rate, and lowers the top rate from 39.6 percent to 37 percent.

The new top rate applies to individuals making more than $500,000 and couples making more than $600,000. Under current law, the top rate of 39.6 percent applies to individuals making more than $418,400 and couples making more than $470,700. The new individual rates are effective for 2018, but are set to expire after 2025, a move Republicans used to keep the plan's overall price tag within the $1.5 trillion limit set by fast-track budget rules.

The bill also roughly doubles the standard deduction to $12,000 for individuals and $24,000 for families, increasing the number of "zero filers" who face no federal income tax liability and the amount of income not subject to taxation for those who opt to take the standard deduction.

The plan preserves the current mortgage interest deduction for existing mortgages but imposes a $750,000 cap for future mortgages. It also preserves the existing deduction for charitable contributions.

The bill repeals Obamacare's individual mandate starting in 2019, an item added during the negotiating process as lawmakers hunted for revenue sources they could use to pay for other rate cuts. It also doubles the current exemption for the estate tax on inheritances from $5 million to $10 million, so fewer people will be affected.

For small businesses, there is a new 20 percent deduction that applies to the first $315,000 of joint income for so-called "pass-through" companies that file their taxes as individuals. For income above that level, there's a deduction for up to 20 percent on profits, a move tax-writers estimate would reduce marginal tax rates to a maximum of 29.6 percent.

Businesses will also be able to immediately write off capital expenses for new equipment, rather than the current system that has them do it over a number of years.

The bill repeals the corporate alternative minimum tax, which is intended to make sure all companies pay at least some tax, and raises the income thresholds for the individual alternative minimum tax.

The state and local tax deduction, which had been on the chopping block at the start of the process, was preserved in part. People can now take a deduction of up to a total of $10,000 for sales, income, and property taxes paid.

The plan also doubles the child tax credit from $1,000 to $2,000, and makes $1,400 of it refundable against payroll taxes. This change was sought by Senators Marco Rubio and Mike Lee, among others, in order to reach more families that may not make enough to pay federal income taxes.

On the international side, the bill imposes a 15.5 percent "repatriation" tax for cash holdings that companies have parked overseas, and an 8 percent tax for non-cash holdings.

While Republicans are looking for swift passage next week, Democrats have criticized the package, stating that it is tilted toward corporations and the wealthy and doesn't do enough for the middle class. "This tax bill is a moral and economic obscenity," said Sen. Bernard Sanders, Vermont Independent. "It is a gift to wealthy Republican campaign contributors and an insult to the working families of our country."

Title: Former Russian Ambassador to U.S. Denies Significance of Meetings with Sessions, Downplays Extent of Interactions with Trump's Inner Circle

Article:

In an interview aired on Russian state-owned television, former Russian Ambassador to the United States Sergey Kislyak stated that it would take over 20 minutes to list every discussion he had with people close to President Trump. Kislyak made the comment in jest during an interview on Wednesday, after being asked to name every person associated with Mr. Trump he had either met with or spoken to on the phone.

Kislyak, 67, served as Moscow's ambassador to Washington from 2008 until August 2017, and in September he was elected to represent Mordovia in the Russian legislature's upper chamber. During his tenure in D.C., Kislyak made a lasting impression, particularly among Democrats on Capitol Hill who have continued to scrutinize his meetings with people close to Mr. Trump's presidential campaign.

Attorney General Jeff Sessions testified during his January confirmation hearing in the Senate that he "did not have communications with the Russians" while serving as a surrogate for Mr. Trump's campaign. However, during Tuesday's hearing before the House Judiciary Committee, Sessions admitted to meeting with Kislyak at least twice during the 2016 campaign.

Rep. Ted Lieu (D-CA) stated, "That is exactly the opposite answer you gave under oath to the U.S. Senate. Either you're lying to the U.S. Senate or you're lying to the U.S. House of Representatives." Sessions responded, "My story has never changed. I have always told the truth."

Speaking on Russian television the next day, Kislyak downplayed the significance of his meetings with Sessions. "In not one meeting, not with Sessions, not with anyone else, did we use any kinds of techniques or arguments that I would not be able to speak about publicly," Kislyak said.

Kislyak added, "This is no longer about me. This isn't about contacts with us. This is a war that's going on between the opponents of the president, the president and everyone surrounding him."

Separate from Sessions, other members of Mr. Trump's campaign, transition team, and administration have come under scrutiny in recent months for meeting with Kislyak prior to the president's inauguration. Michael Flynn, Mr. Trump's former national security adviser, resigned from that role in February after it emerged that he discussed lifting sanctions against Russia with Kislyak prior to Mr. Trump's inauguration and then to Vice President Mike Pence about the nature of those talks.

Jared Kushner, Mr. Trump's son-in-law and senior adviser, reportedly spoke with Kislyak during the transition period about establishing a secret back channel between the White House and Kremlin.

U.S. intelligence officials have determined that Russian President Vladimir Putin interfered in the 2016 White House race in hopes of electing Mr. Trump over his Democratic rival, Hillary Clinton. Russia's alleged involvement in the race and any collusion between Moscow and Mr. Trump's inner circle are currently being investigated by probes underway in the House, Senate, and Department of Justice, including a probe led by DOJ-appointed special counsel Robert Mueller that has resulted in criminal charges so far for three members of Mr. Trump's 2016 campaign.

Russia has denied meddling in the U.S. election, and the White House has denied colluding with the Kremlin.

Title: Manchin Says Lack of Votes for Expanded Background Checks Bill

Article:

Sen. Joe Manchin III (D-WV) has stated that proponents of a measure to expand gun-purchase background checks to online and gun show sales do not have the necessary votes to pass the bill on Wednesday. This setback for gun-control advocates comes after the Connecticut shooting rampage, where they had hoped for more ambitious controls, such as bans on certain types of weapons and magazines, and universal background checks on all gun sales.

President Obama has been actively promoting the administration's package, which was crafted by Vice President Joseph R. Biden, who has been Mr. Obama's point man on the issue. On MSNBC's "Morning Joe," Sen. Manchin expressed optimism, stating, "If we just had 20 percent of our Republican colleagues—that’s not a heavy ask; that’s not a heavy lift—only 20 percent, that’s nine members, nine members. This thing would be home."

Sen. Manchin's spokesman, Jonathan Kott, stated that Mr. Manchin remains optimistic that if senators read the bill, they will support it. So far, Sen. Manchin has managed to garner support from an A-rated NRA member and three Republican senators, as well as 90 percent of his own party.

Sen. Manchin expressed uncertainty about the bill's passage on the Senate floor Wednesday, stating, "I feel good. I feel I’m here for this purpose. Whatever happens today will happen. I feel we’ve done a good job, and I just ask my colleagues to consider this before we vote sometime this afternoon."

The prospects for the amendment have significantly faded Wednesday as Sens. Kelly Ayotte (R-NH) and Heidi Heitkamp (D-ND) both announced they would not support it. Both senators had voted to move debate forward on the underlying legislation last week, which includes more far-reaching background-check language, stiff penalties for gun trafficking and straw purchasing, and provisions intended to bolster school safety.

Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid (D-NV) has scheduled votes on eight other amendments to the underlying gun legislation, including bans on certain types of guns and magazines. Sen. Chuck Grassley (R-IA) and other co-sponsors unveiled a substitute amendment Wednesday morning, intended to strengthen the National Instant Criminal Background Check System (NICS) and address mental health and school safety, among other provisions.

Sen. Tom Coburn (R-OK) also announced his own amendment, intended to replace the background-check provision from Sens. Manchin and Patrick J. Toomey (R-PA), that would allow people to conduct self-checks through a consumer portal, among other measures. Sen. Coburn stated that the amendment's provisions, which anger special-interest groups on both sides, is a sign of its strength.

Title: Gun-Rights Group Challenges Pennsylvania's Closure of Gun Stores Amidst Coronavirus Outbreak

Article:

A top gun-rights group, the Firearms Policy Coalition (FPC), has filed a case with the Supreme Court of Pennsylvania, challenging Democratic Governor Tom Wolf's inclusion of gun stores in a statewide shutdown of "non-essential" businesses due to the coronavirus outbreak. The Pennsylvania Supreme Court has asked Governor Wolf to respond to the arguments in the case by 8 p.m. on Friday.

Brandon Combs, president of the FPC, stated that his group filed the case on Friday, aiming to block Governor Wolf from ordering gun stores to close. Combs argued, "Weapons and ammunition retailers are one of the most essential business types in the United States." He further stated, "There is no ‘ except in emergencies’ clause in the Constitution, and the government cannot shut down the people’s right to keep and bear arms."

Government mandates shuttering businesses in several states, including California and Pennsylvania, have raised concerns that more gun retailers could be ordered to close. At least one gun store near San Jose has been forced to close, according to a Mercury News report.

Gun-rights advocates argue that Americans' access to firearms and ammunition should not be prohibited during the pandemic. Amy Hunter, a spokeswoman for the National Rifle Association (NRA), stated, "They [retailers] are required by the government to be a point of access to the exercise of fundamental human rights."

As fears of the pandemic increase and police in major cities announce they will no longer make arrests over certain crimes, Americans have flooded gun stores and online ammunition dealers in recent weeks. A shutdown of gun stores would drastically limit their ability to purchase firearms for self-defense.

Gun-rights groups, including the FPC and the Second Amendment Foundation (SAF), have stated they will challenge any attempts to curb gun sales in court if lawmakers attempt to do so. Amy Hunter of the NRA stated, "Law-abiding Americans must not be deprived of the right to defend themselves and their loved ones at any time."

Alan Gottlieb, founder of the SAF, stated, "Gun prohibitionists want to close down every gun store they can and will use any means necessary." He acknowledged that finding a case likely to succeed in court could take time due to several challenges for Second Amendment supporters in the courts.

The National Shooting Sports Foundation, the gun industry's trade group, is also monitoring the situation and is prepared to intervene if necessary. Mark Oliva, a spokesman for the group, stated, "We're monitoring how our businesses are going to be affected as governors start to say we're going to shut down non-essential businesses." He added, "We believe our businesses are essential. We're starting to get ready to defend that if we have to."

Title: New Poll Shows Hillary Clinton's Approval Ratings Dropping in Key States Amid Email Controversy

Article:

A new poll released by Quinnipiac University on Tuesday indicates that former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton is trailing in key states, including Florida and Pennsylvania, amidst the ongoing controversy surrounding her use of a private email account during her tenure as Secretary of State.

In the Sunshine State, Clinton trails former Florida Governor Jeb Bush by a narrow margin, with a 45% to 47% lead. In February, Clinton led Bush by a 10-point margin. The same poll shows Clinton with a 1-point lead over Senator Rand Paul (R-Ky.) in Pennsylvania, a must-win state for the Democrats. In February, Clinton led Paul by 10 points.

The Quinnipiac poll also reveals a decline in Clinton's favorability ratings in both states. Her favorability rating in Florida dropped by 4 points, while in Pennsylvania, it dropped by 6 points.

Peter A. Brown, the pollster for Quinnipiac University, attributed the decline in Clinton's ratings to the ongoing email controversy, stating that it is "taking a toll" on her public image.

Republicans have seized on the email controversy to tarnish Clinton's image and raise questions about her trustworthiness. On Tuesday, the GOP chairman of the House Select Committee on Benghazi requested an interview with Clinton before May 1 to discuss her use of a private email account at the State Department and reports that she wiped her private server clean.

Clinton is expected to announce her candidacy for the 2016 presidential election later this month. The field of potential Republican challengers is growing, with Sen. Ted Cruz (Texas) being the first to formally enter the race last week, and Sen. Marco Rubio (R-Fla.) and Sen. Rand Paul (R-Ky.) expected to announce their candidacies soon.

The deep bench of potential Republican challengers, which also includes Wisconsin Governor Scott Walker, New Jersey Governor Chris Christie, and retired neurosurgeon Ben Carson, is emboldening Republicans.

"I think people are feeling optimistic, and it's really based on our candidates and our plan and vision for the future," said Sen. John Hoeven (R-N.D.). "I think our country is really ready for a change."

Sen. John McCain (R-Ariz.), the 2008 GOP presidential nominee, warned that the Republican party could fumble its chance by becoming embroiled in internecine warfare or failing to reach out to Hispanic voters, an increasingly crucial bloc in presidential elections.

"We have to show we can govern," he said. "There's one other issue, and that's immigration reform."

The email controversy has also revived interest in the Benghazi panel, with Republicans hoping to make a case against Clinton's character. The Quinnipiac poll shows 50% of voters in Florida say Clinton is not honest or trustworthy, while only 41% say she is. Her favorability rating in the state is 49% positive, down 4 points from a month ago.

Ron Kaufman, who served as a senior adviser to Mitt Romney's 2012 presidential campaign, said the email controversy raises questions of trustworthiness.

"I do believe the two twin killers in politics that hurt people more than anything else are arrogance and hypocrisy. They kill people," he said. "Everybody knows she's being totally arrogant — 'I'll decide myself how I'll handle my emails.' The hypocrisy of pretending to be transparent really hurts her."

Democrats argue that Clinton maintains a sizable lead in the polls and predict that GOP candidates will begin to get into their own trouble as the race gears up.

"There's not one person right now, when you match them head to head, who is even in Clinton's weight class," said Rodell Mollineau, a Democratic strategist.

Adrienne Watson, the communications director for Correct The Record, a group dedicated to defending Clinton, accused Republicans of reveling in political inanity.

"Secretary Clinton is talking about the future; about better jobs for working and middle-class Americans, Republicans are talking about a poll a year and a half before Election Day because they have no plan for America's future," she said.

"Manufactured scandals, politicizing an American tragedy like Benghazi and wanting into a person's personal emails will not work for the Republican politicians," she added.

Clinton has a major advantage over potential Republican opponents in that she faces a lightly contested path to the nomination. She has a huge lead over all likely Democratic candidates, according to polls.

"No amount of money or organization is going to erase Jeb Bush's family name or his brother's legacy," Mollineau said. "As much as he says he's his own man, it seems the advisers he's collecting are a redux of the Bush-Cheney administration."

Title: Sydney Cafe Siege: Gunman Takes Hostages in Central Sydney, Police Negotiating

Article:

A gunman took an unknown number of hostages in a cafe in the central business district of Sydney, Australia, on Monday, prompting a city-wide lockdown and a six-hour standoff with police. The siege ended early Tuesday morning when armed officers stormed the cafe and gunshots were heard. The status of the hostage taker, identified as Man Haron Monis, an Iranian, is unclear.

The Lindt Chocolate Cafe, located near the state parliament, the Reserve Bank of Australia, and the headquarters of two of Australia's largest banks, was the site of the incident. About a dozen people are believed to remain in the cafe, with dozens of buildings in the area evacuated due to police receiving information about up to four potential bombs around the city.

Prime Minister Tony Abbott stopped short of labeling the hostage taking a terrorist attack but described it as politically motivated. "This is a very disturbing incident," Mr. Abbott said. "It is profoundly shocking that innocent people should be held hostage by an armed person claiming political motivation."

New South Wales police commissioner Andrew Scipione stated that the police's priority was to safely evacuate the hostages. "Our plan, our only goal tonight and for as long as this takes, is to get those people that are currently caught in that building, out of there safely," he said.

The hostage taker reportedly displayed a black and white flag with the Shahada, a general expression of Islamic faith, in the cafe's windows. The use of the Shahada flag suggests the hostage taker may be responding to calls by Islamic State to carry out attacks, according to Professor Greg Barton of Monash University in Melbourne.

World leaders, including Stephen Harper of Canada, David Cameron of Britain, and Narendra Modi of India, conveyed messages of support. Local Muslim leaders swiftly condemned the hostage taking, with Australia's Grand Mufti, Ibrahim Abu Mohamed, stating that the Islamic community was devastated by the incident.

The Sydney siege bears similarities to recent attacks in Ottawa and Montreal, according to Justin Hastings, a senior lecturer in international relations at the University of Sydney. "These are attacks that send a very strong message that there are terrorists among us and they're very difficult to stop precisely because there is not much planning involved," he said.

More than 70 Australians are believed to be fighting for Islamic militants in Iraq and Syria, and a similar number have had their passports cancelled to prevent them from traveling to conflict zones in the Middle East.

Title: Pope Francis' Unconventional Motorcade: The Symbolism of the Black Fiat

Article:

Pope Francis, the first pontiff to address a joint meeting of the U.S. Congress, has captured the attention of Washington D.C. not only for his historic speeches but also for his unique mode of transportation - a small, black Fiat.

Bill Newbrough, 51, and his colleagues stood on the sidewalk, discussing the car. "This is Washington, after all, and this motorcade is slightly different from the ones we've seen before," he said, referring to the compact Fiat that navigated the city streets with ease.

Stephen Schneck, director of the Institute for Policy Research and Catholic Studies at The Catholic University of America, expressed his admiration for the car. "It looks like a clown car when they all get in it, but it's just such a perfect metaphor for his message," he said.

Pope Francis' preference for a modest vehicle aligns with his vow of poverty taken when he became a Jesuit priest. Although no longer bound by this vow as a bishop, it remains an important aspect of his life, according to Schneck.

In the past, popemobiles became large and bulletproof after the 1981 assassination attempt against Pope John Paul II. However, Francis has reverted to the Fiat and a specialized Jeep with open sides, as noted by The Washington Post in a retrospective of 215 years of popemobiles.

In an interview with the Spanish daily La Vanguardia, Pope Francis explained that he prefers a more open and approachable vehicle, stating, "It's true that anything could happen, but let's face it: At my age, I don't have much to lose."

Schneck attributes the choice of the Fiat to Francis' message of humility and his call for Catholics to focus on the marginalized members of society. Alejandro Cañadas, a professor of economics at Mount St. Mary's University, who has known the pope since his days in Argentina, agrees.

The name Fiat holds religious significance, as it appears in the Bible in Luke 1:38, where Mary responds to the angel Gabriel with the phrase "Behold the handmaid of the Lord; let it be done to me according to your word." In Latin, fiat translates roughly to "let it be done," and for Catholics, this line is known as Mary's fiat.

Cañadas suggests that the pope's choice of the Fiat reflects his attempt to emulate the Virgin Mary and live a life of humility and service to the marginalized.

Back on Pennsylvania Avenue, the pope's motorcade made its way through the city, with the black Fiat nestled among the black SUVs. The simple, unassuming car, with its windows down and the pope waving, served as a tangible symbol of Francis' commitment to humility and accessibility.

Title: Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez Defends Support for Cost-of-Living Increases for Members of Congress

Article:

Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez (D-NY) defended her stance on cost-of-living increases for members of Congress on Tuesday, stating that voting against such increases makes campaign finance reform more difficult. She argued that refusing a cost-of-living increase serves to "punish members who rely on a straight salary, and reward those who rely on money loopholes and other forms of self-dealing."

In a series of tweets, Ocasio-Cortez explained that voting against cost-of-living increases creates pressure on members of Congress to keep "dark money loopholes" open. She also emphasized that all workers, including minimum wage workers, should receive cost-of-living increases, and suggested that worker co-ops and collective bargaining are other forums in which worker pay increases can be voted on.

On Monday, House Democrats withdrew a spending bill that would have provided raises to members of Congress for the first time in a decade due to pushback from swing state lawmakers. Ocasio-Cortez has been vocal on living wage issues and campaign finance reform.

Title: Business Executives Puzder and Tillerson Face Mixed Reception in Democratic Circles

Article:

Two of President-elect Donald Trump's Cabinet nominees, Andrew Puzder and Rex Tillerson, have received a mixed response from the Democratic party, with their business backgrounds being a source of both concern and praise.

Andrew Puzder, chosen to lead the Department of Labor, is the head of CKE Restaurants, the parent company of Hardee's and Carl's Jr. fast-food chains. Puzder, who has experience in hiring and managing employees, has expressed opposition to significant increases in the minimum wage, a stance that has drawn criticism from some Democrats.

In a 2016 article, Puzder wrote, "The fight for dramatic minimum-wage increases could leave millions with no wage at all."
