This viewpoint aligns with standard economic theory, as expressed by Nobel laureate Paul Krugman in 1998, who criticized those who believe that the price of labor can be set based on considerations of justice rather than supply and demand.

Puzder has created jobs, with CKE and its franchisees employing approximately 90,000 people. He has expressed concerns about government regulations that increase his outlets' costs and reduce their profitability. Puzder's perspective, while different from that of a labor activist, may offer a unique viewpoint on labor issues.

Puzder has shown a willingness to compromise on the minimum wage, stating that he is not against a minimum wage higher than the current federal level of $7.25 an hour or one indexed to inflation. Puzder could potentially mitigate some of Trump's more controversial positions, as he has expressed support for a path to legal status for illegal immigrants, albeit short of citizenship.

Rex Tillerson, selected for the position of secretary of state, is not a stereotypical Texas oilman. As president of the Boy Scouts of America, he advocated for allowing gay troop leaders. Exxon Mobil, Tillerson's former company, has donated to Planned Parenthood. Tillerson's stance on issues such as carbon taxes and global warming has led some to view him as a potential ally for liberals on environmental matters.

Critics argue that Tillerson may prioritize the interests of the oil industry over those of the American public. However, CEOs, including Tillerson, are often driven by the interests of shareholders and customers. Tillerson's background in the oil industry may subject him to increased scrutiny, but it also invites a higher standard of accountability for decisions affecting his former industry.

Tillerson's appointment was suggested by Robert Gates, who served as defense secretary under both George W. Bush and Barack Obama. Gates' endorsement of Hillary Clinton notwithstanding, his recommendation carries bipartisan weight, despite his consulting firm's work for Exxon Mobil.

Tillerson lacks diplomatic experience, but he has worked with various regimes, as have other secretaries of state such as John Kerry, Hillary Clinton, and Condoleezza Rice. Tillerson is described as a "hard-eyed realist" by Gates, and his alleged affinity for Russian President Vladimir Putin has been a point of contention. However, former Vice President Dick Cheney, known for his hardline stance on foreign policy, has endorsed Tillerson.

Business executives, including Puzder and Tillerson, can bring valuable assets to government, offering relevant experience and seasoned judgment, which may be in short supply in the Trump administration. After weeks of controversial Cabinet nominations, such as Rudy Giuliani, Sarah Palin, and Newt Gingrich, Puzder and Tillerson are a relief for some, and Senate Democrats are urged to swiftly approve them before Trump might reconsider his choices.

Title: House of Representatives Continues to Reject the Born Alive Protection Act

Article:

WASHINGTON - The House of Representatives has repeatedly rejected efforts to bring the Born Alive Protection Act to the floor for a vote. The bill aims to protect babies born alive after an attempted abortion.

On multiple occasions, including last night, Republican representatives have requested to discuss the act, but have been denied by the Democrats.

Rep. Kevin McCarthy (R-CA) stated, "For the 17th time, we asked to bring up the Born Alive Protection Act. For the 17th time, the Democrats refused."

Rep. Steve Scalise (R-LA) explained, "There are babies being born alive and then ultimately murdered."

Chris Smith (R-NJ), the House pro-life caucus leader, described a case in a Florida abortion clinic where a baby, who was gasping for air, was put in a biohazard bag and thrown in the trash.

Democrats, who currently control the House, have prevented the act from coming to the floor for debate and a vote.

Rep. Liz Cheney (R-WY) expressed her disapproval, stating, "This is the height of shamefulness. It is absolutely an abomination that this is going on and we're having to have this argument in the United States today."

In some states, lawmakers are pushing for radical abortion legislation to keep such practices legal. States like New York, Rhode Island, and Illinois are introducing bills that could potentially make their states abortion havens.

Jill Stanek, national campaign chair of the Susan B. Anthony List, explained, "They've introduced the Reproductive Health Act, which (3107), according to one abortion group, could cement Illinois as the Midwest abortion oasis."

Melissa Cifuentes, a pro-life activist, is fighting a similar law in Rhode Island. She stated, "We are called to use our voice to speak the truth on behalf of innocent lives that are sacred and that are worthy of our protection."

Pro-life activists are urging Americans to contact their representatives in Congress to sign the discharge petition for the Born Alive Protection Act. If the petition gathers 218 signatures, House Speaker Nancy Pelosi is required to let the bill come to the floor for a vote.

Title: Trump's Remarks on Paris and London Attacks Spark Controversy

Article:

In a speech at the National Rifle Association (NRA) convention, U.S. President Donald Trump criticized gun control measures and highlighted the 2015 terrorist attacks in Paris and an increase in knife violence in London. The comments sparked a response from French and British officials.

France, in particular, was incensed by Trump's remarks, with French Foreign Minister Jean-Yves Le Drian issuing a statement on Saturday, expressing "firm disapproval" and calling for respect for the victims. Former French President François Hollande also tweeted his disapproval, stating that Trump's remarks "say a lot about what he thinks of France and its values."

Trump suggested that if Parisians in the cafes under attack had been armed, the outcome might have been different. The Élysée Palace responded by stating that "the free flow of arms within society does not constitute a shield against terrorist attacks."

In the case of London, Trump compared an unnamed hospital to a "war zone" due to knife attacks, despite tough gun laws in the United Kingdom. British officialdom did not push back, with London Mayor Sadiq Khan's office declining to comment to CNN following Trump's remarks.

Former UK Cabinet minister Charlie Falconer tweeted his disapproval, stating that the U.S. murder rate is over five times higher than the UK's and that making it easier to obtain guns would not reduce the murder rate.

Amid the furor, Dr. Martin Griffiths, a trauma surgeon at the Royal London Hospital, invited Trump to visit his hospital to discuss violence reduction in London. Professor Karim Brohi, a trauma surgeon at The Royal London Hospital and director of London's Major Trauma System, also hit back at Trump's speech, stating that the hospital has cut the number of young patients returning after further knife attacks from 45% to 1%.

Trump and British Prime Minister Theresa May spoke by phone on Saturday, discussing China trade, North Korea, Iran, and Trump's upcoming visit to Britain. It's unknown whether they discussed Trump's remarks to the NRA.

A previous version of this story misstated the source of France's comments and the time period when Charlie Falconer was a UK Cabinet minister. The comments came from the French foreign ministry, and Falconer served as Lord Chancellor from 2003 until 2007, and Secretary of State for Justice in 2007.

Title: Grassroots Conservatives Express Disappointment Over GOP's Omnibus Bill

Article:

Grassroots conservatives have expressed their dissatisfaction with the recent omnibus bill passed by the Republican-controlled Congress, accusing the GOP establishment of breaking promises made during their election campaigns. The bill, which funds various government programs and agencies, has been criticized for including provisions that contradict conservative values, such as funding for Planned Parenthood, visas for un-vetted migrants, and H-2B visas for foreign workers.

The criticism stems from the belief that the GOP establishment, in collusion with lobbyists and corrupt politicians, has failed to deliver on their promises to halt the "fundamental transformation of America" as promised during the 2010 and 2014 elections. The omnibus bill, which was written by lobbyists and passed by politicians, has been described as a betrayal of conservative values and a step towards further government spending and debt.

Grassroots conservatives have long rallied to action under the belief that change starts at the ballot box. Many have sacrificed personal time and resources to support Republican candidates, hoping for a conservative majority in Congress and a change in the federal government's direction. However, the passage of the omnibus bill has led to a sense of disillusionment and betrayal among grassroots conservatives, who feel that the GOP establishment has failed to deliver on their promises.

The criticism extends to the GOP establishment's perceived lack of concern for winning national elections. Some argue that the establishment would rather maintain their positions in Congress, even if it means a Democrat in the White House, as it allows them to avoid taking leadership roles and continue to enjoy the perks of office.

Despite the criticism, there are still some within the GOP who are dissatisfied with the status quo and are working to bring about change. The Tea Party movement, for example, has brought more conservative-leaning members to Congress, offering a glimmer of hope for grassroots conservatives.

In conclusion, grassroots conservatives have expressed their disappointment with the GOP establishment over the omnibus bill, accusing them of breaking promises made during the 2010 and 2014 elections. The criticism extends to the GOP establishment's perceived lack of concern for winning national elections and their failure to deliver on conservative values. However, there are still some within the GOP who are working to bring about change, offering a glimmer of hope for grassroots conservatives.

Title: U.S. Economy Grows at 2.6% in Q4, Suggesting Sustained Growth Amid Fed's Patient Approach to Interest Rates

Article:

The U.S. economy expanded at a 2.6% annualized rate in the fourth quarter of 2018, according to a report by the Commerce Department on Thursday. This growth rate is slightly below the 2.2% median estimate of economists surveyed by Bloomberg but follows a 3.4% advance in the previous three months.

The growth was driven by an increase in business investment, which grew 6.2% on equipment, software, and research spending. Consumption, which accounts for the majority of the economy, grew 2.8%, slightly below forecasts. Government spending slowed, trade was a minor drag, and inventories gave GDP a small boost.

The report suggests that the Republican-backed tax cuts may have continued to aid growth, helping bring the full-year figure to 3.1%, just above President Donald Trump's 3% goal. The expansion is poised to become the nation's longest on record at midyear, amid a still-healthy consumer, supportive Fed, and robust labor market.

However, the pace could cool amid the trade war, slowing global growth, and fading impact of fiscal stimulus. A separate report Thursday from the Labor Department showed filings for unemployment benefits rose by more than expected last week to 225,000, still near a five-decade low.

Growth, while slower than the prior two quarters, remains above both the average pace of the expansion and what the Fed sees as the economy's long-run potential of 1.9%. Still, surveys and gauges such as Treasury yields indicate chances of a recession have increased in recent months while remaining unlikely for 2019.

The increase in consumer spending followed the third quarter's 3.5% gain. It contributed 1.92 percentage points to growth. Drivers included health care, financial services and insurance, and other nondurable goods and services, while spending on food services and accommodations fell.

The GDP data may reinforce analyst criticism of the government's recent report on December retail sales. That showed the biggest drop in nine years, even as other figures -- particularly reports from the country’s largest retailers -- indicated consumers continued to open their wallets in the quarter.

Thursday's report showed the third-quarter slowdown in business spending may have been temporary. Nonresidential fixed investment contributed 0.82 percentage point to growth following 0.35 point in the third quarter. Within that category, spending on structures fell 4.2%, the biggest drop in a year, a slowdown that may partly reflect falling oil prices. Business-equipment investment rose 6.7% and intellectual property spending jumped 13.1%.

Housing remained a weak spot last quarter, posting the fourth consecutive drag on GDP growth, with a contraction of 3.5%. Home sales tumbled in late 2018 amid elevated mortgage rates and price increases that continued to outpace wages, though there are signs of demand picking up in early 2019 thanks to a drop in borrowing costs.

Net exports subtracted 0.22 percentage point from GDP growth during the quarter following a 1.99-point reduction in the prior period. The drag reflected a 2.7% rise in imports that outpaced a 1.6% increase in exports, with the tariff war buffeting both sets of flows.

Inventories added 0.13 percentage point to the pace of expansion. Meanwhile, inflation remained muted, adding little urgency for the Fed to consider resuming interest-rate hikes. The GDP report showed the Fed's preferred price index rose at a 1.5% annualized pace last quarter, below the central bank's 2% goal. Excluding food and energy, the index rose 1.7%.

Title: Trump Signs $1.3 Trillion Spending Bill, Averts Government Shutdown

Article:

U.S. President Donald Trump signed the recently passed $1.3 trillion spending bill on Friday, ending a brief period of uncertainty sparked by a tweeted veto threat that hinted at a potential government shutdown.

Trump stated that he had signed the bill, despite his reservations on certain issues, due to a $60 billion increase in military spending, which he considered a worthwhile compromise. He expressed his displeasure with the bill, stating, "I am not going to do it again."

Earlier in the day, White House and Capitol Hill aides were left in a state of confusion following Trump's criticism of the six-month spending bill, despite prior assurances from the administration that he would sign it before the midnight deadline. Trump's initial tweet read, "I am considering a VETO of the Omnibus Spending Bill based on the fact that the 800,000 plus DACA recipients have been totally abandoned by the Democrats (not even mentioned in Bill) and the BORDER WALL, which is desperately needed for our National Defense, is not fully funded."

Trump subsequently held discussions with his senior advisers regarding a potential veto, but was advised against it. Advisers warned him that he would be blamed for a shutdown and that negotiations on the issues he is concerned about were still ongoing, according to one aide.

By early afternoon, Trump appeared before reporters in the Diplomatic Reception Room of the White House to announce he had signed the measure. He acknowledged his dissatisfaction with the bill, stating, "There are a lot of things I'm unhappy about in this bill."

The bill includes $1.6 billion for six months' worth of work on the U.S.-Mexico border wall project, but Trump had sought $25 billion for it. Trump has also been at odds with Democrats in Congress over the fate of Dreamer immigrants - those brought to the United States illegally when they were children.

Trump canceled the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program, which grants work permits to Dreamers and protects them from deportation. The decision is currently tied up in court cases. He offered to extend the protections, tied to a sweeping set of changes to immigration laws, but subsequently rejected bipartisan offers from lawmakers.

As the six-month spending budget deal was being finalized, there had been reports that Trump had balked at the bill and had to be persuaded by Speaker Paul Ryan to support it. The conservative wing of Trump's party had criticized the bill due to its spending increases, while some deficit hawks cheered Trump's Friday morning threat to veto it.

It remains unclear how seriously Republican leaders took Trump's shutdown threat, as neither Speaker Paul Ryan nor Senate Leader Mitch McConnell commented publicly on it. Lawmakers in the Republican-dominated Senate and House of Representatives had already left Washington for a scheduled two-week spring recess, and Trump himself was scheduled to fly to Florida for a weekend at his private resort.

Title: Sen. Cory Booker Proposes Federal Savings Account for Every U.S. Child to Address Economic Inequality

Article:

Senator Cory Booker (D-N.J.), a potential 2020 presidential candidate, has introduced a bill to establish interest-bearing savings accounts for every child born in the United States. The aim is to address rising economic inequality.

The bill, as outlined in a summary released Monday, would create interest-bearing accounts administered by the Treasury Department, with a $1,000 principal balance granted by the federal government at birth. The government would deposit up to $2,000 annually into each child's account, depending on total family income, until the recipient turns 18.

The accounts would be federally insured, and the funds could only be used for homeownership and "human and financial capital investments that [change] life trajectories," according to the summary.

"Everyone in America should have a real shot to succeed, but federal policy over decades and an upside-down tax code that heaps benefits on the very rich and big corporations have grown the gap between those who have much and those who have little," Booker said in a statement. "Today, nearly one in three American families have zero to negative wealth, and it's hard to get ahead if you begin life behind the starting line."

The program, if implemented in 2019, would cost approximately $60 billion and would be funded by increasing the capital gains tax rate by 4.2 points, increasing the estate tax to its 2009 level, and raising taxes on multimillion-dollar inheritances.

Economic inequality, typically measured by the wealth gap between the richest and poorest Americans, has steadily risen since the 2007-2008 financial crisis. The resulting spike in equity and property values has left much of the working class behind. There is also a significant racial wealth gap due to decades of discriminatory laws and business practices that have prevented minorities from accessing the same financial products and investments as whites. The median net worth of whites is roughly 10 times larger than that of blacks, and nearly 1 in 5 black families have zero or negative net worth, according to Federal Reserve data from 2017.

Booker's bill is the latest sweeping policy proposal from a 2020 hopeful aimed at bolstering the economic stability of working- and middle-class Americans. Several of Booker's potential Democratic primary rivals, including Sens. Kirsten Gillibrand (N.Y.) and Kamala Harris (Calif.), have also introduced bills to bolster the supply of affordable housing and increase low-income household wealth. A similar federally funded savings program was instituted in Israel last year.

Title: Turkey Launches Military Offensive Against Kurdish Fighters in Northern Syria

Article:

Turkey launched a military offensive against Kurdish fighters in northern Syria on Wednesday, following President Trump's announcement of the withdrawal of U.S. troops from the region. Airstrikes and artillery bombarded the area, softening defenses for a ground offensive as tensions escalated into a dramatic first day of what Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan called "Operation Peace Spring."

Erdogan described the operation as a push against terrorists, aiming to "destroy the terror corridor which is trying to be established on our southern border and to bring peace... to the region." He also stated that Turkey's objective is to "preserve Syria's territorial integrity and liberate local communities from terrorists."

Although the U.S. administration agreed to remove U.S. troops, which had been working alongside local Kurds to fight ISIS, Trump stated in a Wednesday statement that the White House "made it clear to Turkey that this operation is a bad idea." Trump also emphasized that Turkey "has committed to protecting civilians, protecting religious minorities, including Christians, and ensuring no humanitarian crisis takes place."

Trump defended his decision to withdraw troops, stating, "The United States has spent EIGHT TRILLION DOLLARS fighting and policing in the Middle East. Now we are slowly & carefully bringing our great soldiers & military home. Our focus is on the BIG PICTURE!"

Turkey views the Kurdish People's Protection Units (YPG) in Syria as terrorists due to their ties to militants waging an insurgency inside Turkey. Heavy shelling targeted border towns, causing civilians to flee for safer ground. Turkish jets reportedly pulverized suspected hiding spots of Syrian Kurdish forces in the town of Ras al-Ayn, creating booming explosions that could be heard across the border in Turkey.

A US official, speaking on condition of anonymity, stated that the airstrikes were not coordinated with the U.S. military. Additionally, bombs hit an office of the Syrian Democratic Forces (SDF) in Tal Abyad, sending nearby residents running for their lives.

At least seven civilians and one member of Kurdish-led forces were killed in the first day of fighting, according to Kurdish activists and a Syrian war monitor.

Turkey had been poised to advance into Syria since U.S. forces began vacating the area following Trump's abrupt policy shift, which has been criticized in Washington, including by Republicans, as a betrayal of the U.S.-allied Kurdish fighters who helped combat ISIS.

Sen. Lindsey Graham, typically a reliable Trump supporter, lamented, "Pray for our Kurdish allies who have been shamelessly abandoned by the Trump Administration."

Despite the reservations of Graham and others on both sides of the aisle, Trump insisted in his comments Wednesday that he wants to end "forever wars" claiming American lives. He also stated that the Kurds, while traditional allies of the Americans, haven't always been there.

"They didn't help us in the Second World War, they didn't help us with Normandy," said Trump, adding that they only fight for "their land."

"With all of that being said, we like the Kurds," he added.

The United Nations Security Council is set to meet behind closed doors on Thursday to discuss the conflict. The sit-down was requested by the five European members of the 15-member council—Britain, France, Germany, Belgium, and Poland, diplomats said.

Title: Trump Administration Overturns Obama-Era Rules on Handling University Sex Assault Allegations

Article:

The Trump administration has overturned rules introduced during the Obama administration for handling university sex assault allegations. Education Secretary Betsy DeVos stated that the previous administration's guidance was unfairly tilted against the accused.

Mrs. DeVos emphasized that campuses would continue to confront such "horrific crimes," but she added that the process must be fair and impartial, giving everyone more confidence in its outcomes. The new interim instructions allow universities to decide the standard of evidence to be used when handling complaints.

The DeVos guidelines introduce the higher standard of proof, requiring "clear and convincing evidence" in campus sex assault cases. Under President Obama, universities were able to judge students based on a preponderance of evidence, instead of guilt being proved beyond a reasonable doubt as in criminal cases.

The Obama administration's 2011 and 2014 college sexual misconduct policies also required colleges to investigate complaints even if there was a separate criminal inquiry. Critics of that approach said it protected survivors at the expense of the accused's rights.

The Obama administration took action after dozens of women said their sex assault cases had been mishandled. In one high-profile 2016 case at Stanford University in California, an athlete's six-month sentence, after he was convicted of sexually assaulting an unconscious student, was condemned as outrageously lenient.

However, Mrs. DeVos stated earlier this month, "Through intimidation and coercion, the failed system has clearly pushed schools to overreach. With the heavy hand of Washington tipping the balance of her scale, the sad reality is that Lady Justice is not blind on campuses today."

Advocates for sexual assault victims warned that Friday's policy reversal would deter victims from stepping forward. Kim Churches, chief executive officer of the American Association of University Women, said, "This is a blatant rollback from the strong and much-needed guidance that was in place."

House of Representatives Democratic leader Nancy Pelosi denounced the change as a "shocking attack" on women. In July, Mrs. DeVos's top civil rights deputy, Candice Jackson, provoked fury when she told a reporter that 90% of campus rape investigations "fall into the category of 'we were both drunk.'"

She said the majority of such cases amounted to " 'we broke up, and six months later I found myself under a Title IX investigation because she just decided that our last sleeping together was not quite right.'" Ms. Jackson apologized, and a Democratic senator, Patty Murray of Washington state, called in vain for her to be fired.

Earlier this month, the Education Department said 360 sexual violence cases were under investigation at 250 colleges and universities across the US.

Title: Banning Flavored Vaping Products: A Case of Hasty Policies and Unclear Causes

Article:

The sale of flavored vaping products has been banned in several states, including Michigan and New York, due to a recent outbreak of lung-related illnesses. However, the cause of these illnesses remains unclear, and there is no evidence that the flavoring in these products is responsible.

According to National Public Radio, the role of flavored vape products in the current outbreak is unknown. Some lawmakers and public health advocates have been pushing for flavored vape products to be banned since flavors first entered the market, out of a concern that they appeal to children. The timing of the recent move to ban flavored vape products may be linked to the current public concern about overall e-cigarette safety.

However, this is a case of those who oppose vaping in general using the latest crisis as a means to create a banning frenzy. The Washington Post has reported that the vast majority of the sick vape users have reported using a marijuana oil called THC in their vape pens, and many people have started using illegal vape cartridges containing THC, which also contain significant amounts of vitamin E acetate. The medical news website MedPage Today quoted a New York health official who said, "These were long-time vapers who had recently switched to cheaper THC- or CBD- products purchased from unlicensed retailers."

The matter also needs to be kept in perspective. Smoking combustible cigarettes is a dangerous habit, one likely to shave 10 years off of a smoker's life—and lead to costly and debilitating health problems. Vaping is one of the most effective ways to help adult smokers break their deadly habit. In 2016, the Royal College of Physicians in Great Britain reported that e-cigarettes are 95 percent safer than smoking. More than half a million people die annually from tobacco-related diseases, so vaping's potential health benefits should not be ignored.

Vaping clearly is not without its health risks, and measures need to be taken to keep them out of the hands of underage people. However, e-cigarettes need to be available to help adult smokers quit a more-dangerous habit. If cigarette smokers can no longer buy vaping liquids, they may keep smoking cigarettes, which will still be available at their local convenience store.

Young people have been smoking cigarettes, drinking alcohol, toking marijuana, and vaping in contravention of the law since those substances have been available. The right approach is to enforce current laws and educate children about their dangers. That may not be satisfying amid calls for policymakers to "do something," but it's sensible. That is, unless you seriously think that banning adult sales of wine, beer, and spirits is the best way to combat underage drinking.

Title: Supreme Court Ruling on Trademark Case Affects Native American Groups and Brands' Response to Racial Stereotypes

Article:

In 2017, the Supreme Court made a landmark decision in the case Matal v. Tam, which ruled that it was unconstitutional for the law to ban trademarks deemed "disparaging." The Asian rock band, The Slants, celebrated the victory, with lead singer Simon Tam stating, "It can’t be a win for free speech if some people benefit and others don’t." However, the outcome of Matal v. Tam had far-reaching implications, particularly for the decades-long legal challenge to the Washington Redskins trademark.

The same day as the court's ruling on the Tam case, Dan Snyder, the owner of the Washington football team, issued a statement, "I am THRILLED! Hail to the Redskins." Suzan Shown Harjo, a Cheyenne and Muscogee Creek activist and scholar, and later a team of Native American plaintiffs led by Amanda Blackhorse, had been leading the challenge to the Redskins trademark. Harjo defiantly insisted, "It may have killed our case, but it hasn’t killed our movement."

In the wake of the Black Lives Matter protests, several brands are reevaluating the harmful stereotypes they once perpetuated. Recently, Quaker Oats, the owner of the 131-year-old Aunt Jemima brand, announced changes to the product name in pursuit of "progress toward racial equality." The brand had long capitalized on a romanticized view of antebellum American slavery, even hiring a former slave to impersonate the character of Aunt Jemima at the 1893 Chicago World's Fair.

Following Quaker's announcement, the Mars corporation announced similar changes to its Uncle Ben's rice products. Even Mrs. Butterworth's pancake syrup, with a bottle embodying a racist caricature of a black woman, is undergoing a "complete brand and package review."

Title: Six Cities in Contention for the 2016 Democratic National Convention

Article:

The Democratic National Committee (DNC) has announced six cities that have submitted bids to host the 2016 Democratic National Convention: Birmingham, Alabama; Cleveland, Columbus, Ohio; New York, New York; Philadelphia, Pennsylvania; and Phoenix, Arizona.

DNC chair Debbie Wasserman Schultz expressed enthusiasm about the options in a press release, stating, "We're thrilled with all the fantastic options that we have going into the next cycle." The DNC will evaluate these bids and select a city to host the event, with the technical advisory committee conducting site visits and other inquiries over the coming months. The DNC plans to announce its decision later this year or in early 2015.

The Republican National Committee (RNC) is further along in its selection process. Denver, Dallas, Cleveland, and Kansas City are the final cities bidding to host the 2016 Republican National Convention. The RNC expects to announce its final decision in the fall.

New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio has pitched Brooklyn as the focal point for the Big Apple's bid to host the 2016 Democratic convention. The Barclays Center, home to the NBA's Brooklyn Nets, is intended to serve as the principal venue site for the convention, with other events and accommodations spread across Brooklyn, Manhattan, and New York's other boroughs.

New York City last hosted a major party's presidential nominating convention in 2004, when the Republican National Convention was held in Manhattan's Madison Square Garden. Philadelphia is the only one of the final five Democratic choices to have previously hosted a major party convention, with Republicans officially nominating George W. Bush as the party's standard bearer at the then-named First Union Center in 2000.

Among the 15 cities that were sent an official request for proposal by the DNC, the others include Atlanta, Chicago, Cleveland, Columbus (Ohio), Detroit, Indianapolis, Las Vegas, Miami, Nashville, Orlando, Pittsburgh, and Salt Lake City.

Title: Interactive Tool Simulates Carbon Emissions Reduction in Response to COVID-19 and Climate Change

Article:

A new interactive tool, "ACES: A Post Covid Emissions Simulator," developed by artificial intelligence start-up HyperGiant, provides a perspective on the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on carbon emissions and its relationship to climate change. The tool allows users to adjust pandemic-induced behaviors and calculate the potential carbon dioxide reduction if these changes were made permanent.

For instance, if 30% of the workforce works from home, air travel is reduced by 50%, and people eat 15% less meat, the tool estimates that 18 billion tons of carbon dioxide would be eliminated, which is 38% of the way towards the emissions reduction targets set by the Paris climate accord. The United States signed the Paris Agreement in 2015 and pledged to reduce U.S. greenhouse gas emissions by about a quarter by 2030 from 2005 levels. In 2019, the U.S. officially withdrew from the agreement.

The tool also allows users to activate new technologies, such as carbon capture, renewable power generation, and revolutionary land management and agriculture strategies, to determine what it would take to reach carbon neutrality (where the net total carbon emissions equal zero, either through reducing carbon emissions to zero or supporting enough carbon offset programs that offset carbon emissions).

For example, if 30% of the workforce works from home, air travel is reduced by 50%, people eat 15% less meat, and all vehicles in the U.S. are electric, the tool estimates that 33 billion tons of carbon dioxide would be eliminated by 2050. While this satisfies the Paris Agreement, it is not enough to "reach carbon neutrality and avoid the worst effects of climate change," according to the simulator.

"One of the most difficult things about understanding climate change is understanding the size of the actual climate problem relative to the size of the potential solutions," HyperGiant climate advisor Noam Bar-Zemer tells ███ Make It. "If I tell you that we will not emit billions of tons of CO2 as a result of Covid-19, that sounds like a lot unless you know how to compare it to the size of the greenhouse gas crisis." The tool makes it easier for people to compare and understand the impact of proposed solutions, Bar-Zemer adds.

HyperGiant, headquartered in Austin, Texas, was founded in 2018 and has over 230 employees. The company works with companies in various industries, including space and healthcare, to problem-solve and boost efficiency via artificial intelligence solutions. HyperGiant generates "mid-eight figures" in revenue, CEO Ben Lamm tells ███ Make It.

Title: President Obama Addresses George Zimmerman Verdict, Discusses African-American Community Issues

Article:

In a statement last Friday, President Barack Obama commented on the George Zimmerman verdict, expressing empathy for the late Trayvon Martin. The president stated, "If I had a son, he'd look like Trayvon." The president's remarks were followed by a discussion on the historical context and the disproportionate representation of African-Americans in the criminal justice system.

President Obama acknowledged the complexities of the issue, stating, "We understand that some of the violence that takes place in poor black neighborhoods around the country is born out of a very violent past in this country, and that the poverty and dysfunction that we see in those communities can be traced to a very difficult history."

The president's comments touched on the disproportionate involvement of African-American young men in the criminal justice system. He emphasized that this is not an attempt to make excuses but rather to understand the issue in a historical context.

However, the president's statement also sparked questions about the role of individual choices and societal factors in shaping the circumstances of African-Americans. Issues such as broken families, high abortion rates, and the portrayal of African-Americans in media and entertainment were not addressed in the president's statement.

A reader on The Washington Post's website, posting under the name "Chaquita1," shared a personal story about witnessing a confrontation between an African-American woman and two young men on a train. The woman reportedly admonished the young men for their behavior, stating, "Trayvon Martin died for nothing. His death did not empower you, it should have been a wake-up call."

The president has called for a national conversation about race, and discussions like the one described by "Chaquita1" may contribute to this dialogue, as they highlight the complexities and nuances of racial issues in the United States.

Title: Saturday Night Live Drops Comedian Shane Gillis After Offensive Remarks Surface

Article:

Comedy sketch show Saturday Night Live (SNL) has terminated the employment of comedian Shane Gillis following the resurfacing of videos showing him making derogatory remarks about Chinese people. The 31-year-old comedian was announced as a new cast member for SNL's 45th season just hours prior.

In a statement, an SNL spokesperson said, "We have decided that Shane Gillis will not be joining SNL." Gillis responded on Twitter, "Of course I wanted an opportunity to prove myself at SNL, but I understand it would be too much of a distraction."

The spokesperson explained that the decision to fire Gillis followed a discussion with the comedian. "We want SNL to have a variety of voices and points of view within the show, and we hired Shane on the strength of his talent as a comedian and his impressive audition for SNL," they said.

However, the spokesperson added, "We were not aware of his prior remarks that have surfaced over the past few days. The language he used is offensive, hurtful, and unacceptable." They also expressed regret for not catching the clips earlier and for the subpar vetting process.

A podcast from September 2018 was circulated in which Gillis mocked Chinese people and described his remarks as "nice racism." In another episode from the same month, Gillis used homophobic slurs to describe Hollywood producer Judd Apatow and comedian Chris Gethard.

Gillis defended the comments on Twitter, saying he is a comedian "who pushes boundaries." He continued, "My intention is never to hurt anyone but I am trying to be the best comedian I can be and sometimes that requires risks."

Good Good Comedy Theatre in Philadelphia, Gillis' hometown, stated on Twitter that they had "deliberately chosen not to work" with him because of his "overt racism, sexism, homophobia - expressed both on and off stage."

Comedian Rob Schneider, a former SNL cast member, tweeted his support for Gillis, saying he had fallen foul of "culture unforgiveness." Fellow comics Bill Burr and Jim Jeffries also criticized SNL's decision while appearing on the US series Lights Out with David Spade.

Jeffries said the move was a symptom of "cancel culture." He said, "The guy should not have been fired. It's just a couple of things back in his history - are we going to go through everyone's history? Or are we going to get rid of every sketch that SNL has done that involves race?"

Burr added, "Did they go back and also try and look back at good things the person might have done, or are they just looking for the bad stuff?"

Taiwanese-American presidential candidate Andrew Yang, who Gillis referred to using a slur in a podcast, has said the comedian "deserved another chance to keep his job" but society has become "unduly punitive and vindictive."

Yang said Gillis has reached out to him, and the two will be having a discussion soon. In addition to Gillis, SNL had announced the hiring of two other new cast members: Chloe Fineman and Bowen Yang. Yang will be the show's first full-time Chinese-American cast member.

Title: Senate Democrats Block Bills Aimed at 20-Week Abortion Ban and Health Care Provider Measures

Article:

Senate Democrats blocked two bills on Tuesday that aimed to ban abortions after 20 weeks of pregnancy and impose penalties on healthcare providers who do not provide medical aid to babies born alive after failed abortions. The bills were introduced by Senate Republicans as a means to appeal to their conservative base in an election year and to highlight the Democrats' stance on expanded abortion rights.

One of the measures, sponsored by Sen. Lindsey Graham (R-SC), would have imposed criminal penalties, including a fine or a possible five-year prison term, for medical providers who perform abortions after a fetus reaches five months gestation. The bill included exceptions for pregnancy complications that threaten the pregnant person's life or if the pregnancy is the result of rape or incest.

The Senate voted 53-44 to move forward with the 20-week ban, but it fell short of the 60 votes needed. Senators Joe Manchin III (D-WV) and Bob Casey (D-PA) voted with Republicans, while Senators Susan Collins (R-ME) and Lisa Murkowski (R-AK), two moderate Republicans, voted with Democrats to block the bill.

The bill targeting healthcare providers was blocked 56-41. Sen. Ben Sasse (R-NE) introduced the measure, which required healthcare workers to give medical care to a baby born alive after a botched abortion, ensuring the child is admitted to a hospital. If they failed to act, they would have faced a fine or prison time.

Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-KY) said the two bills provided senators a chance to take a "clear moral stand," suggesting the GOP leader wanted to put Democrats on record for abortion restrictions he called "morally straightforward." Sen. Rick Scott (R-FL) said the votes revealed Democrats stand for infanticide.

Senate Minority Leader Charles E. Schumer (D-NY) said the measures were aimed at energizing the Republicans' far-right base. "Priorities in the Senate are way out of line," the New York Democrat said, adding the chamber should be working on legislation dealing with election security, background checks for firearms, and dealing with the coronavirus.

Critics of the bills said they are unnecessary and aimed at further limiting a woman's control over her body. They argued that state laws already ban murder, pushing back on the need for Sen. Sasse's bill. Proponents of the measures argued that the bills are humane and based on science.

The votes put the senators on record about late-term abortions. Only seven countries permit abortions beyond 20 weeks. Sen. Steve Daines (R-MT), the founder and chairman of the Pro-Life Caucus, said the votes against the measures were "astonishing," and he promised to continue pushing pro-life policies. "This shouldn't be about politics. It's about protecting life," he said.

The Democratic Party has moved toward expanding abortion rights, including for the first time in 2016 making overturning the ban on federally funding for abortions part of the party platform. The issues surrounding late-term abortion, however, remain dicey for the party. Former South Bend, Indiana, Mayor Pete Buttigieg, a top 2020 Democratic presidential candidate, recently got into hot water when he dodged an Iowa voter's question about late-term abortions. He said it should be the pregnant person's decision, not the government's. The remark spurred complaints that he was alienating pro-life Democrats.

Title: Bannon Faces Criticism Following Moore's Loss in Alabama Senate Race

Article:

Steve Bannon, the CEO of Breitbart News and former White House chief strategist, has faced criticism following the loss of Republican candidate Roy Moore to Democrat Doug Jones in the Alabama Senate race. Bannon was one of Moore's earliest and most vocal supporters, campaigning for him both before and after the allegations of sexual misconduct surfaced.

Matt Drudge, a prominent conservative media figure, commented on the election results, stating, "Luther Strange would have won in a landslide... Just too much crazy in nerve-racking times. There is a limit!" Strange was President Trump's preferred candidate in the primary race, leading many to point their finger at Bannon for the whole debacle.

Steve Law, president of the Senate Leadership Fund, issued a statement saying, "This is a brutal reminder that candidate quality matters regardless of where you are running. Not only did Steve Bannon cost us a critical Senate seat in one of the most Republican states in the country, but he also dragged the President of the United States into his fiasco."

Ben Shapiro, editor-in-chief of The Daily Wire and a former Breitbart editor, also weighed in, writing, "Bannon's sure showing those establishment cucks a thing or two right now." Dana Loesch, a talk radio host, author, and NRA spokeswoman, commented on Twitter, "Can we stop now with the 'Bannon is a masterful strategist' nonsense? I've never seen such descriptions used more and deserved less."

Josh Holmes, former chief of staff and campaign manager to Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, tweeted, "Before we get the results, I'd just like to thank Steve Bannon for showing us how to lose the reddest state in the union and Governor Ivey for the opportunity to make this national embarrassment a reality."

Meanwhile, Megan McCain, co-host of "The View" and daughter of Sen. John McCain, simply had this to say: "Suck it Bannon." The criticism comes as Bannon continues to promote his political agenda and influence within the Republican Party.

Title: Grand Jury Indicts Twelve Russian Intelligence Officers for 2016 U.S. Presidential Election Interference

Article:

A Grand Jury in the District of Columbia has charged twelve Russian intelligence officers with conspiring to hack into the computers of U.S. persons and entities involved in the 2016 U.S. presidential election, steal documents, and stage releases of the stolen documents to interfere with the 2016 presidential election. The operation, according to the indictment, targeted over 300 individuals affiliated with the Clinton Campaign, DCCC, and DNC.

The indictment alleges that the operation was sustained and sophisticated, and it was consequential. While the scale of the attack on the Clinton campaign, the DCCC, and the DNC was troubling, the available public evidence at this point suggests that the Russians also attempted to hack Republicans, but the indictment outlines a comprehensive and sustained effort against the Democrats and is silent about a similar conspiracy aimed at Republicans.

The indictment provides a clearer picture of the precise details of alleged Russian election meddling than any other source. It demonstrates why it's important that Special Counsel Robert Mueller be permitted to finish his work, as our nation needs to know what happened in 2016.

The indictment also indicates that Mueller possesses evidence and information that the public hasn't yet seen. For example, paragraph 43a of the indictment contains the first evidence of possible Russian collusion with an American candidate for public office, not President Trump, but an unnamed candidate for Congress. The indictment also includes a disturbing detail about a transfer of information, including the personal identifying information of Democratic donors, to a "state lobbyist and online source of political news."

Furthermore, there's a partial record of communication between the newly indicted Russians and a "person who was in regular contact with senior members" of Trump's presidential campaign. While the indictment doesn't establish collusion between the Trump campaign and the Russians, it clearly indicates that Mueller possesses evidence and information that the public hasn't yet seen.

The indictment makes it even more troubling that President Trump mocks, denigrates, and undermines the Mueller investigation as a "witch hunt." We now know that there was real wrongdoing; we just don't yet know its extent. We don't yet know if Trump cooperated in any way with Russian schemes. However, when we learn more about the extent of Russian efforts to disrupt the 2016 election (and aid Trump), when we remember that Donald Jr. actually tried to collude, when we ponder for more than a few moments the web of financial connections between senior Trump aides such as Paul Manafort and Michael Flynn and the Kremlin or Kremlin allies, and when we know that Russians contacted Trump friends and advisers to offer "dirt" on the Clinton campaign—well, Trump's repeated demands that the investigation end become much less understandable.

Republicans were rightly outraged when Barack Obama opined about the pending Clinton-email investigation, and we have since learned that his gratuitous and public exoneration of the then–likely Democratic nominee created a headache for the FBI. Now it's time for Republicans to be consistent. As Mueller reveals more facts about Russian interference and indicts more individuals for troubling crimes uncovered as part of his entirely legitimate investigation, it's time for the GOP to tell the president that the hunt needs to continue, because the witches are very real.

Title: Pelosi Calls for Removal of Confederate Statues from U.S. Capitol

Article:

Speaker of the House Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) has called for the removal of nearly a dozen Confederate statues from the U.S. Capitol building, following the death of George Floyd and nationwide protests against racial injustice. In a letter to Joint Committee on the Library Chairman Roy Blunt (R-Mo.) and Vice Chair Zoe Lofgren (D-Calif.), Pelosi stated that the statues in the Capitol should embody the nation's highest ideals, not its divisive past.

Pelosi pointed out that two of the statues currently in National Statuary Hall, a landmark in the Capitol housing various historical members, are the statues of the president and vice president of the Confederate States, Jefferson Davis and Alexander Stephens – both of whom were charged with treason against the United States.

Stephens is known for his infamous speech on the Confederacy, in which he stated, "Our new government is founded upon … the great truth that the negro is not equal to the white man; that slavery subordination to the superior race is his natural and normal condition." Pelosi wrote, "Monuments to men who advocated cruelty and barbarism to achieve such a plainly racist end are a grotesque affront to these ideals. Their statues pay homage to hate, not heritage. They must be removed."

Vice Chair Zoe Lofgren (D-Calif.) told Fox News, "I agree that the Joint Committee and Architect of the Capitol should expediently remove these symbols of cruelty and bigotry from the halls of the Capitol. I stand ready, and call on the Chair of the Joint Committee to swiftly approve the removal of these statues."

Pelosi attempted to have the Confederate statues removed in 2017, appealing to then-Speaker of the House Paul Ryan (R-Wis.). Ryan argued that it should be up to the states that placed them in Statuary Hall to remove them. While states have the right to switch out their statue of choice from the Hall, Congress has the final say on what is and is not allowed to be kept in the Capitol.

According to a 1864 law passed by Congress, Statuary Hall allows each state to place up to two statues in the Hall. The law was further amended in 2000, to allow states to replace sculptures placed in the Hall. However, Congressional Research Service reports state that the Architect of the Capitol, upon the approval of the Joint Committee on the Library, is authorized to locate or relocate collection statues within the Capitol.

Pelosi wrote, "While I believe it is imperative that we never forget our history lest we repeat it, I also believe that there is no room for celebrating the violent bigotry of the men of the Confederacy in the hallowed halls of the United States Capitol or in places of honor across the country."

Title: New Research Suggests Microplastic Pollution in Oceans and Rivers May Be Underestimated

Article:

A new study suggests that the abundance of microplastic pollution in the oceans may have been significantly underestimated. Researchers from the Plymouth Marine Laboratory in the UK and other institutions found many more microplastic particles using nets with a fine mesh size compared to coarser ones typically used to filter microplastics.

The research, published in the journal Environmental Pollution, used nets with mesh sizes of 100 microns (0.1mm), 333 microns, and 500 microns. The team found 2.5 times more particles in the finest net than in the 333 micron net, which is the kind usually used to filter microplastics, and 10 times more than in the 500 micron net.

The surface trawls off the coast of Plymouth in the UK and the coast of Maine in the US showed similar results, suggesting they are representative of waters near populated land. The particles were dominated by fibers from textiles such as ropes, nets, and clothing.

Prof. Pennie Lindeque, who led the research, said, "Using an extrapolation, we suggest microplastic concentrations could exceed 3,700 particles per cubic meter – that's far more than the number of zooplankton you would find." These tiny animals are among the most abundant species on the planet.

Another new study, published in the journal Global Change Biology, shows how microplastics have entered the food chain in rivers. The research analyzed the droppings and regurgitated pellets of white-throated dippers at 15 river sites in south Wales. The scientists found that the birds, which feed on river insects, were eating about 200 pieces of plastic a day. These were mostly fibers, and a quarter were larger than 500 microns.

The team also found that the dippers were feeding thousands of plastic fibers to their nest-bound chicks during their development. Previous research by the scientists had shown that half of the river insects contain microplastic fragments.

The impact on the health of the birds is not yet understood. "It is imperative we understand whether microplastics add to the other pollution problems that affect dippers and other river organisms, and we use that knowledge to guide remedial action," said Prof. Steve Ormerod, who led the work.

Microplastic pollution has contaminated the whole planet, from Arctic snow and mountain soils to many rivers and the deepest oceans. It is also being consumed and inhaled by people, and the health impacts are as yet unknown.

Title: Sen. Rand Paul Introduces Bill to End No-Knock Warrants, Citing Breonna Taylor's Death

Article:

Sen. Rand Paul (R-Ky.) has introduced legislation to abolish no-knock warrants, a measure that has bipartisan support as lawmakers discuss broader police reforms. The bill, titled the Justice for Breonna Taylor Act, would prohibit federal law enforcement from executing a warrant until an officer provides notice of their authority and purpose.

The legislation also applies to state and local law enforcement agencies that receive funding from the Justice Department. In a statement, Sen. Paul stated, "After talking with Breonna Taylor's family, I've come to the conclusion that it's long past time to get rid of no-knock warrants. This bill will effectively end no-knock raids in the United States."

Taylor, a 26-year-old black woman, was fatally shot in her home in Kentucky by police executing a no-knock warrant. The bill comes as Congress debates how to respond to the death of George Floyd, an unarmed black man who was killed while in police custody in Minneapolis.

A proposal unveiled by House and Senate Democrats earlier this week would ban the use of no-knock warrants in federal drug cases and tie law enforcement funding to state and local agencies on a similar ban. Sen. Tim Scott (R-S.C.) is drafting a Senate GOP proposal, which he is expected to unveil next week.

Paul's legislation also comes after he had disagreements with Sens. Cory Booker (D-N.J.) and Kamala Harris (D-Calif.) over an amendment to the bill that would make lynching a federal hate crime. In a statement earlier this month, Sen. Paul stated that he was trying to add an amendment that would "apply a serious bodily injury standard, which would ensure crimes resulting in substantial risk of death and extreme physical pain be prosecuted as a lynching."

However, Sens. Booker and Harris accused him of trying to water down the bill. The details of the amendment and the response from the senators are not specified in the provided text.

Title: Progressive Movement Divided: Sanders Endorses Biden, but Not All Follow Suit

Article:

Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-VT) has endorsed Joe Biden for the Democrat nomination, but not all members of his political movement are following suit. On Monday, shortly after Sanders' endorsement, his one-time campaign spokeswoman, Briahna Joy Gray, announced that she was not endorsing Biden.

Gray, who has been vocal about her disagreement with other high-profile national Democrats, cited Biden's unwillingness to adopt progressive stances on the economy and healthcare as the reason for her decision. "With the utmost respect for Bernie Sanders, who is an incredible human being [and] a genuine inspiration, I don't endorse Joe Biden," she wrote on social media.

Gray supported Sanders because he backed ideas like Medicare for All, cancelling all student debt, and a wealth tax. However, she noted, Biden supports none of those.

The ideological differences highlighted by Gray underscore the challenge that lies ahead for Biden. Since the former vice president routed his opposition on Super Tuesday to become the presumptive nominee, progressives aligned with Sanders have been exploring their options for the general election. Many seem to have found Biden, who has unequivocally come out against universal healthcare and has shown disdain for the "socialist" label, wanting.

In recent weeks, as it became apparent that the former vice president would be the nominee, a small but vocal "Never Biden" community has sprouted up on social media. Its members include former campaign operatives, sympathetic media pundits, and the types of average voters that made Sanders' 2016 insurgent campaign possible.

Biden has offered several olive branches to the disaffected Sanders supporters. Last month, the former vice president opted to adopt the bankruptcy proposal authored by his former rival, Sen. Elizabeth Warren (D-MA). The decision was a full repudiation of the Bankruptcy Abuse Prevention and Consumer Protection Act of 2005, which Biden authored and progressives have long claimed was a giveaway to big banks. Biden's shift on bankruptcy was followed up last week by an embrace of lowering the age of Medicaid eligibility to 60 and student loan forgiveness for individuals making below $125,000-per-year.

However, these efforts have not been successful. More than a few members of Sanders' political movement have rejected the olive branches as not going far enough. Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez (D-NY), who endorsed the Vermont senator last year and campaigned for him ahead of the Iowa Caucuses, described Biden's proposal as "almost an insult."

"I think Hillary [Clinton] was looking at policies that lowered it to 50," the congresswoman told The New York Times in an interview published Monday. "So we're talking about a 'progressive concession' that is ten years worse than what the nominee had in 2016."

Policy differences are not the only reason why many members of Sanders' political movement remain uncommitted about backing Biden. Some, in particular, are concerned about new sexual assault allegations leveled against the former vice president by former staffer Tara Reade.

In fact, when Reade's allegations first surfaced last month, a top Sanders supporter announced they believed the accusations were true. Others from the Never Biden community soon echoed the sentiment, with some even openly saying the allegations were disqualifying for the former vice president's candidacy.

This poses a major predicament. In 2016, President Donald Trump won the White House, in part, because disaffected Sanders supporters opted to stay home or vote third party. Decreased turnout for the Democrat ticket that year, coupled with Trump's populist appeals to white working-class voters in the Midwest, led to a GOP victory.

A similar scenario could repeat itself this year. Exit polls from last month's Michigan primary found that only two out of five Sanders supporters would be willing to back Biden in November, according to Politico. If those numbers hold on election day, it would spell disaster for Biden, especially as Michigan is considered a must-win if Democrats have any hope of retaking the White House.

Sanders, himself, appears to understand the predicament members of his one-time movement pose for Biden. On Monday, while endorsing the former vice president, the Vermont senator urged his supporters to fall in line behind the Democrat nominee.

"We must come together to defeat the most dangerous president in modern history," Sanders said.

Title: Sanders' Influence and Work in Congress: A Neutral Analysis

Article:

Representative Anna Eshoo, a California Democrat and close ally of House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, described Senator Bernie Sanders as working independently during his time in the House, with little recall of his collaborations or projects. His influence appears to be more pronounced in the Senate, according to Senator Sherrod Brown, a Democrat from Ohio and progressive.

Senator Brown noted that while some senators, such as Hubert Humphrey and Teddy Kennedy, were effective in both internal and external strategies, Sanders has chosen to focus on external strategy, building support from outside the Senate. His work as the ranking member of the Senate Budget Committee has been mixed, with difficulties in recruiting and retaining top-tier staff for the committee.

Senator Sanders has reportedly sought the assistance of Senator Patty Murray, a highly regarded legislative technician, to help navigate complex budget matters. Sanders is said to have a disdain for mundane, technocratic tasks, as evidenced by a former aide's recollection of him asking, "What's the news for today?" during a discussion of routine committee business.

Senator Sanders' primary objective has been to shift the Democratic Party to the left, rather than negotiate compromises within the system. He has made an impact on select issues, such as challenging both parties' leadership on President Trump's support for Saudi intervention in Yemen, and pushing for improved pay and benefits for large employers like Amazon, Disney, and Walmart.

However, Sanders acknowledged that the legislation aimed at large employers is unlikely to reach the floor. He views the legislation as a means to demonstrate support for workers and assert that significant success can be achieved without passing specific legislation.

Despite his often-perceived curmudgeonly demeanor, Senator Sanders has made efforts to maintain a positive working relationship with Senator Elizabeth Warren. Recently, he was seen reconciling a disagreement between the two campaigns in a Senate hallway.

Title: Jeb Bush's Presidential Campaign Faces Fundraising Challenges as Donor Support Wanes

Article:

Jeb Bush's presidential campaign, which has raised significantly more than his Republican rivals to date, is experiencing difficulties in maintaining its initial momentum. The former Florida governor is slipping in the polls, and top party donors are withholding their commitments.

On Friday, a finance aide for Mr. Bush sent an email to contributors inviting them to a breakfast fund-raiser in Washington next month, with a plea for new donors. Sarah Corsaro, the staff member, wrote, "Please note—this is new money only." She explained, "We are utilizing this event to drive in new funds" for the next quarterly fund-raising disclosure.

The email suggests that in his initial push to raise money after announcing his candidacy in June, Mr. Bush maximized his support among backers in the Washington area capable of giving the $2,700 legally allowed. The campaign is now eager to add wealthy donors who have previously not contributed to Mr. Bush.

The co-chair committee for the $1,000-per-person breakfast indicates why Mr. Bush is so focused on finding new donors: it is a list heavy with family, friends, and former aides and loyalists to his father, brother, and himself.

Mr. Bush raised a combined $114 million for his campaign and "super PAC" in the first half of the year. However, with Donald J. Trump unexpectedly surging and Mr. Bush falling in Republican polls, some of the party's top money raisers are remaining on the fence in terms of supporting Mr. Bush.

This reluctance, and the prospect of a hard-fought Republican contest that could last well into 2016, has prompted Mr. Bush to institute cost-saving measures in his campaign. Some aides have seen their pay cut back as part of an effort to curtail spending.

Additionally, on Friday, three of the candidate's Florida fund-raising consultants left the campaign after apparently clashing with the new leadership team Mr. Bush installed in June. Mr. Bush's hard-charging campaign manager, Danny Diaz, has pushed staffers to work longer hours and be more cost-conscious.

Tim Miller, communications director for Mr. Bush, commented, "Ann Herberger is his longtime fund-raising consultant in Florida. We have a full-time finance staff in Miami HQ, as well. These are consultants with multiple clients. We moved in a different direction."

Title: U.S. Halts Funding to World Health Organization Amidst COVID-19 Pandemic Debate

Article:

In April, the White House announced a decision to halt funding to the World Health Organization (WHO) pending a review of the organization's response to the COVID-19 pandemic. The United States, historically the largest funder of the WHO, is followed by the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation and the United Kingdom.

The announcement has sparked a heated debate, with both sides presenting strong arguments. The WHO is a part of the United Nations, composed of and run by 194 member nations. Member states choose a delegation to represent the country in the World Health Assembly, and the Executive Board operationalizes policies set by the World Health Assembly.

Established in 1948, the WHO has a history of successes, such as eradicating smallpox, and perceived failures, like its delayed response to the Ebola outbreak in 2014. The organization is headquartered in Geneva, Switzerland, and functions through a collection of six semi-autonomous regional offices. Dr. Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus serves as the Director-General of the WHO, currently in a five-year elected term.

The WHO is funded by assessed contributions and voluntary contributions. Assessed contributions are required of each member state, scaled by income and population. Voluntary contributions may be made by member states (in addition to assessed contributions) or by individual donors. As noted, the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation is the second-largest funder of the WHO via voluntary contributions. Overall, voluntary contributions make up 80% of the total.

The WHO's objective is to monitor and coordinate activities related to health issues, including genetically modified foods, climate change, tobacco and drug use, and road safety.

Criticism of the WHO's response to the COVID-19 pandemic has been widespread, with particular concern over China's influential role in the information released during the early stages of the crisis. A new article in the World Association for Disaster and Emergency Medicine states, "Influence from powerful political donors, which has become most evident in the current COVID-19 pandemic, the global community can no longer tolerate an ineffectual and passive international response system, nor tolerate the self-serving political interference that authoritarian regimes and others have exercised over the WHO."

However, the White House's move to halt funding entirely during the pandemic has also been met with considerable criticism. In the analysis below, we'll walk through the key points made by proponents of halting funds and opponents to halting funds.

Both sides agree that the world needs effective and coordinated leadership to respond to global health crises. Proponents argue that halting WHO funding is necessary to address the missteps and clear political bias demonstrated by the WHO. Opponents of halting WHO funding say it's irresponsible to discontinue funding of the world's most influential health organization in the middle of a pandemic.

Title: North Korea Agrees to Talks on Denuclearization with U.S. and South Korea

Article:

North Korea has expressed a willingness to engage in open-ended dialogue with the United States regarding denuclearization and normalizing relations, according to South Korean National Security Advisor Chung Eui-yong. This development follows unprecedented meetings in Pyongyang between high-level South Korean officials and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un.

Kim Jong Un has also agreed to refrain from conducting nuclear and missile tests while engaging in dialogue with South Korea, as per Chung's statement after his return from the meetings. The North Korean leader has shown a desire to be recognized as the primary decision-maker in his government, according to an unnamed official with deep knowledge of North Korea.

U.S. President Donald Trump believes North Korea is sincere in its peace talks with South Korea, stating, "I really believe they are sincere. I hope they are sincere. We'll find out." The U.S. will continue with joint military exercises with South Korea, as per a senior administration official.

South Korean President Moon Jae-in and Kim Jong Un will meet for a summit at the demilitarized zone in April, with the two sides opening a hotline for direct communication between the leaders. The April summit will take place at Panmunjom Peace House on the South Korean side of the demilitarized zone.

The U.S. and South Korea expect to proceed with their joint military exercises, but it is unclear if Tuesday's developments will alter that. During the Tuesday meeting, Kim Jong Un expressed understanding of South Korea's position on the military drills.

The U.S. is looking for North Korea to take concrete actions or "credible moves" toward denuclearization before agreeing to direct talks, according to a senior administration official. The official indicated that a North Korean pledge to stop testing nuclear weapons and ballistic missiles would not suffice if North Korea privately continues to develop its nuclear and ballistic missile programs.

The U.S. has long maintained a policy of bringing "intensifying economic and diplomatic pressure" to bear until North Korea completely and verifiably abandons its nuclear weapons and ballistic missile program, as stated by Vice President Mike Pence last month.

The announcement represents a significant diplomatic accomplishment for South Korean President Moon Jae-in, who has been a proponent of dialogue and engagement with North Korea since his days as a presidential aide to former President Roh Moo-hyun. The detente brought about by the Olympic diplomacy offered Moon an opportunity to dispatch a high-level delegation to Pyongyang, where they met with Kim Jong Un and some of his top aides, including his sister, Kim Yo Jong.

The April summit will mark the first inter-Korean summit since 2007, when South Korean President Roh met Kim Jong Un's father, late North Korean leader Kim Jong Il. Though surprising, the statements from North Korea are not a complete U-turn, as Pyongyang has long maintained its development of nuclear weapons is a response to what it calls the U.S.'s "hostile policy" toward the Democratic People's Republic of Korea, the country's official name.

Experts have noted that the statements from North Korea reiterate its longstanding position, but the context and timing matter, and this opens up the opportunity for more diplomacy. The U.S. and South Korea had postponed joint military exercises during the Winter Olympics but the drills had been expected to resume after the Paralympics end later this month. It is unclear whether Tuesday's developments will alter that.

Title: Opposition Criticizes Indian Government Over Deadly New Delhi Riots; Government Defends Handling of Violence

Article:

India's opposition politicians have criticized the Hindu nationalist government for the deadly anti-Muslim violence that occurred in the capital New Delhi, with the main opposition Congress party calling for the resignation of the interior minister, Amit Shah. The violence, which took place between February 24 and 27, resulted in the deaths of 52 people, mostly Muslims, and caused significant property damage and destruction of religious structures.

The opposition Congress party members of Parliament walked out after Home Minister Amit Shah praised the police for ending the rioting in northeastern areas of the capital within 36 hours and preventing it from spreading across New Delhi. The violence followed a series of anti-Muslim hate speeches by Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) leaders, including Kapil Mishra, who warned Muslims protesting against a new citizenship law to wind down their sit-ins in northeast Delhi.

Asaduddin Owaisi, the chief of the opposition All India Majlis-e-Ittehadul Muslimeen party, accused the governing BJP of spreading hatred against Muslims, the country's largest minority. "What is my dignity when 19 mosques have been destroyed or damaged? What is my dignity when I see a saffron flag being erected on a mosque?" Owaisi said during his speech, referring to the flag associated with Hindu far-right groups planted on a mosque minaret during the violence.

Opposition Congress party leader Adhir Ranjan Chaudhary accused the police of ignoring hundreds of distress calls from people who were under attack and failing to protect them. "In light of the scale of violence and consequent loss of lives and property, we strongly demand the resignation of the home minister," he said.

The Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA), passed last December, fast-tracks naturalization for minorities of all major faiths in South Asia except Islam. Muslims and liberal Indians say it is against the officially secular nation's constitution and is part of Prime Minister Narendra Modi's agenda of Hindu supremacy.

Home Minister Amit Shah, in a statement to the lower house of the Indian Parliament, assured strict action would be taken against the perpetrators of violence and offered his condolences to the families of those killed during the riots. He blamed inflammatory speeches by the Congress party and some Muslim leaders for triggering the rioting. He declined to say how many were Hindus or Muslims but media reports say most of those killed were Muslims.

Muslims have reportedly suffered most of the damages to their properties and religious structures, with many of them living in relief camps. BJP member of Parliament Meenakshi Lekhi accused a little-known Islamist organization and elements of the ISIL (ISIS) group of organizing the violence. She also alleged that US financier and philanthropist George Soros pledged to donate $1bn to finish India's nationalism.

In light of the scale of violence and consequent loss of lives and property, we strongly demand the resignation of the home minister. Adhir Ranjan Chaudhary, Congress party leader.

Another senior Congress leader, Kapil Sibal, accused the government of protecting the guilty. "We know what will happen. You will punish the innocent and give protection to the guilty. Even when you know who the accused are, no FIRs are filed. Don't let such a thing happen," Sibal said in Parliament.

Owaisi, the member of Parliament from Hyderabad, accused the government of failing in discharging its constitutional duties to save the lives of Indians. "Do you have any remorse on your faces? Do you have any embarrassment for what has happened right under your nose? No. You have no embarrassment, you take pride on the dead bodies, which are lying in drains," said Owaisi, who has emerged as a leading voice of Indian Muslims.

Owaisi also accused the government of presiding over two pogroms, referring to the Gujarat 2002 pogrom when more than 1,000 people, mostly Muslims, were killed under Modi's chief ministership. Prime Minister Modi and his close aide Shah have not visited the violence-affected areas of Delhi, with Modi's only comment being a call for calm on his Twitter handle.

Title: Bipartisan Leaders Criticize Democrats for Delaying Paycheck Protection Program Funding

Article:

Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-KY) and House Minority Leader Kevin McCarthy (R-CA) have criticized Democrats and House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D-CA) for refusing to replenish the Paycheck Protection Program (PPP) of the CARES Act, which is expected to run out of funding in a matter of hours.

In a statement, the two leaders stated, "The Small Business Administration and the Department of the Treasury report that the Paycheck Protection Program will exhaust its funding in a matter of hours. It will have to stop accepting applications for job-saving loans."

As of late Wednesday, the Small Business Administration had approved over 1.5 million loans valued at more than $324 billion, with loans still being processed. Both Democrats and Republicans want to add $250 billion to the small-business aid program, but have been sparring over whether to add restrictions to the funds.

Democrats have proposed expanding access to the loans and including more money for hospitals, food assistance, and state and local governments. Republicans, on the other hand, want to keep the bill focused on increasing small-business aid and defer other funding debates until the next, broader legislation is crafted.

The leaders' statement continued, "This did not have to happen. Republicans have been sounding the alarm for more than a week. Last Thursday, Senate Republicans tried to pass a narrow and clean bill that would have simply put more money into this critical program without changing any of the underlying policies that passed the Senate and the House unanimously. Democrats blocked it."

The news comes as large swaths of the American economy have been effectively closed for the last few weeks due to the coronavirus outbreak that originated in Wuhan, China. The U.S., which has led the world in widespread testing, has nearly 630,000 confirmed cases and over 25,000 reported deaths from the virus. The hardest-hit states in the U.S. are New York, New Jersey, Massachusetts, Michigan, and California. The New York City area has been the hardest-hit area in the country, accounting for nearly one-third of all the coronavirus cases in the U.S. and nearly half the deaths in the U.S.
