Clinton's speech in 2008, thanking her supporters for helping to put "18 million cracks" in the "highest, hardest glass ceiling," came late in the primary, in her concession to Obama. This time around, Clinton has been attacking Republicans on women's issues and women's health, hoping that a real contrast on the issues will be what gets her over the finish line in a general election and motivates female voters.

Clinton singled out several Republican presidential candidates by name, including Donald Trump and Dr. Ben Carson, for their positions on women's issues and women's health. She criticized Trump for his statements on women's health issues and his opposition to abortion rights, and took a swipe at Carson for his opposition to abortion rights as well.

New Hampshire voters provided a fitting audience for Clinton's full-court woman press. In 2008, the Granite State was the first in the nation to elect a state legislature with more women than men, Clinton noted in her speech. In 2012, it was the first state to send an all-women congressional delegation to Washington. The chief justice of the Supreme Court in New Hampshire is a woman, and Shaheen made history as the first woman to be elected senator and governor from her state.

"I think the rest of America could learn a few lessons from New Hampshire, don't you?" Clinton said. "Republicans actually say I'm playing the gender card. Well, if calling for equal pay and paid leave and women's health is playing the gender card, deal me in."

Title: Trump Announces Removal from Business Operations to Avoid Perceived Conflict of Interest

Article:

In a press conference scheduled for December 15 in New York City, President Donald Trump has announced his decision to step away from his business ventures to focus solely on his presidential duties. The move is intended to eliminate any perceived conflict of interest between his business interests and his role as President.

Trump, who had previously discussed the idea of placing his business in a "blind trust" during the GOP primary debates, has acknowledged that this would not be a true blind trust, as his children and existing Trump Organization executives would continue to manage the business.

Despite this, Trump has been criticized for involving his family members in diplomatic meetings and business discussions, blurring the line between his personal and professional responsibilities. In the past, Trump has expressed confusion about the concept of a blind trust, only later stating that no such trust was necessary due to the law allowing a president to avoid conflicts of interest.

The President's decision to step away from his business operations follows months of controversy and debate over his business dealings and potential conflicts of interest. Trump's announcement comes as a response to calls for transparency and the appearance of impartiality in his role as President.

The specifics of Trump's legal separation from his business have yet to be disclosed. The President has stated that the move is "visually important" to avoid any appearance of conflict of interest.

Title: The Controversy Surrounding Confederate Statues and Symbols in America

Article:

In recent times, the removal of Confederate statues and symbols has been a contentious issue in America. These monuments have been vandalized, assaulted, and torn down, with authorities working to remove them. President Donald Trump has been a vocal supporter of preserving these symbols, advocating for the retention of military bases named after Confederate generals and suggesting that we should build upon our heritage rather than tearing it down.

Conservatives generally oppose politically correct campaigns to destroy anything that may cause offense. They fear that the eradication of Confederate symbols could lead to the destruction of other historical figures, such as George Washington. They value tradition and are concerned that we are discarding part of our history.

However, the argument for the removal of Confederate statues and symbols is that they are an unnecessary affront to black citizens, who should not have to see defenders of chattel slavery elevated on pedestals, literally. The context in which these monuments were created must be considered, as many were erected as part of an effort to enshrine a dishonest, prettied-up version of the Confederacy.

Large statues in prominent public spaces, erected to glorify the Confederacy, should be moved to museums or battlefields. This should be done lawfully, not via mob action. The Confederate flag should be shunned, as a symbol of a viciously flawed cause. Direct commemorations of the Confederate war dead, such as obelisks with lists of names and Confederate cemeteries, should be preserved to mark the human cost of a terrible conflict.

The case of military bases named after Confederate generals is more complex, as these names have become part of the American military tradition. However, as the source of these names becomes more widely known, it may become increasingly difficult to ask African-American soldiers to overlook these names.

The statue of Robert E. Lee in Richmond, Virginia, which Governor Ralph Northam has announced will be removed, has long been a point of contention. Its 1890 unveiling was a significant moment in the creation of a cult of Lee as a man of "moral strength and moral beauty." This portrayal was part of a Lost Cause mythology that maintained the Civil War was not primarily about slavery, but about Southern states defending their legitimate prerogatives.

Alexander Stephens, the vice president of the Confederacy, would have scoffed at this. In his Cornerstone Speech in 1861, he stated that the new government was built on "the great truth" of slavery. The theory of states' rights used by the Confederacy to justify secession was not intended to preserve the constitutional scheme, but to dismantle it. The idea had been developed by former vice president John C. Calhoun of South Carolina, who believed the country had embarked on an erroneous, nationalist path from the beginning.

The South supported states' rights only to the extent that they were useful in protecting slavery. It insisted, after all, on a federal Fugitive Slave Act. Secession was a traitorous act that threatened to destroy the American nation, to create a rump republic built on slavery, and to make the subsequent rise of the United States to a world power impossible. Its leaders do not deserve to be given a place of honor in our landscape, denied to worthier men. Confederate statues should not be vandalized, but they should go.

Title: Federal Judge Rules President Obama's Immigration Actions Unconstitutional in Criminal Case

Article:

A federal judge in Pennsylvania has ruled that President Barack Obama's recent executive actions on immigration are unconstitutional, but the decision came in a criminal case, leaving its broader impact uncertain. U.S. District Court Judge Arthur Schwab issued the first-of-its-kind ruling on Tuesday in the case of Elionardo Juarez-Escobar, a Honduran immigrant charged in federal court with unlawful re-entry after being arrested earlier this year in Pennsylvania for drunken driving.

In a 38-page opinion, Schwab stated that Obama's unilateral legislative action violates the separation of powers provided for in the United States Constitution as well as the Take Care Clause. The judge argued that Obama's November 20, 2014 Executive Action goes beyond prosecutorial discretion because it provides for a systematic and rigid process by which a broad group of individuals will be treated differently than others based upon arbitrary classifications, rather than case-by-case examination. The judge also noted that the actions allow undocumented immigrants, who fall within these broad categories, to obtain substantive rights.

Schwab rejected a Justice Department legal opinion arguing that Obama's actions fall within the traditional realm of the executive's discretion about which cases to pursue and which to overlook. The judge also quoted in detail from a series of public statements Obama made in recent years about the limits on his executive authority to make sweeping changes in immigration enforcement.

A Justice Department spokesman rejected the judge's legal rationale and his decision to opine on the legality of Obama's actions. "The decision is unfounded and the court had no basis to issue such an order," said the official, who asked not to be named. "No party in the case challenged the constitutionality of the immigration-related executive actions and the department’s filing made it clear that the executive actions did not apply to the criminal matter before the court."

Another administration official, who also asked not to be named, added: "The judge's ruling has absolutely no effect on the president's executive actions. The judge has not been asked to rule on them, and the judge's order does not affect them. [The Department of Homeland Security] continues to prepare to implement the executive actions."

In a court filing earlier this month, prosecutors argued that Obama's decision to defer deportation of many immigrants did not limit criminal cases like the one against Juarez-Escobar. "This policy...relates only to civil immigration enforcement status; it...has no effect on criminal prosecutions," prosecutors wrote in their filing. "Modification of DHS policy to prioritize particular classes of unauthorized aliens in order to allocate resources for civil immigration enforcement does not limit the Department of Justice’s prosecutorial decision on the criminal referral in this case."

Lawsuits challenging Obama's policies in a more direct way are pending in Washington, D.C., and Brownsville, Texas. A hearing on a request to block the presidential actions is scheduled for next week in the D.C. case, brought by Maricopa County, Arizona, Sheriff Joe Arpaio. In the Texas case, a total of 24 states are challenging the legality of Obama's immigration moves.

While those cases have at least the theoretical possibility to halt Obama's actions, the Pennsylvania case—as a criminal proceeding involving a single individual—does not seem to have that potential. However, Schwab's ruling could have some impact, especially since lawyers handling the lawsuits pending in D.C. and Texas filed Schwab's opinion with the judges on those cases late Tuesday.

Since Schwab is a Bush appointee, it will be tempting for many immigrant rights advocates to view his opinion as a political swipe at Obama. Indeed, many of the judge's arguments parallel those being put forward by Republican critics of the president's immigration actions. However, the judge's opinion raises a question that some advocates of more liberal immigration policies will not be able to dismiss so easily: why do not Obama's actions apply to criminal prosecutions as well as deportations? Indeed, what is the point of protecting immigrants from being expelled from the country if they can still be sent to prison for having illegally entered the country in the first place?

Schwab wrote in his ruling Tuesday that he's open to Juarez-Escobar withdrawing a guilty plea he offered in October, less than a month before Obama announced plans to allow family members of U.S. citizens to stay in the U.S for up to three years and obtain work permits. Schwab's opinion appears to have been first reported by the Volokh Conspiracy blog.

UPDATE (Tuesday, 8:47 p.m.): This post has been updated with reactions from administration officials.

UPDATE 2 (Wednesday, 8:38 a.m.): This post has been upated with the filing of Schwab's opinion in the pending lawsuits.

Title: Trump's Unconventional Approach Yields Significant Achievements in First Year

Article:

President Donald Trump, who took office in 2017, faced a wave of negativity and skepticism, with some predicting he would not complete his first year in office or pass major legislation. However, the Pew Research Center reported that 62 percent of news stories about Trump's first 60 days were negative, compared to 20 percent for President Obama and 28 percent for Bush and Clinton.

Despite the negative media coverage, Trump's actions have been pleasing his supporters. The economy is experiencing growth not seen in years, the most significant tax reform since 1986 has been passed, and deregulation efforts are underway. The number of pages in the Federal Register, where new regulations are published, is now two-thirds of where it stood during the Obama administration.

Trump has made a lasting impact on the nation through his conservative judicial appointments. Twelve of his federal appeals court judge nominations have been confirmed by the Senate, and Neil Gorsuch has taken the seat of the late Antonin Scalia on the Supreme Court. With two Supreme Court justices over 80, there is a possibility that Trump will have the opportunity to appoint another conservative justice during his first term.

Reports indicate that Trump will meet with Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell and House Speaker Paul Ryan at Camp David to discuss legislative plans for 2018. Major campaign issues still on the table include immigration reform, welfare reform, and national infrastructure investments. The outcome of these deliberations is expected to reflect a combination of idealism and political realism.

The Senate's Republican margin has narrowed to 51 to 49, increasing the challenge for McConnell. However, Trump's unconventional approach to politics has been marked by a willingness to push through his campaign promises, such as recognizing Jerusalem as the capital city of Israel.

Immigration reform and welfare reform are two issues of critical importance, both with significant impacts on the nation and both politically challenging. The inability of Washington to address these issues was a driving factor for many voters to support Trump. If Trump fails to address these issues, he risks becoming just another politician.

In conclusion, it is expected that 2018 will bring more unexpected accomplishments from Trump as he continues to carry forward his campaign promises. Trump's inaugural address encapsulated his vision for the country: "And whether a child is born in the urban sprawl of Detroit, or the windswept plains of Nebraska, they look up at the same night sky, they fill their hearts with the same dreams, and they are infused with the breath of life by the same almighty creator."

Title: U.S. and European Economic Measures Boost Stocks to Best Day of 2012

Article:

Stocks in the U.S. and Europe surged on Wednesday, marking their best day of the year, following speculation that governments in both regions may take action to support their economies. The Dow Jones Industrial Average surged 286.84 points to close at 12,414.79, its biggest gain since December 20.

Atlanta Federal Reserve President Dennis Lockhart, in a speech, highlighted the "halting and tenuous" recovery, suggesting that further monetary actions may be necessary if the current weak job growth trend continues. Meanwhile, news reports indicated that German and European Union officials were considering a plan to lend money from the European bailout fund to help rescue Spain's struggling banks.

In the ordinary stock market, such developments would likely not cause a significant impact. However, the market has been anything but ordinary lately, posting decline after decline amid the financial crisis in Europe and the slowing U.S. economy. Traders are now hanging on to rumors and speculation, according to Jeff Kleintop, chief market strategist at LPL Financial.

The Standard & Poor's 500 rose 29.63 points to 1,315.13, and the Nasdaq composite rose 66.61 points to 2,844.72. Companies whose stocks have been hardest hit over the past month experienced the best gains. Homebuilders rallied, helped by a strong earnings report from Hovnanian Enterprises and rising applications for new mortgages.

Hovnanian's CEO stated that he sees signs that the housing industry may be entering the early stages of recovery. The Mortgage Bankers Association reported that applications for mortgages rose 1.3 percent last week, largely due to more people trying to refinance their existing loans.

The gains were widespread, with only 11 companies in the S&P 500 dropping, and every industry group in the index rising, led by energy and financial companies. Roughly seven stocks rose for every one that fell on the New York Stock Exchange.

Jim Russell, chief equity strategist at U.S. Bank Wealth Management in Cincinnati, Ohio, said it's natural for the market to have a strong day after an extended period of decline. He described it as a "technical bounce," stating, "There's no bad news today, so the market goes up. Frankly, it's that simple."

U.S. markets followed major European indexes higher, with indexes rising 2.4 percent in the U.K. and France. Borrowing costs eased for Spain, another positive sign. A Federal Reserve survey showed growth across the country, with hiring steady, according to the Fed's "Beige Book." This contrasts with the government's monthly jobs report, which stated that employers added the fewest jobs in a year last month.

The dollar dipped, and Treasury yields rose as investors moved money out of defensive investments. The yield on the benchmark rose to 1.64 percent from 1.57 percent late Tuesday.

Other significant movers included Morgan Stanley, which jumped $1.08, 8 percent, to $13.94 amid reports that the Blackstone Group and other private equity firms may try to buy a stake in the bank's commodities business. UnitedHealth Group gained $1.66, 3 percent, to $57.70 after the health insurer said it will raise its quarterly dividend from 16 cents to 21 cents per share and approved a plan to buy back stock.

Tempur-Pedic International plunged $21.28, 49 percent, to $22.39, as the mattress maker expects quarterly profits to fall by half compared to last year. Tempur-Pedic blamed its competitors' aggressive marketing campaigns and promotions for hurting its sales.

Title: Clinton and Sanders Face Off in New Hampshire Debate Ahead of Primary

Article:

In the lead-up to the New Hampshire primary, Democratic candidates Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders faced off in a debate on Thursday, marking their only meeting before the Granite State primary. This encounter offers some insights into the candidates' strategies and positions.

Eight years ago, Hillary Clinton found herself in a tight spot in New Hampshire, facing a significant loss to Barack Obama. This time around, despite a 40-point lead in New Hampshire last summer, Clinton is currently in a dead heat with Sanders, according to a post-Iowa NBC News/Marist poll. Sanders, however, is not Obama in terms of organizational skills or the ability to build a majority coalition among Democratic voters.

One question that arises is why Clinton struggles to connect with voters on a personal level. As the Clinton team considers their post-New Hampshire strategy, they might want to consult the past campaigns of Mitt Romney, John McCain, and Bob Dole, all of whom made tactical errors by adopting more ideological personas that resonated poorly with their party's grassroots activists.

In the debate, Clinton was intense and focused on highlighting Sanders' 18 trillion dollar wish list of expansive government programs as unrealistic. While she is correct, her approach may not be the most effective way to appeal to Democratic voters, who typically respond well to personality and passion. Successful Democratic presidential candidates have historically run as optimists, not scolds.

Sanders, on the other hand, missed an opportunity to address Clinton's Goldman Sachs honoraria during the debate, despite an ad attacking Goldman Sachs' economic impact. Clinton, in turn, did not mention Sanders' son-in-law, who is a hedge-fund manager. The Clinton family's financial dealings, including speaking fees and other income sources, have been a point of contention and may pose a challenge in the general election.

Bill Clinton went largely unmentioned during the 90-minute debate, and there was no discussion of Donald Trump. MSNBC, the debate's host, missed opportunities to press Sanders on his endorsement plans should Clinton prevail and to address the possibility of Clinton selecting Sanders as a running mate.

As the two candidates debate their progressive credentials, the irony is palpable: either Clinton or Sanders will emerge victorious in this Democratic battle. Gallup's analysis shows that 20 U.S. states are "red" (solidly or leaning Republican) versus only 14 "blue" Democratic states, a significant shift from 2009 when Gallup painted 33 states blue and only five red. The debate's focus on progressive ideals underscores this shift in political landscape.

Title: Trump Admits Son's Meeting with Russian Lawyer was to Obtain Information on Opponent

Article:

US President Donald Trump has admitted that his son, Donald Trump Jr, met with Russian lawyer Natalia Veselnitskaya in June 2016 to obtain information on an opponent. The meeting, which took place at Trump Tower, is being investigated by Special Counsel Robert Mueller as part of his inquiry into Russia's alleged role in helping Mr. Trump win the 2016 presidential elections.

In a series of tweets on Sunday, Mr. Trump called the ongoing investigations in the US "the greatest political witch hunt in history." Russia has repeatedly denied claims it interfered in the November 2016 presidential elections, where Mr. Trump defeated Democratic rival Hillary Clinton.

On Monday, the president quoted a Fox and Friends interview about alleged Democratic collusion with Russia. Mr. Trump has spoken out before about links between Moscow and Mrs. Clinton while saying it is "commonly agreed" that there was no collusion between Russia and him.

Mr. Trump's Sunday tweet appears to contradict a previous statement from the Trump camp about the meeting. When the meeting was first reported by the New York Times, Donald Trump Jr said in a statement that he and Ms. Veselnitskaya had mostly discussed a suspended program for Americans to adopt Russian children. However, he subsequently admitted he had agreed to the meeting after being told he would be offered information that would prove detrimental to Mrs. Clinton. He also released the email exchange that brought about the meeting.

US media then reported that the US president had been involved in the initial statement his son issued on the meeting. This was initially denied by Mr. Trump's team, but his lawyers later confirmed that he had in fact dictated his son's statement.

US commentators have argued that Mr. Trump's new admission that the meeting was to gain information about Mrs. Clinton shows that the earlier statement was misleading. Mr. Trump again denied knowing about the meeting in Sunday's tweet.

The special counsel is currently investigating whether Mr. Trump obstructed justice. Under US law, obstruction cases require proving "corrupt intent" - so while Mr. Trump's tweet does not prove anything illegal, it could serve as evidence of the president's intent.

It is common for US politicians to research their opponents during a campaign. However, legal experts say that Mr. Trump Jr could fall foul of campaign finance laws, which prohibit accepting anything of value from a foreign government or foreign national. Mr. Trump Jr's apparently enthusiastic response to the offer of information about Mrs. Clinton could also breach conspiracy laws.

The Trump team has argued that Mr. Trump Jr ultimately did not receive any damaging information about Mrs. Clinton at the meeting. Some analysts say that by having the meeting at all, Mr. Trump Jr broke the law. But others say it is unclear as no information reportedly exchanged hands at the meeting.

One of Mr. Trump's lawyers, Jay Sekulow, said on Sunday that the meeting had not broken any laws. "The question is what law, statute or regulation's been violated? Nobody's pointed to one," Mr. Sekulow told ABC News.

Title: Trump's Election Raises Concerns for U.S. Allies Worldwide

Article:

The election of Donald Trump as the President of the United States has left governments worldwide, from Canberra to Copenhagen, in a state of uncertainty. If Trump's campaign rhetoric is to be taken at face value, the global landscape could become more dangerous for America's allies.

Since the end of World War II, a network of US-focused military alliances has underpinned global peace and security. Trump has questioned the value of these alliances, suggesting that America does not need them or that Washington should charge more for them. He has also referred to NATO, the bedrock of trans-Atlantic security, as "obsolete."

Trump's comments have raised concerns about the future of NATO, particularly in light of his perceived leniency towards Russian President Vladimir Putin and his apparent indifference towards NATO's collective defense structure. While most Western intelligence agencies warn that Putin's goal is to divide the West and undermine NATO, Trump seems less suspicious and less solicitous of that structure.

In Europe, Trump's election has sparked concerns about the future of the NATO alliance, with some members, such as the Baltic states, especially nervous about Moscow's intentions. In Asia, Trump's strategic intentions are also unclear, with some signs suggesting that he may be ready to abandon key allies like Japan and South Korea to their fate.

In Japan, Trump's election has raised concerns about the future of the security alliance, with the President-elect having said that unless Tokyo paid more for its defense, it should go it alone and perhaps build a nuclear weapon to protect itself. In South Korea, Trump's election has also caused uncertainty, with the President-elect having threatened to pull American forces out of the country unless Seoul pays more for their upkeep.

In Australia, one of America's most distant but most loyal allies, Trump's ascension has sparked unprecedented doubts about the future of a defense partnership with the United States that has undergirded the country's peace and prosperity since the end of World War II. With the signing of the ANZUS Treaty in 1951, Washington guaranteed Australia's security as it developed into one of the richest societies on earth. In return, Australian troops have fought alongside American forces in every war that Washington has fought.

The uncertainty surrounding Trump's foreign policy has left many allies questioning the future of their security arrangements with the United States. As Trump takes office, the world watches with bated breath to see how he will navigate the complex web of alliances that have underpinned global peace and security since the end of World War II.

Title: Georgia Secretary of State Investigates Minority Voter Registration Drive, Pastor Raphael Warnock Accuses of Voter Suppression

Article:

In a heated exchange, Pastor Raphael Warnock, the pastor of Atlanta's Ebenezer Baptist Church, has accused Georgia's Secretary of State, Brian Kemp, of voter suppression in connection with an ongoing investigation into a minority voter registration drive. The investigation, led by Kemp's office, is examining the New Georgia Project, an organization associated with Warnock, for potential fraud in its efforts to register over 100,000 minority voters before the October 6 deadline.

At a press conference in Georgia's Capitol building, Warnock stated, "You don't have to wear a hood -- you don't have to be a member of the Ku Klux Klan to be engaged in voter suppression. We know voter suppression when we see it."

Kemp's office has confirmed 28 cases of fraud in 14 counties, including 25 fraudulent voter registration applications and three fraudulent canvassing sheets. Some applications contained forged signatures, while others had false information. An additional 26 cases were labeled as suspicious. Falsifying a voter registration form is a felony in the state of Georgia.

Kemp told Fox News, "Any time that you're talking about forgery and fraud in Georgia law, it's certainly very serious."

The controversy arises in the context of the narrow margins in the race to replace retiring U.S. Sen. Saxby Chambliss (R-Ga.). Polls show Democratic candidate Michelle Nunn trailing Republican David Perdue. Nunn's campaign believes that if it makes significant inroads into signing up some of the 800,000 unregistered minority voters in Georgia, she could take the seat.

The New Georgia Project was founded by Georgia House Minority Leader Rep. Stacey Abrams, who is a member of Nunn's advisory team. Abrams maintains a clear separation between her work with the Nunn campaign and the New Georgia Project, which she describes as a "nonpartisan" effort to increase minority voter turnout in November.

Kemp has issued a subpoena to the New Georgia Project, demanding all documents and communications related to the voter registration drive by next Friday. The New Georgia Project has responded, proclaiming its innocence and stating that it is strictly following the law. Abrams argues that the subpoena is "overly burdensome and an abuse of power," taking valuable time away from the group's voter registration drive.

At the press conference, Abrams accused Kemp of a pattern of voter suppression and intimidation. The New Georgia Project claims that of the 85,000 new voters they have signed up, 51,000 have not yet been registered. Kemp insists that any valid voter registration forms will be processed by the appropriate county officials and that his office is not blocking the registration of minority voters.

Kemp told Fox News, "I was very disappointed in a lot of the reverend's comments." He added, "I think anybody that knows me knows that I'm not a racist and some of the things that they've said and accused me of are just flat wrong."

New Georgia Project officials claim the words "fraud," "forgery," and "felony" have a chilling effect on any other organizations who might want to sign up new voters.

Warnock demanded at the press conference, "Mr. Secretary of State, stop this dog and pony show with all of the subpoenas -- with all of the false accusations and the smear campaign, and do your job."

Kemp insists his job is to investigate any reports of fraud and forgery brought to his attention by several counties, stating that it is simply his duty to investigate them. He told Fox News that with what is at stake in November, it's not a surprise the matter has become so politicized.

"It's unfortunate that it's gotten political," Kemp said, "but we're in the silly season, if you will, right now, and have some big races in Georgia."

Title: DNC Chairman Urges States to Proceed with Primaries Amid COVID-19 Concerns

Article:

Democratic National Committee Chairman Tom Perez has encouraged states to hold their scheduled presidential primaries despite federal guidance advising against large gatherings due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. On Tuesday, Florida, Illinois, and Arizona conducted their primaries as planned, while Ohio, Georgia, Kentucky, and Louisiana postponed their primaries to prevent the spread of the coronavirus.

Perez commended the states that held their elections, acknowledging the risks associated with people gathering and voting. In an interview with NPR, Perez stated, "I think it's a false choice to suggest we either have to protect safety or protect and ensure our democracy. What you saw in Arizona today, and in Florida, was in Arizona more people voted early than voted in the entirety of the Democratic primary in 2016."

According to NPR, Arizona Democratic Party officials reported a surge in turnout due to early mail-in voting, a practice Perez is advocating for other states to adopt. He added, "I've called on all the states that haven't gone yet to take these steps so that we can in fact have voting and protect our workers, our voters, our candidates."

CBS News reported that some polling places experienced long lines and confusion on Tuesday, with many poll workers staying home to avoid health risks. Ohio Governor Mike DeWine (R) opted to postpone his state's primary to June, defying a judge's decision, as COVID-19 cases continued to rise. DeWine explained during a press conference, "We should not force [voters and poll workers] to make this choice. A choice between their health and their Constitutional rights and their duties."

The two Democratic front-runners, former Vice President Joe Biden and Senator Bernie Sanders (I-VT), chose to engage with voters online rather than campaigning in person in Florida, Illinois, and Arizona on Tuesday. Biden emerged victorious in all three states. The Washington Post noted that both candidates did not campaign in person due to the ongoing pandemic.

Title: Army Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl Faces Desertion and Misbehavior Charges Under Uniform Code of Military Justice

Article:

Army Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl, who was released last summer in a prisoner swap involving five top Taliban commanders, has been charged with desertion and misbehavior in front of the enemy under the Uniform Code of Military Justice. If convicted, he faces life in prison.

Bergdahl's legal defense team will argue in military court that Bergdahl did not desert but was attempting to reach another base to report wrongdoing within his Army unit. The Obama administration has previously defended the decision to secure Bergdahl's release, stating he served with "honor and distinction."

However, a report from the Naval Criminal Investigative Service (NCIS) indicates that Bergdahl not only deserted his unit but deliberately sought out the Taliban and other enemies of the United States. It is worth noting that many of Bergdahl's platoon members have claimed this since the beginning, but were discredited by the Obama administration as unreliable and liars for doing so.

A 2009 NCIS investigation into Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl's activities in Afghanistan revealed clear evidence that Bergdahl was intentionally defecting to the enemy, according to Lt. Col. Anthony Shaffer on Fox News' "The O'Reilly Factor" Monday night.

"He had Afghan contacts and he was actually trying to offer himself up with the Taliban," Shaffer said. "Both are very severe."

Shaffer added that the NCIS investigation, which included interviews with squad mates as well as Afghans working outside the wire, reportedly resulted in Bergdahl being charged with misbehavior toward the enemy.

Lt. Col. Shaffer also noted during the interview that President Obama would have been aware of Bergdahl's desertion through the NCIS before making the decision to negotiate his release.

A preliminary Article 32 hearing has been scheduled for Bergdahl's case and will be held at Ft. Sam Houston, Texas. The exact date of the hearing has yet to be announced.

Title: Senate Faces Pressure to Vote on Keystone XL Pipeline Amidst Tight Election Cycle

Article:

With several Democratic senators facing tight re-elections in November, Majority Leader Harry Reid is under pressure to bring the Canada-to-Texas Keystone XL pipeline to a vote in the Senate. Reid has expressed a preference for a non-binding "sense of the Senate" resolution, which would express support for the pipeline without binding legislative action. However, some Republicans and Democrats are pushing for a more substantial bill to approve the pipeline.

A bipartisan bill to approve the Keystone XL pipeline was introduced on Thursday, and Reid has yet to indicate his position on the matter, with a vote potentially imminent. In response to the pressure, Reid stated, "Originally, it was supposed to be a sense of the Senate. Now they said they want it an up or down on a piece of legislation. They can't decide what it is."

Reid's comments refer to a bipartisan energy efficiency bill in the Senate, sponsored by New Hampshire Democratic Sen. Jeanne Shaheen and Ohio Republican Sen. Rob Portman, which is set for debate and a vote next week. Some lawmakers are seeking to include the Keystone XL pipeline in this debate.

South Dakota Republican Sen. John Thune stated, "In that debate, we ought to have a binding vote on the Keystone pipeline that would force that issue to the American people."

The Obama administration has delayed making a decision on the Keystone XL pipeline multiple times, putting pressure on Reid from both the left and right flanks of the political spectrum. Among the at-risk 2014 Democrats is Louisiana Sen. Mary Landrieu, who has expressed frustration with the White House and Reid over the prolonged study of the pipeline.

Landrieu, who co-sponsored the latest bill, stated, "The Keystone Pipeline is clearly in our national interest and vital to position North America as an energy powerhouse. I will press hard for a vote in the coming weeks to build this pipeline."

White House Press Secretary Jay Carney warned lawmakers, "What we've seen in the past when Congress has passed legislation, it has actually slowed the process down. So we believe this has to be run by the book outside of politics, and that's the way it's being run."

Critics question whether the Keystone XL pipeline is truly beyond politics at this stage. The Senate has already expressed support for the pipeline, passing a nonbinding resolution to approve the project during the Senate budget process in March 2013, in a 62-37 vote. Over in the Republican-controlled House, there remains strong support for building the project.

Georgia Rep. John Barrow, a Democrat who is a vocal critic of the Obama administration on this issue, stated, "Further delays in constructing this pipeline mean that the U.S. will miss out on tens of thousands of jobs and continue to depend on foreign oil from hostile countries."

Barrow argued, "The Keystone XL Pipeline will bring in 840,000 barrels of oil per day from our friend and neighbor, Canada. That could essentially replace the 900,000 barrels we have to get every day from Venezuela - one country we can not count on."

Barrow questions who will be the first to use the oil if the pipeline is not built. "The oil will be extracted, refined, and used by someone. My question: who will be first in line to use it?"

Capitol Attitude is a weekly column written by members of the ███ Capitol Hill team. Their articles take you inside the halls of Congress, and cover the spectrum of policy issues being introduced, debated, and voted on there.

Title: Clinton Email Scandal Threatens Presidential Ambitions, According to Analysts

Article:

Hillary Clinton is facing mounting criticism over allegations that she sent top-secret information from a non-secure email account while serving as Secretary of State. The intelligence community's inspector general stated in a letter to Congress this week that some of Clinton's messages contained information classified above "top secret."

According to Fox News, the information is so sensitive that even senators, who already have clearance, must go through additional security measures to view some of the information Clinton was sending. The Clinton campaign has accused the inspector general, I. Charles McCullough, of politically motivated leaks intended to sabotage her campaign.

However, the email scandal appears to have already taken a toll on Clinton's image. Surveys show that voters view her primary challenger, Senator Bernie Sanders, as more honest and trustworthy.

Brandon Rottinghaus, a political science professor at the University of Houston who specializes in political leadership, stated, "Trustworthiness is not a problem by itself for Clinton, but combined with other past and present scandals weighing her down, alternative candidates like Sanders begin to look more appealing."

A recent Quinnipiac University Poll found that 93 percent of Democratic primary voters consider Sanders honest and trustworthy, while just 66 percent said the same of Clinton. A CNN survey conducted this month found that 55 percent of Democratic voters consider Clinton to be the "least honest" candidate in the race.

Reports surfaced this week that Clinton's private email server contained several dozen more classified emails than previously thought, including some from "special access programs," or SAP. Even top members of the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations are unable to view such messages without additional security steps, including signing new nondisclosure agreements, according to Fox News.

"These declarations cover several dozen emails containing classified information determined to be at the confidential, secret, and top secret/sap levels," Mr. McCullough said in a letter to lawmakers obtained by The Associated Press.

Clinton pushed back against the reports in an interview with NPR, maintaining that she never knowingly sent or received classified email on her private server. "As the State Department has confirmed, I never sent or received any material marked classified, and that hasn't changed in all of these months," she said.

Clinton's campaign argued that the emails appear to have been forwards of a New York Times article on a classified drone program, and say the messages seem to have been retroactively classified.

"How a New York Times public article that goes around the world could be in any way viewed as classified, or the fact that it would be sent to other people off of The New York Times site, I think, is one of the difficulties that people have in understanding what this is about," Clinton told NPR.

The State Department is under a court order to produce about 55,000 emails from Clinton's home server. Most have been released, with the last of them expected on Jan. 29—just days before the Iowa caucuses on Feb. 1.

Clinton's use of private email has been a source of controversy since it was first revealed publicly in March 2015. She began returning her emails to the State Department after the Obama administration, prodded by a House investigation into the Benghazi affair, discovered that Clinton had taken all of her messages with her when she left the State Department at the end of President Obama's first term.

The administration then said that Clinton had refused to use a regular email account on the State.gov email server and instead used a private server that she kept in her home in New York. Clinton has since said she regrets using the private server, but has steadfastly maintained that she did not use the private account to send or receive classified information.

Investigations have also found that the State Department has struggled to fulfill open records requests for Clinton's emails. As of Jan. 7, 177 requests for documents from Clinton were still pending, according to the State Department inspector general.

Specialists suggest that voters on the fence in the Democratic primary election may take the email scandal—and the larger questions about Clinton's honesty—into account when choosing a candidate.

"The problem for Hillary Clinton is that there are alternatives to her candidacy in Bernie Sanders. This is why polls of Democrats don't think Sanders can win [the general election] but are willing to vote for him anyway," Mr. Rottinghaus said.

Title: Kerry Walks Back "Apartheid" Comment Regarding Israel, Denies Using Loaded Term

Article:

In a recent report by The Daily Beast, it was reported that Secretary of State John Kerry stated that if Israel does not reach a two-state agreement with the Palestinians, it risks becoming an "apartheid state." Kerry's comments, made in a closed-door meeting with influential world leaders on Friday, have sparked controversy, particularly among Jewish leaders in America.

In a statement released by the State Department on Saturday, Kerry denied using the term "apartheid" and stated that he should have chosen different words to describe his belief in the need for a two-state solution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. Kerry also expressed his unwavering support for Israel and criticized those who question his commitment to the Jewish state.

In the same statement, Kerry clarified that he does not believe Israel is an apartheid state or intends to become one. He also stated that his use of the term "apartheid" was unintentional and that he regretted any misimpression created by his choice of words.

The use of the term "apartheid" is significant, as it is a loaded term that has rarely, if ever, been used by senior American officials in reference to Israel. President Obama has previously rejected the idea that the term should apply to Israel.

The controversy surrounding Kerry's comments comes at a time when the Israeli-Palestinian conflict remains a contentious issue. In a separate development, the 2012 Democratic National Convention refused to recognize Jerusalem as the capital of Israel, a move that has been criticized by some Jewish leaders. The Orthodox Union, an American Jewish organization, has expressed disappointment over the omission of Jerusalem from the 2012 DNC platform, stating that "facts are facts; Jerusalem is Israel's capital."

Title: Obama Pushes Executive Action on Gun Control as GOP Presidential Candidates Vow to Reverse Measures

Article:

In a shift from his earlier skepticism of aggressive executive power, President Barack Obama is now employing executive action on gun control, with new measures to be announced this week. The new actions include tightening the so-called "gun-show loophole" by requiring occasional gun dealers to obtain licenses and conduct background checks on buyers.

The administration also plans to boost enforcement of federal gun laws, including the hiring of additional FBI personnel to process background checks. Some of the new gun measures require congressional approval, but those enacted by executive order have the force of law and can be undone by the next president.

If a Republican wins the 2016 presidential election, they are likely to reverse many of Obama's executive actions, not just on gun control but also on issues like immigration and women's reproductive health. The large Republican presidential field has uniformly criticized Obama's use of executive power.

Front-runner Donald Trump has vowed to "unsign" any gun control measures Obama enacts unilaterally, while Texas Sen. Ted Cruz and New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie have criticized Obama's actions on guns. However, the reality is that the next president, regardless of party affiliation, is likely to follow Obama's lead on the use of executive authority.

If the Republicans sweep the 2016 elections, winning the White House and keeping control of both houses of Congress, the Democrats will still be able to block legislation they don't like through the filibuster. Even if a Democrat wins the presidency, Republicans are still likely to keep the House, if not the Senate, leaving Washington as gridlocked as ever.

Obama has shown a willingness to use executive action on divisive topics like immigration and gun control, even after saying he's done everything he can. The best example is immigration, where Obama has deferred deportation for young illegal immigrants and undocumented parents of US citizens and legal permanent residents. Democratic front-runner Hillary Clinton has pledged to go even further on immigration via executive action if elected.

On gun control, Obama tried a two-track approach after the Sandy Hook massacre, with executive action and legislation. The effort in Congress was less fruitful, as a bipartisan bill to expand background checks on gun buyers and ban assault weapons failed.

Obama has made clear that in his remaining time as president, keeping guns out of the "wrong hands" is a top priority. Though most of the recent, high-profile gun incidents have involved weapons that were legally obtained, Obama seems undeterred. Polls show expanded background checks have strong public support, though in the wake of San Bernardino, a majority of Americans now oppose a ban on assault weapons.

Title: "CNN Pieces Together Disturbing Past of Florida School Shooter Nikolas Cruz"

Article:

CNN has pieced together a disturbing portrait of Nikolas Cruz, the 19-year-old Broward County man who carried out the nation's most recent mass shooting at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Florida. The shooting resulted in the deaths of 17 people and left another 17 injured.

According to an acquaintance interviewed by CNN, Cruz would introduce himself as "Nick, I'm a school shooter." He also posed with guns and knives in photos posted on Instagram and made a chilling online comment about a mass shooting carried out in New York this summer.

Cruz's attorneys have referred to his chronic battle with mental illness and depression, which they attribute to the recent death of his adoptive mother, leaving him without parents. A defense attorney described him as "a broken child."

Cruz was adopted at a young age by Roger and Lynda Cruz. Roger died years ago, and Lynda died last fall, following an illness. He was taken in by the parents of a schoolmate, according to that family's attorney.

His mother's death capped troubled high school years that ended with his expulsion from Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School. A former classmate, who grew up with Cruz and attended school with him since the sixth grade, said Cruz would sometimes introduce himself as a "school shooter."

Another neighbor, concerned about Cruz "acting weird" in the backyard, took video of him dressed in boxer shorts shooting what appeared to be a BB gun. He sometimes pointed the gun toward their window, the man said.

Cruz had two Instagram accounts featuring weapons and photos. In one picture, he is wearing a kerchief over his face and a Make America Great Again hat. Another photo is taken from behind a gun sight looking out the window.

The FBI received a report of a comment made by a user with Cruz's name attached to it, in response to a story about a disgruntled doctor in New York who used an AR-15 to shoot seven people, killing one and wounding six others. However, FBI officials were unable to determine who was responsible.

Not everyone who crossed paths with Cruz saw reason for concern. The attorney for the family who took him in after his mother's death said they were aware of trouble he'd earlier had at school and saw signs of depression. But, "they did not see any danger," Jim Lewis said of the unidentified family.

According to authorities, Cruz was initially able to leave the crime scene at the school by blending in with students fleeing campus in the wake of the massacre. He went to a Walmart and a McDonald's before being found by police and taken into custody. He has since confessed to the killings, according to court documents.

Gordon Weekes, one of Cruz's public defenders, said he believed Cruz has been placed on suicide watch. He said the defense team would be exploring mental health issues and "the possibility of autism."

"We are trying to save this young man's life," Weekes said.

Title: The Rise of a Scientific Revolution in Conservative Politics: A Call for Objective Analysis

Article:

In a passionate speech at the Conservative Political Action Conference last week, Democratic pollster Pat Caddell accused Republican consultants of widespread corruption, sparking a wave of grassroots outrage. Rush Limbaugh further fueled the fire, criticizing establishment players for their ideological softness and perceived focus on approval from the D.C. elite and financial gain rather than political victory.

These accusations are part of a growing chorus of criticism directed at the performance of the Romney campaign, the Republican Party, and conservative organizations. Critics argue that the Romney campaign's polling, messaging, strategy, tactics, and targeting were all failures. They suggest that these failures, if so obvious and complete, indicate not just incompetence but malfeasance on the part of those in charge.

However, it is crucial to avoid turning this self-examination into a witch-hunt, as some might be quick to condemn the very people who would be praised had an outside event intervened to elect a President Romney. The need now is for a means of distinguishing between effective and ineffective strategies, a strength that Democrats have leveraged through their alliance with academic social scientists.

For over a decade, liberal interest groups have collaborated with social scientists to study politics using the scientific method, deploying randomized, controlled experiments to rigorously test the effectiveness of their messages and tactics. This approach has allowed Democrats to build an objective base of knowledge on what works and what doesn't. Today, the Left is characterized by a culture of testing, with expert opinions treated as hypotheses to be tested with experiments.

For instance, the Obama campaign heavily invested in grassroots field offices, a decision supported by years of randomized-controlled experiments indicating that these offices, despite their expense and difficulty, yield the highest vote return. The Obama campaign also promoted strategies such as strange video pledges to support the president or "voter report cards" informing Democrats of their voting record and how it compared with their neighbors, tactics that experiments indicated are effective at getting out the vote.

In light of these findings, it is clear that a more scientific approach to political strategy could benefit the Republican Party and conservative organizations. By embracing the core of the scientific method, they can objectively determine what works and what doesn't, and ultimately, improve their chances of political victory.

Title: Russian Cyberattacks on U.S. Government Agencies Unveiled

Article:

For years, Russian cyber activities have remained relatively low-profile compared to Chinese cyber espionage, which has been frequently exposed. However, Russian hackers have been stealthily infiltrating U.S. systems, stealing sensitive information such as the designs for the F-35 fighter jet, corporate secrets, and blueprints for gas pipelines. During the 2008 presidential election cycle, Chinese intelligence reportedly hacked into the campaigns of Barack Obama and John McCain, but did not publish the stolen data.

Kevin Mandia, a former Air Force intelligence officer and founder of cybersecurity firm Mandiant (now a division of FireEye), noted that the Russians were "a lot more stealthy." They have been quicker to use cyberattacks for political purposes, as demonstrated by the 2007 cyberattack on Estonia, a former Soviet republic that had joined NATO, and subsequent cyberattacks during Russia's war with Georgia.

Despite initial assumptions, American officials did not anticipate that the Russians would employ such tactics within the United States. Their primary focus was on preventing potential disruptions to critical infrastructure, such as the power grid or cellphone networks, as warned by former Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta about a potential "cyber Pearl Harbor."

However, in 2014 and 2015, a Russian hacking group began systematically targeting the State Department, the White House, and the Joint Chiefs of Staff. According to Michael Sulmeyer, a former cyberexpert for the secretary of defense, and Ben Buchanan, now both of the Harvard Cyber Security Project, the Russians "eventually met with some form of success" in these attacks.

The Russian hackers became increasingly stealthy, tricking government computers into sending out data while disguising the electronic "command and control" messages that set off alarms for anyone looking for malicious actions. The State Department was so severely affected that it repeatedly shut down its systems to evict the intruders. During Secretary of State John Kerry's trip to Vienna for the Iran nuclear negotiations, officials and accompanying reporters had to use commercial Gmail accounts to communicate due to the State Department's crippled systems.

President Obama was briefed on these attacks, but chose not to publicly name the Russians or impose sanctions. This decision, which is now regretted by many in the White House, was reportedly due to fears of escalating a cyberwar and the need for Russia's cooperation in Syria-related negotiations.

Title: GOP Debate Highlights: Marco Rubio, Ted Cruz, and Lindsey Graham Shine in Las Vegas

Article:

The fifth Republican presidential debate on Tuesday night in Las Vegas, Nevada, was marked by the impact of the Paris and San Bernardino attacks, with a significant focus on terrorism. The following is a summary of the standout performances from the main and undercard debates.

In the main debate, Florida Senator Marco Rubio demonstrated consistency throughout the early election season, conveying clear convictions, a common-sense-sounding policy framework, and an optimistic outlook. He displayed confidence without resorting to the braggadocio of Donald Trump, showcasing a likeability that stems from his personal story and avoiding the Senate speak that affected other candidates on stage.

Ted Cruz, a senator from Texas, was the most relentless counter-puncher, scoring points with a passionate and black-and-white approach to issues that appeals to evangelicals and the conservative wing of the party.

Donald Trump, the billionaire businessman, delivered another entertaining performance in a city known for its entertainment value. While his debating skills may be below those of other candidates, he caters to his substantial support base with his take-no-prisoners, no-apologies, and confrontational style. He also displayed his showman skills during his humorous embrace of Ted Cruz near the end of the debate.

Lindsey Graham, a South Carolina senator, was the dominant winner of the undercard debate. His communication skills, honed by years of frequent TV talk-show appearances, outshone the rest of the field in the consolation debate. Graham, a veteran with three decades of service in the Air Force and Air Force Reserves, dominated the discussion on fighting terrorism and rebuilding the U.S. military.

Chris Christie, the New Jersey governor, performed well in the debate, particularly in his role as a former federal prosecutor after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks. He scored effective points when counterpunching against Marco Rubio and Ted Cruz, who became bogged down in a debate on Senate legislative minutiae. Christie also delivered the most pointed attack on President Obama, labeling him a "feckless weakling."

Rand Paul, the Kentucky senator, delivered a more assertive performance than in previous debates but at times seemed evasive or circular in reasoning when the debate moderators tried to pin him down on his own positions or his differences with parts of the GOP debate.

Ben Carson, a retired neurosurgeon, was more confident and explicit in discussing his foreign policy positions, an area where he has struggled in the past. He retained the likeability that forms the core of his popularity.

Jeb Bush, the former Florida governor, gave a more assertive performance than in prior debates but still comes off as the middle daughter Jan from "The Brady Bunch" – always complaining about everything "Donald, Donald, Donald."

Carly Fiorina, a former Hewlett-Packard CEO, seemed flat, grumpy, and indignant on stage. Her repeated efforts to inject herself into the debate with her screed "This is what is wrong in Washington" did not prove effective.

John Kasich, the Ohio governor, came across as a dour college professor lecturing students rather than a presidential contender with an optimistic vision for America.

In summary, the fifth Republican presidential debate in Las Vegas showcased strong performances from Marco Rubio, Ted Cruz, and Lindsey Graham, with each candidate demonstrating their strengths in various areas. The undercard debate was dominated by Lindsey Graham, who showcased his communication skills and military experience. The main debate saw Marco Rubio, Ted Cruz, and Chris Christie deliver strong performances, while Donald Trump, Carly Fiorina, and John Kasich faced criticism for their performances. Rand Paul and Ben Carson were mixed, with each displaying both strengths and weaknesses.

Title: Obama to Campaign During Republican National Convention, Bucking Traditional Incumbent Behavior

Article:

In a departure from traditional incumbent behavior, President Barack Obama will embark on an ambitious campaign next week, coinciding with the Republican National Convention. While the Republicans gather in Tampa, Florida, to nominate Mitt Romney for president, Mr. Obama will campaign on college campuses in Ames, Iowa, and Fort Collins, Colorado, on Tuesday, and in Charlottesville, Virginia, on Wednesday, the third day of the Republican convention. Vice President Joe Biden will be in Tampa for campaign events on the first two days of the Republican convention, and First Lady Michelle Obama will appear on "The Late Show With David Letterman" on Wednesday.

Presidents typically do not campaign during the opposing party's convention, but this practice is not always adhered to by challengers. In 2008, both Mr. Obama and Republican John McCain campaigned during each other's nominating parties. In 2004, Democratic candidate John Kerry and running mate John Edwards campaigned during the GOP convention. In 1988, both George H.W. Bush and Michael Dukakis campaigned during the other's convention.

Obama campaign spokeswoman Jen Psaki stated that Mr. Obama, the first lady, and Mr. Biden will be "laying out the choice the American people are facing in November, cutting through some of the political chatter" while Republicans are meeting. Stephen Hess, a scholar on the presidency at the Brookings Institution, downplayed the suggestion that the 24/7 news media cycle is responsible for breaking the unwritten rule about not campaigning during an opponent's convention.

As Mr. Obama tries to re-energize young voters next week on three college campuses, a poll shows what the president is facing. The survey by the nonprofit group Generation Opportunity found that 89 percent of voters younger than 30 say the economy is affecting their daily lives negatively. The poll also found that 64 percent of young voters think the availability of more quality, full-time jobs upon graduation is more important than lower student-loan interest rates, an issue on which Mr. Obama waged a high-profile battle with Congress this summer.

The survey also indicates that young voters are motivated to vote this year, with 76 percent saying they intend to go to the polls in November. However, it might not be good news for Mr. Obama, who is seeking to recapture the youth vote that helped him win four years ago. The unemployment rate for 18- to 29-year-olds overall in July was 12.7 percent; it was 22.3 percent for blacks in the same age range. If the 1.7 million young adults who have given up looking for jobs are included, the actual unemployment rate for voters younger than 30 is 16.7 percent. The poll did not ask voters for their preference in the presidential election.

Title: FDA's Oversight of Opioid Prescription Training Program Questioned in New Study

Article:

More than a third of opioid-related deaths in the United States can be traced back to long-acting drugs like OxyContin, which are approved for prescription by the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA). However, a new study published in JAMA Internal Medicine has criticized the FDA for lax oversight of a federal program designed to educate doctors about the risks of prescribing addictive opioids.

Researchers from Johns Hopkins University examined thousands of pages of internal FDA documents obtained through public records requests and found that the agency has failed to adequately track the effectiveness of its Risk Evaluation and Mitigation Strategy (REMS) Program, a training program for doctors prescribing long-acting opioids. The program, introduced in 2012, requires opioid manufacturers to pay for this training and to monitor its impact on overdoses and deaths.

According to the Johns Hopkins researchers, the FDA has not been able to demonstrate that its training program has been effective. Opioid manufacturers did not collect the necessary data to track the training's progress, and even after the FDA became aware of this issue, the agency did not take corrective action, the study found.

Caleb Alexander, an author on the study, told the New York Times, "What's surprising here is the design of the program was deficient from the start." As early as 2013, the inspector general of the Department of Health and Human Services warned that the FDA was "not receiving crucial information from pharmaceutical manufacturers" about the training.

The data collected by the FDA is not encouraging. The goal was for 60 percent of doctors who prescribe long-acting opioids to enroll in a training class, but only 27 percent of them did between 2012 and 2016, according to the Johns Hopkins study. Manufacturers also surveyed physicians who participated in the training, and concluded they had "modestly greater" knowledge of safe prescribing practices. However, these surveys were conducted during a period when opioid prescribing rates were decreasing overall in the United States, and they were not designed to prove the classes were responsible for the change.

In response to the study, an FDA spokesperson told ███ that the issue of opioid misuse is a top priority for the Trump administration. The spokesperson noted that assessing the impact of the training program while accounting for other opioid interventions at the municipal, state, and federal levels could be challenging. He added that after learning about difficulties with the data assessment, the agency has discussed with drug manufacturers how to better study the effect of the training on prescriber behavior and patient outcomes, and continues to work with these companies to evaluate the impact of the program.

The spokesperson also highlighted that the FDA has taken other steps to address the opioid epidemic, such as going after illegal imports and sales of opioids and supporting more treatment for people struggling with addiction.

After reaching a peak in 2012, opioid prescription rates fell in 2017—to 58.7 prescriptions per 100 people nationally, compared with 81.3 prescriptions per 100 people in 2012. However, rates are still high in certain parts of the country, and while deaths are now starting to drop, nearly 50,000 people around the country died from opioid overdoses in 2017, a record high.

Title: Obama Addresses HealthCare.gov Fiasco and ACA Implementation Challenges

Article:

In his press conference on Thursday, President Barack Obama addressed the ongoing issues with the implementation of the Affordable Care Act (ACA) and the rollout of HealthCare.gov, the website serving as the portal to the ACA's new insurance market. The website's launch on October 1 was marred by technical difficulties, and the prospects for smooth functioning by November 30, as promised by top officials, are not looking promising.

The ACA, often referred to as Obamacare, is a signature initiative of President Obama's presidency. The president acknowledged the frustrations he has experienced over the past few weeks, particularly the promise he made repeatedly that individuals could keep their existing health insurance plans under the ACA. However, more than 3 million Americans have received cancellation notices due to the ACA's requirements.

During the press conference, Obama admitted that the assumption was that the majority of those with individual market plans would find better policies at lower costs or the same cost in the marketplaces. However, the "grandfather clause" – the provision of the law that allowed plans in place before the ACA passed to continue – did not work as intended.

"And again, that's on us, that's on me," Obama said, acknowledging the responsibility for the issue. "And that's why we're – that's on me."

The president also addressed the embarrassment surrounding HealthCare.gov's ignominious debut, leading to questions about what he knew beforehand and when. When asked, Obama stated that he "was not informed directly" that the site would not be working as intended.

Obama also criticized the federal procurement system for technology, citing it as a significant factor in the ACA's implementation challenges. He suggested that the system is cumbersome, complicated, and outdated, making it difficult to implement new technology projects within the federal government.

Looking ahead, President Obama indicated that he would engage in "Monday morning quarterbacking" regarding HealthCare.gov, suggesting that he should have seen the problems coming. However, he emphasized the need to move forward and address the ongoing issues with the ACA's implementation.

Title: Texas Governor Rick Perry's Job Recruitment Campaigns Spark Controversy

Article:

Texas Governor Rick Perry's aggressive job recruitment campaigns, characterized by radio and magazine ads, personal appearances, and critical remarks about other states' business climates, have sparked controversy and backlash, particularly from prominent Democrats and some Republican business leaders.

Perry's campaigns, which promise low-tax and pro-growth policies in Texas, have been criticized for their attacks on states like California and Illinois, with statements such as "I hear building a business in California is next to impossible" and "an environment that, intentionally or not, is designed for you to fail."

These attacks have led to a political backlash, with Democrats mocking Perry's attempts to steal jobs as clownish and warning him to keep his hands off. California Governor Jerry Brown famously compared Perry's incursions into California to breaking wind.

However, some observers argue that Perry's campaigns are a clever marketing strategy and smart politics. Mark McKinnon, a political strategist with deep Texas ties, told ███, "At the end of the day, no matter how any of the [states] respond, people are left with two distinct messages: That guy down in Texas has got big brass balls and he's creating a lot of jobs."

McKinnon also noted that Perry's campaigns break the rules of interstate diplomacy and protocol. Perry has stepped up jobs raids into the blue states of Illinois and California this year, efforts that come as he looks to announce his next political step after the Texas legislative session concludes.

Perry's bids to encourage companies to relocate, which critics call "poaching," are the most aggressive in the nation, according to experts. Mark Muro, a senior fellow and director of policy for the Metropolitan Policy Program at the Brookings Institution, stated, "It's irresistible to a lot of governors, but Perry has been the leader. This is not necessarily the best way for state executives to spend time, but it's hard to resist. It's politically attractive, the chief executive is seen as, quote, 'trying to do something.' Any successful relocation offers the tried-and-true moment of the ribbon cutting, so it's pretty intoxicating stuff."

President Barack Obama's home state of Illinois has been in the sights of several Republican governors, including Chris Christie of New Jersey, Scott Walker of Wisconsin, and Rick Scott of Florida. They all have tried to lure Illinois companies to move and set up shop in what the GOP chief executives bill as their lower-tax, lower-regulation states. However, even Scott acknowledged, in a letter to members of the Illinois business community, that Texas is leading the way. He noted that the Sunshine State is "nipping at the heels of Texas everyday, as we approach the No. 1 spot."

Some of those who have been on the receiving end say that Perry raises eyebrows as much for his grating style as for the substance of his pitch. Doug Whitley, the president and CEO of the Illinois Chamber of Commerce, told ███, "The biggest difference with Perry was, he was kind of like a Roman emperor coming into town with horns blowing in front of his arrival, his parade."

Title: Dzhokhar Tsarnaev's Condition Improves: Upgraded from Serious to Fair

Article:

Hospital officials at Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center have upgraded the condition of Boston bombing suspect Dzhokhar Tsarnaev from serious to fair. Tsarnaev, 19, was captured Thursday night in a backyard in the Boston suburb of Watertown, Massachusetts, and has been held at the medical center under heavy guard since then.

The U.S. attorney's Office for Massachusetts announced the change in Tsarnaev's condition via a tweet at noon Tuesday EDT. "According to Beth Israel Deaconess, at noon today, Dzhokhar Tsarvaev's condition is listed as ‘fair,’" the tweet read.

Tsarnaev, along with his deceased brother, Tamerlan Tsarnaev, 26, are suspected of committing the Boston Marathon bombings that resulted in three deaths and over 170 injuries. Hours after the FBI released photos of the then-unidentified suspects, the Tsarnaev brothers allegedly committed a carjacking and murdered an MIT police officer before engaging in a firefight with authorities early Friday morning, which left Tamerlan Tsarnaev dead.

Dzhokhar Tsarnaev was arraigned on two terrorism-related charges on Monday. During a court hearing conducted at his bedside at Beth Israel, the 19-year-old suspect nodded his head in response to questions and answered "no" when asked if he had enough money to hire an attorney, according to a transcript of the proceedings. The criminal complaint charging Dzhokhar Tsarnaev with the bombings indicated the 19-year-old suffered wounds to his "head, neck, leg, and hand."

Tsarnaev's next court hearing has been scheduled for May 30. The news of Dzhokhar Tsarnaev's improving medical condition came as new details emerged concerning the brothers' plans had they not been captured or killed by authorities. The suspected bombers were reportedly thinking of going to New York City, according to a carjacking victim who spoke to authorities, as reported by CBS News.

Title: US Employment Dips in September Due to Hurricane Impact, Unemployment Rate Remains Low

Article:

The United States experienced a decline in employment in September for the first time since 2010, as the impact of hurricanes Harvey and Irma on the jobs market became apparent. The Labor Department reported a loss of 33,000 jobs, with a record drop in employment in the leisure and hospitality sector. The department attributed the decline to the two storms, which struck Texas and Florida in late August and early September.

Economists had anticipated a rise of 90,000 jobs last month, but the hurricanes did not affect the unemployment rate, which slipped to 4.2%, the lowest since February 2001. The US Labor Department uses separate surveys to capture payrolls data and the unemployment rate.

The strongest job gains last month came in the health care and transportation and warehousing industries. However, employment in the leisure and hospitality sector shrank significantly, while job figures in many other industries, including construction and government, were largely unchanged.

The US has been experiencing one of the longest stretches of job creation in its history, with the economy adding a monthly average of over 170,000 jobs over the past year. Economists have predicted that this pace is unsustainable and anticipated it would slow.

The September report showed that average hourly earnings rose 0.5% from August and have now risen 2.9% over the past 12 months. Naeem Aslam, a ThinkMarkets analyst, said the earnings figure showed "that job market slack is fading."

Despite the weaker-than-expected wage gains, economists do not see anything in the September report to dissuade the Federal Reserve from raising interest rates before the end of the year, as expected. Ian Shepherdson of Pantheon Macroeconomics said, "Unemployment is what matters, and this report therefore makes a December rate hike even more likely."

Revised jobs estimates for July and August showed US employers added 38,000 fewer jobs than previously reported. However, Mr. Shepherson expects recovery to begin in October, with a bigger rebound in November.

Title: Trump Urges House Republicans to Rally Behind Obamacare Repeal and Replace Legislation

Article:

President Donald Trump will personally urge House Republicans to support legislation aimed at repealing and replacing the Affordable Care Act (Obamacare) on Tuesday. The push comes as GOP leaders prepare for a three-day effort that could determine the fate of the White House's agenda.

The president, known for his negotiating skills, will visit the Capitol to lobby conservatives who argue the plan does not go far enough, and centrists who have demanded more assistance for older Americans whose premiums would increase under the GOP plan.

House Republicans, late Monday, announced they would set aside at least $75 billion to help individuals purchasing insurance who are not yet eligible for Medicare. The amended bill does not significantly increase tax credits for Americans aged 50 to 64, but it allows for the Senate to do so. The bill formalizes agreed-upon changes to Medicaid designed to appease a conservative bloc.

"This is our long-awaited chance to finally get rid of Obamacare," Mr. Trump said at a rally in Kentucky, home to vocal GOP opponents of the bill, Representative Thomas Massie and Senator Rand Paul. Mr. Trump stated he is willing to collaborate with Mr. Paul to make necessary changes to the health bill and then move on to tax reform.

The House Freedom Caucus, a group of more than 30 Republicans who often clash with leadership, remains the most visible impediment to the bill in the lower chamber. Its chairman, Representative Mark Meadows of North Carolina, said the group did not plan to take an official position on the bill late Monday, leaving the door open for negotiations with Mr. Trump and GOP leadership.

Republicans cannot afford to lose more than 21 GOP votes, as every Democrat is expected to reject the bill, which repeals most of Obamacare's taxes and its individual mandate, replaces the ACA's generous subsidies with refundable, age-based tax credits, and reins in and caps spending on Medicaid by 2020.

A "manager's amendment" submitted late Monday would repeal many of Obamacare's taxes sooner, this year instead of 2018, while barring any more states from expanding their Medicaid populations and receiving generous federal matching funds outlined by the 2010 law. The implementation of the so-called "Cadillac tax" on particularly generous employer plans is moved back from 2025 to 2026.

Democrats have invited former Vice President Joseph R. Biden to the Capitol on Wednesday to rally in defense of Obamacare, stating the GOP bill would undo its extension of coverage to more than 20 million Americans.

The House Rules Committee will meet early Wednesday to vet final changes to the GOP replacement and set the terms of debate for floor votes on Thursday, the seventh anniversary of Obamacare's passage. Republicans in the Senate are already considering their own changes, so the House may need to revisit the plan in the future.

As written, the Congressional Budget Office estimated the plan would save over $300 billion but result in 24 million fewer people being insured a decade from now. Criticism of the plan continued to pour in Monday, as doctors' groups and America's Catholic bishops said there were laudable parts of the legislation but that it fell woefully short in maintaining coverage for needy Americans.

Republican leaders have pleaded with conservatives and outside lobbies for more time.
