They argue the bill, which leverages budget rules to avoid a Democratic filibuster later on, is merely the first part of a three-pronged strategy to lower health costs. Phase two involves regulatory action by the Trump administration, while phase three would require Democratic support for future GOP legislation.

Mr. Trump won over members of the Republican Study Committee by agreeing to amendments that would make changes to Medicaid on Friday. The changes would allow states to impose work requirements on able-bodied people in the program and let governors accept a block grant of federal funding for the program instead of a per-capita allotment.

Title: College Students and Community Members Rally to Fill Democratic National Convention Stadium

Article:

College students from various institutions across North Carolina and members of predominantly black churches in neighboring South Carolina are set to arrive in Charlotte in large numbers ahead of the Democratic National Convention. Their objective is to help fill the 74,000-seat Bank of America Stadium to capacity when President Barack Obama delivers his acceptance speech for the Democratic nomination on Thursday night.

The Democratic Party has expressed concern over the possibility of not filling the stadium, as polls indicate decreased voter enthusiasm for Obama and smaller crowds at his battleground state campaign rallies. However, Obama advisers maintain that the stadium will be filled for the speech, with Vice President Joe Biden and Massachusetts Sen. John Kerry also set to speak on Thursday.

Adam Fetcher, a campaign spokesman, stated, "The response we've seen from the community has been incredible, and it's obvious that people have a big interest in owning a piece of the most open and accessible convention in history." He added, "President Obama's speech on Thursday night will bring this election into focus for the American people, and it will be even more significant because so many North Carolinians will be there to see it."

In addition to convention delegates, volunteers, and other Democratic officials already in Charlotte for the party gathering, filling the remaining seats is a piecemeal process. College Democrats of North Carolina President Elena Botella stated that her school is busing 100 students to the speech, while Lonnie Randolph, the president of the South Carolina chapter of the NAACP, said several large black churches in his state are planning to send busloads of members to watch the president's speech.

Obama aides have distributed several thousand tickets to new campaign volunteers in North Carolina, with individuals who complete three volunteer shifts totaling nine hours receiving one ticket to the final speech. This volunteer ticketing program also serves to bolster Obama's grassroots network in North Carolina, a battleground state he won in 2008 for the first time in nearly 40 years. However, Obama is facing an uphill battle in North Carolina this time around, as the unemployment rate exceeds the national average and voters approved a gay marriage ban the day before the president announced his support for same-sex unions.

Comparisons to the 2008 Democratic National Convention, where Obama accepted the nomination before a capacity crowd at an 84,000-seat stadium in Denver, are likely. At that time, there was little concern over filling the stadium due to Obama's ability to attract tens of thousands of people to his campaign rallies across the country. This year, Obama's crowds are significantly smaller, with his largest audience being a 14,000-person crowd at his campaign kick-off rally in May at Ohio State University. Approximately 13,000 people attended Obama's rally at the University of Colorado in Boulder on Sunday.

The campaign states that the size of Obama's events this summer have been intentionally kept low due to the increased costs and security requirements for a sitting president compared to a candidate. Convention organizers in Charlotte may have more control over the crowds than their other major concern: the weather. Heavy evening rains drenched Charlotte over the weekend, and thunderstorms are forecast for Thursday. Officials have stated that the outdoor event will proceed rain or shine, except in the case of severe weather.

Title: New Jersey Governor Chris Christie's Visit with President Obama Sparks Political Speculation

Article:

New Jersey Governor Chris Christie's visit with President Barack Obama has sparked political speculation, with pundits and campaign aides questioning the governor's motives. The visit, intended to assess the damage caused by Hurricane Sandy, has been portrayed as a potential move to secure the ear of the federal government for New Jersey or as a political maneuver for Christie's potential 2016 presidential bid.

As President Obama praised Christie's leadership, Romney aides downplayed the partnership, with Kevin Madden, a Romney adviser, stating, "He's a governor focused on his job. He has said he's not looking at this through the lens of politics. He's right, and I expect most folks are looking at it just like the governor is."

White House Press Secretary Jay Carney also emphasized that the visit should not be seen as a political event, stating, "This is a time to focus on what was a devastating storm and the terrible aftermath of that storm."

However, Christie has not completely set aside politics, as he has criticized Democrats in the State Legislature and picked fights with the Democratic mayor of Atlantic City.

Before the visit, Christie mentioned several times that he and the president had spoken "just the two of us," and that the president had insisted that if he had any problems, he was to call him directly. Mike DuHaime, an adviser to Christie, stated that the governor was acting true to form, saying, "He calls 'em as he sees 'em. If they're working well together, he's going to say it."

Christie has not announced whether he will run for a second term, but if he does, Election Day is a mere year and five days away. His approval ratings are high in New Jersey, but President Obama's are higher.

Republicans have previously criticized Christie for putting his own interests first, such as during his keynote speech at the Republican National Convention, where it took him 15 minutes to mention Mitt Romney's name. However, one Republican close to Romney stated that Christie would have been accused of playing politics if he had declined the president's post-storm visit, as New York Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg had.

Despite the political speculation, at least one resident of Point Pleasant Beach seemed to be staying on message, with someone etching "ROMNEY" in the sand.

Title: 2020 Democratic Presidential Hopefuls to Address SXSW Festival in Austin, Texas

Article:

Several Democratic presidential candidates are set to speak at the South by Southwest (SXSW) festival in Austin, Texas this weekend. The event, known for its focus on technology, film, and music, serves as an opportunity for the candidates to engage with young voters and distinguish themselves in a growing primary field.

Senators Elizabeth Warren (D-Mass.) and Amy Klobuchar (D-Minn.) will speak on Saturday, while former San Antonio Mayor Julian Castro, Colorado Governor John Hickenlooper, and Washington Governor Jay Inslee will speak on Sunday.

Former Texas Representative Beto O'Rourke, who ran for the Senate last year but has not yet announced his 2020 intentions, is expected to attend a film premiere about his longshot Senate bid against Senator Ted Cruz. Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez (D-N.Y.), who is not a presidential contender but is a rising star within the party, is scheduled to be interviewed onstage on Saturday night, according to The Guardian.

Texas is an early primary state for Democrats, but it is a red state in the presidential election as a whole. However, O'Rourke's close race with Cruz suggests that the state could be gradually shifting towards becoming a purple state.

The candidates' presence at the festival also serves as a platform to promote their policies on universal healthcare and addressing the deficit, while aiming to project a cool image and network with potentially enthusiastic young voters who can provide support, volunteering, and social media promotion for their campaigns.

Democratic National Committee Chair Tom Perez told CBS News that events like SXSW offer real opportunities for the party ahead of the 2020 campaign. "It's become an iconic national event, and I wanted to make sure people understood what we're doing at the Democratic Party to win," Perez said. He also cited the 2018 Texas Senate race as evidence that Texas could eventually be up for grabs for Democrats: "Texas is very much in play for Democrats. We made tremendous progress."

Title: Supreme Court Ruling Revives American Indian-U.S. Treaty, Guarantees Hunting Rights on Federal Lands

Article:

The Supreme Court, in a 5-4 ruling on Monday, upheld a treaty signed in 1868 between the U.S. government and the Crow Tribe, overturning a century-old high court precedent and potentially guaranteeing American Indians hunting rights on some federal lands. The case, brought by Crow Tribe member Clayvin Herrera, challenged Wyoming's offseason hunting charges in 2014 for hunting bull elk on the Big Horn National Forest.

Mr. Herrera argued that the treaty, which guarantees American Indians "the right to hunt on unoccupied lands of the United States so long as game may be found thereon," allowed him to hunt on the land. The Crow Tribe leaders signed the treaty, ceding roughly 30 million acres to settlers while retaining about 8 million acres.

Wyoming argued that the treaty expired when it gained statehood in 1890. However, the justices, in their 22-page opinion, sided with Mr. Herrera, stating that there is no evidence that Congress intended to abrogate the 1868 treaty with the Wyoming Statehood Act.

Justice Sonia Sotomayor wrote in the court's opinion that there is no evidence that Congress intended to abrogate the 1868 treaty right through the Wyoming Statehood Act, or that the Crow Tribe would have understood it to do so. The court's decision gives "life" to the rights of American Indians by overruling the prior precedent.

Advocates for Mr. Herrera stated that the decision gives "life" to the rights of American Indians by overruling the prior precedent. Forrest Tahdooahnippah, a lawyer who specializes in tribal issues, said the decision gives "life" to the rights of American Indians by overruling the prior precedent.

One major issue for the justices was the language of the treaty, which said it applied to "unoccupied lands." Wyoming argued that once it became a state, all of the lands were deemed occupied. The court rejected both arguments, though it did leave room for some regulations within the forest, including where Wyoming decides it has an interest in conservation.

The four dissenting justices argued that the majority was ignoring a clear precedent, citing a similar case in 1895 involving the same treaty language and the Shoshone-Bannock Tribes. That time, the justices ruled that the tribes' right to hunt was terminated when Wyoming gained statehood. The court then said if the tribe's rights didn't end, the state would lack the power to regulate the killing of game.

Justice Samuel A. Alito called Monday's majority opinion "wasted ink."

Title: New NAFTA Successor Requires Higher Content Localization for Automakers, Awaits Congressional Ratification

Article:

The new rules for automakers in the successor to the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA) will require a higher percentage of a vehicle's content to be produced in North America to qualify for zero tariffs. The new requirement is set at 75 percent, an increase from the current 62.5 percent. However, the deal is still pending congressional ratification.

According to Kristin Dziczek, vice president for industry, labor, and economics at the Center for Automotive Research in Ann Arbor, Mich, the changes may not significantly encourage investment in the United States as most vehicles will likely meet the new thresholds easily. Even if the administration imposes higher tariffs on foreign car imports, investment may still be hesitant due to the unpredictability of President Trump's trade policies.

Employment in the auto industry has slightly increased under President Trump's administration, from about 955,800 in January 2017 to one million in November 2018. However, the number of vehicles manufactured in the United States has continued to decline, despite a slight uptick last summer. According to the Reshoring Initiative, announcements to increase investment or move companies back to the United States peaked in 2016.

President Trump has renegotiated NAFTA and a bilateral trade deal with South Korea. The changes to the South Korea agreement were modest, but the revised NAFTA strengthens intellectual property rights in Canada. An investigation into China's trade practices concluded that Beijing had violated American intellectual property rights, leading to the imposition of tariffs on $250 billion worth of Chinese products. The two sides are currently in talks over a trade deal to resolve the dispute.

In a separate development, President Trump signed the "Right to Try" legislation into law in May, allowing terminally ill patients to seek access to experimental medicine that is not approved by the Food and Drug Administration. A similar program known as compassionate use or expanded access has been in place since the 1970s, and the F.D.A. says it authorizes 99 percent of the requests it receives. The new law allows patients, with the approval of their doctor, to ask drug companies directly for access, rather than wait for approval by the agency.

Title: Senate Overcomes Filibuster on National Defense Authorization Act, Setting Stage for Potential Presidential Veto

Article:

The United States Senate overcame a filibuster on the annual defense policy bill on Tuesday, marking a significant victory for Republicans and setting up a potential confrontation with President Barack Obama over a threatened veto on the bill. The National Defense Authorization Act, if passed, would authorize military spending, set policy for Guantanamo Bay detainees, and address specific issues that have arisen since the previous bill.

The bill, which is one of the few must-pass measures each year, would be the fifth veto of President Obama's tenure, according to Republicans. They argue that an Obama veto would be equivalent to a surrender given the popularity of the bill and the dangerous threats the military is facing overseas. A final vote is expected on Wednesday, and the bill will then be sent to the president's desk.

Sen. John McCain (R-AZ), chairman of the Armed Services Committee, expressed his disbelief at the prospect of a presidential veto, stating, "I can not imagine a president of the United States vetoing a bill that authorizes the ability of Americans to defend this nation under these most challenging circumstances."

If President Obama follows through on his threat, it would provide the best opportunity yet for Congress to override him, requiring a two-thirds vote in each chamber. The Senate, which voted 73-26 on Tuesday to head off a filibuster, appears to have more than enough support. From the Democratic caucus, 21 members sided with Republicans.

The House fell short of two-thirds support last week, with the bill receiving a vote of 270-156. Ten Republicans joined 146 Democrats in opposition, and many of them may face intense pressure to support an override.

The National Defense Authorization Act sets spending levels and rewrites rules for the Pentagon for the fiscal year. This year's version includes a Defense Department prod to determine whether those working at military recruitment centers can be armed, a response to the Navy recruitment center shooting in Chattanooga, Tennessee, in July. It also protects popular weapons programs such as the A-10 aircraft and calls for new strike fighters for the Navy and Marine Corps, presses ahead with development of a long-range bomber for the Air Force, and restores authority for a next-generation missile defense program.

However, the bill has become entangled in a broader fight over government spending for fiscal year 2016. Republicans want more money for the Defense Department and have proposed classifying some of it as emergency war spending, helping to circumvent the 2011 debt law's automatic "sequester" cuts. Democrats insist that if the Defense Department gets an increase, an equal amount must go toward domestic spending. Such a move would require breaking the sequester caps outright.

Democrats have filibustered the annual defense spending bill but are divided over whether to filibuster the policy bill. The White House has stated that the policy bill and the spending bill are closely linked, and press secretary Josh Earnest said on Monday that the president would veto the bill "quite simply because it includes an irresponsible way for funding our core national defense priorities."

Even if the spending fight is resolved, the White House is troubled by the bill's restrictions on transferring detainees from the Guantanamo Bay facility in Cuba to the U.S., as President Obama has promised to shutter the prison. The latest version of the defense policy bill bans transfers to Libya, Somalia, Syria, and Yemen, and imposes stricter certifications from the Defense Department's secretary before transfers are made to other countries.

The outcome of the veto threat and the spending fight remains uncertain, but negotiations between the White House, Republican defense hawks, and Democratic leaders on Capitol Hill are ongoing. The Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-KY) and House Speaker John A. Boehner (R-OH) have revealed that they are in the middle of negotiations, but the talks need to move faster to avoid a series of deadlines over the debt limit and a potential government shutdown.

Title: President Trump and Vice President Pence Honor 9/11 Anniversary, Offer Tributes at Pentagon and Shanksville

Article:

On Monday, President Donald Trump and Vice President Mike Pence commemorated the 16th anniversary of the September 11, 2001, terrorist attacks. The president honored victims, first responders, and the military in remarks at the Pentagon, while Vice President Pence paid tribute to the passengers of United Airlines Flight 93 in Shanksville, Pennsylvania.

In his remarks at the Pentagon, President Trump stated, "The terrorists who attacked us thought they could incite fear and weaken our spirit. But America cannot be intimidated, and those who try will soon join the long list of vanquished enemies who dared to test our mettle."

The president, who recently announced his administration's strategy for the long-running conflict in Afghanistan, which began in 2001 as a hunt for the organizers of the September 11 attacks, warned that "we are making plain to these savage killers that there is no dark corner beyond our reach. No sanctuary beyond our grasp, and nowhere to hide anywhere on this very large Earth."

Trump offered consoling words to the families of victims who gathered for Monday's ceremony and shared the story of a Pentagon police officer who rushed into the wreckage of the Pentagon and saved "as many as 20 people" over his nearly 36 hours working at the site. The attacks against the U.S., the president said, made the nation more resilient and continue to do so.

At the Pentagon, the president was preceded in his remarks by Gen. Joseph Dunford, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, and Defense Secretary James Mattis. Gen. Dunford declared, "Americans are not made of cotton candy, we're not seaweed drifting in the current, we are not intimidated by our enemies, and, Mr. President, your military does not scare."

Vice President Pence, in his tribute to the passengers of United Airlines Flight 93, said, "I and many others in our nation's capital were able to go home that day to hug our families because of the courage and selflessness of the heroes of Flight 93."

Earlier Monday, the president and first lady Melania Trump observed a moment of silence on the South Lawn of the White House. The president and first lady stood with their hands over their hearts as a bell tolled at 8:46 a.m. and a Marine bugler played "Taps." The president and first lady were joined by his daughter Ivanka Trump and her husband, Jared Kushner, both of whom serve as advisers to the president. Other administration staff members present included Chief of Staff John Kelly, Press Secretary Sarah Huckabee Sanders, Counselor to the President Kellyanne Conway, National Security Advisor H.R. McMaster, Economic Advisor Gary Cohn, White House Counsel Don McGahn, Deputy National Security Advisor Dina Powell, and Communications Director Hope Hicks.

Trump offered no remarks during the brief White House event.

Title: Sondland Testimony: Ambassador Confirms Conversation with Trump, but Clarifies No Direct Quid Pro Quo

Article:

In a significant development in the ongoing impeachment inquiry, Ambassador to the European Union Gordon Sondland testified before the House Intelligence Committee on Wednesday. President Trump claimed that Sondland's testimony should exonerate him of any wrongdoing in the impeachment proceedings.

Speaking to reporters before departing for Texas, Trump stated that Sondland's testimony signified "it's all over" for the impeachment proceedings and that the House inquiry into Trump should cease. However, Sondland's testimony provided a more nuanced account of the events.

During his testimony, Sondland confirmed a conversation with Trump where he asked the president what he wanted from Ukraine. Sondland stated, "He was not in a good mood. And he just said, 'I want nothing. I want nothing. I want no quid pro quo. Tell Zelensky to do the right thing.'"

While Trump argued that Sondland's statement proves there was no quid pro quo between his administration and Ukraine, the central issue in the impeachment probe, Sondland clarified that he never heard directly from Trump about a quid pro quo linking military aid for Ukraine to politically advantageous investigations.

However, Sondland did confirm that a meeting at the White House for Ukraine's president and a phone call with Trump would only happen if President Volodymyr Zelensky agreed to an investigation into the 2016 U.S. election and the Bidens. He also stated that he presumed aid was linked to investigations.

Sondland testified that he sent an email on July 19, just days before the July 25 call at the center of the impeachment inquiry, where he laid out the issue in detail to members of the State and Energy departments and White House staff.

Later in his testimony, Sondland admitted to working with Trump's lawyer, Rudy Giuliani, on Ukraine at Trump's "express direction" and pushing a "quid pro quo" with Kiev because it was what Trump wanted.

House Intelligence Committee Chairman Adam Schiff, D-Calif., described Sondland's testimony as "a very important moment in the history of this investigation" and stated that it showed "for the first time that knowledge of this scheme was pervasive."

Title: Fourth Explosion Rocks Austin, Texas: Police Investigate Possible Link to Previous Package Bombings

Article:

Another explosion in Austin, Texas, has left two people injured, and authorities are investigating whether it is connected to a series of package bombings that have gripped the city in fear. The latest blast occurred around 8:30 p.m. on Sunday in a suburban neighborhood known as Travis Country.

Austin Police Chief Brian Manley told ABC's "Good Morning America" on Monday that the explosion may have been detonated by a trip wire, and if this is the case, it would demonstrate a higher level of skill than previously suspected. Manley stated that the blast was "activated by someone either handling, kicking, or coming into contact with a trip wire that activated the device" as they walked or rode their bikes through the area.

Manley said that the police are "working under the belief" that the explosion is related to the three previous ones, but investigators have yet to process the entire scene. He added that they are "working under the belief that they are connected."

The first explosion occurred on March 2, resulting in the death of 39-year-old Anthony Stephen House. Two more package bombs exploded on March 12, killing 17-year-old Draylen Mason, wounding his mother, and injuring a 75-year-old woman. All three of these explosions were likely related and involved packages that had not been mailed or delivered by a private carrier but were left overnight on doorsteps.

The two men injured in Sunday's blast are in their 20s, with one sustaining non-life-threatening injuries, including nails in his leg. South Austin Medical Center officials reported that the men were in good condition.

Authorities have urged people within a half-mile radius to stay in their homes, and the scene needs to be processed and cleared of any hazards. Police will provide an update at 10 a.m.

A witness described the explosion as a "loud bang," and the neighborhood where it occurred is typically quiet, with a mix of families and professional residents. Thad Holt, a resident who lives near the site of the fourth explosion, said the neighborhood is "very quiet" and "crime-free."

Sunday's explosion marks the fourth to rock Austin in less than three weeks, but the three previous blasts occurred on the east side of the city. The reward for information leading to an arrest in the deadly explosions has risen by $50,000 to a new total of $115,000. More than 500 officers, including federal agents, have conducted 236 interviews and followed up on 435 leads.

Title: Indicted Roger Stone Mocks Special Counsel Robert Mueller, Denies Involvement in Russian Election Meddling

Article:

WASHINGTON – Roger Stone, a longtime political consultant and advisor to President Donald Trump, was indicted on Friday on charges of lying about his role in Russian meddling during the 2016 election. On Saturday, Stone used his Instagram account to mock special counsel Robert Mueller, referring to the charges against him as a "nothingburger."

Stone posted an image of Mueller dressed as a waiter holding an empty burger bun, captioned with the phrase "Here’s what Mueller has on me # nothingburger." Stone's social media posts are known for their candid and sometimes bizarre nature. After his arrest on Friday, Stone posted a photo of himself with the words "Who framed Roger Stone," a reference to the 1988 movie "Who Framed Roger Rabbit."

The indictment, which was unsealed on Friday, lays out investigators' understanding of efforts by the Trump campaign to learn about the website WikiLeaks' plans to release damaging information about Democratic opponent Hillary Clinton. Prosecutors claim that this information was stolen by Russian intelligence seeking to influence the election on Trump's behalf.

The allegations revolve around Stone's alleged contacts with WikiLeaks and the Trump campaign. He is accused of lying about his contacts with WikiLeaks, including dealings with the website's founder, Julian Assange, as well as interactions with members of the Trump campaign about stolen emails.

According to the indictment, during the summer of 2016, Stone spoke to senior Trump Campaign officials about information WikiLeaks might have had that would be damaging to the Clinton Campaign. Stone was also contacted by senior Trump Campaign officials to inquire about future releases by WikiLeaks.

Stone has repeatedly stated his innocence and has accused Mueller of conducting a vendetta against him and the president. After his release on bail, Stone spoke outside a federal courthouse in Florida and made appearances on CNN and Fox News to denounce the charges and boast that he would never testify against the president.

Title: Carly Fiorina Addresses Campaign Strategy and Poll Numbers in South Carolina

Article:

In a bid to clarify her campaign's strategy and address concerns about her declining poll numbers, Carly Fiorina, a Republican presidential candidate, spoke to reporters following an address to a senior community in Bluffton, South Carolina.

When asked about Jeb Bush's campaign scaling back, Fiorina emphasized her campaign's careful management of funds, stating, "We are spending our money very carefully, because we have to go the long haul."

The decision to forego advertising spending has been questioned, given Fiorina's momentum following the first Republican debate. When asked about future advertising plans, she responded, "Well, not for awhile. I think we have spent our time between the efforts of the campaign, and what I understand the'super PAC' Carly Fiorina is doing, we have spent our time making sure we have people on the ground."

Fiorina added, "Of course, I take advantage of earned media any chance I get. The debates are a really important opportunity for me. Every time I get out on that debate stage more people say ‘Oh, I didn’t know she was running for president. I kind of like her.’ So there will come a time for ads, but honestly, other candidates have already spent millions on ads and it’s done nothing for them. So I think the time is not yet."

Regarding the decline in her poll numbers, Fiorina argued that it was not due to attacks on her business record. "If the attacks were working, you’d start to see it in my favorable and unfavorables," she said, referring to poll data. "And in fact, I have very, very strong fave and unfave ratings. I think what you are seeing is that in the debate, half the audience saw me for the first time. You don’t make a sale in one impression. Also, we have been off national television for the last couple of weeks. We have been doing more regional media and more on the ground town halls."

"So I think you have to look at not every little bump in a poll—you have to look at a trajectory," Fiorina concluded.

Title: Poll Shows High Support Among Democrats for Semiautomatic Firearm Ban, Raising Concerns About Second Amendment Rights

Article:

A recent poll by YouGov has shown that 82 percent of Democrats support a ban on semiautomatic firearms, while they are evenly split on a total handgun ban. This revelation has sparked concerns among gun rights advocates, particularly those who support the Second Amendment, as the poll indicates a significant proportion of the Democratic Party supports imposing restrictions on firearm ownership.

The poll, which was conducted in the aftermath of the shooting at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Florida, has reignited the debate on gun control in the United States. The tragic incident left seventeen people dead, and the issue has since been thrust back into the limelight.

During a town hall event on February 21, Sen. Marco Rubio (R-FL) and NRA spokesperson Dana Loesch faced a hostile crowd at a CNN-hosted event in Sunrise, Florida. The event, which was described as an "Orwellian two minutes of hate exercise" by some, was met with criticism for its perceived bias against gun owners, conservatives, and Republicans.

The poll's findings have raised questions about the understanding of firearm terminology among respondents. For instance, when different respondents say they want to ban "semi-automatic rifles," or that they support "universal background checks," it is unclear what they actually mean. Lois Beckett, a journalist covering gun politics, has called on pollsters to survey Americans on their understanding of the basic terms of the debate.

The poll's results have sparked concerns among gun rights advocates about the potential impact on the Second Amendment if the Democratic Party's stance on gun control is reflected in future legislation. The high proportion of Democrats who support a semiautomatic firearm ban, as well as the party's stance on handguns, has raised questions about the possibility of imposing Australian-style gun bans and confiscatory policies in the United States.

In response to the poll, Lois Beckett, a journalist covering gun politics, tweeted, "My plea to pollsters, as a journalist covering gun politics: can you survey Americans on their understanding of what the basic terms of this debate mean?" and "When different respondents say they want to ban'semi-automatic rifles,' or that they support 'universal background checks,' what do they actually mean?"

The poll's findings have raised concerns about the potential impact on the Second Amendment if the Democratic Party's stance on gun control is reflected in future legislation. The high proportion of Democrats who support a semiautomatic firearm ban, as well as the party's stance on handguns, has raised questions about the possibility of imposing Australian-style gun bans and confiscatory policies in the United States.

Title: White House Opens to Possibility of Different Explanations for Benghazi Attack

Article:

Two days after the U.S. Ambassador to the United Nations, Susan Rice, described the deadly attack on the U.S. Consulate in Libya as a "spontaneous" reaction to protests, the White House has opened the door to the possibility of other explanations. White House Press Secretary Jay Carney stated on Tuesday that the FBI is investigating the incident, and the investigation will follow the facts wherever they lead.

Carney clarified that the administration does not have any indication of premeditation or pre-planned attacks at this point, but they are not making declarations ahead of the facts. Significantly, Carney did not provide as detailed an account as Ambassador Rice did in her Sunday interviews, suggesting that the investigation could offer a different version of events.

Rice had stated that the administration believes the attack was not preplanned or premeditated but was a "spontaneous" reaction to protests in Egypt over an anti-Islam film, with extremist elements joining the fray before it "spun out of control." However, this account clashes with claims by the Libyan president that the attack was in fact premeditated. Other sources, including an intelligence source in Libya who spoke to Fox News, have echoed those claims. The intelligence source even said that, contrary to the suggestion by the Obama administration, there was no major protest in Benghazi before the deadly attack which killed four Americans. A U.S. official did not dispute the claim.

In the face of these conflicting accounts, Carney on Tuesday deferred to the ongoing investigation. "It is an absolute tragedy that we lost four Americans in Benghazi," he said. "There is an active investigation underway about what happened and why and what the motivations were."

Some have questioned how an attack that involved RPGs and mortar fire could have possibly been spontaneous. Carney, though, suggested that such weapons are readily available in post-revolution Libya. "There are vast numbers of weapons and certainly a number of violent groups in the country," Carney said. "It is still a very volatile place, there's no question about it."

The ongoing investigation will examine "what role the video played" in the attack, among other things, according to Carney. Fox News was told that the assault on the consulate came without warning and included RPGs and mortars, including at least one round that hit the consulate roof. There were two waves to the assault, Fox News was told. According to the intelligence source, in the first wave, the attackers were heard to say "we got him" - a reference to Ambassador Chris Stevens, who was killed in the attack. Word spread, the attackers regrouped, and the second wave went after the motorcade and support personnel.

The account relayed by the intelligence source on the ground in Libya is consistent with statements by the Libyan president that the attack was pre-mediated and the work of foreign fighters, which is code for Islamist extremists, including the Al Qaeda affiliate in North Africa. It is also consistent with an interview by McClatchy Newspapers with a purported Libyan security guard who was injured in the assault. The guard said the consulate area was quiet and "there wasn't a single ant outside" until dozens of armed men descended on the compound.

Even before Ambassador Stevens' murder, U.S. officials say the CIA determined the security situation in eastern Libya was deteriorating based on four attacks, beginning in June, on diplomatic and Western targets in Benghazi, including the U.S. Consulate. That said, U.S. officials insist there was no specific warning of an armed assault, like the one that killed the four Americans.

Title: Washington and Lee University Faculty Votes to Remove Robert E. Lee's Name

Article:

The faculty of Washington and Lee University has voted to remove the name of Confederate General Robert E. Lee from the Virginia institution. The decision was made during a meeting on Monday, with the resolution passing 188-51. A proposed motion to remove George Washington's name failed.

The faculty had initially added Lee's name to the university, then known as Washington College, in 1870, shortly after Lee's death. Alison Bell, head of the Faculty Affairs Committee, stated, "Lee was a symbol of who the faculty wanted to be, and who they were. The faculty is now, 150 years later, asking the university for a name change because Lee does not represent who we are and who we want to be."

The student government formally requested the removal of Lee's name last week, and over 200 faculty members had signed a petition with the same objective. The board of trustees, which would need to approve the name change, is "carefully monitoring developments regarding issues of race, monuments, and symbols of the Confederacy and their implications" for Washington and Lee, a spokeswoman said last week.

In other parts of Virginia, Confederate names are being removed from public K-12 schools at a rapid pace, according to The Washington Post. Stonewall Middle School in Prince William County and Robert E. Lee High School in Fairfax County are among the schools undergoing name changes. Loudon County High School is also changing its mascot after the school board voted unanimously to drop the Raiders, a reference to Confederate Col. John S. Mosby’s guerrilla troops.

Historians noted that the widespread rejection of Confederate iconography by Virginia schools is unprecedented, according to The Washington Post. James Grossman at the American Historical Association stated that Black students, parents, and communities have objected since the schools were named in the 1950s and '60s, in response to the Supreme Court's landmark ruling in Brown v. Board of Education. Historian Adam Domby added, "It was trying to make black students feel unwelcome, while white students and white communities were emboldened to resist desegregation."

Title: Mueller's Testimony on Capitol Hill Met with Criticism from Trump's Attorney

Article:

Former special counsel Robert Mueller's testimony on Capitol Hill regarding his report on Russian interference in the 2016 U.S. election has been met with criticism from one of President Donald Trump's attorneys, Jay Sekulow. In an interview on Fox News' "Fox and Friends" on Thursday, Sekulow described the investigation as a "terrible, terrible waste of taxpayer money."

Sekulow stated that the investigation, which Trump has referred to as a "witch hunt," was "kind of encapsulated exactly what this is." He added that Mueller, "the architect, the person that's in charge of the investigation," was put on the stand, and the testimony was described as a "disaster," "train wreck," and "horrible" by commentators across various networks.

Sekulow also noted that House Speaker Nancy Pelosi appeared to be putting on a "happy face" at her press conference on Wednesday, but even members of the Democratic Party recognized that the testimony was a "train wreck."

According to Sekulow, there were 12-13 prosecutors who attempted to create a collusion, conspiracy, and obstruction narrative, but despite their efforts, they were unable to do so.

One of the most significant issues, Sekulow said, was when Mueller was asked about the exoneration narrative. He stated that Mueller was asked if there was any historical precedent for the policy on exoneration, to which Mueller responded that there was not. Sekulow argued that this indicates the president is being treated differently than any other citizen in terms of the burden of proof.

Regarding the arrests made during the investigation, Sekulow stated that there has been no discussion, as far as he knows, concerning whether some of those arrested will eventually be pardoned. However, he did note that there has been a lot of injustice in the case.

Title: Deadly 7.8-Magnitude Earthquake Strikes Nepal, Triggering Avalanches and Destruction

Article:

A devastating 7.8-magnitude earthquake hit Nepal over the weekend, resulting in at least 4,400 deaths and over 8,000 injuries, according to reports by Associated Press journalists Binaj Gurubacharya and Katy Daigle. The earthquake caused avalanches at Mount Everest base camp, resulting in at least 18 fatalities. Most of the casualties occurred in Nepal, but there are also reports of victims in India, Bangladesh, and along the Nepal-China border.

The earthquake brought down Dharahara Tower, a popular historical landmark in Kathmandu, built in 1832 and recognized by UNESCO. The tower, which attracted hundreds of visitors to ascend to its top on weekends, collapsed in the quake.

The full extent of the damage from the quake, which struck around noon, is still unknown as rescue workers continue to navigate through the rubble, particularly in the heavily populated Kathmandu Valley, where building quality is often low. Home Ministry official Laxmi Dhakal has stated that the death toll will likely rise.

Further earthquakes and aftershocks have complicated rescue operations. "There have been nearly 100 earthquakes and aftershocks, which is making rescue work difficult," Kathmandu district chief administrator Ek Narayan Aryal told the Associated Press. "Even the rescuers are scared and running because of them."

The initial earthquake was considerably more powerful than the one that devastated Haiti in 2010, and the same magnitude as the 1906 earthquake in San Francisco. However, it falls below Nepal's worst recorded earthquake in 1934, which measured at 8.0 and ravaged the cities of Kathmandu, Bhaktapur, and Patan.

German climber Jost Kobusch shared horrifying footage of an avalanche that reportedly hit a Mount Everest base camp in the aftermath of the initial earthquake. In the video, someone says, "The ground is shaking," before a wall of snow overwhelms a camp with dozens of tents. Two people are shown taking cover from the avalanche as they are pelted by ice and snow. They then walk around, showing the remains of the leveled camp.

Avalanches killed at least 18 people and injured at least 61 more in Nepal over the weekend, according to the Associated Press's Gurubacharya and Daigle. However, Kobusch survived, according to CNN.

Beyond the toll on human life, disasters like this earthquake greatly strain impoverished countries like Nepal. The South Asian country's economy relies heavily on tourism from trekkers and mountain climbers, many of whom are attracted to Mount Everest, the highest mountain in the world.

Experts had warned of a tragic earthquake in Nepal a week before it occurred. A week ago, about 50 earthquake and social scientists from around the world came to Kathmandu, Nepal, to discuss how to prepare the area better for a potential earthquake. Seismologist James Jackson, head of the earth sciences department at the University of Cambridge in England, told the Associated Press that he did not expect such a huge earthquake to hit so soon, but experts were warning that something like it was possible.

Not only is Nepal situated on a natural seismic fault, but local infrastructure is so poorly built to resist earthquakes that the tremors can lead to far more casualties than they would in other places across the world. US Geological Survey seismologist David Wald estimated to the Associated Press that the same level of severe shaking would lead to 10 to 30 deaths per million residents in California but kill 1,000 or more in Nepal and up to 10,000 in parts of Pakistan, India, Iran, and China.

"They knew they had a problem," Hari Kumar, southeast Asia regional coordinator for GeoHazards International, which works on global earthquake risks, told the Associated Press. "But it was so large they didn't know where to start, how to start."

Title: Thousands of Young Illegal Immigrants Line Up for Obama Administration's Deferred Action Program

Article:

Young illegal immigrants are queuing in large numbers at consulates nationwide to apply for the Obama administration's Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program, which commenced on Wednesday. The program, a version of the DREAM Act that failed to pass through Congress, could potentially benefit up to 1.8 million undocumented immigrants.

To qualify, applicants must fill out a six-page form, pay a $465 fee, and submit documents verifying their identity. They must demonstrate that they arrived in the U.S. before turning 16 and are either enrolled in school or vocational training, have a high school diploma, or are military veterans.

Immigration officials have stated that the applications will be thoroughly scrutinized due to the potential for fraud, but there is no uniform standard. The lines for passport applications began forming on Tuesday.

Kristi Alarcon, an applicant, told MyFoxHouston, "We are waiting for our passports. We want to get our passport because Obama might be asking for them."

In Los Angeles, advocates held workshops on Wednesday to guide applicants through the application process. The turnout on Tuesday and Wednesday is the most visible demonstration to date of the interest in the administration's new reprieve program.

The requirements for the DACA program are less stringent than those of the original DREAM Act. Applicants must be in school, have a high school diploma or GED, or be a military veteran. They cannot have a felony record, but a record with fewer than three minor misdemeanors is not disqualifying.

Under the DREAM Act, applicants not only had to show a high school diploma or GED, but after a six-year period, they had to demonstrate that they had attended college or served in the military for at least two years.

Republican lawmakers have criticized Obama for implementing the program, claiming it is an attempt to bypass Congress and favor illegal immigrants over unemployed U.S. citizens. Some, including House Judiciary Committee Chairman Lamar Smith, R-Texas, have labeled the policy a "backdoor amnesty" and expressed concerns about fraud.

"While potentially millions of illegal immigrants will be permitted to compete with American workers for scarce jobs, there seems to be little if any mechanism in place for vetting fraudulent applications and documentation submitted by illegal immigrants," Smith said Tuesday.

On Tuesday, Homeland Security announced the details of the documents illegal immigrants would need to provide to prove their eligibility for the Obama administration's DACA program. The announcement came a day before U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services began accepting applications for the program.

The program is launching just months before a tight White House contest, in which the Hispanic vote may play a significant role. Obama has faced criticism from Hispanic voters and others who believe he has not fulfilled a previous campaign promise to reform the nation's immigration laws.

Title: GOP and Democrats Prepare for Potential Senate Runoffs in Louisiana and Georgia

Article:

Republicans and Democrats are strategizing for potential runoff elections in Louisiana and Georgia that could determine control of the U.S. Senate. If Democratic Sen. Mary Landrieu does not win more than half the vote in the general election, she will likely face a one-on-one runoff with Republican Rep. Bill Cassidy in Louisiana. In Georgia, both parties are preparing for a potential nine-week runoff ending in January.

In Louisiana, Republicans are reserving hotel rooms and millions of dollars worth of ad time, signaling their readiness to pour money into the state after November. If the race goes to a runoff, Democrats believe their best shot at winning is to secure a majority in the initial election, taking advantage of a split between Cassidy and his main conservative opponent, Rob Maness.

In Georgia, both parties have built an infrastructure they are planning to rely on if the race goes to a runoff. Republicans, including the National Republican Senatorial Committee, have reserved significant amounts of TV time for the potential runoff, while conservative outside groups have also booked ad time. Democrats have yet to reserve airtime in Louisiana, and both sides are staying off the air for the runoff in Georgia—for now.

If a runoff occurs, Democrats in Louisiana are planning an aggressive ground and aerial attack to keep the seat, while Republicans, such as Cassidy, are focusing on uniting GOP support behind their candidate by opposing President Barack Obama. Both parties are remaining tight-lipped about their runoff plans, with the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee and Landrieu herself emphasizing their focus on winning both races on Election Day.

Title: Obama to Deliver Economic Speech at Knox College, Kicking Off Series Ahead of Budget Deadlines

Article:

President Barack Obama will deliver an economic speech at Knox College in Galesburg, Illinois on Wednesday, marking the beginning of a series of speeches on the economy over the next several weeks. The speeches are intended to precede key budget deadlines in the fall, including the start of the new fiscal year in October and the approaching government borrowing limit.

The address comes a week before Congress is scheduled to recess for a month, and the White House aims to apply public pressure on lawmakers to avoid the tax and spending showdowns that have characterized past budget debates.

The extensive White House preparations for the economic speech suggest that Obama is embarking on a different kind of agenda, focusing on leaving a historical legacy rather than delivering new policy announcements. The speech may serve as a retrospective on the economy's condition when Obama took office and its current state.

In addition to the economic discussion, the speech is expected to touch on topics such as green energy, investment, the importance of the middle class, and the notion of the wealthy paying their fair share. After the Knox College speech, Obama will travel to Missouri and Florida to deliver similar messages.

One point of interest will be how Obama presents Obamacare as part of an overall improved economy. Last week, when he spoke on healthcare, the Associated Press fact-checker criticized Obama for overstating the benefits of his signature healthcare legislation. Another issue to watch is how Obama will handle his approach to Republicans who refuse to vote for an increase in the debt ceiling without the defunding of Obamacare in return. Congress has only a few weeks to reach a deal.

However, it is likely that today's speech is not primarily about the economy. RealClearPolitics suggests that Obama may be increasingly considering his legacy and how he will be remembered in history. Speeches are a useful tool for leaving a lasting impression, while sifting through old unemployment data is not as exciting.

The speech is scheduled for 12:55 ET and will be streamed live at WhiteHouse.gov.

Title: Former Chinese Censor Claims Interview for TikTok Content Monitoring Role

Article:

A former Chinese internet censor, Liu Lipeng, has claimed that he was interviewed for a role monitoring and policing videos posted by international users of TikTok, a Chinese-owned short video app. Liu, who worked as an online censor in China for a decade, said he was passed over for the job in 2018 after suggesting during the interview that TikTok should not overly censor content due to Americans' value for freedom of speech.

Liu described ByteDance Technology Co., TikTok's parent company, as "the largest and most terrifying censorship machine" he has ever seen. His claims coincide with rising public concerns over TikTok's ties to the Chinese regime and come as the Trump administration considers banning the app over national security risks.

Liu, who built his career as a "content reviewer" for popular Chinese media apps Weibo and Leshi, said he was interviewed for a content manager position that would inspect "globalized videos" on TikTok. The job recruitment notice mentioned globalized videos. Alongside TikTok, ByteDance runs a Chinese version of the app named Douyin.

During the interview, Liu expressed a different vision for the role, stating, "I understand more about how much Americans care about freedom of speech, and therefore, we shouldn't overregulate." Liu was ultimately rejected because of these views, he believes.

TikTok did not immediately respond to a request for comment. The app has previously stated it does not use Chinese moderators to handle content on TikTok. In March, the company announced it would open a "transparency center" in Los Angeles to allow outside experts to see how TikTok moderates content.

Liu, who moved to the United States in March, said being in the United States means that he needs to defend U.S. interests, and there's "no turning back." He noted that the CCP's censorship apparatus has become more restrictive over the past decade, with recruitment being more open and requiring strong "political awareness."

This isn't the first time TikTok has drawn scrutiny for imposing Beijing-style censorship on overseas users. The company has previously been criticized for closing the account of a Chinese international student in New Jersey after he posted a video spoofing the Chinese national anthem and for suspending the account of a U.S. teen who posted a video criticizing Beijing's suppression of Uyghur Muslims in China's far-western Xinjiang region.

A U.S. review panel is currently probing ByteDance's $1 billion acquisition of U.S. social media app Musical.ly—which was rebranded to TikTok—in 2017. It is investigating whether the deal raised national security risks. The Pentagon last year ordered U.S. military personnel to delete TikTok from their work phones, while Wells Fargo recently followed suit, and the Democratic and Republican National Committees have warned staff members about using the app.

Following India's recent decision to ban TikTok and 58 other Chinese apps, the Trump administration confirmed that it was also considering a similar move. White House chief of staff Mark Meadows said on July 15 that a number of administration officials were "looking at the national security risk as it relates to TikTok, WeChat, and other apps." "I don't think there's any self-imposed deadline for action, but I think we are looking at weeks, not months," Meadows said.

Title: Presidential Candidates Address Economic Inequality and Social Policies

Article:

In the ongoing discourse surrounding the American economy and social policies, several Democratic presidential candidates have expressed concerns about economic inequality and the need for systemic reforms.

One candidate has highlighted the decline of the American Dream, citing increased farm bankruptcies, contaminated water supplies, opioid deaths, and high poverty rates, particularly among children. The candidate proposes rewriting the rules of the 21st-century economy to ensure it benefits all Americans.

The proposed solutions include rewriting the tax code to make big corporations pay their fair share in taxes, and using the resulting funds to reinvest in the American people. The candidate also advocates for the Freedom Dividend, a monthly $1,000 payment to every American adult over 18, with the aim of reducing poverty, creating jobs, and providing a financial foundation for individuals.

Another candidate emphasizes the importance of community colleges in preparing students for employment and aligning curricula with skills that lead to good jobs. They also propose federal student aid for quality short-term certificate programs with strong outcomes, extending the earned income tax credit and unemployment insurance to Americans in training programs, and bridging the prosperity divide in America.

The candidates also address the issue of low unemployment, suggesting that it should be the starting point for good social policy, not the end. They argue that a strong labor market creates political space to address social problems such as child care, health care, college costs, and environmental protection, which cannot be solved by a 'good economy' alone.

In addition, the candidates have voiced concerns about the potential escalation of conflict in the Middle East following the assassination of Qassem Soleimani. They question the strategic and moral implications of the action, and the potential for it to lead to a new war with Iran. They call for a careful consideration of the consequences of such a conflict, and the need for a clear war aim and strategy.

Finally, they urge influential Republican senators to remind the president of his promise to keep America out of foreign quagmires and to prevent the president from stumbling further into war with Iran.

Title: National Debt Surpasses $22 Trillion Under Trump Administration, Contrasting Early Campaign Promises

Article:

The United States Treasury Department reported Tuesday that the national debt has reached a record $22.012 trillion, marking the first time it has surpassed the $21 trillion threshold. This figure represents a $2.065 trillion increase since President Donald Trump took office in 2017, when the debt stood at $19.947 trillion.

The department's fiscal statement attributes part of this increase to the rising costs of Medicare and Social Security, but also cites the trillion-dollar deficit resulting from the tax cuts enacted in 2017, which primarily benefited corporations and the wealthy.

During his 2015 campaign, Trump had promised to reduce the national debt, stating he would "reduce our $18 trillion in debt" if elected president. At his official campaign launch, he claimed he would "bring back the American dream bigger and better and stronger than ever before" and "make America great again." In December 2015, he also pledged to "freeze the budget," a promise that has not been fulfilled.

Since his election, Trump has suggested that tariffs would enable him to start paying down the debt. However, the ongoing trade war resulting from these tariffs has reportedly caused significant harm to the agricultural industry, with American farmers uncertain about the impact of negotiations with countries like China, a major buyer of U.S. soybeans.

Since taking office, Trump has been less vocal about the national debt, tweeting about it only a handful of times, including in February 2017, November 2017, and August 2018. His budget proposals have instead been projected to add $7.2 trillion more to the debt over the next 10 years.

As a candidate, Trump frequently criticized President Barack Obama and former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton for increasing the debt, alleging their policies had added $9 trillion. Since taking office, Trump has been less vocal about the debt, focusing on other issues. His first joint address to Congress and subsequent State of the Union addresses did not mention the debt, the budgetary deficit, or any fiscal policy.

In response to the Treasury Department's report, Trump's budget director and current chief of staff, Mick Mulvaney, dismissed budget promises as "hyperbole." It remains unclear if the Trump administration has a plan to reduce the now-$22 trillion debt.

Title: Wisconsin Recall Election: Obama Blames Outspending Democrats for Walker's Victory

Article:

In the aftermath of the Wisconsin recall election on Tuesday, President Barack Obama has attributed the victory of Governor Scott Walker to the Republicans' outspending Democrats during the campaign. Walker, who defeated Milwaukee Mayor Tom Barrett in a repeat of their 2010 showdown, has suggested that presumptive Republican presidential nominee Mitt Romney could make a play for Wisconsin in the general election.

The state has not voted Republican in a presidential election since 1984, but Walker stated that while Romney "is an underdog," he can compete if he presents a bold platform. Walker told MSNBC on Wednesday that "anyone looking at the results last night would also acknowledge that it’s now competitive in Wisconsin."

The central issue in the Wisconsin recall election was the Republican state government's decision to break the public employees unions' grip on setting members' taxpayer-funded salaries and benefits, a move the GOP argued was necessary to address unsustainable liabilities, a problem many other states also face.

Through his spokesman Jay Carney, President Obama expressed his view that the fight was unfair due to the Republicans' significant fundraising and spending advantage over the Democrats in the state, with a large portion of the funds coming from corporate and out-of-state sources.

In 2010, Walker won the governorship on a union-taming platform by a 4-percentage-point margin. Republicans view Tuesday's 7-point margin as a positive sign, potentially indicating growing voter discontent with Democrats' ties to unions. However, whether the Walker win signals a nationwide trend of growing discontent with union power remains unclear.

In Ohio, Governor John Kasich signed a law stripping collective bargaining rights from public employees, only to see the law repealed in a referendum by a 2-to-1 margin. In another Wisconsin recall election on Tuesday, a union-backed Democrat unseated a state senator, shifting control of the chamber to the Democrats.

While Republicans in Wisconsin are optimistic about the election results, outside analysts are more cautious. John Zogby, a pollster who conducts polling for The ███, stated, "I don’t see Wisconsin in play. On Tuesday, voters there chose Obama over Romney and they also chose stalemate."

In response to the Wisconsin results, Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee Chairman Steve Israel has called for Democrats to increase their fundraising efforts ahead of the general election. Israel stated, "The Wisconsin results should serve as a wake-up call for Democrats: on-the-ground organizing is critically important, but it must be coupled with an aggressive air campaign."

As the general election approaches, the focus remains on how the financial resources of both parties will be allocated. Republicans, who in the past have complained about deep-pocket Democratic donors outnumbering and outgiving their Republican counterparts, are now facing similar concerns from the Democratic side. Israel noted, "Democratic groups won’t outspend Republican groups, but they can keep us in the fight."

Title: Federal Investigation Intensifies in Boston Marathon Bombing Case

Article:

Three days after the Boston Marathon bombing, hundreds of federal investigators are actively pursuing the identity of a man seen acting suspiciously on video footage from a department store across the street from the second explosion site. The individual, described as a young white man wearing a black jacket, a gray hooded sweatshirt, and a white or off-white baseball cap on backwards, is the focus of the investigation.

According to FBI personnel, video security clips from Lord & Taylor department store show the man dropping a bag and then leaving the area. Images also reveal him exiting the site shortly after the first explosion, before the second explosion occurred. A spokeswoman for Boston Mayor Thomas Menino, Dot Joyce, told The Boston Globe that the Lord & Taylor camera is the best source of video footage so far, and that investigators are making progress.

Investigators are currently going through cellphone call logs line by line, attempting to determine who made calls from the location around the time of the bombing. They have cellphone owner information they are trying to match to the elusive man.

CBS News correspondent John Miller, a former FBI assistant director, stated that federal authorities decided to release images from the Lord & Taylor video in an effort to enlist the public in identifying the man. However, they have yet to decide whether to proceed with this tactic, according to Miller.

Reports on Wednesday suggested that a suspect had been arrested, citing law enforcement sources. However, the FBI later issued a statement denying such an arrest and asking for media outlets to exercise responsibility and restraint in their reporting on the case.

On Thursday, reports indicated that the FBI is also seeking the identification of a second person captured on video who was seen carrying a backpack and behaving suspiciously in the vicinity of the first person of interest. The Los Angeles Times reported that the image showing two men is the first indication that more than one bomber may have been responsible for the attacks.

The FBI is reportedly using modern facial recognition software to speedily look for matches in FBI databases of arrest photos and criminal suspects. Surveillance cameras in airports and other public locations can also be programmed to look for people with similar features.

The nation remains on edge in the wake of the Boston Marathon tragedy. An explosion at a fertilizer plant in West, Texas, causing many casualties, added to the sense of American unease. In Washington, the FBI announced the arrest of a Mississippi man, Paul Kevin Curtis, in the mailing of letters laced with the poison ricin to President Obama and at least one US senator. President Obama is set to travel to Boston on Thursday for a memorial event for Boston Marathon bombing victims.

Massachusetts Gov. Deval Patrick told the AP that the public's frustration with the lack of arrests is shared, but cautioned that the case will not be resolved "by magic." Governor Patrick stated, "It's going to happen by doing the careful work that must be done in a thorough investigation, which means going through the couple of blocks at the blast scene inch by square inch and picking up pieces of evidence and following those trails, and that's going to take some time."

Title: White House and Congressional Leaders Push for Third Coronavirus Spending Package, Totaling Hundreds of Billions

Article:

White House officials and congressional lawmakers are signaling their intention to advance a third coronavirus spending package, worth hundreds of billions of dollars, while the Senate works on a more modest second relief bill. The White House is reportedly pushing for an $850 billion stimulus, primarily in the form of tax relief measures.

According to Fox News, approximately $500 billion of this would be tied to a payroll tax cut, while $250 billion would come in the form of Small Business Administration loans, and $58 billion would be directed to the airline industry, among other measures. Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin is set to discuss the details of the comprehensive coronavirus proposal with Senate Republicans at a larger-than-usual policy lunch on Tuesday.

Mnuchin, when asked about the proposal's cost on Monday, stated, "I’m not going to comment on the numbers now. But it’s a big number." The Washington Post reported Tuesday that Mnuchin's proposal would come with an $850 billion price tag, focusing mainly on putting cash in the hands of individuals and businesses.

Meanwhile, Senate Democrats will hold their weekly lunch via conference call, with Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer likely discussing a $750 billion proposal he announced Monday to address the coronavirus and the economic crisis. Schumer stated, "As early as tomorrow, I will present a series of proposals to Congressional appropriators that Senate Democrats believe should be part of the next bill to address the coronavirus."

Senate Democrats' proposal includes expanded unemployment insurance and Medicaid funding, addressing strained hospital capacity, providing urgent assistance to small businesses, and assisting schools in transitioning to remote learning as more states close down their public schools.

Sen. Elizabeth Warren, D-Mass., backed Schumer's call for a $750 billion arsenal to battle the coronavirus and its economic effects in an op-ed for CNN Monday. It is unclear what exactly will be in Mnuchin's proposal to Senate Republicans, but there is a chance there could be significant overlap with Schumer's ideas.

In an interview with Chris Wallace on "Fox News Sunday," Mnuchin emphasized the need for a "big stimulus program because we need to help American workers now." Mnuchin made clear that the administration is not asking for a bailout, stating, "If you’re providing liquidity to good businesses that just need liquidity for 3 to 6 months, that’s not a bailout."

Other lawmakers have proposed ideas to combat the coronavirus and help Americans affected by the economic shutdown. Sen. Mitt Romney, R-Utah, suggested providing every American with a $1,000 check to cover expenses due to layoffs, forced leave, or other coronavirus-related expenses. Rep. Tulsi Gabbard, D-Hawaii, proposed a similar idea last week, introducing a nonbinding House resolution to provide each American with a monthly $1,000 payment until the coronavirus threat subsides.

These proposals appear similar to former Democratic presidential contender Andrew Yang's universal basic income (UBI) idea, but are distinguished from it mainly because they are temporary, stopgap measures.

Title: Michael Flynn's Lawyers Cease Communications with Trump's Legal Team in Ongoing Russia Probe

Article:

Lawyers for former National Security Advisor Michael Flynn have halted communications with U.S. President Donald Trump's legal team, potentially marking a significant development in the ongoing investigation into contacts between Trump's election campaign and Russia, sources familiar with the investigation said on Friday.

Flynn's lawyer, Robert Kelner, reportedly called John Dowd, Trump's private lawyer, on Wednesday to say the matter had reached a point where the two could no longer discuss it, two people familiar with the call told sources on Friday. The New York Times first reported that the two sets of lawyers had stopped communicating.

It is unclear whether Kelner made the call because he had negotiated a plea agreement with Special Counsel Robert Mueller for Flynn to cooperate in the probe, or because Flynn had decided to engage with Mueller, said two other sources.

"No one should draw the conclusion that this means anything about General Flynn cooperating against the president," Jay Sekulow, another attorney for Trump, said on Thursday.

Dowd, Mueller's spokesman John Carr, Kelner, and White House officials declined to comment on the matter.

Flynn, a retired Army general, is a central figure in a federal investigation led by Special Counsel Robert Mueller into whether Trump aides colluded with alleged Russian efforts to boost his 2016 presidential campaign.

The cooperation of Flynn, who was a top campaign adviser before becoming Trump's national security adviser in the White House, would be a major asset in Mueller's investigation. In March, as he unsuccessfully sought immunity for his client to testify to House and Senate investigations into the issue, Kelner said, "Mr. Flynn certainly has a story to tell, and he certainly wants to tell it, should the circumstances permit."

Two sources familiar with Mueller's investigation said Flynn may be able to provide insight into three major areas of inquiry. These are: any collusion between the Trump campaign and Russia in the 2016 campaign; money laundering and other possible financial crimes by Trump aides; and whether Trump sought to obstruct justice when he fired former FBI Director James Comey in May, as Comey was probing the Trump campaign's dealings with Russia.

Russia has denied interfering in the election. Trump has repeatedly denied any collusion with Russia by his campaign and has called the inquiry a witch hunt.

Two congressional officials involved in separate probes into the Trump campaign's contacts with Russia said one key area of investigation is whether Flynn or other advisers to Trump ever suggested U.S. economic sanctions on Russia could be lifted in exchange for favorable business deals.

Possible deals include a proposed commercial nuclear power project involving Russian firms that Flynn in recent years worked to promote to potential clients in the Middle East, sources familiar with the project told sources.

"At this point, there is no evidence of an effort to negotiate that kind of deal, but Flynn is near the top of the list of people who probably would know if there was any such effort," said one of the congressional officials, also speaking on the condition of anonymity.

Trump fired Flynn on Feb. 13, after disclosures that Flynn had discussed U.S. sanctions on Russia with then Russian Ambassador Sergei Kislyak in December, the month before Trump took office, and later misled Vice President Mike Pence about the conversations.

Flynn has acknowledged contacts with Kislyak dating back to 2013, but beyond saying they covered a variety of subjects has said nothing about the content of their conversations during Trump's campaign and after his election.

Flynn has been under scrutiny by the special counsel in a number of areas, sources familiar with the investigation have said. Mueller has been investigating whether Flynn knowingly made false statements to the government about his foreign travels, income, and contacts on his security clearance form.

Flynn also has come under scrutiny for work on behalf of Russian clients, and over whether his work for a businessman with ties to Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan was lawful.

Mueller has been investigating Flynn's son, Michael Flynn Jr.'s, involvement in some of his father's business dealings in Russia, Turkey, and elsewhere, the sources said, and that could provide a potent additional incentive for Flynn to cooperate.

Barry Coburn, a lawyer for Flynn's son, declined to comment.

Title: Whistleblower's Lawyers Express Concern Over President Trump's Statements Regarding Identity

Article:

The legal team for the whistleblower whose complaint triggered a US presidential impeachment inquiry has expressed concern over President Donald Trump's statements that could potentially endanger their client. Since the transcript of his call with the president of Ukraine was revealed, Mr. Trump has called for the anonymous whistleblower to be unmasked.

Democrats have stated that the whistleblower will testify to Congress "soon" once steps are taken to protect their identity. Mr. Trump has suggested his opponents could be arrested for treason.

A transcript of a call Mr. Trump made to Ukraine's new President Volodymyr Zelensky shows he urged him to investigate discredited corruption allegations against former vice-president and 2020 presidential candidate Joe Biden as well as his son. The call is now at the center of an effort by Democrats that could see Mr. Trump expelled from office, but doing so would require members of his Republican party to turn against him.

The letter from the whistleblower's legal team, in which the lawyers call attention to Mr. Trump's language, was sent to Acting Director of National Intelligence Joseph Maguire on Saturday and made public on Sunday.

"The events of the past week have heightened our concerns that our client's identity will be disclosed publicly and that, as a result, our client will be put in harm's way," wrote lawyer Andrew Bakaj.

The letter specifically mentions Mr. Trump's call last week for the whistleblower to be identified, as well as the person that supplied the whistleblower with information about the call. It quotes Mr. Trump as saying: "I want to know who's the person that gave the whistleblower, who's the person that gave the whistleblower the information, because that's close to a spy. You know what we used to do in the old days when we were smart? Right? With spies and treason, right? We used to handle them a little differently than we do now."

The letter also references a $50,000 "bounty" that two conservative Trump supporters have offered as a "reward" for information about the whistleblower.

"Unfortunately, we expect this situation to worsen, and to become even more dangerous for our client and any other whistleblowers, as Congress seeks to investigate this matter," Mr. Bakaj's letter adds.

Mr. Maguire faced lawmakers last week and said he believed the whistleblower acted in "good faith."

Impeachment is the first part - the charges - of a two-stage political process by which Congress can remove a president from office. If the House of Representatives votes to pass articles of impeachment, the Senate is forced to hold a trial. A Senate vote requires a two-thirds majority to convict - unlikely in this case, given that Mr. Trump's party controls the chamber.

Only two US presidents in history - Bill Clinton and Andrew Johnson - have been impeached, but neither was convicted and removed.

On Sunday evening, Mr. Trump retweeted a Fox News guest who warned that if Mr. Trump is removed from office, it will spark "a Civil War like fracture in this Nation from which our Country will never heal." Illinois Republican Congressman Adam Kinzinger condemned Mr. Trump's tweet as "repugnant."

It came as part of a massive Twitter volley against his critics, in which Mr. Trump said he wanted to meet the whistleblower.

"I want to meet not only my accuser... but also the person who illegally gave this information, which was largely incorrect, to the 'Whistleblower.' Was this person SPYING on the US President? Big Consequences!"

On Monday, Mr. Trump resumed his Twitter campaign against the whistleblower, as well as Democratic House Intelligence Committee Chairman Adam Schiff, who is playing a leading role in the inquiry and has been one of the most vocal critics of the US president.

"I want Schiff questioned at the highest level for Fraud & Treason," wrote Mr. Trump.

Over the weekend, Republicans began to mount a campaign to defend Mr. Trump, however, some prominent Republican officials appeared to condemn Mr. Trump for this latest scandal. Tom Bossert, who served as Homeland Security Advisor under Mr. Trump, told ABC News: "I'm deeply disturbed by it [the call] as well and this entire mess."

Donald Trump is frequently at his most unfiltered over weekends - and this last one served as evidence in the extreme. Since Saturday morning, the president has fired off more than a hundred tweets and retweets, lashing out at Democrats in Congress, the media, his political critics, and even conservative Fox News.

The recently announced formal impeachment inquiry has become all-consuming for Mr. Trump - and is turning the man who likes to fashion himself as a "counter-puncher" into a whirling frenzy of fists. The risk for the president is the more he lashes out, the more it reminds the American public of what they see as Mr. Trump's greatest flaw.
