Polls consistently demonstrate a majority of Americans - on the left and the right - disapprove of the president's penchant for social media invective and the apparent lack of discipline it represents.

If a weekend spent on scorched-earth responses mark Mr. Trump's impeachment battle plan - with him tweeting the shots from his phone - it may make for a shaky defense and cause growing unease among Republicans who contemplate the challenges of campaigning for re-election under the president's banner in 2020.

In a complaint filed last month, a whistleblower from the intelligence community reported his "urgent concern" that the president had used his office to "solicit interference from a foreign country" in the 2020 US election. The impeachment inquiry launched on Tuesday now focuses specifically on Mr. Trump's call to the Ukrainian president about the Biden allegations.

Democrats accuse Mr. Trump of improperly seeking foreign help in the hope of smearing Mr. Biden and of using military aid as a bargaining tool. Ukrainian ex-prosecutor general Yuriy Lutsenko has told the BBC that there was no reason to investigate Mr. Biden or his son Hunter Biden, who had worked for a Ukrainian energy firm.

Democrats in Congress - which is currently in recess - say they plan to remain in Washington over the break to move "expeditiously" on with impeachment hearings and subpoenas. Lawmakers say in addition to the whistleblower, they also wish to speak with the president's personal lawyer Rudy Giuliani, who Mr. Trump asked the Ukrainian president to co-ordinate with on an inquiry into the Bidens.

Title: Gilead Sciences Announces Cost of Coronavirus Treatment Remdesivir

Article:

Gilead Sciences, a biopharmaceutical company, has announced the cost of its antiviral drug remdesivir for the treatment of COVID-19. In an open letter, Gilead Chairman and CEO Daniel O' Day revealed that the cost for COVID-19 patients covered by Medicare and the governments of developed countries will be $2,340, equating to approximately $390 per vial. For U.S. patients with private health insurance, the cost will be $3,120, or up to $5,720 for a longer duration of treatment.

In the letter, O' Day also confirmed that the company has entered into agreements with drug manufacturers capable of producing generic forms of the drug in developing countries. The company expects to begin charging in July.

The announcement comes amid scrutiny of remdesivir by doctors and medical experts. While the cost covers a five-day treatment course, a medical publication previously noted that remdesivir reduced recovery time by an average of four days based on a 10-day course of remdesivir.

Some medical professionals have expressed concern about the cost compared to the benefits, with some arguing that clinical studies have not yet indicated whether there is a mortality benefit that can justify the cost.

Dr. Eugene Gu tweeted, "Gilead Sciences charging $2,340 for a 5-day course of Remdesivir that maybe reduces time to recovery, doesn't improve survival, and is likely inferior to the much cheaper dexamethasone for ventilated patients reveals Big Pharma's greed and opportunism during this pandemic."

James Todaro, MD, tweeted, "Remdesivir price is out now. As I suspected, it's not cheap. Gilead is charging hospitals between $3,120 and $5,720 per patient. Payment will begin in July, likely in anticipation of making a profit in the second wave of COVID-19. Lot of money for a drug with no mortality benefit."

It is worth noting that Gilead Sciences received a $37.5 million grant from the U.S. government to develop and test remdesivir. Additionally, Gilead projected 2020 revenue for Remdesivir to be $1 billion.

Dr. Anthony Fauci, a leading expert on infectious diseases, previously touted remdesivir as showing promise in the treatment of COVID-19.

Title: Tariffs Reduce U.S. Manufacturing Employment and Increase Prices, According to Federal Reserve Study

Article:

A new study by two Federal Reserve economists suggests that the ongoing U.S.-China trade war has resulted in a reduction in U.S. manufacturing employment and increased prices for the materials manufacturers need. The study, which serves as a natural experiment by comparing trends across different industries, finds that the benefits from being protected from foreign competition are canceled out by the higher costs manufacturers incur due to tariffs.

The study, which breaks out the three main effects of the trade war, estimates its impacts on employment, production, and prices. The vertical lines in the charts represent the first and last phases of tariff hikes, and the shaded areas represent "confidence intervals," meaning the trend lines are estimates, and the true values may lie elsewhere in the shaded areas.

The study finds that rising input costs decreased employment and increased producer prices, while foreign retaliation also decreased employment. On the positive side, import protection did seem to increase employment, though the effect is borderline in terms of statistical significance.

Comparing industries more exposed to each type of effect with those less exposed, the authors find that the former suffered a reduction in employment of 1.4 percent, with the positive contribution from the import protection effect of tariffs (0.3 percent) more than offset by the negative effects associated with rising input costs (-1.1 percent) and retaliatory tariffs (-0.7 percent). The same comparison for producer prices reveals a 4.1 percent increase.

The study's findings must be seen in the context of overall trends. American manufacturing employment was on the rise in 2017 and 2018, but it stalled thereafter, when the tariffs were in full effect. A policy meant to promote manufacturing work may have contributed to its stagnation instead.

The study has some limitations, including the possibility of other equally credible ways of analyzing the data, outright errors, and the fact that it only analyzes the trade war's short-term effects on American manufacturing. The authors also note that the increase in uncertainty generated by recent rounds of tariff increases may be one of the ways in which the effects of past policy persist.

Aside from the possibility the paper is just wrong, these limitations provide little comfort to the people who missed out on job opportunities thanks to protectionism.

Title: Senate's "Nuclear Option" Likely to be Invoked in Gorsuch Confirmation Vote

Article:

The Senate is expected to take a significant step in the confirmation process of President Trump's Supreme Court nominee, Neil Gorsuch, with at least 41 Democrats reportedly planning to block his nomination. This could potentially lead to the Republican-controlled Senate invoking the so-called "nuclear option," a parliamentary maneuver that would eliminate the filibuster for Supreme Court nominees.

The filibuster, a procedural tactic that requires 60 votes to end debate and move forward with a vote, is a unique element in the U.S. Senate, which is the world's most deliberative body. However, the filibuster can be rewritten with a simple majority vote, and the 60-vote threshold is an illusion that has survived only due to a bipartisan, institutional belief in its importance.

If Democrats cannot secure 60 votes to end debate on Gorsuch's nomination, the Senate could face a filibuster, potentially stalling the confirmation process until Gorsuch is withdrawn. If this occurs, Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Kentucky) may trigger the "nuclear option" and abolish the filibuster for Supreme Court nominees.

The process to invoke the "nuclear option" would unfold as follows:

1. The Senate will vote to invoke "cloture," which ends debate on the issue at hand. Under Rule XXII, the Senate requires 60 votes to approve cloture and end a debate.
2. If cloture fails, a Republican senator will move to reconsider the cloture motion. After it fails a second time, McConnell will raise a point of order declaring that all Supreme Court nominees can be approved with a simple majority vote.
3. The Senate President pro tempore will rule on whether points of order are approved or overruled, based on Senate rules and precedent.
4. If McConnell's point of order is overruled, he can appeal the ruling, which triggers an immediate vote on the Senate president's ruling.
5. The vote on the Senate president's ruling is a simple majority vote. If a majority of the Senate votes "nay" on the interpretation of the Senate rules, a new precedent is set to guide future votes on U.S. Supreme Court nominees—namely, a precedent saying cloture is not required.
6. Democrats will likely appeal that vote, with Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer (D-New York) raising a point of order and asking the President pro tempore if cloture is required for U.S. Supreme Court nominees.
7. The Senate President will cite the just-taken vote as a new Senate precedent that the threshold for approving Supreme Court nominees is a simple majority. He will overrule Schumer's point of order.
8. Schumer can appeal this ruling and call for a vote on the Senate President's ruling. This triggers an immediate vote.
9. The Republican majority will defeat Schumer's appeal, and the Senate President's interpretation of the rules (the new interpretation, which says only a simple majority is needed) will be confirmed.
10. Finally, after all the parliamentary shenanigans, the Senate will return to the question of Gorsuch's nomination. With the new precedent in place, a simple majority vote will approve Gorsuch's nomination and make him the 113th member of the U.S. Supreme Court.

The Senate's confirmation process for Supreme Court nominees is often compared to the fictional sport Calvinball, a game played and invented by the characters Calvin and Hobbes in the comic strip Calvin and Hobbes. The game has a slew of complicated rules that are arbitrary and nutty, but any of the rules can be changed at any time, usually by any player. The Senate's rules operate in a similar manner, with the most important thing to know being that any of the rules can be changed at any time, usually by the players themselves.

Title: Amazon Rainforest Fires: A Closer Look at the Data

Article:

The Amazon Rainforest fires have been a global concern, with numerous news outlets reporting unprecedented rates of burning due to human-induced global warming. Headlines such as "Amazon rainforest burning at record rate" (CNN) and "The Amazon rainforest is burning. Be afraid" (New York Daily News) have been common.

However, a closer examination of the data reveals some issues with the information provided. The satellite fire data referenced only began in 2013, making six years of data insufficient for making "record-breaking" statements in any context. Furthermore, the satellite data collected was not intended to be used as a counting tool for the number of fires but rather as a readiness alert system to identify fires before they become uncontrollable.

According to NASA's Global Fire Emissions Database, activity is above average in the states of Amazonas and Rondonia, but below average in Mato Grosso and Pará. The overall numbers are in line with historic data that goes back to 2003, providing a more accurate perspective on the fires.

It is essential to understand that the Amazon fire season begins in late July and peaks in mid-September, ending in November. Most fires are intentionally set due to the difficulty of starting and spreading fires in the damp rainforest. Ranchers have historically used fire to clear the forest, with up to 15% of the original forest cleared in the 1990s and 2000s before conservation efforts slowed the loss of forest.

Fires are rare during much of the year due to the wet nature of the climate. During the dry season, land that has already been cleared is typically burned periodically to regenerate and maintain farmland or pasture. Much of the fire being reported as the virgin tropical rainforest is existing grassland or farmland being regenerated using fire as a tool.

The Amazonian rainforest plays a crucial role in the global ecosystem, and conservation efforts have been effective in stemming the worst of deforestation abuses. The promotion of alarmist and false information misdirects the energies of people, including world leaders, and undermines trust in media and public institutions.

Gregory Wrightstone, the author of the book "Inconvenient Facts: The Science That Al Gore Doesn't Want You to Know," is a geologist with over 35 years of experience researching and studying various aspects of the Earth's processes.

Views expressed in this article are the opinions of the author and do not necessarily reflect the views of ███.

Title: Boy Scouts of America Renames Program, Remains at Odds with Girl Scouts

Article:

The Boy Scouts of America (BSA) announced on Wednesday its decision to drop "Boy" from the name of its signature program, marking a significant shift in the organization's approach to inclusivity. This move comes amid ongoing competition with the Girl Scouts, as both organizations grapple with declining membership.

The BSA's decision, however, did not impress the Girl Scouts, which emphasized the lack of new, "girl-specific" programming in the BSA's offerings. Sylvia Acevedo, CEO of Girl Scouts of the USA, stated, "Girl Scouts is the premier leadership development organization for girls. We are, and will remain, the first choice for girls and parents."

The BSA will retain its name, Boy Scouts of America or BSA, and the term "Cub Scouts" for children aged 7-10 will remain unchanged. The program for children aged 10-17, previously known as Boy Scouts, will become Scouts BSA in February.

Mike Surbaugh, the BSA's Chief Scout Executive, unveiled the group's "Scout Me In" marketing campaign, emphasizing inclusiveness. "As we enter a new era for our organization, it is important that all youth can see themselves in Scouting in every way possible," Surbaugh said.

In October, the BSA announced it would provide programs for girls. In the months prior, the group announced it would accept and register transgender youths into its organization.

Starting this summer, Cub Scouts will formally accept girls. Over 3,000 girls nationwide have already enrolled in the BSA’s Early Adopter Program and are participating in Cub Scouts before the full launch.

The BSA argues that allowing girls into the organization allows busy families to consolidate programs for their children. Most of the actual Cub packs and Scout troops, however, will remain single-gender. Girls and boys can work toward the prestigious title of Eagle Scout.

The BSA claims almost 2.3 million members, down from 2.6 million five years ago. This includes Venturing and Sea Scouting programs, the latter allowing membership up to 21 years of age. In its peak years, BSA had over 4 million participants.

Adults play a major role in the program, with almost 1 million adult volunteers serving as the backbone of the organization.

The impact of the BSA's aggressive recruitment effort on the Girl Scouts is yet to be determined. The Girl Scouts, best known for its lucrative annual cookie sales, currently claims a membership of about 1.8 million.

The Girl Scouts have listed a series of efforts aimed at "staying ahead of the pack of youth organizations." This includes 23 new merit badges focusing on outdoors and STEM (science, technology, engineering, and math), and last month, the organization unveiled a LinkedIn network aimed at tapping a major resource—the group's 50 million alums.

The goal of the network is "to support female advancement in the workforce and help prepare girls for a lifetime of leadership and career success."

However, the impact of the BSA's effort is already being felt. Fiona Cummings, a regional leader of Girl Scouts of Northern Illinois, told the Associated Press that the BSA's decision to admit girls is among the factors that have shrunk her council's youth membership by over 500 girls so far this year.

She stated, "How do you manage these strategic tensions?" She continued, "We both need to increase our membership numbers."

Title: Clinton's Ties to For-Profit University Laureate Raise Questions Amid Presidential Campaign

Article:

Hillary Clinton, during her campaign trail, has been a vocal critic of for-profit universities, accusing them of charging high prices and offering little support, while delivering degrees of questionable value. However, her administration, she says, would crack down on for-profit colleges and loan servicers who have allegedly taken advantage of borrowers.

What is not mentioned in Clinton's campaign speeches are her close family connections to for-profit Laureate Education and the substantial $9.8 billion in loans accumulated by students at Laureate's Walden University in Minnesota. This is according to a Brookings Institution study from last year, making Walden University the second-most indebted U.S. college, trailing only the University of Phoenix.

If Clinton wonders why many voters consider her to be graspy and question her trustworthiness, she need look no further than the tangled, lucrative ties among Laureate, its owners, the Clinton family, and the Clinton Foundation. From 2010 until just two weeks before Clinton launched her presidential campaign last year, the private company paid Bill Clinton $17.6 million as the honorary chancellor, a role that involved offering advice to Laureate executives and speaking to students at some of the school's dozens of campuses around the world.

In addition, since 2007, Laureate and its major investors and financiers—including Goldman Sachs, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co., SAC Capital, and CitiGroup Private Equity—have donated millions more to the Clinton Foundation, Clinton's two presidential campaigns, and related organizations, as well as speaking fees to both Bill and Hillary Clinton, including $900,000 from Goldman and KKR for four appearances by Hillary Clinton in 2013 alone.

Having a former president, and spouse of a sitting secretary of State, become Laureate's public face burnished its reputation as it went on a debt-fueled global buying spree, acquiring dozens of colleges from Latin America to Asia. And having muscular contacts among the global foreign policy elite is helpful in fending off more government regulation in the nearly 30 countries where Baltimore-based Laureate operates.

Robert Zoellick, a former World Bank president and deputy secretary of State, is on the board, and George W. Bush's secretary of State, Condoleezza Rice, is a paid adviser to Laureate who has given speeches on its campuses as far away as China. When Clinton stepped down, Laureate replaced him with a former president of Mexico.

Even as Laureate, which has had net losses totaling $563.4 million in its past three fiscal years and $102.4 million in the first quarter of this year, presents itself as a "public benefit corporation"—a hybrid of profit-seeking capitalism and high-minded do-gooderism—some of its business practices dance close to ethical red lines.

Outside the USA, for example, Laureate pays recruiters legal "commissions" for getting students to enroll in its schools—a practice Congress banned in the U.S. because it encouraged for-profit schools to enroll students and harvest their loan money with little regard to whether they graduated and were able to pay back their loans.

At Walden, Laureate's largest American campus, loan default rates are lower than the national average. However, according to the U.S. Department of Education, three years after undergraduates leave Walden, 56% have yet to repay a single dollar on their loans compared with 33% nationwide.

In any other election, the Clintons' ties to Laureate Education would likely receive more attention. In this contest, though, the Democratic presidential nominee is fortunate that her Republican opponent happens to be the founder of Trump University, an operation that makes Laureate look like Harvard.

Title: Millennial Voter Turnout Remains Low Despite Increased Political Awareness

Article:

Millennial voters are attracting less attention from politicians in the current election cycle due to low expectations for their turnout. In the 2010 midterm election, only 25% of voters aged 18 to 29 cast their ballots, and this year, the projected turnout for voters under 30 is even lower at 23%. These figures are according to Eva Guidarini of the Harvard Institute of Politics, which studies young voters.

The organization Rock the Vote, which was established in 1989 to engage young voters through music stars like Madonna, continues its efforts with a modernized approach. The group's latest video message features rapper Lil Jon.

Historically, young voter participation among millennials had been on the rise, with a peak of 52% in 2008. However, in 2012, the turnout among voters aged 18 to 29 dropped to 45%. Additionally, the percentage of young voters who were registered to vote also decreased after 2008, according to the Pew Research Center. By 2012, it reached 50%, the lowest number recorded by Pew since 1996.

Some attribute the drop in young voter turnout to the disillusionment with the political process. Jacob Bell, a 20-year-old student at the University of Maryland, stated, "I can pull up Facebook in front of me and see five different articles about the next Senate race, and that's something that I know my mom's generation never had."

Ashley Spillane, the president of Rock the Vote, believes that the low turnout among young voters is a result of the current political climate. "Politics right now is really disheartening," she said. "I think it's why you see in the polls that young people are not affiliating with political parties."

However, Spillane also emphasized that millennials are passionate about issues that matter to them and are actively involved in their communities. "They are getting involved at a local level. They are creating startups. They are volunteering with local organizations. They are looking to take problems on in real time and fix them," she said.

The challenge for Rock the Vote is reaching a generation that is politically aware but disillusioned with the current political climate. Eva Guidarini expressed concern about a generation of voters being turned off by politics as they are forming their political identities, but she remains hopeful. "I think that if politics starts to change in a direction that I think all of America wants to see it change — not just young people — then you'll see young people get back in the game," she said.

The question remains whether politics will improve unless a new generation gets more involved and pushes for change. The use of the hashtag #newboom on social media is encouraged to join the conversation about millennial voters.

Title: Sanders Suspends Lawsuit Against DNC, Maintains Case Open for Future Action

Article:

Sen. Bernard Sanders, an independent running for the Democratic National Committee's (DNC) presidential nomination, has announced that he will not actively pursue his lawsuit against the DNC over access to voter data files, but has kept the case open as a precautionary measure. The decision comes after DNC Chairwoman Debbie Wasserman Schultz suspended Sanders' access to the party's voter files last month, alleging that his staff had exploited a computer breakdown to access rival presidential candidate Hillary Clinton's files on the DNC's system.

Sanders apologized for his staff's behavior and initiated an investigation into the wrongdoing. However, he argued that Ms. Wasserman Schultz had no authority to immediately suspend his own access, which is essential for his campaign to develop a strategy for targeting voters in the primaries and caucuses.

The lawsuit, filed by Sanders, claimed that the DNC had breached his contract for data access. After the lawsuit, Ms. Wasserman Schultz relented. The case had been inactive, with Sanders never serving papers on the DNC, until Judge Tanya S. Chutkan demanded clarity on Sanders' intentions earlier this week.

Garvey Schubert Barer, Sanders' lawyer, stated that the parties are engaged in discussions and are cooperating to resolve the litigation. The lawyer added that, "The parties are engaged in discussions and are continuing in their cooperative efforts to resolve the pending litigation. In light of these efforts, plaintiff does not intend to serve defendant at this time. However, if the parties are unable to resolve this dispute, plaintiff reserves the right to serve defendant before the expiration of the time limit for service."

The Federal Rules of Civil Procedure grant Sanders up to 90 days to serve notice of his complaint on the DNC. Clinton's campaign has claimed to have been victimized by Sanders, but Sanders has countered that he had alerted the DNC to problems with its system security earlier last year, and the party had ignored him.

Liberal activists have criticized Ms. Wasserman Schultz for suspending Sanders' access to the voter files, arguing that it could potentially favor Clinton in the primaries.

Title: Jeb Bush Calls for Stronger U.S. Response to Russian Aggression in Ukraine

Article:

In a speech delivered in Berlin on Tuesday, former Governor Jeb Bush, a potential Republican presidential candidate, called on Russian President Vladimir Putin to cease his actions in Ukraine and Eastern Europe. Bush stated that if elected president, the United States would take a harder line on Russian aggression.

Bush emphasized the importance of respecting the sovereignty of all neighbors and questioned the effectiveness of allowing Russia to act without consequences. He stated, "Our alliance, our solidarity, and our actions are essential if we want to preserve the fundamental principles of our international order... an order that free nations have sacrificed so much to build."

The Russian president has denied sending troops into Ukraine, but satellite images suggest otherwise. Bush accused Putin of supporting separatists in their battle against pro-independence forces and urged him to halt his efforts to reintegrate Ukraine into the Russian sphere of influence.

Bush expressed concern over the unfolding situation in Ukraine, stating, "Who will say otherwise, as we watch the fate of Ukraine, slowly unfold in tragedy? Ukraine, a sovereign European nation, must be permitted to choose its own path."

Bush supports economic sanctions on Russia and has advocated for delivering some U.S. military equipment to Ukraine. His remarks follow President Obama's comments made on Monday during his visit to the G-7 in Krün, Germany, where Obama also expressed support for continuing sanctions and urged Putin to seek compromise.

Meanwhile, the Kremlin has vowed to uphold a Cold War-era nuclear treaty, and Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov stated that Russia has no intention of breaking the treaty. The U.S. has accused Russia of testing a ground-launched cruise missile in violation of the treaty, while Russia has countered that some elements of the U.S. missile defense shield violate the same treaty.

During his speech, Bush also addressed economic issues, emphasizing the importance of economic freedom and the need for modern, transparent, and fair standards and rules in global markets. He also spoke about the Trans-Atlantic Trade and Investment Partnership and the relevance of the U.S.-European alliance.

Bush is scheduled to meet with German Chancellor Angela Merkel on Tuesday at the conference of the economic council of the Christian Democratic Union, the political party Merkel leads. Both leaders are delivering speeches at the event.

Title: Tech Giants Face Intense Scrutiny on Capitol Hill, Remain Unscathed in Stock Market

Article:

Tech giants Facebook, Alphabet (Google), Apple, and Amazon faced a day of intense scrutiny on Capitol Hill this week, with the industry's Big Four being placed under the microscope of three different Congressional hearings. Despite the harsh criticism and accusations of anti-conservative bias on Alphabet's Google search and concerns about Facebook's proposed digital currency, the companies' stocks remained largely unchanged, underscoring their continued market dominance and strong financial performance.

Facebook's stock (FB) was flat at $203.84, Alphabet's GOOGL and GOOG shares were up slightly to $1,153.46, Apple's AAPL stock was flat at $204.50, and Amazon's AMZN stock was down 0.5% to $2,007.90. The quartet has a cumulative market valuation of over $3 trillion.

While the government, consumers, and privacy advocates may be concerned about the influence of Big Tech in their lives, investors do not seem to share these concerns. Shebly Seyrafi, an analyst who covers Facebook at FBN Securities, stated in a phone interview that as long as advertisers get high returns on Facebook, which is the largest platform in town, there is no need to look elsewhere. He assessed the one-year high in Facebook's stock price, stating that an antitrust investigation will take years, and legislation a while. Facebook is in no immediate trouble, according to Seyrafi.

Wedbush Securities analyst Dan Ives believes the current clash between the Beltway and Big Tech is "more bark than bite" that will likely result in tweaks to business models and potential fines rather than forced company breakups. Ives also believes the clash could act as a catalyst for "more technology innovation/diversification over the coming years for these titans," as the DoJ case against Microsoft proved to be.

However, representatives from all four companies took their share of criticism during the hearings, with Facebook's digital currency project, called Libra, facing withering skepticism over regulatory and trust issues. Apple, Amazon, and Google also faced criticism for user-data transgressions or restrictive business practices. Apple is being challenged in a class-action lawsuit over its management of its App Store, and Google withstood a barrage of criticism from Sen. Ted Cruz (R-Texas) during the Senate Judiciary subcommittee hearing on "Google and Censorship through Search Engines."

Sen. Richard Blumenthal (D-Conn.) stated in the Google-search hearing, "The hourglass has run out on regulation and tech. Big Tech is in a perfect storm." Karan Bhatia, Google's vice president of public policy and a former senior official in the George W. Bush administration, was also criticized by Sen. Josh Hawley (R-Mo.) for the company's business dealings in China. Amazon was repeatedly questioned on its growing impact in the retail industry and its impact on smaller merchants.

The hearings made for an unrelenting assault on companies that rarely find themselves in defensive postures. However, they might get used to the feeling, if Tuesday was any indication. And more is on the horizon, with potential antitrust investigations of all four companies by either the Department of Justice or Federal Trade Commission.

Stanford law professor Doug Melamed told ███, "Everybody wants to take a swipe at Big Tech these days. But the stock market seems to be ignoring all that is happening out of Washington, except for the Fed."

Title: President Obama's Perceived Failures: A Recap of His Self-Assessed Shortcomings

Article:

In a series of interviews this year, President Barack Obama has been asked about his biggest failure during his first term and has provided three different answers. The president admitted that he has not been successful in establishing a consistent focus on problem-solving and bipartisan cooperation, as he initially intended.

During an interview with Univision's Jorge Ramos, Obama identified the lack of comprehensive immigration reform as his most significant failure. He emphasized that this issue would continue to be a priority for his administration.

In a conversation with CBS News' Charlie Rose, Obama stated that his mistake during the first couple of years of his term was thinking that the presidency was solely about getting policy right. He acknowledged that the role also requires telling a story that instills unity, purpose, and optimism among the American people, particularly during challenging economic times.

In summary, President Obama's self-assessed "biggest" failures are failing to tell enough stories, not changing the tone in Washington, and not achieving comprehensive immigration reform (despite having a supermajority of Democrats during his first two years in office). The president did not mention the economy or job creation as his biggest failures.

It is worth noting that President Obama has a reputation for being inconsistent, as he has given different answers about his biggest failure, claimed not to have raised taxes, and described nearly everything as a top priority.

Title: American Political Polarization Reaches Record High, Shaping 2016 Presidential Race

Article:

According to a report by the Pew Research Centre, American voters are more polarized than ever, with the number of Americans expressing consistently conservative or liberal opinions having doubled over the past two decades. This increasing level of partisanship has become evident in various ways, including the rise of the Tea Party, a grassroots conservative movement, and the government shutdown of 2013.

The polarization is particularly noticeable in the campaign platforms and actions of both the Republican and Democratic presidential candidates. For instance, Republican candidate Mike Huckabee suggested using the American military to prevent women from getting abortions, an issue that is generally considered controversial in the general election. On the left, Bernie Sanders, a self-proclaimed democratic socialist, is gaining traction and is trailing behind Democratic front-runner Hillary Clinton in many political polls.

The rise of partisan politics is attributed to the fact that these political divisions are greatest among those who are more politically active. The Pew Research Report states that the majority of Americans do not have uniformly conservative or liberal views, but the most ideologically oriented and politically rancorous Americans make their voices heard through greater participation in every stage of the political process.

The 2008 recession, which coincided with other issues such as the need to deal with the effects of climate change and the US losing its position as the dominant geo-political entity on the world stage, has motivated many Americans, especially those who were most affected, to push for political change in all directions. The emergence of increasing partisanship and the vocal minorities behind it could be seen as the resurgence of political experimentation in a time of great uncertainty.

In addition to candidates polarizing their party's basic platform, there are also those who are addressing issues generally considered peripheral to the party's concern or opposed to the basic principles of their party. This is best exemplified by 2008 presidential candidate Ron Paul, whose libertarian principles brought him into conflict with fellow Republicans on numerous occasions. The popularity of such "mixed" platforms, that are not generically conservative or liberal, has ironically increased in tandem with the increased polarization of American politics. The interest in more nontraditional and innovative politics can also be seen in the increased interest in US third parties. According to a recent Gallup poll, six to ten Americans now believe a third party is needed. During the 2012 election, the Free and Equal Elections Foundation sponsored a televised third party presidential debate in protest of their exclusion from mainstream political debates.

The US may be primed for dramatic political change that goes beyond the mere polarization or radicalization of basic party principles. The unbridled economic growth and stability of the 1990s and early 2000s have dissipated, and Americans are striving to reconcile themselves with that fact. This polarization of American politics could be seen as giving way to a widening of the ideological spectrum, which can be seen through the increasing popularity of libertarian platforms within the Republican Party and growing interest in US third parties. Hopefully, these misfit candidates or new political parties will emerge and possibly fill the gap between the partisan extremes.

Title: Michelle Snyder, Chief Operating Officer of Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services, Retires

Article:

Michelle Snyder, the Chief Operating Officer (COO) at the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS), is retiring at the end of 2013, according to a statement by CMS Administrator Marilyn Tavenner on Monday. Snyder oversaw the development and debut of HealthCare.gov, the federal Obamacare website that experienced significant issues in October and November before its turnaround by early December.

Tavenner announced Snyder's retirement, stating, "I regret to announce that, after 41 years of outstanding public service, CMS Chief Operating Officer Michelle Snyder is retiring at the end of 2013." Tavenner further expressed her appreciation for Snyder's contributions, acknowledging her as a "good friend and a key member of the agency’s leadership team."

Snyder had initially planned to retire at the end of 2012, but she chose to stay on to assist with the challenges facing CMS in 2013. Tim Love, Snyder's deputy, will serve as the acting COO.

Snyder's departure marks the second high-level exit from CMS since the problematic debut of the Obamacare insurance markets on October 1, 2013. The agency's chief information officer, Tony Trenkle, left in November for a position in the private sector.

In November, Health and Human Services Secretary Kathleen Sebelius identified Snyder as a key person responsible for the HealthCare.gov project.

Rep. Darrell Issa, California Republican and chairman of the House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform, offered some parting remarks for Snyder, stating that she approved the launch of the troubled Obamacare website despite security concerns. Issa claimed that documents and interviews indicated Snyder bypassed the recommendation of CMS' top security expert who suggested delaying the launch of HealthCare.gov due to serious security vulnerabilities resulting from inadequate security testing. Issa added that Americans seeking health insurance are left to bear the risk of a website that is still a work in progress due to the "cult-like commitment" of officials to launching on October 1, 2013.

Title: New Health Law Offers Assistance to Those with Employer-Provided Insurance

Article:

The Affordable Care Act, often associated with providing health insurance to the uninsured, could also offer assistance to individuals and families with employer-provided insurance. This is particularly relevant for those facing high premiums or inadequate coverage.

Rori Callaway and her family, residents of Dallas, experienced a significant increase in their health insurance premiums from their public school teaching job. The family's monthly premium for the cheapest plan available during open enrollment is now $760, a 30% increase.

The law provides new protections for those with employer-provided health insurance. It could help families like the Callaways, who may find relief through state and federally run health insurance exchanges, especially if their plans are deemed unaffordable.

However, the path to relief is complex due to a glitch in the law's wording. The law refers only to the portion an individual's premium contributes to the household income, not the family's premium. This was intended to prevent people from leaving workplace plans for subsidized coverage through the exchanges. However, it may result in some families going without affordable coverage.

The individual's premium is not supposed to exceed 9.5% of the household income. The Callaways' family premium is now almost double that.

Families like the Callaways could still shop on the new exchanges but would not be eligible for subsidies or tax credits, as these are only available to those who cannot afford coverage. If the plans become unaffordable for the first time outside of a typical fall-to-fall plan year, they may qualify for a special enrollment opportunity.

For help calculating whether a policy would be considered affordable under the law, consult your state exchange or call one of the navigators for assistance. Get linked to your state's exchange and search for navigators there at the federal government's HealthCare.gov.

Here are other ways the plans you buy during open enrollment will be different:

1. Essential benefits: Everyone's plan, whether obtained on the exchanges or through an employer, must cover certain essential health benefits, including maternity care, prescription drugs, in-patient hospital care, and lab services.

2. Preventive health care: Doctor or lab visits for procedures such as mammograms, colonoscopies, and blood pressure screening have to be covered in full now, with no co-pays and no cost-sharing allowed.

3. Pre-existing conditions: People with pre-existing conditions trying to buy insurance individually have, until now, sometimes been denied coverage. Those with insurance provided by their employers are sometimes subject to waiting periods that can be as long as 12 months. Employees can no longer be subject to any pre-existing condition waiting period.

4. Out of your pocket: Sometimes premiums go up at open enrollment time, but often it's also your co-payments and maximum out-of-pocket expenses. So even if you did not get good news in your open enrollment package about the money you must spend before insurance kicks in, there's a related perk in the law. Your co-payments now count toward your maximum out-of-pocket expenses, so you'll get there faster in 2014.

Rori Callaway, a freelance writer who also makes notebooks and journals she sells online, may look for seasonal retail work this holiday season. The family is also going to start selling some of their household items on Craigslist to make ends meet and pay up to the $4,800 deductible on their plan.

"The timing is certainly unfortunate," Callaway says of her new plan that took effect a month before the exchanges open. "Surely there will be better options for our family out there with the new health care exchanges. I'm looking for that silver lining."

Title: Cross-Party MPs Introduce Bill to Prevent No-Deal Brexit

Article:

A cross-party group of Members of Parliament (MPs) has presented a bill aimed at preventing a no-deal Brexit in ten days. If passed into law, the bill would require the Prime Minister to request an extension of Article 50, the European Union (EU) exit clause, beyond the current April 12 deadline. Labour MP Yvette Cooper introduced the bill, which supporters hope can pass through the House of Commons in a single day.

The Prime Minister is expected to make a statement shortly. The development comes after the cabinet, which remains divided over Brexit, met for eight hours at 10 Downing Street. The BBC's John Pienaar reported that Theresa May's ministers discussed plans to "ramp up" no-deal Brexit preparations and a snap general election was also discussed.

Ms. Cooper's bill would make it UK law for the Prime Minister to request an extension to prevent a no-deal Brexit, but it would be up to the EU to grant it or not. In March, MPs voted against leaving the EU without a deal, but the vote was not legally binding. Meanwhile, the EU's chief negotiator, Michel Barnier, stated that a no-deal Brexit is now more likely but can still be avoided.

France's President Emmanuel Macron and Irish Taoiseach Leo Varadkar are meeting in Paris to discuss the impact of Brexit. President Macron told reporters that the EU "cannot be hostage to the political crisis in the UK" and the government must come forward with "credible" reasons for an extension. He suggested these could include an election, second referendum, or alternative proposals for the future relationship, such as a customs union.

Mr. Varadkar stated that the UK is "consumed by Brexit," but the EU should not be. He added that the EU "needs to be open" about any proposals the UK brings, including a longer extension, and they will do what they can to "assist." However, he noted that, as things stand, the UK will leave the EU on April 12 without a deal.

Tory MP Sir Oliver Letwin, who supports Ms. Cooper's bill, said, "This is a last-ditch attempt to prevent our country being exposed to the risks inherent in a no-deal exit. 'We realize this is difficult. But it is definitely worth trying.'" Ms. Cooper stated that the UK is "in a very dangerous situation" and MPs "have a responsibility to make sure we do not end up with a catastrophic no-deal Brexit."

Normally, the government chooses which bills to present to Parliament in order for them to become law. However, due to a vote by MPs, backbenchers will be in charge of business in the Commons on Wednesday. This gives backbenchers the opportunity to table their own bills, such as this one from Yvette Cooper. A copy of the bill shows that they want to push it through the Commons in one day. As the backbenchers will be in charge, they will also be able to vote to set aside more time on another day, if they need to complete the process or hold further indicative votes.

However, the bill would also have to be agreed by the House of Lords and receive Royal Assent before it becomes law, which, if the Commons agrees it on Wednesday, could happen as soon as Thursday. Brexiteer Tory Sir Bill Cash stated that trying to go through these stages in one day made it a "reprehensible procedure." However, Speaker John Bercow said that, while it was "an unusual state of affairs," it was "not as unprecedented as he supposes" - citing recent bills on Northern Ireland that have been passed at the same speed.

In the latest round of indicative votes on Monday, MPs voted on four alternatives to the Prime Minister's withdrawal deal, but none gained a majority. MPs rejected a customs union with the EU by three votes. A motion for another referendum got the most votes in favor, but still lost. The votes were not legally binding, but they had been billed as the moment when Parliament might finally compromise.

Independent MP Chris Leslie tweeted that MPs would be seeking more time for indicative votes to take place on Monday. Liberal Democrat MP Norman Lamb stated he is considering resigning the whip after his party refused to back proposals for a customs union and Common Market 2.0 on Monday. He told ███, "If you are seen to be unreasonable, not engaging to find solutions, I don't think it is very attractive to the people."

Earlier, Mr. Barnier stated, "No deal was never our desire or intended scenario, but the EU 27 is now prepared. It becomes day after day more likely." Mrs. May's plan for the UK's departure has been rejected by MPs three times. Last week, Parliament took control of the process away from the government in order to hold a series of votes designed to find an alternative way forward. Eight options were put to MPs, but none was able to command a majority, and on Monday night, a whittled-down four were rejected too.

A five-hour cabinet meeting on Wednesday, April 3: Potentially another round of indicative votes, and Yvette Cooper's bill to be debated.
Thursday, April 4: Potentially another round of indicative votes, and Yvette Cooper's bill to be debated; Theresa May could bring her withdrawal deal back to Parliament for a fourth vote, while MPs could also vote on Ms. Cooper's bill.
Wednesday, April 10: Emergency summit of EU leaders to consider any UK request for further extension.
Friday, April 12: Brexit day, if the UK does not seek or the EU does not grant further delay.
European Parliamentary elections: 23-26 May.
End of Article.

Title: Rolling Stone's "A Rape on Campus" Story Faces Questions, Highlighting Ethical Responsibilities in Reporting Traumatic Events

Article:

The Rolling Stone magazine's high-profile story titled "A Rape on Campus" is facing scrutiny following serious questions about the accuracy of a horrifying alleged gang-rape incident that served as the story's central example.

The story, which began with a narrative from a young woman identified only as "Jackie," detailed a gang rape that she claimed occurred at a fraternity party. In a statement today, Rolling Stone admitted "discrepancies" in Jackie's account and concluded that their trust in her was misplaced.

This story should serve as a reminder of the challenges in accurately reporting on traumatic events and the heightened ethical responsibilities that fall on journalists who do so.

According to the Washington Post, the fraternity where Jackie said the attack took place did not host a party on the night Jackie claimed she was raped, and no member of the house fits Jackie's description of her assailant.

Reporter Sabrina Rubin Erdely did not fully verify the details of Jackie's story before publishing it or contact the alleged perpetrators involved. The Washington Post's report also states that the fraternity in question was not active during the time the alleged incident occurred.

Erdely claimed she was trying to protect Jackie, who feared retribution if Rolling Stone contacted her attackers. However, failing to ensure the story's accuracy before exposing it to public scrutiny did not protect Jackie; it left her vulnerable.

The problem, as the author of this article, a former lawyer who worked with trauma victims, points out, is not that people are making up stories, but that the details that seem important to journalists may not matter to the traumatized individuals.

In severe cases, post-traumatic stress disorder can cause memory loss or make the true details of stories too painful to recount. In less severe cases, people's stories often contain errors or omissions.

Before I had experience working with trauma victims, I would have scoffed at the idea that anyone could make such mistakes. But now I can easily believe it. By failing to check Jackie's story, Rolling Stone and Erdely were not protecting her; they were leaving her vulnerable. That was wrong and irresponsible, not just toward the alleged perpetrators, but toward their readers and Jackie herself.

It is unclear at this time whether any part of Jackie's story is true. The author did not speak to Jackie. It is possible that the entire story is a lie, or that some parts are true but Jackie intentionally changed some details for reasons of her own. If so, then she bears responsibility for that decision. However, it also seems possible that Jackie could be in a similar situation as the people the author worked with in the past, who were diagnosed with post-traumatic stress disorder, which can affect memory and make it more difficult to retell a story accurately.

This incident underscores the importance of ethical journalism, particularly when reporting on traumatic events. Journalists have a responsibility to verify the details of a story before publishing it, to protect the individuals involved and maintain the credibility of their reporting.

Title: Avaaz Launches Global Campaign to Mobilize U.S. Voters Abroad Ahead of Election

Article:

A global campaign, dubbed the "October surprise that will end Trump," has been launched in an attempt to mobilize a "secret swing state" of more than 8 million mostly unregistered "global citizens" and "progressive" Americans living abroad to vote in the U.S. election. The initiative was unveiled in London, United Kingdom, on Wednesday by Avaaz, a registered U.S. charity and one of the world's largest and most powerful activist groups.

Campaigners, who were heard chanting "Don't Vote Trump" and "Vote for Hillary" during the demonstration, claim that the untapped voting block of Americans abroad is more likely to be "progressive" due to their educational backgrounds and political leanings. Avaaz points out that 56% of U.S. citizens living in the UK have master's degrees and overwhelmingly donated to Democratic candidates in the last three presidential primaries.

The campaign, which has been framed as anti-Trump, has been met with controversy as it is illegal for registered U.S. charities to work with or for presidential candidates. A spokeswoman for Avaaz denied any connection to the Hillary campaign when questioned. However, campaigners with Avaaz were recorded shouting "Vote for Hillary" during the demonstration.

Avaaz claims to have enlisted over 30 million people worldwide to share a new tool that enables left-wing American expats to register to vote quickly and en masse. The 8 million Americans abroad almost never vote, and Avaaz argues that the new tool can help increase voter turnout.

"Avaaz has created the world's first, global, citizen's get-out-the-vote drive," said Meredith Alexander, the Campaigns Director for Avaaz. "The more people that share it on Facebook, the more Americans abroad will see it, and the more we will be able to stop the global threat of Trump."

The group chose London for the launch as the UK has the "largest concentration of US expats outside of North America." At the event, several Americans registered to vote before the media to prove how easy it is with Avaaz's new tool.

"For months, the world has sat on the sidelines, horrified by Trump's hate. Now, global citizens have a way to fight back," said Emma Ruby-Sachs, Deputy Director of Avaaz.

Avaaz's website encourages people to email potential U.S. voters in other countries, giving them a template that reads: "8 million Americans abroad could defeat Trump... if they vote! I wanted to make sure you saw this new overseas registration tool that makes voting dead-easy. It literally takes a few minutes : )"

The official campaign makes no mention of other presidential candidates and is framed as simply anti-Trump. Banners on the bus today insisted the campaign is "not authorized by any candidate or candidate office" and linked to Avaaz.org/VoteAbroad, an unintentionally close sound to 'Voter Fraud,' an issue which campaigners will be keen to avoid discussion of.

"We are a charity in the United States, we are governed by American law, and we are not allowed to coordinate with any candidate," said Ms. Alexander. "But, we are absolutely allowed to advocate for our position."

Her argument was that Avaaz was not working for Hillary, which would be illegal, but was instead dedicated to issues like climate change and opposing nuclear weapons, and therefore must oppose Mr. Trump and his policies, which implicitly means backing Hillary.

Avaaz launched in 2007 to agitate for various left-wing causes including animal rights and mass migration. They organized the biggest climate change march in the UK's history and have been described by the Guardian as "the globe's largest and most powerful online activist network."

They claim to be "independent and accountable" and "wholly member-funded." However, Avaaz was formed by the merger of several establishment groups including MoveOn.org, a group that received $1.46 million from George Soros during the 2004 election cycle, and Res Publica, which has received grants totalling $250,000 from the liberal billionaire's Open Society group.

Furthermore, Avaaz co-founder Ricken Patel has worked for, either directly or as a consultant, numerous globalist foundations and corporations such as the Rockefeller Foundation and the Gates Foundation. According to POLITICO, Mr. Soros has committed around $25 million to assisting Hillary Clinton and Democratic Party causes at this election cycle.

Avaaz also campaigned against the UK leaving the European Union under the banner: "Choose Love, Vote Remain." Meredith Alexander said, "Avaaz is just as strongly in support of trying to stop Brexit as we are of trying to stop Trump" and that it is "part of the same challenge" of suppressing populist, anti-globalist movements.

"You have forces of division that are rising in a number of countries, whether it's here with Brexit... the Austrian presidential election, or the American presidential election. The threats that we are facing right now tend to be threats that need global coordination," she said, mentioning the "refugee crisis" and the "climate crisis."

Ms. Alexander also praised London's Muslim Mayor, Sadiq Khan, for touring America to give his endorsement to Hillary Clinton. She said, "I absolutely hope that he has an effect."

Title: Brazil's Jair Bolsonaro Declared Winner of Presidential Election

Article:

Brazil's Supreme Electoral Tribunal announced on Sunday that Jair Bolsonaro, a controversial congressman known for his right-wing positions and sometimes extreme views, has won the country's presidential election. With 96 percent of ballots counted, Bolsonaro secured 55.5 percent of the votes, while leftist Fernando Haddad of the Workers' Party received 44.5 percent.

Bolsonaro, who has a 27-year career in Congress, positioned himself as a political outsider but gained prominence by mixing tough, often violent rhetoric with right-wing positions. His campaign initially gained traction with promises to address violent crime in a country that leads the world in homicides. However, his vows to loosen gun laws and give police a freer hand to use force against suspects have raised concerns about a potential bloody crackdown and erosion of civil rights.

Bolsonaro's campaign also won over much of the business community with promises of enacting market-friendly reforms that would reduce the size of the Brazilian state, including cutting ministries and privatizing state companies.

In a highly unusual move, the chief justice of the Supreme Court, Jose Dias Toffoli, read out part of the Constitution to reporters after he voted, emphasizing the need for the future president to respect institutions, democracy, the rule of law, the judiciary branch, the national Congress, and the legislative branch.

Voters in Sunday's runoff election appeared to look past warnings that Bolsonaro could erode democracy and embraced a chance for radical change after years of turmoil. Supporters of Bolsonaro celebrated in cities like Rio de Janeiro and Sao Paulo, with fireworks, car horns, and crowds gathering with banners and flags. Riot police separated supporters of Bolsonaro and those of his leftist rival Haddad when they briefly scuffled in Sao Paulo.

Bolsonaro went into the election the clear front-runner after getting 46 percent of the votes to Haddad's 29 percent in the first round of the election on October 7. After opinion polls in recent weeks had Bolsonaro leading by as much as 18 percentage points, the race had tightened in recent days, but Haddad was unable to make up the difference.

"I'm not crazy about Bolsonaro. But he is our way to keep the Workers' Party out of office," said Rafaela Rosa, a 32-year-old teacher, after voting Sunday in Sao Paulo. "We have had enough corruption and now we need to clean up."

Title: Akin Huddles with Conservative Leaders in Tampa as He Weighs Senate Bid Amidst Pressure

Article:

Representative Todd Akin (R-MO) is currently in Tampa, Florida, where he is meeting with top conservative activists at the Council For National Policy (CNP) summit to discuss his embattled Senate bid. The meetings come as Akin faces pressure from Republican heavyweights in Washington to abandon his campaign following his controversial comments about rape and pregnancy.

Akin spent Wednesday night and Thursday in a series of private meetings at the two-day conference, which is being held before next week's Republican National Convention in Tampa. The congressman was scheduled to attend the conference before his comments about "legitimate rape" caused a stir in the Republican Party and shifted the focus of the presidential race towards the divisive social issue of abortion.

Multiple sources at the CNP conference told CNN that Akin is being encouraged by leading figures in the conservative movement to remain in the Senate race despite the pressure from the Republican establishment. However, several activists and conservative thought leaders acknowledged the long odds Akin faces, with one person attending the summit saying many were "spooked" by a poll showing Akin trailing Democratic Sen. Claire McCaskill by 10 points.

A source close to Akin told CNN that the congressman is "keeping an open ear to those people who are pushing him or questioning him on viability." However, the source stressed that Akin is "getting a ton of support" from conservatives at the conference.

Several conservatives attending the conference expressed resentment at the aggressive and heavy-handed treatment of Akin by Republican leaders in Washington who have pressured him to quit the Missouri race. At least two people at the conference named Karl Rove, a co-founder of the powerful 527 group American Crossroads, as a specific source of frustration.

Participants in Thursday's meetings said support for Akin was not universal among conservatives. Richard Land, president of the Ethics & Religious Liberty Commission at the Southern Baptist Convention, said that while Akin misspoke and has been treated "unfairly," he should still drop out.

Akin addressed a small dinner on Wednesday night but made no direct mention of the scandal engulfing his campaign, two sources present for that session told CNN. The congressman, who has deep ties to the Christian right, is also hosting an invitation-only reception on Thursday evening.

Much of the discussion about the future of Akin's campaign is taking place during face-to-face meetings with top leaders in the conservative movement attending the CNP summit. Ralph Reed, the founder of the Faith and Freedom Coalition, was among those who spoke privately with Akin on Thursday. Reed declined to reveal details of their conversation but made plain his sympathy for Akin: "As a general rule, I have devoted my career to encouraging men and women of faith to run for office. I don't encourage men and women of faith not to run."

Along with Land and Reed, the conference was attended by Eagle Forum founder Phyllis Schlafly, direct mail specialist Richard Viguerie, National Rifle Association Chairman David Keene, former United Nations Ambassador John Bolton, pollster Kellyanne Conway, Susan B. Anthony List President Marjorie Dannenfelser, Americans United For Life founder Charmaine Yoest, former Ohio Secretary of State Ken Blackwell, and many others.

Also present were a fleet of talk radio hosts, communications consultants, school reform activists, and several Republican political operatives. Little is known about the CNP, aside from a website which describes its members as "the country's most influential conservative leaders in business, government, politics, and religion." New members must be vouched for and invited by current ones. One person described CNP meetings as "media free zones" where conservatives can network and strategize freely.

Even members of the group who spoke to CNN anonymously were hesitant to discuss the group or anything related to the Akin controversy. "I can't talk about what they talk about here, it's all confidential," said one CNP participant. "Sorry."

When Akin was approached by a CNN camera while sitting on a veranda Thursday outside the hotel, an aide quickly moved to block the photographer's shot. Politico first reported Akin's trip to Tampa on Wednesday to attend the conference, but the details of Akin's whereabouts and the details of his meetings were not known until Thursday.

Title: A Dozen Notable Achievements of 2016

Article:

In the final days of 2016, it is worth acknowledging a dozen significant achievements that occurred throughout the year.

1. Minimum wage increases: Minimum wage-earning Americans in 22 jurisdictions, including 20 states and the District of Columbia, received a wage boost in 2017. New York City is set to reach a minimum wage of $15 by 2019, with the rest of the state on a path to that level in the future. Washington state raised its minimum wage to $11 an hour as of January 1, while Arizona increased it to $10 an hour. California is raising its minimum wage by 50 cents in 2017 and again in 2018, and then by a dollar a year through 2022 to reach $15 an hour.

2. Reproductive rights victory: In a 5-3 decision, the U.S. Supreme Court ruled in favor of reproductive rights in the case of Whole Women's Health v. Hellerstedt. The Court found that Texas laws requiring doctors at clinics providing abortions to have admitting privileges at hospitals within 30 miles and that the clinics have facilities equal to a mini-hospital constituted an undue burden on abortion access and violated the Constitution.

3. Harriet Tubman on the $20 bill: Thanks to activist efforts, the Treasury will be replacing Andrew Jackson with Harriet Tubman on the $20 bill.

4. Increase in wild tiger population: For the first time in a century, the number of tigers in the wild increased. The count is now 3,820 compared with 3,200 in 2010.

5. Malaria eradication in Sri Lanka: Sri Lanka's bold 2009 plan to wipe out malaria worked. The country is now malaria-free.

6. Lower U.S. unemployment rate: The U.S. unemployment rate fell to 4.6 percent, the lowest level in nine years.

7. Colombia peace agreement: After 50 years of civil war, the Colombian government and FARC guerrillas signed a peace agreement.

8. Paris climate agreement: The Paris climate agreement came into force. It took 25 years to get a solid agreement, but in October, 55 countries representing 58.85 percent of all greenhouse gas emissions ratified the Paris pact with the goal of cutting those emissions quickly and deeply enough to keep the world's average temperature from rising more than 3.6° Fahrenheit by the turn of the century.

9. Ebola vaccine: Researchers developed a vaccine against ebola that is 100 percent effective.

10. Ending female genital mutilation: 300 West African communities pledged to end female genital mutilation.

11. Olympic success for U.S. gymnasts: U.S. gymnasts Simone Biles, Aly Raisman, Gabby Douglas, Laurie Hernandez, and Madison Kocian won a record nine Olympic medals among them.

12. Criticism of Kent Hovind: In 2005, Ken Ham of the Young Earth Creationist organization Answers in Genesis (AiG) published a point-by-point critique of Kent Hovind, warning that fellow creationists should avoid using Hovind's arguments as they are riddled with errors and/or dishonesty. Ham's organization is known for building a museum that depicts men and women living side by side with dinosaurs 6,000 years ago and for constructing large dioramas of the Ark.

Title: Tennessee School District Reviews Allegations of Unconstitutional Mentoring Program

Article:

Officials from the Kingsport City Schools in Tennessee are reviewing allegations by the Freedom From Religion Foundation (FFRF) that their mentoring program, in partnership with a local church, is unconstitutional. The FFRF, a group that identifies its members as "free-thinkers" (atheists and agnostics), claims in a letter to the school district that the mentoring program with Christ Fellowship Church impermissibly advances religion and that the district "cannot allow its schools to be used as recruiting grounds for churches."

The FFRF does not cite a specific incident in the warning letter where a mentor has tried to proselytize a student. However, it complains that the program uses church personnel to interact with students during school hours. The group states, "Religious organizations should never be allowed access to such young public school children."

Joe Gervais, a mentor from Christ Fellowship Church at Kingsport's John Adams Elementary School, told a School Board meeting that mentors spend 45 minutes to an hour each week with assigned students, often eating breakfast or lunch with them, as well as playing games or reading to them. Gervais said he asks his student about their day, problems they might be having, life in general, and what's going on at home.

School superintendent Jeff Moorhouse described the mentoring program as "just having more hands grabbing an oar" to help students in school and in life. The program involves churches and other groups, according to Moorhouse.

Adams Elementary school counselor Ashley Marlowe reported that fifteen students were mentored under the program at Adams last year and just eight this year due to a shortage of volunteers.

The FFRF's stance is not new, as the group has previously objected to religious practices and traditions in various communities, particularly in the Bible Belt. The group has criticized the governor of Oklahoma for mingling religion and state and objected to prayer before football games, among other issues.

The FFRF's stance raises questions about the role of religion in public schools and the balance between religious freedom and the separation of church and state. The argument brings up the question of whether the FFRF's interpretation of history and the Constitution allows for Christians, acting from faith, to contribute to "social and moral progress" in their communities without leaving their religiously-motivated conviction outside the school premises. The ongoing status of the mentoring program remains uncertain as the school district reviews the allegations.

Title: Radio Host Rush Limbaugh Criticizes Republican Party for Neglecting the Tea Party Movement

Article:

Radio talk show host Rush Limbaugh, in a recent broadcast, criticized the Republican Party for not embracing the Tea Party movement in 2010, a decision he believes cost the party in the 2012 elections. According to Limbaugh, the Tea Party's disenchantment with the Republican Party stems from the issues that sparked their movement in 2010 worsening.

Limbaugh argued that the Republican Party had potential allies in the Tea Party movement but chose to distance themselves. He suggested that the party could have welcomed the Tea Party into their ranks and built a movement around them. However, the Tea Party activists who attended rallies and town hall meetings in 2010 were often vilified by the media and Democrats, causing Republican leadership to distance themselves, Limbaugh claimed.

In Limbaugh's view, the Republican Party establishment perceives the Tea Party as unsophisticated, emotional, and out of control. He suggests that the party leadership aimed to contain the Tea Party rather than embracing them. The Tea Party, on the other hand, understands this, Limbaugh said, and sees the Republican Party as uninterested in their support.

Limbaugh expected the Tea Party to make a significant impact in the 2012 presidential election, but was proven wrong. He attributes this to the Tea Party feeling rejected by the Republican Party. In 2014, there will be no presidential candidate on the ticket, meaning Tea Party members will be less constrained in showing up at the polls, according to Limbaugh. He also believes that the Tea Party will be more motivated due to the desire to prevent President Obama from gaining control over all branches of the government.

Title: Senate's Balanced Budget Proposal Fails to Reach Floor Vote, Signaling Fiscal Responsibility Struggles in Congress

Article:

Sen. Rand Paul's (R-Ky.) balanced budget proposal, known as the "Pennies Plan," failed to reach a floor vote in the Republican-controlled Senate on Monday. The bill fell short during a procedural vote when only 22 senators voted in favor of a cloture motion that would have brought the bill to a final vote. A majority of Republicans and all Democrats voted against proceeding to a floor vote on the bill.

Paul's proposal called for a 2 percent reduction in the federal budget for each of the next five years, aiming to reduce federal spending by about $11 trillion over the next decade. The plan is an adaptation of the so-called "Penny Plan" that Paul has been advocating for several years, though he now argues for an additional penny in cuts for every federal dollar spent to achieve a balanced budget.

The growing gap between federal spending and revenue is a significant concern. During the first seven months of the current fiscal year, which began in October 2018, the federal government ran a $531 billion deficit, marking a 38 percent increase over the same period last year.

According to an analysis from the nonpartisan Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget, about 60 percent of this year's expected deficit is the result of policies—mostly last year's significant increase in spending that surpassed Obama-era budget caps—put in place by current legislators and signed by the current president.

The share of debt held by the public currently stands at about 78 percent of gross domestic product (GDP), a shorthand measure of a country's economic output in a single year. This figure is actually worse, as "debt held by the public" accounts for only $15.8 trillion of the $21 trillion national debt. The remaining debt is held by parts of the federal government, such as the Social Security trust fund.

The Government Accountability Office (GAO) warned in April that America's current fiscal situation is "unsustainable." The GAO estimates that the amount of debt held by the public is on track to surpass the all-time high of 106 percent of GDP within the next 13 to 20 years.

Congress's apparent apathy towards the growing federal debt remains a concern. Paul, in a statement before the vote, criticized both parties for their fiscal irresponsibility. He accused Republicans of supporting balanced budgets in rhetoric but not in action, and Democrats of pushing for excessive spending plans that would exacerbate the national debt or require massive tax increases.

Last year, Paul was able to get the balanced budget proposal to the Senate floor after striking a deal with Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.) during an earlier budget impasse to get the bill on the floor. Paul called that vote a "litmus test for conservatives," and most of them failed it as the measure went down in flames, 76 to 21.

Title: U.S. Imposes Tariffs on Chinese Imports, Affecting Consumer Goods and Retail Sector

Article:

The Trump administration has announced plans to impose tariffs on $200 billion worth of Chinese imports, effective from Monday, with the potential to increase to 25% next year. This move is part of an escalating trade dispute between the world's two largest economies.

The new tariffs, which will primarily target consumer goods, could lead to increased prices for American consumers, according to analysts Seema Shah and Danielle McIntee of Bloomberg Intelligence. They stated in a note on Friday that the new tariffs will negatively impact the retail sector in 2019, with lower-income families being most affected due to potential price increases on everyday items.

The latest round of tariffs follows a 25% duty already imposed on about $50 billion in Chinese goods, which prompted counter-tariffs from Beijing. China has announced plans to retaliate on the U.S.'s $200 billion tariff round by imposing levies on $60 billion of American goods.

The U.S. is monitoring China's retaliation to the $200 billion round of tariffs, but no further announcements have been made regarding additional rounds of duties. Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross previously stated that the tariffs are spread over a wide range of goods, aiming to minimize disruption for American consumers.

The U.S. remains open to trade negotiations with China, but there are currently no scheduled meetings. Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin has extended an invitation to resume trade talks with Chinese counterparts, although China had previously stated they would refuse to negotiate if the Trump administration followed through with the $200 billion tariff round.

Title: White House Discord: Nikki Haley and Larry Kudlow's Remarkable Display of Political Differences

Article:

The recent back-and-forth regarding Russian sanctions and the role of Nikki Haley, the United States Ambassador to the United Nations, has sparked discussions about the Trump administration's foreign policy and the individuals who represent the president. The White House has demonstrated its capacity for bold diplomatic moves, such as the secret meetings between Mike Pompeo, the CIA director and likely future Secretary of State, and North Korean leader Kim Jong-Un. However, the administration's approach to foreign policy has raised questions about communication and coordination.

The controversy began when Haley, during an appearance on "Face the Nation," announced that the administration was preparing to impose sanctions on Russian companies dealing with equipment related to Syrian President Bashar Assad and chemical weapons. These sanctions were expected to be announced by Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin on Monday. However, the sanctions were not imposed as announced, leading to speculation and subsequent discord within the administration.

The New York Times reported that President Trump grew angry when he learned of Haley's statement, leading to a public display of disagreement. Economic adviser Larry Kudlow initially described Haley's statement as a case of confusion, but later apologized for his remarks and acknowledged that there had been a change in policy without Haley being informed.

Haley responded to Kudlow's comments with a statement to Fox News, stating, "With all due respect, I do not get confused." The Washington Post described this as an "extraordinary rebuke of the White House."

The incident has been interpreted as another example of discord within Trump's team regarding foreign affairs. The underlying cause of the disagreement between Haley and the administration remains unclear, with some suggesting it may stem from differing views on Russia and the president's efforts to cultivate good relations with Russian President Vladimir Putin.

The episode has been characterized as a communication breakdown within the White House, with neither Haley nor Kudlow bearing sole responsibility for the misunderstanding. The incident underscores the unpredictable nature of the Trump administration's foreign policy and the challenges of coordinating a diverse team of advisors.

Axios summarized the situation, stating, "These conflicts with top aides—one of them unfolding in the open—show that, in the end, the president will govern how he wants." The future of the Trump administration's foreign policy remains uncertain, with the potential for further disagreements and miscommunications as the administration navigates complex international issues.

Title: Gallup Poll Reveals Record Low Trust in U.S. Media Among Americans

Article:

According to a recent Gallup poll, the trust and confidence Americans have in the media to report news accurately, fully, and fairly has reached an all-time low in the organization's history. Only 32% of respondents expressed a great deal or fair amount of trust in the media, marking an eight-percentage-point decrease from the previous year.

The lowest level of trust was recorded in 1972, when the poll was first conducted, with 72% of Americans expressing trust in the media. However, since then, the sentiment has been steadily declining and has not surpassed a majority level since 2007.

The decline in trust among Republicans has been particularly significant, with only 14% expressing trust, down from 32% a year ago. This represents the lowest level of confidence among Republicans in the past 20 years. Among Democrats, the number stands at 51%, while independents report a trust level of 30%.
