The analyst, Art Swift, suggests that the sharp decline in trust this year may be due to the ongoing election campaign. With many Republican leaders and conservative pundits claiming that Hillary Clinton has received overly positive media attention, while Donald Trump has faced unfair or negative attention, this may be a primary reason for the erosion of trust among Republicans. It is also possible that the lower trust in the media among Republicans is a result of Trump's frequent criticisms of the press.

The poll, which surveyed 1,020 U.S. adults from September 7-11, indicates a continued decline in Americans' trust in the media, raising concerns about the role of the press in a democratic society.

Title: Senators Sanders, Whitehouse, Warren, and Merkley Urge DOJ to Continue Investigation into Fossil Fuel Industry's Climate Denial Tactics

Article:

A group of four Democratic senators, led by Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders, have urged Attorney General Loretta Lynch to continue the Department of Justice's (DOJ) inquiry into the fossil fuel industry's climate denial operations. The request comes a day after Senate Republicans called for the probe to cease.

In a Thursday letter, Senators Sanders, Sheldon Whitehouse, Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts, and Jeff Merkley of Oregon, argued that the DOJ should investigate possible fraud in the fossil fuel industry's climate denial operations. They compared this potential fraud to the tobacco industry's deceptive practices regarding the health risks of smoking.

In March, Ms. Lynch stated that she had referred information on what Mr. Whitehouse described as "the climate denial scheme" to the FBI. Senate Republicans have criticized this effort as an attack on free speech and scientific inquiry.

The Democrats' letter asserts that "fraud is not protected by the First Amendment," and they draw parallels between the tobacco industry and oil-and-gas companies that have been skeptical of catastrophic climate-change predictions. They also reference the DOJ's 2006 civil lawsuit against the tobacco industry, using it as a template for the DOJ's potential investigation into the fossil fuel industry.

Critics have disputed the comparison, arguing that there is more scientific disagreement on the impact of increased carbon dioxide levels in the atmosphere on the climate than there was on the link between smoking and major health problems.

Ms. Lynch stated at a Senate oversight hearing in March that she had referred information to the FBI to determine "whether or not it meets the criteria for what we could take action on." The status of the inquiry remains unclear, as Justice Department spokesman Wyn Hornbuckle declined to comment further on the matter.

In a Wednesday letter, Senate Republicans argued that efforts to prosecute climate-change skeptics constitute a "blatant violation of the First Amendment and an abuse of power that rises to the level of prosecutorial misconduct." The letter was signed by Sens. Mike Lee of Utah, Ted Cruz of Texas, Jeff Sessions of Alabama, David Perdue of Georgia, and David Vitter of Louisiana.

Last week, 13 House Republicans sent letters seeking information from a coalition of state attorneys general, known as AGs United for Clean Power, on their efforts to pursue climate-change skeptics. Two of those attorneys general—New York's Eric Schneiderman and the Virgin Islands' Claude E. Walker—have since issued subpoenas to ExxonMobil. Mr. Walker withdrew last week a subpoena issued to the free-market Competitive Enterprise Institute.

Title: Corey Lewandowski Refuses to Answer Questions Regarding 2017 Oval Office Meeting During House Judiciary Committee Hearing

Corey Lewandowski, a former campaign aide to President Donald Trump, clashed with House Democrats during a public impeachment hearing on Tuesday, refusing to answer questions about a 2017 Oval Office meeting that was detailed in the Mueller report.

In his opening statement, Lewandowski, who is considered close to the White House, criticized the Democrats and former special counsel Robert Mueller's investigation, describing it as "harassment" and alleging that some critics sought to bring down the president.

"Sadly, the country spent over three years and 40 million taxpayer dollars on these investigations. It is now clear the investigation was populated by many Trump haters who had their own agenda — to try and take down a duly elected president of the United States," Lewandowski said.

During the hearing, Chairman Jerrold Nadler (D-N.Y.) sought to question Lewandowski about the 2017 Oval Office meeting in which Trump asked Lewandowski to persuade then-Attorney General Jeff Sessions to reverse his recusal and set new limits on the Mueller probe.

Lewandowski initially insisted that Nadler provide a copy of the Mueller report so that he could follow along with the passages as Democrats read them. He then stated that he does not remember the meeting in question.

The hearing became chaotic as Republicans and Democrats argued over whether the clock should be suspended on Nadler's five minutes of questioning. The GOP members pushed for an adjournment of the panel.

Democrats have stated that they will not accept limitations on Lewandowski's testimony, as he is the committee's first fact witness and is considered part of the president's efforts to block Mueller's probe into possible obstruction. They also criticized the White House for seeking to block his testimony on the grounds that his discussions with Trump fall under executive branch confidentiality interests.

Title: U.S.-China Trade Tensions: A Historical Perspective and Current Developments

Article:

The ongoing trade tensions between the United States and China have been a topic of significant discussion, with President Trump frequently criticizing China's trade practices. He often states that the U.S. has been disadvantaged in trade relations with China for many years, referring to the past four decades during which China has rapidly transformed from a poor, developing country to an economic powerhouse.

China's emergence as a global economic power was rapid and extreme, according to the article, outpacing the world's ability to adapt in some ways, even China's own capacity to manage such growth. The U.S. and other Western nations facilitated much of China's rise through open trade, but have struggled to get China's fundamentally different economic system to adhere to free market rules.

A pivotal moment came in 2001, after 15 years of negotiations, when China joined the World Trade Organization (WTO). This organization sets the rules for free and fair trade between member countries. The U.S. and other countries put numerous demands on China for reforms, and China agreed to lower tariffs and reduce the government's role in business operations. However, China argued, as it still does now, that it should be held to less stringent free trade standards due to its status as a developing country.

China has continued to operate as a centrally planned economy, with the government owning, influencing, or subsidizing major industries, giving them an artificial competitive edge. There are heavy restrictions on foreign investment, and foreign companies are pressured to share their technologies.

In 2001, after China joined the WTO, there was an enormous surge of Chinese exports to countries worldwide, and particularly to the U.S. The U.S. and other countries complained that China was not opening its markets enough and was keeping the value of its currency artificially low to make Chinese exports more attractive.

The Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP), initiated by Bush and signed by Obama, was an attempt to counter China's growing economic power. The TPP was intended to boost trade, support jobs, and establish stronger rules for trade across the Asia-Pacific region. However, President Trump withdrew the U.S. from the TPP on his third day in office.

Trade tensions between the U.S. and China continue to escalate, with both countries imposing tariffs on each other's goods. The article suggests that China sees its economy as strong enough to withstand the U.S.'s tariffs, while the U.S. aims to generate a moment of crisis to force China to reform its economic practices. The future of U.S.-China trade relations remains uncertain.

Title: Marco Rubio's Presidential Campaign Faces Fundraising and Organizational Challenges

Article:

Marco Rubio's presidential campaign has faced setbacks in terms of fundraising and organization, according to a recent analysis of the Florida senator's third-quarter campaign finance report. The campaign has been criticized for inaccurate financial statements and a lack of early-state organization compared to many of its rivals.

Rubio's campaign initially claimed to have more campaign cash in the bank than fellow Floridian Jeb Bush, but it was later revealed that the statement was inaccurate. The campaign also overstated its fundraising for the last quarter, reporting $6 million instead of the actual $5.7 million.

Moreover, Rubio's third-quarter filing revealed a campaign that is out-manned by many of its rivals in the early-voting states. Rubio's staff is primarily based in Washington, with a small umbrella of early-state operatives. This puts Rubio at a disadvantage because he has not invested the time in early-state visits that some of his opponents have.

Operatives in early-voting primary states like Iowa and New Hampshire have noted that Rubio has spent a combined three weeks in these states this year, while New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie, who trails Rubio in the polls, has spent six weeks in New Hampshire alone. A longtime New Hampshire operative stated that Rubio has "missed a lot of opportunities over the year where he could've been here more regularly."

Rubio's cash-on-hand for the primary season is currently $9.7 million, trailing Ben Carson, Sen. Ted Cruz, and Jeb Bush in cash heading into the last three months of 2015. Donald Trump, the frontrunner, has pledged to primarily self-finance his campaign.

Rubio's campaign has set a fundraising target of $15 million for the next quarter, but this is more than double what Rubio raised between the end of June and the end of September. Rubio is also hampered in his hunt for home state dollars by Jeb Bush, who released a bundler list Thursday that is studded with Florida heavyweights.

With primary elections in Iowa, New Hampshire, South Carolina, and Nevada in February, followed by a burst of Southern primaries on March 1 and the do-or-die Florida primary on March 15, Rubio's more vigorous fundraising operation will be necessary.

Rubio allies note that his ambitious fundraising goal is not out of reach. Rubio has had some success in winning over supporters of former Wisconsin Gov. Scott Walker, who dropped out of the race in late September. He has also been aggressively courting some megadonors whose support could make a significant difference due to their political donor networks.

Backers emphasize that there is plenty of time to continue building out a field organization in key states, and that large campaign operations are not always winning operations. Rubio and his aides take pride in the campaign's small staff footprint, with only 54 full-time staffers.

Jeff Sadosky, spokesman for a super PAC backing Rubio, Conservative Solutions, states that Rubio's message and talent at communicating it are undervalued. "The right message coming from the party’s best messenger is as effective a turnout machine as anything you can put together," said Sadosky. "I can also say that Conservative Solutions PAC stands ready to provide the support needed to ensure that Marco’s message is heard by voters in the early states."

In South Carolina, an early state where Rubio has shown signs of strength, his allies remain confident about his prospects. "I would suggest the senator has the most robust operation in South Carolina already," said Mikee Johnson, a Rubio fundraiser and chairman of the state's Chamber of Commerce. "His supporters are... ardent to the point of volunteerism for his effort and for our country. I know this sounds idealistic, but I have seen it first-hand."

Title: Senate Confirms Neil Gorsuch as Supreme Court Justice

Article:

The United States Senate has confirmed President Donald Trump's Supreme Court nominee, Neil Gorsuch, following a contentious 14-month battle for control of the highest court in the nation. The chamber voted 54-45 on Friday to confirm Gorsuch's appointment.

Republicans, who control the Senate, took the unprecedented step this week of changing the chamber's rules to expedite the confirmation process. The battle to appoint a justice to the judicial bench began with the death of Justice Antonin Scalia, a conservative justice, in February 2016. This marked the longest period a seat has remained unfilled on the Supreme Court since the American Civil War in 1862.

During his confirmation hearings, Gorsuch, a 49-year-old judge from the Denver appeals court, proved evasive when questioned on legal matters. However, he has a conservative judicial pedigree and is expected to rule accordingly. Republicans hope Gorsuch will provide a 5-4 majority for the bench's conservative justices.

Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell praised Gorsuch, stating, "He's going to make an incredible addition to the court." In contrast, Senate Democratic leader Chuck Schumer, who led the opposition to Gorsuch, said, "The court is increasingly drifting towards becoming a more pro-corporate court that favors employers, corporations, and special interests over working America."

On Thursday, McConnell invoked a legislative maneuver known as the "nuclear option" when Republicans lacked the 60 votes required to end debate on Gorsuch. The chamber's majority leader effectively dismantled the rulebook after Democrats mounted the first filibuster of such a nominee in half a century.

The confirmation of Gorsuch marks a significant victory for Trump's young presidency. Many of those who voted for him prioritized getting a conservative judge on to America's highest court. "Congratulations to an exceptionally qualified and respected judge," Trump tweeted.

The vacancy on the nine-judge bench had left the justices to pass over many controversial issues, potentially to avoid a 4-4 stalemate. Democrats were left frustrated last year when Republicans refused to consider former President Barack Obama's nominee to the court.

In 2013, Democrats used the "nuclear option" to overturn Republican filibusters against executive branch and judicial nominees for lower courts. However, they left the filibuster in place for Supreme Court nominees. Gorsuch may be sworn in as early as Friday to prepare for the court's next session of oral arguments this month.

Title: Man Arrested for Carrying Assault Rifle in Washington D.C. Pizzeria, Intending to Investigate "Pizzagate" Conspiracy

Article:

A North Carolina man, identified as Edgar Maddison Welch, was arrested in Washington D.C. on Sunday after he entered a popular pizzeria, Comet Ping Pong, armed with an assault rifle, to investigate the "Pizzagate" conspiracy theory. According to reports, Welch pointed his gun at an employee and apparently fired it into the ground before police arrested him. No one was injured, and Welch was charged with assault with a dangerous weapon.

The "Pizzagate" conspiracy theory, which has been debunked as baseless, posits that Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton and her campaign manager, John Podesta, were involved in a child sex trafficking ring. Comet Ping Pong has been a target of visitors seeking to verify the conspiracy theory for weeks, despite the restaurant not having a basement, a key element of the conspiracy theory.

The restaurant's owners and employees have been subjected to threats and unsubstantiated stories about trafficking for weeks. Comet Ping Pong owner James Alefantis stated that the abuse they have endured is baffling, especially considering the restaurant does not have a basement.

The restaurant's owners supported Clinton during the presidential election, which some believe may have played a role in the development of the conspiracy, as even those close to President-elect Donald Trump have reportedly half-bought into the rumor. Alefantis expressed hope that those involved in promoting the falsehoods will stop doing so, stating, "What happened today demonstrates that promoting false and reckless conspiracy theories comes with consequences."

Title: US Customs and Border Protection Deploys Teargas Against Migrants in Tijuana

Article:

U.S. Customs and Border Protection (CBP) deployed teargas towards a group of approximately 150 Central American migrants attempting to cross the border in Tijuana, Mexico, during the early hours of New Year's Day. The incident occurred as the migrants attempted to breach the border fence.

In a statement released later on Tuesday, CBP stated that the teargas was aimed at rock throwers, not the migrants attempting to cross the border. The statement read, "No agents witnessed any of the migrants at the fence line, including children, experiencing effects of the chemical agents, which were targeted at the rock throwers further away."

However, an Associated Press (AP) photographer reported seeing at least three volleys of gas launched onto the Mexican side of the border, affecting migrants, including women and children, as well as journalists. The AP saw rocks thrown only after U.S. agents fired the teargas.

CBP reported that agents saw "toddler-sized children" being passed over concertina wire with difficulty. They stated that their agents could not assist the children due to the rocks being thrown. Agents responded with smoke, pepper spray, and teargas, according to CBP, and the AP journalist also observed plastic pellets fired by U.S. agents.

A total of 25 migrants were detained, while others crawled back into Mexico through a hole under the fence. CBP stated that under its use of force policy, the incident will be reviewed by its Office of Professional Responsibility.

Many of the migrants are reported to have arrived in Tijuana last month as part of the caravan from Honduras. The caravan, which grew to over 6,000 members during its month-and-a-half journey north, has been a constant target of President Donald Trump, who frequently referred to it in the run-up to the midterm elections in November.

Many of the migrants are waiting in Tijuana for a chance to apply for asylum in the U.S., but there was a backlog before the caravan's arrival, and the wait is expected to be many months. Others have found jobs in Mexico and tried to settle there.

In a previous incident, U.S. agents launched teargas across the border after some migrants tried to breach the border following a peaceful march in Tijuana on 26 November. Hundreds of migrants who were downwind of the gas were affected.

President Trump is currently embroiled in a fight with congressional Democrats over funding for the border wall that he wants to build. The stalemate has led to a partial government shutdown.

Title: Facebook Executives and Employees Contribute Significantly to Committees Questioning CEO Mark Zuckerberg on User Privacy

Article:

Members of the House Energy and Commerce Committee, which will question Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg about user privacy protection next week, are among the biggest recipients of campaign contributions from Facebook employees directly and the political action committee (PAC) funded by employees. The Senate Commerce, Science, and Transportation Committee, which will also question Zuckerberg, is the second-highest recipient.

According to the Center for Responsive Politics, members of the House Energy and Commerce Committee have received nearly $381,000 in contributions tied to Facebook since 2007. The Senate Commerce, Science, and Transportation Committee received $369,000, while the Senate Judiciary Committee, which will also question Zuckerberg, received $235,000.

Facebook's contributions to the House Energy and Commerce Committee are disproportionately skewed towards Republicans, with Republicans receiving roughly twice as much as Democrats. Of the $7 million in contributions to all federal candidates tied to Facebook, Democrats received 65%, while Republicans received 33%.

The House Energy and Commerce Committee has 55 members this year, and all but nine have received Facebook contributions in the past decade. The average Republican received $6,800, while the average Democrat received $6,750. Committee Chairman Greg Walden, R-Ore., received $27,000, while Rep. Frank Pallone of New Jersey, the top-ranking Democrat, received $7,000.

Walden and Pallone jointly announced that the committee will question Zuckerberg on April 11 to "shed light on critical consumer data privacy issues and help all Americans better understand what happens to their personal information online."

A Facebook spokesman responded to questions about the contributions by pointing to an April 2017 statement the company issued to employees about "political engagement." The statement said it is important for the company to "develop relationships with elected officials...who share our vision of an open Internet." The statement also described the company's PAC and said decisions about which candidates get support are based on whether their policy positions are consistent with the company's "and whether the candidate holds a key committee or leadership position."

A spokesman for Democrats on the House committee, C.J. Young, said he could not discuss campaign contributions. "But the premise that Facebook is getting softballs from the committee isn’t grounded in the facts," Young said, citing Walden and Pallone's insistence that Zuckerberg appear at a public hearing to address user privacy.

Facebook estimated that as many as 87 million accounts could have had their data improperly shared by Cambridge Analytica, a political targeting firm that worked on President Trump's 2016 campaign. Facebook suspended the firm's account after concluding Cambridge Analytica obtained and did not destroy personal information from users who had downloaded a personality profile app.

A member of both of the Senate committees that will question Zuckerberg on Tuesday is Sen. Ted Cruz, R-Texas. As an opponent of Trump in the 2016 presidential race, Cruz's campaign paid Cambridge Analytica $5.8 million. Cruz received a $15,000 contribution tied to Facebook in 2012, but nothing since then. Rep. O'Rourke, the Texas Democrat vying to unseat Cruz, is the fourth-highest recipient of contributions tied to Facebook in this election cycle, receiving nearly $13,000.

Fred Wertheimer, founder and president of the campaign finance reform advocacy group Democracy21, said having a committee that got the most contributions from Facebook question its top executive about a national controversy demonstrates why the system needs to be changed. "Powerful interests provide lots of money to the committees that have jurisdiction over them, and they do it to gain influence with those members of Congress," Wertheimer said. "It’s a fundamental problem that exists throughout the system and throughout the committee structure, and it undermines public confidence that the members are going to make decisions in the best interests of the American people."

Another giant in the tech industry, Google parent Alphabet, gave more in the 2016 presidential race, $8.8 million, than Facebook's PAC and its employees gave in the past decade. The top House committee receiving Alphabet contributions that year was again the Energy and Commerce Committee, according to the Center for Responsive Politics' data. Members of a handful of other Senate committees got more than members of the Senate Commerce or Judiciary committees, however.

The top recipient of Facebook contributions on the House commerce committee, receiving $51,050, was Rep. Anna Eshoo, a California Democrat whose district is adjacent to Facebook's headquarters and is home to many company employees. Eshoo narrowly lost a battle with Pallone for the top Democratic spot on the committee after the 2014 election.

House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi, a California Democrat who is not on the committee, received the most Facebook contributions in the House, totaling $55,150 since 2007. Overall, Facebook has contributed $1.1 million to House members, split almost evenly between the parties.

In addition to campaign contributions, Facebook spent $11.5 million lobbying Congress last year, and its total spending on lobbying since 2009 is nearly $52 million. Plus, nearly 30 members of Congress own Facebook stock, according to a story in Roll Call, including two Democratic members of the committee who will question Zuckerberg next week. Massachusetts Rep. Joseph Kennedy's investment is worth at least $80,000 and is held in trust funds. Oregon Rep. Kurt Schrader's stake is worth at least $15,000.

Title: Minimum Wage Hikes and Automation: A Closer Look at California's $15 Hourly Wage

Article:

As states like California and cities such as Seattle implement minimum wages of up to $15 per hour, critics have expressed concerns about potential job losses due to increased automation. Outlets like the Wall Street Journal's editorial page and Forbes' Tim Worstall argue that significant increases in minimum wages will lead to job loss through automation, with robots replacing workers in industries like fast food.

However, this perspective may be misguided. Firstly, there is no guarantee that increased minimum wages will accelerate the development and adoption of labor-saving technology. On the contrary, the implementation of higher minimum wages could incentivize the creation and adoption of high-quality new equipment to automate elements of industries like the food service industry, leading to a positive outcome.

Productivity-enhancing technology is a crucial component of social and economic progress. If minimum wage hikes do indeed spur the creation and adoption of such technology, it would imply that minimum wage hikes are a good idea.

California's minimum wage hike presents unique challenges, as it pushes the issue beyond the terrain in which it has been studied. The optimistic outcome is a significant increase in automation. The primary concern should be that the robots may not materialize, not that they will.

For workers displaced by automated service industry jobs, many would find new employment opportunities. Most restaurants would likely extend their operating hours, providing more shifts for workers. The advanced robo-restaurant technology itself would be a valuable American export good, creating jobs in design and sales.

Some low-wage work would be reallocated out of the relatively low-social-value restaurant sector and into areas like child care and home health assistance, where there is ample demand. As poor people earn more money, they would have the means to purchase goods and services they previously could not afford, creating demand for new jobs.

If robots can perform a significant portion of the work, we could afford to reduce the workweek, lowering the retirement age and providing more financial support to college students and new parents. Fewer people would be doing part-time food service work, and more would be able to take advantage of four weeks of paid vacation and extended parental leave.

The scenario to worry about with minimum wage hikes is that no technological solution will emerge. In this case, restaurant operations would remain the same, but employing people to work in them would become more expensive. In pricey, crowded cities, the results wouldn't be so bad, as operating a restaurant would become less lucrative, leading to lower bids for prime restaurant locations.

However, in less crowded, less expensive locations where labor is a larger slice of the overall cost pie, it would mean fewer restaurants opening and shorter operating hours. This would make it more difficult for people to find jobs, not just low-end jobs, but also better-paying managerial and construction jobs. Convenient meals would also be harder to come by.

Some people would benefit through higher pay, but others would struggle to find work unless they move to a different state that is friendlier to opening new restaurants. The ability of a legislative push for high pay to spur the development and deployment of new productivity-enhancing technology is the significant unknown about the minimum wage.

Existing studies of the labor market impact of minimum wage hikes generally find very small effects on employment based on small wage increases. The question they address is essentially whether a small hike in the wage floor introduces a small inefficiency into the labor market or whether it corrects for an existing inefficiency that gives employers some monopoly pricing power over workers.

This is an interesting question, but the wage-innovation question is a much more difficult—and yet important—one. The prevailing conventional wisdom in Western policy circles over the past generation has been that innovation is something that just happens. However, the assumption that the government cannot summon productivity-enhancing technology into existence by waving a magic minimum wage wand is not a proven proposition.

The fact that so many minimum wage skeptics think it's intuitively wrong is telling and interesting. A cheap labor economy may not offer as many incentives for companies to identify and promote managers who are skilled at finding, developing, and deploying labor-saving technology. Perhaps if a large, dynamic, and innovative state like California forces companies to eschew cheap labor, they will respond by innovating and reducing their need for workers.

At least, residents of inland California had better hope that happens. Otherwise, they may find themselves packing their bags for Texas.

Title: Hillary Clinton's Use of Personal Email During Tenure as Secretary of State

Article:

Hillary Clinton, during her tenure as Secretary of State, exclusively used a personal email account for conducting official government business, according to a report in the New York Times. This practice may have violated federal requirements that official correspondence be retained as part of the State Department's records.

Clinton did not have a government email address during her four-year term at the State Department. Her aides took no actions to have her personal emails preserved on department servers at the time, as required by the Federal Records Act. It was only two months ago, in response to a new State Department effort to comply with federal record-keeping practices, that Clinton's advisers reviewed tens of thousands of pages of her personal emails and decided which ones to turn over to the State Department. All told, 55,000 pages of emails were given to the department. Clinton stepped down from the secretary's post in early 2013.

The expansive use of the private account was alarming to current and former National Archives and Records Administration officials and government watchdogs, who called it a serious breach. This is not the first time the Obama administration has been caught evading federal records laws by using personal email, which ultimately allows officials to escape scrutiny under the Freedom of Information Act and Congressional investigation.

The existence of Clinton's personal email account was discovered as a House committee investigating the attack on the American Consulate in Benghazi sought correspondence between Clinton and her aides about the attack. The Benghazi Select Committee, headed by Congressman Trey Gowdy, is continuing its investigation. Clinton will likely have to answer for her non-transparency and years of federal law violation should she announce a run for the White House in April.

Title: Former UN Secretary-General Kofi Annan Dies at 80

Article:

The former United Nations Secretary-General, Kofi Annan, has passed away at the age of 80 following a brief illness, his family and foundation announced on Saturday. Born in Kumasi, Ghana, on April 8, 1938, Annan served as the seventh Secretary-General and held the position for two terms between 1997 and 2006. He was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize for his humanitarian work jointly with the UN in 2001.

Annan died in a hospital in Bern, Switzerland, in the early hours of Saturday, with his wife, Nane, and three children, Ama, Kojo, and Nina, by his side. He had retired to Geneva and later lived in a Swiss village.

The Annan Foundation issued a statement on his Twitter account on Saturday, describing him as a "global statesman and deeply committed internationalist who fought throughout his life for a fairer and more peaceful world."

Kofi Annan's (@KofiAnnan) Twitter account shared a statement that read, "In many ways, Kofi Annan was the United Nations. He rose through the ranks to lead the organization into the new millennium with matchless dignity and determination."

The current UN Secretary-General, António Guterres, who was appointed to lead its refugee agency by Annan, said, "Kofi Annan was a great diplomat, a true statesman, and a wonderful colleague who was widely respected and will be greatly missed."

The former UK Prime Minister, Tony Blair, expressed his shock and distress over Annan's death on Twitter, stating, "He was a good friend whom I saw only weeks ago. Kofi Annan was a great diplomat, a true statesman, and a wonderful colleague who was widely respected and will be greatly missed."

The Russian President, Vladimir Putin, and the German Chancellor, Angela Merkel, also paid tribute to Annan, with Putin describing him as a "wise and courageous" leader, and Merkel as an "exceptional statesman in the service of the global community."

Annan was the chair of The Elders, an independent group of global leaders working for peace and human rights founded by Nelson Mandela. Gro Harlem Brundtland, the former Prime Minister of Norway and the body's deputy chair, said she and her colleagues were devastated by Annan's death.

"Kofi was a strong and inspiring presence to us all, and The Elders would not be where it is today without his leadership. Throughout his life, Kofi worked unceasingly to improve the lives of millions of people around the world," she said.

Kumi Naidoo, Amnesty International's Secretary-General, said the world had lost a great leader. "Kofi's dedication and drive for a more peaceful and just world, his lifelong championing of human rights, and the dignity and grace with which he led will be sorely missed in a world which needs these characteristics more than ever."

Before becoming Secretary-General, Annan joined the UN system in 1962 as an administrative officer with the World Health Organization in Geneva. He later served with the Economic Commission for Africa in Addis Ababa, the UN Emergency Force in Ismailia, the UN High Commissioner for Refugees in Geneva, and in several senior posts at its headquarters in New York.

Annan's tenure as Secretary-General, which began six years after the collapse of the Soviet Union and also covered the 9/11 attacks and subsequent US-led war against Iraq, was one of the UN's most turbulent periods since its founding in 1945. His tenure at the UN was tarnished by a 2005 investigation of Annan and his son over the "oil-for-food" scandal.

An inquiry cleared Annan of any serious wrongdoing, but found ethical and management lapses linked to his son's ties with a Swiss company that won lucrative contracts in the oil-for-food scheme. Annan later admitted that the scandal had sorely tested his mettle not only as Secretary-General, but as a father.

In his final speech as Secretary-General in December 2006, Annan delivered a parting shot at the administration of George W. Bush, accusing the US of committing human rights abuses in the name of fighting terrorism. He acknowledged more recently that the UN still had its faults, stating, "The UN can be improved, it is not perfect, but if it didn't exist, you would have to create it."

Title: Obama Authorizes Direct Action in Iraq to Prevent Humanitarian Crisis

Article:

President Barack Obama has authorized direct military action in Iraq following a coordinated offensive by the Sunni fighters of the Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant (ISIL) that posed a threat to both American personnel and facilities, as well as the potential genocide of the Yazidi religious minority.

On Thursday night, Obama announced the authorization of direct action, allowing U.S. military warplanes based in the Middle East to attack ISIL. The threat of a deadly attack on the Kurdish capital of Erbil, home to U.S. allies and diplomats, and the systematic murder of tens of thousands of Yazidis, prompted the president's decision.

The U.S. military warplanes have not attacked as of early Friday, but the situation is rapidly evolving, and it is unclear when such strikes might occur. "If we see actions anywhere in Iraq that threaten our personnel or facilities, we stand prepared to take targeted action to protect them," one senior administration official said. Obama and other White House officials emphasized that no scenario would involve large numbers of combat troops returning to Iraq.

Obama has tried to avoid "kinetic" military action since Mosul and much of Iraq's north fell to ISIL last month. The U.S. wants Iraqi Prime Minister Nouri al-Maliki out of the picture, and White House press secretary Josh Earnest stated earlier Thursday that the U.S. did not want any government in Baghdad to be able to take refuge behind American military power.

However, as the danger for atrocities has grown, Obama made clear on Thursday night that the U.S. cannot stand idly by. "When we face a situation like we do on that mountain — with innocent people facing the prospect of violence on a horrific scale, when we have a mandate to help — in this case, a request from the Iraqi government — and when we have the unique capabilities to help avert a massacre, then I believe the United States of America can not turn a blind eye," Obama said. "We can act, carefully and responsibly, to prevent a potential act of genocide. That's what we're doing on that mountain."

Three Air Force cargo planes dropped food and water to help the Yazidis sustain their position, and the Defense Department is ready to launch another airdrop if required. Two Navy F/A-18 Hornet fighters escorted the cargo aircraft, and a defense official made clear that the fighters would be ready in case ISIL tried to target the resupply aircraft.

The exact air defense capabilities of the Sunni fighters have been a question mark as American officials in Washington have considered how or whether to use American air power in Iraq. The U.S. never sold Iraq shoulder-fired anti-aircraft missiles, officials say, but they do not know what kind of Iraqi or other weapons ISIL obtained when it scattered Iraq's army in June, or what weapons it has been able to export from its other theater of operations in Syria.

Even as national security officials made clear their readiness to resupply and attack if ordered, White House officials also tried to convey that Obama's orders were narrowly focused. "We are not launching a sustained campaign against ISIL here," said one. The overall administration message remained the same: The U.S. cannot bomb its way out of the Iraq crisis. Only Baghdad can end the dilemma by forming an inclusive government, officials insisted, one that will enfranchise Iraq's Sunnis and other minorities and entice them to turn away from extremist forces like ISIL.

"An enduring solution to the persistent threat posed by ISIL will require further reconciliation among Iraqi communities and strengthened Iraqi security forces," said Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel. However, the White House also acknowledged that even if Baghdad overcame its political dysfunction, its military would still face a daunting task in trying to retake the territory ISIL has claimed — something the Pentagon believes it could not do without American military help.

"Nobody believes this is something you can just turn around overnight," said one senior administration official.

Obama's critics in Congress were not mollified by the president's decisions. Arizona Sen. John McCain and South Carolina Sen. Lindsey Graham, two outspoken Republican hawks, criticized what they called the president's policy of "half measures."

"We need a strategic approach, not just a humanitarian one," they said. "A policy of containment will not work against ISIS. It is inherently expansionist and must be stopped. The longer we wait to act, the worse this threat will become, as recent events clearly show."

McCain and Graham joined other conservative critics who charged that Obama's policy of disengagement in the Middle East has caused the crises in Syria, Iraq, and elsewhere to get steadily worse as they fester without strong American action.

"If ever there were a time to reevaluate our disastrous policy in the Middle East, this is it," they said. "Because of the President's hands-off approach, the threats in the region have grown and now directly threaten the United States. We are already paying a very heavy price for our inaction, and if we do not change course, the costs of our inaction will only grow."

Title: Congress of 2013 on Track to Become Least Productive in History

Article:

The 113th United States Congress is on track to become the least productive Congress in history, with only 49 laws enacted so far, a figure not reached since at least 1947. This low productivity is partially attributed to the strained relationship between President Barack Obama and congressional Republicans, which has led to the first government shutdown in 17 years and flirtations with a historic debt default.

The slow pace of legislating comes despite significant issues facing the nation, such as a $17 trillion debt, the potential for a second government shutdown in mid-January, the bumpy rollout of the health care law, and overseas threats from countries like Iran. The inaction on a new farm bill is expected to disrupt rural America and cause milk prices to rise. Even legislation that seems to appeal to both parties, such as an immigration overhaul, remains stalled.

Senate Majority Whip Dick Durbin (D-Ill.) commented, "If I look at the last 12 weeks, we can count on one hand what we’ve achieved." He added, "We put the government back in business thank goodness, but beyond that the strategic helium reserve bill is really the centerpiece of what we’ve done."

Despite the low productivity, there is still a glimmer of hope for some major bills to pass, including the overdue overhaul of farm policies, the annual defense policy bill, the comprehensive immigration bill, a budget deal, and an omnibus spending package. However, the farm bill's chances for passage this year have taken a significant hit, and the emotional politics of an immigration overhaul may derail it next year. Any budget deal is expected to be limited in scope.

Sen. John McCain (R-Ariz.) expressed concern that the defense bill could join the list of proposals that fail in the 113th Congress, despite the annual Pentagon authorization measure passing Congress every year for the last 51 years. Sen. Lindsey Graham (R-S.C.) added, "I just think after today, legislating’s going to be pretty tough."

Part of the problem is the lack of coordination between the schedules of the GOP-controlled House and the Democratic-led Senate, making bicameral meetings and consensus-building sessions more challenging. The Senate has been in session for legislative business on only seven Fridays in 2013. The House is expected to be out for just one week before adjourning for the year on Dec. 13, while the Senate begins a two-week recess.

Title: CNN Poll Shows 2014 Midterm Elections Tightening, Obama's Approval Hits All-Time Low

Article:

A new CNN poll indicates that the 2014 midterm elections are now a toss-up, with the Republican Party marginally ahead of the Democratic Party by 49% to 47%. This represents a significant 10-point swing in public opinion compared to a month ago, when Democrats held a comfortable lead of 50% to 42%.

The poll results serve as a reminder that voter sentiment can be volatile and is influenced by current events. The rise of President Barack Obama's coalition, often perceived as unbeatable, is not a historical inevitability but a product of temporary trends.

In the past, the narrative was that the Republican Party had proven itself incapable of governing wisely and, consequently, of winning elections. The party's attempt to use the government shutdown to delay the implementation of the Affordable Care Act, also known as Obamacare, was met with criticism for prioritizing partisanship over national interests.

The shutdown's aftermath saw a decline in the Republican Party's approval ratings across all demographics. According to the poll, eight in ten voters disapproved of the shutdown, including two in three Republicans or independents who lean Republican.

However, the Democratic Party's triumphalism was short-lived. The latest polling showing a turnaround was prefigured by two election results that demonstrated residual conservative strength. In one, Chris Christie won a landslide victory, making significant inroads into traditionally Democratic demographics such as women, Hispanics, and African-Americans. In another, an unpopular ultraconservative Republican, Ken Cuccinelli, lost his gubernatorial race in Virginia but only by a small margin, despite being heavily outspent.

Christie's victory was likely due to his personal appeal to voters, but the outcome of the Virginia contest may have been influenced by public frustration over the botched rollout of the Obamacare exchanges. The website's troubles and the discovery that millions could lose their existing coverage, contrary to the President's repeated assurances, may have contributed to the public's disillusionment with the Democratic Party.

In conclusion, the National Journal reports that "race-by-race polling conducted over the last month has painted a grim picture of the difficult environment Senate Democrats are facing next year." The poll results suggest that the health care issue, with its direct impact on voters' lives, may have a greater long-term resonance and could potentially sway the 2014 midterm elections.

The key word in the data seems to be "volatility." Voters are disillusioned with Congress and disappointed in President Obama. The outcome of the elections will depend on events and good timing. The idea that Barack Obama established a new New Deal coalition in 2012 that cannot be broken by conservative politicians is clearly not supported by the data.

Title: Samsung Develops AI System to Create Deepfake Videos with Minimal Data

Article:

Samsung has developed a new artificial intelligence (AI) system that can generate deepfake videos using as little as one photograph. The technology, which was detailed in a paper earlier this week, can create convincing forgeries by using machine learning to fabricate a moving, speaking human.

The technology, if used maliciously, could potentially lead to misinformation, election tampering, and fraud, according to Hany Farid, a Dartmouth researcher who specializes in media forensics to root out deepfakes. The rapid development of such techniques, which require less and less data and are generating more and more sophisticated content, raises concerns about the ease of mass deception due to the difficulty in debunking deepfakes.

Deepfake software produces forgeries by using machine learning to convincingly fabricate a moving, speaking human. Though computer manipulation of video has existed for decades, deepfake systems have made doctored clips not only easier to create but also harder to detect.

The Samsung system uses a trick that seems inspired by Alexander Graham Bell's famous quote about preparation being the key to success. The system starts with a lengthy "meta-learning stage" in which it watches lots of videos to learn how human faces move. It then applies what it's learned to a single still or a small handful of pictures to produce a reasonably realistic video clip.

Unlike a true deepfake video, the results from a single or small number of images end up fudging fine details. For example, a fake of Marilyn Monroe in the Samsung lab's demo video missed the icon's famous mole. It also means the synthesized videos tend to retain some semblance of whoever played the role of the digital puppet, according to Siwei Lyu, a computer science professor at the University at Albany in New York who specializes in media forensics and machine learning. That's why each of the moving Mona Lisa faces looks like a slightly different person.

Generally, a deepfake system aims at eliminating those visual hiccups. That requires meaningful amounts of training data for both the input video and the target person. The few-shot or one-shot aspect of this approach is useful, Lyu said, because it means a large network can be trained on a large number of videos, which is the part that takes a long time. This kind of system can then quickly adapt to a new target person using only a few images without extensive retraining, he said. "This saves time in concept and makes the model generalizable."

The rapid advancement of artificial intelligence means that any time a researcher shares a breakthrough in deepfake creation, bad actors can begin scraping together their own jury-rigged tools to mimic it. Samsung's techniques are likely to find their way into more people's hands before long. The glitches in the fake videos made with Samsung's new approach may be clear and obvious. But they'll be cold comfort to anybody who ends up in a deepfake generated from that one smiling photo posted to Facebook.

Title: Parliamentary Committee Warns of "Democratic Crisis" in the UK, Calls for Tougher Regulation of Social Media Companies

Article:

A parliamentary committee has warned of a "democratic crisis" in the United Kingdom, with voters being targeted with "pernicious views" and data being manipulated. The Digital, Culture, Media and Sport (DCMS) Committee, which has been investigating disinformation and fake news following the Cambridge Analytica data scandal, is set to release its first report, according to a leaked copy obtained by Dominic Cummings, the director of the official Brexit campaign group Vote Leave.

In the report, MPs suggest that social media companies should face tougher regulation or a new tax. The report comes after months of investigating the impact of technology giants and how people are affected by the rise in fake news on social media. It also probed whether Russia had a role in influencing voters in the EU referendum.

The leaked report, which was due to be officially published on Sunday, is expected to be very critical of Facebook, which has been under increased scrutiny following the Cambridge Analytica data scandal. The report alleges that Facebook has hampered the committee's efforts to obtain information about the company throughout the inquiry.

The committee's report will also say it had received "disturbing evidence" of hacking, disinformation, and voter suppression in elections since 2010. It urges the government to ensure that the National Crime Agency thoroughly investigates these allegations.

The report is expected to call for clear legal liability for tech companies to act against harmful and illegal content on their platforms. It will suggest creating a "new category of tech company" that is something in between a platform or publisher, to establish legal accountability for tech companies.

The rules on political campaigns should be made fit for the digital age, the report will say. The committee will call for a public register for political advertising, so that anybody can see what messages are being distributed online. Online political advertisements should have a digital imprint stating who was responsible, as is required with printed leaflets and advertisements.

The report will also warn that social media sites should be held responsible for interference in elections by malicious actors. Electoral fraud fines should be increased from a maximum of £20,000 to a percentage of an organization's annual turnover. An independent body such as the Competition and Markets Authority should audit the social networks, and security mechanisms and algorithms used by social networks should be available for audit by a government regulator.

The committee will also warn that fake accounts on sites such as Facebook and Twitter "not only damage the user experience, but potentially defraud advertisers" who could be paying to advertise to accounts not run by real people.

The report will suggest a tax on tech companies to fund education and regulation. Some of the money should fund the extra responsibilities of the regulators, while the rest should be spent on digital education in schools and a public awareness campaign to help people identify disinformation and fake news.

The report will summarize the evidence collected during the committee's inquiry, which was launched in September last year. Whistleblower Christopher Wylie and Cambridge Analytica chief executive Alexander Nix were among the 61 witnesses that gave evidence.

Tom Baldwin, who has written a book on the relationship between politics and media, told BBC Radio 4's Today programme that the report's recommendations did not go far enough. Will Moy, the head of fact-checking charity Full Fact, and Jamie Bartlett, the head of think tank Demos, also shared their views on the report's implications. The final report is expected before the end of the year. Facebook and Twitter have yet to respond to a request for comment.

Title: Government Shutdown Affects Death Gratuity Benefits for Families of Fallen Service Members

Article:

The ongoing partial government shutdown has resulted in the Department of Defense announcing that it would be unable to pay the $100,000 death gratuity benefit to support families of the fallen. This decision, which was met with quick condemnation from various sectors, has left many questioning the sincerity of the government's support for America's troops and veterans.

The death gratuity benefit is a financial assistance provided to the families of service members who die while on active duty or as a result of a service-related injury. The news of the benefit's temporary suspension has caused distress among the military and veterans community, as well as pundits.

Politicians from both parties have rushed to denounce the decision and call for the benefits to be reinstated. The strong bipartisan support for the issue has led veterans to question the genuine nature of the government's support, with some speculating that the pledges of support may serve as a symbolic fallback issue for legislators during tough governing times.

Fortunately, the military charity Fisher House Foundation has stepped up and will cover these benefits for the Pentagon until the problem is solved.

The shutdown's impact on veterans and military families extends beyond the death gratuity benefit. Veterans and military families are left to wonder if the pledges of support are genuine or merely symbolic. The shutdown has also affected veterans who make up 27% of the federal workforce, who are now furloughed. National Guard drills are being rescheduled or canceled in many states, affecting troop readiness and pay. On base, services that military families count on are now closed. Veterans who rely on disability and GI Bill benefits are facing the very real possibility of not getting their benefits next month, as Veterans Affairs Secretary Eric Shinseki testified Wednesday.

The political games and posturing surrounding the shutdown have generated a style of bandwagon politics that is getting stale. Rather than focus on solving the problems that resulted in the shutdown, politicians are conveniently highlighting veterans and military families without doing the one job that will really help: ending the shutdown. The political games and posturing need to end, and solutions need to be found to help veterans and military families who are hurting during the shutdown.

Title: Republican-Led State Legislatures Advance Conservative Agenda, Stripping LGBT Rights and Limiting Social Services

Article:

Republican lawmakers in North Carolina recently passed a bill, known as House Bill 2, that restricts transgender individuals from using bathrooms that align with their gender identity and prevents local governments from outlawing discrimination against LGBT citizens. The bill, which has been criticized as one of the most anti-LGBT rights laws in the country, was vetoed by Governor Nathan Deal of Georgia after intervention from corporate actors, including Disney and the NFL.

The bill's passage in North Carolina is indicative of a larger divide in the United States, with Republican-controlled states advancing conservative agendas that limit civil rights and social services, while Democratic-controlled states strengthen protections and expand social services.

In the past six years, Republican control of state governments has led to a number of changes in red states. Abortion restrictions, such as the recent ban on abortions in cases of fetal disability in Indiana and the end of state funding for preventive health services at medical centers where abortions occur in Florida, are becoming more common in states with Republican governors or legislatures.

In addition, 19 states have yet to accept Medicaid expansion, a key component of Obamacare, with either a Republican governor or a GOP-controlled legislature. Voting restrictions, such as voter ID laws, early voting restrictions, and the elimination of same-day registration, are also more common in states controlled by Republicans.

In contrast, blue states are more likely to have generous Medicaid and welfare benefits, well-funded public schools, and supportive programs for child care, family leave, foster care, and the homeless and disabled. California recently became the first state to raise its minimum wage to $15, and a similar effort is underway in New York.

Examples of the impact of Republican dominance on the state level can be seen in Kansas and Louisiana, where new governors have prioritized tax cuts for the highest earners, leading to devastating consequences for state agencies, youth services, mental health treatment, and higher education.

Even in purple or blue states, once Republicans take control of state government, they have wasted little time in pushing through conservative agendas, including restricting abortion rights, privatizing public services, and undermining labor protections.

As the nation's politics become more divided, ideologically orthodox conservative Republicans are aggressively pushing their agenda on the state level. The consequences for those living in red state America could be dire.

Title: Boehner Denies Plans for Impeachment of President Obama; House GOP Focuses on Lawsuit Against White House

Article:

House Speaker John Boehner has denied that congressional Republicans are moving to impeach President Barack Obama, labeling such talk as a "scam started by Democrats at the White House." During a meeting with GOP members on Tuesday, Boehner stated, "We have no plans to impeach the President. We have no future plans."

Boehner attributed the discussion of impeachment to "the President's own staff" and congressional Democrats, stating that they are using the issue to rally support for the upcoming elections. Boehner's decision to sue Obama was designed to address outrage from tea party activists and others within the GOP base over a string of Obama executive orders they say circumvented Congress.

The lawsuit covers his decision last year to defer a health law requirement that businesses provide insurance coverage to their employees. However, the suit also opened the door to more discussion about impeaching the second-straight Democratic president by a Republican-led House.

The issue was magnified when incoming House GOP whip Steve Scalise of Louisiana refused to take the issue off the table during an interview over the weekend. Dan Pfeiffer, a longtime aide and senior Obama adviser, stated last week that impeachment talk should not be considered a long shot. Pfeiffer said that the lawsuit was evidence Republicans would consider impeachment down the road.

Congressional Democrats have seized on the issue and show no sign of letting up. Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid raised the subject on the Senate floor on Tuesday at about the same time Boehner was ruling it out. "Look in the papers today, the American people are totally opposed to this," Reid said. "We should not be off on those tracks of impeachment and suing the President. We should be legislating."

In the month since Boehner announced his lawsuit, the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee has raised nearly $7.6 million ahead of the November midterms. However, the campaign arm has pulled in $1 million alone since Scalise's comments on impeachment over the weekend. With the resolution to formally authorize the lawsuit expected on the House floor on Wednesday, House Democrats are likely to continue to argue, regardless of Boehner's comments, that that move is simply the first step toward impeachment.

Title: Telecom Industry Challenges Maine's Broadband User Privacy Law in Court

Article:

The telecom industry, following its successful lobbying to eliminate federal consumer privacy rules, has now filed a lawsuit against the state of Maine over its new broadband user privacy law. The lawsuit, filed this week, claims that the Maine law violates the industry's free speech rights.

The Maine law, passed last June, requires Internet Service Providers (ISPs) to clearly disclose the data they collect and with whom they share it. The law also mandates that users opt in to the sale of sensitive location or financial data and prohibits ISPs from charging extra for privacy protection.

The lawsuit, first spotted by Ars Technica, argues that Maine's law "imposes unprecedented and unduly burdensome restrictions on ISPs' protected speech." The lawsuit further claims that the law's requirements for disclosure and opt-in are discriminatory, as they apply only to ISPs while ignoring similar data practices of other online and offline businesses.

Telecom experts, however, view the industry's lawsuit as a desperate attempt to dodge accountability for a decade of telecom-related privacy abuses. Gigi Sohn, a former FCC lawyer, told Motherboard that the lawsuit is part of a broader industry effort to eliminate all meaningful state and federal consumer protections.

Sohn noted that the lawsuit is a response to the Federal Communications Commission's (FCC) apathy towards consumer protection, which allowed ISPs to engage in practices such as charging consumers rental fees for modems they already own or increasing subscriber bills through bogus fees and surcharges.

In 2017, telecom lobbyists convinced the Trump FCC to not only kill net neutrality but also eliminate most of the FCC's telecom consumer protection authority. The FCC's inaction has allowed ISPs to engage in practices that violate consumer privacy.

In response to federal apathy, states like Washington, California, and Maine have passed their own privacy and net neutrality laws. The industry has complained that this creates a confusing "patchwork quilt" of state consumer protections, but Sohn argues that this problem is self-inflicted, as the industry lobbied to repeal the FCC's broadband privacy rules.

Blake Reid, Associate Clinical Professor at Colorado Law, told Motherboard that the industry's lawsuit is another example of the sector trying to have its cake and eat it too. Reid noted that the industry's argument that the near-total vacuum of privacy protections at the federal level conflicts with Maine's law is disingenuous, as the industry lobbied to repeal the FCC's broadband privacy rules.

With former Verizon lawyers now in charge of both the FCC and the Department of Justice, the federal government has further aided the telecom sector by suing states like California for attempting to protect consumers on issues like net neutrality. Reid stated that it is no surprise that states like Maine have stepped in to fill the void, and the industry can hardly claim that having to protect their customers' privacy conflicts with their non-obligations to do essentially nothing at all under federal law.

Title: The Evolution of Liberal Approaches to Free Speech and Political Discourse

Article:

In recent years, the concept of free speech has become a topic of significant debate, with some arguing that it has become a predominantly conservative idea due to the perceived lack of commitment to it among liberals. This article explores seven strategies that some liberals are said to employ to silence or discredit opposing viewpoints, as described in the provided text.

1. Libsplaining: This phenomenon involves liberals interpreting conservative viewpoints in a way that is often at odds with the original intent. For example, opposition to welfare might be misconstrued as hatred towards certain demographics, or a lack of support for a particular political candidate could be seen as a desire for a fascist regime.

2. Violence: Some liberals are accused of resorting to violence to silence their political opponents, particularly in the context of protests. Groups such as Antifa have been involved in violent demonstrations against individuals and organizations with differing political beliefs, ranging from far-right extremists to mainstream conservatives.

3. De-Platforming: This strategy involves limiting the dissemination of conservative viewpoints by controlling access to media outlets, social media platforms, and other forums for public discourse. This can be seen in the increasing hostility towards conservatives on Twitter, Facebook, Google, and YouTube, as these platforms become less welcoming to conservative voices.

4. Political Correctness, Safe Spaces, and Microaggressions: These concepts are used to silence individuals expressing opinions that liberals find unacceptable. For example, a conservative employee at Google was fired for making scientifically supported arguments about women in STEM fields that were deemed offensive by liberals.

5. Liberal Fakes: In the mainstream media, there is a perceived lack of genuine conservative representation. Many conservative voices in the media are seen as moderate at best and liberal at worst, serving to give the impression that even conservatives disagree with conservative policies.

6. False Labeling: Liberals are accused of labeling their political opponents as white supremacists, Nazis, fascists, or racists, even when the evidence for such labels is tenuous or non-existent.

7. The Ventriloquist Dummy: Liberals are said to use certain individuals, often those who have experienced tragedy or are perceived as innocent and sympathetic, to advance their political agendas. These individuals, such as Cindy Sheehan, the Parkland students, and even former President Barack Obama, are used to shield their arguments from criticism, particularly when the individuals in question are people of color.

It is essential to note that this article presents the strategies described as they are perceived by some, and it does not aim to endorse or condemn these tactics. The purpose of this article is to provide an overview of the strategies that some liberals are said to employ to silence or discredit opposing viewpoints, as described in the provided text.

Title: NPR Battleground Map: Hillary Clinton Gains Significant Lead Over Donald Trump

Article:

The latest NPR analysis of polling, demographics, and on-the-ground reporting indicates that Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton has solidified a substantial lead over Republican candidate Donald Trump. If the election were held today, Clinton would win in a landslide of 2008 proportions, with 273 electoral votes, according to the NPR Battleground Map.

Clinton's leads in key battleground states have grown, and she could potentially win without capturing any of the toss-up states, such as Ohio, Florida, North Carolina, Iowa, Nevada, and Georgia. In the map provided, Clinton would secure a victory with 273 electoral votes to Trump's 174.

Trump's campaign has been marred by a series of missteps, including feuds with families of fallen soldiers, declining to support key Republicans, controversial remarks, and a lack of support from some traditionally Republican demographics. These missteps have reportedly led key voting groups to move more toward Clinton, particularly white, college-educated voters in suburban areas.

The past month has been challenging for any Republican hoping for Trump's victory, with the current state of the race being reminiscent of Barack Obama's 2008 margin of 365-173 over John McCain. However, it is important to note that few things are likely to remain constant almost three months out from Election Day, and this analysis is a snapshot of the current state of the race.

The next significant opportunities for Trump to change the dynamics are the debates, with the first scheduled for September 26 on Long Island, New York, followed by the vice presidential debate on October 4 in Virginia, the second presidential debate on October 9 in St. Louis, and the final debate 10 days later in Las Vegas.

The NPR Battleground Map also shows that several traditionally red states have moved in Clinton's direction. Georgia has been moved to Tossup from Lean R, Utah to Lean R from Likely R, and one electoral vote in Nebraska to Tossup from Lean R. In Georgia, Obama only lost by 5 points in 2008, and some polls are showing Clinton in the lead, although both candidates are only in the low 40s.

In Utah, another poll showed Clinton and Trump within a couple of points of each other, with a significant number of undecided voters. The impact of third-party candidate Gary Johnson is a key question in Utah, as well as in other states. If Johnson can garner high teen or 20-point support, there could be a path for Clinton to win Utah.

In Nebraska, the state splits its votes by congressional district, with Obama winning the Omaha-area district in 2008. The Democratic House incumbent Brad Ashford is favored there, and Omaha-based billionaire Warren Buffett is reportedly planning to help Clinton in the area.

Despite Trump's recent struggles, he has held steady in a couple of states that were previously considered Lean D, such as Florida and Nevada. Both states have moved to Tossup as more polling data has become available. Given demographics and Clinton's turnout operation, both states could be considered favorable for Clinton. However, the Republican National Committee (RNC) has moved staff to Florida to try to save the state.

The NPR Battleground Map also shows that several states previously considered Safe R, such as Alabama, Alaska, Arkansas, Idaho, Kansas, Kentucky, Louisiana, Mississippi, Montana, North Dakota, Oklahoma, South Carolina, South Dakota, Tennessee, Texas, West Virginia, and Wyoming, remain in Trump's column. Meanwhile, Safe D states, such as California, Connecticut, Delaware, Hawaii, Illinois, Maine, Maryland, Massachusetts, New York, Rhode Island, Vermont, Washington, D.C., Washington state, and Wisconsin, remain in Clinton's column.

Overall, the NPR Battleground Map suggests that Clinton currently holds a significant lead over Trump, but the race is likely to evolve in the coming months, particularly in the wake of the upcoming debates.

Title: Genetic Similarities Between Humans and Primates and the Struggle Between Human Nature and Behavior

Article:

In the science fiction novel Dune, an old witch suggests that a young nobleman may be human, implying a close relationship between humans and animals. This statement is supported by genetic research, as approximately 97 percent of the human genome is identical to that of orangutans, which are solitary and pacifistic, and about 99 percent of our DNA is identical to that of chimpanzees, which are intensely social and fierce. The genetic difference between orangutan and chimpanzee is relatively small, and the genetic difference between chimpanzee and Homo sapiens is tiny indeed.

Recent events have highlighted the inner chimp in human behavior, as demonstrated by an incident involving Ivanka Trump, daughter of the president-elect, on a JetBlue airliner at JFK airport in New York. A fellow by the name of Matthew Lasner, a professor at New York's Hunter College, tweeted that his husband had spied Ivanka Trump and her child on a flight and was "chasing them down to harass them." His husband, Daniel Goldstein, apparently did just that, berating the mother and child until he and his husband were escorted off the airplane.

The incident serves as a reminder of the inner chimp that exists within each individual, and the struggle between the better angels of our nature and our baser instincts. It is essential to recognize that we are called to be something more than our emotions, appetites, and allegiances.

Manners are a misunderstood thing, not about aesthetics or making oneself a more pleasant dining companion, but about making other people feel valued, respected, and considered. The point of manners is to keep the peace, to prevent violence, suppression, and misery, which were all most of the human race knew until the day before yesterday, when the emergence of market capitalism taught us how to cooperate with one another and the Industrial Revolution gave us the means to do so on a grand scale.

Politics always brings out tribalism, and this year's election has been more tribalistic than most. Witness how the 80-odd percent of Republicans who opposed bailouts when they were done by Barack Obama reversed course and became the 80-odd percent of Republicans who support bailouts when organized by Donald Trump. It is essential to recognize that we are called to be more, to be human, to be morally and spiritually larger than what lies within our own skins. And if that is beyond one's personal capacity, one is in luck. One doesn't have to be a saint. All one really has to do is to mind one's manners and one can pass for human most of the time.

Title: Social Media and the "Spiral of Silence": A Study on Public Opinion Sharing

Article:

A new study by the Pew Research Internet Project suggests that social media platforms like Facebook and Twitter do not provide a platform for those hesitant to speak up in public on policy issues when they feel their views are in the minority. The study, which surveyed 1,801 adults, focused on the divisive public issue of Edward Snowden's NSA revelations, revealing that people were less willing to discuss the surveillance online than they were in person.

The study found that people were more likely to speak up online if they believed others agreed with them. Those who frequently used Facebook and Twitter were less likely to share their opinions offline. For instance, a person who checks Facebook multiple times a day is half as likely to share their opinion offline as someone who does not go on the site as frequently.

The report attributes this phenomenon to what it refers to as the "spiral of silence." However, it acknowledges that the study's focus on one policy issue may not fully capture the complexity of the issue, and that other factors, such as confidence in one's knowledge and opinions, also play a role.

The report suggests several theories as to why social media perpetuates the "spiral of silence." These include fear of isolation, a desire to avoid losing friends and alienating people, and the observation that those with minority opinions on social media platforms may experience ostracism, which could increase the perceived risk of opinion sharing in other settings.

While the report's theories provide insight into the issue, it is also possible that the problem isn't the "spiral of silence" but rather the overwhelming noise and repetition of the same views on social media. Those who spend a significant amount of time online reading the same views, over and over again, on the same topic, may be tired of hearing it and may not want to contribute to the cacophonic chorus telling itself, over and over again, how right it is, both online and off.

Title: Boko Haram Hostage-Taking in Nigeria Highlights Growing Terrorist Threat in North Africa

Article:

The kidnapping of hundreds of schoolgirls in Nigeria by the militant group Boko Haram has brought to light the increasing strength and influence of Islamic militants operating in the region between the Sahara and sub-Saharan Africa. The Boko Haram terrorists have developed paramilitary capabilities and have expanded their operations beyond Nigeria's Muslim north, posing a growing threat to the country.

The current hostage-taking incident, which has resulted in the largest and most violent example of Boko Haram's growing strength, is not the first such incident. In January 2013, terrorists affiliated with Al Qaeda attacked a natural gas production facility near the town of In Amenas in Algeria, holding over 800 people hostage. The terrorists executed some 40 foreigners before Algerian authorities re-established control, killing nearly 30 terrorists as the rest escaped. The incident occurred during President Obama's second inauguration, resulting in minimal American press coverage.

Shortly thereafter, in Mali, terrorists, many formerly employed by Muammar Qaddafi in Libya, nearly took over the entire country. Repeated military interventions by France in its former colony prevented an Islamist victory. The situation in Mali remains far from secure even today.

The growing terrorist threat across North Africa has received little attention in the United States. In 2012, terrorists assassinated Ambassador Christopher Stevens and three other Americans in Libya on Sept. 11, but there has been no retaliation against the growing terrorist threat in Libya.

The United States needs an effective counterterrorism strategy in North Africa, and it currently lacks one. Despite having created a separate African Command at the Pentagon, separating it from the European Command, inadequate attention has been given to the North African terrorist threat.

The Nigerian government has not dealt effectively with Boko Haram, and other governments in the region also face severe constraints on their operational capabilities. The failure of the Nigerian government to contain Boko Haram has significant political implications throughout northern Africa. If Boko Haram's reach and strength continue to grow, it is not impossible that Nigeria's ethnically and religiously diverse population could face massive internal strife, and perhaps even split apart. The 1967 Biafra secession and subsequent civil war and humanitarian tragedy should remind us just how fragile Nigeria actually is.

If there is instability in Nigeria, and the Nigerian national government loses control over northern Nigeria because of it, it could become a haven for terrorist groups operating worldwide. Northern Africa is much closer to the West than the Al Qaeda and Taliban bases in the mountains of Afghanistan and Pakistan.
