The Obama administration's initial decision to offer assistance from the FBI, while laudable, nonetheless betrays its continuing belief that global terrorism can be handled as a law-enforcement matter rather than the war it truly is. Much more is needed, and not just piecemeal assistance, even from America's military and intelligence agencies.

Neither the Obama administration nor our country as a whole is paying adequate attention. The threat of Islamic terrorism on display now in northern Nigeria is global in scope and continues to grow, political rhetoric by the president notwithstanding. Boko Haram's latest outrage should focus our attention on the continuing threat of Al Qaeda and radical Islam. Whether we pay attention remains to be seen.

Title: Young American Voter Turnout for Midterms Remains Low, Concerns for Democratic "Blue Wave"

Article:

A new survey by the Public Religion Research Institute and The Atlantic has revealed that only one in three young Americans (ages 18-29) are certain they will vote in the upcoming November midterm elections. This is in stark contrast to the expected turnout for older age groups, with 81% of seniors (Americans age 65+) surveyed stating they will vote in the midterms.

The survey, conducted from August 24 to September 13, polled 1,811 Americans over the age of 18. Although participants were randomly selected, the survey over-sampled voters aged 18-29 to gather more data from this age group. The survey had a margin of error of 3%.

The survey's findings could potentially dampen Democrats' hopes for a "blue wave" in the 2018 midterms, as midterm elections typically report low voter turnout. In the 2014 midterms, about 36% of Americans eligible to vote did so, according to the United States Election Project.

Robert P. Jones, CEO of PRRI, stated that young voters are an important demographic for Democrats, as they support Democratic candidates over Republican candidates by a margin of 61% to 35%.

Researchers attribute young Americans' low turnout to various reasons, with Robert Griffin, associate director of research at PRRI, highlighting a lack of information as a significant factor. "We have norms in society not just about being a voter, but being an informed voter," Griffin said. "If you have a portion of the society that judges itself uninformed, that will potentially have an effect on their likelihood of voting."

Another potential reason for low turnout, according to Griffin, is a belief among young Americans that voting may not cause change. While 78% of seniors polled for the survey said voting regularly is the "most effective way to create change," only 50% of young Americans surveyed agreed.

Griffin noted that the current turnout rate for young voters in November looks consistent with 2014, which was "one of the lowest turnout years for young voters probably in the last three decades." However, he also stated that this does not necessarily spell disaster for Democrats, citing special elections since 2016 that have "indicated large swings to the left."

In conclusion, the survey's findings suggest that young American voter turnout for the 2018 midterms may remain low, potentially impacting the anticipated "blue wave" of Democratic victories. However, the survey's results do not necessarily predict the entire election cycle, as special elections since 2016 have shown significant swings to the left.

Title: House Budget Committee Chairman Paul Ryan Renews Push for Obamacare Repeal

Article:

House Budget Committee Chairman Paul Ryan has renewed his efforts to repeal the Affordable Care Act, also known as Obamacare. Ryan, who is a potential 2016 presidential contender, discussed his plan to balance the budget in a decade, which includes the repeal of Obamacare, during an interview on Fox News Sunday.

Ryan's plan to repeal Obamacare is a recurring theme in his political career. He has consistently advocated for its repeal in previous budget proposals and during the 2012 campaign trail. The Republican Party has attempted to repeal Obamacare more than 30 times, with the latest attempt being a measure introduced by Rep. Michele Bachmann in the current session.

The Supreme Court upheld the law in a politically charged decision last year. A poll conducted by the Kaiser Family Foundation after the November presidential election found that just 33% of those polled support repealing Obamacare. Even House Speaker John Boehner, R-Ohio, acknowledged after the election that the GOP's mission to repeal the law would change.

Ryan is expected to release his budget this week, providing a preview of his plan on Wednesday. His continued push for Obamacare repeal, despite the political challenges, is seen as a strategic move to appeal to the most conservative members of the Republican base should he decide to run for president in 2016.

Political experts suggest that Ryan's stance on Obamacare is a bargaining position and a tactic to gain the Republican nomination in 2016. John Geer, a political science professor at Vanderbilt University, stated, "I don't think it's necessarily a surprise. It's where he stood before the election, and it's a bargaining position. Also, it's a classic position to take if in 2016 if he wants to run for president. He knows it's not very realistic to try to repeal Obamacare, but it's a good way to try and get the nomination in 2016."

Ryan is also dealing with two political realities, according to Nathan Gonzales, deputy editor of the Rothenberg Political Report. "He's trying to appeal to several audiences," Gonzales said. "There's trying to get something done, but there's also appealing to the party's base."

Senate Budget Committee Chairman Patty Murray, D-Washington, is expected to soon unveil a budget that will likely include an increase in taxes for wealthy Americans and businesses while cutting some spending as a way of addressing the deficit. Some in the Republican base support the idea that nixing costs associated with Obamacare would help trim the deficit.

Last year, the Congressional Budget Office and Joint Committee on Taxation wrote that one such effort to repeal Obamacare "would reduce direct spending by $890 billion and reduce revenues by $1 trillion between 2013 and 2022, thus adding $109 billion to federal budget deficits over that period."

While the prospects of repealing Obamacare may be slim, Ryan's continued push for its repeal underscores the deep political divide over the law and the ongoing efforts by some Republicans to dismantle it.

Title: Fact-Checking the New York Times' Report on Liberty University's Reopening Amid COVID-19

Article:

In an article published on March 29th, The New York Times reported on Liberty University's decision to reopen its campus, suggesting that the school's president, Jerry Falwell Jr., had put students at risk and that a dozen students had contracted the coronavirus. However, a closer examination of the facts reveals a different story.

While it is true that Liberty University reopened its campus, the characterization of the reopening as a broad, uncontrolled event is misleading. According to sources within the university, the reopening was targeted, focusing on foreign students who had no other place to go. Contrary to the article's claims, the university was largely deserted, with less than 1,500 out of 15,000 students remaining on campus, primarily foreign students.

The article also claimed that one student had tested positive for COVID-19 and that Dr. Eppes, a Liberty University physician, had made statements suggesting the university had lost control of the situation. However, Dr. Eppes has since come forward to deny the accuracy of the quote attributed to him.

Furthermore, the article's claim that students were "starting to get sick" is questionable. The article does not specify the symptoms that were "suggestive of COVID-19," and it is unclear whether these symptoms were unique to the coronavirus or could have been caused by other respiratory illnesses.

The New York Times' article also failed to mention that Liberty University had taken additional precautions, such as constant cleaning of frequently touched surfaces, removing two out of every three computers from the lab to ensure social distancing, and quarantining those suspected of carrying the virus in a former hotel 3 miles from campus. Two surprise visits from state health inspectors found no violations.

In response to the article, Mr. Falwell was widely criticized, and many, including the author of this article, expressed concern about the potential risks to students. However, as more facts have come to light, it appears that the initial report was factually incorrect.

The New York Times' article has been widely criticized for its inaccuracies, and some have questioned the paper's journalistic integrity. The Wall Street Journal's columnist William McGurn wrote an article titled "The Education of Jerry Falwell Jr.: Attacked for keeping Liberty University open, he now seems to have made a good call." McGurn's article highlights the fact that no Liberty student living on campus tested positive, and no staffer stationed on campus tested positive.

In conclusion, the initial report by The New York Times on Liberty University's reopening appears to be factually incorrect. The university took precautions to ensure the safety of its students and staff, and there is no evidence to suggest that the reopening led to a significant number of COVID-19 cases. It is essential for journalists to report facts accurately and avoid sensationalism, especially during a global pandemic.

Title: Trump Threatens to Block Financial Aid for USPS Unless Package Rates Raised

Article:

President Donald Trump on Friday threatened to withhold financial aid for the United States Postal Service (USPS) unless it increases package shipping rates for retail giants like Amazon. During a meeting in the Oval Office, Trump stated, "The postal service is a joke," and suggested that package shipping rates should be increased by approximately four times.

The CARES Act, which Trump signed into law last month, included a provision allowing the cash-strapped USPS to borrow up to $10 billion from the Treasury Department to cover losses during the coronavirus pandemic. However, Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin stated on Friday that the lending plan is tied to "postal reform." Trump offered more specifics, stating that he only wants to free up the money if the Postal Service raises rates.

Trump reiterated his long-held belief that Amazon and other large shipping retailers are receiving too favorable rates from USPS. "For some reason, they're very cozy with some of these companies," Trump said. "If they don't raise the price, I'm not signing anything."

Later on Friday afternoon, the president took to Twitter to praise postal service employees while criticizing the leadership of the USPS. "I will never let our Post Office fail," the president tweeted. "It has been mismanaged for years, especially since the advent of the internet and modern-day technology. The people that work there are great, and we’re going to keep them happy, healthy, and well!"

Trump's sharp criticism of the post office came after he signed a $484 billion bipartisan coronavirus relief bill targeted largely at small businesses.

House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, D-Calif., accused the Trump administration of trying to use its leverage over the loan to seek to privatize the USPS. She urged Americans to speak up in favor of their mail carriers, who are especially vital for delivering medicine and communications for senior citizens, she said.

"Right now I see a very big danger for our country in the form of the Trump administration's interest in privatizing the post office," Pelosi said on Friday. "This is really dangerous, and Mnuchin at Treasury is trying to leverage the debt situation in a way that must be stopped."

The Postal Service has repeatedly defended its arrangement with Amazon.

Title: US Expands Travel Ban to Include Six Additional Countries, Critics Allege Discrimination

Article:

The United States has expanded its travel ban, often criticized as a Muslim ban, to target citizens from six additional countries. The move, announced on Friday, has been met with criticism from immigrant advocates and critics who argue that the policy discriminates against Muslims and others.

The new restrictions will affect citizens from Eritrea, Kyrgyzstan, Myanmar, Nigeria, Sudan, and Tanzania. The Trump administration maintains that these countries failed to meet US security and information-sharing standards, necessitating the new restrictions.

The problems officials cited range from subpar passport technology to a failure to sufficiently exchange information on "terrorism" suspects and criminals. The restrictions on the six new countries will take effect on February 21.

The US will suspend the issuance of visas that can lead to permanent residency for nationals of Eritrea, Kyrgyzstan, Myanmar, and Nigeria, acting Secretary of Homeland Security Chad Wolf said on Friday. Non-immigrant visas will not be affected. According to the State Department, non-immigrant visas include those for tourism, short-term business, medical purposes, education, and journalism, among other types of visas.

During December, for example, about 650,760 non-immigrant visas were granted worldwide. Immigrant visas include those for spouses, certain family members, certain sponsored employment, and other purposes.

The Trump administration has stated that there are exceptions to the restrictions. The US government will also stop issuing "diversity visas" to nationals of Sudan and Tanzania, according to a presidential proclamation. These visas, which President Trump has criticized in the past, are available by lottery for applicants from countries with low rates of immigration to the US.

The State Department uses a computer drawing to select people from around the world for up to 55,000 diversity visas. Nigeria is already excluded from the lottery along with other countries that had more than 50,000 natives immigrate to the US in the previous five years.

The existing version of the ban includes the Muslim-majority nations of Iran, Libya, Somalia, Syria, and Yemen. North Korea and Venezuela also face visa restrictions, but those measures affect relatively few travelers.

The current ban suspends immigrant and non-immigrant visas to applicants from the affected countries, but it allows exceptions, including for students and those who have established "significant contacts" in the US. The Venezuelan ban mostly affects government officials and their family members.

Title: President Obama Supports Senate Democrats' Enactment of the "Nuclear Option" to Alter Congressional Rules

Article:

President Barack Obama on Thursday expressed his support for Senate Democrats' move to implement the so-called "nuclear option" and alter congressional rules to expedite the confirmation of judicial and executive nominees.

During remarks in the White House press briefing room, President Obama stated, "Enough is enough. I'm a former senator. So is my vice president. We both value any senator's duty to advise and consent. It's important we take that very seriously. But a few now refuse to treat that duty of advise and consent with the respect it deserves..."

The nuclear option, as described, changes Senate rules and eliminates the possibility of a filibuster for presidential nominees, allowing the White House to swiftly appoint prospective officials who, thus far, have been blocked by Republicans.

The Senate voted 52-48 earlier Thursday in favor of the controversial change, with GOP leaders vehemently objecting and casting the step as a power grab by Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid, Nevada Democrat.

It is important to note that the nuclear option does not extend to Supreme Court nominees. However, Republicans have vowed to utilize the new rules to push through their own high-court picks when a Republican occupies the White House in the future.

The Senate rules fight provides the White House an opportunity to shift the focus away from the ongoing controversy surrounding the botched rollout of Obamacare, which has dominated Washington for the past month. President Obama, who, as a senator, opposed the idea of the nuclear option, stated Thursday's action will help the government function more effectively and should alleviate some of the gridlock that has plagued Washington in recent years.

In related news, the White House has changed its stance on the judge standoff, now backing Senate Democrats' filibuster move, as reported in a separate article titled "White House changes tune on judge standoff, backs Senate Dems' filibuster move."

President Obama concluded, "We can't let it become normal. So I support the step a majority of senators today took to change the way that Washington is doing business. More specifically, the way the Senate does business."

Title: Bipartisan Criticism of Trump's Meeting with Putin

Article:

Following a contentious news conference with Russian President Vladimir Putin, President Donald Trump faced criticism from lawmakers across the political spectrum on Tuesday. Trump, in a series of tweets, defended the meeting and blamed the media for the negative reception.

While Trump praised his meeting with NATO leaders, he claimed that his meeting with Putin was even better. He tweeted, "Sadly, it is not being reported that way - the Fake News is going Crazy!"

Critics, including Sen. Bob Corker (R-Tenn.), the Republican chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations committee, criticized Trump for siding with Putin over U.S. intelligence officials who report that Russians interfered in the 2016 presidential election. Corker called for legislation to counter some of the president's foreign policy moves, including tariffs on imports.

Sen. Rand Paul (R-Ky.) was one of the few Republicans to defend the president after he accepted Putin's denials that Russia interfered in the 2016 election. While taking Putin's side, Trump also condemned the ongoing investigation of Russia as a "disaster" driving a wedge between the United States and Russia.

Even some of Trump's supporters, including former House speaker and long-time Trump backer Newt Gingrich, were dismayed by the Putin news conference. Gingrich tweeted, "President Trump must clarify his statements in Helsinki on our intelligence system and Putin."

At least one Republican, former New Jersey Gov. Christine Todd Whitman, called on Trump to resign, stating, "To deny your own country and government in favor of a foreign leader whose country has, for decades, tried to undermine the United States is irrational and dangerous."

Trump defended his performance at the NATO summit in Brussels, claiming that allies are spending more money on defense at his behest. He also criticized the media and Russia while he was at it. Members of NATO, however, said they were already increasing defense spending, irrespective of Trump. They also questioned Trump's commitment to the alliance and said his critical comments about both NATO and the EU were pleasing to Putin and the Russians.

Vice President Mike Pence defended Trump, stating that disagreements between the countries were discussed at length, but what the world saw was that President Donald Trump will always put the prosperity and security of America first.

Trump has meetings at the White House on Tuesday, but so far is not scheduled to speak publicly. One of Trump's meetings is with a group of congressional lawmakers, though the subject is tax cuts rather than Russia. Several Republicans invited to the White House meeting had, only hours earlier, rebuked Trump over his appearance with Putin.

Title: Republican Leaders Boycott Medicare Cost Committee in Challenge to ObamaCare's IPAB

Article:

In a move challenging a controversial element of the Affordable Care Act, the Republican leaders of the House and Senate announced on Thursday that they will boycott the Individual Payment Advisory Board (IPAB), a committee created to control Medicare costs. The IPAB has been criticized by some as a "death panel," though this term is less commonly used in current discussions.

House Speaker John Boehner and Senate Republican Leader Mitch McConnell, in a letter to President Obama, stated they would not recommend any nominees to the committee and reiterated their belief that it should be repealed entirely. The Republicans expressed concerns that the panel would enforce Medicare cuts by reducing payments to providers and potentially eliminating certain treatments.

The 15-member advisory board, also known as IPAB, would have the power to impose payment cuts on insurers, drug companies, and other service providers if Medicare costs rise beyond certain levels. The health care law explicitly forbids the board from rationing care, shifting costs to seniors, or cutting their benefits. However, Boehner, at a news conference on Thursday, said the members still "have the authority to deny seniors access to care."

It is unclear what impact the boycott will have on the panel. The law states the president should consult with Congress on the nominations, but the president is free to make his own appointments. The members of the board are supposed to be from both parties, and nominees would be subject to Senate confirmation.

White House Press Secretary Jay Carney criticized the Republican stance and their renewed efforts to repeal the health care law. "It just demonstrates again how out of touch with what the American people want the House Republicans have become," Carney said. "Instead of focusing on measures that could help us invest in innovation and manufacturing and job creation, instead of focusing on common-sense efforts to reduce our deficit in a balanced way, House Republicans are voting again to repeal the Affordable Care Act."

Asked about the repeated votes to repeal the law, Boehner said there were about 70 new members of the House this year. "Frankly, they have been asking for an opportunity to vote on it, and we are going to give it to them," Boehner said. He added that he supports total repeal of the law rather than efforts to amend it as it goes into effect over the next year.

Republicans claim there have been only two previous votes to eliminate the health care law in its entirety. They say there have been more than 30 votes to partially repeal or defund the law, and several have been signed into law, including one eliminating an unpopular tax-filing requirement that would have affected millions of businesses. Economists have predicted that the Medicare board's services might not be needed in the near future because Medicare cost increases appear to be manageable.

Title: U.S. Strategy Against ISIS Faces Challenges as Allied Countries Pursue Different Interests

Article:

President Obama met with military leaders from 21 allied countries this week to discuss the ongoing campaign against the Islamic State (ISIS) militants. The group, also known as ISIS, has been gaining ground in Iraq and Syria, prompting questions about the U.S. strategy.

The U.S. strategy against ISIS has its upsides and downsides. The upside is that the U.S. has assembled a coalition of 21 countries to combat the militants. The downside is that not all of these countries share the same interests, leading to differences in strategy and approach.

In the past month, President Obama has outlined his strategy for degrading and defeating ISIS. The U.S. and its allies have reported some successes, such as driving ISIS away from the Mosul Dam in Iraq. However, the president remains concerned about the besieged Syrian town of Kobani and parts of Iraq's Anbar province, where ISIS has been tightening its grip.

Critics, such as Republican Senator John McCain, challenge the president's strategy as ISIS captures more territory in both Syria and Iraq. McCain argues that the Iraqis and the Peshmerga, the Kurdish forces, are not winning, and there needs to be a fundamental reevaluation of the U.S. strategy.

Military analyst Anthony Cordesman at the Center for Strategic and International Studies agrees, stating that the air war has fallen short of what was done in Kosovo or Kuwait. The pace of airstrikes has been slow, with an average of 15 strikes per day, and the majority of the strikes have been against individual weapons systems.

Obama stresses that the campaign to defeat ISIS cannot be waged solely on military terms. The U.S. and its allies must offer political and economic alternatives to the militants. The U.S.-led military effort is being hampered by some of the same sectarian and political divisions that helped give rise to ISIS.

The U.S. and Turkey, for example, have yet to agree on which enemy in Syria is a bigger threat - ISIS or the regime of Bashar al-Assad. In Iraq, Sunni Muslims have yet to join forces with Shiites in battling the militants, despite the formation of a more inclusive Iraqi government. The U.S. strategy depends on cooperation from local ground forces to beat back ISIS.

Michael O'Hanlon of the Brookings Institution warns that airstrikes can only do so much, and ISIS will probably expand its control by a few percent. O'Hanlon suggests a limited presence of U.S. Special Forces and military spotters could be helpful.

Obama has been adamant that he will not order American ground forces into battle, but O'Hanlon argues that a limited presence of U.S. troops could be beneficial. Obama has promised that the U.S. is still in the early stages of what he promises will be a long-term campaign against ISIS.

Title: Former National Security Adviser Michael Flynn's Influence Lingers Over Trump Administration Amid Ongoing Controversy

Article:

The dismissal of former National Security Adviser Michael Flynn from the White House 84 days ago continues to cast a long shadow over President Donald Trump's presidency. Since Flynn's highly publicized dismissal in February, the president has praised him as a "wonderful man" and tweeted in his defense hours before former acting Attorney General Sally Yates testified that she warned the White House that Flynn had been "compromised" by the Russian government.

This continued loyalty from Trump has given Flynn a lingering influence over policy in the White House, where staffers initially hired by Flynn, including his deputy K.T. McFarland, remain on the National Security Council and in other positions. Senior administration officials, including chief strategist Steve Bannon, also remain loyal to Flynn and have worked to undermine his successor, Lt. Gen. H.R. McMaster, according to several people familiar with the situation.

Flynn, a three-star general who was dismissed from his post as Defense Intelligence Agency chief under President Barack Obama in 2014, backed Trump early, campaigned alongside him, and developed a close and trusted relationship with the candidate and his senior aides at a time when few serious Republicans would agree to advise him. "Flynn was by far the most accomplished of all of them, and in the land of the blind, the one-eyed man is king," said a former George W. Bush national security official.

Trump's refusal to disavow Flynn has drawn the administration further into a controversy that began with allegations that Trump campaign aides had inappropriate contacts with Russian government officials. Those claims remain under investigation by congressional committees as well as the FBI.

Flynn's failure to disclose his contacts with officials and payments received from Russian government-related entities has deepened the appearance of scandal around the administration. On Monday, NBC News reported that Flynn failed to disclose to the DIA when it renewed his security clearance last year that he received a check totaling nearly $34,000 from a Russian propaganda network.

Yates told lawmakers on Monday afternoon that she warned the Trump administration that Flynn was susceptible to blackmail, though she declined to say why. She echoed the concerns of Obama, who fired Flynn as head of the DIA in 2014 and warned Trump against hiring him when the two sat down after Trump's victory in November.

The relationship Flynn enjoyed with the president differs markedly from that of his successor, McMaster, who has clashed with the president repeatedly since joining the administration. Trump pushed back against McMaster's attempt to replace McFarland, who is set to become ambassador to Singapore. Last week, it was McFarland, not McMaster, who accompanied the president to a meeting with the Australian prime minister in New York, and Trump and McFarland kept reporters waiting on the tarmac for 40 minutes as they talked inside the plane at Andrews Air Force Base on Sunday night, after the president spent the weekend golfing at his club in New Jersey.

White House chief of staff Reince Priebus earlier this month prevented McMaster from bringing on Brig. Gen. Ricky Waddell as his deputy, and though McFarland was supposed to depart for Singapore in mid-May, she has been telling associates in recent weeks that she's not leaving her NSC post anytime soon.

McMaster has worked to reshape the organization in the wake of Flynn's departure, removing Bannon from the NSC's Principals Committee and eliminating a handful of positions created by Flynn. Executive officer John Reed, a Flynn hire, was reassigned to the Coast Guard last week, and Adam Lovinger, a longtime national security official dispatched to the NSC from the Pentagon at Flynn's request, had his security clearance revoked by Secretary of Defense James Mattis' chief of staff, Kevin Sweeney.

Lovinger, according to internal communications reviewed by [source], had also clashed in recent months with his boss at the Pentagon over the types of issues the office focuses on, urging more attention be given to the threat of Iran and Islamic extremism—two issues on which Flynn was outspoken and controversial both in his career at the Defense Intelligence Agency and on the campaign trail with Trump. In response to questions about Lovinger's status, the Pentagon declined to comment on a personnel issue.

But the president overrode McMaster's decision to reassign the NSC's senior director for intelligence, Ezra Cohen-Watnick, after Bannon and Trump's son-in-law, Jared Kushner, who has taken an increasingly prominent role in foreign affairs, made the case that he should remain in his post.

A senior administration official rejected the notion that McMaster is working to rid the NSC of Flynn aides, pointing to over a dozen Flynn hires who McMaster has kept on board, including Matt Pottinger, the council's senior director for Asia, who received an award at an all-hands meeting last Thursday.

Title: Reflections on the Life and Legacy of Martin Luther King Jr. 50 Years After His Assassination

Article:

Fifty years ago, on April 4, 1968, the world lost one of its most influential and courageous leaders, Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. This article recounts a personal account of how Dr. King's life and work impacted a young, impoverished white boy, who, as an 8-year-old, first became aware of the civil rights leader through news reports.

The individual, who later worked in the White House for two presidents and in politics for over 20 years, recalls watching a news program featuring Dr. King, who had become the youngest person to win the Nobel Peace Prize. The young boy was captivated by Dr. King's empathy, kindness, and the powerful message he delivered to tens of thousands of people.

As Dr. King's civil rights work began, the individual's parents, who were destructively dysfunctional alcoholics but also highly intelligent and educated, provided the young boy with magazines and newspapers featuring Dr. King. The first words of Dr. King that the boy read were his "I Have a Dream" speech.

Growing up in poverty and experiencing discrimination, the boy found solace and inspiration in Dr. King's fight against injustice. Dr. King's teachings about the inherent equality of all people, regardless of race, gender, faith, or sexual orientation, resonated deeply with the young boy.

Fifty years after Dr. King's assassination, the individual reflects on the continued relevance of Dr. King's wisdom, words, and compassion in today's divided and angry society. The individual believes that Dr. King's contributions to the nation and the world have been underestimated and that his stateliness and legacy are needed now more than ever.

Title: Ethiopia Faces Worst Drought in Decades, Affecting Millions and Struggling to Secure Aid

Article:

Ethiopia, a Horn of Africa country, is currently experiencing its worst drought in decades, with millions of people lacking food and drinking water. The situation has been largely overlooked by a world preoccupied with other urgent global crises.

Genet Tamisat, a 27-year-old mother of two, sits in the scorching sun cradling her 2-month-old baby, one of hundreds of mothers waiting for their children to be checked for malnutrition. "I have nothing to eat at home. I can't even buy maize by myself," Tamisat said, also caring for a 4-year-old son. "People can look at us and think we're OK, but we are in great danger. We have nothing."

The government and the United Nations are attempting to raise $1.4 billion to feed 10.2 million Ethiopians, but only half of the required funds have been secured so far. The ongoing conflicts in Syria and Yemen, as well as the migrant crisis, have dominated global headlines, diverting attention from Ethiopia's plight.

Chege Ngugi, national director of the charity ChildFund Ethiopia, expressed concern about the slow pace of fundraising. "My priority is to support the efforts of the government of Ethiopia to save lives, but we're not reaching everybody," he said.

A strong El Niño has disrupted two consecutive rainy seasons that typically nourish crops that feed 85% of the country. The drought has forced the government to seek additional food aid from the United States and other donors.

The U.S. Agency for International Development has dispatched an emergency assistance team to Ethiopia, providing nearly $4 million in corn and wheat seeds for over 200,000 families. In the Oromia region, which includes central Ethiopia, the land is arid, with animal carcasses scattered across patches of dusty earth.

Humanitarian needs in Ethiopia have tripled since the start of 2015, and malnutrition rates in the worst-affected areas have surpassed 20%, exceeding the World Health Organization's emergency threshold of 15%. This year, the food program will help over 2 million children, pregnant women, and breast-feeding mothers suffering from moderate acute malnutrition.

The United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF) estimates that almost 500,000 children need treatment for severe acute malnutrition. Eyoel Lemma, who works at ChildFund Ethiopia in Fentale, noted that providing supplementary food and malnutrition treatment to children under age 5 is challenging due to families migrating in search of water and pasture for their livestock and jobs.

Haso Bultum, a 27-year-old mother, walked for hours in the sun across barren mountains to reach a rural health care facility in Fentale with her malnourished 9-month-old twins. "It's very hard. I've had no sleep, because we're trying to find some food for our cattle," she said. "To save ourselves, we're constantly moving."

Ethiopia has the fastest-growing economy in the world and has lifted millions of citizens out of poverty, but 80% of Ethiopians are still dependent on agriculture. Challiss McDonough, regional spokeswoman for the U.N.'s World Food Programme, warned that her organization could run out of food within two months if significant new funding is not received.

Samuel Ferfu, manager of the Children's and Family Charitable Organization in Fentale, highlighted another major issue: the lack of access to water. Almost 6 million people need emergency water, according to UNICEF. "There's no water at all—the river is dry," he said. "No water makes sanitation impossible, and as a result, the prevalence of disease will increase."

For the time being, Ethiopians are praying for rain, but flooding is a serious risk after a lengthy drought. "Soon the rain will come, and people's worries will be flooding. But they have nothing except their homes to lose. They've already lost all their animals and crops," said Lemma from ChildFund Ethiopia.

For Tamisat and her young children, the prospect of rain in the coming months offers little hope. "We have no water and no food," she said, wiping sweat off her forehead. "I don't know what is coming for the future, but I have no hope about the rain."

Title: Denver City Council Reverses Decision on Marijuana Smoking Ban on Private Property

Article:

Denver officials have rescinded a controversial proposal that would have prohibited smoking marijuana on private property if it was in public view. The Denver City Council on Monday rejected an ordinance that would have restricted marijuana use on front porches, in front yards, or anywhere on private property in public view, according to The Denver Post.

The Denver City Council is expected to take its final vote next week on a revised measure that allows people to smoke marijuana on their properties or with permission from the property owner. Before the reversal, Councilwoman Jeanne Robb had introduced an amendment that would have prohibited marijuana consumption "in any outdoor location on private residential property" where it is "clearly observable from a public street, highway or sidewalk."

Going into Monday's vote, at least six of the 13 city council members were leaning toward the rule, with Councilman Charlie Brown seen as a swing vote. However, the Council voted 7-6 Monday in favor of an amendment reversing Robb's language banning marijuana use on private property.

Colorado, along with Washington state, legalized the possession of up to one ounce of recreational marijuana for people 21 and older in 2012, despite it still being illegal under federal law. Advocates of a public ban, like Robb, believe seeing people smoke marijuana would send the wrong message to children and teens and that it would paint the city in a negative smoky haze.

Opponents, like Mason Tvert, communications director for the Marijuana Policy Project, argue that the amendment strips away the rights voted by residents of Colorado to consume cannabis. "Questions on where adults should use marijuana is a valid question," Tvert told FoxNews.com. "There are likely proposals that may or may not make sense. The one in Denver does not."

While it may be legal to consume alcohol on a porch or in the outdoor area of a bar, there are numerous laws across the country banning public drunkenness. And in most cities, it is illegal to carry an open container of alcohol outside your own property. Cigarette smokers, though, rarely encounter such regulations.

Denver Police Chief Robert White has said if the front porch rule is voted in, it will be among the city's lowest priorities, and he doesn't expect many – if any – citations will ever be written.

As Colorado prepares for the start of legal pot sales on Jan. 1, Washington state is also gearing up for the start of marijuana sales by 2014. So far, there haven't been any local efforts to stop the production, sales, or use in that state, but many in the area are likely to study the lessons and tactics used in the Denver fight.

Officials in Chicago are also getting a jump-start on creating strict regulations about where pot can be grown and dispensed. The city's Department of Planning and Development has been working on legislation in anticipation of a state law taking effect that would make Illinois the 20th state in the country to allow medical marijuana use. The Chicago measure must still be voted on and approved by the Chicago City Council. If approved, it would allow 22 centers where cannabis can be grown in the city, with the same measure prohibiting them from opening within 2,500 feet of any school, day care center, or residential area.

Title: Conservative Media Faces Calls for Improved Journalistic Integrity at CPAC

Article:

The conservative media is undergoing a period of introspection, with leading figures in the right-wing media sphere acknowledging a need for greater journalistic integrity. This issue has gained national attention following last year's election and the subsequent failed efforts to discredit figures such as Chuck Hagel, now President Obama's Secretary of Defense.

At the annual Conservative Political Action Conference (CPAC), representatives from prominent conservative news outlets, including Fox News, Townhall, and The Daily Caller, will gather to discuss the future of conservative media. The panel, titled "Survivor: Conservative Journalism," is a side event in the larger CPAC calendar, but it addresses one of the most pressing issues facing the Republican Party: the need for conservative media outlets to gain more recognition and credibility among mainstream media.

Keith Urbahn, a former chief of staff to Donald Rumsfeld and one of Friday's panelists, stated, "That the conservative movement now has its own media outlets is a terrific thing. But with that comes a basic responsibility to report facts and admit error—something we slam the mainstream media for all the time. We don't always live up to those standards."

In late February, influential Red State blogger Erick Erickson argued that conservative journalists had "forgotten the basics of reporting" because they were "trying so hard to highlight controversies, no matter how trivial." Similarly, The New Yorker editor Alex Koppelman argued that right-wing journalists would have to take the "commitment to journalism more seriously" if they wanted "to be taken more seriously."

These columns were written after the conservative website Breitbart.com published articles alleging that Hagel had received funding from a group called "Friends of Hamas." The group turned out to be non-existent—a fact easily uncovered by a few minutes of basic reporting.

Erickson told ███ that conservatives need to focus on building up "good journalists committed to the basics." Katie Pavlich, the news editor of Townhall and one of Friday's panelists, likewise told ███ that "moving forward, solid and documented investigative reporting will be key in gaining even more credibility throughout the industry."

Title: Trump's Criticism of NFL and NBA Players Sparks Controversy

Article:

President Donald Trump faced criticism from professional athletes over the weekend following his comments about NFL and NBA players during a campaign rally in Alabama on Friday night. Trump's remarks, which included calling for the firing of NFL players who kneel during the national anthem and withdrawing a White House invitation to NBA star Stephen Curry, sparked a series of responses from athletes on social media.

At the rally, Trump criticized NFL free agent Colin Kaepernick, saying that players who kneel during the national anthem should be fired and that fans should leave games. Several NFL players responded to Trump's comments on Twitter, while commissioner Roger Goodell issued a statement condemning Trump's "divisive" rhetoric.

"The NFL and our players are at our best when we help create a sense of unity in our country and our culture," Goodell said. "There is no better example than the amazing response from our clubs and players to the terrible natural disasters we've experienced over the last month."

Meanwhile, Trump stirred conflict early Saturday by announcing via Twitter that Curry was no longer welcome at the White House after the Golden State Warriors point guard said he did not want to pay the president a visit, a tradition for championship teams. NBA players, including LeBron James and Stephen Curry himself, clapped back at Trump, with James calling Trump a "bum" and saying that visiting the White House was an honor "until you showed up."

Curry had told reporters on Friday that he did not want to go to the White House, and said in June that he "probably would not visit the White House due to Trump's stances on a variety of issues."

"By not going, hopefully it will inspire some change for what we tolerate in this country and what we stand for, what is accepted and what we turn a blind eye toward," he said. "It's not just the act of not going. There are things you have to do on the back end to push that message into motion."

A formal White House invitation has not been issued to the Warriors, however the NBA has been communicating with the White House about a visit, according to ESPN.

Trump's feuding with the NFL and NBA athletes came as his party's latest efforts to make good on their promise to repeal and replace ObamaCare stumbled, with Sen. John McCain coming out against the plan on Friday. McCain's opposition potentially dooms the bill sponsored by Sens. Bill Cassidy and Lindsey Graham, which GOP leaders had hoped to vote on in the coming week.

Trump swiped at McCain several times during the rally in Alabama, where he was campaigning for Sen. Luther Strange ahead of the Senate GOP primary runoff on Tuesday. The president called McCain's opposition "terrible," while vowing that Republicans would replace his predecessor's signature health-care law "eventually."

The head of the NBA Players Association, Chris Paul, also slammed the president's remarks, questioning whether the president would call players "a son of a b----" to their face. With everything that's going on in our country, why are YOU focused on who's kneeling and visiting the White House? # StayInYoLane, Paul tweeted.

The controversy over Trump's comments about NFL and NBA players comes as the president faces growing criticism from both sides of the aisle over his handling of various issues, including his response to the recent natural disasters and his comments about Charlottesville.

Title: U.S. Middle Class Struggles to Recover from Financial Crisis, Despite Resilient Consumer Spending

Article:

The economic impact of the 2008 financial crisis on American families has been further illuminated in a recent survey, with economist Jared Bernstein, an adviser to Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., stating that the details "underscore how devastating this has been for the middle class." The survey reveals that while consumer spending has remained surprisingly resilient, families saved less and only slowly repaid debts.

The survey indicates a decline in the number of families saving anything over the previous year, with the share falling from 56.4 percent in 2007 to 52 percent in 2010. This suggests that a smaller group of families is saving more money, while a growing number manage to save nothing. Total savings have increased since 2007, but this increase is due to a smaller number of families saving more, not an overall increase in savings.

The survey also shows a shift in the reasons families save money. More families are saving as a precautionary measure, to ensure they have enough liquidity to meet short-term needs. Fewer families are saving for retirement, education, or for a down payment on a home.

The report also highlights the limited progress households have made in reducing debt. The share of households reporting any debt declined by 2.1 percentage points over the last three years, but 74.9 percent of households still owe something, and the median amount did not change.

The decline in reported incomes could have increased the weight of those debts, tying up a larger share of families' take-home pay. However, historically lower interest rates have helped to offset this effect. Families have also been able to reduce debt payments by refinancing into mortgages with longer terms and deferring repayment of student loans and other obligations.

The survey confirms that Americans are shifting the kinds of debts they carry. The share of families with credit card debt declined by 6.7 percentage points to 39.4 percent, and the median balance fell 16.1 percent to $2,600. Conversely, the share of families with education-related debt rose to 19.2 percent in 2010 from 15.2 percent in 2007. Education loans now make up a larger share of the average family's obligations than loans to buy automobiles for the first time in the history of the survey.

The cumulative statistics conceal large disparities in the impact of the crisis. Families with incomes in the middle 60 percent of the population lost a larger share of their wealth over the three-year period than the wealthiest and poorest families. The wealth of the middle class is mostly in housing, and the median amount of home equity dropped to $75,000 in 2010 from $110,000 in 2007. Housing prices have hardly budged since the crisis.

Those middle-income families also lost a larger share of their income. The earnings of the median family in the bottom 20 percent of the income distribution actually increased from 2007 to 2010, in part because of the expansion of government aid programs during the recession. Wealthier families, which derive more income from investments, were also cushioned against the recession.

The data does provide the latest indication that the recession reduced income inequality in the United States, at least temporarily. The average income of the wealthiest families fell much more sharply than the median, indicating that some at the very top of the ladder slipped down at least a few rungs.

Ranking American families by income, the top 10 percent of households still earned an average of $349,000 in 2010, with an average net worth of $2.9 million.

Title: GOP Faces Tax Hike Reality as Obama Negotiations Progress

Article:

With three weeks remaining before the expiration of the Bush tax rates and potential spending cuts for the Pentagon and federal agencies totaling tens of billions of dollars, a reality for the Republican Party has emerged: Tax rates are increasing, and the primary question is by how much and for whom.

Discussions on Capitol Hill and K Street revolve around a slight increase in marginal tax rates, which would be coupled with raising the threshold for wealthy Americans facing tax increases from $250,000 to $500,000 or higher in annual income. However, any rate increase for Republicans, one that could garner support from rank-and-file lawmakers, would necessitate significant cuts to entitlement programs. As of yet, there is no evidence that President Barack Obama and the Democrats have agreed to specific entitlement cuts in closed-door negotiations, particularly those substantial enough to offset a rate change and an increase in the threshold for the wealthy.

"Both sides have to hold hands and jump on this one," said a top Senate aide.

If House Speaker John Boehner (R-Ohio) and Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.) fail to reach an agreement with Obama, the highest marginal tax rate will increase from 35 percent to 39.6 percent on January 1, the same as it was under former President Bill Clinton. Tax rates on estates will also surge, and nearly 30 million more Americans will be affected by the alternative minimum tax, initially designed to ensure wealthier individuals and families did not completely avoid federal taxes.

The proposed modest tax hikes in exchange for entitlement cuts have numerous issues, according to GOP Hill aides, who emphasized that this trade-off has not been formally presented yet.

First, Democrats believe they are in a position of strength during these negotiations and are unlikely to relinquish concessions on entitlement programs without significant moves from Boehner.

"We are winning," said a top Hill Democratic staffer. "We don't have to give up on anything yet."

Boehner also faces pressure from his right and is concerned whether House Majority Leader Eric Cantor (R-Va.) and Budget Committee Chairman Paul Ryan (R-Wis.) will support him. He has so far refused to agree to any increase in tax rates, even though many in his party are acknowledging such an outcome as unavoidable. The best Republicans can do, these lawmakers say, is limit the size of the increases while attempting to shift the political blame to the Democrats.

"The speaker is opposed to raising tax rates, because raising tax rates costs jobs," said Michael Steel, spokesman for Boehner.

Any suggestion of Republicans backing a tax increase faces opposition in the Senate.

"That doesn't really help solve the problem," said Sen. Orrin Hatch (R-Utah), ranking member of the powerful Finance Committee. "I'm against raising tax rates. We know that if we raise those tax rates and we don't have corresponding reductions in spending, we'll get the tax rates and no spending reductions. That's just a game that the Democrats play over and over and over, and the American people let them get away with it sometimes."

Title: Senate Republicans Incorporate Obamacare Individual Mandate Repeal in Tax Cut Bill

Article:

Senate Republicans have revised their tax cut bill to include the repeal of the individual mandate under the Affordable Care Act (Obamacare). This move, which was pushed by President Trump, is expected to generate over $300 billion in savings over the next decade that can be used for deeper tax cuts for average Americans.

The Senate's top leaders, including Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, have expressed optimism about the move, stating that it will provide more tax relief to individuals. However, Democrats have criticized the move, with Senate Minority Leader Charles E. Schumer stating that it will raise premiums for middle-class Americans and potentially leave 13 million people without health care coverage.

The tax cut bill, as revised, amounts to a $1.5 trillion tax cut over 10 years, with about 60% going to businesses and the rest to individual taxpayers. The plan slashes the corporate tax rate from 35% to 20% and lowers the top individual rate from 39.6% to 38.5%, while adjusting other individual tax brackets so they kick in at higher income thresholds.

The revised plan also includes a doubling of the child tax credit from the current $1,000 to $2,000, and some other tweaks to individual tax rates. The plan also makes changes so more "pass-through" companies that file their taxes as individuals can claim a new 17.4% deduction, designed to give a boost to small businesses.

The plan eliminates a number of deductions, such as the one for state and local taxes paid, and uses the savings to pay for lowering the rates. With the plan bumping up against the $1.5 trillion cap set in the 2018 budget for tax cuts, lawmakers were left searching for new ways to free up money to do more for the middle class.

The individual mandate plan, which the Congressional Budget Office said would save the government over $300 billion over the next 10 years, was seen by some Republicans as a natural solution to their failure this year to repeal Obamacare in its entirety.

The House tax bill that advanced out of the Ways and Means Committee last week did not include a repeal of the mandate, though some Republicans have expressed a desire to include it in the discussion as leaders prepare for a floor vote in the House this week. House Speaker Paul D. Ryan stated that the House is pushing the bill "as we have it," though he described things as a work in progress. The House plan also lowers the corporate tax rate to 20% immediately, while the Senate version delays it for one year. The House also includes a full repeal of the estate tax on inheritances, while the Senate doubles the exemption rate but leaves the tax in place.

Title: Clinton's Testimony on Benghazi Attack: A Look into the Democratic Mindset

Article:

Last week, former Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton appeared before two congressional panels to discuss the events that transpired at the U.S. Consulate in Benghazi, Libya, on September 11, 2012. During the hearing, Clinton was questioned about the administration's initial response to the attack, which was characterized as a spontaneous protest sparked by an offensive YouTube video.

On that fateful day, the consulate was overrun by heavily armed terrorists, who killed the U.S. ambassador and set the building on fire. Following the attack, dozens of Americans fled to a more heavily fortified annex nearby, but U.S. forces did not intervene during the next 10 hours, resulting in the deaths of three more individuals, including two Navy SEALs.

For weeks, the White House and top administration officials maintained that the assault was a spontaneous response to a video posted on YouTube that Muslims found offensive. However, during a Senate hearing, Clinton was asked why the administration had provided faulty information for such a prolonged period. In response, Clinton became visibly upset and stated, "With all due respect, the fact is we had four dead Americans. Was it because of a protest or was it because of guys out for a walk one night decided to go kill some Americans? What difference, at this point, does it make?"

The hearing was intended to be a fact-finding mission, with lawmakers seeking to understand what went wrong and, if possible, the cause of the deadly blunder. They also aimed to hear from Clinton about the administration's initial assertion that a video caused an impromptu protest that led to the death of the U.S. ambassador.

During the hearing, Clinton made it clear that she did not feel accountable to elected lawmakers or the American people. "What difference does it make?" she exclaimed. Clinton's response was met with criticism, as many felt that the hearing was intended to determine why the administration had initially attributed the attack to a video-sparked protest.

In the days preceding the hearing, senators had made it clear that they planned to ask about the administration's initial response to the attack. Clinton, however, maintained that it was less important to understand the motivations of the attackers than to find and bring them to justice.

The hearing served as a glimpse into the Democratic mindset, with some viewing Clinton's response as a reflection of the party's tendency to prioritize their goals above all else, even if it means bending or outright lying about the truth. This approach has been a hallmark of the Clinton family's political career, with past instances of alleged dishonesty, such as Bill Clinton's affair with a White House intern and Hillary Clinton's cattle futures contracts, being downplayed or dismissed.

As the 2016 presidential race approaches, some political analysts see Clinton's response to the Benghazi hearing as a potential indicator of the type of candidate she may be in the future. Critics argue that her unwillingness to answer questions and her dismissive attitude towards lawmakers' inquiries could set a dangerous precedent for a potential Clinton presidency.

Title: Roger Ailes, Founder of Fox News, Dies at 77

Roger Ailes, the Ohio-born television pioneer who founded Fox News and built it into the nation's long-running No. 1 cable news network, died Thursday morning at the age of 77. The cause of death was complications from a fall at his home on May 10, according to the Palm Beach County Medical Examiner's Office.

Ailes, a confidant of presidents and an acknowledged master of communications, resigned from Fox in July amid charges of sexual harassment. His widow, Elizabeth Ailes, confirmed the news in a statement.

"I am profoundly sad and heartbroken to report that my husband, Roger Ailes, passed away this morning," the statement read. "Roger was a loving husband to me, to his son Zachary, and a loyal friend to many. He was also a patriot, profoundly grateful to live in a country that gave him so much opportunity to work hard, to rise—and to give back."

Rupert Murdoch, executive chairman of 21st Century Fox and Fox News Channel, said he was saddened by the development.

"Everybody at Fox is shocked and grieved by the death of Roger Ailes," Murdoch said. "A brilliant broadcaster, Roger played a huge role in shaping America's media over the last 30 years. He will be remembered by the many people on both sides of the camera he discovered, nurtured, and promoted."

Sean Hannity, a Fox News host, tweeted tributes to his onetime boss in a series of messages.

"Today, America lost one of its great patriotic warriors," Hannity tweeted. "He has dramatically and forever changed the political and the media landscape, single-handedly for the better."

Ailes was born in Warren, Ohio, and attended Ohio University in Athens, where he majored in radio and television. After graduating in 1962, he launched his career in black and white-era television by working for then-local personality Mike Douglas. When the show was syndicated a few years later, Ailes' star rose with it.

It was during a 1967 taping of "The Mike Douglas Show" that Ailes met future president Richard Nixon, who later tapped him to serve as his executive producer for television. That experience began a decades-long dual track in which Ailes cast long shadows over both television and politics, culminating in his founding of Fox News.

In 1984, Ailes worked on President Reagan's re-election campaign. Four years later, he was a key player in the successful presidential campaign of George H.W. Bush, helping to plot effective messaging and television advertising strategies. He later helped build CNBC before Murdoch chose him to launch Fox News.

As recently as last fall's election, and after his career at Fox had ended, Ailes reportedly advised President Trump in preparation for debates. Ailes and Elizabeth were married in 1998. Their only son, Zachary, was born on New Year's Day 2000.

Title: State Department Releases Previously Undisclosed Emails from Hillary Clinton's Tenure as Secretary of State

Article:

The State Department has released 44 previously undisclosed email exchanges from Hillary Clinton's tenure as Secretary of State. These emails were not included in the 30,000 private messages Clinton handed over to the government last year. The emails show Clinton interacting with lobbyists, political and Clinton Foundation donors, and business interests during her time as Secretary of State.

The conservative legal group Judicial Watch obtained the emails as part of its lawsuit against the State Department. The emails cover Clinton's first three months as Secretary of State in early 2009, a period for which Clinton did not turn over any emails to the State Department last year. The government found the newly disclosed messages during a search of agency computer files from longtime Clinton aide Huma Abedin.

One instance shows Clinton exchanging messages with a senior Morgan Stanley investment executive whom she met with later that year at her office in Washington. These emails were among 246 pages of Abedin messages turned over to Judicial Watch.

Clinton campaign officials did not immediately answer questions about the issue.

The emails are separate from a larger batch of several thousand work-related emails that FBI officials recovered from Clinton's private server. Clinton's legal team turned over more than 30,000 emails from her server to the State Department last March but only after deleting another 30,000 messages that Clinton's team deemed private and personal. The FBI plans to turn over the reconstructed Clinton emails to the State Department for public release.

The new Clinton emails include a February 2009 message to her from Stephen Roach, then-chairman of Morgan Stanley Asia, saying he planned to testify to Congress that week and was "happy to help in any way I can." Roach later met with Clinton over the summer for 30 minutes, according to Clinton calendars obtained by The Associated Press.

In another email, Clinton's chief of staff, Cheryl Mills, informed her that National Security Agency and State Department officials discussed an attempt to develop a modified Blackberry for Clinton that might be used when she worked in a restricted State Department office that did not allow private phones. Clinton called the development "good news," but she continued using a private Blackberry tied to her private server.

Title: Report Suggests John Podesta's Email Hack Resulted from Phishing Attack

Article:

A new report suggests that the hacking of John Podesta's email account, which led to the release of thousands of emails belonging to the Democratic National Convention and later, the Clinton campaign chair, was the result of a common phishing attack. According to a report by Motherboard, a security firm, SecureWorks, investigating the hackings, found that Podesta had fallen prey to a phishing attack set up by a Russian hacking ring known as Fancy Bear.

The group reportedly sent several members of Hillary Clinton's inner-circle emails in March with a custom Bitly link leading to a fake Gmail login page. Podesta had clicked on the link and entered his password, thus giving the hackers unfettered access to his account.

Fancy Bear, also known as APT28 and Sofacy, was also allegedly behind a similar attack on the Democratic National Committee (DNC) last summer. Thomas Rid, a professor at King's College, wrote in Esquire that the group made its "gravest mistake" by forgetting to set the Bitly links to private, allowing investigators to see whom else the group had targeted.

The Russian government is believed to be sponsoring the attacks and disseminating the information to Clinton's foes, including WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange. A Clinton spokesman stated, "There is no longer any doubt that Putin is trying to help Donald Trump by weaponizing WikiLeaks."

The threat of Russian espionage has become one of the key issues in the 2016 election, not just because it reveals critical weaknesses in America's cyber-security, but also because it highlights how Russia has sought to tilt the presidential election in favor of Donald Trump. John Podesta, for one, is not making matters easier. It is hoped that the next time the 67-year-old former chief of staff to Bill Clinton and Barack Obama receives an email with a funny-looking link, he thinks twice before clicking.

Title: Governors Divided on Trump's Plan for Reopening Economies Amidst COVID-19 Pandemic

Article:

As the death toll from COVID-19 continues to rise, governors across the United States are grappling with the challenge of reopening their economies while ensuring the safety of their citizens. On Thursday, the White House released a three-phase plan outlining guidelines for when states might reopen. During a call with governors, President Trump suggested states should begin easing restrictions after a 14-day decline in new COVID-19 cases.

The response to the plan varied by party. Democratic governors generally expressed concern that it was too early to provide a timeline for reopening and called for more testing support from the federal government. Republican governors, while urging caution, were more optimistic about the possibility of a swift return to normalcy.

New Mexico Gov. Michelle Lujan Grisham, a Democrat, stated, "We appreciate their suggestions, and we will evaluate them thoroughly, but the plain overriding fact is we cannot put the cart before the horse." She emphasized that the Centers for Disease Control, Federal Emergency Management Agency, and public health experts across the country have not yet deemed it safe to reopen, and doing so prematurely would endanger many more people and potentially lead to increased transmission of the virus.

New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo, also a Democrat, expressed the need for federal help in fully reopening the state's economy. He accused President Trump of "passing the buck without passing the bucks." In response, Trump tweeted, "Governor Cuomo should spend more time 'doing' and less time 'complaining.'"

Washington state recently extended its stay-at-home order to early May. Democratic Gov. Jay Inslee told NPR's All Things Considered that two conditions would need to be met before the state could reopen its economy: a significant reduction in infections and a comprehensive and robust testing and contact-tracing system. Inslee stated that the contact tracing system is dependent on widespread testing, which does not currently exist in the United States.

Colorado Gov. Jared Polis, a Democrat, told NPR's Morning Edition that the federal guidelines resemble the plan the state adopted the day before. Polis expressed a desire for a national testing strategy, stating, "Most other countries are doing it nationally." He added, "I wish that we had more help from the federal government."

In North Carolina, Democratic Gov. Roy Cooper said he appreciated the White House's guidance but noted the need for more federal assistance with testing and personal protective equipment. Oregon Gov. Kate Brown echoed other Democratic governors' calls for more federal aid.

In contrast to Democrats, the response from Republican governors was more enthusiastic. Tennessee Gov. Bill Lee stated, "I think the president and his team are headed in a very good direction." Iowa Gov. Kim Reynolds said her takeaway from the call with Trump was that the federal government is a partner. Nebraska Gov. Pete Ricketts and Idaho Gov. Brad Little also expressed support for the president's guidelines.

On Friday, Texas Gov. Greg Abbott announced a series of executive orders that would start to reopen shuttered businesses, making Texas the first state to lay out a defined rollback of COVID-19 restrictions. Retail outlets in the state will be able to open on April 24, as long as they can deliver items to customers' cars or homes to minimize contact. Texas will also loosen restrictions on surgeries, permitting procedures that would not deplete the hospital capacity or the personal protective equipment needed to cope with COVID-19.

Title: President Trump Accuses Media of Pushing "Radical Left Democrat Views" in Response to Coverage of Congresswomen Attacks

Article:

President Donald Trump took to Twitter on Monday to lash out at the media, particularly The Washington Post, as he continued his attacks on four progressive congresswomen. In a series of tweets, the president claimed the "Mainstream Media" has "gone bonkers" and accused the media of pushing "Radical Left Democrat views."

"They have gone bonkers, and no longer care what is right or wrong," Trump tweeted. "This large scale false reporting is sick!" He added, "Fake News Equals the Enemy of the People!"

For the second consecutive day, Trump pushed back on a Washington Post story recounting the fallout of his incendiary tweets targeting Reps. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez (D-N.Y.), Ilhan Omar (D-Minn.), Rashida Tlaib (D-Mich.), and Ayanna Pressley (D-Mass.). He went on to decry "fake news" as "the Enemy of the People."

Trump took issue with a line of The Washington Post piece that said advisers wrote out talking points and handed the president "reams of opposition research on the four Congresswomen." However, a photo taken by a Post photographer last week showed Trump at a White House event with sheets of paper containing bullet points of information about Omar and the other representatives.

The president followed up his criticism of the Post story with broader condemnation of the press, accusing it of pushing "Radical Left Democrat views." Trump frequently describes coverage he deems unfavorable as "fake news," and has regularly labeled certain media outlets the "enemy of the people" despite warnings from press advocates about the danger of the term.

Trump has been preoccupied for days with the media coverage of his attacks on the four congresswomen, which began with tweets eight days ago saying the lawmakers should "go back" to their countries despite all four being U.S. citizens. Only Omar, who came to the U.S. as a Somali refugee, was born outside the U.S. Trump has escalated his attacks in the days since, claiming repeatedly that the lawmakers hate the country and defending supporters who chanted "send her back" about Omar as "incredible patriots."

Title: Giuliani Clarifies: No Pardons for Russia Investigation Targets During Ongoing Inquiry

Article:

WASHINGTON – President Donald Trump's lead attorney, Rudy Giuliani, clarified on Sunday that the president will not issue pardons to targets in the ongoing investigation into Russia's interference in the 2016 election during the inquiry.

"The president is not going to issue a pardon in this investigation," Giuliani said. "I want that to come out loud and clear."

However, Giuliani, in an appearance on CNN's State of the Union, left open the possibility that the president could take action when the Russia inquiry is concluded if he determines that people had been "treated unfairly."

"You are not going to get a pardon just because you are involved in this investigation," the outspoken former New York mayor said, before quickly adding that those targets "certainly won't be excluded."

Giuliani raised the prospect of pardons late last week, after former Trump campaign chairman Paul Manafort was jailed for violating terms of his bail in Washington. Manafort is awaiting a September trial on money laundering and fraud charges. He also faces a July trial in Alexandria, Va., where he is charged with bank and tax fraud.

A federal judge revoked Manafort's $10 million bond on Friday after he was charged with obstruction for allegedly tampering with witnesses in the pending criminal cases against him.

Manafort is one of 20 people known to be charged in the yearlong Russia investigation. Five people, including former national security adviser Michael Flynn and Trump campaign deputy Rick Gates, have pleaded guilty.

"When the whole thing is over, things might get cleaned up with some presidential pardons," Giuliani told the New York Daily News. "You put a guy in jail if he’s trying to kill witnesses, not just talking to witnesses."

Giuliani also renewed his attacks on the legitimacy of the Russia investigation headed by Justice Department special counsel Robert Mueller. Citing findings in last week's Justice Department inspector general's report related to the conduct of two senior FBI agents, the former mayor called for a review of the origins of the Russia investigation.

The inspector general, during an 18-month review of the handling of the Hillary Clinton email investigation, unearthed text messages exchanged by the agents in which they disparaged Trump. Both of the agents held top positions in both the FBI's Clinton and Trump investigations.

In one of the messages, FBI counter-intelligence official Peter Strzok suggested that he might take action to "stop" Trump's candidacy.

"We want the Mueller probe to be investigated," Giuliani said Sunday.

Later Sunday, Giuliani said on CBS' Face the Nation that he would continue to push for such an internal review as a condition in the ongoing negotiations with Mueller who is seeking an interview with Trump in the Russia inquiry.

As part of that investigation, Mueller's team is reviewing whether Trump sought to obstruct the probe when he fired FBI Director James Comey last year.

"We are in rather sensitive negotiations," Giuliani said, adding that it was important to first learn whether Strzok had "infected" the Russia investigation before he was removed last year.

"I don't want to do it," Giuliani said, referring to a Mueller interview with Trump. "The president wants to do it."

The former mayor said a decision on a possible interview would likely be made by July 4.

Title: Democrats Raise Record Funds in Third Quarter, Outpace Republicans in Congressional Elections

Article:

In the final stretch of the 2018 midterm elections, Democrats have raised substantial funds, with 60 of their candidates raising over $1 million in the last three months, a significant increase from the $1 million that was once the standard for congressional candidates during the administration of President George W. Bush. This surge in fundraising has erased the Republicans' typical fundraising edge, as Democrats capitalize on an energized base of small donors.

In Fresno, California, prosecutor Andrew Janz, a Democrat, raised an impressive $4.1 million in the third quarter. He is challenging eight-term Republican Rep. Devin Nunes, the chair of the House Intelligence Committee and a staunch ally of President Trump. Janz's donor base is widespread, with support coming from various parts of the country and state.

Similarly impressive fundraising numbers have been announced by other Democratic challengers. Sharice Davids, in an eastern Kansas district, raised $2.7 million. Amy McGrath, in central Kentucky, raised $3.65 million. Elissa Slotkin, in southern Michigan, raised $2.6 million.

Compiled spending numbers offer some good news and some bad news for the Republicans. The Congressional Leadership Fund, a GOP super PAC aligned with House Republicans, has spent $90 million on the general-election campaign, compared to $51 million by its Democratic rival, the House Majority PAC. However, the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee (DCCC) has outspent the National Republican Congressional Committee (NRCC) $64 million to $47 million. Furthermore, Democratic House candidates, fueled by small-donor contributions, have outspent Republican candidates $109 million to $60 million.

Former DCCC chair Steve Israel stated, "The Republican super PACs may not be able to just write a single check to buy a single race because of the massive grassroots fundraising energy behind Democrats this year."

While fundraising success does not guarantee Democrats an easy path to victory, most of them are challenging incumbents, who have previously won on the same terrain. Andrew Janz's opponent, Devin Nunes, was reelected two years ago with a 35-point margin, and a recent poll showed Nunes leading Janz by 8 points.

Janz initially focused on building a robust fundraising operation because, as he stated, "we knew that the national party and the DCCC were not going to be supporting us."

As the election approaches, both parties are starting the process of reallocating super PAC and party funds from candidates who have failed to gain momentum. For some House Republicans, the race may be virtually over, with Reps. Rod Blum of Iowa, Mike Coffman of Colorado, and Mike Bishop of Michigan among those who have lost support as the NRCC and CLF cancel ad buys and shift dollars to other contests with better prospects.

Tom Davis, a former Republican congressman who worked two election cycles as chairman of the NRCC, suggested the script for the NRCC chair as he delivers bad news to a colleague in the House Republican Conference: "We thought we'd be able to do a million dollars in TV, but now we have to put that somewhere else because frankly, you're just not performing, and we can't afford to waste it to make you feel good."

Title: Fox News: Ailes' Departure and Shine's Promotion Raise Questions About Culture Change

Article:

Following the departure of former Fox News co-founder Roger Ailes, the network has undergone significant changes, with some employees interpreting the events as a shift in the company's culture, while others view it as an attempt to move past the sexual harassment allegations that led to Ailes' exit.

Ailes, who was known for his close associate Bill Shine, was succeeded by interim CEO Rupert Murdoch after his departure. In a move that seemed counter-intuitive to some, the Murdochs, who are the sons of Rupert Murdoch and are still commonly referred to as "the Boys," promoted Shine and Fox Television Stations executive Jack Abernethy to co-presidents of Fox News.
