The company also retained Dianne Brandi, the general counsel, and Suzanne Scott, executive vice president of programming and development.

These moves have raised questions about the extent of the culture change at Fox News. Some within the network view the swift removal of Ailes as a concession to the Murdoch sons, particularly James Murdoch, who reportedly was not a fan of Ailes' role in promoting Donald Trump and was troubled by the aging demographics of Fox News' audience.

According to three people briefed on the matter, the company provided Paul, Weiss lawyers with a list of women to speak to during their internal investigation. The promotion of Shine, who was reportedly implicated in the allegations made by former Fox booker Laurie Luhn, has been a subject of debate, with some questioning whether the Murdochs vetted him thoroughly before making the appointment.

As the internal investigation continues, it remains to be seen how these changes will impact the future of Fox News and the extent to which the network will undergo a cultural transformation.

Title: White Nationalists Rally at University of Virginia, Clash with Counter-Protesters

Article:

Hundreds of white nationalists gathered at the University of Virginia on Friday, protesting against plans to remove a statue of Confederate General Robert E. Lee. The group, which chanted "White lives matter" and "You will not replace us," marched through the Charlottesville university, leading to clashes with counter-protesters.

The event, organized by Jason Kessler, who has previously accused the town of "anti-white hatred," was described by Kessler as an "incredible moment for white people who've had it up to here and are not going to take it anymore."

The New York Times and Washington Post reported that the crowd also chanted "Jew will not replace us" during the event. Demonstrators held lit torches, some of which were seen as a reference to the Ku Klux Klan, and chanted "Blood and soil" and "One people, one nation, end immigration."

A smaller group of counter-protesters had gathered, surrounding the university's statue of Thomas Jefferson, holding a banner that read "VA Students Act Against White Supremacy." The marchers and counter-protesters clashed violently, with one counter-protester reportedly spraying pepper spray at the marchers.

The rally was met with criticism from many local residents and politicians. Charlottesville mayor Mike Signer called the march "a cowardly parade of hatred, bigotry, racism, and intolerance." He wrote on Facebook, "Everyone has a right under the First Amendment to express their opinion peaceably, so here's mine: not only as the Mayor of Charlottesville, but as a UVA faculty member and alumnus, I am beyond disgusted by this unsanctioned and despicable display of visual intimidation on a college campus."

Charlottesville is considered a liberal college town, with 86% of the county voting for Hillary Clinton in last year's presidential elections. However, the town has become a focal point for white nationalists after the city council voted to remove a statue of General Lee.

Some observers also argue that President Donald Trump's election to the White House re-energized the far right across the US. Last month, Ku Klux Klan supporters staged a march in Virginia but were outnumbered by counter-protesters.

Title: Trump to Call for International Pressure on North Korea, Criticize Iran and Venezuela at UN General Assembly

Article:

U.S. President Donald Trump is set to address the United Nations General Assembly later today, his first speech to the world body. The address will take place at 10:30 New York time (14:30 GMT). According to White House officials, Trump will refer to Islamist militants as "losers" and criticize Iran and Venezuela in his speech.

Trump has previously hinted at the possibility of the U.S. cutting its UN funding. UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres has stated that if the U.S. withdraws from international affairs, the void left will be filled by others.

In his speech, Trump is expected to call on UN member states to act against North Korea's "destabilizing, hostile, and dangerous behavior." North Korea stated on Monday that more sanctions and pressure would only make it accelerate its nuclear program. The country has conducted repeated missile tests this year and its sixth nuclear test earlier this month.

Trump will also express concern about Iran in his speech. Last week, he stated that Iran had "violated the spirit" of a 2015 deal aimed at stopping it from developing a nuclear weapon. The U.S. president has been a frequent critic of the agreement.

U.S. Secretary of State Rex Tillerson stated last week in London that Iran was not contributing positively to regional security "through their actions to prop up the Assad regime [in Syria]," by engaging in "malicious activities in the region," and by "aggressively developing ballistic missiles."

A White House official briefing reporters on Trump's speech stated that Iran and North Korea presented a "shared menace" to the world. The official was quoted by Reuters news agency as saying, "Nations can not be bystanders to history and if we do not confront the threats now, they will only gather force and become more formidable."

Trump was at the UN on Monday and held meetings with some world leaders, in addition to attending a special meeting on UN reform. He told the leaders of some Latin American countries that the situation in Venezuela was "totally unacceptable," calling it a socialist dictatorship. He stated that the U.S. was "prepared to take further action if the government of Venezuela persists."

Title: Trump's Frustration with Sessions Continues Amidst Ongoing Russia Probe

Article:

Press Secretary Sarah Huckabee Sanders stated on Tuesday that President Trump's frustration with Attorney General Jeff Sessions is not abating, following a series of critical tweets from the president regarding Sessions' handling of the Russia meddling investigation and perceived lack of action on Hillary Clinton's alleged crimes.

Sanders, in an interview with "Fox & Friends," neither confirmed nor denied reports that Trump has discussed the possibility of firing Sessions. She did not rule out the possibility, stating that any such decision would be the president's to make. Sanders also addressed rumors about former federal prosecutor and ex-New York Mayor Rudy Giuliani being considered for the job, stating that Giuliani is someone Trump "respects," but that Sessions is currently the attorney general.

Earlier in the day, Trump tweeted a series of messages criticizing Sessions for the absence of an investigation into Clinton's connections to Ukraine and his alleged stance on other Clinton controversies. Trump's tweets read, "Ukrainian efforts to sabotage Trump campaign – 'quietly working to boost Clinton.' So where is the investigation A.G.?" and "Attorney General Jeff Sessions has taken a VERY weak position on Hillary Clinton crimes (where are E-mails & DNC server) & Intel leakers!"

Sessions has been under fire since last week, when Trump leveled harsh criticisms in a New York Times interview, calling Sessions' recusal "very unfair to the president" and adding that he never would have appointed him attorney general had he known he would do so. Sessions, however, has stated that he intends to stay in his post.

According to The Associated Press, citing three people who have recently spoken to the president, Trump continues to express anger over Sessions' decision to recuse himself from all matters related to the Russia investigation and has discussed the possibility of firing him. Those who have spoken with the president cautioned that a change may not be imminent or happen at all.

If Trump were to fire Sessions, Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein would be elevated to the top post on an acting basis. This would leave the president with another attorney general of whom he has been sharply critical in both public and private for his handling of the Russia probe, according to four White House and outside advisers who, like others interviewed, spoke on condition of anonymity to discuss private conversations.

The president's tweet about Sessions comes less than a week after Trump, in a New York Times interview, said that Sessions should never have taken the job as attorney general if he was going to recuse himself. Sessions made that decision after it was revealed that he had met with a top Russian diplomat last year.

Trump and Sessions' conversations in recent weeks have been infrequent. Sessions had recently asked senior White House staff how he might patch up relations with the president, but that effort did not go anywhere, according to a person briefed on the conversations.

Newt Gingrich, a frequent Trump adviser, stated that the president, with his criticisms of Sessions, was simply venting and being "honest about his feelings." However, he added that the president's comments would have repercussions when it comes to staff morale. "Anybody who is good at team building would suggest to the president that attacking members of your team rattles the whole team," Gingrich said.

Sessions and Trump used to be close, sharing both a friendship and an ideology. Sessions risked his reputation when he became the first U.S. senator to endorse the celebrity businessman and his early backing gave Trump legitimacy, especially among the hard-line anti-immigration forces that bolstered his candidacy. Several of Sessions' top aides now serve in top administration posts, including Stephen Miller, the architect of several of Trump's signature proposals, including the travel ban and tough immigration policy.

After Trump's public rebuke last week, Sessions seemed determined to keep doing the job he said "goes beyond anything that I would have ever imagined for myself." "I'm totally confident that we can continue to run this office in an effective way," Sessions said last week.

Title: Federal Agents Deployed to Chicago: Mayor Lori Lightfoot Rejects Trump's Plan, Cites Safety Concerns

Article:

In a move that has sparked controversy and raised safety concerns, President Donald Trump has threatened to send federal agents to Chicago to quell protests and address violent crime. This decision has been met with opposition from local politicians, including Chicago Mayor Lori Lightfoot, who has rejected the idea of deploying federal agents to the city.

According to reports by the Associated Press, Trump's threats come after Chicago recorded a weekend with a dozen fatalities and 63 people wounded by gunfire. In response, Lightfoot sent a letter to the White House, rejecting the deployment of federal agents who "arrest, and detain residents without any cause."

Lightfoot suggested alternative measures such as universal background checks, federal enforcement of existing laws, and help from the federal government on illegal gun sales. In her letter, the mayor expressed that bringing in federal agents to Chicago would be dangerous and make communities there unsafe.

During a White House press conference on Monday, Trump targeted Chicago, questioning if the city needed help after the weekend's violence. In response, Lightfoot requested more aid for the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives officials and federal prosecutors. Lightfoot, a former federal prosecutor herself, also stated, "We don't need federal agents without any insignia taking people off the streets and holding them, I think, unlawfully."

In an interview with Joy Reid on MSNBC Monday night, Lightfoot expressed her intention to defend Chicago against Trump's plans, stating, "If they try it, I'm going to use every tool at my disposal to stop them. We still have a constitution, we still have laws on the books, and I'm going to use those to deploy against them. We're not going to have tyranny in the city of Chicago. It's just not going to happen."

This development comes after federal agents were sent to Portland, Oregon, beginning July 14, where they were seen arresting and detaining peaceful demonstrators, according to The Oregonian. The Trump administration has come under fire for this action, with local politicians and demonstrators expressing anger. The president has also threatened to send federal officers to other cities, including New York and Philadelphia, to address unrest and violence.

Title: Google's Top News Sources Skewed Toward Left-Leaning Outlets, Study Finds

Article:

A new study from the Computational Journalism Lab at Northwestern University has found that Google's top news sources for search results are predominantly from left-leaning outlets. The study, conducted by researchers Daniel Trielli and Nicholas Diakopoulos, analyzed the results of more than 200 news-related questions every day in November 2017.

The researchers found that 86% of Google's Top Stories came from only 20 news sources, with three sources dominating the coverage, accounting for 23% of all impressions. CNN, The New York Times, and The Washington Post accounted for 10.9%, 6.5%, and 5.6% of the impressions, respectively.

The study's methodology involved counting an "article impression each time one of those links appears" in Google's Top Stories Box. However, the study's methodology drew some concerns about potential duplication of certain links skewing the impression count and the fact that the study considered results from 2017, a time when Google makes thousands of changes to its search engine each year.

Google, through its spokesperson, argued that its algorithms cannot detect political affiliations or sentiments when collecting content, but rather measure a variety of factors, including relevance, timing, and authoritativeness of a source. The company stated that its algorithms are designed to elevate news from authoritative sources and require publishers to be transparent and accountable to be represented in news results.

The study also compared the list of sources to another study that measured the ideological affiliation of a news outlet by analyzing the political stances of those sharing content on Facebook. From that, they found that 62% of the impressions were from sources considered left-leaning, and only 11% from right-leaning outlets.

Google confirmed the research duo's theory, noting that bigger outlets have more manpower to produce more articles, and their engine essentially crowdsources based on available content. In light of the growing scrutiny on how Google might be able to influence the news cycle, the company launched its own "How News Works" page, stating that it does not have an editorial point of view and is committed to fostering a healthy and diverse news ecosystem. The website states, "We don't have an editorial point of view. Instead, Google products are designed to connect you with a broad array of information and perspectives to help you develop your own point of view and make informed decisions."

Title: James Carville Defends Clinton Foundation Amidst Allegations of Conflicts of Interest

Article:

In a discussion on MSNBC's "Morning Joe," Democratic strategist James Carville defended the Clinton Foundation amidst allegations of potential conflicts of interest. Carville argued that the benefits of the Clinton Foundation, which raises funds for various charitable causes, outweighed any potential drawbacks.

"The good would be that we wouldn't be gabbing about it here," Carville said. "The bad would be that we would be out hundreds of millions of dollars that are doing good." He further stated that the Clinton Foundation takes money from wealthy donors and distributes it to those in need, a practice he described as "a pretty good idea."

Carville acknowledged that, given the political climate surrounding Democratic presidential nominee Hillary Clinton, it may not have been politically palatable for the Clinton Foundation to operate as it had. However, he maintained that the foundation was doing a lot of good.

When asked about the political advisability of the Clinton Foundation's operations, Carville replied, "As a political adviser, of course." However, as a human being, he expressed doubt, stating, "As a human being I think [the foundation] does an enormous amount of good."

Co-host Joe Scarborough countered Carville's claims, stating that the charity could have operated effectively without Bill Clinton leading fundraising efforts. Scarborough argued that if the charity was a strong one, it could stand on its own and other people could raise funds for it. He also disputed Carville's assertion that the Clinton Foundation's operations were a zero-sum game, stating that it was not a matter of Bill Clinton raising funds while his wife was running for president, leading to dire consequences.

Title: Michael Cohen Indicates Willingness to Cooperate with Mueller Investigation

Article:

Michael Cohen, former lawyer and fixer for President Donald Trump, has expressed a willingness to cooperate with the investigation led by special prosecutor Robert Mueller into Russian interference in the 2016 election. Cohen made these statements during an off-camera interview with ABC News correspondent George Stephanopoulos on Sunday night.

Stephanopoulos, who posted a summary of the conversation, reported that Cohen indicated a readiness to cooperate not only with Mueller but also with federal prosecutors in New York who are investigating Cohen for potential election law and financial crimes. Cohen's lawyer, Guy Petrillo, will reportedly provide guidance on these decisions.

Cohen stated, "My wife, my daughter and my son have my first loyalty and always will." He continued, "I put family and country first."

In April, Trump tweeted that Cohen was a businessman "who I have always liked & respected." Trump's tweet went on to suggest that Cohen might cooperate with investigators if given the opportunity, stating, "Most people will flip if the government lets them out of trouble, even if it means lying or making up stories."

When asked by Stephanopoulos how he might respond if the president or his legal team attempted to discredit him and his work for Trump, Cohen replied, "I will not be a punching bag as part of anyone's defense strategy. I am not a villain of this story, and I will not allow others to try to depict me that way."

Mueller's investigation into Russian ties to the 2016 Trump campaign has resulted in charges against former national security adviser Michael Flynn and ex-campaign officials Paul Manafort and George Papadopoulos. The departures of other campaign aides have also been linked to the probe.

Federal investigators have been examining Cohen's business dealings, including payments to adult-film star Stormy Daniels and other women who claimed they had affairs with Trump. In April, investigators raided Cohen's home and office.

Since then, Trump's personal lawyers, Cohen's attorneys, and federal officials have been embroiled in a legal battle over access to millions of documents.

Cohen told Stephanopoulos, "I respect the prosecutors. I respect the process." He added, "I would not do or say anything that might be perceived as interfering with their professional review of the evidence and the facts."

Title: White House Selects Trump's Miami Resort for G7 Summit, Sparking Ethics Concerns

Article:

WASHINGTON (AP) — The White House announced on Thursday that President Donald Trump's golf resort in Miami, Trump National Doral, will host next year's Group of Seven summit. The decision has sparked criticism from those who view it as the most overt example yet of the President using his office to boost his business empire.

Acting White House Chief of Staff Mick Mulvaney, in announcing Trump National Doral as host, stated, "It's not the only place. It's the best place." Mulvaney cited the resort's location and amenities as reasons for the selection. He also asserted that the President will not profit because the resort will be booked "at cost."

However, the decision raises concerns about Trump's apparent conflicts of interest, as foreign dignitaries will have no choice but to spend money at his resort during the June 10-12 summit. Ethics lawyer Kathleen Clark of Washington University School of Law commented, "He is daring anyone to prevent him from further enriching himself from the presidency."

The decision comes amid several lawsuits accusing Trump of violating the Constitution's emoluments clause, which bans the President from receiving gifts or payments from foreign governments. The decision also follows Trump's repeated accusations against Joe Biden's family for profiting from public office due to Hunter Biden's business activities in Ukraine during his father's vice presidency.

Mulvaney dismissed such concerns, as well as the idea that the summit at Trump's Doral course would serve as a massive promotion for his brand. He stated, "Donald Trump's brand is strong as it is. It's the most recognized name in the English language."

Trump himself suggested the idea during a brainstorming session on possible sites, stating, "What about Doral?" Mulvaney noted that Trump National Doral was "far and away the best physical facility" among a dozen potential sites that were considered. He added that holding the event at Doral would be dramatically cheaper and promised to provide financial figures after the event to support this claim.

Critics noted that Trump National Doral, the biggest source of revenue among Trump's 17 golf properties, appears to have been struggling since before he became President. Financial disclosure reports filed by the President show revenue is barely growing, up just $1 million last year, to $76 million. The Trump Organization itself has admitted it was struggling, arguing in a tax appeal to local authorities last year that it is "seriously underperforming."

The Doral, which Trump purchased out of bankruptcy in 2012 for a reported $150 million, also faces a heavy debt load. At the end of last year, Trump had two mortgages on the resort, one for more than $50 million and another for as much as $25 million.

Noah Bookbinder, executive director of Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington, stated, "The president is now officially using the power of his office to help prop up his struggling golf business."

U.S. Sen. Richard Blumenthal of Connecticut, among the Democrats in Congress who have sued the President over the emoluments issue, saw it as a troubling development. "It's so brazen and craven," he said. "It's virtually saying, 'To heck with the rule of law.'" Added U.S. Rep. Jerrold Nadler of New York, "The emolument clauses of the Constitution exist to prevent exactly this kind of corruption."

The Trump Organization did not respond to questions about Doral's finances. Instead, it issued a statement saying that it is "excited to have been asked to host" the summit and "honored by this recognition."

Title: Michael Cohen to Serve Remainder of Prison Sentence in Home Confinement Due to Coronavirus Pandemic

Article:

WASHINGTON (AP) — President Donald Trump's former lawyer and longtime fixer Michael Cohen will be released from federal prison to serve the remainder of his sentence in home confinement due to the coronavirus pandemic. Cohen is currently incarcerated at FCI Otisville in New York after pleading guilty to numerous charges, including campaign finance fraud and lying to Congress. He will remain under quarantine for 14 days before his release. Federal statistics show 14 inmates and seven staff members at the prison have tested positive for the coronavirus.

After his release, Cohen will serve the remainder of his sentence at home. This decision was made following a directive from Attorney General William Barr, who ordered the Bureau of Prisons to increase the use of home confinement and expedite the release of eligible high-risk inmates.

As of Thursday, 473 federal inmates and 279 Bureau of Prisons staff members had tested positive for the coronavirus at facilities across the U.S. Eighteen inmates have died since late March. Many federal inmates have been seeking home confinement as the number of coronavirus cases grows in the federal prison system, but advocates have accused the Bureau of Prisons of moving too slowly to release inmates. The Bureau of Prisons said it had moved more than 1,000 inmates to home confinement since March 26, when Barr first issued a directive to increase its use.

A federal judge had previously denied Cohen's attempt for an early release to home confinement after serving 10 months in prison. However, the Bureau of Prisons can take action to move him to home confinement without a judicial order.

Other high-profile inmates have also been released as the number of coronavirus cases soars. Last week, a judge ordered Michael Avenatti, the attorney who rose to fame representing porn star Stormy Daniels in lawsuits against Trump, to be temporarily freed from a federal jail in New York City and stay at a friend's house in Los Angeles. Avenatti had said he was at high risk of getting the coronavirus because he had a recent bout with pneumonia and his cellmate at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in Manhattan was removed due to flu-like symptoms.

Former New York state Senate leader Dean Skelos, 72, who was also serving a sentence at Otisville, is also expected to be released soon from prison to home confinement after testing positive for the coronavirus, prosecutors told a judge Wednesday. CNN first reported Cohen was being released to home confinement. A spokesman for the U.S. attorney's office in Manhattan declined to comment.

Title: Trump Refuses to Endorse Ryan, McCain Amidst Intensifying GOP Divisions

Article:

The Republican nominee, Donald Trump, has declined to endorse the re-election campaign of House Speaker Paul Ryan, as well as Senator John McCain, amidst intensifying divisions within the GOP. In an interview with the Washington Post, Trump stated, "I like Paul, but these are horrible times for our country. We need very, very strong leadership. And I'm just not quite there yet. I'm not quite there yet."

Trump's words appear to be a reference to Ryan's comments in May, when the House speaker was asked if he was backing Trump. Ryan responded, "I'm just not ready to do that at this point. I'm not there right now."

In addition to Ryan and McCain, Trump also refused to endorse the party's 2008 nominee in his bid for re-election. Both Ryan and McCain are longtime critics of many of Trump's remarks, but both have said they would support the Republican nominee in the general election.

Ryan's campaign responded through a spokesman, Zack Roday, who said, "Neither Speaker Ryan nor anyone on his team has ever asked for Donald Trump's endorsement. And we are confident in a victory next week regardless."

In recent months, both Ryan and McCain have been critical of Trump following a string of racially and religiously charged statements. In June, Ryan described Trump's attacks on a federal judge, Gustavo Curiel, as "the textbook definition of a racist comment," and McCain issued a strong rebuke of Trump's remarks about the Muslim family of a dead army captain.

Ryan also criticized Trump for his comments, saying, "Many Muslim Americans have served valiantly in our military, and made the ultimate sacrifice." He added, "Captain Khan was one such brave example."

Even Chris Christie, the New Jersey governor and a Trump ally, broke rank to tell reporters that Trump's remarks on the Khan family were inappropriate. Christie told a press conference, "I didn't see Mr. Khan's speech at the DNC but I'll just say this: I'm a father and I just can't imagine the pain of losing a child under any circumstances. For Mr. and Mrs. Khan, the pain of losing their son while defending our country is unfathomable, and I think it gives them the right to say whatever they want, whether they're right or wrong."

Two weeks after a party convention that attempted to focus on party unity, new rifts are appearing between Republicans and their candidate. On Tuesday, the retiring New York representative Richard Hanna became the first Republican member of Congress to say he would vote for Hillary Clinton in November, saying of Trump, "He is unfit to serve our party and can not lead this country."

Later the same day, the Hewlett-Packard executive Meg Whitman, a prominent Republican fundraiser, also threw her support behind Clinton. "Donald Trump's demagoguery has undermined the fabric of our national character," she said.

They join dozens of high-profile GOP leaders who have previously said they would not vote for Trump, including the party's 2012 nominee, Mitt Romney, and the former Florida governor Jeb Bush. With the Khan row ongoing, the New York Times reported that mass defections by Republican politicians were now a possibility.

In his harshest comments about Trump yet, President Barack Obama on Tuesday described him as "unfit" and "woefully unprepared" to be president, urging Republican party leaders to take the unprecedented step of denouncing their nominee.

Away from the frontline of politics, veterans and the families of soldiers killed in war continue to call on Trump to apologize for his treatment of the Khan family. Dakota Meyer, one of a handful of living Medal of Honor recipients and the former Alaska governor Sarah Palin's son-in-law, wrote Tuesday on Twitter, "If @realDonaldTrump wants to be the Commander in Chief, he needs to act like one. And that can't start until he apologizes to the Khans."

Trump's refusal to support McCain and Ryan comes exactly one week before Ryan faces a primary challenge from the businessman Paul Nehlen, a candidate who has sought to emulate Trump's rhetoric and policies. Nehlen has branded Ryan "a soulless globalist" and attacked him as the candidate of open borders.

On Tuesday, Trump praised Nehlen for running "a very good campaign."

McCain is also facing a primary challenge at the end of August from Kelli Ward, a former Arizona state senator who has accused the 2008 Republican nominee of being "directly responsible for ISIS." If the five-term senator manages to fend off the primary challenge, he still faces a competitive general election against the Democratic representative Ann Kirkpatrick, in what McCain has described as "the race of my life."

Although Arizona was once solidly Republican, the heavily Latino state is now considered an electoral toss-up because of Trump's unpredictable effect on candidates whose names follow his own on the ballot. For over a year, McCain has also called on Trump to apologize for saying he prefers "people who weren't captured" to prisoners of war, like the senator was himself in Vietnam. Trump has not apologized.

Title: Greece Agrees to New $96 Billion Bailout, Implementing Economic Reforms Under Supervision

Article:

Europe has proposed a new $96 billion bailout for Greece, marking the country's third financial aid package since 2010. The agreement, which requires approval from Greece's Parliament by Wednesday, aims to secure Greece's place in the Eurozone and prevent a potential exit that could have destabilized the continent.

Greece has agreed to significant economic reforms, including pension cuts, higher taxes, and the sale of some government assets. The deal hinges on Greece's commitment to follow through with these measures.

Eurozone leaders, led by Donald Tusk, have agreed in principle to start negotiations on the bailout. Greece's Parliament must approve the measures, and Europe will assign monitors to ensure that Greece will also have to give up control of the proceeds from government sales, with the bulk being earmarked for debt payments.

Greece had sought to have some of its massive debt load canceled, but Europe rejected this request, stating that it would consider easing the terms with longer grace periods. The deal is still a proposal and could face resistance in Greece's Parliament.

Greece urgently needs the European Central Bank to restart money flows to reopen its shuttered banks. However, the ECB has not yet indicated readiness to do so. Finance officials will reconvene later Monday to discuss supporting Greece while the details of the bailout are being negotiated.

The economy has deteriorated sharply in recent weeks, further damaging Greece's already fragile finances. There was a complete breakdown in trust between Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras and other European leaders due to a series of U-turns and his decision to call a referendum to reject reforms, only to sign up to them days later.

Under pressure from skeptical voters, some European leaders wanted ironclad guarantees that they would not be throwing good money after bad. Europe and the IMF have already lent Greece about 233 billion euros since 2010.

The agreement requires Greece to give access to bailout monitors on the ground in Athens, including officials from the IMF, a point Tsipras resisted. The deal will raise questions about whether Tsipras can continue in his post.

Without a new bailout, Tsipras knew Greece's economic situation would worsen, bringing the country ever closer to exit from the Eurozone. Greece's banks have been shut for two weeks, and cash withdrawals are capped. The vital tourism industry is suffering, and the healthcare system is running out of imported medicines.

Greece needs to pay pensions and wages this week and make a significant debt repayment to the European Central Bank next week. Without an injection of funds quickly, it would have to issue IOUs, a first step to printing its own currency.

Assuming Greece accepts a broader overhaul of the economy, there are still other potential roadblocks standing in the way of a third bailout. A handful of other eurozone countries, including Germany and Finland, will need to win votes in their parliaments this week on a new rescue. Only then can formal negotiations begin.

Title: 2020 Democratic Presidential Candidates' Stances on Abortion Revealed in New York Times Survey

Article:

The 2020 Democratic presidential candidates have coalesced around an abortion rights agenda more far-reaching than any past nominees, according to a survey by The New York Times. The positions reflect a significant shift on one of the country's most politically divisive issues.

Among the top-tier candidates, Elizabeth Warren, Pete Buttigieg, and Bernie Sanders want to force all private insurers to cover elective abortions and make the abortion drugs misoprostol and mifepristone available over the counter. Joe Biden did not provide an answer to either of these questions.

All candidates favor repealing the Hyde amendment to provide unlimited taxpayer funding of elective abortions for Medicaid recipients. Only South Bend, Ind., mayor Pete Buttigieg says, as a practical matter, he'd be willing to sign a budget that includes the Hyde amendment, while the other candidates dodge the question.

The Times reports that only Tulsi Gabbard, Joe Sestak, and Marianne Williamson now say abortion should be "safe, legal, and rare" - a phrase popularized by President Bill Clinton and repeated by Hillary Clinton, which reflected a search for common ground with people not fully supportive of abortion rights. Other candidates prefer to call for abortion to be "affordable" or "accessible" rather than "rare."

Perhaps most striking of all, the Times reports: "Asked if they supported restrictions after 24 weeks - roughly when a healthy fetus can survive outside the womb, though viability varies from pregnancy to pregnancy - only Mr. Sestak said yes. (Ms. Gabbard, who did not complete the survey, has also said she supports restrictions in the third trimester.)"

Comparing the 2020 Democrats with the last Democratic presidential candidate who won the White House, here's what Barack Obama told a Christian magazine in 2008 after he had effectively wrapped up the nomination:

"I have repeatedly said that I think it's entirely appropriate for states to restrict or even prohibit late-term abortions as long as there is a strict, well-defined exception for the health of the mother. Now, I don't think that'mental distress' qualifies as the health of the mother. I think it has to be a serious physical issue that arises in pregnancy, where there are real, significant problems to the mother carrying that child to term."

The only thing Joe Biden has going for him is his association with Barack Obama, but he is apparently unwilling to now associate himself with Obama's position on abortion in 2008. In the 1990s, Biden said he would like to "ban all post-viability abortions," but now his campaign is dodging the question on whether he supports any restrictions on aborting viable babies. The rest of the top-tier candidates - Buttigieg, Warren, and Sanders - forthrightly oppose any restrictions after 24 weeks of pregnancy.

It's quite odd that Tulsi Gabbard thinks abortion should sometimes be restricted after 28 weeks (the start of the third trimester), but she will not say if she supports restrictions after 24 weeks. The third-trimester distinction is a relic of the medical capabilities of the 1970s. When a plurality of Supreme Court justices declared in the Planned Parenthood v. Casey decision in 1992 that there is a right to abortion after viability, they wrote that the "soundness or unsoundness of that constitutional judgment in no sense turns on whether viability occurs at approximately 28 weeks, as was usual at the time of Roe, at 23 to 24 weeks, as it sometimes does today, or at some moment even slightly earlier in pregnancy, as it may if fetal respiratory capacity can somehow be enhanced in the future." (As the Times has acknowledged in earlier articles, viability has now moved up to 22 weeks into pregnancy.)

Out of all the candidates running for president in 2020, only Joe Sestak (a candidate most Democrats have never heard of) is willing to tell the Times he favors some modest legal restrictions on abortion after viability.

Title: Senate Democrats Threaten to Let Bush-Era Tax Cuts Expire, Citing Fiscal Cliff Consequences

Article:

Senate Democrats have indicated a willingness to let the Bush-era tax cuts expire at the end of the year, potentially triggering what is commonly referred to in Washington as the "fiscal cliff." This move could occur if Republicans do not agree to President Obama's plan to increase taxes on top earners.

Sen. Patty Murray (D-Wash.), head of the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee, made these remarks during an address Monday afternoon at the Brookings Institution. If all the tax cuts expire, it would diminish the Republican argument that the Democratic plan constitutes a tax hike, as any change to the tax code in 2013 would be considered a tax cut.

The fiscal cliff refers to the approaching deadline at the start of 2013, when the Bush tax cuts are set to expire, and billions of dollars in automatic spending cuts—resulting from last summer's debt-ceiling debate—are set to take effect. Lawmakers on both sides of the aisle are hoping to reallocate these spending cuts to spare key areas like defense, and to temporarily extend the Bush tax rates for at least some Americans. Some have warned that failure to do so could send the nation back into recession.

Murray stated that if a balanced deal, which calls for the wealthy to pay their fair share, is not reached, Democrats will continue the debate into 2013 rather than locking in a long-term deal this year that would allegedly disadvantage middle-class families.

Murray also suggested that if the automatic spending cuts, known as the "sequestration," set to take effect at the start of next year, are not negotiated to her party's liking, her party would let those cuts happen as well.

Republicans, on the other hand, claim that Democrats are the ones standing in the way of relief for millions of Americans. In the Republicans' weekly radio address, Sen. Rob Portman (R-Ohio) accused Obama of pushing a tax hike that will hurt employment. The political strategy underscores the heated debate over the Bush tax cuts and the potential risks for the American people.

Title: Al Franken Advocates for Transparency in Surveillance Programs

Article:

Senator Al Franken has expressed concerns about the lack of transparency regarding the scope and legal authorities of U.S. surveillance programs. In a statement, Franken emphasized the need for a balance between national security and privacy, stating that Americans cannot make informed decisions about the protection of their civil liberties if the details of surveillance are kept secret.

Franken, who has been working to increase transparency in surveillance programs since joining the Senate, has supported amendments to the Patriot Act and the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (FISA) that would require more public reporting on the use of surveillance authorities and greater disclosures about the legal opinions and safeguards that support them.

When these amendments failed, Franken voted against renewing both the Patriot Act and FISA. He clarified that his vote was not a rejection of the programs themselves, but rather a call for increased transparency. Franken believes that these programs protect the country and have saved lives, but he argues that the lack of transparency undermines public trust and the ability of the electorate to hold the government accountable.

Franken is currently working on legislation that would require the federal government to annually report on how it uses key authorities under the Patriot Act and FISA, including the authorities underlying the phone metadata and PRISM electronic surveillance programs. The government would be required to disclose how many Americans' information is being collected and how many Americans' information is being queried and actually seen by federal officers or agents.

In addition, Franken's legislation would allow companies to publicly report on how many Patriot and FISA orders they receive and how many of their customers these orders affect. Franken argues that this level of transparency can be achieved without harming national security, citing Google's reporting on the number of national security letters it receives as an example.

As chairman of the Senate Judiciary Subcommittee on Privacy, Technology, and the Law, Franken is committed to ensuring that privacy laws keep pace with technology. He believes that, in light of recent disclosures, it is long overdue for a public conversation about what constitutes a reasonable expectation of privacy. Franken contends that it is impossible to have this debate when the details of surveillance programs are kept secret.

Title: White Nationalist Protesters Return to Charlottesville Two Months After Deadly Clashes

Article:

White nationalist protesters have returned to the US town of Charlottesville two months after a violent clash that resulted in a woman's death. The town's mayor, Michael Signer, described the protesters' appearance at the statue of Confederate General Robert E. Lee as "another despicable visit by neo-Nazi cowards."

The brief torch-lit rally, organized by far-right figure Richard Spencer, took place in Emancipation Park, where the statue of Confederate General Robert E. Lee is located. The statue was also the venue for the "Unite the Right" rally in August, which was held to oppose plans to remove it. Heather Heyer, a 32-year-old counter-demonstrator, was killed when a participant drove into a group of counter-protesters at high speed during the August rally.

Between 40 and 50 people are thought to have attended the rally in Emancipation Park. The statue of General Lee is currently covered up while a legal challenge to its removal takes place. In a video live-streamed by Mr. Spencer, he stated that Charlottesville had become a symbol of the suppression of free speech and the destruction of historical monuments.

In the video, the group, all dressed similarly and holding lit torches, could be heard chanting "the south will rise again" and "Russia is our friend." Another speaker said the group was there to "represent white America's interests" and criticized the local community and the media. Police reported that the group left the park shortly before 20:00 (0:00 GMT). Mayor Signer stated that officials were looking at legal ways to prevent further events.

Richard Spencer is the founder of a right-wing website and think-tank and has made a series of controversial comments at public events, including allegedly advocating "peaceful" ethnic cleansing. The US has been embroiled in a national debate on whether to remove Confederate symbols from the US civil war due to their association with slavery. After the violence in Charlottesville, many local governments acted to remove Confederate monuments.

Title: Judge Dismisses Claims Against Exxon Mobil in New York Climate Change Lawsuit

Article:

A New York State Supreme Court judge has ruled in favor of Exxon Mobil in a climate change lawsuit, marking a significant victory for the oil giant. The decision was a setback for the New York Attorney General's Office, which brought the case.

Justice Barry Ostrager, in his ruling, stated that the attorney general's office failed to prove that Exxon Mobil had violated any laws. Ostrager wrote, "Nothing in this opinion is intended to absolve ExxonMobil from responsibility for contributing to climate change through the emission of greenhouse gasses in the production of its fossil fuel products." However, he added, "this is a securities fraud case, not a climate change case."

In a three-week trial, New York state prosecutors argued that the oil company had downplayed the financial risks it faces from potential climate regulation. Attorney General Letitia James stated that doing so made Exxon's assets appear more secure than they really were, which in turn affected its share price and defrauded investors.

Ostrager concluded that James' office "failed to prove by a preponderance of the evidence that ExxonMobil made any material misrepresentations that 'would have been viewed by a reasonable investor as having significantly altered the 'total mix' of information made available."

Following the verdict, James released a statement, saying that the case had compelled Exxon "to answer publicly for their internal decisions that misled investors." James also said, "Exxon's inability to tell the truth further underscores the lies that have been sold to the American public for decades."

Exxon said the ruling "affirms the position ExxonMobil has held throughout the New York Attorney General's baseless investigation. We provided our investors with accurate information on the risks of climate change." The company also stated, "Lawsuits that waste millions of dollars of taxpayer money do nothing to advance meaningful actions that reduce the risks of climate change."

The state's case showed signs of weakness. On the last day of the trial, the attorney general's office withdrew two counts of fraud from its lawsuit. Exxon asked the judge to rule on those counts anyway, saying the state had tarnished the company's reputation in making its case on them.

The state went forward with two counts based on the Martin Act, a New York statute that grants the state's attorney general the authority to pursue investigations and actions against those suspected of securities fraud. The Martin Act has a lower burden of proof: Prosecutors must show that a company made misrepresentations to investors and that there were consequences.

Ostrager minced no words in describing how he thought the trial had gone: "The testimony of the expert witnesses called by the Office of the Attorney General was eviscerated on cross-examination and by ExxonMobil's expert witnesses." Ostrager's ruling found Exxon not liable on any of the counts.

The highest-profile witness in the landmark case was former Secretary of State Rex Tillerson, Exxon's CEO from 2006 to 2017. Exxon used two methods to estimate the impact of potential climate-change regulations on its future business. Tillerson testified that one assessment was used to estimate the effect of future climate change regulation—such as a carbon tax—on the global energy system. For specific projects, such as the Alberta oil sands in Canada, the company would use a different method of calculating a "greenhouse gas cost."

Tillerson insisted that this was appropriate, and that Exxon had no incentive to underestimate carbon costs internally, since "we'd be misinforming ourselves."

Exxon battled for years to prevent this case and others from reaching trial, but there are now numerous pending lawsuits against Exxon and other oil companies, including a similar case that was recently brought in Massachusetts. In Massachusetts, Attorney General Maura Healey accuses ExxonMobil of systematically misleading investors about climate change's impact on the economy and its own business, and of deceiving consumers about fossil fuel's environmental impact.

Elsewhere, many city and state governments are using "public nuisance" arguments to try to hold energy companies accountable for their role in climate change. The idea is to force them to help pay for the mounting impact of climate change that communities now struggle to address. Fossil fuel companies often attempt to get the cases moved to federal courts, which they believe will be more sympathetic to their side.

Title: Obama Proposes Lifting 2013 Spending Caps, Adds Billions in New Spending

Article:

President Barack Obama has unveiled a $3.99 trillion budget proposal for the 2016 fiscal year, which aims to lift the automatic spending caps imposed in 2013 and increase government spending in various areas. The proposal, which is already drawing criticism from Republicans, includes tens of billions of dollars in new spending for domestic programs and defense.

In a speech at the Department of Homeland Security, President Obama stated, "I'm not going to accept a budget that locks in sequestration going forward... It would be bad for our security and bad for our growth." He emphasized the need to end sequestration and reverse the cuts to domestic priorities in 2016, and to match the investments made domestically with increases in defense spending.

The president's budget proposal calls for an additional $37 billion in spending on domestic programs, which would fund initiatives such as an expanded child care tax credit and subsidies for community college tuition. The plan also includes an extra $38 billion in defense spending, with the funds intended for the ongoing fight against the Islamic State and military support for NATO allies affected by Russian aggression in Ukraine.

To offset these costs, President Obama has proposed higher taxes on big banks and the wealthy. The plan would raise approximately $210 billion over the next decade by increasing the capital gains tax rate and taxing gains on inherited wealth. A new financial fee on highly leveraged banks would generate an additional $110 billion over the next 10 years.

The president is also proposing a one-time, 14 percent tax on the profits that U.S. corporations have amassed overseas, which is expected to raise an estimated $238 billion for improvements to roads, bridges, and other public works.

Republicans, who now control both chambers of Congress, are unlikely to approve the president's proposed tax hikes. However, they may be willing to negotiate on the spending caps. Cory Fritz, a spokesman for House Speaker John Boehner, stated, "Republicans believe there are smarter ways to cut spending than the sequester and have passed legislation to replace it multiple times, only to see the president continue to demand tax hikes."

The president's budget would reduce the federal deficit to $474 billion in the upcoming fiscal year, which is just 2.5 percent of the overall economy. White House forecasters expect the deficit to remain at a manageable 3 percent of GDP or less throughout the 10-year budget window. However, this assumes substantial increases in tax revenues, which may be difficult to achieve given the Republican-controlled Congress's opposition to tax hikes.

One idea that has been removed from the budget is a plan to tax 529 college savings accounts. This proposal faced opposition from both Republicans and Democrats, as critics argue that the tax-advantaged accounts primarily benefit upper-income families.

A preliminary analysis by the nonpartisan Tax Policy Center found that while the wealthiest Americans would pay higher taxes under the president's plan, most of the benefits would go to those at the bottom of the income ladder. The 60 percent of Americans in the middle would more or less break even.

President Obama has described his budget as an exercise in "middle-class economics." However, the Tax Policy Center's analysis suggests that the majority of the benefits would accrue to lower-income Americans. The budget proposal is now under review by Congress, and negotiations between the White House and Republican lawmakers are expected to continue in the coming months.

Title: Harvard Freshman Deported After Immigration Interrogation at Boston Airport

Article:

Incoming Harvard freshman Ismail B. Ajjawi, a 17-year-old Palestinian resident of Tyre, Lebanon, has had his education at Harvard, considered one of the world's preeminent universities, put in doubt after being detained and deported by American immigration officials at Boston Logan International Airport last Friday.

Upon arrival, Ajjawi faced questioning from immigration officials, along with several other international students. While the other students were allowed to leave, Ajjawi alleges that an immigration officer continued to question him about his religion and religious practices in Lebanon. The same officer then asked him to unlock his phone and laptop and left to search them for approximately five hours, Ajjawi alleges. After the search, the officer questioned him about his friends' social media activity.

In a statement, Ajjawi wrote, "Upon arrival, I faced questioning from immigration officials along with several other international students. While the other students were allowed to leave, I was questioned by an immigration officer about my religion and religious practices in Lebanon. The same officer then asked me to unlock my phone and laptop, and left to search them for roughly five hours. After the search, the officer questioned me about my friends' social media activity."

University officials told The Crimson they are still trying to resolve the situation in time for Ajjawi—whose enrollment at Harvard was made possible by a scholarship from a nonprofit organization—to be in class when the semester starts on Sept. 3.

"I have no single post on my timeline discussing politics," Ajjawi wrote. "I responded that I have no business with such posts and that I didn't like, share, or comment on them, and told her that I shouldn't be held responsible for what others post."

According to The Crimson, Ajjawi claims that the immigration officer continued to question him, eventually telling him that his study visa was being canceled and that he was being deported. The details of the immigration officer's actions and the reasons for Ajjawi's deportation are currently unavailable.

Title: Trump Delivers Harsh Indictment of Media in Unprecedented White House News Conference

Article:

In an extraordinary news conference, President Donald Trump delivered a harsh indictment of the media, marking one of the most critical addresses from the White House in recent history. The event, described as riveting, saw Trump criticizing the media for what he perceived as biased and inaccurate reporting.

Trump's speech was met with mixed reactions, with supporters viewing it as a brilliant takedown of a corrupt media, while opponents considered it a display of crazed or unhinged behavior, as CNN anchor Jake Tapper put it.

The president touched on various topics, including the issue of leaks, media bias, and the tone of his coverage. He justified his complaints about an unprecedented flood of illegal leaks aimed at damaging him. However, he did not dispute the accuracy of reports, such as The Washington Post's account of Michael Flynn's past contacts with the Russian ambassador, which led to Flynn's dismissal.

Trump also criticized the tone of his coverage, which he described as unrelentingly negative. He took particular issue with a Wall Street Journal report that some spies are withholding sensitive intelligence from him, stating that the paper never called him. The story's fourth paragraph quoted a White House official denying the allegations.

Trump's comments on CNN and its host Don Lemon were particularly pointed, although he did not mention Lemon by name. He accused CNN of having anti-Trump panels, a claim that remains subjective.

What was most revealing, in regard to CNN and the media more generally, was Trump's assertion that some journalists have "hatred" for him. He has expressed similar grievances about his coverage since 2015, but as the commander-in-chief, these feelings are now more significant.

Trump's ability to improve his press coverage can be enhanced by accomplishing some of the big-ticket items on his agenda, marking a shift from the focus on media criticism to real news, not fake.

Title: Colorado Court Upholds Employer's Right to Fire Medical Marijuana User for Positive Test

Article:

In a ruling on Thursday, the Colorado Court of Appeals upheld an employer's right to terminate an employee who tests positive for marijuana, even if the employee is a medical marijuana user. The court's decision overturns a state law that protects employees from being fired for engaging in lawful activities outside of their jobs.

The case in question involves Brandon Coats, a medical marijuana user who was rendered quadriplegic after a car accident and qualified for Colorado's medical marijuana program. Coats was fired by Dish Network after testing positive for marijuana, with no evidence that he was intoxicated at work.

Coats sued Dish Network to regain his job, arguing that a Colorado law protected him from being fired for engaging in lawful activities outside of the workplace. However, the district court ruled against Coats, stating that Dish was able to terminate Coats due to federal laws against marijuana. The Colorado Court of Appeals upheld that ruling on Thursday.

In the majority opinion, Judge Janice Davidson wrote, "We can find no legislative intent to extend employment protections to those engaged in activities that violate federal law."

Coats and his lawyer have stated that they will take the case as high as the Colorado Supreme Court. Michael Evans, Coats' lawyer, told Reuters, "If someone's going to pick a fight with the federal government, it will be the state supreme court and not the court of appeals."

Colorado is one of 20 states (not including the District of Columbia) that has legalized marijuana for medicinal use. In November, both Colorado and Washington voted to legalize marijuana for recreational use as well. However, marijuana remains illegal under federal law, which trumps state laws in this case.

Title: Virginia Gubernatorial Candidates Court Diverse Voters Ahead of Off-Cycle Election

Article:

In the lead-up to the off-cycle Virginia gubernatorial election, Democratic candidate Terry McAuliffe and Republican candidate Ken Cuccinelli have made numerous campaign stops, focusing on reaching out to the state's rapidly diversifying electorate.

During a campaign stop at Todos Supermarket in Woodbridge, Virginia, McAuliffe, a former Democratic National Committee chairman, expressed support for a state-level DREAM Act, emphasizing the importance of an open and welcoming state for all residents. He also highlighted the supermarket's San Salvador-born owner, Carlos Castro, as an example of the "American dream."

McAuliffe's campaign itinerary includes numerous events aimed at diverse communities, such as toasting the Lunar New Year with Korean, Chinese, and Vietnamese groups, celebrating the Persian New Year holiday of Nowruz, addressing the Democratic Latino Organization of Virginia, and holding a special campaign kickoff aimed at the Asian-American and Pacific-Islander communities.

Cuccinelli, the Republican candidate, has also focused on outreach efforts, attending meetings with the Pakistan American Business Association and the Moroccan American Network, celebrating Filipino-American culture at festivals in Richmond and Virginia Beach, and giving interviews to Indian, Korean, Moroccan, and Vietnamese-oriented media, among other outreach events.

The political logic behind these itineraries is rooted in the significant increase in nonwhite voting groups in Virginia over the past decade. In the 2004 presidential race, Latino voters made up 3% and Asians made up 2% of the Virginia electorate, according to exit polls. By 2012, those numbers had risen to 5% for Latinos and 3% for Asians—a combined 60% increase in these heterogeneous groups. In a low-turnout election, this shift could be particularly impactful.

Cuccinelli, who has won multiple state Senate elections in a Fairfax-based district, near the epicenter of Virginia's demographic change, has emphasized his long ties to the state and his involvement in local institutions. He has also highlighted his focus on creating jobs and his opposition to quotas, while advocating for internationally savvy constituencies to be better represented in the state's economic development agencies and boards.

The national conversation on immigration has cast a shadow over Cuccinelli's campaign, and his outreach meeting in Richmond served as a case study in both his strengths and limitations as an aspiring big-tent GOP leader. Cuccinelli emphasized his long ties to the state and his involvement in local institutions, contrasting that with McAuliffe's upbringing in national politics.

Title: President Trump Vows to Protect Thanksgiving Name, Pardons Two Turkeys

Article:

In a rally in Sunrise, Florida, on Tuesday, President Donald Trump pledged to protect the traditional name of the annual Thanksgiving holiday, stating that some individuals, whom he referred to as the "radical left," want to change the name. Trump expressed his opposition to those who aim to target the secular holiday in a similar manner as they have with Christmas, which celebrates the birth of Jesus Christ.

"You know, some people want to change the name Thanksgiving," Trump said at the rally. "They don't want to use the term 'Thanksgiving.' And that was true also with Christmas."

The president went on to say, "But now we're going to have to do a little work on Thanksgiving. People have different ideas. Why it shouldn't be called Thanksgiving. But everybody in this room, I know, loves the name Thanksgiving. And we're not changing."

The HuffPost earlier this month raised questions about the environmental impact of the traditional Thanksgiving meal, suggesting alternatives such as skipping turkey to save animals, criticizing travel-related carbon emissions, and addressing food waste. This led to a series of reports on a supposed "war on Thanksgiving" by Fox News.

Twitter users responded with the hashtag "#WhatLiberalsCallThanksgiving" to mock the president's remarks. One user, who identified as Native American, suggested instead naming the fourth Thursday of November a #nationaldayofmourning.

Since 1970, Native Americans in New England have organized an annual protest on the same day as Thanksgiving, gathering at noon on Cole's Hill in Plymouth. The protest is known as the National Day of Mourning, and it serves as a reminder of the genocide of millions of Native American people, the theft of their lands, and the relentless assault on their culture, according to a plaque erected at the protest site by the Town of Plymouth on behalf of the United American Indians of New England.

Earlier on Tuesday, Trump pardoned two Thanksgiving turkeys – Bread and Butter – and wished Americans a Happy Thanksgiving. The president joked that the two turkeys, specially raised by farmer Willie Jackson, had already received subpoenas to appear in the basement of Adam Schiff, the California Democrat leading the impeachment inquiry against Trump.

"It seems the Democrats are accusing me of being too soft on turkey," Trump said, addressing the birds. "But Bread and Butter, I should note that unlike previous witnesses, you and I have actually met. It's very unusual."

Title: Target Corporation Drops Health Care Plan for Part-Time Workers, Cites Obamacare Exchanges

Article:

Retail giant Target Corporation has announced its decision to discontinue its health care plan for part-time workers, citing low participation and suggesting that employees would benefit from coverage under the Affordable Care Act (Obamacare) insurance exchanges. In a blog post on Tuesday, the Minneapolis-based retailer stated that it will provide a $500 cash payment to each employee affected by the change.

Target presented the move as a sensible decision, but did not disclose the potential savings for the company. The company also implied that it was facilitating health care options for its part-time employees by stepping aside from the health care arena under the Affordable Care Act.

"The launch of health insurance marketplaces provides new options for health care coverage that we believe our part-time team members may prefer," the company stated in the blog post, which featured its top human resources official. "In fact, by offering them insurance, we could actually disqualify many of them from being eligible for newly available subsidies that could reduce their overall health insurance expense."

The company reported that less than 10% of its employees participate in the company's health care plan for part-timers, but the move raises questions about the impact of the Affordable Care Act on employer-based coverage, which is the primary source of health insurance for a majority of Americans. Analysts suggest that employers may opt to move health care coverage into the individual market and state-based exchanges, where individuals may be eligible for government subsidies based on income.

Target is not the first company to make changes to its health care plan in response to the rollout of the Affordable Care Act. In August, UPS announced that it would drop health care coverage for approximately 15,000 employees' spouses who are eligible for coverage from their own workplaces. The company stated that the move was necessary to control health care costs, given the fees and minimum coverage requirements under Obamacare.

The impact of Obamacare on the employer-based market is complex, as it involves numerous factors that affect annual premium changes. However, given the political climate and the early problems with HealthCare.gov and the individual market, many critics may attribute any premium increases to the law.

Analysts have stated that smaller employers face the most significant consequences because they are less able to handle adverse changes to the balance of sick and healthy employees than larger firms can. This is a pressing concern because the law prohibits insurers from rejecting people with pre-existing conditions and from charging older consumers more than young people by more than a 3-1 ratio.

Additionally, the health care overhaul includes numerous taxes and fees that may be passed along to consumers in the employer-based insurance market.

Target stated that employees who work 20 to 31 hours would still be eligible for vacation, dental, disability, life insurance, and 401(k) benefits. The company also stated that it had no plans to reduce hours as part of the move.

"At any time, our team members can talk to their manager about their interest and availability to work more hours," the company stated. "In fact, during the holiday season, we offered our year-round part-time and full-time [employees] the opportunity to take on additional hours or cross-train to work in other areas—at their request."

House Republicans recently cited the millions of Target customers who had to monitor their bank accounts after hackers stole their credit card numbers as they sought support for an Obamacare Web privacy law. The law, which requires the federal government to notify consumers within two days if their personal data has been breached on online-based insurance markets tied to the health care overhaul, was passed with the help of 67 Democrats.

Title: Obama Campaigns in New Hampshire, Addresses Second Term Agenda and Criticism

Article:

In Manchester, New Hampshire, President Barack Obama addressed a crowd of approximately 6,000 supporters on Thursday, aiming to counter criticism from Republican nominee Mitt Romney regarding the lack of a clear agenda for a second term. The race in this small but crucial swing state is tightening, with a Suffolk/7News poll on Monday showing the candidates tied at 47 percent.

Two weeks ago, Obama led Romney by an average of 6 percentage points in New Hampshire. The Suffolk poll suggests that voters are uncertain about Obama's plans for a second term, with Romney receiving a slight edge in terms of fixing the economy (45 percent to 42 percent).

The president's campaign team has outlined an agenda for a second term, which includes hiring 100,000 more teachers, boosting domestic energy production, creating more manufacturing jobs, and cutting the deficit. Obama also argued that his second term would serve as a bulwark against repeating the mistakes made by his Republican predecessors.

Obama highlighted his achievements, such as reducing unemployment from 10 percent to 7.8 percent, and emphasized the need to continue progress. However, it is worth noting that the national jobless rate was 7.6 percent when Obama took office.

The president attempted to clarify his vision for the future, discussing subsidized college tuition, increased U.S. exports, raising taxes on the wealthy, and promoting clean energy. Despite these efforts, it appears that his message is not always resonating with the public.

Ron Chito, a supporter from Medford, Massachusetts, stated, "Not really" when asked if the president has done a good job describing his vision for a second term. Chito, a retired utility worker, expressed hope for more Democratic representation in the House and Senate to pass a good jobs bill.

Cynthia Malbon, a supporter from Manchester, plans to vote for Obama but expressed skepticism about his ability to achieve a stronger economy. She expressed a desire for more specifics on how Obama plans to accomplish this.

Throughout his speech, Obama criticized Romney's economic plan, which includes across-the-board tax cuts for all wage earners. He also addressed the impact of Romney's policies on women's health, stating that Romney would repeal "Obamacare," potentially allowing insurance companies to charge women more for healthcare coverage.

The president emphasized the importance of women's health issues in the election, stating that the health care law passed by his administration puts health care choices in the hands of individuals, while Romney's approach would give employers control over such decisions.

Obama also criticized the Republican-led New Hampshire legislature on women's health, stating that they sometimes act as if they know better than women when it comes to women's own health care decisions. He also mentioned Romney's stance on funding for Planned Parenthood.

The president stated his intention to cut the deficit by $4 trillion over 10 years, but this would require higher taxes on families earning more than $250,000. He emphasized that he would not cut education or research that contributes to economic growth.

The Romney campaign responded, stating that Obama's leadership has failed over the past four years and that the economic future under him would be bleaker due to his unwillingness to confront the "fiscal cliff" of spending cuts and tax increases pending before Congress in January. The campaign also emphasized Romney's plan to create 12 million jobs and restore the economy.

Title: President Obama Delivers Unifying Speech at Democratic National Convention, Outlines Modest Policy Goals and Criticizes Mitt Romney

Article:

President Barack Obama delivered a speech at the Democratic National Convention on Thursday, outlining his case for a second term. The speech, which took place in Charlotte, North Carolina, was characterized by a more subdued tone compared to his 2008 speech in Denver.

In his address, President Obama referenced the transformational legacy of Franklin D. Roosevelt to justify his reelection bid. However, the speech also reflected the more cautious approach of a sitting president, as he urged a wary and concerned electorate to maintain the current course to avoid a Mitt Romney presidency.

Unlike some Democrats' expectations, President Obama did not present an affirmative rationale for reelection rooted in ambitious policy proposals. Instead, he offered a blend of cautious optimism, harsh criticisms of Mitt Romney's foreign policy inexperience, and relatively modest policy goals, such as a pledge to create 1 million new manufacturing jobs.

The speech focused on portraying Romney as evading tough decisions and intensifying attacks on his opponent's record, which have primarily been waged through media outlets.

President Obama launched a scathing attack on Romney from various perspectives, particularly on foreign policy, a weakness for Obama in 2008 but a stronger electoral ground for a seasoned commander in chief. He criticized Romney for his perceived lack of diplomacy, citing his comments on the ending of the Iraq war and his stance on the Olympics.

The economic and political realities of the 2012 election year necessitated some messaging improvisation and significant downsizing of the blue-sky appeal of his 2008 campaign. President Obama acknowledged the challenges faced in solving issues that have accumulated over decades and emphasized the need for collective effort, shared responsibility, and bold, persistent experimentation.

Over the past two years, Obama's advisers have grappled with a fundamental messaging dilemma: how to make the case for reelection on a half-recovery, and how to communicate what he has done for the American people without claiming that he has made everything better.

Title: Senate Republicans Unveil Police Reform Bill Addressing Racial Disparities

Article:

Senate Republicans, led by Senator Tim Scott (R-SC) and Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-KY), have introduced legislation aimed at addressing racial disparities in law enforcement. The bill, titled the JUSTICE Act, was unveiled on June 17, 2020, at the U.S. Capitol.

The bill includes provisions to incentivize law enforcement agencies to ban the use of chokeholds, except when deadly force is authorized. It also aims to ramp up data collection efforts regarding officer-involved deaths or serious harm, provide federal funds for alternative force training, recognize the history of lynching in the United States, require law enforcement agencies to report on no-knock warrants to the attorney general, and establish a commission to study issues affecting Black men and boys.

The bill follows President Donald Trump's executive order, which incentivizes police departments to update their standards and strengthen efforts to track officer misconduct. The Republican bill aligns more closely with the president's actions than the comprehensive legislative proposal put forward by congressional Democrats last week.

White House press secretary Kayleigh McEnany stated that the bill has Trump's full support. She added, "It's a great bill, it's more great action from Republicans, and we hope we can have bipartisan support on that."

Unlike the Democrats' proposal, the Republican bill does not address the issue of qualified immunity, a doctrine that shields officers from legal liability unless a plaintiff can show that their constitutional rights were clearly violated. The Trump administration has stated that amending qualified immunity is a "non-starter."

The Supreme Court announced on Monday that it would not hear cases addressing the doctrine of qualified immunity. The GOP proposal also does not end the use of "no-knock" warrants in drug cases, as the Democratic bill does, and it provides new funds for police department training.

The 106-page bill is spearheaded by GOP Senator Tim Scott of South Carolina, one of three Black senators, and is backed by Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky). Senator Scott stated at the Capitol Hill news conference, "The bill speaks to the fact that we believe the overwhelming number of officers in this nation are good people."

Title: Amazon Eliminates Monthly Bonuses and Stock Awards for Warehouse Workers as Part of $15 Minimum Wage Implementation

Article:

Amazon.com Inc. has announced the elimination of monthly bonuses and stock awards for its warehouse workers and other hourly employees, following the company's pledge this week to raise pay to at least $15 per hour.

Previously, warehouse workers for the e-commerce giant in the U.S. were eligible for monthly bonuses that could amount to hundreds of dollars per month, as well as stock awards. The company informed these employees on Wednesday that it would discontinue both compensation categories to cover the costs of the wage increases, according to two individuals familiar with Amazon's pay policies.

Amazon received praise when it announced on Monday its decision to raise minimum pay. The wage increase quelled criticism from politicians and activists, and positioned the company favorably for the recruitment of temporary workers during the crucial holiday shopping season.

Despite the elimination of bonuses and stock awards, hourly operations and customer-service workers will see their total compensation increase, the company stated in a statement.

"In addition, because it's no longer incentive-based, the compensation will be more immediate and predictable," Amazon said.

Workers whose pay was already above $15 per hour will receive hourly raises of $1, according to two individuals familiar with the matter who requested anonymity regarding the company's compensation practices. Some long-time workers expressed dissatisfaction that their raises are smaller compared to newly hired workers who will see hourly pay increases of up to 40%.

David DeBoskey, an accounting professor at San Diego State University, stated that a higher hourly wage that new workers immediately receive is a more effective recruiting tool in a tight labor market than stock options that take years to materialize, especially in the warehousing industry that experiences high turnover.

Amazon plans to hire 100,000 seasonal workers for the holiday rush this year, and temporary workers do not receive stock awards.

"In a tight labor market, when you're the leader paying $15 an hour, that's a big advantage," DeBoskey said. "They probably realized people weren't applying for warehouse jobs for the stock options."

Title: Bipartisan Meeting at White House Aims to Address DACA, Budget Deadline Looms

Article:

Republicans and Democrats will convene at the White House on Tuesday for a bipartisan meeting with President Donald Trump, aiming to make progress on protecting hundreds of thousands of immigrants from deportation. However, a long-standing partisan divide over immigration policy and an approaching budget deadline pose challenges to the negotiations.
