According to Republican and Democratic negotiators involved in discussions over the January spending deal, DACA (Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals) has become a key factor in unlocking any funding agreement. Some participants are frustrated with the current state of negotiations, with Republicans alleging that Democrats have effectively halted talks on spending caps until a resolution on DACA is reached.

Senate Republican John Cornyn, the Senate's No. 2, expressed his view that Democrats are holding the spending deal hostage for DACA negotiations. "We are meeting at the White House tomorrow on a bipartisan basis with the President to see what that might look like," said Cornyn, "but I think that's going to make the January 19 date pretty hard to hit."

Negotiations have been described as a "mess" by a person directly involved in the discussions. A separate GOP aide stated that the broader political environment for both parties is "not in a good place right now."

Democrats argue that the White House has not been fully engaged in the negotiations and claim that a long and broad policy wish list released last week further irritated Democrats working on the immigration compromise. One Democratic aide described the White House's list as "out of the realm of reality."

"No wall," said Democratic Sen. Kamala Harris of California. "I believe in border security. I think it's very important that we have a secure border, but spending billions and billions of dollars on this wall because of a political promise and a campaign promise is ridiculous."

The anticipated meeting at the White House on Tuesday is expected to symbolize Trump's growing commitment to finding a bipartisan resolution. However, the inclusion of GOP lawmakers that Democrats view as openly hostile to finding a consensus deal on DACA adds tension to the meeting for Democrats.

Details are still being worked out on what a plan to help DACA recipients would look like, and a bipartisan group of Senate lawmakers led by Democrat Dick Durbin of Illinois and Republican Lindsey Graham of South Carolina continues to negotiate. The tensions that existed in December but were temporarily resolved with a holiday deadline are now playing out in real time between the two parties.

"I think this is going to be the flexion point where we get some things done or we don't," said Rep. Adam Kinzinger, a Republican from Illinois, on Monday afternoon on CNN.

Bipartisan talks have been ongoing for months, and the group of senators led by Durbin and Graham acknowledge they need Trump to lay out clear priorities to move forward. The thinking is that Trump, who campaigned on promises of mass deportations and a border wall, can offer political cover for Republicans who may be fearful of backing any immigration bill viewed as amnesty among their base. With Trump's blessing, Republicans believe they can find a way to move ahead on DACA. Without it, the votes are compromised.

The bipartisan meeting at the White House on Tuesday follows Trump's meeting with Republicans last week, during which Sen. Jeff Flake of Arizona refused to attend, citing the lack of bipartisanship. White House Chief of Staff John Kelly, formerly the Secretary of Homeland Security, will also be in the bipartisan meeting on Tuesday and has been leading outreach to lawmakers on Capitol Hill on the ongoing talks.

In addition to the bipartisan working group, conservatives including Cornyn and Senate Judiciary Chairman Chuck Grassley of Iowa are having their own conversations. Republican Sens. Thom Tillis of North Carolina and James Lankford of Oklahoma will also be at the White House on Tuesday.

In the House, multiple efforts are underway, with Republican Rep. Will Hurd of Texas and Democratic Rep. Pete Aguilar of California releasing their own bipartisan framework for a deal after weeks of negotiations. Aguilar is the whip for the Congressional Hispanic Caucus. That deal focuses on DACA and border security, but the lawmakers hope additional measures could be added if necessary to finalize a deal.

The bipartisan Problem Solvers Caucus, including Republican Rep. Carlos Curbelo of Florida, a longtime DACA advocate, had also been working to reach a compromise before the break, similar in concept to what the Senate group was working on.

As in the Senate, a group of more conservative Republican lawmakers are working on their own proposal, including House Homeland Security Chairman Mike McCaul of Texas and House Judiciary Chairman Bob Goodlatte of Virginia, which would be strongly to the right of most bipartisan compromises. Both men will also be at the White House on Tuesday.

Title: Americans Offer Suggestions for President Obama's Second Term Agenda

Article:

In his second term, President Obama should focus on rebuilding the nation's infrastructure, according to Cherry Davis, a struggling job seeker in Los Angeles. Davis suggests a modern New Deal, which she believes would create jobs, update the nation's infrastructure, and bring the middle class back.

Education is another top concern for some Americans. Tyler Stocks, an Obama voter and rising East Carolina University student, expressed his worry about the rising costs of college tuition and textbooks. He hopes the president can work to ensure that students like him are afforded the opportunity to receive a good education.

Mark Ivy, who voted for Mitt Romney, believes that Obama's leadership skills need improvement, particularly in dealing with Congress. He thinks the president should focus on forging a way through the tangled web of Congress and displaying real leadership in his second term.

Small business owner Egberto Willies, a politically active Obama supporter, is concerned about the dwindling middle class and income and wealth inequality. He believes the tax structure should be changed to resolve these issues.

The issue of leadership and the president's approach to dealing with Congress has also been a topic of debate among iReporters and commenters. Some believe that a leader builds consensus by understanding that it is better to bring different viewpoints together for a common cause, rather than always wanting to win the argument.

The tax structure has also created a big conversation on CNN.com, as commenters went back and forth over corporate tax rates and how much taxes ought to be raised on the wealthy. The plight of the dwindling middle class, immigration, and gun control are other issues that have been raised by iReporters and commenters.

CNN.com commenter Bruce Rubin stated, "Unless this country goes back to a tax structure pre-Reagan, all but the top 1% is doomed." Small-business owner Egberto Willies added, "The reality is none of the other issues matter if the decline of the middle class continues."

The article concludes by asking readers to share their thoughts below on which issues they believe ought to be the priority over the next term and whether iReporters and commenters missed the mark by not talking about the economy.

Title: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu: A Churchillian Statesman and His Iran Policy

Article:

Israeli columnist Ari Shavit, author of "My Promised Land: The Triumph and Tragedy of Israel," describes Benjamin Netanyahu as a "serious statesman" with an "extraordinary comprehension and uncanny foresight." Despite acknowledging Netanyahu's human flaws and problematic behavioral patterns, Shavit maintains that the Israeli prime minister is neither cynical, corrupt, nor facile, and possesses an "unrealized potential for greatness."

Netanyahu's self-perceived role, according to Shavit, is akin to Winston Churchill's, viewing himself as the savior of the West and Israel as the Great Britain of the 21st century. This perspective, rooted in Netanyahu's Zionist beliefs, has been shaped by non-Jewish philo-Zionists, primarily British, conservative, and imperialist.

Netanyahu's Churchill complex, as described by Shavit, is deep, obsessive, and multidimensional. This complex is evident in Netanyahu's comparison of the Oslo Accords' ambitions to Neville Chamberlain's appeasement of Hitler in the 1930s and his current view of a nuclear deal with Iran in the same light.

As a result of this complex, Netanyahu scorns Democratic politicians and liberal intellectuals, viewing them as weak. He is not primarily concerned with social justice, human rights, or the rule of law, instead focusing on the perceived threat from Iran and the clash of cultures between Iran and the West.

In 2009, when Netanyahu took office, he defined his Churchillian mission as preventing Iran from acquiring nuclear weapons, achieving regional hegemony, and annihilating the Jews. Netanyahu's military training in an elite unit of the Israeli Army has equipped him with the focus and determination to complete his mission, as demonstrated by his efforts to turn himself into the Churchill of the 21st century.

Netanyahu's actions in 2009-10, including maneuvering the Iranian nuclear threat to the top of the international community's agenda, investing resources in an Israeli military option against Iran, and diplomatically leveraging this military option, have been significant in shaping the international community's policy towards Iran. The extent to which Netanyahu seriously considered attacking Iran or was merely playing strategic poker remains unclear. However, it is clear that, up to a point, Netanyahu has succeeded in standing up to a totalitarian rival and enlisting the help of the American superpower, as his hero, Winston Churchill, did.

Title: Romney and Obama in Virtual Tie as Election Day Nears; Gender Dynamics Shift in Presidential Race

Article:

With less than two weeks remaining before Election Day, the Associated Press-GfK poll shows a tight presidential race between Republican Mitt Romney and President Barack Obama. The poll indicates that Romney is favored by 47 percent of likely voters, while Obama receives 45 percent support, a result within the poll's margin of sampling error.

The poll reveals a significant shift in the gender dynamics of the race. Romney has erased Obama's 16-point advantage among women, with both candidates now receiving 47 percent support from women. Meanwhile, Obama has largely eliminated Romney's edge among men, with the former president's support among men at 45 percent, compared to Romney's 47 percent.

Romney's improved standing among American voters is attributed to his strong performance in the first debate and increased confidence in his ability to handle the economy and understand the problems of the average voter. At the same time, expectations that Obama will be re-elected have slipped, with half of voters now expecting the president to win a second term, down from 55 percent a month earlier.

However, Romney's standing in the election's final stretch will be crucial, as the race is still being decided in the handful of states whose electoral votes are still up for grabs. Polls in several battleground states still appear to favor Obama.

Recently, Romney has been attempting to court female voters by downplaying social issues and projecting a more moderate stance on matters such as abortion. The AP-GfK poll shows that Romney is now even with Obama among women on women's issues, after trailing by 16 points a month earlier.

However, the campaign is facing fallout from a comment by a Romney-endorsed Senate candidate in Indiana, who said that pregnancy from rape is "something God intended." Romney quickly distanced himself from the remark, but Obama campaign spokeswoman Jen Psaki said the incident was "a reminder that a Republican Congress working with a Republican President Mitt Romney would feel that women should not be able to make choices about their own health care."

Among female likely voters, 55 percent say Obama would make the right decisions on women's issues, compared with 41 percent who think Romney would. Romney's pitch to women has been focused on the economy, making the case that what women want most is to ensure their families and their country are on a solid financial footing. The poll shows that message appears to be taking root.

A month ago, women favored Obama over Romney on the economy by 56 percent to 40 percent. Now, the split has shifted to 49 percent for Romney and 45 percent for Obama. Similarly, Obama's lead among women as the candidate who better understands the people's problems has narrowed considerably, from a 58-36 Obama advantage last month to a 50-43 Obama edge now.

Obama has been working to shore up his support among men, who tend to be more Republican than women. In the 2008 election, men broke 49 percent for Obama to 48 percent for John McCain, even though Obama got 53 percent of the vote overall. The president's job approval ratings among men have tended to fall below his ratings among women throughout his first term.

A month ago, Romney's advantage among men was 13 percentage points. Now, it's down to 5 points, with most of the shift toward Obama coming among unmarried men. Obama's election chances hinge on turning out voters like Jon Gerton, a disabled construction worker from Jonesboro, Ark., who is a staunch Obama supporter but did not vote in 2008.

Overall, people are significantly more optimistic about the economy and unemployment in the coming year than they have been at any point in AP-GfK polling going back to March 2011, when the poll first started asking those questions. And likely voters are even more optimistic than other adults. Nearly six in ten likely voters think the economy will improve in the next year, up from 46 percent last month. And 42 percent think the number of unemployed Americans will drop in the next year, up from 32 percent in September.

Title: Enthusiasm Gap Favors Clinton in Ohio Early Voting, According to Twitter and Polls

Article:

A significant enthusiasm gap appears to favor Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton over her Republican counterpart, Donald Trump, in Ohio's early voting, according to data from Twitter and recent polls. The hashtag #OHVotesEarly, which started trending on Twitter as early voting began in Ohio, has shown a substantial disparity in mentions of the two candidates.

Twitter data indicates that of the tweets sent using the hashtag #OHVotesEarly over the last 24 hours, 75 percent included mentions of Clinton, while just 25 percent mentioned Trump. This disparity is attributed to various factors, including the Clinton supporter who originally tweeted the hashtag on October 2, the Clinton campaign's widespread promotion of the hashtag, and the Trump campaign's error in announcing an incorrect start date for early voting.

Recent polls also suggest a shift in favor of Clinton in Ohio. A new poll by Baldwin Wallace University Community Research Institute, conducted after Sunday's debate, shows Clinton leading Trump by 9 percentage points in a four-way race and by 11 percentage points in a head-to-head race. This marks a significant change from polls conducted a month ago, which showed Trump with a lead in Ohio.

The Trump campaign, however, maintains its optimism, stating that they will utilize every day of early and absentee voting to secure votes for Trump. Bob Paduchik, Trump's Ohio state director, said in a statement, "Our campaign will be using every day of early and absentee voting to get out our voters, culminating in an Election Day win for Mr. Trump."

Early voting returns in other states also show a slight advantage for Clinton. According to a new report by NBC News and the voter data firm TargetSmart, Clinton has received more votes during the early voting period in Iowa, Virginia, Wisconsin, Michigan, and North Carolina, while Trump is leading in Georgia and Florida.

Clinton campaign manager Robby Mook expressed optimism about these results, noting increased vote by mail requests among key demographics in Florida and high absentee ballot requests in Ohio. Mook also suggested that Nevada, North Carolina, and Florida could be decided before Election Day.

Regardless of the early voting trends, the Clinton campaign may face a challenging task in convincing skeptical Trump supporters, and Trump himself, that the election results are legitimate, should Clinton emerge victorious.

Title: Trump Doubles Obama's 2012 Vote Total in New Hampshire Primary

Article:

President Donald Trump secured more than 120,000 votes in the New Hampshire primary on Tuesday, more than doubling former President Barack Obama's 2012 vote total in the state. With 87 percent of precincts reporting, Trump's vote count surpassed Obama's 49,080 total votes in 2012. The gap between the two presidents is expected to widen as more precincts report their totals Wednesday.

Trump's vote count dwarfs the totals of other incumbent presidents. Then-President George W. Bush received 53,962 votes in the largely uncontested GOP primary in New Hampshire in 2004. In 1996, incumbent President Bill Clinton received 76,797 votes in New Hampshire's primary.

The high turnout for Trump in New Hampshire is a result of a coordinated effort by the Republican National Committee and the Trump campaign to drive up turnout for the president. Trump himself rallied his supporters at a packed and fiery rally in Manchester, N.H., on Monday, the eve of the state's primary.

In the line to get into Trump's Monday rally, many of his voters seemed to have an uncommon zeal for supporters of an incumbent president. Jay McDonald of North Providence, R.I., said he "100 percent" supported Trump four years ago and "nothing's changed." McDonald said he's "maybe more angry that they could do that [impeachment] to a president and get away with it over nothing."

Democrats largely owned the turnout in New Hampshire Tuesday, with first and second place finishers Bernie Sanders and Pete Buttigieg combining for almost 140,000 votes with 87 percent reporting. The Democratic primary is still wide open, and there was almost nothing at stake for Trump in the New Hampshire race. His only primary challenger on the ballot was former Massachusetts Gov. Bill Weld, who had less than 10 percent of the GOP vote with 87 percent in.

The Trump campaign also touted a record turnout for an incumbent in the Iowa caucuses, which came on the same night that Democratic turnout fell well below expectations. About 176,000 Iowa Democrats attended their precinct caucuses, a slight uptick from 2016 but fewer than expected. That total is nowhere near the party's 2008 numbers, when roughly 238,000 Iowans participated in the kickoff clash among Hillary Clinton, Barack Obama, onetime Iowa favorite John Edwards, and a handful of others.

Title: Rep. Justin Amash Forms Exploratory Committee for Presidential Run as Libertarian Candidate

Article:

Representative Justin Amash, a five-term incumbent from Michigan and former co-founding member of the House Freedom Caucus, has formed an exploratory committee for a potential presidential run under the Libertarian Party (L.P.). The 40-year-old congressman, who is the son of Middle Eastern immigrants, aims to become the first high-profile presidential candidate and the most prominent L.P. standard-bearer in the party's half-century of existence.

Amash, who is known for his advocacy of limited government, has been touted as the heir apparent to former Representative Ron Paul on Capitol Hill. He has described himself as "the only libertarian member of Congress" and has led congressional efforts to dismantle the surveillance state, restore legislative-branch responsibility, and oppose federal overreach.

However, Amash's lack of active engagement with the L.P. and its events has drawn criticism from some within the party. Future of Freedom Foundation founder Jacob Hornberger, a prominent L.P. figure, has been critical of Amash's interest in the party's presidential nomination, citing the congressman's lack of attendance at L.P. conventions and debates.

In the only 2020 three-way poll conducted thus far, Morning Consult found that just 1% of 1,992 registered voters would vote for Amash over Joe Biden and Donald Trump. Two national polls in 2019 had Amash averaging 5.5%. The potential impact of Amash on the presidential swing state of Michigan is a matter of interest for both major parties, though a highly polarized political climate following a close presidential election tends to be unfavorable for minor candidates.

It remains unclear whether Amash will officially withdraw from his reelection campaign, as he cannot seek both offices come November. The L.P. is scheduled to select its nominee in late May, but the physical and legal status of the national convention is in coronavirus limbo, and the event's Austin hotel has been canceled. The L.P. National Committee may reschedule the convention, providing Amash with additional time to convince wary delegates.

Title: U.S. Surpasses 100,000 COVID-19 Deaths, Leads World in Cases

Article:

The United States has surpassed 100,000 deaths from COVID-19, according to data compiled by the Center for Systems Science and Engineering at Johns Hopkins University. This makes the U.S. the country with the most confirmed deaths from the virus. As of 6 p.m. Eastern Time on May 27, the death toll stands at 100,047.

This number is equivalent to the entire population of mid-sized cities like Albany, N.Y., or Boca Raton, Fla. It surpasses the number of American lives lost during the Korean War, the Vietnam War, and the Sept. 11, 2001 attacks combined.

Initially, White House officials projected that between 100,000 and 240,000 Americans could die from COVID-19, even with preventive measures like social distancing. Independent researchers have often produced even higher estimates. On May 26, a Harvard health policy expert told NPR that the U.S. could see an additional 100,000 COVID-19 deaths this summer alone.

Daily U.S. coronavirus cases and deaths have declined substantially since a peak in April, including in many of the country's hardest-hit areas, like New York City. However, experts have warned that rural areas may not have seen the worst of COVID-19 yet. During the week ending May 26, about 7,000 people in the U.S. died from COVID-19, according to data from Johns Hopkins University's COVID-19 tracker.

The U.S. leads the world in coronavirus cases, with nearly 1.7 million cases reported as of 6 PM Eastern Time on May 27, according to Johns Hopkins data. This number is likely an underestimate due to inadequate testing capacity and the number of people who develop mild illnesses and do not seek medical attention.

New diagnoses are starting to decrease, but the trend seems to have reversed itself in recent days. This may be due to the country's commitment to social distancing appearing to falter as states reopen and summer weather draws people out of their homes.

A top World Health Organization official warned on May 26 that "we're right in the middle of the first wave [of coronavirus cases] globally" and said "we're still very much in a phase where the disease is actually on the way up" in many parts of the world.

Experts do not know when COVID-19 cases and deaths will level off for good, but they do know that, in the absence of a vaccine that can provide widespread immunity, social distancing is among the best—and only—ways to keep infection, hospitalization, and death rates as low as possible. A Columbia University analysis published May 20 estimated that 36,000 lives could have been saved if the U.S. broadly adopted social-distancing policies a week earlier than many places did, in mid-March.

The 100,000 lives already lost in the U.S. serve as a painful reminder of what happened instead.

Title: Obama Faces Significant Hurdles in Pursuit of Grand Bargain Amidst Tax Increase Controversy

Article:

President Obama is facing substantial, and possibly insurmountable, obstacles in reviving a grand bargain, with the most significant hurdle being his decision to implement a $600 billion tax increase in December. At the time, Obama claimed victory by imposing new taxes on the wealthy while preserving George W. Bush's tax cuts for other individuals. However, this victory now appears more like a missed opportunity than a political or policy triumph.

Instead, it seems likely that the $600 billion in tax increases will represent the extent of new revenue Obama can secure. This is significantly less than the $1.6 trillion he aims for, or even the $1 trillion-plus that was discussed in previous grand bargain negotiations.

Obama initially believed he could pressure Republicans into doubling the size of his tax increase to avoid severe defense cuts due to the sequester. However, he was mistaken. Once Republicans accepted the $600 billion in tax hikes, they made it clear they were no longer open to further tax increases for the current Congress. According to Republicans, they are indeed done raising taxes.

The primary reason top Democrats and Republicans dismiss the possibility of a grand bargain this time around is the strained relationship between Obama and Republicans on Capitol Hill. House Majority Whip Kevin McCarthy (R-Calif.), the third-ranking House Republican, shared an anecdote of an exchange he had with Obama at Saturday night's white-tie Gridiron dinner. During a break in the program, McCarthy approached Obama, who was reading his BlackBerry.

According to McCarthy, Obama responded to McCarthy's jest about waiting for a dinner invitation by referring to House Budget Chairman Paul Ryan and stating, "You guys give us too much credit. We’re not doing all that stuff you think we are." As McCarthy walked away, he thought: "He’s still a law professor. He’d rather lecture you and put a red mark on your paper than talk to you."

Another reason for the diminished prospects of a grand bargain is the rancid relationship between Obama and Republicans on Capitol Hill. A senior Democratic leadership aide stated, "Nobody is even talking about a grand bargain. It is not even on our radar right now." An adviser to Speaker John Boehner echoed this sentiment, stating that the window for a grand bargain was closed by Obama's hardball tactics since the tax hike.

Title: Newly Released Text Messages Suggest FBI Officials Knew No Charges Would Be Filed Against Hillary Clinton Before Interview

Article:

The Justice Department has provided nearly 400 pages of additional text messages between two FBI officials, Peter Strzok and Lisa Page, who were removed from Special Counsel Robert Mueller's investigation into alleged collusion between the Trump campaign and Russian officials. The messages, which were released to congressional committees on Friday, reportedly indicate that Strzok and Page knew that charges would not be filed against Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton as a result of the investigation into her email server before Clinton was interviewed by the bureau.

Strzok, an FBI counterintelligence agent, and Page were pulled off the probe last summer after it emerged that some of their messages to each other included anti-Trump content. Strzok was reassigned to the Bureau's human resources division after the discovery of the exchanges with Page, with whom he was having an affair.

According to a Saturday letter to FBI Director Christopher Wray from Sen. Ron Johnson, R-Wis., the chairman of the Senate Homeland Security Committee, the Justice Department provided 384 pages of messages to lawmakers on Friday. However, Johnson noted that additional texts sent between Dec. 14, 2016, and May 17 of last year were not preserved by the FBI's system.

One exchange between Strzok and Page, dated July 1, 2016, referenced then-Attorney General Loretta Lynch's decision to accept the FBI's conclusion in the Clinton investigation. Lynch's announcement came days after it was revealed that the attorney general and former President Bill Clinton had an impromptu meeting aboard her plane in Phoenix.

"Yeah, that is awful timing," Page agreed in the message. In a later message, she added, "It's a real profile in courage, since she knows no charges will be brought."

Four days later, then-FBI Director James Comey announced that no charges would be brought against Clinton, even though -- as he put it -- her actions in regard to the private server were "extremely careless."

Another exchange from the day before referenced a change to Comey's statement closing out the investigation. While an earlier draft of the statement said Clinton and President Barack Obama had an email exchange while Clinton was "on the territory" of a hostile adversary, the reference to Obama at first was changed to "senior government official" and then omitted entirely in the final version.

Last month, the Justice Department released hundreds of text messages that the two had traded before becoming part of the Mueller investigation. Many focused on their observations of the 2016 election and included discussions of the Clinton investigation. Republican lawmakers have contended the communication reveals the FBI and the Mueller team to be politically tainted and biased against Trump -- assertions Wray has flatly rejected.

In Johnson's letter to Wray, he asked whether the FBI had any records of communications between Strzok and Page during that five-month window and whether the FBI had searched their non-FBI phones for additional messages. He also asks for the "scope and scale" of any other records from the Clinton investigation that have been lost.

A source on the committees receiving the texts told Fox News it was "outrageous" that the FBI had not previously indicated that the five-month gap in the messages existed. The source said it was incumbent on the FBI to prove that the missing texts do not constitute "obstruction" of congressional oversight or "destruction of evidence."

The source added that congressional investigators want to know if the Justice Department's inspector general has copies of the messages.

Title: Investigative Journalist Sharyl Attkisson Exposes "Smear Machine" in Political Landscape

Article:

In her latest book, "The Smear: How Shady Political Operatives and Fake News Control What You See, What You Think, and How You Vote," investigative journalist Sharyl Attkisson discusses the manipulation of public perception through a hidden agenda. In a recent interview with Jenna Browder of ███, Attkisson explained the existence of an industry that targets journalists, whistleblowers, and political figures to smear their reputation.

"There is an industry that is paid to go after and target journalists, whistleblowers, political figures, whatever it may be, and inundate our consciousness and the images we see to try to ruin, destroy, or smear the idea that they don't like or the person who's delivering it on behalf of paid corporate or political interests," Attkisson said.

Attkisson further elaborated on the concept, quoting a smear artist who stated, "Everything you see is put there for a reason." She explained that the images and narratives people encounter, whether it's on social media, television, or in the news, are often placed there by someone who paid a lot of money to do so.

The 2016 election, according to Attkisson, serves as a prime example of this "smear machine" operating at full speed. "There was the idea in the past that conservatives had the edge, but for 2016, going into that race, all seem to agree that Democrats had control of the messaging, particularly when it came to using the news media," she said.

In her book, Attkisson uses statistics from Freedom of Information Act requests and information exposed by outlets like WikiLeaks to illustrate the influence of these groups on the narrative. "These groups say how they were able to influence the narrative. They name names. They talk about the news publications and networks that publish the stories they wanted them to publish. I've even published emails between journalists and these interests that they're supposed to cover, showing what I call transactional journalism, which I think is ethically inappropriate when they're making deals with the news makers," she said.

Despite Democrats' alleged control of the messaging, Republicans ultimately won the election. Attkisson attributes this to voters becoming more media-savvy. "Are people getting wise to these techniques? Are they seeing through some of the narratives? I think it's fair to say that 90 percent of the news narrative was in one direction, and yet Donald Trump still managed to overcome what this huge machine had built against him," she said.

Regarding the Russia probe, Attkisson stated, "President Trump is correct when he says that this is a 'witch hunt' in some respect based on the evidence to date and based on Obama's own intel experts who not only didn't see any evidence of collusion between Donald Trump and the Russians by their own account, but also by the account of all public information, Democrats and Republicans alike, who haven't seen the connection and yet, you've seen it dominate the news narrative."

Attkisson further criticized the coverage of the Russia probe, stating that it is disproportionate to the evidence at large. "I call it like the Brady Bunch, 'Marsha, Marsha, Marsha.' You just hear, 'Russia, Russia, Russia' all the time, and there have been wildly incorrect reports from some formerly top-respected news outlets in the nation about all of this, and in some cases, they haven't even corrected or done mea culpas when what they report has been found to be false," she said.

Attkisson concluded by emphasizing the importance of questioning nearly everything one sees or reads, approaching it with a healthy dose of skepticism. "Nearly every image that's put before them, in the words of the people who operate in this universe, is put before them for a reason by an interest that is often not disclosed. That should make you question when you see themes and memes coming up on social media and common ideas expressed over and over again. That should make you question, who's behind it? Who wants me to think this way?"

Title: Quinnipiac University Poll Shows President Obama Leading in Three Key Battleground States

Article:

According to a new poll conducted by Quinnipiac University, former President Barack Obama is leading his Republican opponent, Mitt Romney, in three key battleground states. The poll, which was jointly conducted with The New York Times and CBS, shows Obama with a significant lead in Florida, Ohio, and Pennsylvania.

In Florida, Obama holds a six-point lead with 51% of likely voters favoring him, compared to 45% who lean toward Romney. In Ohio, the lead is five points, with Obama at 50% and Romney at 44%. In Pennsylvania, Obama's lead is even more substantial, with 53% of likely voters supporting him, compared to 42% for Romney.

The poll also indicates that Obama is viewed more positively by voters in each state, with at least 50% holding a favorable opinion of him. Romney, on the other hand, was underwater on favorability in all three states, performing the worst in Pennsylvania, where only 39% of voters hold a favorable view of the former Massachusetts governor, compared to 47% with an unfavorable view.

The poll suggests that voters supporting Romney in all three states are more likely to back him because they dislike Obama, rather than vice versa. In Florida, for example, nearly two-thirds of Obama's supporters say they strongly favor their candidate, compared to 14% who support him because they dislike Romney. In contrast, 49% of Romney's backers strongly favor him, with 19% supporting him because they dislike Obama.

The poll was conducted from July 24 through July 30 among 1,193 likely voters in Ohio, 1,168 likely voters in Florida, and 1,168 likely voters in Pennsylvania. The sample size of Democrats was greater in the poll, with 36% of Florida voters identifying as Democrats, compared to 27% Republicans and 32% independents. The split was nearly identical in Ohio, with 35% saying they were Democrats, 27% Republicans, and 32% independents. In Pennsylvania, 38% considered themselves Democrats, 32% Republicans, and 26% independents.

Voters were also evenly split on which candidate would do a better job on the economy, the most important issue for voters in all three states. However, they strongly support Obama's plan to raise taxes on households making more than $250,000 to reduce the federal deficit, with 62% of Pennsylvania voters, 60% in Ohio, and 58% in Florida supporting the plan.

Title: U.S. Economy Adds 157,000 Jobs in July; Unemployment Rate Dips to 3.9 Percent

The U.S. economy continued to add jobs at a steady pace in July, with the unemployment rate remaining low. The Labor Department reported a lower-than-expected job growth of 157,000 and an unemployment rate of 3.9 percent, as projected.

Payrolls were revised upward by 59,000 for the prior two months. They grew 248,000 in June, up from the previously reported 213,000, and 268,000 in May, compared with the 244,000 last reported. Over the prior 12 months, payrolls have been growing an average of 203,000 per month.

Manufacturing jobs grew by 37,000 in July, jobs in professional and business services were up 51,000, and leisure and hospitality jobs rose 40,000.

Analysts had estimated that about 190,000 jobs were added in July, and they had expected the unemployment rate to inch down to 3.9 percent from June's 4 percent. Before this year, the last time the jobless rate was this low was in 2000.

In July, average hourly earnings increased by 7 cents, to $27.05. That level is up 2.7 percent over the prior year, the same as June's pace. With the economy at full employment and hiring managers struggling to fill open positions, wages normally would be expected to start rising at a faster rate. However, wages are increasing at a 2.7 percent annual rate, which is lower than some economists' expectations of about 3.5 percent.

The economy picked up dramatically in the second quarter, with a 4.1 percent pace—lifted by jumps in consumer spending and exports—being the strongest in nearly four years. Some economists attributed these factors to temporary factors, such as the Republican tax cuts and increased export shipments ahead of retaliatory tariffs by China on U.S. agricultural products.

President Trump called the numbers "very sustainable," adding, "This is not a one-time shot...Next quarter, I think it's going to be outstanding." The Federal Reserve noted that the labor market has "continued to strengthen" and that the economy overall has also been strong. It decided to keep interest rates unchanged but has signaled that it will hike them twice more this year.

Title: Post-Election Republican Response to Immigration and Latino Vote

Article:

In the aftermath of the 2008 presidential election, Republican elites advocated for an amnesty policy for illegal immigrants, a move that nearly caused a rift within the party, according to a piece by Rich Lowry. The article, titled "The amnesty fantasy," suggests that the post-election Republican reaction was driven by panic, wishful thinking, and ethnic pandering.

John McCain, who supported comprehensive immigration reform, nearly alienated himself within the Republican Party with his stance on amnesty. Despite this, McCain managed to secure 4 percentage points more support among Latino voters in 2008 than Mitt Romney did in 2012, according to exit polls.

The article questions the assumption that amnesty is the key to winning over the Latino vote. It argues that the common thread uniting McCain and Romney, both Republicans, is their support for conservative economic policies, rather than their positions on immigration.

The article also highlights demographic data from the U.S. Census Bureau. Among native-born Hispanics, 50 percent of households with children are headed by unmarried mothers, and about 40 percent of all households receive benefits from a major welfare program. The article suggests that these statistics indicate that these households may not be natural Republican voters.

Furthermore, the article points out that Latinos tend to have liberal attitudes toward government, with 61 percent of Latinos supporting the preservation of Obamacare and 66 percent believing the government should ensure access to health insurance. This could be attributed to the fact that 32 percent of nonelderly Latinos lack health insurance, about twice the national average.

Title: Defense Secretary James Mattis Resigns, Cites Policy Differences with President Trump

Article:

Defense Secretary James Mattis has resigned, citing policy differences with President Donald Trump in a letter released on Thursday. Mattis, a retired four-star general, had been considered one of the president's most critical cabinet members due to his role as a strong check against Trump's national security impulses.

In his resignation letter, Mattis reiterated his belief in America's alliances and partnerships, particularly NATO, and the need for the U.S. to be "resolute and unambiguous" in challenging countries such as China and Russia. He wrote, "We must do everything possible to advance an international order that is most conducive to our security, prosperity, and values, and we are strengthened in this effort by the solidarity of our alliances."

President Trump announced Mattis' departure as a retirement, tweeting that Mattis would be stepping down at the end of February. Trump credited Mattis with helping his administration with the "purchase of new fighting equipment" and helping other countries pay their military obligations. Trump added that he would name a new secretary of defense shortly.

Mattis' resignation comes a day after Trump made the abrupt decision to withdraw 2,000 troops from Syria. The tone of Mattis' resignation letter clashed with Trump's own announcement, which characterized Mattis' decision to quit as a retirement.

Throughout his tenure, Mattis had a mixed record of success with Trump. He opposed pulling out of the Iran deal, moving the U.S. embassy in Israel to Jerusalem, creating a Space Force, and starting a trade war with America's allies. However, he failed to persuade Trump to see things his way on each of those issues, despite his good rapport with the president.

Mattis' departure leaves National Security Adviser John Bolton and Secretary of State Mike Pompeo to face less resistance as they offer more hawkish advice on North Korea, Iran, and more. Mattis had a few notable successes, such as stopping Trump from ordering the assassination of Syrian President Bashar al-Assad and ensuring the Trump administration stuck to a diplomatic approach with North Korea rather than a military one. However, he also made questionable decisions, such as recommending an attack on terrorists in Yemen that led to the death of a Navy SEAL and avoiding speaking on camera to the press and curtailing media access to the Pentagon.

With Mattis gone, there are concerns that Trump is left with few if any moderating influences on his national security team. Mattis, along with National Security Adviser H.R. McMaster and Secretary of State Rex Tillerson, were frequently labeled as some of the few "adults" in the room whose military and strategic expertise would help them gain Trump's trust and moderate the president's most dangerous foreign policy impulses. However, like much in Trump's world, it didn't happen quite that way. Many still say they'll miss Mattis, and that U.S. foreign policy may be worse off without him.

Title: Biden's Interview with Charlamagne tha God: A Testy Exchange or a Productive Dialogue?

Article:

In a recent interview with Charlamagne tha God, the popular African American radio host and former Vice President Joe Biden, the presumptive Democratic presidential nominee, engaged in a conversation that has been described as a "testy exchange." However, this characterization may not accurately represent the nature of the discussion.

Charlamagne, known for his incisive questioning of politicians, pressed Biden on various issues, including the Democratic Party's relationship with black voters, Biden's support of the 1994 crime bill, the decriminalization of marijuana, and the push for a black woman as a running mate. The interview, which was taped on Thursday, was cut short twice due to scheduling conflicts, but Biden continued the conversation both times.

During the interview, Biden addressed several policy proposals, including his defense of the good aspects of the 1994 crime bill and his plans for the future. Charlamagne, who has a significant following of 2.1 million Twitter followers, engaged Biden in a respectful and probing manner, allowing the interviewee to answer tough questions without being overly confrontational.

The interview ended with a light-hearted exchange, during which Biden jokingly stated, "You got more questions, but I tell you what, if you have a problem figuring out whether you’re for me or Trump, then you ain’t black." This statement, made in the context of the previous 17 minutes and 21 seconds of the interview, is likely to be interpreted as a humorous comment, given Biden's long-standing relationship with the African American community and his service as Vice President to the nation's first black president.

The willfully ignorant might misinterpret Biden's statement as a challenge to one's blackness, similar to questioning someone's blackness for not having seen a particular movie. Instead, it appears to be an expression of exasperation, akin to saying, "Where have you been?" rather than "You’ve been voted off the island."

The interview concluded with an invitation for Biden to return to the Breakfast Club, where Charlamagne will continue to press him on various issues affecting the African American community, and Biden will have another opportunity to seek the support of black voters.

Title: Mega-Donor Glass Ceiling: Women Largely Absent in Political Contributions

Article:

In the 2012 election, Miriam Adelson, a physician and drug addiction expert, was the top female donor, contributing approximately $46 million, primarily to Republican committees and super PACs. This amount was more than twice the combined contributions of the next top 15 women donors. Her husband, Las Vegas casino mogul Sheldon Adelson, donated $50 million. However, Miriam Adelson did not receive the same attention as her husband, despite her significant contributions.

Women are making strides in various political spheres, but their campaign contributions lag significantly behind those of male donors. Reasons for this disparity include a relative lack of cash, distaste for the political process, and the decision to donate money elsewhere, according to a ███ survey.

The lack of women megadonors has an impact on the political discourse, as it is wealthy men such as Charles and David Koch, Jeffrey Katzenberg, or Foster Friess who often have the clout. These individuals are the ones who are chased down by reporters, appear on cable TV, and whose ideas can drive the national conversation.

Siobhan “Sam” Bennett, president and CEO of the Women’s Campaign Fund and a former Democratic congressional candidate, stated, “It would be naive to say that political giving doesn’t influence what gets discussed and what gets talked about.” Amber Mostyn, a Democratic megadonor and Houston trial lawyer, who donated $1.3 million to federal candidates and super PACs in the 2012 election, and thousands more to state-level candidates in Texas, said the lack of women donors “absolutely” affects policy.

The discrepancy in political contributions is evident in the numbers. Of the top 100 overall donors, 11 were women, accounting for approximately 17% of the total amount given by those 100 donors, according to a ███ review of Federal Election Commission reports and data from the Center for Responsive Politics. The disparity continues down the line, with women accounting for 28% of the top 31,000 donors, according to the Sunlight Foundation.

The numbers are based on contributions to campaigns, committees, and super PACs, and do not include contributions to 501(c)(4) nonprofits such as Americans for Prosperity that are not required to disclose donors. Although seven of the 400 richest self-made people in the United States are women, according to Forbes, and women hold far fewer high-level corporate jobs and board seats, donations from women to political causes, parties, and candidates have lagged behind men even when controlling for income.

Susie Tomkins Buell, a Democratic megadonor associated with Democracy Alliance, an exclusive group of top liberal donors, stated, “The reason women don’t give to politics is because they’re lacking the mentorship and the support that men receive.” Buell added, “But once they get invited in, they feel very empowered by the act.”

Title: U.S. Prosecutor Accuses Prince Andrew of Zero Cooperation in Jeffrey Epstein Investigation

Article:

NEW YORK (AP) — Britain's Prince Andrew has provided "zero cooperation" to the American investigators who want to interview him as part of their sex trafficking probe into Jeffrey Epstein, a U.S. prosecutor said Monday.

Speaking at a news conference outside Epstein's New York mansion, U.S. Attorney Geoffrey Berman said prosecutors and the FBI had contacted Andrew's lawyers and asked to interview him.

"To date, Prince Andrew has provided zero cooperation," said Berman, the top federal prosecutor in Manhattan.

Prince Andrew announced last year that he was withdrawing from his royal duties amid renewed public attention on a woman's claim that she had several sexual encounters with the prince at Epstein's behest, starting when she was 17.

Virginia Roberts Giuffre says that after meeting Epstein in Florida in 2000, the millionaire flew her around the world and pressured her into having sex with numerous older men, including Andrew, two senior U.S. politicians, a noted academic, wealthy financiers, and the attorney Alan Dershowitz, who is now part of President Donald Trump's impeachment defense team.

All of those men have denied the allegations. Epstein killed himself in his jail cell last summer while he was awaiting trial on sex trafficking charges.

Giuffre has said she had sex with Andrew three times, including once in London in 2001 at the home of Epstein's girlfriend, Ghislaine Maxwell. It isn't clear what legal exposure Andrew might have in the case, if any. The age of consent for sex is 16 in England and 17 in New York. However, Giuffre claims that she was paid by Epstein for her sexual encounters with Andrew. That could constitute a violation of U.S. sex trafficking laws if she was under age 18 or was coerced into unwanted sex acts.

Andrew, who is eighth in line for the British throne, and Maxwell have both denied any knowledge that Epstein was sexually abusing teenage girls. In a TV interview last fall, Andrew insisted he was out having pizza with his children on the night Giuffre says they were together in London.

U.S. Attorney General William Barr has vowed to aggressively investigate and bring charges against anyone who may have helped Epstein.

Andrew, in the statement he released in November announcing his intention to "step back from public duties," said he regretted his "ill-judged association with Jeffrey Epstein."

"Of course, I am willing to help any appropriate law enforcement agency with their investigations, if required," he wrote.

Berman made his remarks about the case during a joint appearance with members of Safe Horizon, a nonprofit victim services agency, to discuss a new New York law that made it easier for people to sue over childhood sexual abuse.

He wouldn't discuss the Epstein investigation in detail but reiterated that the case didn't end with his death.

"Jeffrey Epstein couldn't have done what he did without the assistance of others, and I can assure you that the investigation is moving forward," Berman said.

Numerous women who said they were sexually abused by Epstein as teenagers have claimed in lawsuits and interviews that he got help recruiting young girls from both Maxwell and several assistants.

Giuffre's lawyers have, for months, been calling on Andrew to agree to be interviewed both by investigators and by the lawyers helping the women with those civil lawsuits.

To date, the only people besides Epstein who were charged in connection with the scandal are two jail guards who were supposed to be monitoring Epstein the night he was found dead. Both have been charged with falsifying the jail's log books to indicate they were performing checks on prisoners, when they were actually sleeping or browsing the internet.

Title: White House Confirms President Obama's Support for Assault Weapons Ban in Gun Control Push

Article:

Washington, CNN – President Barack Obama has announced his intention to seek passage of an assault weapons ban as part of a broader push for new gun control laws, according to a White House official. This announcement comes after Vice President Joe Biden's presentation of potential gun control proposals on Thursday, which did not include an assault weapons ban.

The omission of an assault weapons ban in Biden's proposals led to speculation in news reports that the White House had abandoned the idea. However, White House spokesman Matt Lehrich stated, "Those reports are false." Lehrich added, "The President has been clear that Congress should reinstate the assault weapons ban, and avoiding this issue just because it's been politically difficult in the past is not an option."

Over the past week, Vice President Biden has been meeting with various stakeholders in the gun control debate. On Thursday, he held discussions with the National Rifle Association (NRA) and other gun owners groups, as well as representatives from the film and television industry.

Administration officials note that Biden's comments on Thursday were aimed at "consensus" proposals emerging from the task force meetings. An assault weapons ban would not fit this category.

In a statement following their meeting with the vice president, the NRA expressed disappointment and accused the administration of pursuing an "agenda to attack the Second Amendment."

Organizations advocating for tougher gun control laws argue that an assault weapons ban is crucial in addressing the nation's recent spate of mass shootings. However, implementing such a ban could face challenges in a gridlocked Congress.

A spokesman for House Speaker John Boehner stated it would be premature to comment on Vice President Biden's remarks. The Biden task force is expected to deliver its recommendations to the president on Tuesday. "Once the President makes some recommendations, we'll take a look at them," Boehner spokesman Brendan Buck said.

Title: Clinton and Kaine Criticize Trump's 100-Day Agenda, Emphasize Democratic Traditions

Article:

In a campaign event on Saturday, Democratic presidential nominee Hillary Clinton and her running mate, Senator Tim Kaine of Virginia, criticized Republican rival Donald Trump's proposed first 100 days in office. The criticism centered on Trump's threat to sue women who have accused him of making unwanted sexual advances.

Speaking to reporters on their campaign plane, Clinton and Kaine argued that Trump seemed more focused on settling personal grievances than on governing. Trump had earlier spoken at the Civil War battlefield in Gettysburg, Pennsylvania, where he outlined his agenda for the first 100 days of his presidency and threatened to sue his accusers after the election.

Clinton stated, "Our opponent, Donald Trump, went to Gettysburg, one of the most extraordinary places in American history, and basically said if he’s president, he will spend his time suing women who have made charges against him based on his behavior."

In contrast, Clinton and Kaine emphasized their focus on serving the American people if elected. "Tim and I are going to keep talking about what we want to do if we’re given the great honor of serving as president and vice president," Clinton said. "We’ll get to work the day after the election and do everything possible to be prepared on Jan. 20 to start doing the business of the American people."

Kaine added that Trump "seemed most personally invested in...all of the scores that he needs to settle with people he’s mad at."

The event followed a rally at a local high school in Pittsburgh, where Clinton touched on a theme she has emphasized in recent days: that Trump poses a threat to America's democratic traditions. Clinton has criticized Trump for suggesting he might not concede the election in the event of a defeat.

Clinton stated, "Failing to accept election results, however disappointing, is the difference between 'leadership and dictatorship.'" She added that Trump shows a troubling disregard for constitutional freedoms and protections.

Clinton also referred to Trump's contention that she should be jailed for using a private email system while she was secretary of state. "Every time he says he wants to jail his opponent—meaning me—I think to myself, 'We don’t do that in America. We actually have laws and courts and an independent judiciary,'" she said.

Clinton also devoted time to the campaign of Democratic Senate candidate Katie McGinty, who is challenging incumbent Pennsylvania Republican Pat Toomey. Democrats believe McGinty's defeat is central to retaking control of the Senate and providing Clinton with a friendlier Congress should she win in November.

In devoting time to McGinty's campaign, Clinton demonstrated her focus on down-ballot races that would affect her policy agenda should she win on Nov. 8. "Katie will help us break through the gridlock—actually make a difference in people’s lives," Clinton said.

Title: Senate Democrats Block Unanimous Vote on Additional Small Business Aid Amid Disagreements Over Coronavirus Relief Package

Article:

Senate Democrats have blocked a Republican push to unanimously pass a bill to provide an additional $250 billion for a loan program aimed at small businesses affected by the coronavirus pandemic. The move came after Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-KY) attempted to approve the measure by a unanimous vote, but was stalled by Sen. Ben Cardin (D-MD), who objected to the request.

On the Senate floor, McConnell stated he was not "talking about changing any policy language" that was part of an unprecedented $2 trillion emergency spending package negotiated between the parties last month. He urged Democrats not to "block emergency aid you do not even oppose just because you want something more" – referring to proposed changes to the small business aid program and additional emergency funding for hospitals and states, a proposal Democratic leaders outlined on Wednesday.

Sen. Chris Van Hollen (D-MD) then attempted to unanimously pass a Democratic amendment, which McConnell blocked, leading to the Senate adjourning until Monday after a roughly 30-minute pro forma session. It is unclear if Republicans and Democrats will try to reach agreement on emergency legislation in the coming days.

House Speaker Nancy Pelosi has indicated she could try to pass a Democratic bill on Friday, which Republicans can likely block with most representatives out of Washington. Speaking to reporters on Thursday, Pelosi called McConnell's move a "stunt."

Pelosi also stated that Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin asked for a quarter of a trillion dollars in 48 hours without providing data to justify the need. Pelosi echoed Sen. Ben Cardin in calling McConnell's move a "stunt."

The Kentucky Republican contended that the small business aid is the only part of the $2 trillion rescue law "at risk of exhausting its funding right now." The Trump administration cited strong demand for the loans this week as it asked Congress for more money for the program, which is designed to help small businesses keep employees on payroll. Lawmakers initially approved $350 billion for loans, which can be forgiven partly or fully if companies use them on expenses such as payroll, rent, and utilities.

On Wednesday, Pelosi and Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer asked for an emergency bill to include $250 billion for hospitals, health systems, state and local governments, and food assistance programs, in addition to money for small companies. However, Pelosi said she only wanted $125 billion for the existing program specifically, and another $125 billion for community-based lenders and SBA disaster assistance loans and grants.

The Democrats have expressed concerns about the small business loan program, citing reports of confusion around applications, loan terms, and eligibility. They also worry that the program may leave out rural business owners, farmers, and small firms who do not already work with a bank participating in the program. McConnell contends that Democrats do not need to attach other emergency funding measures to the small business plan.

"Nobody believes this is the Senate's last word on COVID-19. We do not have to do everything right now," McConnell said.

Title: Ezra Klein's Book "Why We're Polarized" Explores American Polarization, Minimally Attributing Role to Technology

Article:

In a conversation with Nicholas Thompson, editor-at-large at Vox and host of The Ezra Klein Show podcast, Ezra Klein discusses his new book "Why We're Polarized." The book, released during the impeachment hearings, delves into the historical context of American polarization, arguing that the country has become significantly more polarized over the past 50 years.

Thompson, who had read the book's galleys, praised its captivating exploration of American history and its persuasive argument that the country is more polarized now than in the past. When asked about the role of technology in the book, Klein clarified that while social media is a polarization accelerant, it plays a relatively small role in the overall story of American polarization, as the bulk of the increase in party polarization predates social media.

Klein's core argument is that over the past 50 years, the country's dominant political coalitions have sorted themselves by ideology, race, religion, geography, psychology, consumer behavior, and cultural preferences. This sorting has triggered a series of feedback loops in which political institutions (media, Congress) and actors (candidates, individual journalists) adopt more polarized strategies to respond and appeal to a more polarized audience, which further polarizes the audience, the institutions, and so on.

Thompson expressed concerns about the role of the press in this feedback loop, citing the example of a newspaper that is relentlessly critical of a particular political figure, which may attract critics of that figure, leading to increased page views and incentivizing more of the same. Klein agreed with Thompson's assessment, acknowledging the two basic problems caused by this kind of polarization: a constant state of anger and agitation, and the inability of political institutions to function effectively due to the high levels of compromise required.

Klein's primary concern is that the current level of polarization makes bipartisanship irrational for the out-of-power party to offer, as winning an election rarely grants the power to govern. In a polarized system, bipartisanship is necessary, but with parties as polarized as they are, bipartisanship is irrational for the out-of-power party to offer. This leaves the public trapped in a system where everyone is fighting, but their problems are not being resolved.

Title: Obama Administration Launches Nationwide Campaign to Promote Health Care Enrollment

Article:

President Barack Obama's public appearances may suggest that he has retired from campaigning, but the White House is gearing up for a significant campaign this summer, aiming to cover all 50 states and the District of Columbia. The success or failure of this campaign could potentially shape Obama's legacy, as the Affordable Care Act, also known as "Obamacare," faces a new challenge: convincing uninsured individuals to purchase health care when it becomes available on October 1.

During his commencement address at Morehouse College this month, Obama urged graduates to sign up for health insurance in the fall. He emphasized the importance of universal health coverage, stating, "We've got to make sure everybody has good health in this country. It's not just good for you, it's good for this country. So you're going to have to spread the word to your fellow young people."

David Simas, deputy senior adviser to the president, oversees the implementation of universal health coverage from a windowless basement office in the West Wing. The administration aims to enroll 7 million people across the country in the first year, a goal that Simas says will require television ads, door-to-door canvassing, and extensive word-of-mouth efforts.

The administration is developing an Expedia-style website to make the enrollment process as user-friendly as possible. However, attracting people to this website is a significant challenge. A Kaiser Family Foundation poll from last month revealed that 4 in 10 Americans are unaware that the health care law is still in effect.

Nancy-Ann DeParle, who has worked on this issue for years, including as Obama's deputy chief of staff, is not concerned about this lack of awareness. She believes that people were not paying attention until now, as there is so much else happening that would have made a campaign two years ago ineffective.

However, the administration's efforts have already faced obstacles. Health and Human Services Secretary Kathleen Sebelius has repeatedly requested funding from Congress to implement Obamacare, but Republicans have consistently refused, while voting to repeal the law. Without the requested funding, Sebelius attempted to fundraise for an independent group called Enroll America, which focuses on implementing Obamacare. This move has sparked controversy, with Republicans accusing Sebelius of bypassing Congress by soliciting private donations.

Two Republican-controlled House committees are now investigating these solicitations, which has reportedly made potential donors hesitant. If health care companies hold back, it could make it more difficult to reach the target audience in various communities.

Another crucial aspect of the campaign is ensuring that young and healthy individuals, who typically require less medical care, enroll in the system to balance out the financial structure. Administration officials are expected to deliver more commencement speeches this season, encouraging young graduates to sign up for health coverage in the fall.

Title: House Republicans Resist Senate's Call for IRS Tax Enforcement Measures

Article:

House Republicans, who have criticized the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) for over a year, are now resisting calls to strengthen tax enforcement measures. They are opposing several Senate proposals aimed at addressing tax evasion, such as targeting doctors with back taxes, simplifying the process of verifying mortgage interest deductions, and reducing incorrect child tax credit claims.

This shift in stance represents a significant departure from a few years ago when Republicans supported efforts to enhance IRS's ability to clamp down on tax shelters and collaborate with foreign banks to identify undeclared American income abroad.

The change in attitude is attributed to a 2013 report by an inspector general that criticized the IRS for excessively scrutinizing tea party groups seeking tax-exempt status. Since then, over 20 congressional hearings have been held, leading to a lack of confidence in the IRS among both the public and Congress members.

Representative Pat Tiberi (R-Ohio), a member of the tax-writing Ways and Means Committee, stated, "There’s not a whole lot of confidence right now about what the Internal Revenue Service does among the American people, let alone members of Congress. Why should we give them more tools to harass taxpayers?"

Political considerations also play a role in the resistance to tax enforcement measures. Cracking down on tax evasion could conflict with the House Republicans' campaign message this election year, according to Floyd Williams, the IRS's former director of legislative affairs.

The disagreement not only jeopardizes efforts to collect the estimated $400 billion in unpaid taxes annually, but it also threatens unrelated legislation. A highway budget bill containing several of the provisions is set to expire in the Senate this week due to House Republican opposition. Another Senate measure offering tax cuts to startup companies, small businesses, and certain industries is also at risk.

The position of House Republicans contrasts with that of Senate Republicans, who have traditionally been less zealous in their pursuit of the IRS. Senator John Thune (R-SD), a member of the Senate Finance Committee, stated, "I don’t think Senate Republicans on the [Finance] committee have a big problem with just making sure taxes that are owed are being collected. It’s just a function of enforcing the law."

Senate Finance Committee Chairman Ron Wyden (D-OR) expressed concern that House Republicans are undermining a traditionally bipartisan cooperation on tax enforcement matters. "This has been a traditional position supported by both sides of the aisle," he said. "Certainly, this is a departure that needs to be addressed."

Before the tea party scandal, lawmakers had agreed to raise tens of billions of dollars by improving tax collections, often relying on third parties like banks and credit card companies to verify taxpayer declarations. This approach not only made it easier for the IRS to detect errors but also encouraged more accurate reporting due to the knowledge that someone else would also be reporting the information.

Title: ISIS Claims Responsibility for Death of Aid Worker Peter Kassig, Releases Video

Article:

The Islamic State group has released a video on Sunday, allegedly showing the beheading of a dozen Syrian soldiers and claiming responsibility for the death of U.S. aid worker Peter Kassig. The video, posted on websites known to be used by ISIS, ends with a militant standing over a severed head he identifies as Kassig's. The White House confirmed Kassig's death on Sunday afternoon.

The high-definition video shows the beheadings of about a dozen men identified as Syrian military officers and pilots, all dressed in blue jumpsuits. The video was filmed in Dabiq, a town in northern Syria that ISIS uses as the title of its English-language propaganda magazine and where they believe an apocalyptic battle between Muslims and their enemies will occur.

The main militant in the video who speaks to the camera has a British accent and warns that U.S. soldiers will meet a similar fate. "We say to you, Obama," the militant said, "... You claim to have withdrawn from Iraq four years ago, but here you are: You have not withdrawn. Rather, you hid some of your forces behind your proxies."

A U.S.-led coalition is targeting the Islamic State group in airstrikes, supporting Western-backed Syrian rebels, Kurdish fighters, and the Iraqi military. The militant's voice is distorted in the video. Previous videos featured a militant with a British accent that the FBI says it has identified, though it has not named him publicly.

Later in the video, the militant claims Kassig, 26, was killed because he "fought against the Muslims in Iraq while serving as a soldier." Kassig, from Indianapolis, Indiana, served in the U.S. Army's 75th Ranger Regiment, a special operations unit, and deployed to Iraq in 2007. After being medically discharged, Kassig formed the aid organization Special Emergency Response and Assistance (SERA) in Turkey to aid Syrian refugees. He delivered food and medical supplies and provided trauma care to wounded Syrian civilians before being captured in eastern Syria last year. Friends say he converted to Islam in captivity and took the first name Abdul-Rahman.

Burhan Agha, a Syrian friend who worked with Kassig in Lebanon and who moved to Switzerland seeking asylum, wept when recounting his generosity. "If I could apologize to each American, one by one, I would, because Peter died in Syria, while he was helping the Syrian people," Agha told the AP by telephone. "Those who killed him claimed to have done it in the name of Islam. I am a Muslim and am from Syria.... (His killers) are not Muslims."

The White House said the U.S. intelligence community was examining the video. National Security Council spokeswoman Bernadette Meehan said that if the video is authentic, the White House would be "appalled by the brutal murder of an innocent American." British Prime Minister David Cameron said he was "horrified by the cold-blooded murder."

The Islamic State group has beheaded and shot dead hundreds of captives—mainly Syrian and Iraqi soldiers—during its sweep across the two countries, and has celebrated its mass killings in extremely graphic videos. The group has declared a self-styled Islamic caliphate in the areas under its control, which it governs according to its violent interpretation of Shariah law.

On Sunday, the Islamic State group claimed a bombing at the Baghdad International Airport that wounded five people, saying it was trying to strike Americans there. No one was wounded in a passing United Nations convoy, the organization said. The Islamic State group has its roots in al-Qaida's Iraqi affiliate but was expelled from the global terror network over its brutal tactics and refusal to obey orders to confine its activities to Iraq. It became even more extreme amid the bloody civil war in neighboring Syria and grew strong enough to launch a lightning offensive across Iraq. Syria's war began as an uprising against President Bashar Assad. Activists say that conflict has killed more than 200,000 people.

Title: House Democrats Release Trove of Documents from Lev Parnas, Including Handwritten Note on Biden Investigation

Article:

WASHINGTON (AP) — House Democrats have released a trove of documents they obtained from Lev Parnas, a close associate of President Donald Trump's personal lawyer Rudy Giuliani, including a handwritten note that mentions asking Ukraine's president to investigate "the Biden case."

The documents, obtained as part of the impeachment investigation, show Parnas communicating with Giuliani before the removal of Marie Yovanovitch, who was the U.S. ambassador to Ukraine. A man named Robert F. Hyde disparaged Yovanovitch in messages to Parnas and gave him updates on her location and cell phone use, raising questions about possible surveillance.

Democrats released the files Tuesday as they prepared to send articles of impeachment to the Senate for Trump's trial. The documents add new context to their charges that Trump pressured Ukraine to investigate Democrats as he withheld military aid.

Parnas was in frequent communication with Giuliani and with Ukrainian officials, the messages show. He appeared to be pushing unsubstantiated allegations that Democrat Joe Biden and his son, Hunter Biden, were somehow engaged in corruption in Ukraine.

Among the documents is a screenshot of a previously undisclosed letter from Giuliani to Ukrainian President Volodymir Zelenskiy dated May 10, 2019, which was before Zelenskiy took office. In the letter, Giuliani requests a meeting with Zelenskiy "as personal counsel to President Trump and with his knowledge and consent." In the letter, Giuliani said he would be accompanied at the meeting by Victoria Toensing, a Washington attorney and Trump ally.

One of the documents is a handwritten note on stationery from the Ritz-Carlton Hotel in Vienna that says "get Zalensky to Annonce that the Biden case will be Investigated." Trump asked Zelenskiy in a July call to investigate his political rival, Democrat Joe Biden, and his son Hunter, who served on the board of a gas company based in Ukraine.

Democrats said that Parnas' attorney confirmed that Parnas wrote the notes.

The documents — including phone records, texts, and flash drives turned over by Parnas — were sent to the House Judiciary Committee by three other House panels "to be included as part of the official record that will be transmitted to the Senate along with the Articles of Impeachment," according to a statement. Some of the materials were made public while others were marked as sensitive.

Parnas and his business partner, Igor Fruman, both U.S. citizens who emigrated from the former Soviet bloc, were indicted last year on charges of conspiracy, making false statements, and falsification of records. Prosecutors allege they made outsize campaign donations to Republican causes after receiving millions of dollars originating from Russia. The men have pleaded not guilty.

In several of the documents, Parnas communicated with Giuliani about the removal of Yovanovitch. The ambassador's ouster, ordered by Trump, was at the center of the Democrats' impeachment inquiry. Yovanovitch testified in the House impeachment hearings that she was the victim of a "smear campaign."

Trump, on a July 25 call, had promised Zelenskiy that Yovanovitch was "going to go through some things." Roughly two months earlier, she was recalled from her diplomatic post.

On April 23, just before Yovanovitch was directed to return to the United States, Giuliani texted Parnas, "He fired her again." Parnas texted back, "I pray it happens this time I'll call you tomorrow, my brother."

Parnas also received messages from Hyde, who referred to Yovanovitch as a "bitch." Hyde is now running for a U.S. House seat in Connecticut.

After texting about the ambassador, Hyde gave Parnas detailed updates that suggested he was watching her. In one text, Hyde wrote: "She's talked to three people. Her phone is off. Her computer is off." He said she was under heavy security and "we have a person inside."

Hyde at one point texted Parnas that "they are willing to help if we/you would like a price," and "guess you can do anything in Ukraine with money... is what I was told."

Lawrence Robbins, an attorney for Yovanovitch, called for an investigation into the messages.

"Needless to say, the notion that American citizens and others were monitoring Ambassador Yovanovitch's movements for unknown purposes is disturbing," Robbins said. "We trust that the appropriate authorities will conduct an investigation to determine what happened."

On Twitter, Hyde dismissed the claims as "laughable" and appeared to try to distance himself from Parnas. He said he would "welcome" an investigation.

The text messages show that Parnas consulted Giuliani in Jan. 2019 after the U.S. denied a visa for former Ukrainian Prosecutor General Viktor Shokin. Giuliani replied: "I can revive it."

The following day, Giuliani told Parnas: "It's going to work. I have no 1 in it." Giuliani then predicted "he will get one" before giving Parnas the phone number for Jay Sekulow, the leader of the president's personal legal team. Sekulow is expected to be part of Trump's legal team during the impeachment trial.

A federal judge earlier this month ruled that Parnas could provide the materials to Congress as part of the impeachment proceedings.

Democrats voted in December to impeach Trump for abuse of power and for obstruction of Congress.

Title: Romney Promises Opposite Approach to Obama on Israel, Faces Protests in Pennsylvania

Article:

Mitt Romney, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee, has pledged to adopt an opposite approach to President Barack Obama on Israel during a speech to religious conservatives in Pennsylvania on Saturday.
