The speech, delivered via video uplink from his campaign bus, marked Romney's first extensive discussion of Israel since becoming the likely Republican nominee.

Romney criticized Obama for appearing more concerned about Israel potentially attacking Iran than he is about Iran obtaining a nuclear weapon. He stated, "I think, by and large, you can just look at the things the president has done and do the opposite."

The speech was met with criticism from Democrats, who accused Romney of distorting Obama's record on Israel. Spokesman Ben LaBolt said Obama has provided Israel with more security assistance than any other administration and has stood with Israel at the United Nations.

During the day, Romney's bus tour was disrupted by Democratic protests in Quakertown, Pennsylvania. The protests forced Romney to take a detour, leading him to visit a different Wawa store instead of the originally planned location.

Romney's bus tour, which is his first traditional campaign swing since the primary, is aimed at undecided voters in six pivotal states won by Obama in 2008: New Hampshire, Pennsylvania, Ohio, Wisconsin, Michigan, and Iowa. The tour represents a new mode for Romney in the general election and will test him in less-scripted environments.

In addition to his speech on Israel, Romney also discussed economic issues during the tour, emphasizing the need for a "very careful review" of who is giving a fair shot to the American people. He made three appearances in small towns in Pennsylvania, including Quakertown, Cornwall, and the national historic landmark, Cornwall Iron Furnace.

Romney also took time to engage with the local culture, learning the Pennsylvania term for submarine sandwiches—hoagies—and noting the intra-state rivalry between Wawa and Sheetz, two popular convenience stores in the state. However, his efforts to connect with the crowd in Cornwall were met with mixed reactions, as the town is near the state's geographic center, and the crowd was split on their preference for Wawa or Sheetz.

Title: Chicago Mayor and Ivanka Trump Disagree on Interpretation of Chicago's Weekend Violence Incidents

Article:

Chicago Mayor Lori Lightfoot and Presidential adviser Ivanka Trump have engaged in a public disagreement over the interpretation of gun violence incidents in Chicago. In response to the back-to-back mass shootings in Dayton, Ohio, and El Paso, Texas, Ms. Trump tweeted about the violence in Chicago, stating, "As we grieve over the evil mass shootings in El Paso and Dayton, let us not overlook that Chicago experienced its deadliest weekend of the year, with 7 dead and 52 wounded near a playground in the Windy City."

Mayor Lightfoot, in a statement to reporters on Tuesday, rebuked Ms. Trump's tweets, stating they were "misleading." According to the Chicago Tribune, Lightfoot clarified that the incidents did not occur near a playground, and the number of fatalities and wounded were not as high as suggested in the tweet.

Mayor Lightfoot emphasized the importance of accuracy when discussing such sensitive matters and focused on her efforts to keep the city safe. "I'm not going to be distracted by nonsense tweets from people who don't know what they're talking about," she said.

A spokeswoman for Ms. Trump issued a statement reiterating that Chicago had experienced "one of the deadliest weekends" this year and that the first daughter's "point remains the same" about inner-city violence. The statement also acknowledged that the shooting incidents did not occur in one location, as the tweet might have suggested.

Mayor Lightfoot and Ms. Trump previously met in May in Washington, where they discussed workforce development and criminal justice reform, according to the Chicago Tribune.

Title: Analogies Drawn Between Alabama Senate Candidate Roy Moore and George Wallace

Article:

History professor Gordon Harvey at Jacksonville State University in Alabama has noted similarities in the political strategies of Roy Moore, a Republican Senate candidate, and George Wallace, a former Alabama governor known for his staunch segregationist views.

Moore, like Wallace, has been involved in controversial political moments. In a campaign mailer, Moore sent out a statement that read, "Think if a black man went after high school girls, anyone would try to make him a senator?" This statement, while not as incendiary as some of Wallace's remarks, has sparked discussions about the campaign's racial politics.

George Wallace, a Democrat, is often referenced in contemporary Alabama politics due to his significant impact on the state's political landscape. Wallace was a boxer, a circuit judge with ambitious political aspirations, a state leader who defied federal authority, a symbol of defiance against the national cultural direction, a hero to many rural and small-town whites, and a politician who ran national campaigns on a promise to "send them a message." These descriptions align well with Moore's political career.

Wallace's successful 1970 run for governor is often cited as an analogous race. He took on an "unholy coalition" of the Republican and Democratic national parties, militant blacks, and country club millionaires, as described by a national newspaper column. This coalition, with the exception of the White House, is similar to the groups Moore has faced in his political career, following President Trump's endorsement of his candidacy.

However, those who knew Wallace well are quick to point out that the messengers are not alike. Despite the similarities in their messages, the context, intent, and political affiliations of the two individuals are significantly different.

Title: Obama Dismisses Criticism of Syria Response, Cites Substance Over Style

Article:

In an interview with ABC's "This Week" on Sunday, President Barack Obama dismissed criticism of his handling of the Syria crisis, stating that Washington often prioritizes style over substance.

"Folks here in Washington like to grade on style," Obama said. "Had we rolled out something that was very smooth and disciplined and linear, they would have graded it well, even if it was a disastrous policy.... We know that because that's exactly how they graded the Iraq War until it ended up blowing [up] in our face."

The president has faced criticism since last summer when he stated that Syrian President Bashar Assad would "cross a red line" if chemical weapons were used in Syria's ongoing civil war. The criticism intensified last month when Obama suggested the United States should launch a military strike against Assad for using sarin gas in an Aug. 21 chemical weapons attack that killed nearly 1,500 Syrians, but first wanted congressional approval.

However, Congress, the American public, and other world leaders showed little interest in a military strike, which led to potential diplomatic solutions, the origins of which remain unclear.

Some of the sharpest criticism has come from Tennessee Republican Sen. Bob Corker, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. "It's like watching a caged dog," Corker said recently. "Words like ad-hoc, improvised, unsteady come to mind."

Obama, now in his second term, acknowledged he is used to such criticism. "I'm less concerned about style points. I'm much more concerned about getting the policy right," he said in a wide-ranging interview in which he also talked about Iran's pursuit of a nuclear weapon and criticized House Republicans' approach to fiscal negotiations, including an upcoming talk on increasing the federal debt limit.

Obama said the United States' approach to Syria should show Iran that there's the potential for diplomatic solutions to arms standoffs. However, he also said Iran should not assume that his preference for diplomacy means the U.S. won't strike Tehran.

Obama said Iranians understand that their pursuit of a nuclear weapon is "a far larger issue for us" than the use of chemical weapons in Syria. The president also said he has exchanged letters with Iran's new president, but the two have not spoken directly. Obama said he believes Iranian President Hasan Rouhani understands the potential for a diplomatic solution to his country's disputed nuclear program but will not "suddenly make it easy."

Title: New Yorkers Adapt to COVID-19 Etiquette: A Guide to Courteous Living During the Pandemic

Article:

New York City, known for its fast-paced lifestyle and often brusque inhabitants, is facing a new set of social norms during the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. As residents navigate the city's uncharted territory, they are learning to adapt and be more considerate of each other to make quarantine life more bearable.

The New York Post spoke with therapists, professional shoppers, and other experts to compile a guide to courteous living during the pandemic.

Grocery shopping, for instance, requires new etiquette. If your grocery store hasn't mandated that only one person from your party enters the store, follow suit, advises Tim Hickey, an Instacart shopper from Staten Island. This helps essential workers maintain a safe distance at work.

Wearing a mask, even though it may be uncomfortable, is also crucial, Hickey adds. If you're getting your groceries delivered, consider the items you've selected. Heavy items like cases of water bottles or large bags of rice from Costco are hard to carry, making professional shoppers less likely to select your order, says Hickey.

Delivery people prefer no-contact deliveries. Don't expect your groceries to be brought into your home. If you'd like them left in a certain area, note that in the app or contact your driver. "I don't want to hand food to you. It's best if you stay inside your house when I'm delivering anything," says Hickey.

Tipping within the app is best right now, says Hickey, who also drives for DoorDash and Uber Eats. Most of his customers have been tipping him more than 20 percent, he adds.

In normal times, personal space isn't a concept for busy New Yorkers, who pack themselves like sardines into subway cars. However, during the pandemic, it's essential to be mindful about how much room you're taking up on the sidewalk. It's okay to go on walks with members from your household, but step aside when around strangers. Make sure you're staying 6 feet apart, and if there's someone nearby, rearrange yourself into a single file to make passing safer.

Working from home shouldn't change your behavior much, says Maggie Craddock, founder of Workplace Relationships. If you wouldn't alert your team if you're stepping out for 20 minutes in an office setting, there's no need to do so now, either.

Videoconference calls through Zoom or Google Hangouts have become the norm, but they should be used wisely, says Craddock. "Everybody's moods are so fluid right now," she says. So ask your team if they'd prefer to do a call over video or by phone. "One day, people might be dying to see each other's expressions"; other days, not so much.

Be extra kind—to your teammates, who are also under additional strain, and to yourself. If you're feeling burnt out or dealing with a personal problem, be honest about it, and ask for assistance. "If you're honest and direct about it, people are usually willing to help," she says.

If you're living with someone who isn't taking social distancing seriously, be blunt, says Matt Lundquist, a psychotherapist and the founder of Tribeca Therapy. "People need to say, 'Sorry, I know you think I'm being unreasonable, but I need to really insist on this,'" he says. If they push back (don't be the person who pushes back!), say something like, "You don't need to agree on all the nuances of what is and isn't risky, but you do need to respect me."

For other issues, compromise is key. Adults moving back into their parents' house should be extra careful to keep the peace right now—which can mean reigning it in when you want to sound off. This is not the time to have fights that make you re-evaluate your relationship with your mother. "People are needing to make concessions to survive," says Lundquist.

Those concessions can come into play with couples, too. "One partner [may] drink too much," says Lundquist. "I think this is not the moment to be getting in a fight around that. Maybe you're learning things about the long-term viability of this relationship, [which should be dealt with] when we're in a post-pandemic world."

Random video calls are becoming the norm because most of us are at home all day. If this is happening to you and you're not into it, be direct with your loved ones. You can say, "I'm really down today and I'm not up for it," or "I'm exhausted and I had a busy work day." "I think everyone really understands right now," says Gina Tomaine, health and wellness editor at Philadelphia magazine.

Now might also be a good time to check in with your friends about their preferences—are they OK with you calling or inviting them to a video chat without warning, or would they prefer a text first? Tomaine has also noticed that it's harder to end calls gracefully, "because we don't have somewhere to go." She suggests using household obligations as a point to say goodbye, like having to shower or make dinner, to make those transitions smoother.

Title: Presidential Campaign 2020: A Look at the Current Political Landscape

Article:

The 2020 Presidential campaign is shaping up to be an intriguing spectacle, with several potential candidates considering their participation. Mitt Romney, a former Republican candidate, is reportedly contemplating a return to the political arena, possibly attracting support from donors who previously backed Jeb Bush.

Hillary Clinton's campaign continues to garner attention, but there is uncertainty regarding a potential title should she be elected. Suggestions such as "Madame President," "Mrs. President," and "Miss President" have been proposed, with each carrying its own set of connotations.

Vice President Joe Biden, known for his affable yet sometimes gaffe-prone demeanor, remains a contender. His recent suggestion to gun owners to take a shotgun to the front porch and fire at night has sparked controversy.

The Republican establishment is grappling with taking Donald Trump's campaign seriously, as he maintains a lead in polls. Trump, referred to as an "outlier" or "outsider," has attracted criticism for his unconventional political style and controversial remarks.

The liberal media has been critical of Trump's recent rally in Mobile, Alabama, where he reportedly drew a crowd of 20,000 people in a stadium seating 30,000. The crowd size has been a topic of debate, with some arguing that the event exposed empty seats and invited unfavorable comparisons.

President Obama made waves on Monday by suggesting that he might endorse a candidate in the Democratic primaries, hinting that it may not be Hillary Clinton. In a statement, press secretary Josh Earnest expressed admiration for Vice President Joe Biden's political experience and understanding of campaign strategy, without explicitly endorsing him.

An Obama endorsement could carry significant weight in the Democratic primary, signaling support for a candidate who will uphold his legacy. However, in a general election, an Obama endorsement might be perceived as a liability, as some voters may view Obama's presidency as a historical anomaly.

The Republican establishment's apprehension about Donald Trump stems from the fear that his unconventional style and lack of political experience could lead to an electoral defeat, much like the 1940 Republican nomination of Wendell Willkie, a Wall Street lawyer with no prior political experience. The Republican grassroots, a minority of a minority, are reportedly seeking a candidate who will deliver "rough justice" without mercy.

-Wesley Pruden, Editor Emeritus of The Washington Times.

Title: OPM Data Breach: Lawmakers Call for Change as OPM Director Faces Criticism

Article:

In the aftermath of a potential data breach affecting up to 32 million Americans, lawmakers have called for changes in leadership at the Office of Personnel Management (OPM) following a hearing on Wednesday. Katherine Archuleta, the director of the OPM, faced criticism from key lawmakers over her handling of the agency's cybersecurity.

During the hearing, Archuleta acknowledged that she herself may be a victim of the breach and took the matter seriously. However, her performance was described as uneven, with lawmakers expressing dissatisfaction and calling for a housecleaning at the agency.

Committee Chairman Jason Chaffetz, a Utah Republican, stated, "I think you’re part of the problem. I think if you want different results, we’re going to have to have different people." He also addressed OPM Chief Information Officer Donna K. Seymour, stating, "You’re in over your head."

The hearing followed a report by a cybersecurity firm that found federal employees' login and password information scattered across the internet, with dozens of agencies vulnerable to the same type of hack that affected the OPM. The OPM has acknowledged losing data in two breaches: one intrusion stole personal information of about 4.2 million current and former federal employees, and hackers in the second breach gained access to the background check system, with some of the most sensitive information on millions of Americans who have filled out the government's background check packet.

Despite the White House's insistence that President Obama still has faith in Archuleta, Congress has expressed growing impatience. Archuleta refused to disclose the total number of people affected by the data breaches, stating that the OPM cannot determine how many had information stolen in the more intrusive hack of federal background check systems.

At the hearing, Archuleta vehemently denied press reports that 18 million people had been breached, but she could not rebut Chaffetz's speculation that the number could be nearly twice that. In addition to a modernization plan to update its systems, the OPM has also released a cybersecurity plan that includes hiring a cybersecurity adviser by August 1 and learning best practices from industry leaders.

The OPM's inspector general, Patrick McFarland, expressed major concerns with Archuleta's staff's approach and predicted the costs will far exceed the $93 million the OPM has projected. McFarland stated, "The approach that they’re taking, I believe, will fail. They’re going too fast. They’re not doing the basics. And if that’s the case, then we’re going to have a lot of problems down the road."

Criticism also extended to some of the contractors that work with the OPM and suffered their own breaches, including U.S. Investigations Services and Keypoint Government Solutions.

Title: Potential Latino Vice Presidential Candidates for Mitt Romney

Article:

Republican presidential candidate Mitt Romney's potential vice presidential pick is generating significant discussion, with several Latino politicians being mentioned as possibilities. Beyond Sen. Marco Rubio, other Latinos being considered include Govs. Susanna Martinez of New Mexico and Brian Sandoval of Nevada.

Historically, Republican presidential candidates have had difficulty courting Latinos, with the best performance being George W. Bush in 2004, who received 44% of the Hispanic vote. In 2008, only 31% of Latinos voted for Sen. John McCain, while nearly 7 in 10 voted for then-Sen. Barack Obama.

GOP strategist Leslie Sanchez stated, "Republicans need about 40% of the Hispanic vote to be competitive nationally. To add a candidate who happens to be of Hispanic descent is incredibly important, not only because it shows the party can be inclusive, but open-minded Latino independent voters will really see this is a reason to take a second look at the Republican party."

New Mexico Gov. Susanna Martinez is a gun-toting conservative and the first Latina governor in U.S. history. However, she has clashed with fellow Hispanics in New Mexico due to her stance on illegal immigration and her desire to reverse a state law allowing illegal immigrants to get drivers' licenses.

Nevada Gov. Brian Sandoval is a budget-cutting, government-shrinking Republican, but he favors abortion rights, which could be a drawback as a GOP running mate. Sandoval is Latino but does not speak Spanish.

Alberto Gonzales, the first Latino U.S. attorney general, stated that a Hispanic at the top of the ticket may help lure Latino voters, but not a vice president. He emphasized that experience is key, and all three potential candidates - Rubio, Martinez, and Sandoval - were elected to their posts less than 18 months ago.

One challenge in picking a Latino running mate is the diversity within the Hispanic-American community. Rubio is Cuban-American, while Martinez is Mexican-American. In the Latino community, each poses risks for potential culture clashes. Two-thirds of Hispanics in the United States are of Mexican descent, and a much smaller percentage, about 4%, are Cuban.

Some Latino politicians and strategists argue that Hispanics are a natural constituency for the GOP, not the Democratic party. Many Latino voters tend to be fiscally and socially conservative.

The source of the decades-old GOP problem among Hispanic voters is historically doing little to no outreach. That has changed in recent years, but the fight over immigration reform has hampered efforts, which many Hispanic voters perceive as anti-Latino.

Romney's stance on illegal immigration during the GOP primary battle turned particularly strident, which Republican Latino strategists worry may not exactly pull voters to the GOP. While GOP Hispanics such as Gonzales and Sanchez disagree over whether a Latino running mate would really help Romney with Latino voters, they do agree it would be, when it comes to inclusiveness, an extremely important gesture. And it may help Republicans with Latinos in the long run.

Gonzales stated, "If Governor Romney makes a decision that one of the people you mentioned should be with him on the ticket, and if Governor Romney were to win in November, I mean there would be a great deal of pride in the Hispanic community in having that person being in that position."

Title: Senate Confirmation of Mike Pompeo for Secretary of State Faces Opposition Despite Qualifications

Article:

The confirmation of Mike Pompeo as the U.S. Secretary of State is facing opposition despite his qualifications, with the fight not centered on his abilities but rather a power play to deny President Trump a top cabinet official.

Pompeo, currently the Director of the Central Intelligence Agency (CIA), has been praised for his competent leadership and respect among intelligence professionals. His extensive experience, having served as a congressman since 2011, and his impressive academic credentials, including graduating top of his class at West Point and attending Harvard Law School, where he edited the Harvard Law Review, are undisputed.

However, some Democratic senators, such as Jeanne Shaheen of New Hampshire, have expressed opposition to Pompeo's nomination due to his personal views on issues like gay marriage and abortion. This has led to the Foreign Relations Committee, for the first time, withholding its support for a secretary of state nominee.

Despite the opposition, Pompeo is expected to be confirmed, but he may require Democratic votes due to the narrow Republican majority in the Senate. The reduced majority is a result of the controversial support of Roy Moore in Alabama by Steve Bannon and the absence of John McCain, as well as the obstructionist stance of Rand Paul on budgetary matters and foreign affairs.

Senator Rand Paul's opposition to Pompeo, despite his own party's agenda and President Trump, is a matter of intrigue in Washington. Another Republican, Jeff Flake of Arizona, has hinted at opposing Pompeo based on travel restrictions to Cuba, but this issue is not considered significant enough to block a secretary of state nomination, especially given the ongoing mystery surrounding the damaging sound attacks on U.S. embassy employees in Havana.

A glimmer of support for Pompeo's nomination came from Heidi Heitkamp, a Democrat from North Dakota, who announced her support yesterday. More red-state Democrats are expected to follow suit, but the confirmation vote is likely to be historically narrow, reflecting the intense opposition to President Trump among Democrats and a potential sign of things to come if Democrats regain control of the Senate in the future.

Title: Senate Averts Government Shutdown with Passage of Stopgap Spending Bill

Article:

The United States Senate passed a stopgap spending bill on Friday, averting a potential government shutdown. The bill, which keeps federal agencies running until April 28, was passed with a vote of 63-36. The Senate also wrapped up a contentious water projects bill and other last-minute business, allowing senators to leave for the holidays.

The spending bill, known as a "continuing resolution," maintains most government agencies at 2016 funding levels but increases defense spending by $8 billion annually. The bill also provides $4.1 billion in disaster relief and reconstruction funds, as well as $170 million for addressing drinking water problems, including the lead-tainted water in Flint, Michigan.

The main sticking point in the passage of the bill was a standoff over coal miners' health benefits. Sen. Joe Manchin III of West Virginia and other Democrats had pushed for a year-long extension of the benefits, but ultimately conceded defeat and agreed to a four-month renewal.

Incoming Senate Minority Leader Charles E. Schumer, a New York Democrat, stated that the party's push for the year-long extension was not intended to shut down the government, but rather to highlight the seriousness of the issue. The House of Representatives had already left for the year, and Senate GOP leaders had warned Democrats to accept the measure as-is or take the blame for a partial government shutdown.

The water projects bill, which easily passed the House with a vote of 360-61, also faced opposition from some Democrats who wanted to include a "Buy America" provision requiring infrastructure projects to use U.S.-made steel and iron. However, their protests gradually subsided as the threat of a shutdown became more imminent.

The bill is the only one of the dozen annual spending bills that Congress is supposed to approve each year, leaving most agencies running on stopgap funding since October 1, the start of the fiscal year. The latest bill also includes $7 million to reimburse law enforcement agencies protecting President-elect Donald Trump in Manhattan and a provision clearing the way for retired Marine Corps Gen. James N. Mattis to be Mr. Trump's defense secretary. The law requires at least seven years to have elapsed before a retired member of the military can take over at the Pentagon, but Republicans want to quickly approve a waiver of the law next year. The new bill changes the usual debate rules, preserving the 60-vote threshold but limiting the amount of time a Democratic filibuster could last.

Title: Ferguson Voter Registration Numbers Corrected: Director of Elections Admits Error in Reporting

Article:

USA Today's Yamiche Alcindor reported on October 7 that the local director of elections in Ferguson, Missouri, had miscalculated the number of residents who registered to vote following the August 9 shooting of Michael Brown. The actual number is 128, not 3,287 as previously reported.

The director of elections stated, "A discrepancy was identified in the report that provided us with the numbers we released to you last week." After two days of meetings with the Secretary of State's Office, they were given the correct number.

Yamiche Alcindor also reported that the director of elections was "flabbergasted" by the mistake but that it was "a mistake, pure and simple... no hanky-panky." The secretary of state's office confirmed that the St. Louis County Election Board had pulled the wrong report.

Previously, it was reported that since the shooting, 4,839 people in St. Louis County registered to vote, and 3,287 of those people lived in Ferguson. This number was significantly higher than the number of people who registered to vote in Ferguson in 2002, 2006, and 2010, according to a report from the St. Louis County Board of Election Commissioners.

The surge in voter registrations may not necessarily translate to thousands of new votes. Only 1,484 of the 12,096 registered voters cast ballots during local elections in April. However, if 12 percent of new registrants vote, that's 400 more voters, certainly enough to impact a municipal election.

The rise in registrations could reflect efforts, particularly by St. Louis committeeman Anthony Bell, to sign people up to vote during and after the height of the protests. The surge in voter registrations may reflect the residents' desire for change in their local government, as many of Ferguson's residents have expressed concern that their local government does not represent the city's black community. Although 67 percent of Ferguson's population is black, the mayor and police chief are white, one of six council members is black, and no one on the local board of elections is black.

The problem, as previously reported, is low voter turnout during local elections in March and April. The overall turnout numbers for Ferguson's mayoral and city council election are discouraging, with just 12.3 percent of eligible voters casting a ballot in 2014, according to numbers provided by the county. In 2013 and 2012, those figures were even lower: 11.7 percent and 8.9 percent, respectively. As a rule, the lower the turnout, the more the electorate skews white and conservative.

Title: Treasury Secretary Warns of 'Catastrophic' Consequences if Debt Limit Not Raised

Article:

Treasury Secretary Jack Lew warned Congress on Thursday that failing to raise the debt ceiling could cause significant disruption in financial markets and harm the U.S. economy. The government will run out of its ability to borrow money starting on Oct. 17, and will soon after not be able to pay all government bills on time and in full, according to Treasury.

Lew's warning comes as some Republicans have questioned the severity of the situation and suggested there is more time to negotiate over a debt limit hike than Treasury has stated. In a hearing before the Senate Finance Committee, Lew urged lawmakers to avoid an "ideological fight" that could put the entire economy at risk.

Republicans have been critical of Lew, arguing he is trying to scare financial markets to get Congress to boost the debt ceiling without attaching a budget deal or changes to the president's health care law to the legislation. Sen. Orrin Hatch (R-Utah) told Lew at Thursday's hearing that the administration is causing needless panic with suggestions that Social Security recipients and disabled workers would see deep cuts without an increase in the debt limit while failing to explain how the government could manage a default.

Lew did not rule out the possibility of prioritizing payments to bondholders in the event of a default, but did not provide details of how Treasury would manage a default. He also questioned what meaningful difference there is between paying bondholders and not paying other government creditors, such as Social Security recipients or contractors.

Under questioning from Hatch, Lew declined to say specifically how large of a debt limit increase the administration wants, telling the committee the president will sign any bill that avoids default and does not contain other policy provisions.

The Dow Jones Industrial Average was up more than 180 points in early morning trading on Thursday, with financial markets more interested in reports of growing interest in Congress for passing a short-term debt ceiling increase. The Senate Finance Committee's top Republican, Sen. Orrin Hatch, expressed concern about the administration's warnings of financial stability risks arising from the debt limit impasse, stating that the Financial Stability Oversight Council has been silent and refused to tell the American people how it would respond to these risks.

Title: College Students as Agents of Change in Countering Political Polarization

Article:

Few would dispute the growing political polarization in the United States over the past few decades. The Brookings Institution, one of America's oldest and most reputable think tanks, labels political polarization as "damaging to the political process" and warns that the growing ideological gulf in the society is now deeply embedded.

Political polarization is not the result of specific political events such as Sen. Ted Cruz's marathon filibuster against the Affordable Care Act or the October 2013 battle over the debt ceiling that led to a 16-day government shutdown. Instead, political polarization stems from the American people themselves. A study by the Pew Research Center found that Americans self-segregate politically, clustering geographically by ideology, and consume news with a bias towards their beliefs.

Political polarization may seem an unsolvable problem due to its vast scale. The actions and motivations of politicians like Cruz, former Gov. Mike Huckabee, Sen. Elizabeth Warren, Sen. Bernie Sanders, or Republican candidates Dr. Ben Carson and Donald Trump may appear beyond our control. However, as Northwestern students, we cannot ignore our responsibility as young Americans and future political leaders to address our nation's problems.

Tackling political polarization is a bottom-up project, best approached by those of us in the best position to engage with individuals of differing views: college students. Ending political polarization requires understanding and empathy. The first step in countering political polarization is understanding what people of differing ideologies actually believe. More often than not, I have found that liberals and conservatives fundamentally do not understand each other's views and often make little effort to do so.

Upon arrival at NU, I joined non-partisan political organizations, such as the NU Political Union and Politics & Policy, with the hope of engaging with students of differing political perspectives. The Political Union's weekly debates expanded my understanding of conservatives' political perspectives. Over the past few years, Political Union members have discussed similar experiences with me, how listening to debates changed their understanding of others' beliefs.

More importantly, the friendships I developed with Republican, libertarian, centrist, and even more radically liberal students than myself through the Political Union and my freshman and sophomore residential hall, deepened my understanding of differing viewpoints on a personal level. The second step to ending political polarization is reaching a point of empathy, where students' differing views are understandable on an emotional and experiential level. Developing strong friendships with people of differing ideologies gives a glimpse into how fellow students' experiences have shaped their political beliefs. Empathy counteracts the most insidious element of political polarization, the notion that your opposition is inherently bad, or even evil.

Political polarization goes beyond the Democrat-Republican divide. It touches overarching campus debates, such as the struggle over political correctness, to issues deeply sensitive and personal to so many students on campus, such as Israel-Palestine. For many of those students most involved in discussions of these issues, politics are integral to identity. Discussing ongoing regional conflicts or what constitutes offensiveness is undoubtedly difficult for those most directly affected. It is nonetheless important. The first step is spending time with one's ideological opposites; social psychological research shows that intergroup contact reduces animosity, even between groups on the opposite sides of enduring, deeply entrenched conflict.

College is the single best opportunity to bridge the ideological divide. Before social mores prohibit discussion of politics in work and various social settings, sit down with fellow NU students and talk politics. Establish boundaries—no personal attacks, a la Donald Trump, for example—pick a topic, and go. When politics are too sensitive to start with, build trust and establish a bond with fellow students before touching on the more difficult issues. It is time we, as future voters and political leaders, took steps to end political polarization and self-segregation on our own campus, reached out, and built friendships with those who disagree with us. With each discussion, empathy builds, and political polarization, at least on a micro-scale, subsides.

Title: GOP's Response to COVID-19 Pandemic: A Look at Voter Preferences and Policy Decisions

Article:

A new poll by The New York Times and Siena College reveals that voters overall prioritize controlling the pandemic over reopening the economy, but this preference appears to be more pronounced among Democratic voters. Republican voters, seemingly influenced by the White House and Fox News, hold the opposite view.

The divide in attitudes extends beyond policy decisions, as partisanship seems to influence individual behavior as well. Self-identified Democrats are significantly more likely to wear face masks and practice social distancing than self-identified Republicans.

The question arises as to why the United States has struggled to manage the pandemic effectively, but the focus of this article is on the Republican Party's response to the coronavirus.

Part of the explanation lies in short-term politics. At the beginning of the year, President Donald Trump's re-election message centered on economic triumphalism, with low unemployment rates and rising stock markets. The administration wasted crucial weeks denying the viral threat due to a reluctance to acknowledge bad news.

Moreover, they advocated for premature reopening, aiming to restore conditions as they seemed in February. Even recently, the same Trump officials who initially downplayed the risks of Covid-19 dismissed the potential risks of a second wave.

While the GOP's coronavirus denial can be partly attributed to short-term politics and the 2020 election, it is argued that the roots of this response go deeper. Covid-19, like climate change, is a menace the party is reluctant to acknowledge.

It is not that the right is averse to fearmongering. However, it does not want individuals to fear impersonal threats requiring policy responses, such as wearing face masks, but rather to be afraid of people they can hate—people of a different race or liberal individuals.

Title: Tillerson Departs, Warns of Russia's "Troubling Behavior"; Pompeo Tapped as New Secretary of State

Article:

Former ExxonMobil CEO Rex Tillerson, who was sacked as the U.S. Secretary of State, has issued a statement warning of Russia's "troubling behavior and actions" in a parting statement. Tillerson, who was fired by President Donald Trump via Twitter, did not thank the president or praise his policies in the statement.

Tillerson had a series of public rifts with the White House after being appointed last year. He spoke to reporters at the Department of State, stating that good work had been done to have better relations with China and rein in North Korea's nuclear weapons program. However, he added that "much work remains to respond to the troubling behavior and actions on the part of the Russian government."

Tillerson's departure comes as Mike Pompeo, the current CIA Director, is set to replace him. Gina Haspel, who will become the CIA's first female director, was also named by Trump in the same tweet. Speaking to reporters outside the White House on Tuesday, Trump stated that his differences with Tillerson came down to personal "chemistry."

Tillerson will not officially leave until March 31, but his deputy, John Sullivan, will take over running the State Department pending the confirmation of Pompeo. Tillerson stated that it is important to ensure an orderly and smooth transition during a time that the country continues to face significant policy and national security challenges.

The White House and Tillerson have had a series of public disagreements, and the circumstances surrounding his firing have been a subject of contention. The White House insists Tillerson received a phone call on Friday from Chief of Staff John Kelly, who told him that he was being let go. They say Tillerson then asked if the announcement could be held until his return from a tour of Africa.

However, Tillerson's team stated that he felt unwell on Saturday and decided to cut short his tour by a day. His firing was reported by the Washington Post on Tuesday before any tweet was sent, according to a White House official. A statement released by Under Secretary Steve Goldstein implied that Tillerson was first made aware of his firing by President Trump's tweet. After this statement was released, Mr. Goldstein himself was fired by the White House.

Tillerson also stated that he received a call from the president about three hours after Mr. Trump sent a tweet announcing his departure. The end of Tillerson's tenure as Secretary of State was a "perfect metaphor for the relationship," according to the New York Times.

A US Senate report found that Ms. Haspel, the new CIA deputy director, ran a CIA prison in Thailand where prisoners were waterboarded in 2002. Haspel was also accused of destroying dozens of videotapes of interrogations at the camp.

Pompeo, the new Secretary of State, is a hardline conservative former lawmaker from Kansas and a Trump loyalist. In 2014, he defended the CIA officers who waterboarded detainees as "patriots." Both the new Secretary of State and CIA Director will have to be confirmed by the Senate.

Reports had swirled since last year of a rift between Trump and his top diplomat. Last October, Tillerson was forced to convene a news conference to deny claims he planned to quit, though he did not address a report that he had referred to his boss as a "moron" after a Pentagon meeting.

Trump also publicly undercut Tillerson by tweeting that he was "wasting his time" trying to negotiate with North Korea. In December, the Secretary of State offered to begin direct talks with Pyongyang without preconditions. The White House distanced itself from his remarks, and Tillerson was reported to be astonished at how little Trump grasped the basics of foreign policy.

Title: Mental Health Professionals and Political Opponents: A Historical Perspective and Ethical Considerations

Article:

A debate has arisen regarding the mental health of President Donald Trump, with some mental health professionals suggesting that he may be suffering from conditions such as dementia or other mental illnesses. This has led to discussions about the possibility of removing the president from office or requiring him to undergo psychiatric or psychological testing.

The author, a former professor of psychiatry at Yale University and co-editor of a basic text in the field, argues that it is unprofessional, unethical, and absurd for mental health professionals to offer diagnoses or predictions about President Trump without examining him. The author, who has written extensively on the ability and inability of psychiatrists to predict future conduct, states that it is dangerous to democracy to pathologize or psychiatrize political opponents based on their political views.

The author draws parallels to the 1964 presidential election, when similar allegations were made against Senator Barry Goldwater, who was running against President Lyndon B. Johnson. In the lead-up to the election, an article in Fact magazine, based on interviews with over 1,100 psychiatrists, concluded that Goldwater was mentally unstable and psychologically unfit to be president. The author notes that the misdiagnosis of Goldwater should not be surprising, as none of the psychiatrists had ever examined or met the Arizona senator, and their diagnoses were based on their political disagreements with him.

The author argues that it is unethical for mental health professionals to offer diagnoses or predictions about public figures without examining them, a principle established by the American Psychiatric Association following the Goldwater-psychiatrist debacle. The author concludes that while it is appropriate to debate the merits and demerits of President Trump's policies, effectiveness, personality, and other factors relevant to his presidency, it is irresponsible to remove a duly elected president from office based on amateurish speculation about his mental health. The author emphasizes that diagnoses should be left to doctors who have examined their patients.

Title: Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid Advocates for Constitutional Amendment to Limit Campaign Spending

Article:

Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid (D-NV) has announced his support for a proposed constitutional amendment aimed at limiting campaign spending by outside groups. The amendment, introduced earlier this year by Democratic Sens. Tom Udall of New Mexico and Michael Bennet of Colorado, would give Congress the authority to regulate raising and spending limits for federal elections.

Reid announced on the Senate floor that the Judiciary Committee would soon hold a hearing on the amendment, and that the full Senate will vote on the legislation. The measure, if passed, would curb unlimited campaign spending, particularly by super PACs, which have grown significantly since the 2010 Supreme Court ruling in the Citizens United case.

The amendment is expected to pass the Judiciary Committee, where it only needs a simple majority to advance. However, its chances of passing the full Senate, where it needs a two-thirds majority, are extremely slim due to broad GOP opposition.

Reid has been vocal in his criticism of the billionaire industrialists David and Charles Koch, who have spent hundreds of millions since 2010, through the conservative non-profit political advocacy group Americans for Prosperity and other organizations, to attack Democrats and support Republicans. Overall, pro-GOP outside groups have heavily outspent their pro-Democratic rivals since the 2010 Supreme Court ruling opened the floodgates.

"There is absolutely no question the Koch brothers are in a category of their own, in both degree and kind. No one else pumping money into the shadowy campaign organizations and campaigns like they are. There isn't even a close second," Reid said. "They are doing this to promote issues that make themselves even richer."

Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-KY) criticized the amendment, stating that it represents an all-out assault on the right to free speech and is a clear sign of Democrats' desperation to hold onto power.

The issue of campaign spending was also in the Supreme Court's spotlight earlier this spring, with a 5-4 ruling eliminating limits on how much money individuals can donate in one election season. The decision left intact the current $5,200 limit on how much an individual can give to any single candidate during a two-year election cycle. The ruling means a wealthy donor can give as much money as desired to federal election candidates across the country, as long as no candidate receives more than the $5,200 cap.

The constitutional amendment faces all-but-certain defeat on the Senate floor, but Democrats believe public opinion is on their side, and that the efforts to push the amendment could motivate their base, which is crucial in traditionally low-turnout midterm contests.

Title: House Republicans Introduce Bill to Allow Americans to Keep Their Health Plans Amidst ObamaCare Controversy

Article:

Following the failure to derail ObamaCare during the partial government shutdown, congressional Republicans have shifted their focus to a House Republican-backed bill that would allow Americans to keep their health plans. The bill, scheduled for a vote on Friday, capitalizes on President Obama's apology last week for earlier assurances that the public could stay on their health insurance if they liked it.

The House Energy and Commerce Committee bill aims to address the controversy surrounding the ObamaCare website's failed rollout last month. The bill is part of escalating attacks on the Affordable Care Act, with members in both chambers now using the website's technical problems as a new line of attack.

Republicans have targeted various aspects of the website failures, from contractors who helped build the site to suggesting the site's technical problems are just "the tip of the iceberg." The centerpiece of the attack has been pressing Department of Health and Human Services Secretary Kathleen Sebelius into testifying before a House committee earlier this month.

Energy committee Chairman Fred Upton appears to have seized on the Obama apology as a means to garner Democratic support for the chamber's bill. "Actions speak louder than words," Upton said. "If the president is serious about offering relief to Americans whose health plans are being canceled, then he should strongly support the Keep Your Health Plan Act.... The president ought to embrace the bipartisan call for legislative action."

In addition to the House bill, Republicans have also proposed legislation to delay the mandate that Americans get insurance and to verify that low-income people receiving federal subsidies to pay for the insurance indeed qualify for them.

Some Democrats, particularly those seeking re-election next year in conservative-leaning states, are also trying to change the law. Among them are Mark Begich of Alaska, Mary Landrieu of Louisiana, and Kay Hagan of North Carolina, who are also facing conservative groups vowing to spend millions to show voters their early support for ObamaCare.

Landrieu, in fact, introduced a bill last week similar to the House one that would allow Americans to keep their existing health plans. "When we passed the Affordable Care Act, we did so with the intention that if you liked your health plan, you could keep it," she said. "A promise was made and this legislation will ensure that this promise is kept. I have said repeatedly that the... act is not perfect, and I am willing to work with anyone who wants to improve it and implement it correctly."

Republican strategists insist that focusing on ObamaCare throughout the 2016 presidential election cycle is a winning strategy, pointing to the recent Virginia governor's race in which Republican nominee Ken Cuccinelli lost but managed to close a double-digit lead by hammering away at the law in the closing weeks of the campaign.

Title: House Speaker John Boehner Rules Out Negotiations on Senate's Immigration Bill, Signaling Stalemate

Article:

House Speaker John A. Boehner, in a meeting with fellow Republicans on Wednesday, flatly rejected the possibility of entering into negotiations with the Senate on the Senate's immigration bill, signaling that the issue may remain unaddressed until after the midterm elections. Boehner stated that he would not be bound by President Obama's timeline for action and rejected the Senate's approach, which would legalize most illegal immigrants and rewrite the legal immigration system.

Boehner emphasized the House's intention to adopt a step-by-step, common-sense approach to immigration, stating that the House would not take up the 1,300-page Senate bill, which was passed without thorough review. He also made it clear that the House has no intention of ever going to conference on the Senate bill.

This stance represents a shift in Boehner's position, as he had previously expressed a willingness to work with President Obama on the issue following Obama's re-election a year ago. Boehner's use of the term "comprehensive," which is often associated with the broad legalization approach advocated by Obama and Democrats, has been a point of contention in the immigration debate.

Immigrant rights supporters remain hopeful that action will be taken in the House next year, citing political pressure as a potential catalyst. Senator Charles E. Schumer, the New York Democrat who wrote the Senate bill, expressed belief that the House will eventually come to its senses and address the issue in a bipartisan manner.

The Senate bill, which called for quick legal status for most illegal immigrants, included provisions for border security, increased funding for the Border Patrol, and changes to the legal immigration system to prioritize job skills and deep family ties. House Republicans have opted for a piecemeal approach, with committees clearing bills on border security, interior enforcement, and guest-worker programs, and leaders working on a bill to legalize young illegal immigrants.

Congressional Democrats and President Obama had hoped that the House would pass some of these bills, leading to a conference committee to finalize a deal with the Senate. However, Boehner's recent statements suggest a shift in the House's position, with Boehner asking House Judiciary Committee Chairman Bob Goodlatte to develop a broad set of principles for addressing immigration.

White House press secretary Jay Carney expressed skepticism, stating that it seemed "a little bit late in the game" and noting that Obama has already laid out principles for the House to follow. Immigrant rights advocates have criticized the House Republicans' approach, with Frank Sharry, executive director of America's Voice, a lobby group, stating that Boehner risks his party's political future by stalling action on immigration.

House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi, California Democrat, has been vocal in her support for immigration reform, tweeting that taking up immigration should be easy for the House. Pelosi has introduced a bill that would strip out the specific, tough border security measures from the Senate's legalization program and replace them with a call for the Department of Homeland Security to devise a security plan. Pelosi believes the House has enough votes to pass her bill.

Following Obama's re-election last year, Boehner had announced that immigration would be a key area of agreement between the president and House Republicans. However, the backlash from rank-and-file House Republicans has forced Boehner and his lieutenants to navigate a difficult path to maintain support within their conference. Even Senator Marco Rubio, a Florida Republican who helped craft the Senate bill, later abandoned it, urging his House colleagues to follow their own path and avoid negotiations with the Senate.

Title: Trump Imposes Tariffs on Brazil and Argentina, Sparking Uncertainty and Currency War Speculation

Article:

President Donald Trump has imposed tariffs on steel and aluminum imports from Brazil and Argentina, a move that has been met with criticism from the left and business leaders seeking more certainty in the global trade landscape. This latest move marks a shift in Trump's rationale for the tariffs, as he now claims that the two South American nations are manipulating their currencies.

In 2018, Trump first imposed tariffs on steel and aluminum imports, citing national security concerns. This new rationale, however, is a departure from his previous statements. The announcement of the new tariffs also saw Trump call on the U.S. Federal Reserve to lower interest rates, a move that could weaken the U.S. dollar.

The economic situations in both Brazil and Argentina are complex. Argentina's right-leaning government, led by the soon-to-be outgoing President Mauricio Macri, has been battling a financial crisis, including struggling to control the falling peso. Brazil's own currency has also suffered recently, with the situation in Argentina partially to blame, according to Trump's own Treasury Department. As of May, neither Brazil nor Argentina were on the watch list of countries requiring closer attention to their currency practices.

The political implications of Trump's announcement are somewhat peculiar. Brazil's new right-wing populist President Jair Bolsonaro has strengthened the country's relationship with the Trump administration, and Trump had previously talked up a possible US-Brazil free trade deal. The US-China trade spat has rattled the global economy, and Trump is still waging a trade battle with the EU, though some of the recent tariffs were allowed by the World Trade Organization. He has yet to get his revised NAFTA deal through Congress, though there's still hope there.

This latest incident has opened the door for China to potentially accelerate its push into Latin America. In the realm of trade talks with China, investors are betting that President Donald Trump will deliver a partial trade deal soon, boosting anemic economic growth, sustaining the bull market in stocks, and offering the hope of calmer waters for global commerce. However, the prospect of a phase one deal, even if it sticks through the 2020 presidential election campaign, may make a broader phase two agreement even harder.

In the U.S. political landscape, the Democratic presidential candidates are also making headlines. Senator Elizabeth Warren has provided more detail on her Medicare financing than other candidates, including on the taxes she would raise. Her Medicare plan comes much closer to paying for itself than various Republican tax cuts. However, her approach of forcing people to join Medicare, rather than allowing them to opt in, has been criticized for not addressing public anxiety about radical changes to the health care system.

Former Vice President Joe Biden's opposition to marijuana legalization puts him at odds with the majority of Democrats and even a majority of Republicans, who support legalization. This stance has been a source of concern for criminal justice reformers, as Biden has a long record of pushing for punitive criminal justice and drug policies.

In summary, the global trade landscape is experiencing further turbulence due to Trump's latest tariff announcement, while the U.S. political landscape is seeing a heated debate on healthcare and drug policy reforms among the Democratic presidential candidates.

Title: U.S. Consumer Prices Increase in June, Inflation Remains Moderate Despite Economic Reopening

Article:

The U.S. consumer price index increased by 0.6% in June, marking the largest monthly rise since August 2012, according to data released by the Labor Department on Tuesday. This increase ended three consecutive months of declines. The increase was primarily driven by rises in the prices of gasoline and food.

In the 12 months through June, the Consumer Price Index (CPI) climbed 0.6%, following a 0.1% increase in May. Economists polled by Reuters had forecast a 0.5% increase in June and a 0.6% year-on-year rise.

Businesses have reopened after shuttering in mid-March to slow the spread of Covid-19. However, new cases of the respiratory illness have surged in large parts of the country, prompting some states to dial back or pause reopenings.

The Federal Reserve is injecting money into the economy through extraordinary measures, including large-scale asset purchases and funneling loans to firms. Separately, the government has provided nearly $3 trillion in fiscal stimulus, contributing to a record monthly budget deficit in June.

Despite the unprecedented stimulus, economists expect inflation to remain benign due to a record 33 million people on unemployment benefits. The core Consumer Price Index, which excludes the volatile food and energy components, rose 0.2% in June, following a 0.1% decrease in May.

In the 12 months through June, the core Consumer Price Index increased 1.2%, matching May's gain. The Federal Reserve tracks the core personal consumption expenditures (PCE) price index for its 2% inflation target. The core PCE price index increased 1.0% on a year-on-year basis in May, the smallest advance since December 2010. June's core PCE price index data will be released at the end of this month.

Title: Multiple Incidents of Explosions, Stabbings Occur Across U.S.

Article:

Multiple incidents of explosions and stabbings occurred across the United States on Saturday, September 17, 2016.

In Seaside Park, New Jersey, an improvisational explosive device (IED) detonated at a Marine Charity 5K event. Fortunately, no one was injured. The Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) is currently investigating to determine if it was an act of terrorism. Remnants and residue from the bomb are being sent to an FBI lab for analysis. The device was enclosed in a trash can and contained multiple explosive devices, designed to send shrapnel flying. There were as many as three devices inside the trash can.

In Chelsea, a New York City neighborhood, an explosion occurred around 8:30 pm EST, injuring an estimated 25 people but killing none. A possible secondary device may have been discovered, but this is not yet confirmed. There are conflicting reports as to whether the explosion was caused by an IED.

In St. Cloud, Minnesota, a crazed stabber rampaged and stabbed multiple people before being shot by police. The mall where the incident occurred is still in lockdown, and multiple victims have been taken to the St. Cloud Hospital.

Social media posts and news reports provide additional details about these incidents. For example, one Twitter user posted a picture of the explosion in Chelsea, and another user shared a picture of their apartment building near the explosion site. There are also conflicting reports about the causes and details of the incidents, with some sources attributing the New York explosion to a bombing, while others are speculating about the type of explosive used in the Seaside Park incident.

Authorities are still investigating the causes and details of these incidents, and more information is expected to be released over time. The FBI is investigating the Seaside Park incident as a potential act of terrorism, and the St. Cloud stabbing is being investigated as a possible hate crime. The public is advised to avoid the areas where the incidents occurred and to follow the instructions of local authorities.

Title: Clinton Refuses to Hand Over Email Server, Claims Server Wiped Clean in Response to Subpoena

Article:

Former Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton has declined to turn over her email server to an independent third party, instead claiming she has wiped the server clean. This development has reportedly set back the special investigative committee looking into the 2012 Benghazi terrorist attack, according to a statement from Committee Chairman Trey Gowdy late Friday.

Gowdy stated that the House will need to decide on the next steps in the pursuit of information from Mrs. Clinton, but she will likely be required to appear and testify about her email-related decision-making. Gowdy's statement criticizes Mrs. Clinton's actions, stating that she was the sole arbiter of what constituted a public record and that she deleted all emails from her server, preventing others from verifying her analysis in the public interest.

In response to Gowdy's subpoena, Mrs. Clinton reportedly re-transmitted several hundred pages of emails that the State Department has already made public. Representative Elijah E. Cummings, the top Democrat on the Benghazi probe, stated that this proves Mrs. Clinton has already produced all of her official records concerning the terrorist attack.

Cummings called for the committee to stop the investigation and make the documents public, as well as schedule Mrs. Clinton's public testimony.

At a press conference earlier this month, Mrs. Clinton explained that she culled through more than 60,000 emails from her time as secretary and decided about 30,000 of them were public records that should have been maintained. She stated that the rest were private messages relating to her daughter's wedding or her yoga class schedule, and she did not keep those.

However, Gowdy stated that Mrs. Clinton's lawyers informed him on Friday that she "unilaterally decided to wipe her server clean and permanently delete all emails" from it. The exact timing of this decision is unclear, but it appears to have occurred after the State Department requested her to turn over her government business messages in late October.

Mrs. Clinton opted to use a private email account during her four-year tenure as secretary, first relying on an account she used while a senator and later setting up an email server at her home in New York and using an account on that to conduct all of her business, both public and private.

She maintains that she followed the law, which at the time did not require officials to use government-issued accounts but did require them to turn over all official records to be stored. Mrs. Clinton did not turn over those records until last December, after the Benghazi probe noticed she had used a private email and requested those records from the State Department, which then asked Mrs. Clinton for them. The law does not specify a date for turning over records.

Open-records experts, however, question Mrs. Clinton's designation of her server as private, stating that it was set up to conduct government business, and so it and the emails on it arguably belong to the government.

Mrs. Clinton's email practices have put the Obama administration in a difficult position. Obama lawyers have admitted in federal court that for years, they were not correctly performing open-records searches because they did not have her emails, but they claim they are now unilaterally going back and doing those searches.

Title: Polish President Expresses Reservations Over Trump's Proposal to Reinstate Russia in G-7

Article:

Polish President Andrzej Duda voiced serious reservations on Monday about President Donald Trump's campaign to reinstate Russia into the Group of Seven (G-7), an elite group of leaders from wealthy nations. During a news conference with Vice President Mike Pence at Poland's Presidential Palace, Duda did not outright reject Trump's proposal but made it clear he was not enthusiastic about the idea.

"I believe we must not proceed according to the business-as-usual principle" when it comes to Russia, Duda said through an interpreter. "This is my position, and I do not hesitate to express it."

Duda's comments came on the second and final day of Pence's visit to the Polish capital. Pence made the trip after Trump canceled his plans to travel to Poland, citing the need to monitor Hurricane Dorian in the United States.

While Duda was not supportive of Trump's push to readmit Russia to the G-7, he was sympathetic to Trump's reasons for canceling his visit. Trump had to postpone his visit due to "the nature of things which cannot be predicted," Duda said. Trump has stated his intention to reschedule, and Duda expressed hope that Trump can make the trip this fall.

Trump has repeatedly called for leaders of other member nations to allow Russia back into the group in recent weeks. Trump pressed the case last week during the group's annual gathering in Biarritz, France. Trump argued that readmitting Russia to the group would ease negotiations on global issues.

Russia was a member of the group, then known as the G-8, but was ousted in 2014 over its annexation of Crimea. The decision was supported not only by the U.S. but also by the group's other six member countries. The G-7 is made up of the United States, Canada, France, Germany, the United Kingdom, Japan, and Italy.

During the news conference, Duda, whose country relies heavily on U.S. military support, also expressed concerns about bringing Russia back into the fold, citing Russia's continued occupation of Crimea and other issues.

"Russia, over the last years, has been undertaking actions which... nobody who wants to have peace in the world, and nobody who respects the dignity of other nations and states, can turn a blind eye to," he said.

For his part, Pence lauded the "remarkable bond" between the U.S. and Poland and stressed that NATO allies must remain "vigilant" about countering "the intentions and the actions taken by Russia."

During his two-day visit to the Polish capital, Pence delivered remarks at a ceremony commemorating the 80th anniversary of the start of World War II and held bilateral meetings with Duda and Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky.

In his meeting with Duda, Pence said they discussed several issues, including Poland's plan to buy weaponry from the United States, the U.S.'s plans to send an additional 1,000 troops to Poland, and the possible establishment of a permanent military base for U.S. troops in Poland.

"Make no mistake about it," Pence said. "This alliance, this relationship between America and Poland, has never been stronger."

The two countries also signed a joint agreement calling for them to work together to improve the security of Poland's 5G telecommunications system. The deal comes as the Trump administration is trying to counter the influence of the Chinese telecom giant Huawei. The U.S. accuses Huawei of facilitating Chinese spying, a charge the company denies.

Asked if Poland has any evidence that China has used Huawei technology for spying, Duda said Polish counterintelligence services have detected actions "which might have been of an espionage nature."

Title: 6th Circuit Court of Appeals Upholds Contraception Mandate, Split with 10th Circuit Decision

Article:

The 6th Circuit Court of Appeals on Tuesday sided with the Obama administration in the ongoing legal battle over the mandate to cover contraception services in the Affordable Care Act (ACA). This decision marks the second time a federal appeals court has rejected a company's claim that the mandatory coverage of birth control violates its religious beliefs.

In a separate ruling in July, the 10th Circuit Court of Appeals granted an injunction to Hobby Lobby, a crafts franchise based in Oklahoma City, shielding the company from the ACA mandate until the merits of their case can be heard. The split rulings suggest the matter may be headed for the Supreme Court in Washington.

In the latest decision, the 6th Circuit Court of Appeals ruled that a Michigan-based manufacturing company, Autocam, must comply with the mandate despite it violating the owners' Roman Catholic beliefs. The Kennedy family, like other plaintiffs who have sued over the mandate, argued that the Obama administration's rule required them to choose among violating their beliefs, dropping Autocam employees' health coverage, or facing substantial fines for non-compliance.

Conservative lawmakers and religious groups have advocated for a religious exemption from the mandate, citing particular objections to morning-after pills they equate with abortion. Supporters of the mandate argue that contraception use is widespread but often unaffordable for many women. They contend that corporate owners should not be able to impose their personal beliefs on the diverse array of people they employ at secular companies by stripping contraception coverage from their health plans.

The 6th Circuit panel wrote that the Kennedys' actions with respect to Autocam are not actions taken in an individual capacity but as officers and directors of the corporation. The judges agreed with government lawyers who said "that Autocam has not carried its burden of demonstrating a strong likelihood of success on the merits in this action."

In late July, about a week after Hobby Lobby's successful plea to the 10th Circuit Court of Appeals, judges on the 3rd Circuit provided no relief to Pennsylvania-based Conestoga Wood Specialties. A decision tracker at the Becket Fund says 29 companies have secured an injunction against the mandate at either the district or circuit court level, while five firms, including Conestoga and Autocam, have been denied relief.

Kyle Duncan, general counsel for the Becket Fund for Religious Liberty, which is representing some of the plaintiffs who object to the mandate, said the Obama administration has until Sept. 25 to decide whether it will ask the Supreme Court to take up the Hobby Lobby case that went against them. "I can't imagine that the United States [government] will just acquiesce in that," Mr. Duncan said.

Earlier this year, the Obama administration outlined an accommodation for religious nonprofits such as hospitals and universities that object to the mandate. Under the compromise, employees of the nonprofits can still acquire contraception coverage through separate policies set up by their companies' insurers or third-party administrators. This, the administration said, would allow the faith-based employers to distance themselves from the coverage, although some objectors have said the accommodation does little to alleviate their concerns.

Title: House Republicans Criticize Senate for Failing to Pass Health Care Repeal Bill

Article:

A group of House Republicans gathered on Capitol Hill on Friday criticized the Senate for failing to pass its health care repeal bill earlier in the day. The House had passed a health care bill in May, and some representatives argued that the Senate had not fulfilled its part of the bargain.

Rep. Morgan Griffith of Virginia stated, "The Senate's got to do the Senate thing. We got a bill passed in the House." He further added, "The Senate needs to decide whether they can do anything. If the Senate is incapable of functioning, then the House will have to once again step up to the plate and figure out what we're going to do."

Rep. Diane Black, who chairs the House Budget Committee, said senators had broken their promise to "save" Americans from Obamacare. "The Senate's failure to even continue the legislative process is a slap in the face to the voters that trusted and elected them. They deserve better," she said.

In an early-morning vote, the Senate voted down Majority Leader Mitch McConnell's latest offer of a bill that would repeal or delay some of Obamacare's mandates and taxes. The bill failed on a 49-51 vote, with three Republican senators - Susan Collins of Maine, John McCain of Arizona, and Lisa Murkowski of Alaska - joining Democrats to doom the legislation.

House Speaker Paul D. Ryan was more diplomatic in his response, stating he was "disappointed and frustrated" but that lawmakers should not give up. "While the House delivered a bill to repeal and replace Obamacare, unfortunately, the Senate was unable to reach a consensus," Mr. Ryan said in a statement.

Rep. Trent Franks, an Arizona Republican, suggested that the parliamentary situation in the Senate could make further action difficult. "We're in a situation here where the parliamentary physics of the existing Senate rule construct makes doing things almost impossible if they're of consequence," Mr. Franks said.

Title: Oregon Anti-Government Protesters Labeled as Domestic Terrorists

Article:

CNN National Security Analyst Juliette Kayyem, a professor at Harvard's Kennedy School of Government, former assistant secretary in the U.S. Department of Homeland Security, and founder of Kayyem Solutions, has labeled the armed protesters occupying a federal building in Oregon as domestic terrorists. In her commentary, Kayyem argues that the protesters' actions, regardless of their claims of peacefulness or lawful militia status, constitute terrorism due to their use of violence and disregard for federal law.

The protesters, led by Ammon Bundy, the son of Nevada rancher Cliven Bundy, have taken over a federal building in Oregon, claiming they are defending themselves and their cause. Kayyem asserts that their actions are not benign, but rather dangerous, unforgiving, and in violation of federal law.

Kayyem suggests that the protesters' cause is difficult to decipher, but it appears to stem from opposition to a rancher being jailed for arson due to his refusal to sell his land. The analyst warns against attempts to downplay the group's actions, stating that they are, in fact, domestic terrorists.

Kayyem proposes a strategy for resolving the standoff, emphasizing the importance of avoiding violence and treating the protesters as domestic terrorists. She suggests that federal authorities should adopt a patient approach, giving themselves ample time to respond, and offering reduced sentences or misdemeanor charges to those who disarm and surrender.

Kayyem also recommends dividing and conquering the group, offering incentives to some members to disarm and surrender, and reminding those inside that they will be considered accomplices to first-degree murder if a federal agent or public safety official is harmed or killed.

Furthermore, Kayyem suggests that the Obama administration should be prepared to mobilize federal military support if necessary, to make a statement about the rule of law and the importance of upholding it in a civil, democratic society. Local law enforcement officials, she notes, may be biased due to their relationships with the protesters, and a show of federal force could help treat the protesters as they should be treated: as domestic terrorists who are putting the community at risk.

Kayyem concludes by referencing the Waco siege in 1993, cautioning against an overly aggressive response that could turn the protesters into martyrs, as was the case in Waco, which radicalized a different round of domestic terrorists.

Title: Democratic Official Clarifies "Z" Reference in Ukraine Pressure Campaign

Article:

A Democratic official involved in the impeachment trial has acknowledged that the initial interpretation of a term "z" may have been incorrect, but maintains that the term was commonly used as a shorthand for "Zelensky" among those involved in the Ukraine pressure campaign. The official also noted that the word document does not reveal its author or source.

The official emphasized that there is little question that Giuliani and Parnas sought "high-level engagement with President Zelensky and his administration." The official stated, "Beginning with Mr. Giuliani’s May 10 letter to President Zelensky two months earlier and leading up to Mr. Giuliani’s August 2 meeting with Mr. Zelensky’s representatives in Spain, Mr. Giuliani and Mr. Parnas actively sought high-level engagement with President Zelensky and his administration to carry out the President’s corrupt scheme."

The official further added, "If Mr. Giuliani sought out dirt from other sources, that would be consistent with their overall effort."

There are examples of Giuliani attempting to arrange a meeting with Zelensky, and he did in fact meet with top aides to the Ukrainian president, despite Parnas' role in the matter still being unclear. Democrats have not based their impeachment trial arguments primarily on Parnas' new allegations, making limited references to the former Giuliani associate in their brief.

However, it appears that Democrats may have misjudged at least one instance where they thought they found an example of Parnas trying to arrange a meeting between Giuliani and Zelensky, according to the unredacted material. Democrats received the Parnas evidence from the courts only last week and were scrambling to sort through all the materials ahead of the Senate impeachment trial.

A Republican aide criticized the assumption that "mr Z" is a reference to Zelensky, stating, "The most charitable view of the situation is that [Schiff’s] staff committed the equivalent of Congressional malpractice by not looking more than an inch deep to determine the facts before foisting this erroneous information on his colleagues and the American public."
