The aide further added, "Given the selective redactions and contextual clues, it seems as though Chairman Schiff sought to portray an innocuous meeting with Ukrainian oligarch Mykola Zlochevsky as an insidious one with the President of Ukraine simply because both of their surnames start with the letter Z."

Title: U.S. Army Sergeant Bowe Bergdahl Faces Desertion and Misbehavior Charges

Article:

U.S. Army Sergeant Bowe Bergdahl, who was held captive by the Taliban in Afghanistan, was formally charged on Wednesday with desertion and misbehavior before the enemy. The Army stated that if convicted of the most serious count, desertion, Bergdahl could face a life sentence in prison.

An Article 32 investigation hearing is scheduled for April 22 at Fort Sam Houston in San Antonio, Texas, to determine whether there is sufficient evidence to proceed with a court-martial. Bergdahl, 28, disappeared on June 30, 2009, from Combat Outpost Mest-Lalak in Paktika Province in eastern Afghanistan and was subsequently captured.

The Army stated that the investigation, similar to a civilian grand jury proceeding, would determine whether there is enough evidence to proceed with a court-martial. Bergdahl was released from Taliban custody last summer in a controversial prisoner swap that saw five Taliban prisoners held at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, transferred to Qatar, where they were required to remain for a year.

Some of Bergdahl's former Army comrades have come forward and stated that he deserted his post. Former Army Sergeant Evan Buetow, who served with Bergdahl, said on Wednesday that the former war prisoner had been treated fairly by the Army and needed "to answer for what he did."

"He put all of our lives in danger," Buetow said. "Men from our company died, when I do not believe they would have if he would not have left."

Republican lawmakers also backed the Army's decision to move ahead with the charges. Senator John McCain, head of the Senate Armed Services Committee and himself a Vietnam War prisoner, said it was an "important step" toward determining Bergdahl's accountability.

Representative Mac Thornberry, head of the House Armed Services Committee, accused the administration of making the case more difficult by failing "to follow the law surrounding the release of the Taliban 5."

Bergdahl's case has been under review by General Mark Milley, head of U.S. Army Forces Command. As a result of the review, Bergdahl was charged with desertion with intent to shirk important or hazardous duty and misbehavior before the enemy by endangering the safety of a command, unit, or place.

The desertion charge carries a maximum prison term of five years, while the misbehavior count carries a maximum term of life in prison. The charges also carry a number of other potential punishments, including a dishonorable discharge, reduction in rank to private, and forfeiture of all pay.

Bergdahl's parents declined to comment on the Army's decision to charge their son. Some residents in his hometown of Hailey, Idaho, also expressed reluctance to comment on the developments, citing anger at the community that came after it showed support for him following his release.

A rally for Bergdahl was abruptly canceled last summer amid the political uproar. The family and several supporters received threats by email and telephone, Hailey officials said. Debbie O'Neill, one of the co-organizers of the canceled rally, said she thought people were shocked by the Army's decision on Wednesday.

"Other than that, I think we have to wait for the military justice system to play out," she said. "I'm sure the military has enough evidence to back up the charges, but my heart breaks for him (Bergdahl)."

After a period of rehabilitation following his release, Bergdahl was reassigned to military duties. He currently has an administrative role in an office at Fort Sam Houston in San Antonio. A spokeswoman at the base said it would be up to the lawyers to determine what would happen to Bergdahl now that he has been charged.

Title: Presidential Candidate Ben Carson Threatens to Leave Republican Party

Article:

Retired neurosurgeon and former Republican presidential hopeful Ben Carson has threatened to leave the Republican Party following a reported closed-door meeting of GOP establishment leaders. The meeting, which included Republican National Committee chairman Reince Priebus and Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, reportedly discussed the possibility of a "brokered national convention" if there is no clear winner in the party's primary election season.

In a statement, Carson expressed disapproval of the alleged plan, stating, "If this was the beginning of a plan to subvert the will of the voters and replace it with the will of the political elite, I assure you Donald Trump will not be the only one leaving the party." Carson's statement referenced Trump's repeated threats to leave the GOP if treated "unfairly."

The Republican National Committee did not immediately respond to questions about the meeting and Carson's threat.

A third-party run by Carson or Trump could pose a significant challenge for the GOP. While Carson is slipping in recent polls, an independent bid that siphoned even a few percentage points away from the party's nominee could make it all but impossible for the Republican nominee to win the general election.

Spokesman Doug Watts stated that Carson was appalled at reports suggesting that Republican leaders were trying to manipulate the party's presidential nominating process. He acknowledged that Carson, like Trump and the rest of the Republican field, signed a pledge not to launch a third-party bid.

"The pledge is not meaningless," Watts said. "But he signed the pledge based on everybody playing by the rules."

Title: China's Fervent Celebration of Xi Jinping Recalls Mao Era

Article:

China is currently witnessing a wave of enthusiasm not seen since the Mao era, as the country celebrates the leadership of General Secretary Xi Jinping. Street-side banners and billboards, Communist Party publicity tours, official choral performances, and song-and-dance routines are some of the methods being employed to promote the party's message.

According to a dance troupe director, "As performers, it's our duty to educate the masses about how they benefit from party and state policies."

The United States, on the other hand, is grappling with its own political and social issues, as demonstrated by the recent wedding cake case heard by the Supreme Court. The case centers on the question of whether a Colorado baker, acting on religious conviction, can deny a gay couple's request for a wedding cake. The state of Colorado has ruled against the baker, and the U.S. Supreme Court's decision is expected to be close, with Justice Anthony Kennedy likely to play a decisive role.

The larger question at hand is the extent of government power in promoting and enforcing views that are more backed by government power than by popular consensus. In Xi Jinping's China, government power is seemingly limitless, with the party's decrees carrying the force of law. In the United States, consent of the governed has long been a guiding principle.

One example of government overreach is the practice of busing for racial balance, which, half a century ago, led to forced integration of schools, causing widespread resistance and exacerbating racial segregation.

Government attempts to impose conformity in the name of a beneficial cause can ignite controversy and stifle reconciliation, especially when judges impose their views on the masses. Reconciliation, in practice, is often met with resistance by educators and judicial authorities who seek to mold the thoughts and behaviors of the unenlightened masses.

The "American way of life" is a flexible concept, encompassing a wide range of beliefs and lifestyles. It is hoped that freedom from unnecessary government molding of thought and behavior will continue to be a cherished aspect of American society.

The article concludes by questioning the path that led the United States to its current political climate, where government intervention in personal matters is a contentious issue. The author expresses concern over the potential for government overreach and the stifling of individual freedoms.

Title: Social Media Companies Accused of Allowing Chinese Communist Party Propaganda on U.S. Platforms

Article:

Investigators with the House Foreign Affairs Committee have accused major American social media companies, including Twitter, Facebook, and YouTube, of allowing the Chinese Communist Party (CCP) to disseminate propaganda to U.S. audiences with little oversight or warning. The investigation, led by Rep. Michael McCaul (R-Texas), is part of a broader effort by congressional leaders to crack down on China's influence operations in the United States.

The investigation, presented in the form of report cards, graded each company on whether they have banned CCP officials and news outlets, applied warning labels to their content, and fact-checked their claims for accuracy. All of the websites failed these tests. Twitter received a D-, Facebook a C+, and YouTube a C-, implying each still permits the dissemination of anti-U.S. communist propaganda, often without warning labels for readers.

The investigation found that Twitter is the platform most heavily abused by the CCP, with the company only applying a fact-check label to a tweet about the coronavirus originating with the U.S. military after it had been on the platform for over a month. Facebook allows several Chinese state-controlled propaganda outlets to freely post misinformation, potentially reaching millions of Americans. YouTube does not block communist officials and news outlets or remove their materials but attempts to fact-check and police this content for inaccuracies.

Congressional investigators remain concerned that China does not rank as a top priority for these websites, with Twitter only fact-checking tweets from prominent voices such as the president. Facebook and YouTube have not taken sufficient action to prevent the CCP from using their platforms to spread propaganda and lies about COVID-19, according to the report.

Title: North Carolina Governor Signs Controversial Election Law Overhaul

Article:

North Carolina Governor Pat McCrory signed into law on Monday a contentious bill that significantly alters the state's election laws. The new legislation mandates government-issued photo IDs at polling stations, reduces the early voting period by one week, and eliminates same-day registration.

McCrory, a Republican, referred to the changes as "common sense reforms" and asserted that they would safeguard the "integrity" of the voting process. In a statement from his office and a 95-second YouTube video, the governor emphasized that residents can obtain a free photo ID at local Department of Motor Vehicle offices across the state. To allow ample time for compliance, McCrory stated that photo ID would not be enforced until the 2016 elections.

Democrats and minority groups argue that the new law will suppress voting and make it more difficult for minorities, the elderly, and youth to cast their ballots. The American Civil Liberties Union and other civil rights groups have pledged to challenge the changes. The Reverend William Barber, president of the state chapter of the NAACP, told The Associated Press that the law is a "trampling on the blood, sweat, and tears of the martyrs—black and white—who fought for voting rights in this country." He added that the law places McCrory "on the wrong side of history." The NAACP chapter has filed a legal challenge to the measure.

NPR's Kathy Lohr reports that McCrory signed the bill into law just weeks after the U.S. Supreme Court struck down a section of the Voting Rights Act that required North Carolina and other states to secure approval from the federal government before altering their election laws. The Justice Department is reportedly considering filing a lawsuit against the new North Carolina law, as it is currently engaged in a similar legal battle over a Texas voting law.

Title: Turkish President Threatens Europe with Refugee Influx Over Syria Operation Label

Article:

Turkey's President Recep Tayyip Erdogan warned Europe on Thursday that he would flood the continent with 3.6 million refugees if European leaders label the ongoing Turkish military operation in Syria as an "occupation." According to Reuters, Erdogan made the statement during a meeting with officials from his ruling AK Party.

The Turkish military operation in northern Syria, which began on Wednesday, involves airstrikes and artillery fire targeting U.S.-allied Kurdish forces on the ground. The operation followed President Donald Trump's surprise announcement last week of a U.S. troop withdrawal from a part of Syria that had been reclaimed in a bloody and prolonged war between the U.S.-led coalition and the Islamic State (IS).

Trump's decision was framed as a move to hand the responsibility of containing IS to the Turks. On Wednesday, Trump defended his decision by stating that the Kurds did not assist the U.S. during World War II. Ground fighting against the extremist group since 2014 was primarily led by Kurdish forces, which make up the majority of the Syrian Democratic Forces (SDF), a U.S.-backed organization responsible for governance of the area and containment of resurgent IS fighters and overcrowded IS prisons.

In certain instances, Turkey refused to aid the Kurdish forces in the anti-IS fight, viewing them as allies to dissident Kurds in the country. Erdogan has vowed to rid the area of "terrorists," and claims his objective is to facilitate the return of Syrian refugees in Turkey to their homes. However, numerous U.S. officials have expressed doubt about this promise.

Ankara has long promised to eliminate the Kurdish militia presence along its border in northern Syria, which it views as a security threat and indistinguishable from a separate Kurdish terrorist group waging a counterinsurgency inside Turkey.

Title: Oregon Resident Shares Mixed Feelings on Trump Presidency, Highlights Republican Control of State Legislatures

Article:

A resident of deep blue Oregon, who did not support Donald Trump during the Republican primaries, has shared their mixed feelings about the President's term so far. Despite not voting for Trump in the general election, the individual expressed excitement when it seemed likely that Trump would win, comparing the feeling to a sports victory.

According to CBS News, Republicans have expanded their power in state capitols to their strongest levels in decades. Thirty-three of 50 governors are now Republican, a 95-year high not seen since 1922. Daily Kos notes that Republicans control both legislative chambers in 32 states, while Democrats only control the legislature in 13 states, one of which is Oregon.

The Oregon resident expressed gratitude for a president who respects law enforcement and the military, and for someone other than Hillary Clinton appointing Supreme Court justices. They were pleased with Trump's Cabinet picks and key appointments, including Neil Gorsuch for the Supreme Court, James Mattis for secretary of Defense, Jeff Sessions for attorney general, Rick Perry for secretary of Energy, and Nikki Haley as U.S. ambassador to the United Nations.

The resident also highlighted an aspect of Trump's supporters that they had missed: the president's advocacy for a large, unrepresented segment of Americans, particularly those living in the Rust Belt whose jobs had left, and other Americans who were suffering silently with no spokesperson or lobbyists.

The resident expressed cautious optimism, stating that the big victory was the Supreme Court nominees being selected by someone other than Clinton. They acknowledged concerns about Trump's temperament and character but were pleasantly surprised by many of his conservative appointments and actions so far.

The resident also addressed the criticism Trump has faced, particularly regarding his history of despicable comments and credible allegations of sexual assault and unwanted advances. They questioned the hypocrisy of the left in criticizing Trump while seemingly overlooking similar allegations against Bill and Hillary Clinton. The resident called for fair and evenly applied accountability for all parties involved.

Dan Lucas, an independent researcher and policy advocate, is the past editor of the conservative blog Oregon Catalyst. This column first ran in the (Salem, Ore.) Statesman Journal. Readers can submit letters, comments, or columns through the newspaper's submission guidelines.

Title: The Washington Post Suspends Reporter Felicia Sonmez: A Closer Look at the Controversial Suspension

Article:

The Washington Post suspended national political reporter Felicia Sonmez on Monday following her tweet about the death of Kobe Bryant, which linked to a 2016 Daily Beast article detailing Bryant's sexual assault allegations. The reasons behind the suspension remain unclear, with conflicting reports emerging from various sources.

On Sunday, Sonmez shared a link to the article, which was widely discussed on social media. The level of backlash she received was intense, with Sonmez receiving numerous death threats and abusive messages. In response, Sonmez defended herself, stating that public figures should be remembered in their entirety, even if their totality is unsettling.

The Post demanded that Sonmez delete her tweets and placed her on administrative leave, according to Erik Wemple, the Post's media critic, who interviewed Sonmez and determined that the paper's suspension was "misguided." Wemple questioned, "What did Sonmez do to deserve this brushback? She tweeted out a very good story from the Daily Beast."

The Post provided a statement, stating that Sonmez was placed on administrative leave while the paper reviews whether her tweets violated the Post's social media policy. Managing editor Tracy Grant's statement, however, raises questions, as it does not specify any policy violations.

The Post's social media policy, which dates back to 2016, states that journalists must refrain from posting anything that could objectively be perceived as reflecting political, racial, sexist, religious, or other bias or favoritism. It is unclear how Sonmez's tweets violate these guidelines.

Matthew Keys, citing an unnamed source, reported that Sonmez was suspended because the screenshot she tweeted out revealed the full names of those who had written her. However, Sonmez told Wemple that she had not heard this explanation from the Post. In fact, it was Sonmez who was doxxed, as her address was posted online, and she checked into a hotel out of fear for her safety.

It is also unclear how Sonmez's tweets "undermined the work of her colleagues," as Grant put it. The Post has published numerous stories on Bryant's death, and Sonmez's social media posts do not appear to have interfered with the coverage.

When asked to elaborate on the reasons for Sonmez's suspension, the Post's communications manager, Molly Gannon, stated, "We do not have anything additional to share."

By suspending Sonmez, the Post has made itself the focal point of a distracting newsroom drama that could have been avoided had it treated one of its employees with a little more respect.

Title: Senate Democrats Accuse President Trump of Responsibility for 3D-Printed Gun Availability

Article:

Senate Democrats have accused President Donald Trump of bearing responsibility for the availability of 3D-printed guns, should they end up on the streets, if his administration does not take immediate action to block a Texas company from posting blueprints for the firearms online.

Senator Ed Markey (D-Massachusetts) stated, "The ball is in his court — he has a chance to prevent this from happening." Markey further added, "Donald Trump will be totally responsible for every downloadable, plastic AR-15 that will be roaming the streets of our country if he does not act today."

The senator and other congressional Democrats are advocating for legislation aimed at blocking Defense Distributed, the company, from posting downloadable blueprints online. The issue has sparked a wave of legal action following a settlement last month between the State Department and the company, which allows Defense Distributed to post the files once again after a years-long legal battle that spanned both the Obama and Trump administrations.

Defense Distributed and its founder, Cody Wilson, argue that their right to move forward with the plans to post the files online falls under constitutionally-protected free speech.

Senator Richard Blumenthal (D-Connecticut) stated, "These guns are a menace. The failure to ban them will mean blood on the hands of officials who have that responsibility. I call on the Trump administration now to do the right thing."

President Trump tweeted on Tuesday that he is looking into the issue and has spoken to the National Rifle Association about it. However, Sen. Blumenthal stated, "He can blame it on anyone if he wants to save face, but it's his doing. It's his responsibility, and the blood's going to be on his hands. It's that simple and stark."

The senators and other Democrats in Congress are now pushing legislation aimed at blocking the company from posting the prints and looking to ban "untraceable" guns that don't have serial numbers or metal parts that can be crafted using 3D printers.

Senate Minority Leader Charles E. Schumer predicted that nothing would come of President Trump's tweet, calling it "a dollar short and a day late." Schumer stated, "[As] sure as we're here today, nothing is going to happen from this administration." He added, "We're going to have to pass legislation [because] they are just enslaved by the NRA."

House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi stated last month's decision "is a death warrant for countless innocent men, women, and children." Pelosi further added, "This settlement makes clear that the GOP is a wholly-owned subsidiary of the NRA."

Title: Healthcare Exchanges Fail to Post Consumer Ratings, Leaving Consumers in the Dark

Article:

In the United States, the implementation of the Affordable Care Act (ObamaCare) has been met with technical issues and a lack of consumer ratings, leaving shoppers with limited information to make informed decisions about their health plans. The consumer ratings, called for in the Affordable Care Act, would be provided by an independent company, allowing consumers to judge health plans based on treatment outcomes, service, and consumer satisfaction.

However, federal and state officials have not published these ratings, citing concerns that it would reflect poorly on the insurance exchanges if some companies were rated and others were not. This controversy arose last week in California, where three highly-rated providers, including Western Advantage, Kaiser Permanente, and Sharp Health Care, complained that the state failed to post their ratings due to opposition from lower-rated plans.

Garry Maisel, CEO of Western Health Advantage, stated, "When a quality rating is available, consumers should have access to it. If I was a consumer, I would want to know [if] the plan I pick, the network of providers I access care through, was just put together or has been around a long time."

The National Council on Quality Assurance (NCQA) rates almost every health plan available nationwide on treatment, prevention, and customer service. Each category is scored on a scale of 1 to 5, and plans are ranked from best to worst. Eighty percent of insurers nationwide are rated by the NCQA. However, only eight states are posting those ratings, with the rest, including the 34 state health care exchanges managed by the federal government, not posting them.

Betsy McCaughey, a health care analyst, stated, "To make a smart choice, we need more information, that is why this rating system is so important. Otherwise, choosing a plan on these exchanges is just a shot in the dark."

Some states, like Colorado, Minnesota, and Oregon, do post ratings. The Oregon website lists the quality score right next to price, allowing for an apples-to-apples comparison. Maisel stated that it is a model other states should strive for.

"Value is a combination of price versus quality," he said. "It's like an equation, like a teeter-totter. So put it out there! Price is out, so put the quality rating out there and let the consumer decide who they want to buy based on value."

Under the law, the health care exchanges have until 2016 to display quality-of-care data.

Title: Tucker Carlson Questions Double Standard in FBI's Investigation of Alleged Hate Crimes

Article:

Tucker Carlson, host of Fox News Channel's "Tucker Carlson Tonight," opened his Tuesday program by questioning the double standard in the investigation of alleged hate crimes compared to other crimes. He pointed to the Department of Justice and FBI's investigation of the alleged hate crime at the Talladega Superspeedway in Alabama, contrasting it with the alleged crimes committed by the "mob."

Carlson argued that the apparent conclusion was that the "mob" was an arm of the Democratic Party's establishment. He questioned the authenticity of the noose incident involving NASCAR driver Bubba Wallace, citing the lack of evidence and the history of similar incidents being hoaxes.

Carlson highlighted six high-profile alleged hate crimes involving nooses between 2015 and 2018, all of which turned out to be hoaxes. He also mentioned the case of Jussie Smollett, who was charged with staging a hate crime against himself.

The host questioned the FBI's response to the Bubba Wallace incident, with 15 agents investigating the alleged provocation, while mobs were reportedly roaming the country, burning property, and assaulting people with seemingly little law enforcement intervention.

Carlson concluded that the FBI's response to the Bubba Wallace incident was a hoax, as there was no hate crime in Wallace's garage. He also questioned the FBI and Federal prosecutors' response to the vandalism of the statue of American patriot, Francis Scott Key, in San Francisco, where the words "Kill the colonizers. Kill whitey" were spray-painted.

Carlson suggested that the double standard in the investigation of hate crimes and the response to the "mob" indicated that the "mob" was an arm of the Democratic establishment. He also pointed to the City of Philadelphia's Mayor and District Attorney, who allegedly supported the destruction of public property, while threatening to prosecute those trying to protect statues.

Title: Justice Department Files Lawsuit Against Ferguson to Overhaul Police and Court Operations

Article:

The Justice Department has filed a lawsuit against the city of Ferguson in an attempt to force a reformation of the city's troubled police and court operations. Attorney General Loretta Lynch announced the decision on Wednesday, following a rejection by the Ferguson City Council of a consent decree that was previously agreed upon.

The lawsuit alleges that local law enforcement conduct in Ferguson routinely violates the Constitution. The residents of Ferguson have been waiting nearly a year for an agreement that would protect their rights and ensure their safety, according to Lynch.

The city's troubles, which include a pattern and practice of racially biased policing, were highlighted by the August 2014 police shooting death of an unarmed black teenager, Michael Brown. The incident and subsequent protests led to a wide-ranging investigation by the Justice Department, which concluded nearly a year ago that the city's police and municipal court unfairly targeted African-American residents, who make up about 70% of the population.

Ferguson Mayor James Knowles and city council members raised concerns about the cost of implementing the tentative agreement, which they estimated could cost nearly $10 million over the next three years. The city has a budget of about $14 million and is facing about $2.8 million in debt due to police overtime during the unrest following Brown's death and lost tax revenue from businesses destroyed or badly damaged in rioting.

In response to the lawsuit, Ferguson Mayor James Knowles stated, "The ball is in their court. We're sitting and waiting to talk. If they want to threaten legal action, then that's what they're threatening."

The Justice Department's decision to file a lawsuit comes after city leaders sought to revise the settlement, citing prohibitive costs. However, the Justice Department maintains that there is no cost for constitutional policing.

The city of Ferguson has been at the center of a national discussion on police tactics and community relations, prompting the appointment of a special White House panel. In Ferguson, city leaders hosted a series of emotionally-charged hearings this month on whether to ratify the tentative Justice settlement. Some residents urged the City Council to reject the deal and take their chances in court, while others favored the agreement as a way for the city to regain the trust of a wary African-American community.

Wesley Bell, a Ferguson council member, said members of the council felt it was important to present their concerns about the costs of implementing the deal. He stated that the amendments to the agreement were not meant to be a "take it or leave it" offer.

"We hope the Justice Department is willing to sit down and talk to us and continue negotiations," Bell said. "If this case goes to court, it will not be because of the city of Ferguson."

Proponents of the Justice agreement noted that fighting a legal battle could be costly and prove more expensive in the long-term than settling now. However, Mayor Knowles disputed this notion, stating that the city's analysis shows "the agreement, as it currently stands, will cost more to implement than it would be to fight a lawsuit."

Title: U.S. Troop Withdrawal from Afghanistan: A Look at the Prisoner Exchange and the Seven-Day Reduction in Violence Agreement

Article:

The recent seven-day reduction in violence agreement between the United States and the Taliban has sparked discussions about the future of Afghanistan and the role of negotiators in such agreements. The deal, which may not guarantee lasting peace, has been met with mixed reactions, with some viewing it as a significant step towards ending American involvement in the war, while others criticize certain aspects of the agreement.

One contentious issue is the prisoner exchange, with experts noting that the Taliban has long demanded a large prisoner release before negotiations. The U.S. made this a precondition for the Afghan government and the Taliban to engage in talks, a move that has reportedly caused tension with the Afghan government, which is holding the Taliban prisoners.

The Trump administration has been criticized for not anticipating or managing this issue more effectively beforehand. However, the administration has argued that ending American involvement in the war is the right thing to do, especially given the difficult terrain and tribal complexities of Afghanistan, which have made it notoriously difficult to govern and conquer.

President Trump has expressed his aversion to foreign military entanglements, and he has pledged to get the troops out. The politics of the moment should not obscure the fact that ending American involvement in the war is a decision that has been reached, with the seven-day reduction in violence agreement being a step towards this goal.

Comparisons have been drawn between the current administration's approach and that of former President Obama, who was criticized for releasing five Taliban detainees in exchange for a captured U.S. soldier, Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl, in 2014. In contrast, the Trump administration has agreed to the release of an estimated 5,000 Taliban prisoners.

Despite the criticisms, some argue that the Trump administration has achieved in its first term what the Bush and Obama administrations were either unable or unwilling to do over two terms each. The seven-day reduction in violence agreement and the prisoner exchange are significant steps in the ongoing peace process, and it is hoped that they will lead to a more stable and peaceful Afghanistan. However, it is important to acknowledge that Afghanistan is still a long way from peace, and the road ahead is likely to be challenging.

Title: Five Killed in Shooting at Annapolis Newspaper; Suspect Identified as Jarrod Ramos

Article:

A shooting at the Capital Gazette newspaper in Annapolis, Maryland, on Thursday left at least five people dead and several others injured. The suspect, identified as Jarrod Ramos, 38, of Laurel, is believed to have had a long-running feud with the newspaper.

According to authorities, Ramos fired through a glass door, looked for victims, and then sprayed the newsroom with gunfire. Acting police chief of the Anne Arundel County Police Department William Krampf confirmed that Capital Gazette assistant editor Rob Hiaasen, 59, was among the victims. Wendi Winters, 65, Rebecca Smith, 34, Gerald Fischman, 61, and John McNamara were also killed, he said. Smith was a sales assistant, and the others were journalists.

Krampf stated, "This was a targeted attack on the Capital Gazette. This person was prepared to shoot people. His intent was to cause harm." The suspect is currently in custody, but as of Thursday evening, he has not been booked.

Ramos is believed to have brought a defamation lawsuit against Eric Hartley, formerly a staff writer and columnist with The Capital, and Thomas Marquardt, then editor and publisher of The Capital, in 2012. In 2015, Maryland's second-highest court upheld a ruling in favor of the Capital Gazette and a former reporter who were accused by Ramos of defamation.

Phil Davis, a Capital Gazette crime reporter, said he was hiding under his desk along with other newspaper employees when the shooter stopped firing. Davis told the Baltimore Sun, "I don't know why he stopped."

Police are treating the shooting as a local incident, with no links to terrorism. Law enforcement officials are still investigating the motive behind the attack. When police found the suspect, his weapon was on the ground and "not in his immediate proximity," according to Anne Arundel county executive Steve Schuh.

Capital Gazette runs multiple newspapers out of its Annapolis office and includes one of the oldest newspapers in the United States, The Gazette, which traces its origins back to 1727. The company, part of the Tronc Inc media group, publishes newspapers in and around Annapolis, home of the U.S. Naval Academy. The papers have thrived by focusing on local news in the shadows of two much larger competitors, the Washington Post and Baltimore Sun.

Law enforcement in Baltimore and New York City have deployed extra officers to the offices of the New York Times and other major media outlets as a precaution. The shooting drew the attention of media groups, including Reporters Without Borders, which said it was deeply disturbed by the events in Annapolis.

U.S. President Donald Trump has been briefed on the shooting, and White House spokeswoman Lindsay Walters said, "My thoughts and prayers are with the victims and their families." White House Press Secretary Sarah Sanders said on Twitter, "A violent attack on innocent journalists doing their job is an attack on every American."

Jimmy DeButts, an editor at the Capital Gazette, tweeted that he was devastated, heartbroken, and numb. "I'm in no position to speak, just know @capgaznews reporters & editors give all they have every day. There are no 40-hour weeks, no big paydays - just a passion for telling stories from our community," he wrote. One of the group's flagship papers, The Capital, plans to publish a Friday edition. "I can tell you this: We are putting out a damn paper tomorrow," reporter Chase Cook wrote on Twitter a few hours after the shooting.

Title: Former Massachusetts Governor Mitt Romney Calls for Comprehensive Strategy Against Islamic State, Tightened Refugee Policies

Article:

In a commentary published in The Washington Post, former Massachusetts Governor Mitt Romney has called for the West to take a more aggressive approach towards the Islamic State (ISIS), including a call to wage war to "eradicate" the group "once and for all." Romney criticized President Barack Obama's handling of ISIS, stating that the group has "metastasized" during his administration.

Romney argues that the current air campaign is insufficient and calls for a comprehensive strategy that integrates efforts with regional allies such as the Kurds, Turks, Saudis, Egyptians, and Jordanians. He also suggests that the United States should not accept refugees from the Middle East without proper vetting, particularly young men.

The call comes in response to the Paris attacks, where it was confirmed that a Syrian refugee, who was registered in several European countries last month, was found near the body of one of the attackers.

Romney emphasizes the need for American leadership in this war, stating that "only America can lead this war, and that leadership means being willing to devote whatever resources are required to win – even boots on the ground." He criticizes Obama's assertion that the advance of the jihadists had been "contained" as proven wrong.

Romney also calls for a clear and unambiguous identification of the enemy, stating that "We will not defeat it if we are afraid to call it by its name." He differentiates between radical Islamists and the Islamic faith, stating that the Islamic State represents the greatest threat among branches of this ideology. Romney suggests that the broader Islamic world will play a critical role in this war.

Title: Democrats Consider Trade of Bidens for Bolton in Impeachment Trial

Article:

In the ongoing impeachment trial of President Donald Trump, there is a potential shift in strategy among some Democrats, as they consider trading the testimony of Hunter Biden, the son of former Vice President Joe Biden, for that of former National Security Adviser John Bolton.

According to a report by The Washington Post, Democrats are now seriously contemplating this trade-off, with the aim of hearing from their desired witnesses, such as Bolton. Sen. Sherrod Brown, a Democrat, has previously stated that he would find it "fine" for Hunter Biden to testify, as Democrats "take the position that we want to hear from the witnesses."

However, the political implications of this move are uncertain. Democrats believe that calling either Biden could potentially harm Trump and the Republican Party, providing a platform for the Bidens to counterattack and portray Republicans as overly focused on damaging a 2020 presidential rival.

Yet, this strategy may not be advantageous for Democrats. Trump has thus far managed to survive numerous attempts to remove him from office, and his presidency remains intact. Moreover, the Bidens may face significant challenges in a Senate hearing, given Hunter Biden's past admissions of his role at Burisma and the public's unfavorable perception of his actions.

Further complicating matters, the presence of Joe Biden in the Senate chamber could potentially lead to internal conflicts among the Democratic candidates, as they vie for the party's nomination. With some candidates already publicly criticizing Hunter Biden's role in Burisma, a Senate trial could provide additional opportunities for attacks on the frontrunner.

Ultimately, the decision to call either Biden or Bolton may not significantly alter the course of the impeachment trial, as both parties are likely to face political risks. The public's sentiment regarding impeachment is already largely set, and John Bolton is expected to corroborate the existing evidence against Trump.

S.E. Cupp, the host of "S.E. Cupp Unfiltered" on CNN, suggests that Democrats should avoid involving the Bidens in the impeachment trial and accept that Trump's downfall may ultimately be self-inflicted.

Title: California Voters Approve Sentence Reduction for Some Prisoners, Reject Abolition of Death Penalty

Article:

California voters have approved a ballot initiative that alters the state's three-strikes law, potentially making thousands of prisoners eligible for sentence reductions. However, a proposition to abolish the death penalty in the state was rejected.

The approved initiative modifies the three-strikes law by eliminating the mandatory 25-years-to-life sentence for a third felony if the crime is nonviolent. As many as 3,000 prisoners could appeal their original sentences due to this change, a concern for the author of the original three-strikes law, Mike Reynolds.

On the other hand, the proposition to replace the death penalty with life imprisonment without the possibility of parole was rejected. Mark Klass, the father of Polly Klass, a 12-year-old girl murdered in 1993, expressed relief that the man convicted of the crime will remain on death row.

More than 700 inmates are currently on California's death row, and 14 of them have exhausted all legal appeals. It remains unclear when executions will resume in California.

Former Los Angeles District Attorney Gil Garcetti, who had joined with the ACLU and a former head warden of San Quentin prison to try to abolish the state's death penalty, argues that the death penalty does not serve as a crime deterrent. He also points out that the state has spent $4 billion to house death row inmates and pay for their appeals.

While Californians rejected Proposition 34, they did vote to change the state's three-strikes law. Los Angeles District Attorney Steve Cooley argues that repeat offenders will still have to serve time, but their sentences will be proportionate to the crime committed. He claims this practice has been successful in reducing crime rates in Los Angeles County for the past 12 years.

Adam Gelb, director of the Public Safety Performance Project at the Pew Center on the States, notes that California previously had the nation's harshest three-strikes law. He suggests that the vote to revise it indicates a growing tiredness among voters of spending money on nonviolent offenders serving long prison sentences. Gelb also suggests that this could lead to other states reforming their three-strikes laws.

Title: Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel Resigns, President Obama to Announce Decision Later Today

Article:

The White House confirmed on Monday that Secretary of Defense Chuck Hagel is stepping down. President Obama will announce Mr. Hagel's resignation, first reported by The New York Times on Monday, in the White House later this morning.

Over the past two years, Secretary Hagel has managed an intense period of transition for the United States Armed Forces, including the drawdown in Afghanistan, the need to prepare our forces for future missions, and tough fiscal choices to keep our military strong and ready.

A senior administration official stated, "Over nearly two years, Secretary Hagel has been a steady hand, guiding our military through this transition, and helping us respond to challenges from [the Islamic State] to Ebola." The official added that Secretary Hagel began speaking with the President about departing the administration given the natural post-midterms transition time in October.

The official also mentioned that a successor to Mr. Hagel will be named "in short order," and until then, the secretary will remain in his post. Mr. Hagel submitted his resignation Monday morning, and it was accepted by Mr. Obama, according to The Associated Press.

A White House official told AP that Mr. Obama and Mr. Hagel "determined that it was time for new leadership in the Pentagon." The President reportedly asked the sole Republican on his national security team to step down on Friday after a series of meetings over the past several weeks.

Mr. Hagel leaves for the next defense secretary a host of issues to confront, notably the Obama administration's military campaign against the Islamic State terrorist group. The New York Times reported that possible replacements for Mr. Hagel include Michele Flournoy, the former under secretary of defense; Sen. Jack Reed, Democrat of Rhode Island and a former officer with the Army's 82nd Airborne; and Ashton B. Carter, a former deputy secretary of defense.

Title: The Rise of ISIS: An Examination of Key Factors and Responsibility

Article:

Peter Bergen, a national security analyst for CNN, vice president at New America, and a professor of practice at Arizona State University, is the author of the forthcoming book "United States of Jihad: Investigating America's Homegrown Terrorists." In discussing the origins of ISIS, Bergen addresses the question of how the Obama administration's exit from Iraq at the end of 2011 may have contributed to the rise of ISIS.

The emergence of ISIS can be traced back to a Jordanian militant named Abu Musab al-Zarqawi, who founded ISIS's parent organization, al Qaeda in Iraq. In 2004, Zarqawi was responsible for the televised beheadings, starting with the killing of American businessman Nick Berg, and ignited a civil war against the Shiites in Iraq the same year. These tactics and policies remain at the core of ISIS today.

The opportunity for Zarqawi to create al Qaeda in Iraq was provided by George W. Bush's decision to invade Iraq in 2003. Saddam Hussein, the Iraqi dictator, brutally suppressed all opposition to his regime, and before the Iraq War, al Qaeda had no presence in Iraq. Al Qaeda in Iraq grew in strength in 2006, controlling much of the massive Anbar province in western Iraq, before being largely extirpated by U.S. troops in 2008.

However, al Qaeda in Iraq surged back as ISIS due to four significant factors. The first was the Syrian civil war, which began in 2011 in response to President Bashar al-Assad's brutal repression of peaceful protests against his dictatorship. Elements of what would become ISIS traveled from Iraq into Syria to fight against Assad, gaining strength in Syria, which they drew upon when they re-entered Iraq as a reinvigorated force in 2013, seizing much of Anbar a year later as well as Mosul, the second-largest city in Iraq.

The second factor was the role that some of Hussein's former officer corps played in helping ISIS to its victories. A number of the late dictator's former commanders helped to professionalize ISIS as a fighting force. The Bush administration's decision to disband the Iraqi army in 2003 had helped push some Iraqi officers to join Sunni militant groups.

The third factor was the feckless and incompetent rule of then-Iraqi Prime Minister Nuri al-Maliki, who marginalized Sunnis and disenfranchised them from Iraq's political process to the point that many Sunnis preferred the rule of the Islamist militants in ISIS to that of the "Shia" government in Baghdad. Inexplicably, the Obama White House kept backing Maliki despite his manifest flaws as a leader.

The fourth factor was the hollowing out of the Iraqi army, which simply ran away as ISIS made its most dramatic advances during the first half of 2014. The Iraqi army was poorly led, poorly paid, and riven with corruption.

None of these factors can be easily ascribed to Obama or Clinton, although they did preside over the withdrawal of all U.S. troops from Iraq at the end of 2011, a plan bequeathed to them by Bush. Could the Obama administration have fought harder to retain a U.S. troop presence in Iraq? Possibly. Would the Iraqi government have allowed such a presence? Not likely, as the Iraq government was by the time of the U.S. withdrawal more aligned with Iran than with the United States.

Obama was also slow to recognize the threat posised by ISIS, famously referring to the Islamist terrorist group gaining ground in Syria and Iraq as a "JV" team in a January 2014 interview. Since the summer of 2014, the Obama administration has mounted an aggressive campaign against ISIS, but it has proven reluctant to do much on the ground. Could more be done? Yes. More U.S. Special Forces fighting side by side with Iraqi forces and more U.S. forward air controllers calling in close air support would certainly help the Iraqi military against ISIS.

In Syria, a no-fly zone targeted at Assad's air force and safe zones for refugees fleeing the fighting would help tamp down the death toll that plays into the hands of ISIS and other Sunni militants who can position themselves as the only groups that are really defending the Sunni population.

Rather than making loose and unsubstantiated claims that Obama and Clinton created ISIS, it would behoove Trump if he advanced some real policy ideas about how to solve the Syrian and Iraqi civil wars. Of course, to do that he would have to get beyond the inflammatory slogans and sound bites that have characterized his campaign.

Title: Trump's Tax-Cut Proposals Shift Focus Away from Fiscal Discipline

Article:

President Trump's new tax-cut proposals have sparked a debate over the nation's fiscal discipline as the focus shifts towards tax cuts and away from tax reform that would maintain revenue levels. The proposals, which include slashing corporate tax rates from 35 percent to 15 percent and individual tax cuts, mark a shift in the Trump administration's approach to fiscal policy.

This shift is not unique to the Trump team, according to fiscal-policy experts. Politicians and their advisors are reportedly less focused on restraining government debt and deficits compared to previous eras. However, this does not mean that the goal of fiscal discipline has been completely disregarded, as Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin acknowledged the need for fiscal discipline during Wednesday's announcement of the tax-cut goals and principles.

The economic implications of the tax cuts are a subject of debate among economists. While some argue that fiscal stimulus can provide a short-term boost to the economy, others are skeptical that Trump's tax cuts would significantly increase growth.

Historically, the United States has seen a surge in federal deficits during and after economic downturns, but deficits have since fallen sharply and are now near their five-decade average as a share of the US economy. However, even without tax cuts, the annual gap between revenue and spending is expected to rise again, potentially driving a parallel surge in public debt in the coming decades due to rising obligations for health-care entitlements and interest on the debt.

The shift in fiscal policy is not solely a political issue, but also reflects a change in economic thought, with some liberal economists arguing that fiscal stimulus may be justifiable in some non-recession times. However, the long-term consequences of this shift in fiscal policy remain a topic of debate among economists and the public.

While the legislative outlook is uncertain, some experts are hopeful that forces of fiscal restraint will revive in the future. Bill White, a former Houston mayor and author of a book on America's fiscal history, believes that a backlash among small-government conservatives and a growing understanding among Democrats of the dangers of rising interest costs could lead to a renewed focus on fiscal discipline.

Title: Tillerson Hails "Historic Moment" in U.S.-Saudi Relations During Joint Address with Saudi Foreign Minister

Article:

Secretary of State Rex Tillerson and Saudi Arabian Foreign Minister Adel bin Ahmed Al-Jubeir emphasized strategic and economic partnerships during a joint address in Riyadh on Saturday, May 20, 2017. Tillerson described the occasion as a "historic moment" in U.S.-Saudi relations.

Accompanied by President Donald Trump on his first foreign trip as commander in chief, Tillerson referenced multiple potential threats facing the two countries. He highlighted the development of a new center for combating extremist ideology, to be based in Riyadh, and the need to defeat ISIS not only on the battlefield but also in the cyberspace.

The new defense deal, which includes upgrades to Saudi communications, missile defense, maritime, border, and cyber security, is expected to lower the demands on the U.S. military and strengthen Saudi security forces for the future. Tillerson stated that the arms sales package would reduce the burden on the U.S. to provide the same equipment to its own military forces.

Tillerson also discussed other Middle Eastern countries with high levels of conflict, including Yemen, where he suggested a "political" solution is needed and that it's "important to put pressure on parties to come to the table and talk."

On Iran, Tillerson stated that the U.S. is closely coordinating its efforts to counter Iran's extremism, particularly its support for foreign fighters, foreign fighter payments, and militia operating in Yemen, Iraq, and Syria. He mentioned the possibility of a conversation with Iranian Foreign Minister Mohammad Javad Zarif in the future, though no plans are set.

Tillerson also addressed the economic benefits of Saudi Arabia's direct investment in the U.S., stating that it would bring "hundreds of thousands" of jobs to American workers. Earlier, Trump described the investments as "hundreds of billions" for the U.S. and jobs for its citizens.

Saudi Foreign Minister Al-Jubeir called for a change in the conversation in the U.S. and the broader Western world to "one of partnership," while directly quoting Trump's rhetoric. He stated that the partnership would "truly change our world, and we will have truly drowned the voices of extremism, and we will have drained the swamp from which extremism and terrorism emanates."

Title: Senate Nuclear Option Threatened as Republicans Block Nominees

Article:

The "nuclear option" has resurfaced in the United States Senate following the Republican party's blocking of two of President Barack Obama's nominations to both the executive and judicial branches. The votes, which took place on Thursday, have reignited discussions about changing the Senate's rules to allow nominations to pass with a simple majority, rather than the current 60-vote threshold for procedural votes.

The Senate voted 56-42 to block Rep. Mel Watt's (D-NC) nomination to head the Federal Housing Finance Agency, and Patricia Millett's nomination to the D.C. Circuit Court of Appeals was stopped in a 55-38 vote.

Senate Democrats, who have long advocated for rules changes to allow for simple majority votes on nominees, view Thursday's votes as another reason to eliminate the 60-vote threshold. Sen. Sherrod Brown (D-Ohio) stated, "Support is growing for changing the rules when they play these games."

Sen. Tom Udall (D-N.M.) commented, "The pattern of 'obstruct and delay' has returned as the norm in the U.S. Senate with today's filibuster of two highly qualified nominees."

Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid (D-Nev.) has stated he will file cloture on two additional D.C. Circuit Court of Appeals nominees before deciding whether to invoke the nuclear option again. Reid and No. 3 Senate Democrat Chuck Schumer (D-N.Y.) have pledged to reconsider the Watt and Millett nominations "at some point in the very near future."

However, some Democrats, including Sen. Jeff Merkley (D-Ore.), believe the Senate should eliminate the filibuster on nominees as soon as possible. Merkley has long advocated for limiting the minority's power.

The GOP blocked Watt's nomination because they saw him as a political pick, rather than a housing policy expert. Republicans objected to Millett because they believe the court has a minimal workload and are concerned that Obama is trying to stack the 11-seat bench ideologically. They contend that Senate Democrats made similar arguments when President George W. Bush was trying to get his judges confirmed.

The Senate is expected to recess for a long weekend, leaving a bitter taste in the mouths of many Democrats. Vice President Joe Biden, who was on Capitol Hill to swear in Cory Booker as New Jersey's new Democratic senator, called the vote on Watt a "gigantic disappointment."

Title: Colorado Voters' Support for Recreational Marijuana Law Increases, but Majority Views It as Harmful to State's Image

Article:

A new survey conducted by Quinnipiac University indicates that slightly more Colorado voters support the state's new recreational marijuana law compared to six months ago. The poll, which was conducted from January 29 to February 2, interviewed 1,139 registered voters in Colorado by telephone. The overall sampling error is plus or minus 2.9 percentage points.

The new recreational marijuana law, which went into effect on January 1, now has the support of 58% of voters, up from 54% in August. However, the margin of 4 percentage points falls within the survey's sampling error.

The poll also reveals that a majority of Colorado voters, 51%, consider the law as harmful to the state's image, compared to 38% who disagree and 10% who are unsure or do not have an opinion.

Breaking down the numbers by demographics, 39% of Republicans support the new law, while 76% of Democrats and 55% of independents favor it. The law is more popular among those in the 18-29 age group, with 78% in support. The number drops as the age increases, with only 33% of those 65 or older supporting the law.

While support seems to be trending upwards, the survey also shows that 51% of Colorado voters have tried marijuana previously, but only 10% say they have used marijuana since it became legal last month.

The current law allows Coloradans to grow up to a dozen marijuana plants in their homes. The survey found that more than seven in ten (71%) say they would not be bothered if one of their neighbors was growing marijuana.

In terms of edibles, only 17% say it is very or somewhat likely they would try marijuana brownies at a gathering. Eighty-one percent would be somewhat or very uncomfortable riding in a car with a driver who has had moderate amounts of marijuana.

The survey also asked about the likelihood of trying marijuana brownies at a gathering. Only 17% say it is very or somewhat likely they would try marijuana brownies at a gathering. Eighty-one percent would be somewhat or very uncomfortable riding in a car with a driver who has had moderate amounts of marijuana.

Title: Former President Bill Clinton Calls for Supreme Court to Overturn Defense of Marriage Act

 Article:

 In a recent op-ed published by The Washington Post, former President Bill Clinton has called on the Supreme Court to rule the Defense of Marriage Act (DOMA) unconstitutional. The law, signed into law by Clinton in 1996, defines marriage as a legal union between a man and a woman, denying federal benefits to same-sex couples in the nine states where same-sex couples can legally wed.

 In the op-ed, Clinton wrote, "On March 27, DOMA will come before the Supreme Court and the justices must decide whether it is consistent with the principles of a nation that honors freedom, equality, and justice above all, and is therefore constitutional." He continued, "As the president who signed the act into law, I have come to believe that DOMA is contrary to those principles and, in fact, incompatible with our Constitution."

 When it was first enacted, Clinton wrote, "it was a very different time." He added that many supporters of the bill believed its passage would "defuse a movement to enact a constitutional amendment banning gay marriage, which would have ended the debate for a generation or more."

 Under those circumstances, he wrote, the bill came to his desk, opposed by 81 out of 535 members of Congress. Fast forward to 2013, and the climate is much different. Nine states (plus the District of Columbia) have passed laws allowing same-sex marriage, and public opinion polls show a majority of Americans think it should be legal. According to a CBS News poll conducted last month, 54% of Americans think same-sex couples should have the right to legally wed, while 39% oppose same-sex marriage.

 Looking back, Clinton said he had hoped DOMA would not provide an excuse for discrimination. "I know now that, even worse than providing an excuse for discrimination, the law is itself discriminatory," he wrote. "It should be overturned."

 Same-sex couples who are legally married in the United States are still denied "more than a thousand federal statutes and programs available to other married couples" because of the law, he wrote.

 While he previously opposed same-sex marriage, Clinton went public in 2009 with a change of heart. "I was against the constitutional amendment to ban gay marriage nationwide, and I still think that the American people should be able to play this out in debates," Clinton told CNN's Anderson Cooper in September 2009. "But me, Bill Clinton personally, I changed my position."

 "I am no longer opposed to that," he added. "I think if people want to make commitments that last a lifetime, they ought to be able to do it."

 In his op-ed, Clinton wrote that "while our laws may at times lag behind our best natures, in the end they catch up to our core values."

 "I join with the Obama administration, the petitioner Edith Windsor, and the many other dedicated men and women who have engaged in this struggle for decades in urging the Supreme Court to overturn the Defense of Marriage Act," he wrote.

Title: White House Officials Criticize Netanyahu for Accepting Congress Invitation, Citing Disrespect Toward Obama Administration

Article:

White House officials have expressed disapproval towards Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu for accepting House Speaker John Boehner's invitation to address Congress in March. According to unnamed senior U.S. officials, Netanyahu's decision was perceived as a direct challenge to President Barack Obama, with one official describing it as a "spit in our face."

The planned speech before Congress is expected to see Netanyahu urging lawmakers to impose tougher sanctions on Iran to halt its suspect nuclear program, as reported by The Times of Israel and Haaretz. Last week, Obama reportedly personally requested Netanyahu to tone down his support for new sanctions legislation, a measure Obama has pledged to veto.

The Washington Post reported that Netanyahu's apparent disregard for U.S. leadership was particularly offensive to Secretary of State John Kerry, who has made numerous efforts on Israel's behalf on the world stage over the past month. This includes dozens of calls to world leaders to oppose a U.N. Security Council resolution that would have set a time frame for the establishment of a Palestinian state.

In response to Kerry's criticism of Netanyahu's stance on new sanctions, Israel's intelligence chief, Tamir Pardo, has denied contradicting his boss during a January meeting with U.S. officials. Pardo stated that he reiterated the need for "firm pressure" to bring about meaningful compromises from the Iranian side, rather than the reported "throwing a grenade into the process."

Title: Senate Majority Leader McConnell Calls for Senate Intelligence Committee to Investigate Russian Election Interference

Article:

Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.) has called for the Senate Intelligence Committee to investigate recent findings that the Russian government attempted to influence the U.S. presidential election. In a statement on Monday, McConnell described the allegations of Russian meddling as "disturbing."

McConnell suggested that the Intelligence Committee is capable of conducting a comprehensive review of the matter, dismissing calls for a special select committee to investigate the issue. When asked about the possibility of a special bipartisan commission, McConnell indicated that the Senate would follow "regular order" and review the matter on a bipartisan basis.

McConnell sits on the Intelligence Committee as an ex-officio member, and incoming Senate Democratic Leader Charles Schumer (N.Y.) will soon join him in the same capacity. Sen. John McCain (R-Ariz.), a leading Senate voice on national security and the threat posed by Russia, has also called for a special committee to delve into the issue.

McConnell noted that McCain and Sen. Richard Burr (R-N.C.), the chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee, will both be looking at the issue and doing so on a bipartisan basis. McConnell declined to comment on the possible appointment of ExxonMobil CEO Rex Tillerson, who has close ties with Russian President Vladimir Putin, to serve as Secretary of State.

While McConnell strongly condemned allegations that Russia may have breached U.S. "cybersecurity measures," he cautioned against taking leaked characterizations of the motivation behind Russian hacking at face value, suggesting a possible partisan lens. McConnell noted that prior to the election, the director of National Intelligence released a statement about hacking activities directed by the Russian government, but cautioned that any leaks about U.S. intelligence findings "is irresponsible, likely illegal, and potentially for partisan political gain."

Jason Miller, a spokesman for President-elect Donald Trump, dismissed efforts to investigate Russian interference in the election as coming from "people who are bitter their candidate lost." Trump has dismissed the CIA report, calling it "ridiculous" on Sunday and following up on Twitter on Monday.

Title: Historical Ignorance and Political Polarization: A Reflection on Trump's Speech in Poland

Article:

During President Trump's speech in Warsaw, Poland, on Thursday, he paid tribute to Pope John Paul II's historic 1979 visit to the city. Many historians attribute the Pope's Mass in Victory Square as a pivotal event that set in motion the events leading to the fall of the Berlin Wall and the dissolution of the Soviet Union.

During the speech, President Trump referenced the millions of Poles who attended the Mass, stating, "They did not ask for wealth. They did not ask for privilege. Instead, one million Poles sang three simple words: 'We want God.'" However, some viewers and Twitter users assumed the President was making unfounded statements or speaking irrationally.

This response is understandable, given President Trump's reputation for making controversial statements. Yet, it is a reminder of the widespread political and ideological polarization that exists today. The instantaneity of television and social media platforms like Twitter only amplifies this problem.

Ignorance, being the absence of knowledge, is a common human foible. It is a vacuum that, when filled with assumptions and misinformation, can lead to misunderstandings and polarization. As historian Daniel Boorstin once noted, "The greatest enemy of knowledge is not ignorance; it is the illusion of knowledge."

The instantaneity of television and social media platforms only amplifies the problem. For instance, on the Fourth of July, NPR's Morning Edition tweeted out the text of the Declaration of Independence, 140 characters at a time. The angry responses, from both the Left and Right, were a spectacle to behold.

World War II and the Cold War, particularly Vietnam, used to define the intellectual framework for understanding many events. For people in their 30s, that framework changed to the Iraq War and the War on Terror. In my more curmudgeonly moments, it seems like the new paradigm for Millennials (and the journalists and politicians who pander to them) isn't some major geopolitical test or moment but the adventures of Harry Potter.

It is essential to recognize that a children's book about a magical boarding school for wizards is of limited utility in understanding the world. In my more curmudgeonly moments, it seems like the new paradigm for Millennials (and the journalists and politicians who pander to them) isn't some major geopolitical test or moment but the adventures of Harry Potter.

Today, we face a multitude of challenges, at home and abroad, that can only be met by people with a modicum of historical literacy. If only Harry Potter could cast a spell to give it to us.

Title: Nuclear Option and Medicare: A Tightly Linked Issue

Article:

The recent invocation of the "nuclear option" by Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid, which permanently prohibits filibustering judicial and executive branch nominees (excluding Supreme Court nominees), has sparked a debate among political pundits, particularly those concerned with fiscal issues and healthcare costs. This debate, while seemingly unrelated, is actually closely linked, as these fiscal hawks owe Reid a significant debt of gratitude for his actions.

In an interview with NewsmaxTV, Time magazine's Mark Halperin inadvertently exposed the tension between these two issues. Halperin, in discussing the nation's healthcare spending, suggested that rationing end-of-life care is necessary due to the high cost of such care. However, his comments sparked controversy when they seemed to confirm the "death panel" narrative.

Halperin later clarified that he was referring to the Independent Payment Advisory Board (IPAB), a cost-cutting panel created by the Affordable Care Act to cap Medicare spending growth. IPAB, if fully staffed and operational, would be tasked with cutting payments to healthcare providers to keep spending at a manageable level, creating an incentive for providers to allocate resources wisely.

The contradiction lies in the fact that Republicans, who are currently blocking IPAB nominations, would likely have nullified the panel altogether if Reid had not invoked the nuclear option. Without IPAB, the Secretary of Health and Human Services would have to act as a cost-cutting board, a role that would be more vulnerable to politicization and abolition by Congress than a fully staffed IPAB.

If one cares about how the country spends its healthcare dollars, as Halperin claims, Reid's decision to go nuclear is of significant consequence. The IPAB can be overridden by Congress, but only by replacing its recommendations with equivalent savings. If Congress chooses to abolish IPAB altogether, it will have to address how to finance the higher relative health spending it will create.

Republicans, and some Democratic IPAB opponents, characterize it as a rationing board. Most of them avoid "death panel" rhetoric. However, the question for them, once IPAB is up and running, will be who should be rationing these dollars instead. Should insurers do it, while pocketing a profit?

In conclusion, the nuclear option's impact on the functioning of Washington, as Halperin suggests, is a matter of perspective. While some view it as a partisan power grab, others see it as a necessary step to address the nation's fiscal health and healthcare spending. The honest, straightforward discussion Halperin called for may indeed be on the horizon, thanks to Reid's decision to invoke the nuclear option.

Title: President Trump Announces Permanent Residency Change to Florida

Article:

In a tweet on Thursday evening, President Donald Trump announced that he and his family have changed their permanent residency status to Florida. The President stated that he will continue to reside at the White House during a potential second term, but his new home will be Palm Beach, Florida, where his Mar-a-Lago Club is located.

Trump expressed his affection for the White House, stating, "1600 Pennsylvania Avenue, the White House, is the place I have come to love and will stay for, hopefully, another 5 years as we MAKE AMERICA GREAT AGAIN." However, he cited his treatment by New York City and state political leaders as the reason for his decision to change his permanent residence.

The President stated, "I cherish New York, and the people of New York, and always will, but unfortunately, despite the fact that I pay millions of dollars in city, state, and local taxes each year, I have been treated very poorly by the political leaders of both the city and state." He added, "I hated having to make this decision, but in the end, it will be best for all concerned."

New York Governor Andrew Cuomo and New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio responded to the news with tweets. Cuomo wrote, "He’s all yours, Florida," while de Blasio tweeted, "Don’t let the door hit you on the way out or whatever."

Senator Elizabeth Warren, a potential Democratic presidential candidate, accused Trump of making the move to hide tax information from New York authorities. The specifics of Trump's tax situation were not available at the time of publication.

Title: Dr. Ben Carson Forms Exploratory Committee for 2016 Presidential Run

Article:

Dr. Ben Carson, a renowned neurosurgeon, has announced the formation of an exploratory committee to consider a potential run for the 2016 presidential election. In a video released alongside the announcement, Carson expressed his dissatisfaction with the current state of political leadership in Washington and his desire to bring common-sense solutions to the table.

Carson's potential candidacy positions him as an anti-establishment, non-traditional candidate, aiming to appeal to voters who are disillusioned with the political status quo. He has already garnered a strong following due to his professional achievements and public speaking abilities.

However, some political analysts question whether Carson would be better suited for a Senate seat, given the upcoming vacancy of longtime Sen. Barbara Mikulski's (D-MD) seat in 2016. Jonah Goldberg, a conservative political commentator, suggests that Carson might have a greater impact on the national political landscape as a senatorial candidate. Goldberg argues that Carson could potentially flip a safe Democratic seat in the tough 2016 election year for Republicans, given his national appeal and the potential for rolling over his presidential campaign funds.

Despite these speculations, Carson has indicated that a Senate run has not crossed his mind, as his announcement today seems to confirm. It appears that a Senate bid is not part of his current political plans.

It is worth noting that Dr. Carson has no prior political office experience, which may impact his chances of winning the 2016 nomination. However, several candidates have run for a U.S. Senate without prior government service and have been successful. Elizabeth Warren, for example, defeated incumbent Sen. Scott Brown (R-MA) just three years ago and is now considered a serious contender for the 2016 presidential race by progressive circles.

In conclusion, Dr. Ben Carson's decision to form an exploratory committee for a potential 2016 presidential run signals his intent to challenge the political establishment. While his lack of political experience may pose a challenge, history has shown that candidates without prior government service can still achieve political success.

Title: CNN Interview: Kellyanne Conway and Brianna Keilar Clash Over Trump's Remarks on Hillary Clinton and Paul Ryan

Article:

In a heated interview on CNN's The Situation Room, CNN host Brianna Keilar grilled Trump campaign manager Kellyanne Conway over the Republican presidential candidate's repeated statements about sending Hillary Clinton to "jail" if he becomes president.

During the nearly 30-minute interview on Wednesday, Conway attempted to downplay Trump's comments as a "quip," but the candidate's remarks at a Florida rally on Wednesday seemed to contradict that assertion. "She has to go to jail!" Trump declared to cheers from his supporters.

When confronted by Keilar about those remarks, Conway again repeated her "quip" line before quickly pivoting to an attack on Clinton for "imperiling our national security." As Keilar continued to press Conway to explain why Trump insists on talking about "jailing your political opponent," the campaign manager stopped her.

"You're taking it literally," Conway said. "You're stuck on this one thing."

"I'm talking about what your candidate is saying, which is more important than what you are saying about this," Keilar responded. "He is saying she has to go to jail. He is not talking about she has to stand and be judged. He is saying she has to go to jail."

Conway attempted to use her rhetorical gymnastics to escape the question, listing off some of things Clinton has said about Trump, but Keilar kept hammering her. "He is saying, if he were president, she would be in jail," the host said.

Later in the interview, Keilar also did not let Conway get away with denying that Trump has been "attacking" House Speaker Paul Ryan after the Republican leader said he would no longer defend the candidate. "Come on, Kellyanne, he tweeted repeatedly. He called him weak and ineffective. So I mean, you want to give him credit for not attacking him at one rally?" she asked. "Is he done attacking the House Speaker then?"

As the interview progressed, Conway resorted to attacking CNN for ignoring the "substance" of Trump's campaign. "You're doing a disservice to the American people by not telling them exactly everything, fully and fairly, of what one of the presidential candidates actually the only one who goes out and talks to voters on a daily basis about issues," she said.

Miraculously, despite the tension and animosity between the two women, Conway stuck around during a commercial break, something she may have regretted when Keilar opened the next segment with accusations from a former Miss Arizona who accused Trump of walking in on her changing backstage before one of his pageants, something Trump himself bragged about doing on The Howard Stern Show.

"I can't comment on what she is saying because I am not her and I was not in the pageant or any other pageant," Conway said. Like Trump, she tried to shift the conversation to Bill Clinton.

"The fact is that all you want to do, it seems, is talk about something he said ten, 15 years ago and, yet, we never ever want to talk, particularly CNN, where we offered up these women to you," Conway said, referring to the pre-debate press conference Trump held, flanked by women who had accused the former president of sexual assault and harassment. "We never want to talk to the women shamed and blamed by Hillary Clinton because they had sexual contact with her husband."

"Maybe you want to ask me who it is I see day by day, this intelligent, clever, gracious, gentleman, frankly, whose family is making a huge sacrifice to run for president," Conway said, entering full-on rant mode. "Nobody wants to talk about that. You want me to comment on something he said to Howard Stern in 15 seconds ten years ago and somehow I am an expert on it. I want to see the CNN poll that shows Americans want to focus on that, I truly do."

As Conway urged more serious discussion about issues facing Americans, Keilar pushed back. "When does Donald Trump stop saying things like Hillary Clinton has to go to jail? He brings these things up himself," she said. "You're saying this should be discussed. Why doesn't he make a pivot? Why doesn't he talk more seriously as a candidate about the issues and not upstage himself?"

Conway's stated desire to focus on issues that Americans care about as opposed to decades-old comments and behavior flies directly in the face of a new report from Bloomberg Businessweek that says the Trump campaign will go all in on accusations made by women against Bill Clinton. That plan, spearheaded by campaign CEO Steve Bannon and others, aims not only to distract from Trump's own apparent history of sexual misconduct but also to depress the vote of millennial women. "We’re going to turn him into Bill Cosby," Bannon reportedly told Trump staffers.
