By the end of the CNN interview, they had reached an impasse, and all Keilar could do was thank Conway for being "generous" with her time. "Nice to be here," Conway replied, though it was unclear whether there was any more truth to that than to her insistence that Trump doesn't really want to jail his opponent.

Title: Attorney General Loretta Lynch Faces Challenges in Improving Police-Community Relations Amid Baltimore Riots

Article:

The confirmation of Loretta Lynch as the 83rd Attorney General of the United States was delayed for an unprecedented 167 days, sparking speculation that Time, the inexorable force governing our universe, may hold a grudge against her. The delay was initiated by the Senate, but the subsequent riots in Baltimore have raised questions about the timeliness of Lynch's stated goal of improving police morale.

The unrest in Baltimore, which paralyzed the city this weekend, has been linked to the death of Freddie Gray, a 25-year-old African-American man who sustained a broken neck while in police custody. The circumstances surrounding Gray's death remain unclear, with reports suggesting he may have been beaten during transport, but an autopsy showing no other injuries. The Baltimore Police Department (BPD) has admitted to failing to provide Gray with necessary medical care, but the cause of his injuries remains undetermined.

The BPD's history of lawless violence has been identified as the catalyst for the riots. The widespread practice of giving "a rough ride" is a leading suspect in Gray's case, but the exact cause remains unknown. The fact that such incidents can occur and only become major stories after activism from peaceful protesters and the destructive actions of violent rioters is a concern.

The BPD's reputation, with many Baltimore residents hearing Gray's story with weary outrage rather than shock or indignation, is a significant issue. The fact that the BPD rank-and-file feels comfortable with extralegal brutality and are accustomed to wielding it, demands accountability, and leaves them panicking, is a problem.

Attorney General Lynch's interest in finding common ground between law enforcement and minority communities has been noted, but the current situation in Baltimore and similar cities may require more than dialogue. What is needed instead are actions demonstrating a commitment to addressing police brutality, ending police militarization, and ensuring accountability for officers involved in such incidents.

The authorities in Baltimore, Maryland, and D.C. must stop pandering to police unions and instead take fears of the rise of the "warrior cop" seriously. The deaths of individuals like Freddie Gray should not be seen as "tragic" but as crimes. Suspending officers involved in such incidents is not enough; Lynch must make clear that she understands this and that her predecessor's groundbreaking report on Ferguson, Missouri, was no aberration.

What is needed, in short, is for the people most apt to use "the language of the unheard" to feel that someone who matters is finally listening. And that those in public office prove with actions that they believe an African-American life is worth no less than a cop's. Now is not the time for Lynch to focus on making law enforcement happy. Now is the time for her to promote equal justice. Improving police morale can wait.

Title: Grassroots Activists Express Disappointment with Republican Handling of Obamacare Repeal

Article:

Jenny Beth Martin, president and co-founder of the Tea Party Patriots, has stated that the group's email blasts against the Affordable Care Act, also known as Obamacare, still receive hundreds of responses from activists who are angry about it. The group made over 100,000 phone calls in a 48-hour period when the House was voting on its bill in early May to repeal and replace the healthcare law.

However, Martin clarified that the group is not yet in support of what the Senate is doing regarding the repeal. Grassroots activists, such as Pat Daugherty, who once marched on Washington against Obamacare, now express similar levels of frustration with Republicans in Congress as they did during the early days of the Tea Party movement.

Daugherty, a retired university administrator in Athens, Ga., stated, "Every Republican in Congress ran on repealing Obamacare." She questioned why it is now difficult for Republicans to repeal Obamacare when they are in the majority. Daugherty added, "I know a lot of conservatives who are more upset with Republicans than with Democrats."

David Zupan, who organized Tea Party groups in Ohio against the Affordable Care Act, attributed the law to rising healthcare costs and the closure of his technology support business. Before the law, he paid $910 per month to insure himself and his wife with a $750 annual deductible. When he renewed his policy last year, he said, the rates had increased to $2,845 per month with a $3,500 deductible.

Zupan had hoped to confront Senator Rob Portman to demand a full repeal, but he gave up after being unable to locate Portman during the recess. Portman has expressed concern that the Senate bill would roll back Medicaid too far, particularly jeopardizing treatment for opioid addiction.

Zupan expressed his dissatisfaction with the current state of the bill, stating, "Nothing they're going to do to this bill is going to make it better."

Title: Whistleblower's Democratic Ties and Potential Bias Alleged in Ukraine Scandal

Article:

The Republican National Committee's Rapid Response Director, Steve Guest, has accused the mainstream media of disregarding evidence suggesting that the whistleblower who sparked the House investigation into President Donald Trump's phone conversation about U.S. aid to Ukraine is a Democratic operative. Guest stated, "The silence is deafening," in an interview on Thursday.

According to Guest, the whistleblower has a professional tie to a 2020 Democratic candidate, coordinated and took guidance from House Intelligence Committee Chairman Adam Schiff's staff. Schiff, in turn, allegedly lied about this and his staff recommended attorneys for the whistleblower.

Furthermore, Guest claims that the whistleblower's lawyers have worked for former Director of National Intelligence James Clapper, former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton, Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer, and donated to Joe Biden's presidential campaign. One of the whistleblower's attorneys is also reportedly a member of the #Resistance, an anti-Trump movement.

However, the Washington Examiner reported on August 26 that Inspector General Michael Atkinson, in a letter to the whistleblower, acknowledged some indicia of an arguable political bias in favor of a rival political candidate. The Examiner also reported that the whistleblower had a significant tie to one of the Democratic presidential candidates.

Lawyers for the whistleblower, Mark Zaid and Andrew Bakaj, have denied these allegations of bias. They stated that their client has never worked for or advised a political candidate, campaign, or party. They also clarified that their client has come into contact with presidential candidates from both parties in their roles as elected officials, not as candidates.

Mark Zaid, a lawyer for the whistleblower, has a history of anti-Trump sentiment. In a podcast last year, he stated, "I'm not a Trump fan. I go out of my way on Twitter to say '#Resistance.' It's not a resistance against the GOP or a Republican -- I do not think [Trump] is a Republican, quite frankly."

Meanwhile, House Intelligence Committee Chairman Adam Schiff is facing criticism over a September meeting his staff apparently had with the whistleblower. When Schiff was questioned about this meeting in September, he stated that his committee had not spoken directly with the whistleblower. However, The New York Times reported that a House Intelligence Committee aide did have contact with the whistleblower, contact that Trump has argued was illegal.

The GOP's Guest also told the media that he believes the Democrats' impeachment push is a coordinated political smear reminiscent of the Russia hoax and the phony Brett Kavanaugh allegations.

Title: Obama Campaign Strategy Shifts Focus to Non-Issues During Debates, Diverting Attention from Economic Concerns

Article:

The Obama campaign's post-debate strategy has been criticized for focusing on trivial matters rather than addressing significant economic issues. During the first presidential debate, Governor Mitt Romney's comments on government spending sparked a response from the Obama campaign that focused on the cuts to public broadcasting, specifically Big Bird, rather than addressing the economic issues raised.

At the second debate, Romney's use of the term "binders full of women" to describe his efforts to hire qualified senior-level women was met with criticism from the Obama team, who accused him of waging a "war on women." However, it was later acknowledged that Romney had hired numerous senior-level women and promoted women as executives during his tenure as governor.

During the foreign-policy debate, Romney's comment about the Navy having fewer ships than at any time since 1917 was met with Obama's response, "Well, governor, we also have fewer horses and bayonets." The Obama campaign later bought the search term "bayonets" on Twitter, and the media declared the line as one that would "live forever."

The debates have been criticized for the Obama campaign's strategy of capitalizing on small issues to divert attention away from major problems such as the economy, deficit, and entitlement spending. The Obama administration's barrage of attack ads on Romney's wealth, involvement with Bain, and shipping jobs overseas has been met with criticism for focusing on personal matters rather than addressing economic issues.

Romney capitalized on the enthusiasm gap for Obama's economic policies by offering a five-point plan that would create 12 million new jobs. He positioned himself as the man with the plan, offering solutions for the middle class, and highlighted Obama's record by citing statistics on the mounting federal debt, the decline in household incomes, a growing entitlement state, and soaring gas prices.

As the election nears, it remains to be seen whether Obama's reelection strategy of diverging from four years of hostility to job creators will be successful. The next generation deserves a serious discussion of serious issues rather than political efforts to trivialize them.

Title: Hillary Clinton Leads Donald Trump by 13 Points in New Poll, According to CNN/ORC Survey

Article:

A new poll released by CNN/ORC on Wednesday indicates that former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton leads presumptive Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump by 13 points in a head-to-head match-up. The poll, conducted from April 28 to May 1, shows Clinton leading Trump by 54 percent to 41 percent.

The polling was concluded before Sen. Ted Cruz of Texas announced on Tuesday that he was suspending his campaign, which led Republican National Committee Chairman Reince Priebus to declare that Trump will be the presumptive GOP nominee. Trump's significant win in Indiana on Tuesday effectively knocked Cruz out of the race.

Sen. Bernie Sanders of Vermont defeated Clinton in Indiana, but Clinton remains the favorite to clinch the Democratic nomination. The poll found that 56 percent of voters have an unfavorable view of Trump, compared to 41 percent who reported a favorable view. Clinton had an even 49 percent/49 percent favorable/unfavorable split.

Voters said Clinton would better handle climate change, foreign policy, education, health care, the income gap between rich and poor, immigration, and terrorism, while they gave Trump the edge on the economy. In the survey, more than half of both Clinton voters and Trump voters said their vote was more about opposition to the other candidate than support for their preferred candidate.

Clinton led Mr. Cruz by 10 points, 52 percent to 42 percent, and Sanders beat him by 18 points, 57 percent to 39 percent. Ohio Gov. John Kasich, who is still in the GOP race, led Clinton head-to-head by 7 points, 51 percent to 44 percent. Sanders outperformed Clinton in head-to-head match-ups against the two remaining Republicans. The Vermont senator led Trump by 16 points, 56 percent to 40 percent, and he led Kasich by 4 points, 50 percent to 46 percent.

Mr. Sanders had a 61 percent/33 percent favorable/unfavorable split among voters, and Mr. Kasich had a 54 percent/29 percent split. Mr. Cruz's overall favorability, meanwhile, was worse than Trump's. The Texas senator had a 37 percent/56 percent favorable/unfavorable split.

Title: Johnson's Conservative Victory: A Shift Towards Fiscal Liberalism in the UK

Article:

Britain's Prime Minister Boris Johnson and Labour Party leader Jeremy Corbyn participated in a head-to-head debate on the BBC in London on December 6, 2019. The election results, with Johnson's Conservative Party securing a majority, are seen as a guarantee for Brexit, but the victory is not a triumph for traditional conservatism.

The sources of Boris Johnson's colossal victory are multiple: some voters turned away from Corbyn's anti-Semitism and hard-left economics, while others sought to complete Brexit and move forward. Despite these powerful factors and Johnson's personal appeal, he felt it necessary to add another element to secure the outright majority: a spending blowout.

Johnson campaigned against the Conservative party's alleged post-financial-crisis "austerity" policies and promised new spending. He did not make a case for the private sector's growth, instead painting a picture of growth and economic security derived from government spending. The Left denounced him as an apostle of austerity, but it didn't work. Johnson successfully convinced the voters that if they allowed him to pull Brexit across the finish line, he would restore left-of-center economics.

Though Johnson proved more formidable than Theresa May in fighting for Brexit, he has continued with her disturbing policy of conceding the premises of liberal economics. He has implemented a moratorium on fracking, accepted left-wing scaremongering about earthquakes linked to the process, and promised significant increases in spending on infrastructure, schools, the minimum wage, teacher salaries, and the National Health Service, among other areas. He also promised not to raise taxes and to decrease the budget deficit.

Some of Johnson's fiscal liberalism is linked to social conservatism, with promises of longer jail sentences for violent criminals, 20,000 additional cops, fewer limits on searching suspects, and limits on immigration through an Australian-style points system. Bringing home Brexit would be the signature social-conservative achievement of the British century and make Johnson's premiership one of the most consequential in history.

In order to win his majority, Johnson had to vigorously contest seats in traditional Labour constituencies whose distaste for the Tory party is deeply ingrained. Free-spending promises may have been the only way to win those voters over and guarantee five years of Conservative government and achieve Brexit. However, the cost of this victory is a significant shift towards a more left-leaning economic platform, abandoning a core conservative principle. The parameters of British economics have taken a large step to the left. If a nominally conservative party lacks the courage or the communications skills to sell conservative economics when it can boast of having reduced unemployment to a 44-year-low and when its opponent promises to implement unreconstructed socialism, it bodes ill for those on either side of the Atlantic who wonder whether any party will ever even gesture in the direction of sane fiscal policy again.

Title: U.S. Economy Adds 162,000 Jobs in July, Unemployment Rate Drops to 7.4%

Article:

The U.S. economy added 162,000 jobs in July, according to a report by federal economists, while the unemployment rate edged down from 7.6% to 7.4%. The jobs count, which narrowly missed analyst expectations, follows Wednesday's dour news that the economy grew by only 1.7% in the second quarter. Federal economists also reduced their estimate for first-quarter growth down to 1.1%.

The 7.4% unemployment rate is the lowest of President Barack Obama's presidency, as the rate dipped to its lowest level since December of 2008. The unemployment rate is based on a separate survey—one that relies on data from a survey of households—than from the jobs number, which is calculated via a survey of employers' payrolls. The household survey, which has a larger margin for error than the payroll count, estimated 227,000 more people were employed in July than in the month before.

However, the falling unemployment rate is due to both positive and negative news. While more people found jobs, 37,000 people left the labor force in July, contributing to the rate's decline.

"The report, like many of late, contains good news and less good news," said Jared Bernstein, a senior fellow at the Center for Budget and Policy Priorities and a former economic adviser to Vice President Joe Biden, in a post on his website. "Most of the decline in unemployment was due to more people getting jobs, but part of it was due to a slight fall off in the labor force, a signal of not-too-strong labor demand."

The stubbornly slow job growth left 11.5 million people unemployed, with another 8.2 million part-time employees unsuccessfully looking to add more hours to their work week. Among the unemployed, 4.2 million have been unsuccessfully seeking work for 6 months or more.

In the past year, the unemployment rate has fallen 0.8% with the count of officially unemployed persons falling by 1.2 million.

At this point, the job reports are used as little more than talking points in the fiscal debate between the White House and Republicans, but they are a key indicator for the Federal Reserve as it weighs when it will begin to scale back its efforts to stimulate the stalled economy.

Fed Chairman Ben Bernanke has said the central bank is watching for signs that it should scale back a series of monthly multi-billion dollar asset purchases that are aimed at driving down long-term interest rates and sparking new growth.

Paul Ashworth, chief U.S. economist for Capital Economics, predicted Friday that the report will push the Fed to ramp down its efforts when the bank's policy committee next convenes in September.

While it may not spur action in Congress, the employment report and GDP data jointly add further urgency to the newly reinvigorated economic debate between President Barack Obama and congressional Republicans.

Title: Vice President Pence Reaffirms U.S. Commitment to NATO, Baltic Allies amid Tensions with Russia

Article:

Vice President Mike Pence, during a visit to Estonia, pledged the Trump administration's support for NATO's Baltic members in the face of perceived threats and intimidation from Russia. In a speech, Pence reiterated the U.S. commitment to the defense pact and its solidarity with the Baltic states.

"At this very moment, Russia continues to seek to redraw international borders by force, undermine the democracies of sovereign nations, and divide the free nations of Europe one against another," Pence said after meeting with the presidents of Estonia, Latvia, and Lithuania.

Pence's visit coincided with mounting tensions between the U.S. and Russia, with Russian President Vladimir Putin expelling 755 U.S. diplomats in retaliation for new sanctions legislation that the U.S. Congress passed and President Trump is expected to sign. The legislation codifies financial and diplomatic sanctions on Russia for its annexation of Crimea and meddling in the U.S. presidential election.

Pence's message reinforced President Trump's support of NATO's Article 5, which pledges mutual defense for all member nations and is the heart of the alliance. Pence also met with NATO troops from Britain, France, and the U.S. that are stationed in Estonia, as part of the alliance's deployment of approximately 4,000 troops and military hardware in the Baltic states and Poland to counter Russia's buildup in the region.

The former Soviet states of Estonia, Latvia, and Lithuania became NATO members in 2004, part of a NATO expansion into Eastern Europe that alarmed Russia. Pence emphasized the importance of a strong and united NATO, stating, "We stand together, here and across the world, because we know that a strong and united NATO is more necessary today than at any point since the collapse of communism a quarter-century ago, and no threat looms larger in the Baltic states than the specter of aggression from your unpredictable neighbor to the east."

Pence's European tour also includes stops in Georgia and Montenegro, two other countries facing strong pressure from Russia.

Title: Trump's First Week with Republicans in Congress: A Test of Unlikely Partnership

Article:

In the first week of President Donald Trump's term, the relationship between the new president and Republicans in Congress can be likened to a shotgun marriage, an unlikely alliance formed by circumstances, as they navigate their way through a potentially challenging partnership.

During a speech before House and Senate Republicans at their retreat in Philadelphia on Thursday, President Trump showcased his characteristic bravado, boasting about his electoral victory in the state, listing his "record" number of executive orders, and outlining an ambitious 200-day legislative agenda. The agenda includes repealing and replacing the Affordable Care Act, tax reform, regulatory rollback, addressing the debt ceiling, funding the border wall, and, at the president's insistence, infrastructure.

The ambitious agenda, especially for an institution designed to be slow and deliberative, poses a significant challenge. This is not Trump's style, and his impatience and tweeting reflexes could add friction to the GOP's efforts to push their legislative priorities through Congress.

The ambition is not unprecedented. Democratic President Lyndon B. Johnson, a Senate veteran, had a "massive agenda" in the 1960s, including civil rights laws and his antipoverty program. However, Johnson was skilled in dealing with Congress, while Trump is not, according to James Pitney, a congressional expert at Claremont McKenna College in Claremont, California.

"[Trump] has all of LBJ's ego, without any of LBJ's legislative skill," says Prof. Pitney. Johnson "knew the mechanics. He knew the personalities. Trump does not."

Republicans plan to use a special budget process to pass their top priorities, Obamacare repeal and tax reform, by majority vote and without Democratic support. However, the issues are complex, and views differ among Republicans about how best to address them. For instance, GOP lawmakers cannot agree on whether to repeal taxes that support Obamacare or keep them in place during a transition period.

At a joint press conference with Speaker Paul Ryan on Thursday, Senator Mitch McConnell was confident that they would accomplish their top priorities, but acknowledged the challenges ahead, such as confirming Trump's cabinet appointees and the upcoming Supreme Court nomination.

The president's business acumen does not translate well to Congress, according to John Feehery, former spokesman for Dennis Hastert, the longest-serving Republican speaker of the House. "They go in, they give money, they don't get what they want, they get frustrated," he said, referring to Trump. "He's on a steep learning curve."

In another surprise, The New York Times reported that the Trump administration was considering reopening "black site" prisons and undoing restrictions on interrogations. Lawmakers quickly distanced themselves from such a move, stating there would be no return to torture. The White House denied the Times story, saying the leak was an old memo from the transition period.

Despite the challenges, Republicans are determined to prove their ability to govern effectively. "This Congress is going to be the busiest Congress we've had in decades, maybe ever," the president told his Republican colleagues. However, the slow nature of Congress and the complexities of the issues will require patience, according to seasoned politicians like Senator Jim Risch.

Title: Perry Accuses Clinton of Alienating Texas Voters over Voter ID Laws

Article:

In a recent interview on CNN's "State of the Union," former Texas Governor Rick Perry criticized Democratic presidential front-runner Hillary Clinton for her stance on voter ID laws, accusing her of alienating Texas voters. Perry's comments came in response to Clinton's speech last week, where she criticized voter ID laws, including those in Texas.

In 2011, Texas passed a strict voter identification law, which was upheld by the U.S. Supreme Court. In the interview, Perry argued that Clinton was "way outside the norm of ridiculous" in her call for easier voter ID laws, asserting that Texas already makes it easy for residents to vote.

Clinton, for the first time, called out Perry, along with three other Republican presidential hopefuls, in a speech in Texas on Thursday. She also criticized their support for voter ID laws and opposition to early voting. The next day, Perry, on Fox News, accused Clinton of "taking on" Texas voters for supporting the voter ID law.

Clinton's rapid-response team, Correct the Record, responded to Perry's criticisms on "State of the Union." Communications director Adrienne Watson wrote in an email that Perry and other Republicans are "trying to deny citizens this fundamental right [to vote] under the fictional specter of voter fraud." Watson also accused Perry of signing a law that was intentionally written to discriminate against minority voters.

In the same interview, Perry also defended the populist tone of his announcement speech, taking another shot at Wall Street banks. He stated, "I don't think it's right for Wall Street to be able to walk away from bad mistakes that the people on Main Street have to pay for." Perry added that if that was considered populism, he was proud to be a populist on that issue.

Asked later on CBS' "Face the Nation" about what he'd do to prevent reckless Wall Street behavior, Perry said, "regulate them," though he added that he believed the Dodd-Frank regulatory reforms signed by President Barack Obama went too far and were harming community banks.

Perry launched his second straight presidential campaign on Thursday with an upbeat, muscular speech in an airplane hangar outside Addison, Texas. He also made an appearance at Iowa Sen. Joni Ernst's "Roast and Ride" event, where Perry rode a motorcycle and addressed the crowd in blue jeans and a baseball cap.

On Thursday, influential conservative activist Sam Clovis signed on to head Perry's Iowa operation, a significant boost for the former governor, who beat out Texas Sen. Ted Cruz and other conservative GOP hopefuls for his services.

Title: American Public's War Skepticism and North Korea: A Closer Look at Recent Polls and U.S. Policy

Article:

A new poll by the Chicago Council of Foreign Affairs (CCFA) reveals that 75 percent of Americans view North Korea as a critical threat to the United States, a significant increase from 55 percent two years ago. This heightened sense of threat does not seem to be affected by President Donald Trump's historically low approval ratings, currently standing at 38 percent.

The poll also indicates that 62 percent of respondents express a decrease in their confidence in Trump's ability as president, and 61 percent express unease about his ability to thwart North Korea. These numbers are unlikely to improve, as Trump responded to North Korea's regular threats with one of his own this afternoon.

In response to North Korea's threats, Trump stated, "North Korea best not make any more threats to the United States. They will be met with the fire and the fury like the world has never seen." Meanwhile, the CCFA poll finds broad bipartisan support for increased sanctions against North Korea, with 76 percent of Americans favoring increased sanctions, despite their limited effectiveness over the last decade-plus.

Reports suggest that North Korea has successfully "miniaturized" a nuclear warhead for missile delivery, overshadowing progress on the diplomatic front. North Korean missile tests are followed by successful U.S. missile defense tests. The CCFA poll found a majority of Americans supporting military action if North Korea attacked South Korea, and large majorities think North Korea should not be allowed to keep its nuclear weapons.

North Korea is unlikely to accept any arrangement where it cannot keep at least some of its weapons. The U.S. has taught the world some lessons about this in recent decades, and Pyongyang has been paying attention. The U.S. invaded Iraq in 2003, but no weapons of mass destruction (WMDs) were found. The Iraq war did have a knock-on effect on proliferation, as Libyan dictator Moammar Qaddafi indicated an interest in voluntarily relinquishing his WMDs and WMD programs.

The message changed dramatically when the U.S. helped depose Qaddafi in 2011. Libya's post-disarmament experience made a powerful impression on any regime that may have been entertaining the idea of avoiding American military action by disarming. Indeed, it created a strong incentive to acquire WMDs and maintain a formidable military force as a deterrent against U.S. aggression.

For all the hype about the North Korean regime, Pyongyang has been a relatively rational actor. For decades, the regime has adeptly manipulated various regional powers and the U.S., allowing it to survive even as communism collapsed nearly everywhere else. The U.S., by contrast, has survived despite often acting in a less than rational fashion. The ocean buffer that sandwiches America has given us space to do that, as has our massive military superiority.

Trump ran on a platform of questioning America's security commitments around the world. While he has since embraced much of America's role as world policemen, other countries remain understandably skeptical. This has led South Korea and even Japan to consider developing their own nuclear arsenals—a development that, counterintuitively, could go a long way in improving the prospects of peace in the region. American opinion, meanwhile, is working against peace. Coupled with Trump's sinking approval ratings, the relatively widespread approval of a more aggressive approach in Korea could prompt Trump to drop any attempts at negotiation. Diplomacy is easy to mock, after all. War comes with a rally-'round-the-flag effect. This post was updated to include new comments by President Trump.

Title: Trump Administration Proposes Changes to Obamacare, Insurers Caution on Impact

Article:

The Trump administration has proposed changes to the Affordable Care Act (Obamacare), with the final rules expected to be published in the Federal Register on Friday, allowing public comment until March 7. The proposed changes are seen as "important first steps to rescue a collapsing Obamacare individual market" by Senator Lamar Alexander, the Republican chairman of the Senate health committee.

However, insurers have expressed caution, stating that the proposed changes, while helpful, would not provide a solution if the Republican-led Congress introduces legislation to repeal major provisions of the Affordable Care Act. The tighter restrictions on special enrollment periods could potentially cause problems for cancer patients, according to Christopher W. Hansen, the president of the advocacy arm of the American Cancer Society.

The Internal Revenue Service (IRS) is also making changes that could weaken incentives for people to obtain insurance. The IRS has stated it will accept and process tax returns even if taxpayers fail to indicate whether they have coverage, qualify for an exemption, or are paying the penalty for going without insurance. The individual mandate, requiring most Americans to have insurance, is still in force until changed by Congress, according to the IRS.

The proposed changes also allow states to determine whether insurance plans have enough doctors, hospitals, and other healthcare providers to serve patients. This is intended to attract more insurers into the market. Insurers could also refuse to provide new coverage to consumers who failed to pay premiums owed in the previous year. If an insurer terminates coverage for non-payment of premiums, it could require consumers to pay all past-due premiums owed to that insurer before restarting coverage.

Lastly, insurers would be allowed to sell health plans covering a smaller share of expected costs. The administration claims this would provide consumers with "more coverage options," but acknowledges that some consumers could see increases in their deductibles and other out-of-pocket costs. The exact impact of these changes remains to be seen, as the final rules are yet to be issued.

Title: New Poll Shows Preference for Republican-Led Congress Among Likely Voters in Upcoming Midterms

Article:

A new poll conducted by The Wall Street Journal, NBC News, and Annenberg from October 10-16 has found that a majority of likely voters prefer a Republican-led Congress in the upcoming November 4 midterm elections. The survey polled 1,172 voters and found that 49 percent of likely voters prefer a Republican-controlled Congress, compared to 44 percent who would prefer a Democratic-controlled Congress.

The poll also showed that Republicans have an advantage among all registered voters, with 45 percent preferring a Republican-led Congress, compared to 43 percent who prefer a Democratic-led Congress. This is the first time in five weeks that the GOP came out ahead, according to The Wall Street Journal.

The findings appear to reinforce polling results from last week that showed that Democrats are less interested in the election than Republicans. The survey found that among those most interested in the election, 51 percent favored the Republicans, compared to 44 percent for Democrats. Lower-interest voters support the Democrats by 52 percent, compared to 37 percent.

The survey comes as pundits continue to predict that the Republicans have the best chance of taking control of the Senate. Last week, Larry Sabato, director of the University of Virginia's Center for Politics, projected that the GOP could take up to eight seats. "Our projection remains a five- to eight-seat Republican gain in the Senate, and with less than three weeks to go, we would much rather be holding the cards Republicans have been dealt versus the ones dealt to the Democrats as both sides play for a Senate majority," Sabato said in his "Crystal Ball" analysis.

The Washington Post also predicted last week that Republicans will take control of the upper chamber, and explained its analysis by looking at the most competitive races. As of Sunday, The New York Times election model gives Republicans a 69 percent chance of winning the Senate.

President Barack Obama's low approval ratings are believed to be a major factor dragging down the Democrats' chances. His support among women, in particular, has dropped sharply in battleground states where Democrats are already lagging among male voters.

Title: Trump's Response to Mueller Report: Changing the Subject Amidst Calls for Accountability

Article:

In the aftermath of the release of the Mueller report, President Donald Trump has been accused of changing the subject to divert attention from the investigation's findings. Instead of moving into a new phase of his presidency, as some suggest, the report's publication has allegedly led Trump to revert to his familiar pattern of response to scandals.

The pattern, according to the article, consists of three phases. First, the president lies about the facts of the matter to create uncertainty and inoculate his base and a portion of the population against accepting the reality of the situation. Second, he attacks his antagonists. Third, he attempts to change the subject.

In the case of the Mueller report, the article claims, Trump and his surrogates have asserted that the president was completely exonerated, despite Mueller not making such a judgment. They have also accused the media and Democrats of conspiring to bring down the president.

Since the release of the report, the article states, Trump has attempted to change the topic in two ways: by focusing on healthcare and immigration. In healthcare, the Trump administration has advocated for the Affordable Care Act (Obamacare) to be declared unconstitutional, potentially stripping healthcare benefits from tens of millions of Americans with no plan for alternative coverage. In immigration, Trump has increased his anti-immigrant rhetoric and threatened to close the U.S.-Mexico border, a move that would harm millions of Americans and undermine cooperation with Mexico in handling the migrant crisis.

The article argues that these self-destructive measures demonstrate that what Trump is really after is headlines, not solutions. It suggests that Democrats should stay focused on obtaining a full copy of the Mueller report and making its contents known to the public, rather than going along with Trump's wishes.

The article also emphasizes the importance of establishing the principle that America has a president, not a king, and that the president is bound by the rule of law. It argues that the investigation is not about relitigating the 2016 election, but about restoring accountability to American public life, finding out how American national security was compromised in 2016, and restoring faith in American government among the public.

The article concludes by suggesting that Trump's reluctance to release the report may be due to the need to maintain control of the narrative and avoid accountability for his actions. Democrats, the article argues, should not let Trump change the subject.

Title: Unlikely Republican Support for Pelosi's Speaker Bid Amidst Democratic Opposition

Article:

As Democratic House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi faces a challenging climb to secure the necessary support from her own party to reclaim the Speaker's gavel in January, she is receiving an unexpected source of support: Republicans.

Pelosi, who previously held the Speaker position between 2007 and 2011, the last time Democrats held the majority in the House, is facing a growing rebellion from her own members. A number of Democrats have signed a letter pledging not to support her for Speaker on the House floor. Fox News confirmed on Thursday that at least 17 House Democrats, including incumbents and incoming members, have signed onto a document stating they will not support Pelosi for Speaker. A Democrat familiar with the effort says they are trying to add more names before the letter is publicly released.

If all those Democrats vote against Pelosi on the floor, Pelosi would not have the votes for Speaker. To secure the gavel, Pelosi will first need to garner a majority of the Democratic caucus in internal leadership elections, then go on to win an absolute majority of the House.

A group of Republicans is floating the idea of offering Pelosi support in the House, thinking it could benefit them in the long term. President Trump tweeted after the midterms that if Pelosi struggled, "perhaps we will add some Republican votes." However, it was not clear if this remark was serious or tongue-in-cheek.

Republican Tom Reed suggested on Thursday that if Pelosi embraced a bipartisan package of rules reforms that would make it easier for members to get legislation to the floor, he could support her. "A Democratic candidate who embraces these rules reforms, I will stand with," he told CNN. "I am so frustrated with this institution being a top-down driven organization...it is time to change this, and if Nancy Pelosi is the only one that's there, I'm open to it."

Reed conceded that there would be "significant backlash" from other Republicans, but other Republicans have also suggested backing her bid—as it could help them in the long term.

Republican strategist Chris Wilson suggested on "Fox and Friends" on Friday that Republicans should back Pelosi. "Republicans are not going to have a speaker of the House. So why not try and...put her back in that chair?" he asked.

Pelosi, at a press conference on Thursday, dismissed the idea that she would need Republican help to win the gavel. "I intend to win the speakership with Democratic votes," she later said, adding that she had "overwhelming support" in her caucus.

In 2016, Pelosi fended off a leadership challenge from Rep. Tim Ryan, D-Ohio. During a recent appearance on Fox News' "Cavuto," Ryan said, "I don't think this is a done deal yet" in terms of Pelosi becoming Speaker again. Ryan also said he "hopes somebody does" challenge Pelosi.

On Friday, Pelosi met for 45 minutes with Rep. Marcia Fudge, D-Ohio, who is mulling a prospective leadership challenge. Other Democrats have been more supportive, with House Progressive Caucus Chairwoman Pramila Jayapal, D-Wash., telling Fox News on Friday that "she has the experience."

"She's someone who gets things done. We don't need someone with a learning curve," Jayapal said, adding that "we need to deliver some real wins pretty quickly."

Title: Justice Department Refers Criminal Investigation into Former FBI Deputy Director Andrew McCabe

Article:

The Justice Department's inspector general has referred the findings of its report on former FBI Deputy Director Andrew McCabe to federal prosecutors in Washington for potential criminal investigation. The Washington Post reports that the referral to the D.C. U.S. Attorney's Office occurred after the inspector general concluded McCabe had lied to investigators or his own boss, then-FBI Director James B. Comey, on four occasions, three of them under oath.

The referral does not guarantee that McCabe will be charged with a crime. Michael R. Bromwich, McCabe's lawyer, stated in a statement that they were advised of the referral within the past few weeks. Bromwich added, "We are confident that, unless there is inappropriate pressure from high levels of the Administration, the U.S. Attorney's Office will conclude that it should decline to prosecute."

The inspector general's report, which Attorney General Jeff Sessions used as the basis for firing McCabe last month, was leaked almost as soon as it was completed. Similarly, news of McCabe's criminal referral was also leaked on Thursday, though the referral was made weeks ago or even longer.

The inspector general's report specifically charged that McCabe "lacked candor" with internal investigators at the agency and concluded he was not authorized to disclose to reporters the existence of an investigation into the Clinton Foundation.

Former FBI Assistant Director Frank Figliuzzi, on MSNBC Thursday, called the criminal referral on such a matter "unprecedented." Figliuzzi stated, "If this is indeed true, that the charge that's being referred or recommended is for a 'lack of candor' during an internal inquiry, I can not recall that ever happening in my 25-year FBI career." Figliuzzi added that approving an unauthorized leak could rise to the level of criminal referral.

Title: Melania Trump's Speech at the Republican National Convention Alleged to Contain Plagiarized Passages from Michelle Obama

Article:

Melania Trump's speech at the opening night of the Republican National Convention has been accused of plagiarizing passages from Michelle Obama's address to the 2008 Democratic National Convention. A section of Trump's speech, focusing on the values she and her husband share, appears to be a direct copy of Obama's comments on the same subject eight years ago.

The controversy marked a chaotic start to the Republican National Convention. The day began with Trump's campaign attacking popular Ohio Governor and former presidential challenger John Kasich for not attending the convention in Cleveland. By the afternoon, conspiracy theorist Alex Jones was rallying people outside, only to be interrupted by a popular comedian asking the fringe radio host to "have sex with my wife."

Later in the day, a fight erupted on the convention floor, with anti-Trump delegates demanding a roll call vote before the RNC got underway. At another point, Rep. Steve King was on MSNBC suggesting white people are superior to any "sub-groups." By the evening, speaker after speaker recalled in detail the attacks on the U.S. compound in Benghazi.

Melania took the stage and, almost line-for-line, repeated passages that Michelle Obama had spoken in 2008. Here are the similarities:

"From a young age, my parents impressed on me the values that you work hard for what you want in life, that your word is your bond and you do what you say and keep your promise; that you treat people with respect," Melania said. "They taught and showed me values and morals in their daily life. That is a lesson that I continue to pass along to our son, and we need to pass those lessons on to the many generations to follow because we want our children in this nation to know that the only limit to your achievements is the strength of your dreams and your willingness to work for them."

"Barack and I were raised with so many of the same values: that you work hard for what you want in life; that your word is your bond and you do what you say you’re going to do; that you treat people with dignity and respect, even if you do not know them, and even if you do not agree with them. And Barack and I set out to build lives guided by these values, and pass them on to the next generation. Because we want our children—and all children in this nation—to know that the only limit to the height of your achievements is the reach of your dreams and your willingness to work for them," Michelle Obama said.

Before the convention, Team Trump told CNN that Melania spent five to six weeks working on the speech. She told Matt Lauer on Monday afternoon that she had "as little help as possible" writing it.

The Trump campaign did not acknowledge the plagiarism allegation when it first surfaced. "In writing her beautiful speech, Melania’s team of writers took notes on her life’s inspirations, and in some instances included fragments that reflected her own thinking," spokesman Jason Miller said in a statement late Monday. "Melania’s immigrant experience and love for America shone through in her speech, which made it such a success."

By 1:30 a.m., the campaign finally addressed the plagiarism, and attacked Hillary Clinton. "This is once again an example of when a woman threatens Hillary Clinton, she’ll... take her down," campaign manager Paul Manafort told CNN. "It’s not going to work."

By 7:30 a.m., Chris Christie offered a more qualified defense of Melania's speech when the Today show asked him if it was plagiarism. "Not when 93 percent of the speech is completely different than Michelle Obama’s speech," he said. "They expressed some common thoughts."

The idea that any Republican would share "common thoughts" with Michelle Obama would have been shocking to the GOP until last night. Republicans went ballistic when the future First Lady told a crowd of voters in Feb. 2008, "For the first time in my adult life, I am really proud of my country because it feels like hope is finally making a comeback."

The Obamas subsequently explained that what she meant was that she was thrilled to see Americans turning out to vote, but the meme that the Princeton and Harvard Law grad was a crypto-black militant had stuck.

To take but one example from Glenn Beck in 2012, "This is who they are. They’re anti-colonialists. They believe America has oppressed the rest of the world."

Trump himself used Joe Biden's plagiarism scandal to question Obama's running mate in 2008, telling Wolf Blitzer, "You know, he's also been involved in pretty big controversy like plagiarism in college and various other things. That's a pretty big statement. So perhaps you change over a period of time. But when you plagiarize, that's a very bad statement."

Title: "SeaWorld Responds to Allegations in Documentary "Blackfish""

Article:

The documentary "Blackfish," which aired on CNN and portrays the treatment of killer whales in captivity at SeaWorld, has led to a decline in visitors to the theme park. The film alleges that the captivity of these animals is cruel, with greedy businessmen taking baby whales from their mothers and imprisoning them in small aquariums, causing psychological trauma.

However, SeaWorld has responded to these allegations, stating that they have not separated whales from their mothers in 35 years and have no plans to do so in the future. They claim that much of the film is deceitful and that the things described in the documentary did not happen.

One of the most controversial scenes in "Blackfish" is a mournful cry of a mother whale whose baby was taken from her. However, SeaWorld claims that the "baby" in question was an adult with its own offspring, and the scene was manipulated with sound effects that are not even appropriate for killer whales.

The film also claims that captive whales' droopy dorsal fins indicate that the whales are miserable. However, whale expert Ingrid Visser states that killer whales in the wild also have collapsed dorsal fins.

SeaWorld claims that its whales are "happy." While it is acknowledged that it is impossible to know what the whales are thinking, SeaWorld's head veterinarian Chris Dold states that he knows his dog is happy and that they have a good relationship.

There have been instances of conflict between humans and whales at SeaWorld, such as a whale drowning a trainer. However, SeaWorld argues that there is no evidence that the whale's behavior was a result of frustration due to living in a tank.

"Blackfish" also claims that captive whales die young, but SeaWorld points out that they have a 50-year-old whale living at SeaWorld, and their life parameters are the same as whales in the wild.

The documentary has sparked controversy and debate, with some arguing that it is cruel to imprison whales in tanks where they are forced to perform tricks. However, SeaWorld argues that marine parks and zoos are often the only way people learn about nature, and ticket sales fund education and conservation efforts. SeaWorld alone has helped rescue 25,000 animals.

It is important to note that the opinions expressed in this article are based on the information provided in the source text and do not reflect any personal opinions or biases of the author. The author does not presume to know if it is moral to keep animals in captivity, but acknowledges that the activists may distort the truth.

Title: Trump Discusses CNN Correspondent, Mueller Investigation, and Foreign Policy in Fox News Sunday Interview

Article:

In a taped interview with Chris Wallace on Fox News Sunday, President Donald Trump addressed a range of topics, including the behavior of CNN correspondent Jim Acosta, his appointment of acting Attorney General Matthew Whitaker, and foreign policy concerns regarding North Korea, Saudi Arabia, and Pakistan.

The president criticized Acosta's behavior during a recent press briefing, stating, "CNN's White House correspondent was unbelievably rude to [White House Press Secretary] Sarah Huckabee Sanders." If Acosta misbehaves, Trump warned, "we'll throw him out or we'll stop the news conference."

Trump also discussed his appointment of Matthew Whitaker as acting Attorney General, stating that he was unaware of Whitaker's past remarks about the Mueller investigation into possible collusion between the Trump campaign and Russia when he appointed Whitaker to replace Jeff Sessions at the Department of Justice.

In the interview, Trump also commented on the recent midterm elections, expressing his support for GOP Senate candidate Rick Scott in Florida. He claimed that without his intervention, Scott would have lost the election due to "votes that disappeared at the very end."

Regarding foreign policy, Trump expressed solidarity with the mayor of Tijuana, Mexico, stating that the U.S. is "ill-prepared" to absorb the caravan of migrants traveling through Mexico towards the U.S. border. He also urged Democrats to "approve Border Security & Wall NOW!"

Trump also discussed his interactions with former President Barack Obama, stating that Obama offered him guidance on North Korea shortly after his 2016 election. He also mentioned the ongoing tensions with Saudi Arabia, stating, "We give Pakistan $1.3 billion a year...[bin Laden] lived in Pakistan, we're supporting Pakistan, we're giving them $1.3 billion a year--which we don't give them anymore, by the way."

Trump also expressed regret for not visiting Arlington National Cemetery on Veterans Day, stating, "I should have done that...I was extremely busy on calls for the country...I probably, you know, in retrospect I should have and I did last year and I will virtually every year."

Title: DEA and ATF Collaborate on Monitoring Gun Show Attendees with Automatic License Plate Readers, ACLU Reveals

Article:

The American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU) has disclosed information obtained through a Freedom of Information Act request that reveals a collaboration between the Drug Enforcement Administration (DEA) and the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms, and Explosives (ATF) to monitor gun show attendees using automatic license plate readers (ALPRs).

According to an email from April 2009, the DEA Phoenix Division Office is working closely with the ATF on plans to monitor gun shows, including programs or operations with ALPRs at the gun shows. The government redacted parts of the email, but the ACLU concluded that these agencies used ALPRs to collect information about law-abiding citizens attending gun shows.

An ALPR cannot distinguish between individuals transporting illegal guns, legal guns, or no guns at all; it only documents the presence of any car driving to the event. Mere attendance at a gun show, it appears, would have been enough to have one's presence noted in a DEA database.

In response to inquiries about the document, the DEA stated that the monitoring of gun shows was merely a proposal and was never implemented. The ACLU, however, had rationally concluded, based on the scrap of information left unredacted in the document, that gun show monitoring was underway.

It is noteworthy that the Department of Justice's own surveys of prison inmates show that criminals do not primarily obtain their firearms from gun shows. The ACLU's revelation raises concerns about potential infringements on the constitutionally protected right to assemble.

The collaboration between the DEA and ATF, and their apparent interest in tracking law-abiding, innocent gun show attendees, is particularly striking in light of the agencies' lack of interest in tracking more than 2,500 weapons they purposely provided to Mexican-narco terrorists through Operation Fast and Furious, which were used to kill hundreds of people, including U.S. federal law enforcement officers.

Title: Study Reveals Challenges Faced by Immigrant Students in U.S. Schools and the Importance of Supportive Environments

Article:

A recent study has shed light on the experiences of immigrant students in American schools, revealing that a significant number of students face negative perceptions from their peers and challenges in integrating into the educational system.

The study found that 65 percent of the students surveyed were met with negative adjectives when their national origin was mentioned, with comments such as "lazy," "gangsters," "drug addicts," and "job stealers" being common. A 14-year-old boy from the Bay Area shared, "Most Americans think we are lazy, gangsters, drug addicts, that only come to take their jobs away."

The research also indicated that many educators view immigrant parents as uninformed and uninvolved, further complicating the challenges faced by these students. The study found that having just one friend who spoke English fluently was a strong predictor of positive academic outcomes. However, more than a third of the students reported little or no opportunity to interact with native-born students.

The study also highlighted the difficulties faced by students who immigrate during their high school years, particularly those who experience interrupted schooling, family instability, and traumatic dislocations. The younger brother of the Boston Marathon bombers, Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, is an example of this, as he was a "smart" and "respected" student in high school but struggled academically at the University of Massachusetts, Dartmouth.

Despite these challenges, the study found that a quarter of the students sustained high academic performance over five years, and another 11 percent showed significant improvement. These students tended to be enrolled in supportive schools, have caring teachers, and develop informal mentorships with coaches, counselors, or ministers.

The study also found that the second generation, American-born children of immigrant parents, assimilate and excel to a greater extent than the "1.5 generation" (children who immigrate in or before their early teens).

The study's findings suggest that providing academic, psychological, and other supports to immigrant students is crucial for their successful integration into American society. The Internationals Network for Public Schools, which focuses on students' distinct needs and develops authentic connections with their families, is one successful model.

The study's authors caution that the experiences of the Tsarnaev brothers, who faced family estrangement, multiple relocations, and possibly religious radicalization, are not representative of all immigrant students. However, they emphasize that the broad lesson - assimilating immigrant students into the fabric of society through academic, psychological, and other supports - should inform educators and policy makers in the future, as immigrants and their children will account for most of the nation's population growth.

Title: George Zimmerman's Wife Sentenced to Probation and Community Service for Perjury

Article:

Shellie Zimmerman, the wife of George Zimmerman, the neighborhood watch volunteer acquitted in the killing of Trayvon Martin, has been sentenced to one year of probation and 100 hours of community service after pleading guilty to a misdemeanor perjury charge for lying at her husband's bond hearing.

On April 22, 2012, during her husband's bond hearing, Shellie Zimmerman told Judge Kenneth Lester that the couple had little funds. However, in a court filing, State Attorney Angela Corey stated that Shellie Zimmerman perjured herself by failing to reveal that George Zimmerman had collected more than $100,000 through Internet donations.

According to recordings of jail calls released by the Florida State Attorney's Office, George Zimmerman instructed Shellie Zimmerman on how to transfer money from his bank account into hers and his sister's while he was in jail in April 2012. According to an affidavit, Shellie Zimmerman transferred more than $74,000 to her personal account days before the April bond hearing, with nearly $50,000 transferred to an account held by Zimmerman's sister.

Taped phone calls between the couple revealed that they had discussed the money transfers in code to hide the funds, according to the affidavit. Prosecutors allege that Zimmerman and his wife talked about $10, $20, and $100 to mask the fact that they were referring to thousands of dollars. The calls also showed that George Zimmerman instructed his wife to "pay off all the bills," including payments to American Express and Sam's Club.

Judge Lester ruled on June 3, 2012, that Shellie Zimmerman had "testified untruthfully" about their finances. She was later arrested on June 12, 2012, and jailed briefly in Seminole County before posting a $1,000 bond.

George Zimmerman killed Trayvon Martin on Feb. 26, 2012, in a gated townhouse community in Sanford, Fla., as the teen returned home from buying snacks at a convenience store. Zimmerman said he shot the unarmed teenager in self-defense after being attacked. A jury last month found Zimmerman not guilty of second-degree murder and manslaughter.

Shellie Zimmerman had originally faced a third-degree felony perjury charge but the court accepted a plea deal. On Wednesday, she pleaded guilty to "perjury not in official proceedings," which is a misdemeanor. She also filed in open court a letter of apology to Lester. The details of the letter were not immediately available.

Assistant State Attorney John Guy, one of the attorneys who argued before the court at George Zimmerman's trial, was back in court to handle Shellie Zimmerman's case.

As part of Shellie Zimmerman's one-year probation, she was given a list of conditions she must abide by. In part, she cannot possess, carry, or own a firearm and must get permission to own any other type of weapon. She also must get permission from her probation officer before moving, changing jobs, or leaving the county where she lives.

She must also report regularly to a probation officer, pay $263 in court fees/fines, and pay the state of Florida $50 per month as a cost of supervision while on probation. Her probation can also be revoked if she violates the law, associates with anyone engaged in criminal activity, or uses any drugs not prescribed by a doctor.

Title: Trump Extends Social Distancing Guidelines for 30 More Days to Combat Coronavirus

Article:

President Donald Trump announced on Sunday that the federal guidelines urging Americans to socially distance to slow the spread of the coronavirus will remain in place for another month, potentially lasting until June. The guidelines, which were initially set for 15 days, are now extended until April 30, with formalized plans to be announced on Tuesday.

Under the guidelines, the Trump administration is urging people to avoid restaurants, bars, and other situations involving more than 10 people and to restrict travel to essential trips only. During a news conference in the Rose Garden, Trump emphasized the importance of following the guidelines, stating, "The better you do, the faster this whole nightmare will end."

Trump had initially announced 15-day guidelines, which were set to end on Monday, and had suggested the recommendations could be relaxed. However, on Sunday, Trump said the guidelines will continue to ask Americans to socially distance until April 30.

Models of the virus's spread indicate that the worst days of the pandemic could hit the country in two weeks, according to Trump. The president had previously stated he would like to see the country "reopen" for business on Easter, a notion that deeply unsettled infectious disease experts, who said such a move could exacerbate the crisis.

Trump's optimistic assessment was not a mistake, he said on Sunday. "It was just an aspiration," Trump said. "That could be the peak number of deaths before it starts coming down." The president said of coronavirus cases around Easter, which is April 12, "It was just an aspiration."

Trump's decision to extend the social distancing guidelines was made following conversations with Anthony Fauci and Deborah Birx, two doctors and public health experts on the White House's coronavirus task force. Fauci and Birx pointed to leading coronavirus models, which they said show that, even with social distancing and other mitigation measures in place, millions of Americans are anticipated to become infected and up to 200,000 could die. If social distancing is not followed, the estimates are even more grim, Trump noted, saying the model suggested some 2.2 million Americans could have died in the U.S. if officials ended containment efforts.

"Now we're looking at numbers that are going to be much, much, much lower than that," Trump said. "And it makes everything we're doing feel much better to me."

The hope is that the model's estimates are overstating the likely case load and death toll, according to Birx. "We can do better than what the predictions are," Birx said.

Trump indicated that months more of social distancing could be in store, saying he hopes the country's rebound from the virus will start in June. "We think by June 1, a lot of great things will be happening," Trump said.

Coronavirus cases in the U.S. continue to soar, and virus-related deaths are mounting, with America's total fatalities doubling in just two days. More than 2,000 people affected by the virus in the United States have now died, according to Johns Hopkins University researchers.

Expecting the surge of coronavirus cases to continue, state and local officials are bracing for shortages of medical equipment and supplies. State leaders, including Gov. Andrew Cuomo of New York, the nation's current virus epicenter, are predicting that in the coming weeks critical supplies like ventilators could be far outmatched by the volume of critically ill coronavirus patients.

In the news conference on Sunday, Trump raised suspicions, without evidence, that medical professionals could be "hoarding" masks. "Something's going on," said Trump, urging reporters to look into why supplies are being used so rapidly. "Where are the masks going? Are they going out the back door? How do you go from 10,000 [used normally] to 300,000?"

The president made the same unsubstantiated claim against hospitals, floating the unproven idea that hospitals could be hoarding ventilators. During Sunday's briefing, federal officials highlighted that the pace of testing has substantially sped up in recent weeks. About 894,000 tests have been conducted nationally as of Saturday, according to Adm. Brett Giroir, assistant secretary for health and head of the Public Health Service, who is overseeing the administration's testing coordination.

The news conference took a hostile turn when PBS NewsHour reporter Yamiche Alcindor asked the president about remarks he made on Fox News Channel saying he did not believe states like New York need the number of ventilators state leaders are requesting. "I did not say that," Trump said, denying words that were broadcast nationally to Fox News host Sean Hannity. "Why do you act a little bit more positive? It always trying to 'get you. Get ya. Get ya.' "

The president then attempted to make a disparaging remark to Alcindor for leaving The New York Times to join PBS.

Title: Islamic State Claims Responsibility for Deadly New York Truck Attack

Article:

Islamic State has claimed responsibility for a truck attack in New York City that killed eight people, marking the deadliest assault on the city since September 11, 2001. The militant group made the claim in a weekly issue of its Al-Naba newspaper, identifying the accused attacker, Sayfullo Saipov, as "one of the caliphate soldiers."

Saipov, a 29-year-old Uzbek immigrant, was charged in federal court on Wednesday for acting in support of Islamic State by driving a rented pickup truck down a popular riverside bike path, resulting in the deaths of eight pedestrians and cyclists and injuring a dozen more. According to the criminal complaint against him, Saipov told investigators he was inspired by watching Islamic State propaganda videos on his cellphone, felt good about what he had done, and asked for permission to display the group's flag in his hospital room in New York.

Saipov was shot in the abdomen by a police officer before his arrest and was taken to Bellevue Hospital. U.S. President Donald Trump, who has called for Saipov to receive the death penalty, said on Twitter on Friday that Islamic State had claimed Saipov as their soldier, responsible for the "Degenerate Animal" who killed and wounded "the wonderful people on the West Side" of Lower Manhattan.

In the Middle East, the Islamic State's self-proclaimed caliphate appeared to be on the verge of defeat, with Syrian government forces seizing its last major city on one side of the border and Iraqi troops taking its last big town on the other. The group's leader, Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, is believed to be hiding in the desert near the frontier, and regional officials fear the group will reconstitute itself as a guerrilla force, capable of waging attacks without territory to defend.

Saipov's sister believes he may have been brainwashed, and she appealed to Trump on Friday to ensure he gets a fair trial. Speaking by phone from the Uzbek capital Tashkent, she expressed hope that Trump would help make sure her brother was given "more time" and "a fair trial." In a separate interview with Radio Free Europe, she said she spoke with her brother the day before the attack and he was in a good mood.

Five Argentine tourists, a Belgian woman, a New Yorker, and a New Jersey man were among those killed in Tuesday afternoon's attack. The attack unfolded just blocks from the site of the World Trade Center, where some 2,600 people were killed when suicide hijackers crashed two jetliners into the Twin Towers 16 years ago. The Federal Bureau of Investigation has located another Uzbek man, Mukhammadzoir Kadirov, 32, who it said was wanted for questioning as a person of interest in the attack.

Title: Bill Gates Warns of Future Epidemics in Article for New England Journal of Medicine

Article:

In an article published in the New England Journal of Medicine, Bill Gates, a businessman and philanthropist, has outlined a potential scenario for future epidemics of highly infectious diseases. He emphasized the need for the world to learn from the Ebola outbreak and prepare for future epidemics that may be more infectious than Ebola.

Gates wrote that there is a significant chance that an epidemic of a substantially more infectious disease will occur within the next 20 years. He cited major epidemics that occurred during the 20th century, such as the Spanish influenza epidemic of 1918-1919 and the ongoing human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) pandemic, as examples.

Gates further stated that the most likely cause of an epidemic that could kill more than 10 million people worldwide is an epidemic stemming from either natural causes or bioterrorism. He suggested that the world should treat future epidemics like war, requiring a plan and an organization to manage and coordinate responses.

Gates pointed out that despite efforts by the United States and a few other countries, there are still significant gaps in the world's ability to respond to an epidemic. He proposed a rigorous study of the cost of building a global warning and response system and a plan for contributions from various countries.

However, not everyone agrees with Gates' assessment that the problem lies with international response. Emmanuel d'Harcourt, senior health director of the International Rescue Committee, told NPR that while a global response system might be helpful, that's not where the trouble is. D'Harcourt emphasized the importance of local preparedness and response, stating that local responders are usually the first to act in most disasters, including epidemics.

A year after the Ebola outbreak began, cases continue in Sierra Leone, and they are on the rise in Guinea, according to the World Health Organization.

Title: Media's Criticism of Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton's Campaign

Article:

The media's coverage of the 2016 U.S. Presidential election has been characterized by intense scrutiny of the candidates, particularly Republican nominee Donald Trump. The New York Times, in a recent article, alleged that Trump could have avoided paying income tax for 18 years due to business losses in the 1990s. It is important to note that the article states "could have," not "did."

The media's portrayal of Trump has been criticized as harsh, with some commentators going as far as to diagnose him with psychiatric conditions such as being a "puerile, sophomoric sniveler" and a "terroristic man-toddler." The media's coverage has been accused of overshadowing the Democratic nominee, Hillary Clinton, and her political record.

Clinton's campaign has been characterized by some as lacking in ideas and convictions of significant importance to the country. During the primaries, her positions on various issues shifted significantly in response to her main rival, Bernie Sanders. Sanders, a self-proclaimed progressive, pushed Clinton to the left on issues such as free college and a higher minimum wage.

The media's focus on Trump's personal attributes, such as his unfitness for the presidency, has been criticized for deflecting attention from Clinton's own political record and lack of evidence of significant convictions beyond a desire for power and acclaim. The potential consequences of a Clinton presidency, in terms of policy and the direction of the country, remain a topic of debate.

Title: Presidential Candidates' Vice Presidential Selection Process in 2012 and 2016, and Biden's 2020 Vice Presidential Pick

Article:

In the 2012 and 2016 U.S. presidential elections, the selection process for vice presidential candidates varied among the major parties.

Mitt Romney, the 2012 Republican nominee, initially had a list of about 80 potential running mates, which he narrowed to 20 in early April 2012. By late July, the list had been further reduced to five men, after former Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice declined the campaign's invitation to be vetted. Romney eventually chose Representative Paul Ryan.

Donald Trump's 2016 vetting process was less structured, but among those he interviewed during his search was Senator Joni Ernst of Iowa.

Hillary Clinton started with a list of 40 potential candidates for the vice presidency in 2016. This list was narrowed to nine who underwent a process of serious vetting, an interview, and a campaign appearance with the candidate. While Clinton considered several women for the vice presidency, only Senator Elizabeth Warren advanced to the final stages of the process.

For the 2020 Democratic presidential election, Joe Biden, 77, is aiming to select a woman as his running mate. A younger woman could help assuage concerns about Biden's age and address critiques about a primary process that started with the most diverse field in history and ended with two white men. Biden's campaign hopes the early announcement that he will select a woman will generate enthusiasm from voters, even as the presidential election is affected by the coronavirus.

On Thursday, Biden's campaign sent a fund-raising appeal asking supporters to "commit to standing with" Biden and his future female running mate. By announcing he will pick a woman, Biden is aiming to give his ticket a modern-day balance in a party focused on issues of racial and gender representation.

Choosing Senator Kamala Harris, 55, would not only provide gender balance but also add a black woman to the ticket after black voters helped revive Biden's campaign in February. However, recent criticism from Jill Biden may impact Harris' chances. The specific nature of Jill Biden's criticism of Harris is not available in the provided text.

Title: Foxconn's Planned Wisconsin Facility Shifts from Manufacturing to Technology Hub, Job Creation Lags

Article:

The tech giant Foxconn, initially promised to build a manufacturing facility in suburban Milwaukee, Wisconsin, with a commitment of more than $3 billion in subsidies, is now reconsidering its plans. Instead of the promised 13,000 blue-collar jobs, the company is likely to transform the Wisconsin facility into a "technology hub" that will focus on research facilities and the production of specialized tech products.

Louis Woo, a high-ranking assistant to Terry Gou, Foxconn's chairman, told Reuters that the jobs created will primarily be "knowledge" positions, not blue-collar jobs. This shift in strategy was already hinted at in November when The Wall Street Journal reported that the company was planning to import workers from Taiwan and China to meet its hiring goals in Wisconsin.

Foxconn is currently lagging behind its job-creation promises. While the company originally promised to create 5,200 jobs by the end of 2020, Foxconn stated earlier this month that the actual number would be about 1,000.

The problems with the Foxconn factory were not difficult to foresee. Building television screens with relatively expensive American labor was always a question mark, and it was never clear how Foxconn planned to operate a massive manufacturing center "in what was essentially the middle of nowhere, without the sort of dense ecosystem of suppliers and sub-suppliers required for making a major factory hum."

Foxconn has a history of abandoning similar projects. The company previously walked away from a plan to invest $5 billion and create 50,000 jobs in India, and similar deals in Vietnam and Brazil. Even in America, there was evidence that Foxconn should not be trusted to make good. A planned manufacturing facility in Harrisburg, Pennsylvania, was supposed to employ 500 people and come with a $30 million investment, but it never materialized.

Even if everything had worked out, the Foxconn giveaway was a bad idea. According to Wisconsin's Legislative Fiscal Bureau, it would take the state until 2043 to recoup the $3 billion handout, which was the largest such subsidy in Wisconsin history. Even if all 13,000 promised jobs went to Wisconsinites, the tab would be more than $230,000 per job created.

Another lousy part of the deal is the use of eminent domain to remove residents of Mt. Pleasant, Wisconsin, where the new facility is to be built. Foxconn will receive more than 1,000 acres of land for free, with the logic being that the subsequent increase in land value will pay for itself eventually in the form of higher property taxes.

It was always unlikely that the Foxconn deal would live up to the promises made by the company, former Republican Gov. Scott Walker, and President Donald Trump. That it is failing so spectacularly, and so early, should serve as a stern warning to the next politician who considers a similar scheme.

Title: New York City Sees Surge in Adoptions Amidst Coronavirus Pandemic

Article:

In the midst of the coronavirus pandemic, an unexpected shortage has arisen in New York City: pets, particularly adopted or fostered cats and dogs. Shelters such as Muddy Paws Rescue and Best Friends Animal Society are reporting a significant increase in applications, with some shelters running out of or nearing depletion of animals.

New Yorkers, ordered to shelter in place, appear to be adopting pets as a means to alleviate boredom and anxiety. Anna Lai, the marketing director at Muddy Paws, stated, "For the moment, we definitely don't have any dogs left to match with foster volunteers. Which is a great problem to have."

This surge in pet adoptions is reflected in the stock market, with Chewy Inc., an online pet product supplier, experiencing a 7% increase this year. The increased volume has led to delivery times of between seven and ten days for most customers, according to the company's website.

RBC Capital Markets noted in a report, "Chewy’s in-home delivery model mitigates the public health concern of consumers shopping at brick-and-mortar retailers." Additionally, pet food is considered recession-proof, providing another advantage for pet-related companies during economic downturns.

The trend of adopting pets seems to extend beyond New York City, particularly in disease hotspots.
