The American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals reported a 70% increase in animals going into foster care in Los Angeles. Best Friends Animal Society also reported similar trends in shelters across the United States.

However, rescue organizations are concerned about a potential rise in surrendered pets as Americans lose their jobs and may not be able to care for their animals. Lisa LaFontaine, CEO of the Humane Rescue Alliance, which operates adoption centers in the District of Columbia and New Jersey, stated, "We don't know what's going to happen when the economic wave starts hitting."

Despite the current shortage, some individuals are still finding and welcoming new pets into their homes. Tom Drescher and his wife, Becky Nolin, recently adopted a 10-year-old mixed breed dog named Goldie, found online at an adoption site. Drescher, 35, shared, "It occurred to us it would be a good time to adopt a dog because we'd have the time and bandwidth to help it settle in. It's been a blast for us so far—we've been thrilled to have her."

Title: FBI Investigation into Hillary Clinton's Emails and WikiLeaks Releases Add Uncertainty to Presidential Race

Article:

The race for the White House has become increasingly uncertain as federal investigators begin searching through newly discovered emails belonging to Hillary Clinton's top aide, Huma Abedin. The emails were found on a laptop belonging to Abedin's estranged husband, Anthony Weiner, who is currently under investigation for allegedly sexting an underage girl. Officials have obtained a warrant to search those emails, but it is unlikely the review will be completed by Election Day.

Meanwhile, the presidential race has tightened dramatically in the last several days. The gap was closing even before Friday's news that the FBI would reopen the investigation into Clinton's emails, but now the contest is virtually a dead heat. Even though the polls are close, Clinton still has an apparent advantage in the Electoral College. Consequently, both candidates are hitting key swing states where the election will likely be decided.

Addressing supporters at a rally in Kent, Ohio, on Monday, the former secretary of state sounded defiant about the email controversy. "I'm sure a lot of you may be asking what this new email story is about and why in the world the FBI would decide to jump into an election with no evidence of wrongdoing with just days to go?" Clinton said. "That's a good question," she continued. "First of all, for those of you who are concerned about my use of personal email, I understand. As I said, I'm not making excuses; I understand and I regret it," she continued. "They should look at them. And I'm sure they will reach the same conclusion they did when they looked at my emails for the last year. There is no case here."

Meanwhile, campaigning in Michigan, Republican rival Donald Trump kept his focus on Clinton's latest controversy. "Thank you, Anthony. I never liked you, Anthony, but thank you very much," the GOP nominee said. "The Clinton crime spree ends on Nov. 8. It's gon'na end on Nov. 8."

Clinton could face more problems in the days ahead. WikiLeaks is reportedly set to release more hacked emails related to the presidential campaign. The organization has already caused another problem for Democratic operatives. CNN dropped former analyst Donna Brazile after WikiLeaks revealed she had leaked a question from one of the debates in the Democratic primary to the Clinton campaign.

No one knows what effect the FBI investigation or the WikiLeaks releases will have before Election Day. The last week before the election could be as unpredictable as the entire campaign has been so far this year.

Title: Senate Democrats Elect Chuck Schumer as Minority Leader for New Congress

Article:

Senate Democrats have elected New York Senator Chuck Schumer as their minority leader for the new Congress. In his first remarks following his election, Schumer stated, "I am going to wake up every single day focused on how Senate Democrats can effectively fight for America's middle class and those struggling to join it."

Schumer emphasized the need for his party to learn from its recent election losses and unite behind a stronger economic message that acknowledges the system's unfairness to many Americans and the need for improvement. To this end, he expanded the Democratic leadership team from seven to ten members, adding former Democratic presidential candidate Bernie Sanders of Vermont as outreach chairman, Tammy Baldwin of Wisconsin as Democratic Conference secretary, and moderate Joe Manchin of West Virginia as vice chair of the Democratic Policy and Communications Committee.

Schumer acknowledged a post-election debate among Democrats about the party's direction but emphasized the need for a unified approach that speaks to and works on behalf of all Americans. He emphasized the need for a "bigger, bolder, sharper-edged economic message" that focuses on helping middle-class Americans do better and deals directly with the unfairness in the American economic system.

Schumer emphasized the importance of learning from the election results, stating, "When you lose an election like this, you can't flinch. You can't ignore it. You need to look it right in the eye and ask why, analyze it, and learn from it." He noted that the American people felt that the government was not working for them and that the economy was rigged against them in many places.

Schumer suggested that Democrats may find common ground with President-elect Donald Trump, stating, "A silver lining in the deep clouds of this election is that President-elect Trump and his campaign were closer to us (on the economic issue) than to the Republican leadership."

Schumer will replace 77-year-old Sen. Harry Reid of Nevada, who opted to retire rather than run for re-election to the Senate. Schumer, who turns 66 next week, offers a much different style than Reid, who grew up in tiny Searchlight, Nev. Reid was a savvy backroom deal-maker but is not as telegenic or outgoing as Schumer.

Schumer will be negotiating with Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, R-Ky., who was re-elected to the top leadership spot by his GOP colleagues on Wednesday. McConnell has been majority leader since 2015 and served as minority leader in the previous four Congresses. Both Schumer and McConnell are Senate veterans, with McConnell, 74, being Kentucky's longest-serving senator, and Schumer having been elected 18 years ago after serving in the House representing Brooklyn and Queens for 18 years.

Throughout his career, Schumer has sponsored significant legislation, including the Omnibus Crime Bill, the Violence Against Women Act, and the Brady Bill. In the Senate, he was one of the "gang of eight" senators who crafted a bipartisan immigration reform bill that passed the Senate in 2013 but was never taken up by the House.

Schumer was born in Brooklyn in 1950 and was one of three children born to Selma, a homemaker, and Abe, who owned a small pest extermination business. After graduating from Harvard Law School, Schumer returned home to Brooklyn and won a seat in the New York State Assembly. At age 29, he won his first congressional race.

Schumer still lives in Brooklyn with his wife, Iris Weinshall, and they have two grown daughters. Weinshall is the chief operating officer of the New York Public Library, former vice chancellor at the City University of New York, and former commissioner of the New York City Department of Transportation.

Title: Record Number of Voters Register to Vote in 2018 Midterms

Article:

The 2018 midterm elections, scheduled for November 6, are witnessing a surge in voter registration across the United States. According to data, more than 800,000 people registered to vote on National Voter Registration Day in September, compared to 154,500 in 2014. This increase in political engagement is being seen as a significant indicator of the upcoming battle for Congress.

The heightened political activity is attributed to the polarizing nature of Donald Trump's presidency, which has energized voters from both the left and right. For Democrats, the elections represent the first opportunity to channel the energy from marches and protests into tangible action at the ballot box. Republicans, on the other hand, view the midterms as another chapter in the culture wars that have characterized Trump's first term.

The outcome of the elections will determine which party controls Congress and could potentially alter the course of Trump's presidency. Democrats need to flip 24 Republican seats to regain the majority in the House of Representatives for the first time since 2010. The Senate map is more favorable to Republicans, who are aiming to expand on a narrow 51-49 seat majority by defeating several red-state Democratic incumbents.

Several states have reported record numbers of voters registering to cast their ballots in November. In California, 19 million residents have registered to vote, an increase of about 1.5 million compared to the 2014 midterms. A similar trend was observed in Texas, where state officials reported an 11% rise in registered voters from the previous midterms.

California hosts several key battleground races for the House, while the Senate race between Democrat Beto O'Rourke and Republican Ted Cruz in Texas is one of the most closely watched contests. A record number of people also registered to vote last month on National Voter Registration Day.

However, it remains uncertain how many of the newly registered voters will actually cast their ballots. Michael McDonald, an associate professor of political science at the University of Florida, stated that there was not yet enough data to draw any definitive conclusions, and that there had been little evidence to suggest the kind of turnout in midterms that the country typically sees when the White House is in play.

Politicians, celebrities, and other public figures have intensified their calls for voters to register as deadlines approach in states that could prove influential in November. Trump, who has increased his campaign appearances for Republican candidates, urged his supporters to register to vote in a tweet on Tuesday. Celebrities such as Rihanna and Taylor Swift have also joined the chorus, using their social media platforms to encourage voter registration.

Raven Brooks, the COO of Vote.org, noted that celebrities were particularly effective in motivating young voters to the polls. He reported a significant increase in voter registrations, with the majority of registrations coming from voters aged 18 to 24, followed by those aged 25 to 29. This trend is a stark contrast to the 2016 election year, where registration numbers were dominated by voters aged 30 to 39 and older.

"You're getting a lot of people into the process that are new voters, they're young voters," said Brooks. "That changes, over time, what our political leaders look like."

Title: Missouri Republican Primary Debate Remains Civil, Health Care and Federal Spending Dominate Discussion

Article:

The Republican primary for the Missouri Senate seat currently held by Democratic Sen. Claire McCaskill took a civil turn during a debate on Monday night near St. Louis. The candidates, Rep. Todd Akin, businessman John Brunner, and former state Treasurer Sarah Steelman, answered questions about health care, federal spending, and foreign policy in a 90-minute debate at Lindenwood University in St. Charles.

Health care was a dominant topic of the evening. All three candidates expressed their desire to repeal President Obama's health care law, including provisions that some Republicans support, such as requiring insurers to cover young adults on their parents' plans.

When asked about their health care plans, Mr. Brunner supported the Medicare plan written by Rep. Paul Ryan (Wisconsin Republican) and Sen. Ron Wyden (Oregon Democrat). Mrs. Steelman suggested allowing insurers to sell across state lines and making health savings accounts more accessible. Mr. Akin proposed dismantling the entire system of employer-based insurance to allow Americans to keep their coverage when changing jobs.

The debate saw a brief moment of direct attack when candidates were asked about which parts of the federal government they would like to eliminate. Mrs. Steelman criticized Mr. Akin for not cutting the Department of Education and Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) budgets while serving in Washington. Mr. Akin responded by expressing his desire to eliminate these agencies but lamented the lack of support from fellow Democrats.

Differences emerged when the candidates were asked about handling the growing unrest in Syria. Mrs. Steelman and Mr. Brunner emphasized caution but were open to committing troops to the country, while Mr. Akin advocated for staying out of the "no-win situation."

On Social Security, all three candidates agreed that the system should be preserved for current seniors but younger folks should be allowed to set up private savings accounts.

Following the debate, Mrs. McCaskill's campaign released an email accusing all three candidates of favoring Wall Street investors over seniors.

According to the latest polls, Mr. Brunner and Mr. Akin trail Mrs. Steelman, but all candidates beat Mrs. McCaskill in hypothetical matchups. Mr. Brunner and Mrs. Steelman did not exchange any blows, despite spending the past few weeks attacking each other.

Title: Trump Administration Evaluating Nuclear Deal with Iran as Vice President Pence Discusses Iran's Nuclear Program and Missile Tests

Article:

The Trump administration is currently evaluating whether to maintain the nuclear deal with Iran, Vice President Mike Pence stated in an interview with ABC News that aired on Sunday. The deal, which aims to halt Iran's nuclear program in exchange for relief from economic sanctions, was made between the Obama administration, Iran, and other world powers.

Vice President Pence expressed his disapproval of the agreement, stating that it allows Iran to develop a nuclear weapon in the years ahead and received hundreds of millions of dollars in cash in exchange. When asked about the future of the deal, Pence said, "We're evaluating that as we speak."

Last week, the U.S. imposed renewed sanctions on Iran following the country's ballistic missile tests, which are considered a violation of international norms. Top Democrats, including Senator Dianne Feinstein of California, have joined the White House in condemning the tests.

In a separate interview on "Fox News Sunday," Senator Feinstein stated, "I think Iran is wrong on this."

Regarding the potential reimposition of economic sanctions, House Speaker Paul Ryan seemed to indicate that it would be difficult to undo the deal entirely, particularly when it comes to reinstating multilateral economic sanctions that were lifted as part of the agreement. Speaker Ryan told NBC's "Meet the Press," "A lot of that toothpaste is already out of the tube. I never supported the deal in the first place. I thought it was a huge mistake. But the multilateral sanctions are done." He added, "I don't think you're going to go back and reconstitute the multilateral sanctions that were in place."

Title: U.S. Debate over Boko Haram Designation and Response, 2012-2013

Article:

In mid-2012, a debate unfolded behind the scenes at the U.S. State Department regarding the definition of the Boko Haram threat and the appropriate response to the escalating violence in Nigeria, Africa's top oil-producing nation. According to several analysts and officials who spoke anonymously with The Times, there was resistance to adding Boko Haram to Washington's official terrorist organizations lists due to concerns that such a designation would boost the group's global standing and facilitate its growth and recruitment.

In June 2012, the State Department designated three Boko Haram leaders as "global terrorists" with "close links" to al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb (AQIM). However, the Obama administration continued to resist labeling the entire group as a global terrorist organization, despite mounting evidence that Boko Haram was gaining access to military hardware such as rocket-propelled grenades through jihadist smuggling networks in Mali and Libya.

Alternatively, the administration seemed to be supporting a strategy, pushed during 2012 by Nigerian President Goodluck Jonathan, to create an amnesty program that would offer Boko Haram members the opportunity to avoid prosecution in exchange for laying down their weapons. This approach, which had been successful in curbing militant activity in Nigeria's Christian south during the late-2000s, yielded no significant results in the predominantly Muslim north.

The situation in Northern Nigeria became increasingly dire, with the Nigerian security forces being implicated in "serious human rights violations" such as execution-style killings of detainees, according to a Human Rights Watch report in October 2013. This report, along with the deteriorating situation in Northern Nigeria, served as a backdrop for the State Department's sudden move in November 2013 to officially designate Boko Haram as a terrorist organization, ending a heated debate over the group's status.

The recent kidnapping of more than 200 Nigerian schoolgirls by Boko Haram has brought renewed attention to the group's activities. It remains to be seen whether the dispatching of U.S. and British officials to aid Nigerian authorities in attempting to rescue the girls will lead to a deeper U.S. involvement in the situation.

Title: House Speaker Pelosi Suggests Rescheduling or Written State of the Union Address Amid Government Shutdown

Article:

Washington, D.C. - House Speaker Nancy Pelosi has requested President Donald Trump to reschedule his State of the Union address this month if the ongoing government shutdown persists, or to deliver it in writing. In a letter to Trump on Wednesday, Pelosi suggested an alternative date of January 29th for the written address.

The current government shutdown, now in its 26th day, marks the longest in U.S. history. The impasse stems from Trump's demand for $5.7 billion to fund a wall along the U.S.-Mexican border, a proposal that Democrats oppose.

Pelosi's letter cited the designation of State of the Union addresses as a "National Special Security Event," which requires a high level of security. The Secret Service, responsible for such events, is part of the Department of Homeland Security, which is affected by the shutdown.

Pelosi argued that the State of the Union requires hundreds of people to work out logistics and security, most of whom have been furloughed or are working without pay due to the shutdown. Trump, according to Pelosi, could deliver the speech from the Oval Office if he wished.

In response, House Minority Leader Kevin McCarthy stated that Trump "has a right" to give the speech and that Americans "have the right" to hear it. McCarthy criticized Pelosi, stating, "I think Speaker Pelosi is playing politics like I’ve never seen a speaker before."

Written State of the Union-type addresses were once common practice. The nation's first two presidents, George Washington and John Adams, delivered annual messages to Congress in person. Thomas Jefferson, who succeeded Washington, began submitting his messages in writing in 1801, a practice that continued for over a century.

President Woodrow Wilson revived the practice of in-person speeches in 1913. The U.S. Constitution mandates that presidents "shall from time to time give to the Congress Information of the State of the Union," remarks formally known as the "Annual Message" for decades. President Franklin Roosevelt began describing the speeches as the "state of the Union," a term officially adopted in 1947 during Harry Truman's administration.

The last president to submit only a written State of the Union was lame-duck Jimmy Carter in January 1981, four days before he left office.

On Wednesday, Trump met with the Problem Solvers Caucus, a bipartisan group of House members, to discuss the shutdown. The day before, a moderate group of House Democrats declined Trump's invitation to a White House luncheon, viewing it as an attempt to bypass Pelosi as Trump tries to win support for funding for the border wall.

Seven Democrats were among the Problem Solvers who met with Trump on Wednesday: Reps. Josh Gottheimer of New Jersey, Thomas Suozzi of New York, Vicente Gonzalez of Texas, Anthony Brindisi of New York, Dean Phillips of Minnesota, Max Rose of New York, and Abigail Spanberger of Virginia.

In a joint statement, the Democrats expressed their agreement that the government must be reopened and that the shutdown is compromising security, safety, and the economy, causing suffering for millions of families. They stated that, once the government is reopened, there is a possibility to work together and find common ground to address the country's toughest problems.

The names of the Republican House members who attended the meeting have not been released. White House spokeswoman Sarah Sanders described the meeting as "constructive."

Title: Betsy DeVos Selected as Education Secretary, Nikki Haley Named U.S. Ambassador to the United Nations

Article:

President-elect Donald Trump selected Betsy DeVos, a charter school advocate and GOP donor from Michigan, to be the education secretary on Wednesday. DeVos becomes the second woman chosen to fill a spot in Trump's Cabinet. Earlier in the day, Trump named South Carolina Governor Nikki Haley as the U.S. ambassador to the United Nations. Both Cabinet-level positions require Senate confirmation.

While some initially cheered Haley's selection despite her limited experience on the international stage, the DeVos choice faced criticism even before it was formally announced. Conservatives warned that DeVos, a longtime Republican donor, previously supported the Common Core education standards that Trump railed against during the campaign.

Trump, who was at his Palm Beach estate for the Thanksgiving holiday, called DeVos "a brilliant and passionate education advocate." DeVos, from Michigan, is a longtime advocate for charter schools and school vouchers. She currently leads the advocacy group, American Federation for Children, and sits on the board of the Jeb Bush-led Foundation for Excellence in Education.

"Under her leadership, we will reform the U.S. education system and break the bureaucracy that is holding our children back so that we can deliver world-class education and school choice to all families," Trump said. DeVos said in her own statement, "The status quo in education is not acceptable."

The DeVos family has been active in Republican politics for decades, especially as donors to GOP candidates and the Republican Party. DeVos' husband, Dick, is an heir to the Amway fortune and a former president of the company. The couple gave $22.5 million to the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington in 2010, at the time the largest private donation in the center's history.

Hours before the DeVos pick was announced, conservative policy leader Frank Cannon, president of American Principles Project, called her "an establishment, pro-Common Core secretary of education."

"This would not qualify as 'draining the swamp,'" Cannon said, referencing Trump's campaign trail slogan. "And it seems to fly in the face of what Trump has stated on education policy up to this point."

In a statement to ███, American Federation of Teachers President Randi Weingarten said DeVos "has no meaningful experience in the classroom or in our schools."

"The president-elect, in his selection of Betsy DeVos, has chosen the most ideological, anti-public education nominee put forward since President Carter created a Cabinet-level Department of Education," Weingarten said. "In nominating DeVos, Trump makes it loud and clear that his education policy will focus on privatizing, defunding, and destroying public education in America."

Former presidential contender and Florida Governor Jeb Bush called DeVos "an outstanding pick" for the position.

"She has a long and distinguished history championing the right of all parents to choose schools that best ensure their children’s success," he said in a statement.

When asked about DeVos' support for the Common Core standards, Trump spokesman Jason Miller said "the president-elect has been consistent and very clear in his opposition to Common Core."

"Anybody joining the administration is signing on to the president-elect's platform and vision for moving America forward," Miller said.

Haley, the daughter of Indian immigrants, is the only minority member chosen by Trump so far. Retired neurosurgeon and Trump loyalist, Ben Carson, an African-American, has been offered the job of secretary of the Department of Housing and Urban Development, according to a person familiar with the offer who spoke on the condition of anonymity because the person was not authorized to discuss the deliberations publicly. Carson has not yet accepted the offer, but he tweeted on Wednesday that "an announcement is forthcoming about my role in helping to make America great again."

Trump said that Haley, his UN choice, "has a proven track record of bringing people together regardless of background or party affiliation to move critical policies forward for the betterment of her state and our country."

"She is also a proven dealmaker, and we look to be making plenty of deals," he said in a statement. "She will be a great leader representing us on the world stage."

South Carolina Senator Lindsey Graham praised his home-state governor as a good choice and said in a statement that he looks forward to working with her on "overdue reforms of the United Nations." Graham is chairman of the Senate's Foreign Operations Subcommittee on Appropriations, which is responsible for funding the UN and all American foreign assistance.

Haley said she accepted the assignment partly out of "a sense of duty."

"When the president believes you have a major contribution to make to the welfare of our nation, and to our nation's standing in the world, that is a calling that is important to heed," she said in a statement.

Not all presidents have treated the ambassadorship to the U.N. as a Cabinet-level position, and Republicans have tended not to grant that status. Trump spokesman Jason Miller said Trump is "spending significant time" weighing his choice for secretary of state. Among those he has interviewed is 2012 GOP presidential nominee Mitt Romney, who repeatedly denounced Trump during the 2016 campaign.

After secretary of state, the UN ambassador is the highest-profile diplomatic position, often serving as the voice for U.S. positions on the international stage. As part of the Cabinet, Haley would have more opportunity to shape U.S. policies, rather than simply defend the administration's positions.

Yet it could be an awkward role at times. Trump campaigned on the theme of "America first" and said he is skeptical about "international unions that tie us up and bring America down." Trump has also described the United Nations as weak and incompetent.

Haley would be the third consecutive female U.S. ambassador to the UN, after Susan Rice and Samantha Power, the current ambassador. Bad blood between Trump and Haley was evident through much of the campaign.

"The people of South Carolina are embarrassed by Nikki Haley!" Trump wrote on Twitter in March. Haley denounced several of Trump's campaign comments and urged voters to "reject the siren call of the angriest voices." She told The Associated Press in July, "A lot of the things he has said are very off-putting and concerning."

Title: Former Presidents and First Ladies Gather for Barbara Bush's Funeral; Trump Absent

Article:

Former Presidents Barack Obama and Bill Clinton, along with their respective wives Michelle Obama and Hillary Clinton, attended the funeral service for former First Lady Barbara Bush in Houston on Saturday. The event was also attended by members of the Bush family, including former Presidents George H.W. Bush and George W. Bush, and former First Lady Laura Bush.

Notably absent from the gathering was President Donald Trump, who opted to watch the funeral services from his Mar-a-Lago resort in Palm Beach, Florida. The White House stated that the president chose to skip the funeral to avoid disruptions due to added security and out of respect for the Bush family and friends attending the service.

Melania Trump brought two White House staff members who were close to the Bush family as her guests to the funeral. The president was accompanied by former White House head maitre d' George Hainey and current White House usher Buddy Carter, according to the first lady's office.

It is not uncommon for sitting presidents not to attend the funerals of former first ladies.

Title: Trump to Announce Supreme Court Nominee on Monday, Four Finalists Named

Article:

WASHINGTON - President Donald Trump will announce his pick on Monday to replace retiring Supreme Court Justice Anthony Kennedy. The president told reporters on Sunday that he is close to making a decision, and the four finalists are "excellent, every one." The four finalists are Brett Kavanaugh, Raymond Kethledge, Amy Coney Barrett, and Thomas Hardiman.

The president is said to be leaning toward Hardiman, who was the runner-up to Neil Gorsuch during the last Supreme Court nomination. Senate Republicans have expressed confidence that whoever the president chooses from this "supreme final four" will be a winner.

Senate Democrats have expressed opposition to the nomination, citing the so-called Mitch "McConnell rule" of not voting on nominees during an election year and the potential for nominees who may be committed to overturning Roe v. Wade.

Democratic leaders are targeting moderate Republicans, hoping to get them on their side of the battle. Sen. Lindsey Graham (R-SC) noted that all four finalists are highly qualified. The nomination could have major implications for vulnerable candidates come midterm elections.

300 News will provide special coverage of President Trump's announcement on Monday night at 9:00 pm ET on Facebook LIVE and on CBNNews.com.

Title: New Poll Shows Hillary Clinton Leading Donald Trump by 8 Points Following Democratic National Convention

Article:

Following the Democratic National Convention, Hillary Clinton now leads Donald Trump by 8 points — 50 percent to 42 percent — according to the latest NBC News|SurveyMonkey poll. This represents a significant increase from a single-point difference last week.

Clinton's gain also comes after a series of controversial comments made by the Republican nominee this past week regarding the family of a fallen American soldier and Trump's suggestion that Russian hackers should seek out deleted Clinton emails. The Republican National Convention did not result in a post-convention bounce for Trump.

In a four-way general election match-up against Trump, Libertarian Gary Johnson, and Green Party candidate Jill Stein, Clinton now leads Trump by 5 points — 43 percent to 38 percent. This is a lead-reversal from last week, when Trump was beating the Democratic nominee by 2 points. Support for Johnson (9 points) and Stein (4 points) remained virtually unchanged from last week.

These results are according to the latest NBC News|SurveyMonkey Weekly Election Tracking poll conducted online from July 25 through July 31 among 12,742 adults who say they are registered to vote.

Perhaps a result of a series of well-received speeches from high-profile Democrats, Clinton's gains this week were not only in the horserace numbers. Overall, the number of voters who say they have a strongly favorable impression of the Democratic nominee is up 5 points — from 15 percent to 20 percent — since the question was asked two weeks ago.

Clinton's favorability among Democrats and Democratic-leaning voters rose from 74 percent two weeks ago to 80 percent this week. Her unfavorable rating also dropped among Democrats from 24 percent to 19 percent.

President Obama, who spoke at the convention last week, also got an increase in approval this week. His job approval rating is up 3 points — 52 percent approve this week compared to 49 percent last week.

After a contentious primary season, the convention offered Democrats the chance to unite as a party. Overall, most voters who watched or followed the convention did not view the Democratic Party more favorably as a result — 27 percent viewed the Democratic Party more favorably as a result of the convention, but 35 percent viewed the party less favorably, and 37 percent said their opinion of the Democratic Party didn't change.

Among Democrats and Democratic-leaning voters, half said they have a more favorable opinion of the Democratic Party as a result of the convention. Among Independent voters, 42 percent said they view the Democratic Party less favorably, and 49 percent said the convention did not change their opinion. These results are similar to the favorability ratings we saw for the Republican Party last week following the GOP convention.

Overall, four in ten voters said they were more interested in this year's Democratic National Convention compared to previous years. Among Democrats, 58 percent said they were more interested in this year's convention than in prior years. Roughly the same number of Republicans said that about the GOP convention last week. Among Independents, 46 percent said they had about the same level of interest this year as in previous years, and 34 percent said they were less interested this year.

A strong Democratic convention combined with Trump's troubles over the past few days surrounding his tweets toward the Khan family and comments about Russia produced a very good bounce for Clinton. The question is whether the bounce is short-lived or represents a more permanent shift in the race.

The NBC News|SurveyMonkey Weekly Election Tracking poll was conducted online July 25 through July 31, 2016, among a national sample of 12,742 adults who say they are registered to vote. Respondents for this non-probability survey were selected from the nearly three million people who take surveys on the SurveyMonkey platform each day. Results have an error estimate of plus or minus 1.2 percentage points. For full results and methodology, click here.

Title: Berlin Christmas Market Attack: Suspect Identified, Perpetrator Remains at Large

Article:

The manhunt for the perpetrator of an Islamic State-claimed attack on a Christmas market in Berlin continued Tuesday as German police cautioned that "we may still have a dangerous criminal out there." The attack on the market outside Kaiser Wilhelm Memorial Church on Monday resulted in at least 12 fatalities and over 50 injuries after a truck plowed through a crowd at the market.

Investigators are treating the incident as an act of terrorism, according to Peter Frank, the country's top prosecutor. ISIS, through its media arm, claimed responsibility for the massacre and referred to the attacker as a "soldier of the Islamic State," a typical phrase used by the group when an assailant has been inspired but not directed.

Initially, a man, identified as a Pakistani citizen who arrived in Germany last year, was in custody based on a description of a man who jumped out of the truck and fled after the attack. However, federal prosecutors stated late Tuesday that he denied any involvement and they found no forensic evidence proving he was in the cab during the rampage. Additionally, no witnesses had followed him from the scene to the spot where he was picked up.

Police sources told Germany's Die Welt newspaper that they had the "wrong man" and that the true perpetrator "is still armed, at large, and can cause fresh damage." Berlin police chief Klaus Kandt echoed this sentiment, stating, "We may still have a dangerous criminal out there."

The method used in the attack bore similarities to the truck attack in Nice, France, in July, and the new "modus operandi" used by Islamic extremist groups, according to Frank. For this reason, he said, they are "naturally on high alert and are investigating in all directions."

Six out of the 12 people killed have been identified and are all Germans, but the identity of the other six remains unknown. Berlin police urged people to remain "particularly vigilant" and to report "suspicious movement" to a special hotline.

In related news, the German government increased police presence and cleared jail cells in preparation for New Year's Eve celebrations. The attack came less than a month after the U.S. State Department called for caution in markets and other public places across Europe, citing the focus of extremist groups including Islamic State and Al Qaeda on the upcoming holiday season and associated events.

The Islamic State and Al Qaeda have both called on followers to use trucks in particular to attack crowds. On July 14, a truck plowed into Bastille Day revelers in the southern French city of Nice, killing 86 people. Islamic State claimed responsibility for that attack, which was carried out by a Tunisian living in France. No group had claimed responsibility for the Berlin attack as of early Tuesday.

The revelations about the attacker's identity are likely to add to the pressure on German Chancellor Angela Merkel, whose decision to accept waves of migrants from Africa and the Middle East has been a contentious issue. In a Tuesday press conference, Merkel expressed her shock, shock, and deep sadness over the attack. She also stated that it would be "particularly sickening" if it was confirmed the attack was carried out by an asylum-seeker who sought refuge in Germany.

The truck's owner, Ariel Zurawski, was asked by German authorities to identify the driver from photos. Zurawski, the victim's cousin, described the driver's final moments, stating, "It was really clear that he was fighting for his life. His face was swollen and bloodied. Police informed me that he had suffered gunshot wounds. Despite being stabbed, he was shot dead."

The investigation into the attack is ongoing, with federal prosecutors handling the case. The United States has offered assistance in the investigation and response. U.S. President-elect Donald Trump has blamed Islamic extremists for the attack, but the assessment's basis remains unclear. Germany has not experienced any mass-casualty attacks by Islamic extremists, but has been increasingly wary since two attacks by asylum-seekers in the summer that were claimed by ISIS.

Title: Trump Mocks Christine Blasey Ford at Mississippi Rally, Draws Criticism from Senators

Article:

In a lively campaign-style rally in Mississippi on Tuesday night, President Donald Trump mocked Christine Blasey Ford, a woman who testified last week at a Senate Judiciary Committee hearing that Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh had sexually assaulted her when she was a teenager.

During the rally, Trump mimicked Ford's testimony, in which she vividly described a violent sexual assault she alleges Kavanaugh committed against her in the early 1980s, while admitting that certain details of the time and place were lost to memory.

Republican Senator Jeff Flake, a key member of the Senate Judiciary Committee, called Trump's remarks "kind of appalling" on Wednesday. Trump has been accused of sexual misconduct by at least 20 women, whose allegations he has denied and dismissed. Last week, he called Ford a "very credible witness" and said, "I thought her testimony was very compelling and she looks like a very fine woman to me, very fine woman."

At the rally, the president mocked Ford's testimony with a question-and-answer routine that brought cheers from the crowd in Southaven, Mississippi.

"How did you get home?" Trump said, echoing a question Ford was asked by the committee. "I don't remember," the president said.

"How did you get there?" 'I don't remember.' Where is the place?" 'I don't remember.' How many years ago was it?" 'I don't know.' What neighborhood was it?" 'I don't know.' Where's the house?" 'I don't know."

Trump concluded the routine by lamenting the personal cost to Kavanaugh of Ford's allegations and by insinuating that Ford was part of a partisan conspiracy. "They destroy people, these are really evil people," Trump said.

Senator Flake, who triggered an FBI investigation of Kavanaugh last Friday, said on NBC, "To discuss something this sensitive at a political rally is just not right. It's just not right, and I wish he had not done it."

Flake made his about-face having signaled moments earlier that he would vote to approve Kavanaugh outright, then huddling in frantic negotiations with Democrats on the committee. He has since continued his strong stance of questioning Kavanaugh's nomination.

On Tuesday night after the remarks, Michael Bromwich, a member of Ford's legal team, condemned "a vicious, vile and soulless attack."

"Is it any wonder that she was terrified to come forward, and that other sexual assault survivors are as well?" Bromwich said on Twitter. "She is a remarkable profile in courage. He is a profile in cowardice."

Last week's day of drama had followed an extraordinary hearing by the committee the day before when Kavanaugh and Ford gave dueling testimony about a party in their high school years at which Ford says the then 17-year-old Kavanaugh attempted to rape her, when she was 15. He furiously disputed the account in an emotional and partisan display.

In contrast to Trump's portrayal on Tuesday evening, Ford accurately placed multiple people in Kavanaugh's contemporaneous social circle, as established by his archived calendars from the era, at the scene, and gave a clear account of the alleged attack itself.

In her testimony, she said, "I am here today not because I want to be. I am terrified. I am here because I believe it is my civic duty to tell you what happened to me while Brett Kavanaugh and I were in high school."

Kavanaugh is Trump's second pick to fill a Supreme Court vacancy. The confirmation process for Trump's first pick, Neil Gorsuch, proceeded to a vote without significant controversy.

However, Kavanaugh has been waylaid by accusations of sexual assault by Ford and two other women who have spoken out publicly, and by doubts about his testimony before the Senate, which included conspiracy-mongering and dubious descriptions of his high school and college years.

Speaking under oath before the Senate committee, Kavanaugh denied any drinking problem and denied bragging about sexual conquests in a high school yearbook entry. Former classmates have since stepped forward to say that Kavanaugh was a frequent drunk. The New York Times on Tuesday published a handwritten letter by Kavanaugh instructing friends participating in an upcoming holiday rental to "warn the neighbors that we're loud, obnoxious drunks with prolific pukers among us."

In testimony last Thursday, Ford described attending a house party in the Washington DC suburbs in the early 1980s at which she was pushed into a bedroom where a drunk Kavanaugh held her down, groped her, tried to strip her, and left her fearing for her life. Ford told the Senate she was "100%" certain that he was her attacker, while Kavanaugh said he was "100%" certain he was not.

Title: Obama Vows Continued Executive Action, Announces Partnerships with Businesses and Education Institutions

Article:

In the concluding days of a busy week, President Obama, in his weekly address on Saturday, pledged to continue taking executive action wherever possible and to seek new partners outside Washington to help him achieve his goals.

"Wherever I can take steps to expand opportunity for more families on my own, I will," the president said. "I'm going to ask business leaders, education leaders, and philanthropic leaders to partner with us to advance these goals."

This commitment is part of the president's "year of action," during which he has demonstrated his intention to work with CEOs, higher education institutions, and others to accomplish his aims.

On Friday, for instance, the president announced a new agreement with over 300 businesses, including some of America's top companies such as Apple, AT&T, Ford, and others, to aid the long-term unemployed. Under the deal, companies will place less emphasis on the length of time a job applicant has been out of work and less importance on credit histories.

This agreement is part of a larger effort to get the long-term jobless back into the workforce while an extension of unemployment benefits remains stalled in Congress.

In addition, the president has used executive power to raise the minimum wage for all federal contractors from $7.25 to $10.10, established new government-backed, interest-bearing retirement accounts for all American workers, and taken other steps.

Meanwhile, Republicans on Capitol Hill have countered the president's executive actions by proposing pieces of legislation that they believe both sides of the aisle should support.

For example, Rep. Gregg Harper (Mississippi Republican) pointed to a bill that would eliminate public funding for political party conventions and use those dollars to fund pediatric research at the National Institutes of Health.

"We can't fix it all, but surely creating a lifetime of hope and opportunity for our most vulnerable kids is more important than subsidizing week-long political pep rallies," Mr. Harper added.

Other Republican responses to the president's weekly address included Rep. Martha Roby of Alabama, who highlighted a measure that would allow workers in the private sector to use their overtime toward paid time off, and Rep. Susan Brooks of Indiana, who called on the president to support legislation consolidating federal training programs and strengthening federal partnerships with community colleges.

Republicans believe these bills and others can help spur new cooperation with the president this year and slow down what looks to be a wave of executive actions.

"We believe that this can be a year of bipartisan action, a moment when speeches give way to solutions," said Rep. Fred Upton (Michigan Republican and chairman of the House Energy and Commerce Committee). "The American people never let us down, and we can not let them down either."

Title: Democratic Presidential Candidates and the Question of Free Speech

Article:

The opinions expressed in this article do not represent the views of Townhall.com.

The article discusses the issue of free speech in the context of the current race for the Democratic nomination, comparing it to a police state and Maoist tribunals. The article argues that some Democratic candidates have been required to apologize for statements that are considered politically incorrect, and that this is a form of authoritarianism and "woke" fascism.

The article mentions Pete Buttigieg, Beto O'Rourke, Kirsten Gillibrand, and Al Sharpton. It notes that Buttigieg was criticized for saying "all lives matter," O'Rourke was criticized for a joke about his wife, and Gillibrand was criticized for expressing sympathy for the idea of a closed border. All three have since apologized for their statements.

The article also mentions Al Sharpton and his tax-exempt organization, which the Democratic candidates have recently visited to express support for race-based reparations. The article questions the candidates' silence during the mid-1990s when Sharpton was denouncing a Jewish landlord in Harlem, leading to the firebombing of his store and the deaths of eight people.

The article concludes by questioning whether the country wants to live in a society where such people have political power, where humor and dissent are criminal acts, where lying is the currency of public life, and where authorities can destroy individuals for thinking the wrong things. The article compares this to the social media platform Twitter and imagines a scenario where Twitter had control of the U.S. military.

The article does not provide a clear answer to the question it poses, but rather presents a critical view of the current state of free speech in the Democratic Party and the potential consequences of allowing authoritarianism to take hold.

Title: Ryan's Voting Decisions on Fiscal Cliff and Sandy Relief Bills Spark Political Speculation

Article:

Representative Paul Ryan, a key figure in the Republican Party, has recently found himself at the center of political speculation following his votes on two significant bills. On Tuesday, Ryan voted against most of his GOP House colleagues and with President Obama to raise taxes on wealthy Americans and increase the national debt by an estimated $4 trillion. In a separate vote, Ryan opposed a bill that would allow the National Flood Insurance Program (NFIP) to take on $9.7 billion in new debt to aid those affected by superstorm Sandy.

Ryan's vote against the Sandy relief bill was less surprising, as he had previously spoken out against some of the extraneous items in the legislation. In a statement on Friday, he stated, "It would be irresponsible to raise an insolvent program's debt ceiling without making the necessary reforms."

In a statement after the bill's passage, Ryan expressed his stance on the fiscal cliff, stating, "We'll never get our debt under control unless we tackle its main drivers: too little economic growth and too much spending." He added that it was time to "return our attention to the real problem: out-of-control spending."

The two votes could potentially impact Ryan's political future, particularly if he decides to run for president in 2016. The fiscal cliff vote could become an issue, especially if his potential opponent, Florida Sen. Marco Rubio, highlights the fact that Ryan voted for the measure while Rubio voted against it. The Sandy vote could also be a point of contention if his rival is New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie, who criticized members of his own party this week for not voting on a $60 billion Sandy relief package.

Republican strategist Ron Bonjean suggested that the votes could be politically manageable for Ryan. "Looking through the 2016 primary lens, I think he can easily explain voting yes to avert the fiscal cliff, meant to protect 98 percent of taxpayers, and the issue of Hurricane Sandy, designed to save taxpayers money," Bonjean said. He added that if the bill had gone through the regular House committee process, there would be no possibility of waste, fraud, and abuse.

Ryan has been known to maintain a low profile during negotiations, letting House Speaker John Boehner and House Majority Leader Eric Cantor be the faces of the fight. However, Ryan's spokesperson, Kevin Seifert, stated that Ryan's votes were simply a matter of him voting his conscience.

The two votes in 2016 may mean nothing or could potentially haunt Ryan if he decides to run for president. The outcome will depend on the political landscape at the time and the candidates vying for the nomination.

Title: Fox News Remains Silent on Twitter Amidst Boycott, Third Week of Absence

Article:

Fox News, a prominent American cable news network, has not tweeted since November 8, marking the third week of its absence from the social media platform. The network, which launched its new subscription streaming service Fox Nation on Tuesday, did not use its Twitter feed, capable of reaching 18.3 million followers, to announce the launch.

The network's silence follows a silent protest against Twitter, initiated after a group of demonstrators posted the home address of star host Tucker Carlson on the social network. The boycott also includes the Fox Business Network Twitter feed, as well as a few other official Fox News feeds.

The reasons behind Fox News' avoidance of Twitter and the intended outcomes of the boycott remain unclear. However, owner Rupert Murdoch, who has expressed frustration with social media platforms like Twitter in the past, is believed to be a significant factor. Murdoch argues that these platforms benefit greatly from news publishers' content without offering enough in return.

According to analytics tracker SimilarWeb, 1.4 percent of FoxNews.com's traffic in October came from Twitter, while nearly 70 percent came from direct clicks on the site. Raju Narisetti, a Columbia Journalism School professor and former senior vice president at Murdoch's company, News Corp, stated that Twitter is not a significant revenue issue for Fox News.

Staff members within Fox News describe the current mood as "talking and confused." Some believe the boycott would have ended by now, particularly with the Fox Nation launch. However, the standoff's resolution remains uncertain.

The network's silence stems from frustration over Twitter's response to the harassment of Carlson, according to a Mediaite report that Fox News has not disputed. A Washington anti-fascist group had posted his address on the platform, leading a group of people to assemble outside his home and shout threats. After news reports, Twitter removed the offending tweets and suspended the group's account.

While some hosts, including Carlson, also stopped tweeting, others, including his prime-time colleagues Laura Ingraham and Sean Hannity, have continued. The network's silence and the ongoing boycott have raised questions about the publicity they are losing with the Fox Nation launch.

Fox News and Twitter declined to comment for this story. The network's relationship with Twitter, while not generating significant traffic, is still valuable due to the presence of influential accounts. The analytics support this view, with Comscore finding similar results to SimilarWeb.

Despite the ongoing boycott, some are surprised that Fox News did not leverage its 18 million Twitter followers to promote the Fox Nation launch. The network's absence from Twitter, according to some, is a "hell of a lot easier" when Twitter is more of a "pain in the ass" than a benefit for the organization.

Title: Media Matters President's Past Offensive Online Posts Come to Light

Article:

In a recent report by Daily Caller News Foundation reporter Peter Hasson, it has been revealed that the president of Media Matters, Angelo Carusone, has a history of inflammatory and offensive statements on his now-defunct blog. The posts, which include derogatory remarks about transgender individuals, Bangladeshis, Jews, and other groups, have sparked controversy and criticism.

One particularly offensive post, titled "Tranny Paradise," was written by Carusone in November 2005. In this post, Carusone criticized a news article that described a gang of transvestites as "attractive." He wrote, "Did you notice the word attractive? What the f*ck is that doing there? Is the writer a tranny lover too? Or, perhaps he’s trying to justify how these trannies tricked this Bangladeshi in the first place?"

Carusone also criticized the police for not advising the public to stay away from "tranny bars" and other places. He wrote, "And while we’re out, what the hell was he doing with $7,300 worth of stuff. The guy’s Banladeshi!"

These are just a few examples of Carusone's offensive posts. Readers can find the full report by Peter Hasson to get a complete understanding of Carusone's controversial views.

The revelation of Carusone's past offensive comments has sparked debate and criticism on social media, with some people expressing outrage and others questioning the hypocrisy of the media and political world. It remains to be seen how Carusone and Media Matters will respond to the controversy.

In the past, similar revelations of offensive comments have been met with a range of responses, from apologies and public statements of regret to dismissals and denials. It is unclear at this time how Carusone and Media Matters will respond to the controversy.

The controversy highlights the ongoing debate about free speech and the role of offensive comments in public discourse. Some argue that offensive comments should be tolerated as a necessary part of free expression, while others argue that such comments have no place in public discourse and can cause harm to marginalized communities.

Regardless of one's position on the issue, the controversy surrounding Carusone's past comments is a reminder of the importance of careful and thoughtful speech, particularly when it comes to issues of race, gender, and identity. It is also a reminder of the need for transparency and accountability in the media and political world, and the importance of holding individuals and organizations to the same standards of behavior and speech.

Title: Trump Releases Second Budget Prioritizing Defense and Immigration Enforcement, Seeking $3 Trillion in Deficit Reduction Over a Decade

Article:

President Donald Trump has unveiled his second budget on Monday, outlining an aggressive set of spending reforms aimed at reducing the deficit by $3 trillion over a decade. The budget, according to a preview released by the White House on Sunday, prioritizes defense spending and immigration enforcement, while minimizing funding for services that American families rely on.

The budget proposal, as stated by White House budget chief Mick Mulvaney, aims to "fund what we must, cut where we can, and reduce what we borrow." The budget choices, however, have been met with criticism, with critics arguing that the language of "hard choices" is misleading, as the budget prioritizes spending on defense and immigration enforcement at the expense of middle- and working-class families.

The budget includes a significant boost to the Pentagon to allow for a "ready, larger, and more lethal military," according to the White House preview. Additionally, the budget allocates funds for border security and Immigrations and Customs Enforcement's ability to detain and imprison immigrants. While Trump is discussing spending some money on the opioid crisis, his approach leans more towards law enforcement rather than treatment and recovery.

It is important to note that the budget's emphasis on "hard choices" is contingent on Republicans' previous decision to grant corporations and wealthy individuals a substantial tax break, which has contributed to the deficit. This tax cut, according to some analysts, has made the budget's spending choices more challenging.

Title: Democratic Senator Apologizes to Republican Colleague for Criticism of Police Reform Bill

Article:

In a recent Senate Judiciary Committee meeting, Democratic Senator Dick Durbin apologized to Senator Tim Scott, the Senate's only black Republican, for dismissing Scott's police reform bill as "a token, half-hearted approach." According to a statement from Durbin's communications director, Emily Hampsten, Durbin's criticism was not directed at Scott's bill but at the Senate Majority Leader for prematurely ending the debate on the issue.

During a floor speech on Wednesday, Durbin, the Senate minority whip, criticized the GOP police reform bill, which was introduced by Scott in response to demands for action on police brutality and racism following the police custody death of George Floyd. Durbin expressed a need for more comprehensive changes to address systemic racism and policing in America.

In response to Durbin's remarks, Scott, a South Carolina Republican, tweeted later in the day, "Y'all still wearing those kente cloths over there @SenatorDurbin?" The tweet referenced about two dozen Senate Democrats who earlier this month donned African kente cloths and knelt in the Capitol's Emancipation Hall to express solidarity with black Americans. Durbin did not participate in that display.

Scott also said the comments from Durbin, who in the same floor speech called Scott a friend and said he respected him, "hurt my soul." In an emotional floor speech, Scott reminded members that Wednesday was the five-year anniversary of the shooting at Emanuel AME Church by a white male who expressed racist views against African-Americans.

The details regarding whether Durbin will further address the matter or if Scott responds are unavailable at this time.

Title: Sen. Cory Booker Releases Additional 'Confidential' Kavanaugh Emails Amid Ongoing Hearing

Article:

Sen. Cory Booker (D-N.J.) on Thursday night released two additional batches of "committee confidential" documents from Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh's work for former President George W. Bush. The documents, totaling 26 pages, are marked "committee confidential," meaning they have not been cleared for public release or discussion.

Booker, who has been a vocal critic of Kavanaugh's nomination, announced the latest release of the emails in a tweet, stating, "Here are two additional 'committee confidential' documents that have been kept out of public view until now."

A spokesman for Sen. Chuck Grassley (R-Iowa), the chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, confirmed that the documents' "committee confidential" classification remains in effect. The releases bring the total tranches of "confidential" documents released by Booker to five.

In one four-page tranche released on Thursday night, Kavanaugh is attempting to set up a meeting with Manny Miranda, a then-GOP Senate aide who was involved in hacking Democratic files. Kavanaugh has been questioned about his knowledge of Miranda's actions.

In a second 22-page tranche released on Thursday evening, Kavanaugh forwards an op-ed in 2003 that describes Roe v. Wade as a "bad law." He adds, "Interesting piece from Stephen Carter, who is not conservative."

The releases come after Booker sparked a heated debate earlier in the day when he warned during a Judiciary Committee hearing that he would be releasing "confidential" information. Booker has defended his decision, arguing the document process set up by Republicans on the Judiciary panel is a "sham."

However, his move has drawn criticism from Republicans who implied that he was breaking Senate rules in an effort to bolster potential 2020 White House ambitions. Sen. John Cornyn (R-Texas) said to Booker, "Running for president is no excuse for violating the rules of the Senate."

A spokesman for the Republican National Committee (RNC) criticized Booker's actions, stating, "Senator Cory Booker boldly declared he is knowingly violating Senate rules." The spokesman added, "30 minutes after his grandstanding for the cameras, Booker says he didn’t violate any Senate rules."

Title: Trump Hires Rudy Giuliani to Bolster Legal Team, Focuses on Russia Probe

Article:

President Donald Trump has hired Rudy Giuliani, a vocal supporter, to bolster his legal team. Giuliani, who served as a U.S. attorney before becoming the mayor of New York City, will reportedly focus on the Russia probe as the White House aims to conclude the president's involvement with the investigation.

Trump's personal attorney, Jay Sekulow, stated that Giuliani will primarily work on the Russia probe. During a joint press conference with Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe on Wednesday, President Trump expressed a desire to bring the investigation to a close, stating, "We want to get the investigation over with, done with, put it behind us and we have to get back to business."

In recent days, President Trump has shown a more relaxed attitude towards the investigation, suggesting he has put the idea of firing special counsel Robert Mueller or Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein, who is in charge of the Russia probe, on hold. Last week, Rosenstein reportedly informed the president that he is not a target of any part of the special counsel's investigation or the probe into Trump's longtime lawyer, Michael Cohen.

The president has maintained transparency throughout the investigation, stating, "As far as the investigation, nobody has ever been more transparent than I have – instructed our lawyers be totally transparent. I believe we've given them 1.4 million pages of documents if you can believe that."

Meanwhile, the Department of Justice, in response to subpoena threats from Republican lawmakers, has provided Congress with copies of several memos written by former FBI Director James Comey during his tenure. The memos detail accounts of meetings between President Trump and Comey before the latter was fired.

Comey, during an appearance on MSNBC, stated that he wrote the memos to have a record of his interactions with the president, as he believed Trump might not tell the truth about their conversations if they became an issue.

In a joint statement, the chairmen of three congressional committees noted that Comey's memos show President Trump requested that allegations of collusion, coordination, and conspiracy between his campaign and Russia be fully investigated. They also pointed out that Comey did not write about feeling obstructed or threatened during his conversations with the president.

President Trump took to Twitter to comment on the memos, stating, "James Comey Memos just out and show clearly that there was NO COLLUSION and NO OBSTRUCTION. Also, he leaked classified information. WOW! Will the Witch Hunt continue?"

This development is the latest in an ongoing investigation that the White House is eager to see conclude.

Title: ICE Enforcement Activities Increase Across U.S., Targeting Undocumented Immigrants

Article:

Over the past five days, Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) agents have conducted an "enforcement surge" in various cities across the United States, resulting in the arrest of more than 160 undocumented immigrants in the Los Angeles area alone. This increase in enforcement activities has been reported in cities such as Atlanta, Phoenix, Charlotte, Austin, and others.

Immigration advocates and lawyers have reported that ICE has increased its enforcement activities, including door-to-door visits in apartment buildings, in these cities. In Atlanta, for example, immigration attorney Sarah Owings stated that over 40 undocumented immigrants have been detained in the Savannah, Georgia, area over the past two days. Owings also reported that ICE officers visited two apartment complexes with high concentrations of Latino residents, asking everyone present for proof of legal U.S. residency.

ICE officials and the White House have stated that these activities are routine. However, immigration activists, lawyers, and members of Congress have expressed concern that this is a significant change in enforcement tactics. Owings described the current situation as ICE "out and they’re hunting."

In a statement, an ICE spokesperson criticized recent media coverage of the Los Angeles apprehensions, stating that reports of ICE checkpoints and random sweeps are false, dangerous, and irresponsible. On Feb. 9, an ICE official told reporters that reports of 100 arrests in the Los Angeles area that day were "grossly exaggerated."

Rep. Raúl Grijalva (D-AZ) stated that among his fellow Democrats, there is "not much" confidence in ICE's statements. Bob Libal, the executive director of Grassroots Leadership, a group based in Austin that opposes immigrant detention and deportation, reported that about two dozen undocumented immigrants have been arrested by ICE agents on Feb. 9 and 10.

Immigration activists have pointed to President Donald Trump's Jan. 25 executive order, "Enhancing Public Safety in the Interior of the United States," as the impetus behind the enforcement surge. This executive order made upwards of 8 million undocumented immigrants top priorities for deportation.

Trump has not kept all his immigration-crackdown campaign promises, such as undoing the temporary deportation protections that President Barack Obama made available to undocumented immigrants who were brought to the U.S. as children.

A staffer for a Democratic congressional office that frequently criticized the Obama administration's immigration enforcement practices stated that the recent surge in enforcement activities is uniquely concerning due to the number of arrests and the simultaneous nature of the operations in multiple cities. Some Hill Democrats worry that this could be the new normal.

"It will happen until the beds are full," the staffer said. "They'll have to stop at some point, right?"

Title: Brazilian President Bolsonaro Accuses NGOs of Starting Amazon Fires, Amidst Increase in Deforestation and Fires

Article:

Brazilian President Jair Bolsonaro has stated that his government lacks the resources to combat the thousands of fires currently burning in the Amazon rainforest. In a press conference, he suggested that non-governmental organizations (NGOs) may have started the fires as retaliation for his government's reduction in their funding, but admitted he has no evidence to support this claim.

On Thursday, President Bolsonaro was questioned about who was responsible for starting the fires. He responded, "The Indians, do you want me to blame the Indians? Do you want me to blame the Martians?... Everyone is a suspect, but the biggest suspects are NGOs." When asked if there was any proof of this, he replied, "Did I accuse NGOs directly? I just said I suspect them."

The increase in fires has been confirmed by satellite data published by the National Institute for Space Research (Inpe), which shows an 85% increase in fires across Brazil this year, with most occurring in the Amazon region. The Amazon, the world's largest rainforest, plays a crucial role in slowing down global warming as a vital carbon store.

At a meeting on climate change earlier this week, Brazil's Environment Minister Ricardo Salles was heckled. Climate activists and conservationists have been critical of the Bolsonaro government and its policies, which prioritize development over conservation. They argue that since President Bolsonaro took office, the Amazon rainforest has experienced accelerated degradation.

The controversy surrounding the Amazon fires has escalated, with President Bolsonaro dismissing the latest data and blaming the "queimada" season, when farmers burn land to clear it before planting. However, Inpe has noted that the number of fires is not in line with those normally reported during the dry season.

The situation has sparked global concern, with millions taking to social media to express their concern using the hashtag #PrayForAmazonia. However, some of the most viral images shared on social media are not current, with some dating back to 1989 and others depicting fires in locations far from the Amazon.

The US space agency, Nasa, has reported that overall fire activity in the Amazon basin is slightly below average this year. The region is home to approximately three million species of plants and animals and one million indigenous people.

The plight of the Amazon has seen millions take to social media to decry reports of a massive yearly increase in forest fires. However, some of the most striking images shared by social media users are not all they seem. The hashtag #PrayForAmazonia started to be widely used on Tuesday and has been included in almost three million tweets since. The most widely shared tweet using that hashtag - with more than a million likes and retweets - includes two aerial images of forest fires, neither of which show the current situation.

Wildfires are common during the dry season in Brazil, but they are also deliberately started in efforts to illegally deforest land for cattle ranching. "The dry season creates the favorable conditions for the use and spread of fire, but starting a fire is the work of humans, either deliberately or by accident," Inpe researcher Alberto Setzer told Reuters news agency.

Ricardo Mello, head of the World Wide Fund for Nature (WWF) Amazon Programme, said the fires were "a consequence of the increase in deforestation seen in recent figures." This article initially stated there was a record number of fires in Brazil this year. After more satellite data was made accessible, it has been updated to reflect the fact the fires are instead the worst since 2010.

Title: Trump Poised to Shape Supreme Court with Second Appointment

Article:

U.S. President Donald Trump is set to appoint a new Supreme Court justice following the retirement of Justice Anthony Kennedy, a move that could cement conservative control of the court and potentially reshape divisive social issues.

On Wednesday, Kennedy announced his retirement, providing Trump with an opportunity to shape U.S. justice for decades to come. A senior White House official stated, "This is a legacy." Trump himself, speaking at a rally in North Dakota on Wednesday night, emphasized the importance of the selection, saying, "We have to pick a great one. We have to pick one that’s going to be there for 40 years, 45 years."

The new justice could play a pivotal role in paring back abortion rights, potentially challenging the Supreme Court's landmark Roe v. Wade ruling in 1973 that established a constitutional right to obtain the procedure. Undoing or limiting this ruling has been a long-standing goal of conservative activists.

Although Kennedy was a conservative justice, he was often considered the "swing vote" on the court due to his tendency to join with liberal justices on certain issues, including expanding gay rights and upholding abortion rights. By selecting a social conservative to replace Kennedy, Trump would have a reliable 5-4 majority on the Supreme Court, even on hot-button social issues.

While Trump did not make rolling back abortion rights a central plank of his campaign, many conservative supporters want Roe v. Wade overturned, and Trump promised to appoint anti-abortion justices to the Supreme Court. However, choosing an ultra-conservative nominee could pose risks, as Trump may need to rely on moderate Republicans to secure approval in the U.S. Senate, where his fellow Republicans hold a narrow majority.

White House officials expect Trump to begin interviewing candidates from a list of 25 people, with the aim of getting the new justice confirmed by the Senate in the autumn. They believe this timeline could boost conservative voter enthusiasm and turnout at the November congressional elections, as Republicans fight to maintain control of both houses of Congress.

In recent weeks, the Supreme Court has handed Trump a series of victories in politically charged cases, including upholding his travel ban on people entering the United States from several majority-Muslim countries. The court's decisions, coupled with Kennedy's retirement, could embolden the administration's lawyers, who are facing legal challenges on multiple fronts, including over Trump's move to separate families who enter the United States illegally and his plan to rescind protections for "Dreamers," young adults brought to the country illegally as children.

An open seat on the Supreme Court was an important factor in rallying conservatives behind Trump's presidential election campaign in 2016. Trump quickly delivered on that promise by selecting Neil Gorsuch, who has become one of the most conservative justices. Trump has also filled a record-breaking number of seats on the influential federal appeals courts and District Courts with the enthusiastic backing of the Senate. Trump appeared to be excited about the new opportunity to reshape the federal judiciary in a conservative direction.

Title: Iowa Poll Shows President Trump Leading in Head-to-Head Matchups Against Warren and Biden, Sanders Ahead of Trump, Harris Struggles in Iowa

Article:

A new Emerson College poll released this week shows President Donald Trump edging out Democrat frontrunners Sen. Elizabeth Warren (D-MA) and Joe Biden (D) in hypothetical general election matchups in Iowa. The poll, taken October 13-16, 2019, among 888 registered voters in Iowa, showed the president leading both Warren and Biden 51 percent to 49 percent. Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-VT), however, appeared to hold an advantage in a hypothetical matchup, leading the president by two points, 51 percent to Trump's 49 percent.

The poll results indicate that Sanders' lead against the president comes despite the fact that he is not currently leading the Democrat field in Iowa. Instead, Warren and Biden are tied with 23 percent support each, followed by Mayor Pete Buttigieg (D) with 16 percent support. Sanders fell to fourth place with 13 percent support, followed by Andrew Yang (D), Gov. Steve Bullock (D), and Sen. Cory Booker (D-NJ) with 5 percent, 4 percent, and 3 percent, respectively.

The poll also showed some trouble for Sen. Kamala Harris (D-CA), who has been trying to revive her floundering campaign by focusing on Iowa. In September, Harris signaled a switch in campaign strategies, telling a colleague that she is "f*cking moving to Iowa." Despite her efforts, she was only able to garner 2 percent support in the state, alongside Rep. Tulsi Gabbard (D-HI) and Tom Steyer (D).

The poll also showed that more Iowans oppose impeachment than support it, 48 percent to 42 percent. Impeachment does not appear to be a top priority among Iowans, with only 6 percent considering it an important factor in choosing whom to support for president. Thirty-three percent said the economy, 19 percent said health care, and 10 percent chose "social issues."

"The Democrats have some work to do in Iowa convincing voters that impeachment is a top priority of Congress; 67 percent of Democrats in Iowa support impeaching the president, but only 10 percent identify it as the most important issue in deciding their vote for president," Emerson Polling Director Spencer Kimball said.

Title: Obama Compares Marijuana to Alcohol, Expresses Concern Over Disparities in Marijuana-Related Incarceration

Article:

In a recent interview with The New Yorker, President Barack Obama weighed in on the ongoing debate about marijuana legalization. Citing his personal experience with marijuana as a child, Obama stated that he views marijuana as a "bad habit" and a vice, not significantly more dangerous than alcohol or cigarettes.

When asked whether marijuana is less dangerous than alcohol, the president, after a pause, responded that it is "in terms of its impact on the individual consumer." However, he emphasized that he does not encourage marijuana use and has warned his daughters about the drug.

One issue that concerns Obama is the disproportionate incarceration rates of minorities and those in poverty for marijuana-related offenses. He noted the hypocrisy of individual users receiving long sentences while those who wrote the laws "have probably done the same thing."

Regarding the legalization of marijuana in Colorado and Washington state, Obama expressed support, stating, "It's important for it to go forward." He argued that it is crucial for society to avoid a situation where a large number of people have broken the law, but only a select few are punished.

However, Obama cautioned against overstating the benefits of marijuana legalization, stating that the new laws in Colorado and Washington state will present challenges and could lead to tougher debates on harder drugs in the future. He raised the question of whether society would be open to the idea of legalizing other drugs if they could be calibrated to cause less harm than alcohol or tobacco.

In conclusion, President Obama has compared marijuana to alcohol and cigarettes in terms of individual consumer impact, but expressed concern over the disproportionate incarceration rates for marijuana-related offenses. He supports the legalization of marijuana in states like Colorado and Washington, but cautions against overstating the benefits and potential challenges that may arise from such legalization.
