Title: The Left's Historical Aversion to Fighting Major Evils: A Focus on Communism and Islamism

Article:

The article discusses the historical tendency of the political left to prioritize lesser or perceived evils over major, tangible threats. The author argues that during the Cold War, the left was more focused on opposing anti-Communism than fighting Communism itself, and this pattern is repeating with the current threat of totalitarian Islam, or Islamism.

During the Cold War, many liberals and conservatives fought Communism, but the left opposed anti-Communism. The left regarded the Cold War as a mere conflict between two powers, rather than a battle against a significant evil. They criticized Ronald Reagan's labeling of the Soviet Union as an "evil empire" and often dismissed anti-Communist efforts as "cold war" mentality.

In the contemporary context, the left is similarly focused on fighting against anti-Islamists, rather than Islamists. The left labels those fighting Islamism as "Islamophobes" and "racists," while ignoring the threat of totalitarian Islam. The author argues that, historically, the left has done more to enable Communist evil than to stop it, and the same holds true for Islamism.

The article suggests that the left's moral clarity lies not in fighting real evils, but in fighting perceived or lesser evils. The left's focus on fighting racism, sexism, and Nazis in America is criticized as misguided, given that America is the least racist multiracial society in history. The author argues that fighting Nazis in America in 2017 is an act of moral onanism, while fighting Nazis during the Nazi regime in Germany was an act of moral heroism.

The article also mentions that the left fights religious Americans, particularly religious Christian Americans, and conservatives who oppose their views. The left is also heavily involved in the fight against global warming. The author concludes by stating that the real fight against evil in the world today is not against carbon emissions, but against Islamism.

The article does not provide specific examples of the left's current actions against statues, but it suggests that the left is in the vanguard of fighting statues, despite being AWOL against Communism and Islamism. The author's argument is that the left prioritizes symbolic battles over real, tangible threats to society.

Title: Congress to Vote on Keystone XL Pipeline Amidst Louisiana Senate Race

Article:

Two bills that authorize the construction of the contentious Keystone XL pipeline are set for a vote in Congress, as their sponsors, Sen. Mary Landrieu (D-La.) and Rep. Bill Cassidy (R-La.), prepare for a runoff election on December 6 to determine the Senate seat winner.

On the Senate floor, Landrieu advocated for action on the Canada-to-Texas pipeline project, stating, "I believe with a push we could actually get the votes that we need to pass the Keystone pipeline." Shortly after, Republican leaders in the House scheduled a vote for Thursday on a Keystone bill sponsored by Landrieu's rival, Cassidy.

The pipeline, developed by energy company TransCanada, would transport tar sands oil from Canada to Texas. It has been a divisive issue, with proponents arguing that it would create thousands of jobs, while opponents claim that tar sands oil is too costly and toxic to refine. While one side maintains that the plan would strengthen the energy industry, the other asserts it would increase greenhouse gas emissions.

Concerned landowners along the pipeline's proposed path have also voiced their opposition, expressing concerns about property disruption and potential damage to farms, particularly in the event of a leak. In February, a Nebraska judge invalidated a 2012 law that allowed part of the pipeline to run through the state.

The Associated Press reports that the Obama administration is not favorable towards news of a vote on the matter:

"While the White House did not issue a direct veto threat, spokesman Josh Earnest said President Barack Obama holds a 'dim view' of legislative efforts to compel action on the project. Earnest reiterated Obama's preference for evaluating the pipeline through a long-stalled State Department review."

Title: Vanessa Trump Speaks Out on Hospitalization After White Powder Incident Involving Donald Trump Jr.

Article:

Vanessa Trump, the ex-wife of Donald Trump Jr., has shared her account of a white powder incident that occurred last February, when she was rushed to the hospital after opening an envelope containing the substance. In a statement to Axios on Friday, she described the event as "personal" and a "cowardly act."

"This is personal for me because I know firsthand what it is like to be targeted and terrorized by a coward with a vendetta," she said.

According to her statement, she was hospitalized in New York City along with two other individuals who were present at the residence when she opened the envelope. She reportedly felt sick and started coughing after the incident. The authorities later identified the substance as cornstarch.

"I was rushed to the hospital, evaluated, and put on Cipro [an antibiotic] for the longest two weeks of my life, and while they worked to identify whether the white powder was deadly, I spent the entire time thinking about the horrifying possibility that I would never see my five beautiful children again," her statement reads.

"It was a cowardly act against a mother. And even today, every time I open the mail, I feel the same fear in my heart as I did that day," she added.

Trump, who is soon to divorce from her husband with whom she shares five children, condemned the recent bomb scares against prominent Democrats, including former President Barack Obama.

"These recent acts are the acts of a coward and nothing more than terrorism, pure and simple. No one, regardless of political party or ideology, should ever have to go through what I went through," Trump said.

In response to his ex-wife's statement, Donald Trump Jr. tweeted, "I am so proud of the mother of my children for sharing this story, which caused our family so much pain. These acts of terror are not owned by one political party. I wish all Americans would acknowledge that fact and condemn all violence. Thank you, Vanessa."

Earlier this month, Daniel Frisiello, the man accused of sending the powder-filled letters to Trump Jr. and other prominent Democrats, pleaded guilty. He will be sentenced in January and has agreed not to appeal his sentence if it is 7 1/4 years or less. One of the messages sent to Trump Jr. read, "You are an awful, awful person. I am surprised that your father lets you speak on TV. You, the family idiot, Eric, looks smart." The message continued, "This is the reason why people hate you, so you are getting what you deserve."

Title: BJP Tweet Sparks Controversy Over National Register of Citizens

Article:

India's ruling Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) has faced criticism for a tweet that some perceive as mocking a phrase used by anti-Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) protesters. The slogan "Kaaghaz Nahi Dikhayenge Hum" (we will not show the documents) has been a common refrain during the more than seven weeks of protests against the CAA.

The BJP tweet, posted on February 8, reads: "Keep the documents safe, you will need to show them again during # NPR exercise." The tweet has garnered over 31,000 likes and has been retweeted more than 10,000 times. Critics argue that the tweet threatens protesters and is a response to the planned National Register of Citizens (NRC).

The government has yet to decide on the implementation of the NRC, but it wants to proceed with the National Population Register (NPR), which critics say is a precursor to the NRC. The tweet has sparked controversy, with some accusing the right-wing party of undermining dissent and threatening protesters.

Senior journalist Suhasini Haider tweeted, "This taunting and mocking tone towards a minority by the ruling party is not just frightening; it is against everything India stands for." Gazala Wahab, assistant professor at JNU's Centre for the Study of Law and Governance, said, "There is reason to believe that the party's bigoted dog-whistling is the true intent, and the union government's denials are not taken seriously even by the party in power itself."

The BJP's Karnataka handle has previously come under fire for controversial tweets. Last month, it posted a tweet comparing a student from Jawaharlal Nehru University (JNU) with a gunman who fired at protesters near Jamia Millia Islamia (JMI) university in New Delhi.

Even some BJP supporters have taken exception to the tone of the tweet. Amrita Bhinder, a vocal supporter of the BJP and a former member of the Bharatiya Janata Yuva Morcha [the BJP youth wing], wrote, "Not done! Adds to the fear factor! Derails PM Modi's pitch. Please be sensible."

Delhi-based activist Shabnam Hashmi told ███ that the Karnataka BJP is "menacingly offensive" and is constantly creating an atmosphere of "hate and polarisation." She said, "It seems to say whether you [Muslims] like it or not, you will have to show the documents during NPR. Not only Muslims but all marginalised sections will suffer heavily during the NRC process, the first step of which begins with NPR."

BJP leaders from Karnataka have been accused of whipping up a xenophobic frenzy, with the state government cracking down on undocumented immigrants from Bangladesh. Last month, hundreds of people were rendered homeless after authorities demolished a slum in the state capital of Bengaluru, also known as the Silicon Valley of India, over rumours it was inhabited by Bangladeshis. It later turned out that all residents were Indian citizens.

Tejasvi Surya, a BJP member of parliament from Karnataka, has been accused of fear-mongering and Islamophobia. "Shaheen Bagh is [a] symbol of Islamic fanaticism in garb of constitutional secularism," he tweeted, referring to the epicentre of anti-CAA protests.

Critics say the citizenship law, which fast-tracks citizenship for non-Muslims from three neighbouring countries, goes against the country's secular constitution. The law, along with the proposed nationwide NRC, has instilled fear among the country's Muslims, who form nearly 15 percent of India's 1.3 billion population.

India has witnessed massive protests after the BJP-led government passed the controversial Citizenship Amendment Act in December last year. Nearly 30 people have died in the anti-CAA protests across the country so far. A similar exercise conducted in the northeastern state of Assam excluded nearly two million people from the citizenship list last year.

The government of Prime Minister Narendra Modi has said no individual will be required to submit any document for the NPR survey, but the tweet by Karnataka BJP says otherwise. BJP spokesman Nalin Kohli also said the NPR does not require citizenship documents. "The tweet by the Karnataka BJP handle… leads to an unnecessary confusion because the NPR does not require any documents and it has been reiterated by the union government on a number of occasions," he said.

Title: Lawmakers Introduce Bill to Enhance Long-Term Budget Transparency: The INFORM Act

Article:

Senators John Thune (R-SD) and Tim Kaine (D-VA) have introduced a bill in Congress, known as the Intergenerational Financial Obligations Reform Act (INFORM), to increase transparency in the budget process and require long-term fiscal planning. The bill aims to provide a clearer picture of the impact of current and future budget decisions on future generations.

The senators expressed concern about the short-term focus of Washington's fiscal thinking, which they believe has led to a lack of information about long-term budget realities. They argue that this lack of information could place significant financial burdens on future generations.

The INFORM Act would require the president to provide a detailed accounting of the administration's budget and policy recommendations, as well as predictions of economic health, in terms of their impact on future generations. Additionally, the Government Accountability Office (GAO) would be tasked with providing an annual analysis of the impact of future budget realities on generations to come and accounting for any fiscal gaps.

The bill's approach, known as generational accounting and fiscal gap analysis, would examine the full scope of the government's obligations, both present and future, and assess the impact those obligations will have on current and future generations. Presidents Bill Clinton and George H.W. Bush each used this tool in submitting executive budgets.

The senators emphasized the importance of young Americans understanding the implications of current lawmakers' decisions for their future. They believe that the INFORM Act will help improve the fiscal health of the country by enabling better decision-making.

The senators' statement underscores a call for more long-term planning in Washington, as opposed to the current practice of short-term budgeting that ignores long-term consequences. The INFORM Act is intended to address this issue by providing a clearer picture of the long-term impact of budget decisions on future generations.

Title: Permanent Work-from-Home Policies Likely as a Result of COVID-19 Pandemic, Experts Say

Article:

The coronavirus pandemic has led to a significant shift in the U.S. workforce, with millions of employees transitioning from office life to working from home. As the pandemic continues, companies and their employees are preparing for several more months of remote work, with some questioning whether some workers will ever return to the office.

Prior to the pandemic, less than 4% of the U.S. workforce worked remotely. In a matter of weeks, this number grew to include approximately a third of all workers in the country. Large companies, particularly those in the tech sector, have extended their work-from-home periods until the end of the year, with Twitter becoming the first major firm to allow employees to work permanently from home if they choose.

Industry experts predict that a significant portion of workers will not return to the office, citing benefits for both employees and companies. Employees save time and money on commuting and have more opportunities to spend time with their families, while companies could see financial benefits from cutting spending on expensive real estate and reducing the cost of maintaining office space.

Companies that were hesitant to allow remote work have found that concerns about lost productivity and harm to company culture are unfounded, according to labor analysts. The pandemic has also forced companies to tackle the expense and logistical challenges that may have been barriers to broad work-from-home policies.

However, some are skeptical that the pandemic will lead to permanent changes. While working from home may be beneficial for some employees, it has been a strain for others, potentially leading to increased depression and loneliness. Certain industries that rely on creativity and problem-solving may fear that work will suffer without in-person collaboration. Other firms might be reluctant to surrender the control that comes from having all employees in the same place.

One thing is certain: many employees have proven they can effectively work from home, and companies are expected to continue letting many do so for a long time. The economic impact of the pandemic will likely force many employers to cut costs, and allowing workers to work from home is an easy solution, one that's less painful than layoffs. Executives and managers have the opportunity to choose quality work over quantity, valuing creative ideas that emerge during a midday hike or meditation session, rather than putting in face time at the office. They can stop rewarding the faster response over the better response, or the longer workday over a more productive workday.

As we sink into a recession, the job market will be tight for everyone. That means that while employers could offer benefits like working from home, they might not feel the need to. Sure, an employee might feel safer and happier if they don't expose themselves to germs on the subway and in the office. But with fewer job openings, a company can probably find someone else who doesn't mind coming in.

Title: Trump to Meet with North Korean Leader: Potential Historic Summit or Diplomatic Risk?

Article:

President Donald Trump has accepted an invitation to meet with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un, marking a potential historic summit that could lead to the removal of North Korea's nuclear weapons. The meeting is set to take place before May, pending various conditions and negotiations.

The invitation and Trump's acceptance come amidst a series of diplomatic overtures from North Korea, a move that, if successful, could be compared to President Nixon's visit to China and the collapse of the Soviet Union in terms of historical significance.

However, the path to this potential meeting is fraught with uncertainty, and much remains to be determined before the two leaders sit down for talks. The location, terms, and conditions of the meeting are still under negotiation, with speculation that it may take place along the Demilitarized Zone (DMZ) separating North and South Korea.

To ensure the sincerity of North Korea's peace offering and to avoid being manipulated in negotiations, President Trump must carefully navigate the diplomatic process. Here are some recommendations for the Trump administration:

1. Insist on the meeting taking place in South Korea, ideally at the DMZ, to avoid legitimizing North Korea and to maintain a strong U.S. presence in the region.
2. Maintain planned U.S.-South Korea joint military exercises, as North Korea has trained its army all winter long.
3. Refrain from offering economic incentives to North Korea, such as food aid or a relaxation of economic sanctions, to prevent the appearance of bribery.
4. Require North Korea to provide a preliminary roadmap for denuclearization, to prevent stalling tactics and the continued development of nuclear weapons and missiles.

If North Korea fails to offer even a preliminary roadmap for denuclearization, President Trump should decline the invitation, as it may indicate that Kim Jong Un is merely seeking sanctions relief and not genuinely interested in denuclearization.

In conclusion, while the potential for a historic summit between Trump and Kim Jong Un is exciting, the road to such a meeting is uncertain and fraught with potential pitfalls. The Trump administration must approach the negotiations with caution, ensuring that North Korea's intentions are sincere and that the U.S. does not inadvertently legitimize or reward North Korea's human rights abuses.

Title: Gabrielle Giffords' Super PAC Takes Tougher Stance on Gun Control Advocacy

Article:

In the aftermath of the 2011 Tucson shooting that left then-Rep. Gabrielle Giffords critically injured, the United States has witnessed numerous mass shootings, including the 2012 Aurora, Colorado, movie theater shooting and the Sandy Hook Elementary School shooting in Newtown, Connecticut. These events led to a renewed push for gun control legislation, with President Obama and many members of Congress advocating for stricter background checks for gun buyers.

Despite widespread public support for such measures, a Republican Senate filibuster thwarted the effort in 2012. In response, Gabrielle Giffords, who retired from Congress and became an ardent advocate for stricter background checks, has taken a more assertive approach in her advocacy.

Giffords' super PAC, Americans for Responsible Solutions, is reportedly employing tougher tactics in the 2023 election cycle. One of the group's ads targets Republican Martha McSally, a retired Air Force pilot running for the Arizona seat previously held by Giffords. The ad features a heart-wrenching testimonial from a woman named Vicki, who recounts the murder of her 19-year-old daughter by an enraged ex-boyfriend. The ad alleges that McSally opposes making it harder for stalkers to obtain a gun.

The ad has been described as "tough" and "emotional" by political analysts. The editorial board of the Arizona Republic has criticized the ad, stating that it exploits a family's tragedy for political gain.

Gabrielle Giffords and her team are reportedly deeply involved in the making of the ads. The former congresswoman, known for her decency and good judgment during her time in office, is under no obligation to adhere to superficial "civility" standards. She has tried to unite Democrats and Republicans behind new gun legislation in the past, but those efforts did not yield significant results.

Now, Giffords is taking a more confrontational approach, tying politicians who resist expanded background checks to the outcomes of mass shootings. The ad featuring Vicki is one example of this strategy. The ad's purpose is to highlight the connection between lax gun policies and instances of gun violence.

Gabrielle Giffords' advocacy for stricter gun laws continues, even as some criticize her tactics as being too aggressive or exploitative. The former congresswoman was a victim of gun violence herself and is determined to prevent others from suffering a similar fate.

Title: Debt Limit Negotiations: Controversial Actions of Conservative Groups Overshadow Final Details of Deal

Article:

As the debt limit negotiations approach a resolution, two perspectives on the standoff have emerged. One interpretation suggests the entire conflict, now in its final stages, is a mere display of political posturing with little substance. The other, held by some movement conservatives, portrays the drama as a modern-day reenactment of the Battle of Gettysburg.

The Associated Press article, titled "Debt limit defeat turns conservatives into neo-Confederate fantasists," presents a stark contrast between the reality of the situation and the sensational narratives being propagated by conservative news outlets. The article highlights several instances of controversial behavior by conservative protesters, including the display of Confederate flags and calls for violence against the President and his administration.

The article notes that these actions are being met with skepticism and concern, as they are not representative of the broader public opinion. The author suggests that these actions are the result of desperation and delusion among conservative dead-enders, as the deadline for a resolution approaches and the parties are haggling over minor details.

The article also discusses the ongoing negotiations between Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid and Republican leader Mitch McConnell, who are quibbling over the specifics of the debt limit increase and government funding bill. The final points of contention include the size of the debt limit increase, the duration of government funding, and the funding level.

The article concludes by mentioning the actions of Senator Lindsey Graham, who has threatened to use the Senate's procedural rules to push a deal past the October 17 deadline, unless he is guaranteed a vote on a measure to strip members and aides of their employer-provided health care compensation. The potential consequences of such a move are discussed, as well as the possibility of other senators using it as a precedent to make larger demands, potentially leading to an accidental breach of the debt limit deadline.

Title: Dispute Over Health Care Subsidies: A Legal and Political Controversy

Article:

The Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act, President Obama's most significant legislative achievement, is facing a dispute over premium tax credits for health insurance. The Congressional Budget Office predicts that 23 million uninsured people will gain coverage through exchanges, with 22 million of them qualifying for subsidies, averaging over $6,000 per person annually. These subsidies, in the form of tax credits, will be available to individuals with incomes from the poverty level up to four times that amount.

The law states that subsidies will be provided to residents of a state to help defray the cost of health plans offered "through an exchange established by the state." A rule issued by the Obama administration allows tax credits for insurance bought in either a state or a federal exchange.

The dispute revolves around the interpretation of the statutory language. Some argue that the law's language is explicit, stating that subsidies are for state-run exchanges, and the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) is attempting to provide subsidies for all insurance exchanges, which will likely be challenged.

Representative Phil Roe, a Republican from Tennessee, and another Tennessee Republican, Scott DesJarlais, have introduced a bill to nullify the IRS rule. Douglas H. Shulman, the I.R.S. commissioner, defended the rule as consistent with the intent of Congress.

The political brawling over health care will continue this week on Capitol Hill, with the House planning to vote on a Republican measure to repeal the health care law. Democrats, who control the Senate, say repeal efforts have no chance of success there.

The dispute over subsidies involves a serious legal issue, according to James F. Blumstein, a professor of constitutional and health law at Vanderbilt University. He stated that the IRS's interpretation will likely be challenged by someone, possibly an employer penalized because one or more of its employees receive subsidies through a federal exchange.

Michael F. Cannon, director of health policy studies at the libertarian Cato Institute, noted the link between subsidies and penalties as a crucial part of the law. He explained that if workers cannot receive subsidies in states with a federal exchange, their employers cannot be penalized, which would hobble federal efforts to get employers to offer coverage in those states.

Prof. Timothy S. Jost, an expert on health law at Washington and Lee University, described the issue as a drafting error that should be obvious to anyone who understands the new health care law. He supports the law but believes Congress made an error in not including premium tax credits for the citizens of states that end up with a federal exchange.

Title: DHS Secretary Nielsen's Resignation and the Future of U.S. Immigration Policy

Article:

The resignation of Department of Homeland Security (DHS) Secretary Kirstjen Nielsen has sparked debate over the future of U.S. immigration policy and the potential appointment of a successor who may be more aligned with President Donald Trump's hardline stance.

Nielsen, who oversaw several controversial immigration policies during her tenure, was reportedly criticized by the president for perceived weakness on border security issues. Despite this, she resisted some of Trump's more contentious demands, such as the reinstatement of family separations and the blocking of asylum seekers.

Nielsen's most notable actions include the implementation of the family separation policy at the southern border, the design of a plan to limit asylum-seekers, and the enforcement of a policy deemed unlawful that prevented immigrants from applying for asylum if they entered the country illegally.

Acting DHS Secretary Kevin McAleenan, who is expected to take over from Nielsen, has expressed a more compassionate approach to immigration, advocating for a fast and responsible screening process and referring to migrants as "vulnerable families" in need of humanitarian treatment.

The effectiveness of U.S. aid to Central America, a point of contention between McAleenan and the president, is another area of potential contrast between the acting secretary and the administration's hardline immigration policies.

The delicate balance between securing the U.S. border and protecting vulnerable asylum seekers is a long-standing issue in U.S. immigration law. Both domestic and international law prohibit the U.S. from refusing entry to people in danger of persecution in their home countries, and offer additional due-process protections to asylum seekers, children, and families.

The resignation of Nielsen and other DHS officials has raised concerns about the direction of the agency under the Trump administration. Some argue that the new era of DHS will prioritize the president's nativist goals, regardless of the law.

The future role of McAleenan in shaping U.S. immigration policy remains uncertain, as does the extent to which he will align with Trump's hardline stance on immigration. The president's anger towards Nielsen is seen by some as a reflection of his dissatisfaction with the delicate balance in U.S. immigration law.

In the absence of an explicit quid pro quo agreement, the context and circumstances surrounding the administration's immigration policies will likely become the focus of ongoing investigation and debate. The extent to which this evidence will lead to impeachment or significant policy changes remains to be seen.

Title: Iranian Officials Reject Trump's Offer for Unconditional Meeting with No Value, Cite Past Negotiations and Economic Pressures

Article:

Iranian officials have expressed opposition to U.S. President Donald Trump's offer for a meeting with no preconditions, stating that such talks would have "no value" and be a "humiliation." The U.S. and Iran have not held leader-to- leader meetings since before the 1979 Iranian revolution.

In May, the U.S. abandoned a deal that curbed Iran's nuclear activities in return for the lifting of sanctions. The U.S. is deeply suspicious of Iranian activity in the Middle East and is an ally of Israel and Saudi Arabia, two of Iran's foes.

On Monday, Mr. Trump said he was open to meeting the Iranian side, stating, "I'd meet with anybody. I believe in meetings... if they want to meet, we'll meet." However, Iranian officials have made it clear that only "returning to the nuclear deal" and "respecting the Iranian nation's rights" would pave the way for talks.

Iran's deputy speaker, Ali Motahari, told state news agency Irna that the U.S. withdrawal from the nuclear deal meant that "negotiation with the Americans would be a humiliation now." Kamal Kharazi, the head of Iran's Strategic Council of Foreign Relations, said there was "no value in Trump's proposal" given Iran's "bad experiences in negotiations with America" and "US officials' violations of their commitments."

The Trump administration regards Iran as a destabilizing force in the Middle East, arguing that the nuclear deal enabled Iran to pursue a more assertive regional policy. Iran has sent hundreds of troops and thousands of volunteer militiamen to Syria, and has strengthened its military presence there. Gulf states have accused Iran of backing Yemen's Houthi rebels with both money and weapons, though Iran has denied this. Saudi Arabia, a key U.S. ally, is a major adversary of Iran and has repeatedly warned about Iran's intentions.

In May, Mr. Trump called the nuclear accord - or Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action (JCPOA) - a "horrible, one-sided deal." He alleged that the deal did not restrict Iran's "destabilizing activities" in the region enough. Analysts also cited the influence of White House hawks including U.S. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo and National Security Adviser John Bolton, and Mr. Trump's tendency to target major policies of his predecessor, Barack Obama.

Iran insists its nuclear program is entirely peaceful, and its compliance with the deal has been verified by the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA), which has said Iran is honoring its commitments. Iran is one of the world's largest oil producers, with exports worth billions of dollars each year. It is already feeling economic pressures, and has seen large-scale protests over rising prices and a decline in the value of its currency, the rial.

Title: Congresswomen Urge Inclusion of Student Debt Cancellation in Next COVID-19 Relief Package

Article:

A group of House representatives, led by Ilhan Omar, Ayanna Pressley, and Alma Adams, have sent a public letter to House Speaker Nancy Pelosi and House Minority Leader Kevin McCarthy, urging them to include student debt cancellation and loan relief in the next COVID-19 relief package. The letter, signed by an additional 28 members of Congress, including Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez and Joe Kennedy III, argues that more relief is necessary to address the economic crisis caused by the pandemic.

The CARES Act, the first relief package, postponed payments for some federal student loan borrowers until September 2020. However, the congresswomen argue that this short-term relief does not reflect the long-term economic impact of the pandemic, which public health experts and economists estimate could last up to 18 months.

The letter proposes three solutions to the student loan crisis. The most aggressive solution is a one-time cancellation of at least $30,000 for all federal student loan borrowers. This, they argue, would disproportionately benefit vulnerable borrowers, potentially eliminating the loan balance of millions of low-income people and borrowers of color.

The CARES Act postponed payments for some federal student loan borrowers, but it excludes one in five borrowers, namely those with commercially held FFEL loans or Perkins Loans. The letter urges Congress to provide long-term payment relief for all federal student loan borrowers and to expand protections to those with private loans through cancellation, a suspension of payments and involuntary collections, as well as the opportunity to refinance any outstanding balance at lower interest rates.

Throughout the letter, the congresswomen highlight the disproportionate impact of the student loan burden on communities of color, particularly Black and Latinx communities. They note that these communities are not only experiencing the worst of the coronavirus pandemic but also face an unequal burden when it comes to student loans.

The bill for the next COVID-19 relief package is expected next week. The letter does not specify the exact amount of debt cancellation or the duration of the loan relief proposed in the bill.

Title: ISIS Blows Up 80-Year-Old Church in Tal Nasri, Syria

Article:

Assyrian Christians in Syria were celebrating Easter Sunday when militants from the Islamic State (ISIS) detonated an 80-year-old church in the Tal Nasri village, located in the western countryside of Hasaka province in northeastern Syria. The church, known as the Church of the Virgin Mary, was originally built in 1934 and is one of three main churches in the Assyrian village.

Since February, Tal Nasri has been under the control of the jihadist group led by self-proclaimed Caliph al-Baghdadi. Fighters from Kurdish militias and Christians who have taken up arms have been attempting to regain control of the village. According to reports, ISIS jihadists booby-trapped the church with explosives before detonating it.

The Assyrian International News Agency (AINA) reported that the church has been "leveled." Christians make up just 10% of Syria's mostly Muslim Sunni population, and this year's Assyrian Easter celebrations have been limited to prayers and masses due to the ongoing conflict in the country.

The bombing is the latest in a series of acts of destruction by ISIS, who have targeted places of worship in the areas they control. ISIS has already destroyed numerous religious sites and shrines, and have raged against any religious or artistic expression that does not conform to their worldview. They have razed temples, Sufi mosques, and churches, as well as destroying statues and archaeological finds with pickaxes.

In recent days, ISIS released a propaganda video showing a group of men engaged in destroying statues and parts of the facade of an old building in Hatra, a city of the ancient Parthian Empire. Another image released by ISIS shows the destruction of the monastery of Mar Behnam in Iraq.

In February, Islamist militants burned down the historic church of Tal Hurmoz, one of the oldest churches in Syria, and destroyed three other churches in the town of Tal Tamer in Hasaka province. All six UNESCO World Heritage Sites in Syria have been damaged.

Title: Vice President Pence Denies Preparing for 2020 Presidential Run, Calls New York Times Report "Fake News"

Article:

U.S. Vice President Mike Pence has denied that he is preparing for a presidential election run in 2020, stating that the suggestion is "disgraceful and offensive." The denial comes in response to a report by The New York Times that some Republicans were forming a "shadow campaign" as though President Donald Trump were not involved.

The report, published on Sunday, stated that multiple advisers to Pence had intimated to party donors that he would plan to run if Trump did not. The article also mentioned that Pence had kept a full political calendar and had created his own independent power base, including a political fund-raising group called the "Great America Committee."

However, Pence called the article "fake news" and stated that his entire team was focused on advancing Trump's agenda and seeing him re-elected in 2020. In a statement, Pence said, "The allegations in this article are categorically false and represent just the latest attempt by the media to divide this Administration."

The Times stood by its coverage, with spokeswoman Danielle Rhoades Ha stating in an email, "We are confident in the accuracy of our reporting and will let the story speak for itself."

Pence has good relations with conservative political groups and some of the Republican Party's big donors, including billionaire brothers Charles and David Koch. He is also a Trump loyalist, and there is typically little distinction between his public statements and the policies of the president.

However, as investigations deepen into Russia's alleged interference in the 2016 U.S. election and possible ties to members of Trump's campaign, Pence has put some distance between himself and the president on the best way to approach Moscow. On a trip to Eastern Europe last week, Pence condemned Russia's presence in the former Soviet republic of Georgia, with which Moscow fought a brief war in 2008. He also said ties with Russia would not improve until Moscow changed its stance on Ukraine and withdrew support for countries like Iran, Syria, and North Korea.

The U.S. Congress recently passed a bill imposing new sanctions on Russia with overwhelming bipartisan support, but Trump signed it into law last week with reluctance. "Our relationship with Russia is at an all-time & very dangerous low," Trump wrote on Twitter after signing the bill. "You can thank Congress."

Trump has described probes into his campaign's ties to Russia, including those underway in Congress and a Justice Department investigation headed by Special Counsel Robert Mueller, as a "witch hunt." The president has also sent mixed messages on whether he agrees with U.S. intelligence agencies' conclusions that Russia tried to intervene in the 2016 election to boost his chances of beating Democratic rival Hillary Clinton.

White House senior counselor Kellyanne Conway also dismissed the idea that Pence was looking at running for president in 2020. "It is absolutely true that the vice president is getting ready for 2020 - for re-election as vice president," Conway told ABC's "This Week" on Sunday. "Vice President Pence is a very loyal, very dutiful, but also incredibly effective vice president, and active vice president," said Conway, adding that she had worked for Pence for a decade as his pollster and senior adviser.

Title: Americans Favorably View Many Federal Agencies, Including CDC and HHS

Article:

A new study by ███ has found that Americans hold broadly favorable views of several federal agencies, including the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) and the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS), which are at the forefront of dealing with the COVID-19 pandemic. Other agencies, such as the Postal Service, the Census Bureau, and the Department of Homeland Security, also receive favorable ratings from the public.

The survey, conducted in March 2020 among 1,013 U.S. adults, found that 79% of respondents express a favorable opinion of the CDC, with large majorities of Republicans (84%) and Democrats (77%) holding positive views. Views of the CDC among Republicans have grown more positive in recent years, while Democrats' views have shown less change.

The survey also found that 80% of respondents view HHS favorably, up 17 percentage points since last fall. In 2013 and 2015, fewer than half of Republicans viewed this agency favorably. Majorities of Democrats have consistently expressed positive views of HHS (70% currently).

The survey found that more than three years into the Trump administration, larger shares of Republicans than Democrats express favorable opinions of eight of the ten government agencies included in the survey. For the other two agencies, the Postal Service and the IRS, nearly identical majorities in both parties have favorable opinions.

Republicans' views of the Justice Department improved after Donald Trump's election, while Democrats turned more negative. Even so, favorable views of the DOJ have increased sharply since September; currently, 76% of Republicans view the DOJ favorably, up from 61% last fall and the highest positive rating for the department in polling going back a decade. By comparison, 50% of Democrats feel favorably toward the Justice Department, little changed from the fall and among the lowest ratings in a decade.

Views of Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) remain polarized, with 77% of Republicans and Republican leaners viewing the agency favorably, compared with only 28% of Democrats and Democratic leaners.

With the decennial census underway, 77% of Americans overall view the Census Bureau favorably, compared with just 12% who hold an unfavorable view. The public holds positive views of several federal agencies, but ratings of the Postal Service continue to stand out, with an overwhelming 91% saying they have a favorable view of the mail delivery service.

Nine of the ten agencies included in the survey are viewed more favorably than unfavorably by the public. ICE is the only agency for which about equal shares express an unfavorable (45%) as favorable (46%) view. Among the agencies viewed in a positive light, the majorities viewing each favorably range from 91% for the Postal Service to 60% for the Justice Department.

About two-thirds view Veterans Affairs and the IRS favorably (both 65%), and slightly more hold favorable views of the Federal Reserve (69%) and the Department of Homeland Security (71%). For many federal agencies, there are only modest differences in ratings between Republicans and Democrats.

The widest partisan divide in the survey is in assessments of ICE, with Republicans and Republican leaners being 49 points more likely than Democrats and Democratic leaners to hold a favorable view of the agency (77% vs. 28%). The share of Republicans with a favorable view of ICE has increased 7 points since September 2019. Among Democrats, ratings of ICE remain overwhelmingly negative (64% view the agency unfavorably), though the share with a favorable view has increased since last fall (up 9 points). The overall gap in ratings of ICE between Republicans and Democrats remains about the same as it has been over the last few years.

As the Census Bureau launches its decennial census, majorities of both Republicans and Democrats hold positive views of the agency. Republicans' views of the Census Bureau have grown considerably more positive over the last two years, with 83% of Republicans viewing the Census Bureau favorably, compared with 66% who held a favorable view of the agency in 2018. Among Democrats, views of the Census Bureau have remained relatively stable, with about three-quarters of Democrats (76%) saying they hold favorable views of the agency today, views were similar in 2019 and 2018.

Title: Amtrak Train Collides with CSX Freight Train in South Carolina, Two Dead, 116 Injured

Article:

Two individuals were killed and 116 were injured in a collision between an Amtrak passenger train and a CSX freight train in Cayce, South Carolina, early Sunday morning. The incident occurred at approximately 2:35 am, with Amtrak Train 91, en route to Miami from New York, colliding with the CSX train.

According to reports, the Amtrak train derailed, carrying eight crewmembers and 139 passengers. The injured individuals were transported to local hospitals, with injuries ranging from minor scratches to broken bones. Approximately 5,000 gallons of fuel were spilled, but authorities stated there is "no threat to the public at this time."

The National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) has been called to investigate the incident. This marks the second fatal crash involving an Amtrak train in recent weeks.

South Carolina Governor Henry McMaster stated that the Amtrak train was on the wrong track, while the CSX freight train, which had no passengers aboard, was on its designated track. Amtrak stated that CSX owns and maintains the area where the collision occurred, with CSX controlling the dispatching of all trains and directing the signal systems.

Robert Sumwalt, chair of the NTSB, stated that one priority in the investigation is to recover data recorders to determine the speed of the Amtrak train at the point of collision.

Derek Pettaway, a passenger on one of the train's rear cars, told CNN that he was awakened by the impact and helped off the train "really quickly" by the crew. He went to the hospital and was discharged with minor whiplash before going to a shelter for passengers at Pine Ridge Middle School.

Local reporter Chad Mills reported that he was told by a source the casualty number isn't expected to rise and "we dodged a bullet on this one."

President Donald Trump was briefed on the incident and is receiving regular updates, according to White House deputy press secretary Lindsay Walters. The president also addressed the incident on Twitter.

The exact cause of the crash, or how fast either train was going at the time of the collision, remains unknown.

Title: U.S. Lifts Arms Embargo Against Vietnam, Boosting Defense Capabilities and Normalizing Relations

Article:

President Barack Obama on Monday fully lifted the United States' 41-year arms embargo against Vietnam, marking a significant step in the normalization of relations between the two countries. At a news conference in Hanoi, Obama stated, "This change will ensure that Vietnam has access to the equipment it needs to defend itself and removes a lingering vestige of the Cold War."

The move comes as a means of bolstering Vietnam's defenses against China, although President Obama denied this intention. He emphasized that the decision to lift the embargo was not based on China or any other considerations, but rather on the completion of the lengthy process of moving towards normalization with Vietnam.

In 2014, the U.S. partially lifted the embargo, but Vietnam sought full access as it navigates China's land reclamation and military construction in the disputed South China Sea. Vietnam has not made any purchases, but the removal of the remaining restrictions indicates that relations are fully normalized and opens the way to deeper security cooperation.

In response, China's Foreign Ministry praised the move, with a spokeswoman stating that normal and friendly relations between the U.S. and Vietnam would be conducive to regional stability. China itself remains under a weapons embargo imposed by the U.S. and European Union following the 1989 military crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrations centered on Beijing's Tiananmen Square.

Obama also addressed the South China Sea issue, stating that the U.S. and Vietnam share mutual concerns about maritime issues and the importance of maintaining freedom of navigation in the region. He clarified that although the U.S. does not take sides on the territorial disputes, it does support a diplomatic resolution based on "international norms" and not based on "who's the bigger party and can throw around their weight a little bit more," a reference to China.

While the announcement is a significant step in normalizing relations with Vietnam, Obama added that the country will not immediately receive a flood of weapons. Each U.S. arms sale will be reviewed on a case-by-case basis, he said, and will still need to meet strict requirements, including those related to human rights. Activists and members of Congress had hoped the president would wait to fully lift the embargo until Vietnam improved its human rights record.

Title: Historic Wins in the 2018 U.S. Elections: A Look at Diverse Trailblazers

Article:

Groundbreaking campaigns have shattered barriers in the 2018 U.S. elections, with a diverse group of candidates making history and reshaping the political landscape. This election has seen a record number of women, Native Americans, Muslims, Latinos, immigrants, millennials, and LGBT candidates running for office. As results continue to roll in, here are some of the key trailblazing candidates who have already won their races:

1. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez (New York): At 29 years old, Ocasio-Cortez has become the youngest woman ever elected to Congress. She unseated a 10-term incumbent in the June primary and will represent New York's 14th district.

2. Ayanna Pressley (Massachusetts): Pressley, the first black woman to serve on Boston's city council, made history again after defeating the 10-term incumbent Michael Capuano in the primary. She did not face a challenger in the general election and will represent Massachusetts' 7th district.

3. Rashida Tlaib (Michigan): Tlaib, a democratic socialist, has become the nation's first Palestinian-American woman in Congress and one of two Muslim women elected on Tuesday. She ran on a platform supporting Medicare for all, a $15 minimum wage, and abolishing ICE.

4. Ilhan Omar (Minnesota): Omar, also the first Somali-American in Congress, is a former refugee who spent the last four years as a state legislator. She ran on a progressive platform, including a $15 minimum wage and subsidizing higher education costs for low-income students.

5. Jared Polis (Colorado): Polis, who declared victory late on Tuesday night, has become the first openly gay governor in the U.S. He ran on a left-wing platform, which included single-payer healthcare, repeal of the death penalty, universal full-day preschool, and stronger gun laws.

6. Kate Brown (Oregon): Brown, who is bisexual, became the first openly LGBT person elected governor in 2016.

7. Sharice Davids (Kansas): Davids, an attorney and former MMA fighter, has become the first Native American congresswoman and the first lesbian congresswoman from Kansas.

8. Deb Haaland (New Mexico): Haaland, a citizen of the Pueblo of Laguna tribe, has become the first Native American woman to chair a state political party and the first Native American congresswoman in the U.S.

9. Marsha Blackburn (Tennessee): Blackburn has become the first female senator in Tennessee's history.

10. Janet Mills (Maine): Mills, the state's attorney general, has become Maine's first female governor.

11. Abby Finkenauer (Iowa): Finkenauer, at 29 years old, is one of the youngest people ever elected to the House and the first woman elected to Congress from Iowa.

12. Jahana Hayes (Connecticut): Hayes, the 2016 National Teacher of the Year and first-time political candidate, won her bid to represent Connecticut's 5th congressional district. She is the first black woman to represent the state in Congress.

13. Veronica Escobar and Sylvia Garcia (Texas): More than a third of the population of Texas may be Latino, but until Tuesday, no Latina had been elected to represent the state in Congress. Veronica Escobar won her race in El Paso, while Sylvia Garcia trounced her Republican opponent in Houston.

These trailblazing candidates are diversifying American politics and breaking barriers, with many more results still coming in.

Title: Huron Daily Tribune Reporter Fired After Expletive-Laced Voicemail to GOP Michigan Senate Candidate

Article:

The Huron Daily Tribune has terminated the employment of reporter Brenda Battel following an expletive-laced voicemail she left for GOP Michigan Senate candidate John James' campaign. The incident occurred Monday evening, hours after Battel's inadvertent insults went viral.

According to an exclusive report by The Daily Caller, Battel, whose LinkedIn and Facebook pages appeared to have been disabled, phoned Mr. James' campaign Monday afternoon seeking an interview for Wednesday to discuss Election Day's results. Thinking she had hung up the phone, Battel expressed her dismay at the prospect of Mr. James, an African-American Army veteran, potentially defeating incumbent Democratic Sen. Debbie Stabenow.

"Man, if he beats her … Jesus!", she exclaimed, The Daily Caller reported. After referring to Mr. James with an expletive, Battel added, "Whew, that would suck! But I don't think that's going to happen though."

The voice message, with Battel's contact information expunged, quickly spread online and, within hours, she was out of a job.

"I have listened to the voicemail left by Brenda Battel to Mr. James' campaign, and find no reason to defend this behavior," said Kate Hessling, editor of The Huron Daily Tribune, in a statement. "Brenda Battel's employment has been immediately terminated."

"The Huron Daily Tribune sincerely apologizes to Mr. James and to the public," Ms. Hessling's statement continued. "These statements do not represent the views of the Tribune as a whole, nor do they reflect the actions of a responsible journalist."

As of Monday night, The Huron Daily Tribune's website did not list Battel among the two reporters on staff. She had not responded to requests for comment Monday afternoon and was not reachable on Tuesday.

As Election Day approached, Mr. James found himself trailing Ms. Stabenow by 8.3 percentage points in the RealClearPolitics polling average, but that marked an improvement from the double-digit deficits Mr. James had through most of October. Some polls have shown an even closer margin.

"It shows you that some media will do anything to keep the status quo and career politicians in power," Tori Sachs, Mr. James' campaign manager, told The Daily Caller in an email. "The liberal media can't stand the idea of a job creator and combat veteran coming to Washington to shake up the system. This happened as we closed within the margin of error."

Title: Tentative Deal Reached Between Trump and Kim Jong Un: A Look at the Proposed Agreement and Its Implications

Article:

A tentative deal between United States President Donald Trump and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un, set to be finalized during their summit in Vietnam, has emerged. The agreement, as currently outlined, appears to be a significant victory for Kim Jong Un.

Under the proposed agreement, the U.S. would agree to lift some sanctions on North Korea and improve relations, in exchange for a commitment from Kim Jong Un to close down a key nuclear facility. The details of the agreement, as described by three individuals familiar with the negotiations who spoke on condition of anonymity to discuss sensitive diplomatic issues, are as follows:

1. Both countries will sign a peace declaration, symbolically ending the Korean War. The conflict, which ended in an armistice in 1953, is technically still ongoing. The agreement would effectively, although not officially, end hostilities between the two countries and significantly improve their relations.
2. North Korea will agree to return more remains of U.S. troops who died during the Korean War, although the number and timing are unclear. Last year, following the Trump-Kim summit in Singapore, North Korea returned the remains of 55 American service members.
3. The U.S. and North Korea will establish liaison offices, which are quasi-embassies with minimal authorities, in each other's nations. This will be the first concrete step toward normalizing diplomatic ties between the two longtime enemies.
4. North Korea will agree to stop producing materials for nuclear bombs at its Yongbyon facility. In exchange, the U.S. will push to lift some UN sanctions on Pyongyang so it can pursue joint economic projects with South Korea. It's also possible the deal will include other nuclear facilities, one source said.

It's important to note that the deal may still change before the summit on February 27 in Vietnam. However, the deal as it currently stands aligns with many expectations heading into the summit.

The most controversial aspect of the proposed deal is the promise from Kim to shutter the Yongbyon facility in exchange for some modest sanctions relief. The Yongbyon nuclear facility is considered the "heart" of North Korea's nuclear program, as it's the only known place where the country can make plutonium for nuclear bombs. If it shuts down, Pyongyang's ability to make plutonium-fueled nuclear weapons will be severely curtailed, although it would not mean the end of its nuclear program.

However, the deal's success hinges on Kim's commitment to allow international inspectors into the facility to verify that nuclear material production has ended. Without these inspections, there's no way to know if Kim has followed through on his promise. This is a move the leader may be reluctant to take, and even if he does so, he could always restart the shuttered facility once the inspectors leave, as his father, Kim Jong Il, did twice before, after deals with the U.S. collapsed.

Experts want any deal on closing Yongbyon to be extremely detailed, with clear and concise language to allow technical experts to monitor and verify each step in the process. If Trump moves to lift sanctions before Kim actually ends all production at Yongbyon, he will have offered a significant concession without receiving anything substantive in return.

By signing a peace declaration, both sides will reduce tensions and improve relations. By returning more troop remains to the U.S., North Korea will demonstrate its commitment to staying in America's good graces. However, the deal does not significantly advance the fundamental goal of denuclearizing North Korea and primarily rewards Kim with much-needed sanctions relief for making vague promises. In this sense, the deal is not a significant win for Trump but is a considerable victory for Kim Jong Un.

However, if this deal serves as a stepping stone to more comprehensive deals in the future, leading North Korea to dismantle its nuclear program, it could be viewed favorably in a few years.

Title: Vice President Pence Reveals Funding Source of Migrant Caravan, Glenn Beck Discusses Implications

Article:

During a media briefing on Tuesday, Vice President Mike Pence revealed that Honduran President Juan Orlando Hernandez stated that the migrant caravan currently traveling towards the southern U.S. border was organized by leftist organizations and financed by Venezuela. This information was discussed further on Wednesday's episode of "The Glenn Beck Radio Program."

Glenn Beck questioned the media's lack of concern regarding the caravan, stating, "Have you noticed that the press is not concerned at all about this caravan? They say the caravan's not going to make it up to the United States, that it's just nonsense and why are they talking about it. Really?"

Beck noted that the 7,000-person-strong migrant caravan appears to be both a political message and a weapon. He suggested that the caravan was organized in Honduras by a leftist political party to embarrass the current right-wing government. Beck also pointed out that moving such a large group of people over 2,500 miles is expensive, and questioned who is funding the food, water, medical care, transportation, and other necessities for the migrants.

Beck asked, "Who is writing the check for all of this?" He suggested that Venezuelan President Maduro, who is struggling financially, could be using the caravan as a means to attack the United States by organizing and funding thousands of people to flood the border. Beck also raised concerns about potential criminal elements, Venezuelan or Cuban spies, and terrorists among the migrants.

Listeners can watch the full episode on TheBlaze TV, with a free trial available for new subscribers. The "The Glenn Beck Radio Program" can also be found on TheBlaze weekdays from 9 a.m. to noon ET, and Beck can be followed on Facebook, Twitter, and YouTube.

Title: Intolerance of Disagreement in Transgender Debate Creeps into Law

Article:

A growing intolerance of disagreement in the debate over transgender issues is increasingly manifesting in legislation, with some local and federal authorities penalizing individuals and organizations for using "wrong" pronouns. This development has sparked controversy and concerns over freedom of speech and the right to conscience.

Yesterday, a heated debate erupted on Twitter over the use of pronouns in a Corner post discussing Chelsea Manning's release from prison. The author, in this case, faced backlash for using male pronouns to describe Manning, who identifies as a woman. The author was labeled a transphobe and faced other derogatory comments for refusing to identify Manning as a woman.

In New York City, the government has enacted legislation that punishes employers, landlords, businesses, and professionals who refuse to use an individual's preferred name, pronoun, or title if they do not conform to gender stereotypes. The New York City Human Rights Commission defines a "violation" of its human-rights law as refusing to use an individual's preferred name, pronoun, or title because they do not conform to gender stereotypes.

The Obama administration also issued guidance, since repealed, that required every federally funded educational institution in the United States to treat students consistent with their gender identity, even if their education records or identification documents indicate a different sex. The guidance also mandated that school staff and contractors use pronouns and names consistent with a transgender student's gender identity.

This compelled speech has been criticized as a violation of the rights of conscience of the speaker and a government effort to coerce verbal agreement with a contested and contentious personal, religious, cultural, and scientific debate. The issue has been compared to the West Virginia v. Barnette case, in which the Supreme Court ruled that the government cannot prescribe what beliefs individuals should hold or force them to express those beliefs through speech or action.

The author of the Corner post argues that using male pronouns to describe Chelsea Manning is not an act of bigotry but a reflection of biological reality. The author cites the biblical account of creation, which states that God created man and woman in His image. The author also rejects the notion that using male pronouns for Manning is a matter of manners, stating that such a definition of manners requires individuals to verbally consent to a fundamentally false and important premise.

The author concludes by expressing concern that dissent from this issue is seen as a "tell" for underlying bigotry and that the debate is beyond reasonable disagreement. The author also criticizes prominent transgender activist Parker Molloy for labeling disagreement on the issue as bigotry and for equating the use of incorrect pronouns with blasphemy in the secular faith of the illiberal Left.

The author calls for open and respectful conversations about pronoun usage, gender identity, and the reasons why a transgender person believes that deeply felt identity trumps biology in defining male and female. However, the author states that these conversations are increasingly hard to find and that dissent from this issue is seen as a "tell" for underlying bigotry. The author warns against the dangers of intolerance moving from irritation into censorship and calls for the preservation of free speech and the right to conscience in the debate over transgender issues.

Title: U.S. Stocks Retreat as Government Shutdown Looms; Dow, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite Decline

Article:

U.S. stocks experienced a broad-based retreat on Friday as a potential government shutdown loomed. The Dow Jones Industrial Average (DJI) dropped 0.33%, the S&P 500 (SP500) declined 0.07%, and the Nasdaq Composite Index (COMP) fell 0.05%.

Earlier in the week, the U.S. House passed a spending package that included $5 billion for President Trump's campaign-promised border wall. However, in the Senate, where 60 votes are required for passage of the spending bill, the measure appeared dead on arrival.

On Friday, shares initially rose as a durable goods report and a revision to the third-quarter gross domestic product—both weaker than expected—indicated that the Federal Reserve might have less reason to raise interest rates.

As the session progressed and a government shutdown appeared increasingly inevitable, the market experienced a broad-based decline. Shares of big capitalization and big tech companies led the retreat. Shares of Google parent Alphabet fell below the $1,000 level for the first time since April 4. The shares entered a bear market on Thursday and are currently down almost 23% from its record close of $1,285.50 on July 26.

Shares of packaged foods company Conagra Brands tumbled to a 52-week low after the company missed sales expectations. Other notable declines include Facebook (-0.66%), Netflix (-3.05%), and Amazon (-1.40%).

On Thursday, U.S. shares tumbled, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling nearly 500 points or about 2% and sliding below 23,000 for the first time in 14 months. The tech-heavy Nasdaq Composite also plummeted, now flirting with bear market territory. The Nasdaq and the S&P 500 lost over 1% during the session. At the same time, volatility spiked to the highest level since February.

The selling accelerated after President Trump told House Republican leaders on Thursday he will not sign a Senate-passed spending package that does not include sought-after border security funds, upending negotiations to avert a government shutdown by the end of the week, as reported by Fox News.

International markets also experienced declines. Japan's Nikkei finished the session lower by 1.1% and down 5.6% for the week. China's Shanghai Composite ended the day down 0.8% and off 3% for the week. In Hong Kong, the Hang Seng index closed out the day higher by 0.5%, but fell 1.3% for the week. In European trading, London's FTSE traded little changed, Germany's DAX added 0.2%, and France's CAC was little changed.

Title: Gary Johnson's Presidential Campaign Gains Momentum Across the U.S.

Article:

Gary Johnson, the Libertarian Party's presidential candidate, has been touring the country, recently moving from Miami to Las Vegas. In Las Vegas, Johnson addressed a "high energy" crowd, emphasizing his commitment to individual choice and limited government intervention.

Johnson expressed his support for gay marriage, abortion rights, and the decriminalization of marijuana. He also criticized the death penalty as a flawed public policy. In Nevada, Johnson encouraged voters to support the November referendum that could legalize recreational marijuana for adults over 21.

The Libertarian ticket, including Johnson and his running mate, Bill Weld, are hopeful about meeting the Commission on Presidential Debates' 15 percent in five polls threshold, although they may not reach it for the first debate on September 26. Weld suggested that if they do not meet the polling benchmark for the initial debate, they could potentially qualify for a later debate, with the final debate scheduled for October 19 at the University of Nevada, Las Vegas (UNLV).

Joe Brezny, a spokesman for the Coalition to Regulate Marijuana Like Alcohol and a former campaign manager for Mitt Romney's presidential bid, expressed his support for Johnson and Weld. Brezny stated, "I watched some good people nominate the least electable person in mankind."

Weld emphasized the fiscal conservatism he and Johnson demonstrated during their gubernatorial tenures as crucial for Washington D.C. Johnson pledged that, if elected, he would present Congress with a balanced budget within the first 100 days of his presidency.

Montana political analysts believe Johnson could easily double his 3 percent from the 2012 election, as Montana voters have historically supported candidates outside of the two major political parties. In 2012, Libertarian candidate Dan Cox received 6.5 percent of the vote in Montana's Senate race, potentially influencing the outcome of the race between Republican Denny Rehberg and incumbent Sen. Jon Tester, a Democrat.

If Johnson manages to secure $10 million in direct campaign donations, he may face the risk of receiving Secret Service protection. The campaign reported pulling $3 million from 92,000 distinct donors in just this month.

In Maine, Johnson will be appearing on August 26. He has gained support from voters like Heidi Sawyer, who appreciates his fiscal conservatism, small government approach, and opposition to wasteful spending. Sawyer, a socially liberal voter, finds appeal in Johnson's stance on issues like gay marriage and foreign policy.

To maintain ballot status as an official party in Maine, the Libertarian Party needs 10,000 registered voters who are enrolled in the party to cast ballots in the General Election, according to the state government. This requirement was discussed in a previous report on Maine's challenging but ultimately successful fight to secure a place on the ballot this year.

Title: Republican Party's Handling of Donald Trump Could Lead to Third-Party Candidacy, Potential Nightmare Scenario

Article:

The Republican Party's public rebuke of billionaire businessman Donald Trump for his inflammatory comments may inadvertently lead to a third-party presidential candidacy by Trump, a potential nightmare scenario for the GOP establishment. This scenario would involve a populist outsider attacking the Republican nominee from the right in the general election, raising issues and attracting votes with his rhetoric on topics like illegal immigration.

Ralph Nader, a multiple-time third-party presidential candidate who is believed to have cost Democrat Al Gore the 2000 election by running to his left, warned that the Republican Party establishment is "playing with nitroglycerine" when they go after Trump and attempt to minimize him or exclude him from the party. A jilted Trump as a third-party candidate could "blow the presidential race wide open and turn it into a three-way race," Nader said in an interview on Thursday.

Trump has become a favorite target of criticism since launching his White House campaign last month, angering fellow Republicans with his comments about Sen. John McCain's status as a war hero last week. Trump has fired back at the criticism, especially a rebuke from the typically-neutral Republican National Committee. He has repeatedly declined to rule out a third-party White House run, saying in an interview with CNN's Anderson Cooper earlier this month that he is constantly being asked to run as an independent. This week, he told The Hill that his decision will depend on "how I'm being treated by the Republicans."

Launching a third-party candidacy is a time-consuming and expensive process, riddled with logistical hurdles, including massive signature-gathering requirements to gain ballot access in each of the 50 states. However, a candidate with significant resources, such as Trump, could potentially overcome these challenges.

Republicans remember all too well businessman Ross Perot's independent candidacy for president in 1992. The Texan made an appeal to voters looking for an alternative to establishment candidates, and his campaign is widely considered to have complicated George H.W. Bush's effort to win reelection against Bill Clinton.

Clay Mulford, Perot's son-in-law and political adviser, said a third-party run from Trump has the potential to energize a part of the electorate that is itching for a fresh face. "There is just a sense of ineffectiveness of the two-party system. So I think he would do better than expected if he were in the debates and if he were considered viable," Mulford said. "And having money helps."

Indeed, poll numbers suggest that a third-party candidacy from Trump would damage Florida Gov. Jeb Bush, a top-tier candidate in the current Republican field. In a head-to-head match-up, Democratic frontrunner Hillary Clinton leads Bush, 50% to 44%, according to an ABC News/Washington Post poll out this week. However, throw an independent Trump into that race, and Clinton's lead grows significantly to 46%, leaving Bush at 30%.

At a campaign stop in New Hampshire on Thursday, Bush made sure to emphasize that he is not dismissive of Trump's candidacy. "I think he's a serious candidate and he's going to have a lot of money. He's tapping into people's angst that are legitimate," Bush said. Meanwhile, during a visit to the U.S.-Mexico border in Laredo, Texas, on Thursday, Trump said his preference is to run as a Republican and he was confident that he could win the party's nomination. However, in many ways, a third-party run makes a lot of sense for Trump. The former host of the reality TV show "The Apprentice" was once a registered Democrat, donated money to members of both parties, and considered running for president in 2000 as an independent. At the very core of his campaign is the idea that he is the anti-politician. Trump has never held public office and he loves to point out that, thanks to his massive wealth—which he claims amounts to more than $10 billion—he is not beholden to anyone, including party leadership. This last point has already created massive headaches for the GOP. Trump sparked furious backlash by referring to some Mexican immigrants that enter the United States as "criminals" and "rapists." Republicans criticized Trump's choice of words as being hurtful and insensitive to the immigrant community, but many chose their words carefully—a sign of how delicate of an issue illegal immigration is. For many Republicans, Trump seemed to cross the line last weekend with his critique of Sen. John McCain. "I like people that were not captured, OK?" Trump said of the Arizona Republican senator, who spent more than five years in as a prisoner of war during the Vietnam War. The RNC, which remains neutral in the GOP nominating process, took the unusual move of speaking out. "There is no place in our party or our country for comments that disparage those who have served honorably," said RNC spokesman Sean Spicer. Bill Hillsman, a political consultant who has worked for a number of independent candidates including in gubernatorial races in Massachusetts and Texas, said the party's condemnation of Trump is likely to have helped fuel Trump's unorthodox campaign. "I think the damage is already done to a large extent," Hillsman said. "All the people who said well, his campaign is over now and blasted him for some of his previous comments, many of which he's walked back, they already have just pretty much dismissed this guy and the polls are saying otherwise."

Title: U.S. Faces Potential Second Wave of COVID-19 Infections Coinciding with Flu Season

Article:

Epidemiologists and public-health officials in the United States are bracing for a potential second wave of COVID-19 infections later this year, coinciding with the peak of the 2020-21 U.S. influenza season. The concern is that this second wave could lead to a new surge of hospital patients in need of respiratory support.

The fear is justified, as both COVID-19 and influenza infections typically begin rising in November and peak at some point in December, January, or February, before subsiding by April. The severity of each wave, however, remains uncertain.

Influenza infection patterns are better understood than those of the SARS-CoV-2 virus that causes COVID-19, but influenza remains a known unknown due to the annual variation in its strains. The severity of the 2020-21 influenza season will depend on how well the vaccine matches the strain of the virus and on the particular strain itself.

Compared to influenza viruses, the behavior of SARS-CoV-2 is a much greater unknown. The seasonal appearance of SARS-CoV-2 resembles that of influenza, except that infections do not disappear in the summer months; instead, they continue at a reduced frequency. The seasonality of viral infections overall remains a mystery, with theories suggesting that cold, dry weather may make people more susceptible to viral infections or that gathering indoors during winter facilitates transmission.

The main factor influencing the magnitude of a second wave of infections is the number of people actively infected by the virus in October, often referred to as the human reservoir. Limiting the number of infections now will reduce the number of infections later. Unfortunately, the U.S. is not limiting COVID-19 infections enough to avoid a severe second wave.

Countries that have successfully tackled the disease have much broader testing regimes and have implemented exhaustive contact-tracing programs that identify all those potentially infected and move them to supervised facilities, often at a local hotel, where they are monitored for symptoms. As U.S. communities reopen and behavior patterns loosen, the country will be forced to face the consequences of its insufficient action.

With seven vaccines and at least one drug with prophylactic potential currently in clinical trials, efforts to develop a vaccine and drugs that may block the virus's transmission have shifted into high gear in laboratories around the world. A vaccine or prophylactic drug must be widely available by the very beginning of the season to have an impact on a second wave of U.S. infections this autumn. That will require maximum coordinated efforts by researchers, manufacturers, and regulators.

Without a medical breakthrough, the U.S. will have to prepare for the worst.

Title: Senate Divisions Over Sequester Threaten to Delay Government Funding

Article:

The ongoing divisions within Mitch McConnell's Republican caucus in the Senate are complicating efforts to avoid the impending budget cuts, also known as the sequester. The Great Sequester pregame show in Washington is set to conclude on Thursday, with Republicans still divided over how to disarm the doomsday budget machine they constructed in the previous Congress, in collaboration with Democrats and President Barack Obama.

As the deadline for implementing the cuts approaches on March 1, Obama will meet with House and Senate leaders on Friday, while his Office of Management and Budget works to meet the deadline. New battle lines are emerging over funding the government past March 27, with Senate Democrats expressing renewed interest in moving a full-fledged omnibus spending package for the remainder of the year.

However, Thursday in the Senate will focus on the sequester, with the debate centered more on political cover than finding solutions. The bill, which requires 60 votes for passage, is unlikely to pass due to the Republican divisions, and even achieving 50 votes for the GOP alternative will be challenging.
