In an attempt to mitigate the fallout from the cuts, the GOP leadership has proposed a controversial plan to grant the White House broad authority to implement the $85.3 billion in reductions for the remainder of the fiscal year. The final 10-page bill, released Wednesday evening, requires Obama to present his own plan to achieve the same level of cuts by March 15, rather than the across-the-board sequester.

Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell signaled his support for the plan early in the day, but the strategy, crafted by his ally Sen. Pat Toomey, continues to face resistance. Freshman Sen. Kelly Ayotte, a Toomey rival in this case, has also proposed her own option to forestall the cuts with long-term alternative savings rather than ceding power to Obama.

Conservatives argue that Ayotte's bill fails to match the immediate deficit reduction promised for 2013, and McConnell has defended the Toomey approach in floor remarks.

For the moment, Republican divisions appear to be playing into the hands of Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid, who has enjoyed surprising unity behind his own plan to forestall the cuts for 10 months by substituting a package of $110 billion in revenues and alternative savings. The plan includes a proposed 30 percent minimum tax on the wealthy and savings from farm subsidies and reduced appropriations for defense spending.

Title: Media Response to Trump's Use of Hydroxychloroquine as Preventive Measure Divides Public Opinion

Article:

President Donald Trump has announced that he is taking hydroxychloroquine as a preventive measure against contracting COVID-19. The announcement has sparked a divided response, with some media outlets criticizing the president's decision while others argue for a more measured approach.

The Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has not endorsed hydroxychloroquine as a treatment for COVID-19, and the National Institutes of Health (NIH) recently began a controlled clinical trial to determine its effectiveness. Some media outlets have criticized Trump's decision to self-medicate, with CNN columnist warning of "the danger in Trump's decision to self-medicate."

Senate Democratic leader Chuck Schumer called Trump's remarks about hydroxychloroquine "dangerous," but the drug itself is no more dangerous than a vast number of pharmaceuticals used every day by millions of Americans. The New York Times' Michelle Goldberg noted that side effects of hydroxychloroquine include paranoia, hallucinations, and psychosis, but warned against drawing hasty conclusions.

The most reckless media personality on the issue has been Trump's former bestie, Joe Scarborough, who repeatedly told his audience that hydroxychloroquine will "kill you." However, the FDA has not stated that hydroxychloroquine "will kill you." Instead, the FDA has noted that there are elevated risks associated with COVID-19 patients taking the medication.

The conscientious way to cover Trump's hydroxychloroquine usage would be to point out that there is no proof that the drug will help treat the coronavirus, though tests are still ongoing. Instead, some media outlets have been subjected to an overwrought lecture series of nasty, childish, partisan attacks and misleading stories about a couple ingesting fish-tank cleaner.

House speaker Nancy Pelosi has also weighed in on the issue, stating that she would rather Trump not take something that has not been approved by scientists, especially in his age group and weight group. However, hydroxychloroquine has been approved for 70 years, and every day doctors prescribe it on- and off-label. If Trump and his doctor think it's okay for him to take it, that's his business.

Whether hydroxychloroquine will be useful in this particular fight is yet to be determined. However, it's important to note that COVID-19 aside, the drug doesn't "kill people." It saves people. The fearmongering isn't helping anyone.

Title: Hillary Clinton Enjoys 46-Point Lead Over Donald Trump Among Hispanic Voters, According to Fox News Latino Poll

Article:

In a new national survey of registered voters, Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton has widened her lead over her Republican rival Donald Trump among Hispanic voters in the presidential race. The Fox News Latino poll, released on Thursday, shows Clinton and her running mate, Virginia Senator Tim Kaine, enjoying an overwhelming 46-point lead over Trump and his running mate, Indiana Governor Mike Pence. The poll indicates a 66 percent to 20 percent advantage for Clinton and Kaine, marking a 7-point increase in Clinton's lead since the same poll in May.

The Hispanic vote is crucial to Clinton's electoral strategy, which aims to assemble a coalition of young voters, minorities, and women. Hispanics are the fastest-growing minority and provided heavy support that helped secure President Obama's 2012 win over Republican Mitt Romney.

In a three-way race that included Libertarian nominee Gary Johnson and his running mate, Bill Weld, 16 percent of Hispanics picked the third-party candidates, while 17 percent backed the Trump ticket. Clinton's share of the vote jumped to 59 percent, according to the poll.

Hispanic voters in the poll overwhelmingly sided with Clinton on immigration issues, which Trump has made a cornerstone of his campaign with get-tough policies. Hispanic voters said that Clinton was better suited to improve the U.S. immigration system by a 52-point margin, 71 percent to 19 percent.

These voters also backed Clinton by wide margins on representing their views (72 percent to 14 percent), on education (73 percent to 19 percent), foreign policy (70 to 21 percent), health care (69 to 22 percent), and the economy (61 to 31 percent).

Alfonso Aguilar, the executive director of the Latino Partnership for Conservative Principles, told Fox News Latino that the results are not surprising given the reaction of Latinos to some of Trump's proposals.

Title: Medicare for All: A Comprehensive Look at Bernie Sanders' Proposed Healthcare Plan

Article:

Senator Bernie Sanders has proposed a healthcare plan, often referred to as Medicare for All. However, the term may be misleading, as the plan encompasses more than just an expansion of Medicare.

Currently, Medicare is a government program that provides healthcare coverage for seniors and the disabled. The costs of Medicare are projected to increase significantly over the next few decades. According to estimates, outlays for Medicare are expected to grow by nearly a third as a share of the economy over the next 10 years, and double over the next 30 years.

Revenues for Medicare, on the other hand, are expected to lag behind these costs. The Medicare trust fund is projected to run out of money by 2029. It is unclear whether the U.S. can afford Medicare as it currently exists, let alone the expansion proposed by Sanders.

Sanders' proposal goes beyond merely including the entire U.S. population in Medicare, which would increase the number of recipients sixfold in just four years. His plan also includes coverage for dental, vision, and hearing needs, which are currently excluded from Medicare. Sanders promises "no more copays, no more deductibles, and no more fighting with insurance companies when they fail to pay for charges."

Under Sanders' proposal, the government would pay for all healthcare expenses, not just for 55 million people but for 325 million. This would include not only the current expenses but also new ones, as relieving patients of any financial obligation would likely induce more people to seek more care.

A study by the Kaiser Family Foundation notes that Medicare has relatively high cost-sharing requirements for covered benefits and does not limit beneficiaries' annual out-of-pocket spending. In 2010, the average recipient paid $2,746 for deductibles, coinsurance, and the like (not counting premiums).

The proposed plan has no price tag, which is a notable shortcoming. Americans might appreciate the additional benefits offered by the plan, but they may not be willing to pay for it. The survival of the Affordable Care Act (ACA) serves as a reminder of the importance of caution and the danger of overpromising when it comes to healthcare reform.

The ACA, once unpopular, gained broad support as Americans came to see it as an incremental and fiscally restrained method of expanding healthcare coverage with minimal disruption. The failed Republican effort to repeal and replace the ACA offers useful lessons, particularly the importance of caution and the danger of overpromising.

Democrats have an understandable attraction to a single-payer healthcare system, but embracing such a system may win votes in the short run while inviting failure in the long run. Good politics often make for bad policy, and bad policy, ultimately, is bad politics.

Title: Georgia, Texas, Kentucky, and Arkansas Hold Primaries; Stacey Abrams Wins Democratic Gubernatorial Primary in Georgia

Article:

Voters in Georgia, Kentucky, and Arkansas cast ballots in primaries on Tuesday, while Texas held a primary runoff election. President Trump won each of the four states in 2016, but Democrats are eyeing potential pickup opportunities in congressional races while making a closely watched play for the governor's mansion in Georgia.

In the marquee race of the night, Democratic gubernatorial candidate Stacey Abrams scored a resounding primary victory, bringing her one step closer to becoming the nation's first African American woman governor if she wins in November. Her campaign is significant, not only for its historic nature, but for the way she's campaigning. She is focusing on expanding the electorate by mobilizing non-voters, including more people of color.

"We are writing the next chapter of Georgia's future where no one is unseen, no one is unheard, and no one is uninspired," Abrams said during a rousing speech at her post-election party.

Progressives who have argued the path to victory for Democrats is engaging a new coalition of voters, rather than chasing Republican-leaning voters, say Abrams' campaign could serve as a model for future campaigns in the South. Several progressive groups endorsed Abrams in the primary along with 2016 presidential candidate Hillary Clinton and her primary opponent, Sen. Bernie Sanders, I-Vt. Clinton recorded a robo-call for her the day before the election.

Abrams has an uphill battle in a red state that has never elected a woman governor. In November, she will face either Lt. Gov. Casey Cagle or Secretary of State Brian Kemp, the Republicans who advanced to a runoff primary on July 24.

In the 7th Congressional District runoff, lawyer Lizzie Pannill Fletcher's defeat of writer and organizer Laura Moser ends a chapter in a high-profile drama that divided left-wing and establishment Democrats. The Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee (DCCC)—the party's House campaign arm—did not want Moser to win. In February, the organization took the extraordinary step of releasing opposition research against Moser, infuriating liberals who endorsed her. They argued Washington, D.C., Democrats were interfering with the will of voters. The DCCC's chairman, Rep. Ben Ray Lujan of New Mexico, defended the decision, saying Moser's "offensive" writings would disqualify her.

On Tuesday, after the results were in, Lujan released a statement saying Fletcher is "in a very strong position for the general election."

"Lizzie won her competitive primary by talking straight to voters in Houston about the issues that actually matter to their economic security, health, and children's future," Lujan said.

House Democrats, who need a net gain of 23 seats to win the majority, are eyeing possible pickup opportunities in this district and two others where Clinton won in 2016. Candidates included in the DCCC's "Red to Blue" program, which gives top-tier candidates organizational and fundraising support, won in the two other runoff primaries. They are Gina Ortiz Jones, who served as an Air Force intelligence officer in Iraq, in the 23rd Congressional District, and civil rights attorney and former NFL linebacker Colin Allred in the 32nd Congressional District's runoff primary.

Among the winners are Ortiz Jones; former combat rescue pilot Mary Jennings "MJ" Hegar, a Texas Democrat; retired Navy Seal Dan Crenshaw, a Texas Republican; and retired Marine Lt. Col. Amy McGrath, a Kentucky Democrat.

"With these wins, we are not only one important step closer to electing four more compelling veterans to Congress, but we are also one step closer to reversing the record-high dysfunction and polarization in this country," said Rye Barcott, a former Marine and founder of the super PAC "With Honor." The cross-partisan organization endorsed each of the candidates in its bid to increase the number of next-generation veterans in Congress.

McGrath gained a national profile last year with an introductory ad that went viral. The Naval Academy graduate and former fighter pilot described her 89 combat missions after her congressman told her when she was 13 that women shouldn't be allowed to serve in combat. If Ortiz Jones wins in November, she will be Texas's first openly LGBTQ person of color elected to Congress, according to the Human Rights Campaign.

Title: NRA Endorses Bipartisan Bill to Strengthen Federal Background Check System and Mental Health Provisions

Article:

The National Rifle Association (NRA) has endorsed a bipartisan bill introduced by Senators Lindsey Graham (R-SC), Jeff Flake (R-AZ), Mark Pryor (D-AR), and Mark Begich (D-AK) to strengthen the federal background check system and prevent individuals deemed mentally ill from purchasing firearms.

The bill, which clarifies the circumstances under which someone loses the right to own a firearm due to mental illness, expands the definition of those adjudicated "mentally incompetent" to include individuals judged to be a danger to themselves or others, found not guilty in a criminal case by reason of insanity, and those who require involuntary outpatient treatment by a psychiatric hospital.

Chris W. Cox, the NRA's chief lobbyist, stated, "This bill will create accurate definitions of those who pose serious threats and should be barred from the ability to buy or possess a firearm, while protecting the rights of law-abiding citizens and veterans. This legislation will significantly improve the National Instant Check System, which is critically needed."

Senator Graham acknowledged the emotional nature of the issue, stating, "But I am hopeful this is one area where we can find tremendous bipartisan support to fix what I think is a gaping gap in our law."

Senator Begich added that the bill creates a clear definition of mental incompetence, only applying to individuals who are committed to treatment involuntarily. It does not affect those in a mental institution for observation or those who voluntarily admit themselves to a psychiatric hospital. Individuals can also regain their right to own a firearm once they have recovered from their mental illness.

The bill is set to be considered by the Senate Judiciary Committee on Thursday, a day after the announcement, alongside four other gun-related measures. The bill is being negotiated by Democratic Sens. Charles E. Schumer of New York and Joe Manchin III of West Virginia, as well as Republicans Mark Kirk of Illinois and Tom Coburn of Oklahoma.

Senator Graham expressed openness to considering other gun-related measures, stating, "Tom Coburn is a good friend, and anything that Tom Coburn thinks is a good idea, I will certainly look at closely. If they can ever reach a bipartisan agreement about the problem with the background checks, I would be open to looking at their work product, but I would say this, as my colleagues have said—we have a background check system that really doesn't create any deterrent."

Neither Senator Schumer, who is carrying the bill, nor Senator Coburn immediately responded to a request for comment on Wednesday.

Title: U.S. and Mexico Hold Second Day of Talks on Trade and Migration, with Tariff Threat Looming

Article:

U.S. President Donald Trump and Mexican officials held a second day of talks on trade and migration on Thursday, with markets rebounding on optimism a deal could be close, although it was unclear if Mexican pledges to curb migration flows were enough to persuade the Trump administration to postpone tariffs.

The U.S. has threatened to impose 5% tariffs on all Mexican exports to the United States starting on Monday if Mexico does not increase efforts to stem an increase in mostly Central American migrants heading for the U.S. border. Bilateral talks in Washington began on Wednesday to attempt to strike a deal, with the Mexican government, U.S. business groups, and even many of Trump's fellow Republicans keen to avert the tariffs, the prospect of which has rattled global financial markets.

U.S. Vice President Mike Pence said Mexico had offered "more" on Thursday than on Wednesday, but it would be up to Trump, who returns from a European trip on Friday, to decide if it were enough. "There has been some movement on their part. It's been encouraging," he said. "The discussions are going to continue in the days ahead."

Mexican Foreign Minister Marcelo Ebrard told reporters the Mexican government had offered to send 6,000 members of the National Guard to secure its southern border with Guatemala. In a sign of a wider crackdown, the leftist administration of Mexican President Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador said earlier that it blocked the bank accounts of 26 people for alleged links to human trafficking, while it detained on Wednesday at least 350 migrants crossing into Mexico and arrested two prominent migrant rights activists.

Ahead of the 2020 U.S. presidential election, Trump is eager to show progress on his 2016 campaign pledges to take a hard line on immigration. Apprehensions at the U.S.-Mexico border hit a decade high in May.

If the tariffs go ahead, the United States would be in a serious trade dispute with both China and Mexico - two of its three top trading partners. Trump said on Thursday he would decide later this month whether to carry out his threat to hit Beijing with tariffs on at least $300 billion in Chinese goods.

Officials of the U.S. Federal Reserve and International Monetary Fund separately warned on Thursday that global trade tensions and rising tariffs posed an increasing risk to decades of U.S. expansion, as well as to the global economy. Analysts warn that tariffs could spark a recession in Mexico. Credit ratings agency Fitch downgraded Mexico's sovereign debt rating on Wednesday, citing trade tensions among other risks, while Moody's lowered its outlook to negative.

The White House has drafted a document for Trump that would declare a new national emergency to implement the Mexican tariffs, according to a copy of the order seen by The Hill newspaper. The head of the U.S. House of Representatives Ways and Means Committee vowed to take steps to block such a move. "If the president does declare a national emergency and attempt to put these tariffs into place, I will introduce a resolution of disapproval to stop his overreach," said the panel's chairman, Democrat Richard Neal.

Mexican officials have prepared a list of U.S. products that may face retaliatory tariffs if talks do not end in agreement. The tariffs would target U.S. products from agricultural and industrial states regarded as Trump's electoral base, a tactic China has also used with an eye toward the president's 2020 re-election bid. U.S. hog farmers fear Mexico could hit back on products like pork. Mexico bought about $1.5 billion worth of American hams and other pork products in 2017, making it the sector's top export market by volume. "People are really scared," said Nick Giordano, vice president and counsel for global government affairs at the National Pork Producers Council. "This is generating a tremendous amount of uncertainty and potentially if this goes forward, it's going to be financial turmoil."

Title: Tulsi Gabbard Advocates for Immediate End to Regime Change Wars in Middle East

Article:

In a question directed towards Democratic presidential candidates Sen. Elizabeth Warren (D-Mass.) and Mayor Pete Buttigieg, Rep. Tulsi Gabbard (D-Hawaii) inquired about their stance on ending regime change wars. Both candidates seemed to evade a clear response.

Warren expressed the U.S. should not maintain a military presence in the Middle East, but suggested a gradual and careful withdrawal of troops. Buttigieg argued that a hasty withdrawal, as currently ordered by President Donald Trump, would betray Kurdish allies and represent a breach of the U.S.'s commitment.

Former Vice President Joe Biden later criticized Gabbard, stating that the U.S.'s involvement abroad was not solely for the defense of the Kurds, but to tie terrorists down and prevent them from causing harm domestically. Biden's remarks were less persuasive due to his initial confusion between Iraq and Afghanistan.

Gabbard was the only candidate on the stage Tuesday night to advocate for a unilateral, immediate end to the disastrous policy of intervening in every conflict in the Middle East with the goal of changing regimes. She highlighted the failures of such policies in Iraq, Afghanistan, Libya, and potentially Syria.

Gabbard also called out both parties and the mainstream media for their role in the U.S.'s foreign policy interventionism. She criticized The New York Times for labeling her an "Assad apologist" and "asset of Russia," stating that the attacks were "completely despicable."

As Christian Britschgi of ███ noted earlier this week, The New York Times' attack on Gabbard was based on "a mix of thin evidence, guilt by association, and conspiratorial framing of actions that any single-issue-focused dark horse candidate is liable to do."

Gabbard, a progressive on domestic policy, supports policies that are often at odds with libertarians. However, among the Democratic candidates, on the specific issue of regime change abroad, Gabbard is nearly the sole advocate for foreign policy that is realistic about the manifest failures of the U.S.'s approach to the Middle East since at least the turn of the century.

Title: Justice Department Investigates Possible Russian Disinformation to Clinton Campaign During 2016 Election

Article:

Attorney General William P. Barr has revealed that the Justice Department is examining the possibility that Russian operatives provided disinformation to the Hillary Clinton campaign during the 2016 presidential election season. This expanded review focuses on the activities of the FBI during the summer of 2016, which included key decisions made by vehemently anti-Trump FBI senior officials in the investigations of Mrs. Clinton and Donald Trump.

One significant question arises from the extent to which the FBI relied on the dossier compiled by former British spy Christopher Steele, which contained information from Russian sources and contributed to the Trump-Russia collusion narrative. The dossier was funded by payments from the Clinton campaign and Democratic National Committee hidden in campaign finance reports behind payments to a law firm.

Republican senators suggest that Mr. Steele's Russian sources may have intentionally fed him disinformation, which then reached the highest levels of the FBI. Former FBI Director James B. Comey's first personal interaction with Mr. Trump was to brief him on the Steele dossier shortly before his inauguration in January 2017.

Sen. Charles E. Grassley of Iowa, the chamber's senior Republican, stated, "That's the definition of collusion."

Mr. Barr stated that he does not know the answer, but he is concerned about this aspect and does not consider it entirely speculative. "That is one of the areas that I'm reviewing," he told the Senate Judiciary Committee.

Democrats expressed dismay at the prospect of a counterinvestigation. They believe the focus should remain on Mr. Trump and his team's efforts to coordinate with Russia in 2016 and then obstruct the subsequent investigation. U.S. intelligence agencies have concluded that the Kremlin ran a major disinformation campaign in 2016 to hurt Mrs. Clinton and boost Mr. Trump in the race.

Sen. Richard J. Durbin, Illinois Democrat, referred to the Republican efforts as "the so-called lock-her-up defense," a reference to a popular Trump campaign trail chant against Mrs. Clinton for her use of a secret unsecured email account while she served as secretary of state under President Barack Obama.

Mr. Durbin stated, "That's old news. That is totally unresponsive to the reality of what the American people want to know."

Mr. Barr was on Capitol Hill to testify about his handling of special counsel Robert Mueller's final report on the Russian hacking operation, submitted to the Justice Department in late March and revealed to the public in lightly redacted form two weeks ago.

Mr. Mueller concluded that despite their shared interest in defeating Mrs. Clinton, there was no evidence that Mr. Trump or his aides coordinated efforts with Moscow in the election. Mr. Mueller stated there was evidence that Mr. Trump tried to hinder investigations into Russia and his presidential campaign, but he did not reach any firm conclusions on criminality. Mr. Barr, however, did reach conclusions, saying it would have been impossible to make a prosecutable case.

This, ironically, is the same conclusion Mr. Comey came to in 2016 when he exonerated Mrs. Clinton for her emails. It was later revealed that the FBI opened a counterintelligence investigation into Trump campaign figures several weeks afterward, though the agency never informed Mr. Trump or his team.

Mr. Barr described the zealous pursuit of Mr. Trump as the work of a few high-placed officials who engaged in "overreach" — and who have since been ousted from their jobs.

"It was a few people in the upper echelons of the bureau and perhaps the department," he said. "But those people are no longer there."

Mr. Barr previously revealed that he was looking into FBI and Justice Department decisions surrounding the 2016 campaign. Congressional Republicans have long pressed the theory that the FBI investigation began illegitimately, fueled by agents who were intent on discrediting the Republican nominee.

Mr. Barr said he will piggyback on the work of the inspector general and investigations completed by congressional committees and Mr. Mueller. Those promises are likely to thrill Mr. Trump, who has long maintained that any criminal behavior during the campaign is connected to Mrs. Clinton.

The Clinton campaign and the Democratic National Committee made payments — hidden in campaign finance documents behind a law firm — to Fusion GPS, a Democratic research operation that paid Mr. Steele to investigate reports of Mr. Trump's financial links to Russia. Mr. Steele produced the dossier that claimed secret meetings between Trump campaign figures and Russian operatives and suggested salacious events such as blackmail-style tapes of a Trump encounter with prostitutes in a Moscow hotel room. The Mueller report found no evidence to corroborate either of the allegations.

Mr. Barr stated he will review how and when the FBI learned of the Democratic backing for the Steele dossier. The attorney general also stated Mr. Trump probably should have been briefed on Russian meddling in the election, including efforts to reach out to his campaign.

"I can't fathom why it did not happen," he said. "If you are concerned about interference in the election and you have substantial people involved in the campaign who are former U.S. attorneys, you had three former U.S. attorneys there in the campaign. I don't know why the bureau would not have gone and given a defensive briefing."

Sen. Ben Sasse, Nebraska Republican, asked whether Mr. Barr would support a change to legislation mandating that presidential nominees be given those kinds of briefings as a matter of course, given foreign governments' interests in subverting U.S. elections.

"The danger from countries like China, Russia, and so forth is far more insidious than it has been in the past because of nontraditional collectors that they have operating in the United States, and I think most people are unaware of how pervasive it is and what the risk level is," he said. "I think it actually should go far beyond even campaigns where people involved in government have to be educated on this."

Title: President Obama to Address 50th Anniversary of the March on Washington, Discussing Progress and Remaining Challenges in Civil Rights

Article:

President Barack Obama will stand in the symbolic shadows of Martin Luther King Jr. and Abraham Lincoln on Wednesday, as he marks the 50th anniversary of the March on Washington. The event will serve as an opportunity for Obama to celebrate the progress made due to the civil rights movement, while discussing the work that still needs to be done to realize King's dream of racial justice in America.

Obama's speech will focus on issues such as protecting voting rights and creating opportunities for economically disadvantaged individuals of all races, which he refers to as "ladders of opportunity." The president does not often discuss race publicly, but it is a subject he has thought and written extensively about.

During a college visit in New York last week, an African-American professor asked Obama where he thought the country was in terms of civil rights. Obama's response was complex, acknowledging the significant strides made but also emphasizing that discrimination still exists and has left lasting barriers to success.

In the aftermath of the Trayvon Martin verdict last month, Obama spoke in personal terms about the experience of being profiled as a black man in America. His remarks were praised in some quarters but criticized in others. Abigail Thernstrom, a member of the U.S. Commission on Civil Rights appointed by President George W. Bush, expressed criticism, stating, "I do not think that the racial climate in this country is helped when the president wades in to what are always turbulent racial waters and stirs things up."

However, Democratic pollster Cornell Belcher disagreed, arguing that resistance to open discussions about race is one reason the country has not made more progress. "It's a conversation that makes a lot of white America uncomfortable and they would rather not have," said Belcher. "And understand, they have not had to have the conversation."

In addition to addressing race, Obama has not shied away from discussing problems within the African-American community, particularly the high rates of poor choices made by young men. In May, he told graduates of Morehouse College that "there's no longer any room for excuses."

On Wednesday, Obama is expected to discuss civil rights in broader terms, encompassing not just blacks and whites but also Latinos, women, and gays. He is likely to reiterate his belief that all individuals are "tied in a single garment of destiny," a quote from Martin Luther King Jr. However, Obama has also warned in recent weeks that persistent economic anxiety threatens to unravel the unifying fabric of the nation.

Obama is expected to leave his audience with the challenge of renewing the promise of civil rights, a promise that King spoke of 50 years ago.

Title: Supreme Court Upholds Voter ID Requirement for North Dakota Elections

Article:

The Supreme Court on Tuesday declined to overturn a lower court's ruling that allows North Dakota to enforce its voter identification requirement during the 2018 elections. The decision came in response to a group of Native American residents' challenge of a new state law that mandates voters to present identification with a current residential street address.

The challengers argued that the new rule disproportionately affects Native American voters, as many live on reservations without standard addresses. The District Court initially agreed and temporarily blocked the North Dakota secretary of state from enforcing the new requirements during the primary elections. However, the 8th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals overturned that court order last month.

The challengers requested the Supreme Court to overturn the 8th Circuit's stay, arguing it has left thousands of Native American voters unable to cast ballots. The court, however, denied the request without explanation. The court's newest member, Brett Kavanaugh, did not take part in the decision.

Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg, on the other hand, filed a dissenting opinion, which was joined by Justice Elena Kagan. Ginsburg stated that she would have granted the challengers' request, citing potential voter confusion and the risk of keeping people from voting due to conflicting court orders affecting elections.

"The risk of voter confusion appears severe here because the injunction against requiring residential-address identification was in force during the primary election and because the Secretary of State’s website announced for months the ID requirements as they existed under that injunction," Ginsburg said.

"Reasonable voters may well assume that the IDs allowing them to vote in the primary election would remain valid in the general election," she added.

Title: Wall Street Economists Rate Government Dysfunction as Leading Risk Factor for 2014 Economic Growth

Article:

The improving economy, defying the political turmoil in Washington, has led to a decrease in the jobless rate, rising house prices, a soaring stock market, and overall economic growth that surpassed expectations. The latest employment report showed a gain of 203,000 jobs in November and a significant drop in the jobless rate to 7 percent, suggesting the economy has overcome the most recent political challenges.

However, the numbers may not be as positive as they seem, and there are still risks that could negatively impact the economy in 2014. Government dysfunction remains the leading risk factor, according to Wall Street economists.

Jan Hatzius, chief economist at Goldman Sachs, stated, "The economy is improving right now because the headwinds from Washington are getting much smaller. If you look at the broad range of indicators, there is more good news than bad news. And everyone assumes a deal gets made on the sequester and the budget. But that's not a certainty, and so Washington remains a risk."

The current economic data, including Thursday's surprisingly strong 3.6 percent read on gross domestic product growth, is reported despite Washington's dismal state. The 16-day government shutdown that featured 850,000 furloughed workers is expected to take a quarter point bite out of GDP growth in the fourth quarter.

While much of the fallout may show up in the fourth quarter, it's also easy to overstate the strength of recent data. The big third-quarter GDP number received a boost from companies stocking up on inventory expecting an uptick in demand. That inventory building will not recur in subsequent quarters, meaning even without the shutdown impact, fourth-quarter growth is likely to be closer to 1 percent than 3 percent. Consumer spending rose just 1.4 percent in the third quarter.

The November jobs report, however, was uniformly good news, with the unemployment rate falling to its lowest level in five years because more people found jobs, not because they left the labor force as in some previous months. Total employment measured by the household survey increased by 818,000, the biggest jump in three decades, partially driven by furloughed workers returning to the job after the government shutdown.

Despite the positive job report, not everyone is optimistic about the economic outlook for 2014. Catherine L. Mann, professor of economics at Brandeis University, stated, "I'm not so sure that 2014 prospects are all that much better than 2013 given that the underlying drivers of growth including consumption, business investment, and exports continue to be very weak. And there is still going to be an awful lot of noise and partisanship and Washington basically being a burr under the saddle of the economy for all of next year."

One hope for 2014 that underlies much of the Wall Street bullishness is that congressional negotiations led by House Budget Committee Chair Paul Ryan and Senate Budget Committee Chair Patty Murray can make a deal to reduce the immediate impact of the 2014 sequester spending cuts on the economy. Reports suggest they are only a few billion dollars in budgetary savings away from an agreement, with their official deadline next Friday.

Title: Trump Threatens Legal Action Against Pelosi and Schiff Over Impeachment Inquiry

Article:

President Donald Trump has threatened to sue House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) and House Intelligence Committee Chairman Adam Schiff (D-Calif.) over the ongoing impeachment inquiry. The threat was made during a speech at the Values Voter Summit in Washington, D.C.

"We're going to take a look at it. We're going after these people. These are bad, bad people," Trump said, referring to Pelosi and Schiff. "I actually told my lawyer, I said sue [Schiff] anyway. I said, even if we lose, the American public will understand."

Trump's comments come amid a wave of revelations regarding his efforts to encourage Ukraine to investigate 2020 presidential candidate Joe Biden and his son. Pelosi announced a formal impeachment inquiry last month, following a whistleblower complaint within the intelligence community that focused on the president's interactions with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky.

The inquiry centers around allegations that Trump carried out a broad effort to pressure Zelensky to find dirt on the Biden family. A White House memorandum of the leaders' July 25 phone call confirms that Trump asked Zelensky to work with his personal attorney, Rudy Giuliani, and Attorney General William Barr on the probe.

Multiple House committees, including the one led by Schiff, have called for documents and depositions from numerous Trump administration officials as part of the inquiry. However, the White House has vowed not to cooperate.

Trump has repeatedly decried the impeachment inquiry, often referring to it as a "coup" and a "witch hunt." During a campaign rally on Friday, he suggested that the impeachment inquiry showed Pelosi "hates the United States of America."

Pelosi's office did not immediately respond to a request for comment on Trump's latest remarks. The U.S. Constitution stipulates that members of Congress cannot be impeached.

Title: White House Pushes for Comprehensive Gun Violence Plan Amidst Ongoing Discussions on Gun Control Measures

Article:

The Obama administration is actively seeking ideas for a comprehensive plan to address gun violence, with Vice President Joe Biden's task force reportedly focusing on various gun control measures. This week, Biden is set to meet with gun safety organizations, gun violence victims' groups, and gun ownership groups, as well as representatives from the entertainment and video game industries.

The White House has vowed to produce a comprehensive plan by the end of the month, following the Newtown, Conn., school shooting massacre that left 20 children and six adults dead. The administration is also considering examining mental health and the entertainment industry in addition to gun control measures.

While much of the discussion and proposed measures revolve around gun control, the White House is reportedly considering measures beyond reinstating a ban on assault weapons and high-capacity magazines. These measures may include universal background checks for gun buyers, a national gun database, strengthening mental-health checks, and tougher penalties for people carrying guns near schools or giving them to minors.

White House Press Secretary Jay Carney reiterated on Monday that President Obama wants to "close the many loopholes in our background check system" and "supports congressional actions right away." However, accelerated efforts to draft new gun control measures have alarmed gun rights groups, including the National Rifle Association (NRA).

Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.) stated that the next round of fiscal deadlines will occupy Congress's attention and push off the consideration of gun legislation for at least three months. The White House, however, maintains that the president still plans to act quickly on Biden's proposals.

Biden's recommendations are expected to include both legislative proposals and executive actions that Obama can sign into law without lawmakers' approval. In addition to Biden's meetings this week, other meetings are scheduled with education, health, and community organizations, as well as business owners and religious leaders. Pro-gun lawmakers on Capitol Hill have said any comprehensive effort to respond to the Newtown shooting must include more than just tighter gun control.

Title: Former Defense Secretary Mattis Breaks Silence, Criticizes President Trump's Response to George Floyd Protests

Article:

In a statement released over the weekend, former Defense Secretary James Mattis, who served under President Donald Trump, has publicly criticized the President's response to the police killing of George Floyd and the subsequent protests. Mattis, who was known for his silence regarding Trump during his tenure, has now broken that silence, citing the direct threat the American experiment faces due to the President's actions.

Mattis, who served in the military for over five decades, swore an oath to support and defend the Constitution. In his statement, he expressed his dismay that troops taking the same oath could be ordered to violate the Constitutional rights of their fellow citizens. He also criticized a photo op involving the President, military leadership, and troops during the protests in Washington, D.C.

The former Defense Secretary implicitly criticized the current Secretary of Defense, Mark Esper, and other senior officials as well. He emphasized that the military should not be used to "dominate" cities, and that public order should be maintained by civilian state and local leaders who best understand their communities and are answerable to them.

Mattis's dissatisfaction with Trump was not a secret within the Pentagon during his tenure. After his resignation, he argued against criticizing a sitting president, stating it would threaten the apolitical nature of the military. However, he acknowledged that there would be a period of silence, which he referred to as not eternal. That period, according to Mattis, is now definitively over.

In his statement, Mattis contrasted the American ethos of unity with Nazi ideology, quoting instructions given to troops before the Normandy invasion that emphasized unity as a strength, while the Nazi slogan was "Divide and Conquer." He urged Americans to summon this unity to surmount the current crisis, confident that they are better than their politics.

Title: College Education and the Production of Personality: A Neutral Assessment

Article:

When evaluating the merits of attending a university in America or the Western world, a crucial question to consider is the type of person the institution produces. This question, regardless of political affiliation, is one that parents can agree on, as they may disagree about the desired outcome but share a common interest in the character development of their children.

The author of this article, Dennis Prager, a nationally syndicated radio talk-show host and columnist, expresses his belief that colleges today often produce individuals who are no better or wiser than when they graduated high school. He cites college drinking, sexual activity, depression, and mental illness as areas of concern.

Alcohol Rehab Guide, an online alcohol addiction site, reports that a large percentage of college students engage in binge drinking, with 80% consuming alcohol to some degree and 50% engaging in binge drinking. The site also states that college environmental factors contribute to heavy, frequent, and abusive drinking.

Regarding sexual activity, the author mentions the sexual encounters that often result from college drinking, which can lead to regret, particularly by the woman.

The author also discusses the mental health crisis among college students, citing clinical psychologist Gregg Henriques' claim that there is a mental health crisis facing America's college students, with higher levels of stress and psychopathology compared to any time in the nation's history.

The author questions whether college students and recent graduates return home as more respectful, grateful, or open-minded individuals. He suggests that the answers to these questions are essential for parents to determine whether they want to risk sending their child to a place that may increase the chances of depression, binge drinking, and character degradation, while also potentially instilling political and social views that may conflict with their own.

The author acknowledges that students pursuing STEM fields may need to attend college, but for most others, sending a child to college is a gamble with their values, character, and even their joy of life. Dennis Prager is the author of "The Rational Bible" and can be contacted at dennisprager.com.

Title: U.S.-Taliban Negotiations: Analysis of Canceled Camp David Summit and Implications

Article:

The cancellation of a planned meeting between U.S. President Donald Trump and Taliban leaders at Camp David has sparked criticism from some political circles, with skepticism towards any potential deal with the Taliban and criticism of Trump's diplomatic efforts.

The cancellation followed a suicide bombing last week that killed a U.S. soldier and several civilians, which Trump blamed for the cancellation. However, some sources suggest that Trump may have gotten cold feet at the last minute about an agreement that could be perceived as a resurgence of al-Qaida and Islamic State in Afghanistan.

The Trump administration's approach to the Taliban has been criticized for attempting to thread an impossible needle: negotiating with the Taliban while ensuring Afghanistan does not become a "Harvard for terrorists." The Taliban has consistently refused to negotiate directly with the Afghan government, despite the fact that the outcome of their talks with the United States will deeply affect the Afghan people and the Afghan government they represent.

The canceled Camp David talks were intended to bring Taliban leaders and Afghan President Ashraf Ghani together. The cancellation may have benefited Ghani, who is running for reelection at the end of this month and may well win. The winner of the election will be in a stronger position to insist that the next round of negotiations with the Taliban must include the duly elected Afghan government.

Trump's dealmaking skills, which he touted during his 2016 campaign, have come under scrutiny in light of the canceled summit. He has been unable to secure a new nuclear deal with Iran, has made little progress in getting North Korea to abandon its nuclear arsenal, and his trade talks with China are going nowhere.

In the absence of an explicit quid pro quo over restarting aid, the context and circumstances of the U.S.-Taliban negotiations are likely to become the focus of investigation. Some argue that circumstantial evidence, such as the timing of the bombing and the cancellation of the summit, is enough to support impeachment proceedings. However, whether it is also enough to convince Republicans and lead to removal is another matter.

The full article was written by Nahal Toosi, Anita Kumar, Wesley Morgan, and Victoria Guida for Politico. The article concludes by stating that a withdrawal from Afghanistan that does not safeguard women's rights, women's rights, and legitimate Afghan governance would prove disastrous for both Afghans and America.

Title: Mueller Suggests Subpoenaing President Trump for Grand Jury Testimony

Article:

In a recent development, it has been reported that Special Counsel Robert Mueller suggested to President Donald Trump's legal team that he could subpoena the president to appear before a grand jury if he refuses an interview with investigators regarding the Russia probe. This escalates tensions over the investigation into allegations of collusion between the Trump campaign and Russian officials ahead of the 2016 election.

According to The Associated Press, John Dowd, Trump's former lead attorney, disclosed this information during a meeting with Trump's legal team in March. The Washington Post and Fox News have reported accounts of the meeting, with the latter confirming the details. Dowd reportedly responded to Mueller's suggestion by stating, "This isn't some game. You are screwing with the work of the president of the United States."

Dowd resigned as Trump's lead lawyer weeks later amid a dispute over how to answer Mueller's request for a presidential interview. The possibility of a subpoenaed appearance by the president adds to the ongoing investigation's tension.

The Washington Post reported on Tuesday that attorney Jay Sekulow, who now leads Trump's legal team, compiled a list of potential questions that Mueller's team wishes to ask Trump. The list includes questions about Trump's interactions with key figures in the Russia saga, such as former FBI Director James Comey, Attorney General Jeff Sessions, and former National Security Adviser Mike Flynn.

The questions also touch on Trump's businesses and his discussions with his personal lawyer, Michael Cohen, about a possible Moscow real estate deal. Cohen's business dealings are part of a separate FBI investigation. The list includes questions about any meetings Trump may have had with Russian President Vladimir Putin and what the president may have known about a possible attempt by his son-in-law, Jared Kushner, to set up a back channel with Russia before Trump's inauguration.

On Tuesday morning, Trump described the leaked list of potential questions as "disgraceful." In a brief phone conversation with Fox News, Dowd denied leaking the list to the media and denied being the source of the initial Washington Post report on the Mueller meeting.

Title: Lobbying Firm Awarded Grant for Obamacare Navigator Services

Article:

A registered lobbying firm, Chatman LLC, has been awarded a half-million-dollar grant by the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS) to help enroll people for Obamacare as Affordable Care Act "navigators." The firm, which lobbies CMS on behalf of a private hospital client and has also lobbied on the health care law itself, was found to be the only registered lobbying firm among more than 100 organizations receiving grants last month to help the public apply for Obamacare coverage.

Craig Holman, legislative representative for the watchdog group Public Citizen, stated that it is unusual for a lobbying firm to secure a government contract, but the company may have won the grant due to its grass-roots outreach apparatus. The firm was awarded the grant to provide navigator services in Delaware.

Mr. Holman suggested additional restrictions on Chatman LLC, including segregating lines of business and ensuring that no grant money can be used toward lobbying. He noted that federal law prohibits the firm from making any contributions to any federal political committee, including super PACs, due to its status as a government contractor.

Navigators, including Chatman LLC, are barred from lobbying on behalf of the health insurance industry and must adhere to strict conflict-of-interest standards, according to CMS spokeswoman Rachel Maisler. She stated that navigators are an important resource to help Americans learn about their health insurance options, enroll in the Marketplace, and find the plan that is best for themselves and their families.

CMS awarded the grants competitively and stated that Chatman LLC was in compliance with all conflict-of-interest rules. Chatman LLC did not respond directly to questions from The Times about whether its lobbying work surfaced during the grant application process. Instead, the firm released a statement highlighting its relevant experience in the rollout of private insurance plans and work experience in Medicaid and reaching consumers with low health literacy.

According to the firm's lobbying disclosure forms, Ms. Chatman works for the Livingston Group—another lobbying firm—on behalf of Rush University Medical Center in Chicago. CMS was the only federal agency that the firm lobbied during the most recent quarter, along with the Senate and House. During the summer, the firm filed a separate disclosure form showing it had lobbied, among other issues, on the Affordable Care Act.

Recent weeks have seen scrutiny of several recipients of the CMS grants. The New York Post reported that Seedco, a community development group that won contract work to enroll people for Obamacare, had been sued by the federal government on claims of fraud. Seedco told the paper that it had made important changes, including installing new management.

Republican lawmakers have raised questions about whether organizations and navigator personnel have been vetted properly. Sen. John Cornyn (R-TX) stated, "It is simply astounding that the administration is urging the American people to give their Social Security numbers and sensitive personal information to people who have not been properly vetted." Last week, Rep. Henry A. Waxman (D-CA), ranking member of the House Energy and Commerce Committee, called on Republican House members to correct "inaccurate statements" about the navigator program.

Title: YouTube's Decision to Terminate Steven Crowder's Partner Program Sparks Debate on Free Speech and Market Competition

Article:

In a recent development, YouTube has decided to terminate American conservative commentator Steven Crowder's eligibility for its Partner Program, citing violations of its policies. This move has sparked a debate on the role of free speech and market competition in the digital age.

The argument posits that, as YouTube is a privately-owned company, it has the right to regulate the content on its platform. Comparing this to electric companies refusing service to homes with political signs, proponents of free markets argue that such restrictions on expression by privately-owned enterprises should be objected to.

The crux of the argument lies in the nature of certain markets. In markets characterized by "bigger is better" economics, where size bestows advantage, refusing service to a few customers can impose significant costs on competing businesses and potentially leave those customers unserved. This is particularly relevant in the case of social media platforms, which benefit from network externalities, making it difficult for rivals to establish themselves.

Critics argue that being excluded from popular social media networks can impose a significant cost on individuals, as the entire point of these platforms is to communicate with others on the network. While it's easy to switch between burger joints, the same may not be true for social media platforms, where the value of the platform is proportional to the number of customers on it.

However, it's important to note that the comparison between electric power and social media access is not exact. While food is more important than power, social media is crucial for many in contributing to the national political debate. Anonymity normally protects consumers from offending big business, but social media companies can potentially identify and ban users, setting their followers count back to zero and destroying the influence they have built up.

Economic blogger Tyler Cowen suggests that, despite social media deplatforming, information technology has given us far more publishing options than we had even in the 1990s. He argues that, given long-term leftist control of most of the media, right-of-center commentators may currently be better situated than any time in the recent past.

The debate over internet censorship and free speech is complex and multifaceted. As technology continues to evolve, the role of social media platforms in shaping public discourse and the potential for censorship becomes increasingly significant. It is a topic that requires careful consideration and ongoing discussion.

Title: Intelligence Community Warned of Coronavirus Threat in January and February, Reports Show

Article:

U.S. intelligence agencies had been warning of the potential danger posed by the novel coronavirus throughout January and February, while the White House downplayed the threat and was slow to roll out nationwide measures, according to reports by The Washington Post.

U.S. officials familiar with spy agency reporting told The Washington Post that the reports did not specify when the virus might spread in the U.S. or recommend specific steps to prevent an outbreak. However, they did track the international spread of the coronavirus and warned that China was initially dismissing the seriousness of what is now a pandemic.

President Donald Trump took early action to close the border to any travelers from China, where the coronavirus first appeared, but the White House was slow to make test kits available and ceded much of the response to state governments.

A U.S. official who had access to intelligence reporting told the Post, "Intelligence agencies have been warning on this since January. Donald Trump may not have been expecting this, but a lot of other people in the government were — they just couldn't get him to do anything about it."

The White House has defended the president's response, dismissing claims that the administration was caught flat-footed and insisting that Trump took early and significant action.

"President Trump has taken historic, aggressive measures to protect the health, wealth, and safety of the American people — and did so while the media and Democrats chose to only focus on the stupid politics of a sham illegitimate impeachment," Hogan Gidley said in a statement to the Post. "It's more than disgusting, despicable, and disgraceful for cowardly unnamed sources to attempt to rewrite history — it's a clear threat to this great country."

Title: President Trump Defends Syria Withdrawal, Visits Iraq Amidst Ongoing Middle East Policy Shift

Article:

In a surprise trip to Iraq, President Donald Trump defended his decision to withdraw U.S. forces from Syria, where they have been aiding in the battle against Islamic State militants. During a visit to a western Iraq base, Trump told American servicemen and women, "We're no longer the suckers, folks." He added, "We're respected again as a nation."

Trump stated that U.S. military gains enabled the withdrawal of 2,000 forces from Syria. This marked his first visit to a troubled region, and he also expressed no plans to withdraw U.S. forces from Iraq.

At al-Asad Airbase west of Baghdad, Trump said, "I made it clear from the beginning that our mission in Syria was to strip ISIS of its military strongholds." He further stated, "Eight years ago, we went there for three months and we never left. Now, we're doing it right, and we're going to finish it off."

Trump indicated that Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan has agreed to take out "any remnants" of IS left in Syria. The U.S. presence in Syria was not intended to be "open-ended," Trump said, adding that other wealthy nations should pay for rebuilding Syria.

"The nations of the region must step up and take more responsibility for their future," said Trump, who stated there would be a "strong, deliberate, and orderly withdrawal" of U.S. forces from Syria.

Trump's trip to Iraq came a week after he announced the U.S. troop withdrawal from Syria, a move that reportedly led Defense Secretary Jim Mattis to resign. Trump's decision has rattled allies worldwide, including in Iraq.

Trump's trip was kept secretive. Air Force One flew overnight from Washington, landing at an airbase west of Baghdad under the cover of darkness Wednesday evening. It was his first visit with troops stationed in a troubled region.

Fifteen years after the 2003 invasion, the U.S. still has more than 5,000 troops in Iraq supporting the government as it continues the fight against remaining pockets of resistance by the Islamic State group. IS has lost significant territory in Iraq and Syria but is still considered a threat.

Trump, who often expresses his support for the U.S. military, had faced criticism for not yet visiting U.S. troops stationed in harm's way as he approaches his two-year mark in office. He told The Associated Press in October that he "will do that at some point, but I don't think it's overly necessary." He later signaled that such a troop visit was imminent.

Trump had initially planned to spend Christmas at his private club in Florida, but he stayed behind in Washington due to the shutdown. It's unclear whether his trip to Iraq was added after it became apparent that the government would be shut down indefinitely due to a stalemate between Trump and congressional Democrats over the president's demand for a wall along the U.S.-Mexico border.

Adding to the tumult, the stock market has been experiencing heavy losses due to concerns about a slowing global economy, Trump's trade war with China, and the president's public slamming of the Federal Reserve and its chairman over interest rate hikes by the independent agency.

Trump's visit comes at a time when his Middle East policy is in flux. He went against the views of his top national security advisers in announcing the Syria withdrawal, a decision that risks creating a vacuum for extremists to thrive. There are dire implications, particularly for neighboring Iraq. The Iraqi government now has control of all the country's cities, towns, and villages after fighting its last urban battles against IS in December 2017. However, its political, military, and economic situation remains uncertain, and the country continues to experience sporadic bombings, kidnappings, and assassinations, which most people attribute to IS.

Iraqi Prime Minister Adel Abdul-Mahdi recently said Iraqi troops could deploy into Syria to protect Iraq from threats across its borders. Iraq keeps reinforcements along its frontier to guard against infiltration by IS militants, who hold a pocket of territory along the Euphrates River.

Trump campaigned for office on a platform of ending U.S. involvement in foreign trouble spots, such as Syria, Afghanistan, and Iraq. The Syria decision will ultimately affect all of the approximately 2,000 troops deployed in the war-torn country. The Pentagon is also said to be developing plans to withdraw up to half of the 14,000 American troops still serving in Afghanistan.

During the presidential campaign, Trump blamed Democrat Hillary Clinton for the rise of IS, due to the withdrawal of U.S. troops from Iraq at the end of 2011 during her tenure as secretary of state. President George W. Bush set the 2011 withdrawal date as part of an agreement with the Iraqi government to gradually shrink the U.S. footprint and slowly hand off security responsibilities to the government and Iraqi security forces. His successor, President Barack Obama, wanted to leave a residual force in Iraq to help the government manage ongoing security challenges. However, he ultimately went ahead with the scheduled pullout in 2011 after Iraqi political leaders rejected terms the U.S. sought for legal protections for the U.S. troops that would have remained.

Two of Trump's recent predecessors visited Iraq early in their terms. Bush visited Iraq in November 2003, about eight months after that conflict began. Due to security concerns, Bush waited until 2006 to make his first visit to Afghanistan. Obama visited Iraq in April 2009, the first year of his eight years in office, as part of an overseas tour. He visited Afghanistan in 2010. Vice President Mike Pence visited Afghanistan in December 2017, not long after Trump outlined a strategy to break the stalemate in America's longest war. Pence met with Afghan leaders and visited with U.S. troops stationed in the country. Trump has not visited Afghanistan.

Title: Nurses Speak Out Against Police Violence During Protests

Article:

Registered nurse Asantewaa Boykin, a member of the National Nurses United (NNU), found herself in the midst of tear gas during a protest in Sacramento, California. The incident occurred when protesters, who were marching for an end to police violence, were met with tear gas fired by the Sacramento police.

Boykin, who has been a social justice advocate longer than she has worked in the emergency department at Sacramento's UC Davis Medical Center, has witnessed various forms of violence against protesters during her work as a protest medic. She has seen injuries ranging from skull fractures caused by police projectiles to abrasions from protesters falling while running to avoid being shot or gassed.

The NNU, the largest union of registered nurses in the country, represents Boykin and 150,000 other nurses. The union advocates for the health and safety of protesters, who are also their patients. Tear gas, a chemical weapon that has been proven fatal in documented cases and is banned in warfare, is one of the weapons used by police departments across the country on protesters.

Tear gas can cause symptoms including vomiting, blurred vision, shortness of breath, tearing, difficulty swallowing, temporary blindness, pain, coughing, and sneezing. During a pandemic, when it's critical not to spread the virus causing COVID-19, the use of tear gas poses a significant risk.

In addition to tear gas, militarized police have used flashbangs (stun grenades) and rubber bullets, which have been responsible for deaths, internal bleeding, organ damage, and bruising. These weapons can cause burns, hearing loss, temporary blindness, injuries from shrapnel, and death.

Nurses have witnessed these violent police tactics in various locations and during different protests, including Occupy Wall Street, Standing Rock, and the U.S.-Mexico border. At Standing Rock in 2016, nurses met Vanessa Dundon, whose eye was shot out by a tear gas canister fired by police.

Nurses are calling for an end to police violence against protesters, stating that it not only costs lives but also perpetuates inequalities and injustices. Chronic stress alone can cause vast negative health impacts for individuals and communities brutalized by the police.

Heather Honstein, RN, a cardiovascular surgical ICU nurse at Washington D.C.'s MedStar Washington Hospital, joined protesters peacefully in Lafayette square near the White House on June 1. Honstein, an NNU member, left the area 30 minutes before federal police violently dispersed the peaceful crowds.

As nurses, we could never have predicted that we would simultaneously be on the front lines of a pandemic at work and the front lines of a local battlefield in our free time. However, in 2020, this is the reality.

The only people who come to protests dressed for war are police officers, and their use of force against protesters exercising their constitutional right to assembly is a threat to democracy. It's also a colossal waste of public resources that would be far better spent on public health and other social programs, especially during a pandemic and economic crisis.

Bonnie Castillo, RN, the executive director of National Nurses United, emphasizes that standing up for racial justice and the issues that matter should not be lethal in any amount.

Title: U.S. and China Agree to 90-Day Trade War Ceasefire, Expect Immediate Action on Tariffs and Intellectual Property

Article:

The United States expects China to take immediate action to cut tariffs on U.S. car imports and end intellectual property theft and forced technology transfers as the two countries move toward a broader trade deal, a White House official said on Monday. President Donald Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping on Saturday agreed to a ceasefire in a trade war that has seen the flow of hundreds of billions of dollars worth of goods between the world's two largest economies disrupted by tariffs.

The two leaders agreed to hold off on imposing more tariffs for 90 days starting Dec. 1 while they negotiate a deal to end the dispute following months of escalating tensions. Global markets rose on Monday to their highest levels in about three weeks on the news. On Wall Street, the Dow Jones Industrial Average, the S&P 500, and the Nasdaq Composite all gained more than 1 percent.

U.S. soybean futures rose to their highest level since at least August, part of a broader commodities rally. China offered more than $1.2 trillion in additional commitments on trade at the dinner between Xi and Trump on Saturday, Treasury Secretary Steve Mnuchin said on Monday. White House economic advisor Larry Kudlow said the figure was a broad benchmark that would depend on private transactions for U.S. goods and was subject to market conditions.

China committed to start lifting tariffs and non-tariff barriers immediately, including reducing its 40 percent tariffs on autos, Kudlow said. "We expect those tariffs to fall to zero," he told reporters. Americans would get a majority ownership in Chinese companies for the first time, Kudlow said on CNBC. Mnuchin, also speaking on CNBC, hailed a shift in tone.

Trump has made improving the terms of trade for the United States a signature of his "America First" presidency and has prided himself on confronting Beijing over trade practices that the United States and its allies complain are unfair. "My meeting in Argentina with President Xi of China was an extraordinary one," Trump tweeted on Monday. "We are dealing from great strength, but China likewise has much to gain if and when a deal is completed. Level the field!"

China's Foreign Ministry spokesman Geng Shuang on Tuesday referred questions on the details of the trade agreement to the commerce ministry, which has yet to provide any. He reiterated that during the meeting the two leaders agreed their economic teams would step up talks to work toward getting rid of all the tariffs, and aim for a mutually beneficial deal so that trade and economic relations can get back on a "healthy" track as soon as possible.

Kudlow, director of the National Economic Council, said he, Mnuchin, and U.S. Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer held private meetings in Argentina with China's Vice Premier Liu He, who told them Beijing would move quickly on its new commitments. "The history here with China promises is not very good. And we know that," Kudlow said. "However, I will say this: President Xi has never been this involved."

Kudlow said: "They can not slow walk this, stall this, meander this. Their word: 'immediately.'" U.S. President Donald Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping attend a working dinner after the G20 leaders summit in Buenos Aires, Argentina December 1, 2018. ███/Kevin Lamarque

Administration officials expressed a mixture of skepticism and optimism on Monday over whether China would deliver. None of the commitments were agreed to in writing and many specifics have yet to be worked out. Kudlow said U.S. officials would monitor Chinese progress closely.

Negotiators will actually have less than 90 days to reach a deal because of holidays in both countries over the next three months, Chinese ambassador to the United States, Cui Tiankai, told reporters on Monday. Trump has appointed Lighthizer, who just completed a new trade agreement with Canada and Mexico and is one of the administration's most vocal China critics, to oversee the new round of talks, officials said. The appointment may signify a harder line with Beijing and marks a shift from the past, when Mnuchin had a lead role.

"He's the toughest negotiator we've ever had at the USTR and he's going to go chapter and verse and get tariffs down, non-tariff barriers down and end all these structural practices that prevent market access," White House trade adviser Peter Navarro told National Public Radio on Monday. The White House is stepping up efforts to prod other countries to build more vehicles in the United States. Lighthizer and other officials, including Kudlow, are set to meet with German automakers, including the chief executives of Volkswagen AG (VOWG_p.DE) and Daimler AG, on Tuesday, people briefed on the matter said.

Kudlow said the meeting was not meant to focus on potential tariffs, though Trump still had that option in his "quiver," and the automakers would be encouraged to build engines in the United States. On Sunday, Trump tweeted that China had agreed to cut import levies on American-made cars. Chinese regulators did not respond to requests for comment on the tweet. Neither country mentioned auto tariffs in their official briefings of the meeting on Saturday.

Title: U.S. President Donald Trump's Actions Spark Political Uncertainty and Calls for Oversight

Article:

In the past 100 days of President Donald Trump's administration, the country has experienced a series of events that have raised concerns about the president's actions and their potential impact on U.S. politics and foreign relations. The focus of the first 100 days was on policy-making, with the confirmation of a Supreme Court nominee, the addressing of foreign-policy challenges, and the hashing out of healthcare reform.

However, in the last ten days, the country has been embroiled in a political maelstrom, with the president's character and actions taking center stage. The firing of FBI Director James Comey, the disclosure of classified information to the Russians, and the alleged attempt to influence an FBI investigation have sparked a wave of controversy and calls for oversight.

The firing of James Comey was met with criticism due to the perceived impulsive and potentially politically motivated nature of the decision. The president's subsequent contradiction of his staff's statements regarding the dismissal has led to layers of falsehoods, giving the impression of an elaborate cover-up.

The disclosure of classified information to the Russians has also caused concern, but the long-term impact on U.S. intelligence relationships remains uncertain. The president's disclosure of sensitive information to the Russians has been compared to past incidents, such as the spilling of secrets during the Obama administration, with little lasting damage to U.S. intelligence relationships.

The most recent controversy involves the alleged attempt by President Trump to influence an FBI investigation into former National Security Advisor Michael Flynn. The White House has issued a statement denying the allegations, but the lack of a signed statement from administration officials has raised questions about the credibility of the denial.

The political turmoil has led to calls for increased oversight and strengthening of the "guardrails" of the U.S. political system. Some have suggested the use of the 25th Amendment to remove the president, but this idea has been met with criticism for potentially undermining the democratic process and the fixedness of the presidential term.

The political landscape remains uncertain, with the president's behavior causing concern and calls for increased oversight. The long-term impact of these events on U.S. politics and foreign relations remains to be seen.

Title: U.S. Revokes Travel Privileges for Bill Browder, Stirring Controversy on Capitol Hill

Article:

The United States government has revoked the travel privileges of Bill Browder, a prominent critic of Russian President Vladimir Putin, causing concern on Capitol Hill. Browder, a key advocate for the Magnitsky Act, found himself barred from traveling to the United States in recent days.

The situation appears to be a response to Russia's decision to place Browder on the Interpol wanted list in pursuit of his arrest. In a statement on Monday, Senators John McCain (R-Ariz.) and Ben Cardin (D-Md.) called for an immediate review of Browder's visa status, stating that it would be unfortunate if the U.S. decided to bar him based on a decision by the same Russian officials targeted by the Magnitsky Act.

Browder, a British citizen, was notified late last week that his status as a member of the Global Entry program, administered by Customs and Border Protection, had been revoked. When Browder attempted to book a flight to the United States, he discovered that his entry privileges as a British citizen had been revoked. Browder uses the Electronic System for Travel Authorization to gain entry into the U.S. under the Visa Waiver Program.

"I discovered that my Global Entry status had been revoked," Browder said. "We then checked into a flight to Newark and the airline wouldn't let me check in, wouldn't let me board because of the visa issue."

Browder added that he learned of Russia's actions on October 17, when they added him to the Interpol diffusion system.

Bill Browder is a British financier who has been a major driving force behind the Magnitsky Act, a bipartisan law passed in 2012 to punish human rights abusers in Russia. The law is named for Sergei Magnitsky, a Russian lawyer who was jailed after discovering a tax fraud scheme and who died under suspicious circumstances. Browder was one of Magnitsky's clients.

Browder's support for the law has made him an enemy of Moscow. Russia has on four previous occasions petitioned to get Interpol to secure Browder's arrest, though the international police organization has rejected the requests, deeming them politically motivated.

In the past, Browder's visa privileges were revoked as a result of Russia's actions, but he said the U.S. government previously had resolved the issue within hours.

"I am hopeful that this is just a technical issue driven by Interpol and it will be resolved quickly," Browder said Monday.

The Department of Homeland Security did not respond to a request for more information. Browder said he received little information from Homeland Security when he inquired about his Global Entry status in recent days.

"After waiting for an hour and a half, I got through to a representative who told me that they couldn't disclose why my Global Entry had been revoked, and if I wanted to find out, I should file a Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request," Browder said. "I only learned why when I went to my law enforcement contacts about Interpol."

Browder discovered that he had again been targeted by Russia just after Canada passed its version of the Magnitsky Act last week. Russia is seeking Browder's arrest on charges of tax evasion and murder.

In a public address on Thursday, Putin accused Canada of playing "unconstructive political games" and derided Browder as a criminal. The revelation that Browder's visa had been revoked triggered immediate scrutiny among critics of the Trump administration.

"This is outrageous. @realDonaldTrump, @StateDept et al, fix this now. Now. Do not join Putin's campaign against @Billbrowder," tweeted Michael McFaul, who served as the U.S. ambassador to Moscow under the Obama administration.

Title: North Korea's Internet Service Restored After Days of Outage

Article:

Following more than nine hours and 30 minutes of downtime, Internet service has been restored in North Korea, according to technology news service Dyn Research. Although access is currently partial, the country's main news service and newspaper have reportedly returned online.
