Earlier reports suggested that North Korea's Internet access became unstable late on Friday, with the service becoming completely offline by Monday, as per multiple news outlets. San Francisco-based CloudFlare, a network and security company that monitors global Web access, told The New York Times that North Korea's Internet access was "toast."

The cause of the outage remains unclear. State Department spokeswoman Marie Harf stated today, "We are not going to discuss publicly operational details about the possible response options or comment on those kind of reports in any way except to say that as we implement our responses, some will be seen, some may not be seen."

In an interview with NPR's Elise Hu, Matthew Prince, the chief executive of CloudFlare, outlined four possible scenarios: North Korea turned off its own Internet; China's upstream provider turned it off; the country's routers failed at an unfortunate time; or it was the result of a denial-of-service attack from either a hacking group or the U.S. Prince expressed doubt that the U.S. was behind the reported outage.

North Korea has one of the lowest Internet penetrations in the world, with access limited mostly to the country's elite. The U.S. has linked the recent hacking of Sony Pictures to North Korean hackers, though North Korea itself has denied responsibility. There are computer security experts who question whether Pyongyang is behind the hack.

Last week, Sony canceled the planned Christmas Day release of The Interview, a comedy that centers on a plot to assassinate North Korean leader Kim Jong Un. The decision followed threats against moviegoers and theaters that showed the film. The threats were attributed to the group that claimed responsibility for hacking Sony.

Title: Supreme Court Grants Stay on Injunction Against Military Funding for Border Wall Construction

Article:

The Supreme Court of the United States has granted the Trump administration's request to stay a district court's permanent injunction against the diversion of $2.5 billion in military spending for the construction of portions of the U.S.-Mexico border wall. This decision allows the wall construction to proceed.

The background of the case is as follows: When President Trump announced his intention to build the border wall without specific congressional authorization, he identified multiple funding sources, including $2.5 billion under the Department of Defense funds transferred for Counterdrug Activities and $3.6 billion reallocated from Department of Defense military construction projects under the President's declaration of a national emergency. The case at hand concerns the $2.5 billion transferred under the Counterdrug Activities provision.

The Sierra Club and the Southern Border Communities Coalition filed a lawsuit, alleging that the funding diversion would harm the environment and constituted an improper and unlawful diversion of funds in violation of specific congressional appropriations. However, private parties do not have the right to challenge administration expenditures without demonstrating that they have suffered a concrete and legally recognized injury as a result of the government's action. In this case, it is less clear how the plaintiffs themselves were harmed by the government's action.

Justice Breyer, in his partial concurrence and partial dissent from the Supreme Court's decision, noted that the case raises "novel and important questions about the ability of private parties to enforce Congress' appropriation power."

In its application for a stay, the Trump administration argued that the "injunction was entered at the behest of private parties whose asserted recreational and aesthetic interests in the enjoyment of public lands do not fall within the zone of interests protected by the transfer statute, and who are thus not, in any event, proper plaintiffs to sue to enforce the conditions in that statute."

Five justices of the Supreme Court agreed, at least for now, holding that it "among the reasons" it granted the stay "is that the Government has made a sufficient showing at this stage that the plaintiffs have no cause of action to obtain review" of the relevant administrative action.

It is important to note that this decision is not a final judgment for the administration, nor does it represent a ruling that the administration's diversion of funds was lawful. The stay remains in effect while the Ninth Circuit decides the case and until ultimate disposition in the Supreme Court.

This decision casts substantial doubt on whether the plaintiffs are the right parties to seek to protect Congressional authority. The Supreme Court may ultimately decide this case on the merits, but for now, it is right to cast doubt on a sweeping lower-court injunction granted on behalf of plaintiffs who have yet to adequately articulate the legally recognized harms they have suffered in what is ultimately a battle between Congress and the President of the United States.

Title: Oregon Governor John Kitzhaber Resigns Amid Allegations of Private Gain by Fiancée

Article:

Oregon Democratic Governor John Kitzhaber has submitted his resignation on Friday, following allegations that his fiancée, Cylvia Hayes, used their public positions for private gain. Reports indicate that Ms. Hayes accepted nearly $200,000 in payments from green nonprofits to work on controversial low-carbon fuel standard policies, while the administration was promoting new legislation on the issue.

The official announcement has not been made public, but sources with direct knowledge of the matter told local news station KOIN 6 that Mr. Kitzhaber met with administration officials on Friday morning to discuss his plans. His resignation will take effect at 10 a.m. on Wednesday.

Upon Mr. Kitzhaber's resignation, Oregon Secretary of State Kate Brown is expected to assume the office, becoming the nation's first openly bisexual governor. Oregon Senate Minority Leader Ted Ferrioli expressed his sentiments on Friday morning, stating that "what should be a day of celebration is turning into a day of reflection and mourning."

Ferrioli told a gathering of the Oregon Wheat Grower League outside the capitol that he would not attend Ms. Brown's swearing-in ceremony but instead would return home "to grieve for the departure in disgrace of one governor and to hope for the healing that can only come if the next governor turns away from policies that put symbolic gestures ahead of the real needs of our citizens."

Oregon House Republican Leader Mike McLane described the situation as "a sad day for Oregon." He stated, "I take no delight in John Kitzhaber's resignation but understand his decision. House Republicans have remained focused on working for the people of Oregon, and that's where our focus will remain moving forward."

Title: Supreme Court Declines to Hear Challenge to Origination Clause of Obamacare

Article:

The Supreme Court declined on Tuesday to take up an appeal that argues Congress violated the Constitution by initiating the Affordable Care Act (Obamacare) in the Senate rather than the House. The Pacific Legal Foundation, which filed the appeal, contends that the Affordable Care Act of 2010, with its revenue-raising provisions, falls under the Founding Fathers' vision of the origination clause, which requires money bills to originate in the House of Representatives.

Lower courts have previously ruled that the primary purpose of the law is to increase health insurance coverage, not to generate revenue. They also found that Congress used an acceptable maneuver to bypass the origination clause, as the key language of Obamacare originated in the Senate.

The Pacific Legal Foundation's plaintiff, Matt Sissel, is an Iraq War veteran and small business owner who objects to being forced to purchase health insurance under the individual mandate, which imposes a tax penalty on those who do not have coverage. The foundation argues that Sissel does not need or want health insurance.

The U.S. Court of Appeals for the D.C. Circuit dismissed Sissel's suit in August, stating that the primary purpose of the law was not to raise money. Other judges on the panel suggested that Obamacare should be labeled a revenue bill, but concluded that Congress did not violate the origination clause, as the Senate inserted text into a legislative shell from the House.

So far, opponents of the overhaul have not had much success before the high court. The justices upheld the law as constitutional in 2012, although the court allowed states to choose not to expand Medicaid under the law. Last year, plaintiffs in King v. Burwell argued that the law's text limited subsidies to states that set up their own exchanges. However, the court ruled that the law, when read in its entirety, allowed qualified Americans to qualify for tax credits regardless of where they live.

The Constitutional Accountability Center stated on Tuesday that "the ultimate outcome of challenges like this one aren't in doubt," suggesting that opponents of Obamacare should cease their legal efforts. Elizabeth Wydra, the center's chief counsel, described the challenges as "meritless." She added, "The Court upheld the ACA for the second time just last June, with Chief Justice Roberts picking up a sixth vote to send a clear signal that he's had enough of what has become a blatant ideological crusade. One questions whether anti-Obamacare legal activists have gotten the message."

Title: TV Networks Boost Ad Rates for Shows President Trump Frequently Watches

Article:

MSNBC and Fox News have increased issue-advocacy advertising rates for shows that President Donald Trump is known to watch, according to a veteran media buyer and a prominent D.C. consultant. The ad rates for "Morning Joe" on MSNBC have more than doubled post-election, while the rates for "The O'Reilly Factor" and other prime-time programs on Fox News have boosted their rates about 50 percent.

Trump, who reportedly watches these shows regularly, has a close relationship with "Morning Joe" host Joe Scarborough and is known to respond directly to what he sees on television and tweet about it. These tweets often drive news coverage during the day.

Some companies are proactively placing ads on "O'Reilly" and "Morning Joe" to reach the president, according to the consultant. One source at MSNBC acknowledged that ad rates for "Morning Joe" would likely increase due to strategically placed ad buys in New York and D.C. Fox News declined to comment.

The consultant stated, "Instead of lobbying through the usual channels, it's like speaking directly into the president's ear." He also mentioned that some companies are placing ads to avoid a Trump tweet or, in at least one instance, trying to prompt Trump to tweet against their competitors.

This strategy allows advertisers to potentially influence the president and his top lieutenants, as Trump's media habits are predictable, according to the media buyer.

Title: Camp David: A Venue for High-Stakes Diplomacy Through the Ages

Article:

Washington – The proposed meeting between President Donald Trump and the Taliban at Camp David, though ultimately scrapped, would not have been the first instance of high-stakes diplomacy at the presidential retreat. Built during the Great Depression by the Works Progress Administration, Camp David, nestled in a national park in Maryland, has been a venue for presidents to engage in delicate negotiations on various global issues.

Camp David, initially named Shangri-La by President Franklin D. Roosevelt, has hosted world leaders since its conversion into a presidential retreat. In 1943, Roosevelt welcomed British Prime Minister Winston Churchill, as Germany advanced across Europe during World War II. The Roosevelt Presidential Library and Museum houses a photograph of the two leaders fishing at the retreat, with Roosevelt holding a fly rod and Churchill his trademark cigar.

President Dwight D. Eisenhower, who renamed the retreat Camp David after his father and grandson, met with Soviet leader Nikita Khrushchev there in 1959. At a time of high Cold War tension, the two leaders made some progress, such as agreeing to open talks on the administration of war-torn Berlin. However, much of the goodwill was lost when an American U-2 spy plane was shot down over the Soviet Union months later.

Perhaps the most famous international gathering to take place at Camp David happened under President Jimmy Carter. In 1978, Carter brought Egyptian President Anwar al-Sadat and Israeli Prime Minister Menachem Begin to the site to broker a peace accord named for the retreat. The touch-and-go negotiations took place over 12 days, all in secret.

President Bill Clinton attempted to recreate the sense of momentum in the Middle East with his own summit in 2000, but Israeli Prime Minister Ehud Barak and Palestinian Authority leader Yasser Arafat failed to reach an agreement. Eisenhower wasn't the only president to host Russians at Camp David. President George W. Bush hosted Vladimir Putin in 2003, and President Barack Obama held a G8 summit at Camp David in 2012, when the Russians were still part of the group of the world's most industrialized economies. Obama hosted the Russian prime minister, Dmitry Medvedev.

Title: Conservative Groups Scramble to Prove Election Impact as Spending Reaches $1 Billion

Article:

In the aftermath of the 2012 election, outside groups, including super PACs and nonprofits, are facing the possibility of spending over $1 billion without electing Mitt Romney or delivering a GOP Senate. As a result, these organizations are taking steps to prove their impact and justify their substantial spending.

For two years, these groups have maintained a secretive approach, withholding details about their methods, strategies, and donors. However, in light of the potential failure to elect Romney and secure a GOP Senate, some groups have begun to disclose their spending. For instance, Americans for Prosperity, a political group associated with the billionaire brothers Charles and David Koch, has revealed details about its $72 million worth of ad buys.

Operatives running these super PACs and nonprofits are seeking to demonstrate their effectiveness in various ways, positioning themselves to claim credit for successes, dodge blame for failures, and show that they are not limited to narrowly targeted advertising.

Karl Rove's Crossroads outfit, which primarily focused on television ads supporting Romney and GOP Senate candidates, has expanded its activities to include House races and get-out-the-vote efforts, collaborating with Ralph Reed's evangelical mobilization group, Faith and Freedom Coalition.

A coalition of groups within the Koch brothers' network, including Americans for Prosperity, 60 Plus, Concerned Women for America, and CitizenLink, recently met to discuss strategies for demonstrating their value to donors.

The pro-Romney Restore Our Future super PAC has been highlighting to donors the role its advertising in Michigan and Wisconsin played in making those states competitive, while the American Future Fund has distinguished itself by spending on anti-Obama ads in traditionally Democratic states like Minnesota.

As the election nears its end, operatives, donors, and fundraisers anticipate a significant reshuffling of the conservative groups that benefited from an unprecedented influx of cash due to wealthy Republicans' antipathy towards President Barack Obama and the 2010 Citizens United decision's loosening of campaign finance rules.

Idaho businessman Frank VanderSloot, who has contributed $1.1 million to Restore Our Future and hinted at donations to Crossroads, stated, "Without question, after it's over, there is going to be a sorting out of who got the job done, and I think there will be some who might lay claim to accomplishments that they maybe didn't personally accomplish." He added, "Some of these organizations will gain in stature, and some will probably fall by the wayside."

Title: Special Counsel Acquires Communications of Erik Prince in Russian Probe

Article:

Special counsel Robert Mueller has reportedly obtained the communications of Erik Prince, the founder of private military contractor Blackwater and a close ally of President Donald Trump. According to a report by The Daily Beast, Prince has cooperated with the special counsel's investigation, providing them with access to his phones and computer.

In a statement to ABC News, a Prince spokesman confirmed that Prince has spoken voluntarily with Congress and cooperated with the special counsel's investigation. The spokesman added that Prince has opinions about the various investigations but will keep them to himself to allow the investigators to do their work.

The statement also noted that much of the reporting and speculation about Prince in the media is inaccurate and expressed confidence that when the investigators have finished their work, they will be able to put the distractions to the side.

In March, Mueller's probe reportedly uncovered evidence that a secret meeting in Seychelles shortly before President Trump's inauguration was intended to create a back channel between the incoming administration and the Kremlin. The January 2017 meeting between Prince and a Russian official close to strongman Vladimir Putin was coordinated to discuss how the Trump administration could communicate with Moscow, according to a Washington Post report.

Prince has previously told Congress that the meeting with Kirill Dmitriev, the Putin-appointed head of Russia's sovereign wealth fund, was a chance encounter "over a beer." However, ABC News reported earlier this year that Mueller had obtained evidence that created doubt about that testimony.

Investigators believe the meeting was intended to establish a line of communication between the countries that was outside normal diplomatic channels. The information came to light after it was revealed that Lebanese-American businessman George Nader, a representative of the United Arab Emirates who was part of the Seychelles meeting, was cooperating with Mueller's probe under immunity.

It was unclear whether Mueller's office would prosecute Prince or make a referral to the US attorney for the District of Columbia if they found convincing evidence of perjury, according to ABC News.

Rep. Eric Swalwell (D-Calif.), a member of the House Intelligence Committee, welcomed the renewed focus on Prince. "I have a lot of questions about whether he was being straight with us," Swalwell told ABC News. "I'm heartened to hear that the special counsel is doing what Republicans on the committee were not willing to do... and follow up and not take Mr. Prince at his word."

Title: Obama Seeks Limited Ground Operations Authorization in Iraq and Syria Against Islamic State

Article:

President Barack Obama has requested Congressional authorization for limited ground operations against the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, marking a departure from his predecessors' approach to war powers. Over the past six months, the United States military has conducted more than 1,900 airstrikes in the region without explicit Congressional approval.

In a letter to lawmakers on Wednesday, Obama reiterated his belief in the authority under current law to conduct such a campaign. However, he emphasized the need for bipartisan support and differentiated his current request from previous presidents' actions.

"It is not the authorization of another ground war, like Afghanistan or Iraq," Obama said in remarks from the White House. While he has sent 2,600 American troops back to Iraq in a support role, he stated, "I'm convinced that the United States should not get dragged back into another prolonged ground war in the Middle East."

Obama also clarified that his mission does not entail "enduring offensive ground combat operations." In a letter to Congress accompanying the proposal, he envisioned the possibility of limited ground action, such as rescue operations or the use of Special Operations forces to take military action against Islamic State leadership. He also allowed for the use of ground forces for intelligence gathering, spotting ground targets for airstrikes, and planning assistance to ground troops of allies like the Iraqi government.

"If we had actionable intelligence about a gathering of ISIL leaders, and our partners didn't have the capacity to get them, I would be prepared to order our special forces to take action," Obama said in his remarks, using an alternative acronym for the Islamic State. "I will not allow these terrorists to have a safe haven."

Title: Cruz Wins Wisconsin Primary, Altering GOP Presidential Race Landscape

Article:

Sen. Ted Cruz has been projected to win the Wisconsin primary Tuesday, marking a significant shift in the Republican presidential race as it moves east later this month. Networks called the race shortly after polls closed at 9 p.m. Eastern Time, based on exit polling that showed Cruz with a substantial lead. With 37 percent of the precincts reporting, Cruz led Donald Trump by 53 percent to 30 percent, followed by John Kasich with 15 percent.

"Tonight is a turning point. Tonight is a rallying cry," Cruz said at his election night party. "It is a call from the hardworking men and women of Wisconsin to the people of America: We have a choice, a real choice."

Cruz attributed his victory to his growing momentum and highlighted the support he has received from five of his former GOP presidential rivals, as well as recent wins in Utah, Colorado, and North Dakota. Cruz stated that he is confident he will earn the 1,237 delegates needed to secure the nomination before the Republican National Convention.

"Either before Cleveland or at the convention in Cleveland, together we will earn the majority of the delegates and together we will beat Hillary Clinton in November," Cruz said.

Cruz emphasized that his victory signifies the consolidation of anti-Trump voters within the GOP behind his bid. Trump, however, was unable to recover from a difficult week that included his campaign manager being charged with simple battery and his own stumbles on abortion and other conservative issues. Trump also faced questions about his declining poll numbers among female voters, leading him to bring his wife, Melania, onto the campaign trail.

The Cruz victory makes it more challenging for Trump to win the nomination outright on a first ballot at the July convention. Ohio Gov. John Kasich, the third man in the race, has vowed to stay in the race despite another loss.

"The nomination contest is now wide open," Kasich campaign strategist John Weaver said in a memo issued just before polls closed. "This week will be remembered as the one in which Ted Cruz and Donald Trump both effectively admitted they will not reach the GOP Convention with enough bound delegates to be the nominee."

Kasich argues, and polling confirms, that he runs the best of the three GOP candidates against Democratic front-runner Hillary Clinton. However, GOP primary voters have shown little interest in this aspect, focusing instead on choosing their champion.

Exit polls from Wisconsin revealed that 56 percent of GOP voters believe the candidate who has collected the most votes in the primaries should win the party's nomination. Four in ten favored a contested convention, where delegates would select the nominee.

Trump's proposals, such as a temporary freeze on non-US Muslims entering the country, were popular among seven in ten voters, according to exit polls. Trade was a significant concern for over half of Republican voters, who felt the United States was receiving a raw deal in trade agreements.

Six in ten GOP voters supported offering a path to citizenship for illegal immigrants, a higher percentage than in most other primary states. A third called for their deportation. Half of the voters sought a candidate with political experience, and about half wanted a candidate from outside the political establishment.

Cruz was viewed as the GOP's best hope to beat Hillary Clinton in a general election match-up, followed by Trump and Kasich, according to exit polls.

Title: Indictments and Political Fallout: A Look at the Impact of Recent Developments on the Midterm Elections

Article:

In a series of events reminiscent of the political scandals that rocked the U.S. Congress in 2006, a flurry of legal actions has taken place in August 2018, potentially impacting the upcoming midterm elections.

On August 21, former Trump campaign manager Paul Manafort was convicted by a federal jury, and former Trump attorney Michael Cohen pleaded guilty to additional charges. Subsequently, Rep. Duncan Hunter Jr., R-Calif., and his wife Margaret Hunter were indicted on charges of using campaign funds for personal expenses. These developments follow the arrest of Rep. Chris Collins, R-N.Y., on insider trading charges two weeks prior.

The charges against Hunter and Collins have no connection to the cases involving Manafort and Cohen. However, their early endorsements of President Trump have raised questions about the potential political motivations behind the indictments.

In a letter to Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein, Hunter's attorney, Gregory Vega, argued that the indictment was "politically motivated" due to Hunter's early endorsement of President Trump. Vega contends that the indictment means "a solidly Republican district is being handed to a Democratic candidate."

Meanwhile, Michael Cohen's attorney, Lanny Davis, stated, "Today he [Cohen] stood up and testified under oath that Donald Trump directed him to commit a crime by making payments to two women for the principal purpose of influencing an election." Davis' statement implies a potential connection between Cohen's actions and those of the president.

The 2006 midterm elections saw a significant shift in power, with Democrats winning control of both the House and Senate. If the current political climate mirrors that of 2006, Republicans could face a similar fate this November. However, it is essential to remember that history does not always repeat itself, and there are numerous uncertainties in the upcoming elections.

Seats in Virginia, Texas, New Hampshire, North Carolina, Nevada, and Minnesota are among those in play, making it difficult to predict the outcome with certainty. Additionally, external factors such as international crises, mass shootings, or the potential for an "October Surprise" could significantly impact the elections.

As the midterm elections approach, the political landscape remains fluid, and the full impact of these recent developments remains to be seen.

Title: Trump's Speech to Congress: A Mixed Display of Unity and Division

Article:

In the 2016 presidential race, a recurring pattern emerged: whenever Donald Trump's erratic behavior and self-created controversies posed a threat to his campaign, his aides would schedule a prepared speech before a sober audience. Trump would then read a script, often appearing bored but sounding calmer and more tempered compared to his usual self. This led to speculation about a new, more presidential Trump. However, within 24 hours, the old Trump would reappear, with his characteristic rallies and petty, vindictive tweets.

Tuesday night's speech before a joint session of Congress was not as insincere as these earlier speeches, and it was better written, albeit with the usual load of misleading statements and inaccuracies. The speech, however, revealed the internal tension within Trump's administration, as they grappled with the desire to let Trump be Trump and the urge to present a more unifying rhetoric.

The speech began with a paragraph that seemed to be added at the last minute, addressing the recent increase in anti-Semitic incidents:

"Tonight, as we mark the conclusion of our celebration of Black History Month, we are reminded of our nation's path toward civil rights and the work that still remains. Recent threats targeting Jewish Community Centers and vandalism of Jewish cemeteries, as well as last week's shooting in Kansas City, remind us that while we may be a nation divided on policies, we are a country that stands united in condemning hate and evil in all its forms."

President Trump's response to the rise in anti-Semitic incidents has been criticized, with him initially offering a half-hearted condemnation and later suggesting that the attacks might be false-flag operations. This implies that Trump believes Jews might be staging anti-Semitic attacks to discredit neo-Nazis.

However, the opportunity for a unifying message was missed, as Trump could have highlighted the extraordinary reaction of local Muslims, who rallied around their Jewish neighbors to repair the damage caused by the vandalism. A reflective president might have used this opportunity to emphasize the resilience, community, generosity, and unity that can be found in America.

Sprinkled throughout the speech were nods at unity, such as Trump's call for cooperation and trust, and his acknowledgment of the shared American identity. Yet, these approving words were interspersed with the usual Trumpian notes of division, fear, and dismissal of those who do not already support him. It seemed as if two different speeches had been merged together.

Trump spoke about the election as if only his voters went to the polls, and he described a fictitious crime wave. He also pledged to "dismantle the criminal cartels that have spread across our nation" and touted his new Victims of Immigration Crime Engagement office, which aims to tally and publicize crimes committed by undocumented immigrants.

Imagining a Victims of Black Crime Engagement or a Victims of Jewish Crime Engagement office highlights the vile nature of this initiative, as its purpose is to spread hatred and fear. This demonstrates the real Trump administration in action, reflecting Trump's heart and the divisive, fear-mongering approach that has characterized his presidency so far.

While Trump managed to act almost presidential for an hour, there are few Americans left who believe that Trump truly wants to bring the nation together. And just wait—within a matter of hours, he will be back on Twitter, and back to his true self.

Title: Egypt's Interim President Appoints ElBaradei as Prime Minister, Later Reverses Decision

Article:

Egypt's new interim president, Adly Mansour, has taken steps to assert his authority and stabilize the country amid ongoing political unrest. On Saturday, Mansour announced the appointment of Mohammed ElBaradei, a prominent critic of former President Mohammed Morsi, as interim prime minister. However, the appointment was later rescinded.

Initially, Mansour's spokesman, Ahmed el-Musalamani, confirmed the appointment, but later denied that the decision was ever certain. Reporters gathered at the presidential palace were led into a room where they were told to wait for the president to announce ElBaradei's appointment.

According to a senior opposition official, Munir Fakhry Abdelnur, the reversal was due to objections from the ultraconservative Salafi el-Nour party, with mediation reportedly underway.

Tensions remain high in Egypt, with tens of thousands of Morsi supporters rallying for a third day near a mosque in a Cairo neighborhood traditionally supportive of Islamists. The protesters chanted against Wednesday's removal of the country's first democratically elected president, General Abdel-Fattah el-Sissi, who has denied the military staged a coup, claiming he was acting on the wishes of millions of Egyptians protesting Morsi.

No major violence was reported on Saturday, as all sides regrouped after a night of fierce clashes between Morsi's supporters and opponents that turned downtown Cairo into a battlefield.

The youth opposition group behind the series of mass protests that led to Morsi's ouster has called for Egyptians to rally on Sunday in support of the new order.

Mansour, 67, the former chief justice of Egypt's constitutional court who was installed by the military as an interim leader, met with General Abdel-Fattah el-Sissi, Interior Minister Mohammed Ibrahim, and the three young leaders of Tamarod, the group that organized the massive opposition protests, on Saturday.

Meanwhile, Morsi's Muslim Brotherhood has vowed to boycott the political process, labeling the military's actions as a coup that overthrew a democratically elected government. Morsi, a U.S.-trained engineer, remains under detention in an undisclosed location.

Title: Congress Faces End-of-Year Deadline as Parties Disagree on Top Tax Rates to Avoid Fiscal Cliff

Article:

Congress faces an end-of-the-year deadline as massive spending cuts are scheduled to kick in and tax breaks begin to expire, including the Bush-era tax cuts at the end of December. This looming crisis, often referred to as the "fiscal cliff," also includes so-called sequestration -- automatic across-the-board spending cuts set to trigger at the beginning of 2013 if Capitol Hill fails to create a deficit-reduction plan.

In a formal speech on Capitol Hill Wednesday, House Speaker John Boehner sounded conciliatory even as he made it clear higher tax rates would be unacceptable to Republicans who control the House. Boehner stated that forging a bipartisan agreement that begins to solve the problem, they are willing to accept new revenue, under the right conditions, but not from higher tax rates on higher earners.

Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid, on the other hand, insisted that raising taxes on wealthier Americans has to be part of any compromise to resolve the crisis. Reid said, "There was a message sent to us by the American people, based on the campaign. People making all this money have to contribute a little bit more."

Boehner and top House GOP leaders held a conference call with all House Republicans shortly before the speaker made his speech. According to two participants on the call, the speaker gave a full readout of what he planned to say publicly, and while he reinforced his pledge not to agree to tax increases, he did urge rank and file members to give him some room to negotiate with the White House.

President Obama weighed in as well by placing separate calls to Reid, Boehner, McConnell, and House Democratic Leader Nancy Pelosi. The White House said he told them tax increases for wealthy Americans need to be part of a deal to avoid the fiscal cliff and reduce the debt.

As part of a broader compromise, Boehner said that tax reform must be coupled with "concrete steps to put our country's entitlement programs on a sounder financial footing." The speaker also expressed hope that an agreement can be reached "that sends a signal to our economy, and to the world, that after years of punting on the major fiscal challenges we face, 2013 is going to be different."

However, Boehner also said he did not think a deal could be struck in the next month and a half during a lame-duck session of Congress. Instead, he wants to reach an agreement with Democrats on a framework or bridge that would postpone the cuts and tax-rate changes for one year until a broader deal on deficit reduction -- including entitlement and tax reform -- can be worked out.

This stance is at odds with Reid, who said he opposes "kicking the can down the road" anymore. "Waiting for a month, six weeks, six months, that's not going to solve the problem," Reid said. "We know what needs to be done. So, I think that we should just roll up our sleeves and get it done."

Boehner's spokesman said there are no meetings scheduled yet between the speaker and the president, and reiterated that any deal needs to be hashed out between the principals, not in a public back-and-forth series of photo ops. Senate Republican Leader Mitch McConnell reinforced Boehner's opposition to higher tax rates and argued it's up to President Obama to "propose a way for both parties to work together in avoiding the fiscal cliff without harming a weak and fragile economy."

Title: Bush's Legacy Lives On Through Supreme Court Appointments, as Seen in the Confirmation of Clarence Thomas and Brett Kavanaugh

Article:

Former President George H.W. Bush, who passed away on Friday at the age of 94, has been widely praised as the antithesis of President Donald Trump. The contrast between the two presidents, in terms of their approach to politics and their legacies, has been a recurring theme in the media.

One of the most significant similarities between the 41st and 45th presidents lies in their Supreme Court appointments. Both nominated men who were later accused of sexual misconduct, and both stood behind those men during their confirmation battles.

Clarence Thomas, nominated by Bush in 1991, has served on the Supreme Court for 27 years. Brett Kavanaugh, nominated by Trump in 2018, is also likely to serve for decades, outlasting Trump's presidency regardless of the outcome of the 2020 election.

The appointment of a Supreme Court justice is one of the most consequential decisions a president can make, and its impact is far more enduring than the manners a president displays while in office. Bush defended Clarence Thomas after he was accused of sexual harassment by Anita Hill.

The nomination of Thomas was controversial from the beginning. When Justice Thurgood Marshall, the first black justice on the Supreme Court, announced his retirement in 1991, Bush could have honored his legacy by naming a respected African-American judge or legal scholar. Instead, Bush selected a staunch conservative in Clarence Thomas, who today is known as the most conservative member of the Court.

After Thomas was nominated, news broke of Anita Hill's allegations against him. Bush was undeterred, and on October 9, 1991, he declared that he had "total confidence" in his nominee. On October 11, after Hill and Thomas testified before the Senate, Bush called Thomas's statement "very powerful and convincing" and said the nominee had been smeared.

Hill was mocked and criticized in the press and in the Senate, and Thomas was confirmed on October 15, 1991. He has since voted consistently against abortion rights and in favor of restrictions on campaign finance. His vote has been instrumental in several landmark cases, including Bush v. Gore, which helped George H.W. Bush's son become president of the United States.

Thomas is not necessarily considered influential, but his vote continues to matter. With the addition of Brett Kavanaugh and Neil Gorsuch, anti-abortion advocates believe they have enough votes to overturn Roe v. Wade. Thomas, a staunch opponent of abortion throughout his career, is likely to be one of those votes.

The similarities between Thomas's confirmation process and Kavanaugh's extend to the role of the president. Trump's defense of Kavanaugh in many ways mirrored Bush's defense of Thomas. Both men have succeeded in pushing onto the Court someone accused of sexual misconduct, whose decisions will affect all Americans for decades to come.

Bush may have been polite where Trump is crude, restrained where Trump is over-the-top. But a look at today's Supreme Court is a reminder that when it comes to a president's legacy, style matters less than substance. And there are few decisions more substantial than the decision of what kind of person deserves to spend his or her life on the country's highest court, handing down rulings that can shape the country for generations.

Title: Global Carbon Emissions Remain High Despite Pandemic-Induced Decline

Article:

The ongoing coronavirus pandemic has led to a significant reduction in global carbon emissions, but experts warn that this is not enough to address climate change. According to the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Association, the atmospheric concentration of carbon reached a new record of 416.21 parts per million in April, surpassing levels seen in 800,000 years based on ice core records.

A new study published in the journal Nature Climate Change estimates that global carbon emissions fell by 17 percent between January and April of this year compared to daily levels in 2019. The most significant decrease was observed in the aviation sector, which makes up the smallest portion of the global footprint and saw a 75 percent decrease. Other sectors, such as ground transportation, cars, industrial manufacturing, and power demand, also experienced declines, though less dramatically.

The International Energy Agency and Carbon Brief estimate an 8 percent and 5 percent global drop in carbon emissions, respectively. Last week, the U.S. Energy Information Agency projected that carbon emissions from the electric sector alone will fall 11 percent nationally this year, and renewable energy use is on track to eclipse coal for the first time ever.

However, these declines only put us at the 2006 carbon emissions levels, and the effects are likely to be short-lived. The extent to which carbon emissions rebound depends on how governments respond to the pandemic and climate change. If politicians choose to delay climate programs, such as weakening standards for more efficient buildings and cleaner cars, emissions could eventually rebound to levels worse than before.

According to a study by the climate policy think tank Energy Innovation, U.S. emissions will bounce back from an 11 percent drop to business-as-usual by 2025. From 2030 on, the pandemic would have no material impact on pollution levels.

Megan Mahajan, an energy policy analyst with Energy Innovation, states, "We're still going to be relying on the same fossil fuel technology we relied on before the pandemic. The types of fuels we're relying on have not changed. There isn't a fundamental shift from how we power our electricity, our homes, and modes of transportation."

Experts warn that more fundamental long-term transformation of the biggest climate fuels for electricity, industrial activity, and transportation is necessary to address climate change. The world needs to hit at least a 7.6 percent drop in total carbon emissions every year for the next decade to contain warming well below a disastrous 2 degrees Celsius.

Title: Arizona Governor Appoints Rep. Martha McSally to Fill John McCain's Senate Seat

Article:

Arizona Governor Doug Ducey has appointed Rep. Martha McSally to fill the Senate seat previously held by the late Sen. John McCain. The appointment comes just over a month after McSally lost the race for Arizona's other Senate seat to Democrat Kyrsten Sinema.

McSally, a two-term congresswoman, gained national attention when she faced off against Sinema in the fall, both vying for the Senate seat vacated by Sen. Jeff Flake's decision not to run for re-election. Sinema won the seat in a relatively close race, with 50 percent of the vote to McSally's 47.6 percent. McSally conceded six days after the election.

With McSally's appointment, Arizona will be one of only a few states to be represented by two women in the Senate. McSally and Sinema will be the only serving bipartisan pair of female senators representing their state. The only other instance of this happened in New Hampshire from 2011 to 2017.

Sen. John McCain passed away in late August, just days before the Republican primary in the race for Flake's seat. McCain held his seat for decades, but it lies within the power of the governor and not McCain's family to determine who will fill the seat until a special election can be held to formally fill it in 2020.

At a news conference today, Ducey said that he was grateful that McSally and Cindy McCain "were able to get together and visit earlier this week and clear the air." Cindy McCain posted a tweet supporting the decision and calling on McSally to remember her husband's legacy.

For her part, McSally said that she looks forward to working with her recent rival Sinema, whom she accused of treason during the campaign, while they both serve as the state's representatives in the Senate for the next two years.

Assuming McSally's appointment progresses, the special election for McCain's seat will be held in 2020, and then would be up for its regularly scheduled re-election in 2022. Should McSally continue forward and run for re-election, she will have campaigned three times in six years, losing once. And since McCain won his sixth term in 2016 and Sinema's seat is up for re-election in 2024, Arizonans will have gone through five Senate elections in a decade.

Title: Call for Temporary Liquor Store Closures to Combat Domestic Violence During Pandemic

Article:

The Fresno Sheriff's Department has reported a 77 percent increase in domestic violence incidents over the past two weeks compared to three weeks ago. Similarly, the Seattle Police Department has received 614 calls in the last two weeks, a 22 percent increase compared to the average rate. Domestic violence prevention organizations in Boston are also warning of an increase in cases.

With the ongoing coronavirus pandemic and stay-at-home orders, domestic violence rates appear to be rising. The increased confinement of families, sudden demands for home schooling, job loss, and worry over the virus are contributing factors. However, alcohol is identified as a significant aggravating factor in domestic violence incidents.

According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), millions of Americans are injured or beaten annually by drunken domestic partners and parents. It is estimated that just 10 percent of adults consume 75 percent of all alcohol sold, with 10 or more drinks per day. Excessive alcohol use can impair judgment, engender anger, agitation, and dysphoria, and lead to violent behavior.

Historically, reducing access to alcohol has been shown to decrease domestic violence incidents. For instance, Finland's liquor store employee strike in the 1970s and Sweden's curtailment of liquor store sales on certain days in the 1980s both led to a decrease in domestic violence incidents. South Dakota also imposed twice-daily sobriety breathalyzer checks for individuals with multiple arrests for drunk driving, which resulted in a decrease in both drunk driving rates and domestic violence incidents by about 10 percent.

Given the current pandemic situation, the increased risk of domestic violence and the challenges in identifying such incidents due to stay-at-home orders, some experts are calling for the temporary closure of liquor stores. This measure could help reduce the frequency of domestic violence incidents during the crisis.

Healthcare workers, teachers, and other professionals are often the first to identify signs of domestic abuse. However, with the shift to telemedicine and virtual classrooms, victims are left in their homes with their abusers, and the privacy and confidentiality that in-person consultations provide are lost.

Alcoholics Anonymous (AA) meetings have moved online, but access to a private setting and the internet are prerequisites for participation, and not all members have these resources. A recent analysis found that AA is the most effective means to help people stay sober. Keith Humphreys, one of the authors of that report and a professor at Stanford University, stated, "When supports for sobriety are low and alcohol supply is high, more people get intoxicated and inflict harm on themselves and their families."

The cascading effects of domestic violence also exacerbate the pandemic. Each house call by police or paramedics is another opportunity for the disease to spread. It consumes time and personal protective equipment that are in desperately short supply. Any preventable visit to the emergency room chokes off that bottlenecked resource. And even trips to the liquor store are an avoidable reason for people to come into contact under stay-at-home orders.

Banning alcohol sales, even temporarily, will come at some cost. Liquor stores will close, and many will have to forgo their occasional glass of wine at dinner or their "quarantini" with a twist. However, the benefits to domestic violence victims and potential victims during this crisis should be prioritized.

Doctors will need to be on the lookout for patients who may be in need of extensive assistance due to alcohol withdrawal. The treatments for withdrawal are well known, widely available, and effective. Even with these possible downsides, the benefits to domestic violence victims and potential victims whom we have few other ways of helping through this crisis should be our priority.

Peter B. Bach, a physician at Memorial Sloan Kettering in New York City, emphasizes the need for a balanced approach. "Banning alcohol sales, even temporarily, will come at some cost," he said. "Liquor stores will close. Many who enjoy a glass of wine at dinner will have to forgo that pleasure for a few weeks or months. I can give up my occasionally 'quarantini' with a twist. And we can all give up the alcohol during our Zoom happy hours."

However, he adds, "With liquor stores closed, many people addicted to alcohol will have to endure the physical effects of withdrawal. For most, it lasts days and is deeply unpleasant. For about 5 percent, it can be life-threatening without medical care."

In conclusion, while the temporary closure of liquor stores may come with some challenges, the potential benefits in reducing domestic violence incidents during the pandemic cannot be ignored. The priority should be the safety and well-being of domestic violence victims and potential victims.

Title: Sanders and Trump Secure Primary Wins in Michigan and Mississippi

Article:

In a surprising turn of events, Vermont Senator Bernie Sanders has defeated former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton in Michigan's Democratic primary, marking the ninth and largest state he has won in the Democratic presidential campaign so far. The race was expected to be a significant lead for Clinton, with all 15 pre-election polls in Michigan this year showing Clinton leading Sanders by double digits.

On the Republican side, Donald Trump, the current front-runner, secured a convincing victory in Michigan, defeating Texas Senator Ted Cruz by 47 percent to 36 percent of the vote. Marco Rubio and John Kasich trailed behind with 9 percent and 5 percent of the vote, respectively. Trump also won Mississippi's Republican primary, while Cruz was projected to pick up a win in the Idaho GOP primary, and Trump was projected to easily win the Hawaii Republican caucus.

Trump's wins in Michigan and Mississippi have increased his delegate lead over Cruz, who has been pushing to consolidate conservative support. Cruz has argued that Trump is not the candidate he claims to be. However, Trump used his wins to downplay the chances for his remaining rivals, as he and the rest of the field look ahead to next week's vital winner-take-all contests in Ohio and Florida.

Meanwhile, Clinton easily won Mississippi's primary, thanks in part to her overwhelming support from black voters. She is likely to pick up more delegates in Tuesday's contests than Sanders. However, Sanders' surprising Michigan win could give him a bounce as he and the rest of the candidates charge into the vital March 15 primaries in Florida, Ohio, Illinois, Missouri, and North Carolina.

In the Republican race, Trump and Cruz have been the main contenders, with Rubio and Kasich trailing behind. Rubio, who campaigned in Michigan Tuesday, told reporters he was focusing on the Midwestern states and repeated his vow to win Ohio. Kasich, who also campaigned in Michigan Tuesday, told reporters he was counting on a win in his home state of Ohio next week to salvage his campaign.

On the Democratic side, Clinton is still trying to regain her footing as Sanders has demonstrated his grassroots support in several recent contests. Over the weekend, he claimed three victories to Clinton's one. Thanks in part to so-called "superdelegates" - party leaders and officials free to support whomever they want - Clinton maintains a huge delegate lead over Sanders. As of early Wednesday morning, she had 1,221 to Sanders' 571.

Looking ahead, Rubio rallied a home-state crowd Tuesday evening, saying: "I believe with all my heart that the winner of the Florida primary next Tuesday will be the nominee of the Republican Party... And I need your help. I need your vote." Clinton, meanwhile, is still trying to regain her footing as Sanders has demonstrated his grassroots support in several recent contests.

Title: Influential Church Figures Push for Recognition of Homosexual Relationships at Upcoming Vatican Synod

Article:

Evidence is emerging of concerted efforts by a group of influential church figures, primarily from Germany and northern Europe, to influence the Catholic Church's stance on homosexual relationships, particularly through the upcoming church synod on the family. The group aims to make the meeting focus on same-sex relationships, while cloaking their agenda in vague and abstract language.

Their objectives include "enriching" the "biblical and theological foundations" of the synod (a euphemism for disregarding traditional church teaching), creating a "new theology of love" (an abstract concept aimed at legitimizing extramarital unions), and finding a "nonhostile" language to convey church doctrine (a watering down of Catholic teaching).

While these figures publicly distance themselves from endorsing same-sex "marriage," they support church recognition of homosexual relationships and acts, which were once considered grave sins. The October Synod on the Family, called by Pope Francis and to be attended by over 400 bishops and experts, is intended to discuss how to better pastorally apply the church's teaching on marriage and the family. However, some fear that the meeting may be derailed by powerful lobbies, some of whom are running the synod itself.

On Monday, 50 participants, including nine bishops and over 20 liberal theologians, attended a secretive "study-day" at Rome's prestigious Gregorian Jesuit university. During the meeting, none of those attending opposed church recognition of same-sex relationships when it was explicitly proposed by one of the speakers.

The meeting was organized at the invitation of the heads of the German, Swiss, and French bishops' conferences. Cardinal Reinhard Marx, president of the German bishops and one of nine cardinals advising the Pope on church and Vatican reform, gave the meeting's closing address.

Professor Manfred Spieker, a German church expert, wrote on the website Kathnet that the meeting was "divisive" and an abuse of the presidents' offices, given that only those bishops sympathetic to the homosexual agenda were invited. He criticized the event, stating it undermined the purpose and intent of the upcoming synod and promoted views that have "schismatic potential."

The study-day took place just days after a referendum in Ireland to allow same-sex marriage, leading some to believe the timing was not coincidental. German Cardinal Walter Kasper, whose theology Pope Francis admires, told Corriere della Sera May 27 that the Irish vote means the church needs to address the question of same-sex couples more fully, and that what was a "marginal topic" at the last Synod on the Family in October 2014, has now become "central."

The church, he said, has been too silent about this issue for too long and, in later comments, said the church needs to "disarm" its language to try to make contact with the secular world. The church, he believes, needs to honor long-lasting same-sex relationships.

Such sentiments are roundly rejected by faithful Catholics who view this kind of approach as surrendering to secular values and sowing confusion. However, the church homosexual lobby, driven by ideology more than the well-being of the souls of homosexuals themselves, is unlikely to be deterred.

One of the tools it is using to achieve its goal is the media. The major German publishing house, Herder, is to publish a large book in September—just a month before the synod—by a group of Catholic academics pushing the homosexual agenda. Called "Who Am I to Judge?" after the Pope's misquoted remark on the issue, it calls for more acceptance of the homosexual lifestyle on the grounds that condemning homosexuality no longer meets with a "positive response" among the faithful.

Although Pope Francis has warned of a homosexual lobby in the church, it remains unclear how seriously he is in confronting it. A significant number of church leaders and academics and some of his closest advisers are pushing the agenda, but his silence and inaction in the face of such dissent is causing increasing distress among many faithful Catholics.

Church historian Roberto de Mattei observed that during the Irish referendum, the Pope kept a "sepulchral silence" and, despite its gravity, chose instead to often rail against other evils such as "corruption, trafficking in arms and slaves, and the vanity of power and money." De Mattei and others feel that if the Pope, given his popularity, had strongly urged the Irish people to vote no a week or so before the ballot, it could have swung the result by as much as 10 percent, possibly enough to have led to a no vote.

By not doing so, they argue, not only was the Irish vote lost, but church divisions are being left to fester and deepen, driven by a wealthy and powerful German church that has all but lost its faith. Last week, church figures in Germany publicly rebuked Cardinal Pietro Parolin, the Pope's deputy, for saying the Irish referendum result was a "defeat for humanity." Meanwhile, media pressure is beginning to be exerted on those few German bishops who are resisting the homosexual lobby.

Arguably, a positive element to all of this is that the homosexual lobby is being exposed as they look to the synod for their salvation. However, the potential damage they will cause the church and souls in the meantime could be beyond measure.

Title: "Obama and Romney in Deadlock as Election Day Approaches"

Article:

With five days remaining until the U.S. presidential election, both the Obama and Romney campaigns are making strong arguments for their respective electoral victories. According to top campaign advisers interviewed by The Wall Street Journal, President Obama's re-election strategy has been to disqualify Mitt Romney, often at the expense of making his own case. However, this strategy has not been successful in swaying voter favorability, as the latest polls show Romney and Obama tied on favorability, and both over 50 percent.

The Obama campaign's strategy has been to focus on the Rust Belt states, where a series of polls indicate that Romney may fall just short of an electoral victory. This has led to a narrative in the establishment press that Obama will be re-elected. On the other hand, Romney's advisers argue that close is good enough for the Republican nominee, pointing to high voter intensity on the Republican side and a strong performance with several key groups that were crucial to Obama's 2008 victory.

The Obama campaign's decision to move left after taking office and stay there has hardened Republican opposition and boosted a traditional turnout advantage for the Republican Party. The Obama Democrats argued that superior resources and a community organizing approach to governance and campaigning would allow Obama to overwhelm the organic advantage of the Republicans. However, early voting data suggests that this strategy has not been successful, as the early vote in swing states is erased or even reversed compared to 2008.

Independents are the most promising field of persuadable voters, and Romney is leading among this group by a wide margin. In the latest poll, Romney holds a 7-point lead among independent voters, with 16 percent still undecided or supporting a marginal candidate. It is highly unlikely that the incumbent will get half of these remaining undecided voters, giving Romney a clear advantage.

Chris Stirewalt, digital politics editor for Fox News, noted that the incumbent's "Axelrod mustache promise" has doubled voter intensity, with some voters indicating they will vote twice on Election Day. The race remains tight, and the outcome is uncertain, but Romney's lead among independent voters suggests that he may have the edge in a race that goes down to the wire.

Title: McConnell Adopts Aggressive Strategy for Reelection Campaign

Article:

In the political landscape of Kentucky, Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R) is gearing up for a robust reelection campaign, adopting a strategy reminiscent of recent efforts by Senate stalwarts such as Harry Reid and John McCain. The incumbent senator is reportedly using a combination of substantial fundraising, targeted voter messaging, and aggressive outreach to secure support from state GOP legislators.

McConnell's strategy appears to have already deterred at least one potential challenger, actress Ashley Judd, who announced on Wednesday that she would not seek the Democratic nomination. The senator's aggressive approach involves employing "every penny" of a war chest expected to surpass the $21 million he spent in 2008.

The Kentucky secretary of state, Alison Lundergan Grimes, is currently the most likely Democratic contender. If Grimes decides not to run, the Democratic party could be left without a top-tier candidate to challenge McConnell.

In the face of growing opposition from both the tea party movement and the Democratic party, McConnell is attempting to balance his political stance by appealing to both the Republican base and middle-of-the-road voters. He has expressed interest in supporting a gun control bill being drafted by Sen. Chuck Grassley (R-Iowa), but has stated his opposition to more sweeping gun-control measures.

On spending, McConnell has shifted his rhetoric from promoting earmarks as a sign of his influence in Washington, to criticizing President Barack Obama and Democratic budget plans as a means of appealing to the conservative base's concerns about the deficit and new spending.

McConnell has also been instrumental in drafting several bipartisan deals with the White House, including the year-end tax accord in 2010, the 2011 Budget Control Act, and the 2013 New Year's Day law to avert the fiscal cliff. The focus now shifts to the upcoming primary elections and the strategies each candidate will employ to secure their party's nomination.

Title: White House Outlines Potential Consequences of Looming Spending Sequesters

Article:

The White House has outlined some of the potential costs of looming spending "sequesters," stating that the administration would cut 70,000 youngsters from Head Start, reduce federal loans to small businesses, and decrease the number of food safety inspectors on the job. The $85 billion in cuts, primarily in defense but also covering basic domestic spending, is expected to harm the economy, according to the White House.

David Werfel, the federal controller for the White House's Office of Management and Budget, stated, "Sequester is a blunt and indiscriminate instrument that poses a serious threat to our national security, domestic priorities, and the economy. It does not represent a responsible way to achieve deficit reduction."

Under the 2011 debt deal, the automatic cuts are scheduled to take effect every year for the rest of this decade, in exchange for Congress granting President Obama the authority to borrow more money. All of that borrowing space has been used up, but Mr. Obama wants to cancel the cuts and replace them with tax increases instead, arguing that the wealthy can afford to pay more in order to fund those priorities.

House Speaker John A. Boehner has stated that he wants to avoid the sequesters, and would prefer to cut spending in other areas, though they reject tax hikes, and any replacement must be alternative spending cuts. Defense-hawk Republicans say they cannot stomach the deep cuts to the Pentagon, which the White House now says would total 8 percent on an annualized basis.

Many rank-and-file Republicans argue that the sequesters are the best deal the GOP can get at this point to actually see some spending cuts. This sentiment was bolstered after the "fiscal cliff" agreement, which saw Republicans agree to $650 billion in new taxes over the next decade without any corresponding spending cuts.

The White House has detailed a series of specific cuts from the sequesters that it says would be too devastating to allow to happen. These include:

* 600,000 women and children would lose food stamps, which could also cost at least 1,600 state and local jobs due to reduced funding.
* 100,000 formerly homeless people would lose their government-financed housing.
* Cuts to special-education money would eliminate federal support for 7,200 school employees around the country.
* Job safety inspectors might have to be furloughed, which the White House warned "would leave workers unprotected and could lead to an increase in worker fatality and injury rates."

The White House also laid out the broader negative consequences the sequester would have when it comes to the economy as a whole. Private forecasters, the Congressional Budget Office, and others have estimated that letting the sequester take hold would cost the country millions of jobs.

If Congress cannot reach a deal, the White House urged lawmakers to delay the sequester by at least a three-month period to allow time to find targeted spending cuts, instead of an arbitrary across-the-board slash to all budgets, defense and domestic. Jason Furman, the principal deputy director of the White House's National Economic Council, said, "The notion here is to delay these very severe impacts that I've described so that you have time to work out a deal that can delay and avoid them more permanently."

Title: Senate May Reconsider Bipartisan Gun Background Checks Bill This Year

Article:

The 113th Congress continues its debate over gun control and background checks, with Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid hinting at a potential re-vote on the bipartisan bill this year. The renewed focus on the issue follows a mass shooting in Las Vegas that left five people dead, including the shooter, who was reportedly a felon and could not have purchased a gun with background checks.

In a statement to reporters on Tuesday, Reid argued that the failure of the Senate's bipartisan background check legislation last spring has not slowed the number of high-profile instances of gun violence. He stated that the Las Vegas shooter, who was a felon, would not have been able to purchase a gun if background checks were in place.

When asked if the Senate would revisit the legislation from Senators Joe Manchin (D-W.Va.) and Pat Toomey (R-Pa.), Reid replied that he would not be surprised if there was another vote on the bill. Manchin, who has been a vocal advocate for the legislation, stated that Reid's message is that if the Senate can secure five additional votes to break a 60-vote filibuster threshold, the legislation will be reintroduced.

Manchin, who is a gun owner and a supporter of the Second Amendment, emphasized that he supports responsible gun ownership and would not sell his gun to a stranger, criminal, or someone with a history of mental illness or irresponsible behavior.

Senator John McCain of Arizona, one of the four Republicans who supported the Manchin-Toomey bill last year, stated that he would vote the same way if the bill comes up again this year and expressed no qualms with Reid calling for a re-vote.

The shooting in Las Vegas appears to have rekindled Reid's legislative focus on gun control for the remainder of the year, after months of inactivity. On Monday, Reid stated that the "American people are counting" on the Senate to pass the bill, and when the White House tweeted about passing gun legislation on Tuesday, Reid's account tweeted back, "Very few things that I deal with really cause me the heartache that this issue does."

Title: House Speaker John Boehner Moves Toward Lawsuit Over President Obama's Immigration Executive Actions

Article:

House Speaker John Boehner announced on Tuesday that he is moving closer toward suing President Obama over his executive actions on immigration. According to the National Journal, House Republicans are expected to vote on a resolution that would allow Congress to join the existing lawsuit that 26 states have filed against Obama, or file its own lawsuit against the president.

The lawsuit is anticipated to allege that the program President Obama announced last fall, which would grant protection from deportation to unauthorized immigrant parents of U.S. citizens and permanent residents, exceeds his legal authority. It is unclear whether the lawsuit will also claim that the president's existing "deferred action" program for young unauthorized immigrants, which has been in place since 2012, is illegal.

The difference between targeting both programs and just targeting the new set of executive actions is a matter of political and legal nuance. The Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program, which has granted protection from deportation to approximately 600,000 unauthorized immigrants, is a controversial topic due to the broader set of executive actions taken by President Obama in recent years.

The DACA program, which was not controversial when it was first announced, has become politically contentious as Obama considered and eventually implemented executive actions to provide relief to a broader group of unauthorized immigrants. The GOP did not sue Obama in 2012 or even in 2014 over the existing program.

Suing Obama now over both programs could raise questions about why Congress is only taking legal action over something that has been ongoing for years if it truly believes it is a significant constitutional threat. This is relevant to the GOP's legal case and to the politics of the issue, as the DACA program was generally popular when it was rolled out. Polls show mixed opinions on the new executive action, with Americans either favoring letting Obama's actions stand by a margin of 15 percentage points or wanting it to be blocked by a similar margin.

Title: Politicians Should Not Define Patriotism: A Call for Separation of Politics and Patriotism

Article:

The role of politicians in defining and directing patriotism has been a contentious issue, with some critics arguing that such self-aggrandizement is more reminiscent of cults of personality rather than American republicanism. The use of inauguration days to declare "National Days of Renewal and Reconciliation" or "National Day of Patriotic Devotion" has been criticized as a form of self-aggrandizement.

The article points out that treating politicians like quasi-religious figures and tying patriotism to political ideologies or office is not in line with the vision of the Founding Fathers. It is argued that if one's devotion to America is contingent upon the party or the person in office, it may not align with the original vision of American patriotism.

The article also criticizes the use of terms like "economic patriotism" or "economic nationalism" to replace American idealism. The author argues that these terms are used to justify policies that may infringe upon unalienable rights, such as avoiding excessive taxation, which is considered one of the most American things to do.

The article further criticizes economic nationalism, which is seen as a form of populism that lays blame on others for American problems and values power over principles, including liberty. The author argues that economic nationalism is not American patriotism, but rather a form of nationalism that is inseparable from the desire for power.

The article concludes by emphasizing that it is possible to hate one's president and still be patriotic. It is also possible to hope for a president's failure and still be patriotic. The author calls for a separation of politics and patriotism, arguing that presidents are politicians with agendas that may not always align with individual worldviews. The author suggests that devotional veneration of political ascendency every four years should be avoided.

Title: Trump Tweets Doctored Video of Biden Amidst Ongoing Allegations of Inappropriate Behavior

Article:

Less than two months ago, Alva Johnson, a former Trump campaign staffer, came forward to accuse Donald Trump of kissing her without her consent in 2016. This made Johnson the 16th woman to accuse the president of groping, kissing, or assaulting her. At least seven additional women have also accused Trump of sexual harassment.

In October 2016, Trump was infamously recorded bragging about groping women. When his remarks were published by the Washington Post, Trump issued a perfunctory apology and downplayed it as "locker room talk," but the behavior he boasted about reflects the accounts of many of his accusers.

On Thursday afternoon, Trump tweeted out doctored footage of Joe Biden that was meant to mock the former vice president for a video he shared the day before. In the original video, Biden responded to accusations he repeatedly invaded women's personal space by promising "to be much more mindful."

In the video Trump tweeted, Biden is shown grabbing himself on the shoulders and kissing himself on the head—the same sort of inappropriately handsy behavior the former vice president is now reckoning with.

Trump's decision to try to capitalize on accusations of inappropriate behavior despite all the allegations against him illustrates the sheer shamelessness of his administration. And it's not just the president. During a Fox News interview last Sunday, White House counselor Kellyanne Conway said video of Biden's "creepy" behavior would be "a big problem" for him if he ran for president, completely ignoring the fact that her boss has been accused of far worse.

The video Biden posted on Wednesday stops short of apologizing for his behavior, and his line that "social norms are changing" obfuscates the fact that at least two women—Lucy Flores and Amy Lappos—accused him of conduct they say was inappropriate at the time, not just in hindsight. If Biden decides to run in the first post-#MeToo presidential election, his treatment of women will rightfully be something he has to answer for.

But Trump is definitely not in a position to make a good faith case against him. So, if Trump isn't genuinely concerned about the treatment of women, what's the point of his tweet? One likely possibility: ending Biden's candidacy before it officially begins. The vice president continues to outpoll the Democratic presidential candidates who are already officially running, and he's currently outpolling Trump by anywhere between five and 13 points.

The news moves fast. To stay updated, follow Aaron Rupar on Twitter, and read more of ███'s policy and politics coverage.

Title: Young Americans' Support for Socialism: A Closer Look at the Factors Influencing the Trend

Article:

A recent shift in political ideology among young Americans has seen an increase in support for socialist ideas, as demonstrated by the election of a group of progressive congresswomen, commonly referred to as "The Squad," and the growing popularity of Senator Bernie Sanders, who identifies as a democratic socialist.

In a Harris poll, it was found that about half of millennials would prefer to live in a socialist country. This trend can be attributed to several factors, including economic hardships, such as the burden of student loan debt, and dissatisfaction with the political and economic status quo.

One significant factor contributing to this shift is the high level of student loan debt among college-educated Americans. Estimates suggest that they collectively owe an estimated $1.5 trillion in unpaid student loans. Many of these debtors struggle to repay their loans, and the prospect of debt cancellation is an appealing solution for those burdened with college loans.

Another factor is the impact of globalization on the American economy. Over the past 30 years, globalization has created wealth disparities, with the elite benefiting disproportionately, while many Americans have been left behind. Additionally, "free" but unfair trade agreements have contributed to the hollowing out of the American middle class.

The current generation of young people is also more urbanized and concentrated in coastal cities, where the cost of living is high, and opportunities for well-paying jobs are limited. This economic reality, combined with the allure of urban life, may contribute to a culture that emphasizes instant social justice and a desire for government intervention to address economic inequality.

It is worth noting that young people's support for socialism may not necessarily reflect a deep understanding of socialist ideologies or their historical consequences. Many young activists may be unaware of the bloody careers of historical figures such as Cambodian dictator Pol Pot, Soviet Union strongman Joseph Stalin, and Chinese revolutionary leader Mao Zedong, who each killed millions of their own people.

Furthermore, the education system's focus on race, class, and gender indoctrination rather than the empirical study of economics, history, and politics may contribute to a lack of understanding of the historical and economic reasons for the wealth and stability of nations that have embraced free-market capitalism and constitutional government.

In conclusion, the shift in political ideology among young Americans can be attributed to several factors, including economic hardships, urbanization, and a lack of understanding of socialist ideologies and their historical consequences. It is essential for education systems to provide unbiased information about economics, history, and politics to ensure that young people make informed decisions about their political beliefs.

Title: Trump's Response to Coronavirus Contrasts with His Border Policies and Nationalist Stance

Article:

President Donald Trump's response to the coronavirus outbreak has been markedly different from his stance on border control and his emphasis on the importance of borders and the perceived danger of China. Despite the coronavirus originating from China and posing a foreign threat, Trump initially downplayed the severity of the virus, contradicting his long-held nationalist views.

In 2015, Trump famously called for a "total and complete shutdown" of Muslims entering the United States. However, in response to the coronavirus, Trump has largely adopted a more dismissive attitude, despite the risks of the disease still being unknown.

Trump's more somber tone was evident in his Oval Office address, but many of his supporters have followed his initial attitude, dismissing the threat of the coronavirus. Arguments such as it being similar to the flu, only affecting the elderly, or that the swine flu had a higher death toll have been used to downplay the severity of the virus.

The coronavirus, originating from China, has posed a significant threat to the United States. It is China that has given the world the coronavirus, making it a more damaging issue than, for instance, the production of iPhones. Borders, the first line of defense, have been a key focus for Trump, with travel restrictions being implemented.

The spread of the virus has been facilitated by globalization and increased interconnectedness. The so-called Deep State, the federal bureaucracy, has been criticized for botching the initial testing in the United States. The New York Times reported on a Seattle-area research project that wanted to test for the coronavirus early, but was repeatedly denied by federal agencies due to senseless rules.
