Global supply chains have increased the vulnerability of the U.S. if the virus runs out of control, with China manufacturing a large share of medicines for the U.S., and other countries beginning to hold on to the masks and protective gear they produce.

The government will have to organize the U.S. response, not the free market, which is a key assumption of populist nationalists. Despite this, Trump supporters have resorted to denial rather than reacting to a threat that should be in their wheelhouse with tools congenial to them.

There are honorable exceptions, such as Senator Tom Cotton, the Arkansas Republican, who has been warning of the coronavirus since the country was still preoccupied with impeachment. Tucker Carlson has also been vocal about the potential dangers from the beginning.

Big events often carry a distinct ideological charge. The September 11 attacks had a strong conservative valence, while the financial crisis had a liberal one. The coronavirus outbreak, originating from China, poses a threat that should vindicate key assumptions of populist nationalists and spur them to action, but Trump and his supporters have been on a path toward allowing the coronavirus to discredit them.

Title: Dayton Shooter Identified as Left-Wing Activist with Anti-Police, Pro-Gun Control Views

Article:

In the early hours of Sunday morning, Connor Betts, armed with a rifle, rampaged through a Dayton entertainment district, resulting in the deaths of his sister and eight other individuals, and leaving dozens more wounded. Police subsequently killed Betts.

Heavy.com reports that they have identified Betts as the gunman through various means, including a matching tattoo, family connections, similar photos, and references to college and growing up in Ohio and Dayton.

Betts' Twitter account, @iamthespookster, paints a picture of a left-wing anarchist and discontent, contrasting sharply with the anti-immigration manifesto of the El Paso gunman from the previous day.

The Twitter account reveals Betts' political leanings as far-left. He expressed support for the Democratic party, with a tweet reading "Vote blue for gods sake," and a post on the day of Sen. John McCain's death stating "F--k John McCain."

Despite his fascination with guns, Betts was also a proponent of gun control, blaming the Republican party for school shootings. He tweeted, "This is America: Guns on every corner, guns in every house, no freedom but that to kill," and, on the day of the Parkland, Florida, school shooting, he tweeted at Sen. Rob Portman, "Hey rob. How much did they pay you to look the other way? 17 kids are dead. If not now, when?"

In reference to the 2017 Las Vegas shooting, he tweeted, "You can’t kill 50+ people and injure 600 (! ) In 10 minutes with cigarettes my dude."

Politically, Betts was on the far left. His pinned Top Tweet was a retweet of someone else's claim that "Millennials have a message for the Joe Biden generation: hurry up and die."

When another Twitter user posted a picture of Sen. Elizabeth Warren and 2020 Democratic presidential candidate Kamala Harris and asked "co-Presidents?", Betts expressed disdain. He replied, "Nahh, but only cuz Harris is a cop - Warren I’d happily vote for."

Betts also shared posts about "concentration camps" at the border and wrote, "Cut the fences down. Slice ICE tires. Throw bolt cutters over the fences."

As of Sunday, Dayton police have stated they have no proof of Betts' motive.

Title: House Judiciary Committee Holds Closed-Door Hearing with Hope Hicks, Former White House Communications Director

Article:

The House Judiciary Committee held a closed-door hearing on Wednesday with Hope Hicks, former White House communications director, in relation to the investigation led by special counsel Robert Mueller into Russian interference in the 2016 election. During the hearing, Hicks declined to answer several questions regarding her tenure in the White House.

Representative David Cicilline (D-RI) expressed his dissatisfaction to NPR during a break in the hearing, stating, "There's a whole bunch of lawyers in there." He added, "She's staffed up with many lawyers — her own lawyers, White House counsel lawyers — all there to make sure that she follows White House directions to not share information, to prevent Congress from conducting its oversight."

Hicks was the first senior administration official to agree to testify before the House committee about Mueller and President Trump's orders. President Trump criticized Democratic officials in Congress for putting Hicks "through hell" months after the Mueller report had already concluded.

In a tweet on June 19, 2019, President Trump questioned why former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton deleted and acid-washed her emails after receiving a subpoena from Congress, stating, "Anybody else would be in jail for that."

Republicans, as reported by Fox News, criticized their Democratic colleagues for wasting taxpayer money and refusing to focus on issues like the immigration crisis. Representative Doug Collins (R-GA) said, "The Democrats can try to re-litigate the Mueller investigation, but they don’t have the resources, and they're simply just having dramatic readings." Collins added, "This is not something we need to be doing when we have a border crisis, when we have other things going on... this is just another press release for the Democrats."

Hicks was originally subpoenaed by the committee, but after negotiations, she agreed to a closed-door testimony. The transcript of the hearing will be released in the next few days.

Title: Obama Faces Strategic Choice in Nominating Supreme Court Justice Replacement

Article:

President Barack Obama has pledged to fulfill his constitutional duty of nominating a successor for the late conservative Supreme Court Justice Antonin Scalia, who passed away over the weekend. The decision now lies with Obama on whether to attempt to sway Republican senators with his pick or make a political statement in the election year.

Several Senate Republicans have already declared they will not confirm a new justice before the fall's presidential elections, given the potential impact on the court's balance of power. Mark Hurwitz, a political scientist at Western Michigan University, stated, "I don't see the Republicans just giving in and giving President Obama the opportunity to do that."

With the Senate's Republican majority unlikely to confirm Obama's nominee before the elections, the president is left with a strategic choice: what he aims to achieve. Constitutionally, Obama cannot force the Senate to vote on his nominee, but he can apply public pressure through Republican inaction. Some Democrats hope that Republicans will at least allow a hearing, even if they block Obama's nominee.

If his nominee does not even receive a hearing, Obama can make a statement by choosing a lower court judge who has already undergone a rigorous vetting process or by reaching out with a politically acceptable candidate. One potential candidate is District of Columbia Circuit Court Judge Sri Srinavasan, who was confirmed by the Senate 97 to 0 in May 2013.

Republicans might not be inclined to cooperate, given their lingering resentment over Democrats' 2013 move to eliminate filibusters for lower court federal judges. With Obama having already made Democratic appointees the majority on nine of the nation's 13 circuit courts, Republicans are unlikely to concede easily on Scalia's replacement.

This could lead Obama to nominate an overtly liberal candidate, using the political fallout from the stymied nomination to mobilize voters in November. The political maneuvering underscores the significant consequences of the nomination, affecting issues such as campaign finance, affirmative action, religious freedom, and the Second Amendment.

Jay Wexler, a professor at the Boston University School of Law, noted that the nomination "will likely have enormous consequences for constitutional law in the nation." Professor Hurwitz of Western Michigan University added, "Republicans became very aware, particularly during the Reagan administration, how important judicial nominations were. With a presidential election looming, they smell the White House right now, and they don't want to lose this."

Title: NBC News Aims for 50% Diversity in Workforce and Long-Form Investigative Focus on Communities of Color

Article:

NBC News, a subsidiary of NBCUniversal News Group, has announced a new initiative, the "Fifty Percent Challenge," with the goal of achieving a more diverse workforce. The initiative, as stated by NBCUniversal News Group Chairman Cesar Conde, aims to have 50% of the organization's employees be women and 50% be people of color.

Currently, women make up 50% of the organization's workforce, while people of color make up 27%. The company employs approximately 3,000 people, with news organizations including NBC News, MSNBC, and CNBC.

In an internal memo, Conde expressed the importance of reflecting the diversity of the country and the communities they serve. He stated, "We want to increase diversity and inclusion both in front of and behind the camera, and earn the trust of every community in America that relies on us for exceptional journalism."

The chairman acknowledged that this objective is ambitious and will require time to achieve. He emphasized the need to start the effort now to reach the goal in the future. In addition to diversifying the workforce, the company will also focus on doing more long-form investigative pieces on issues that impact people of color.

The announcement comes amidst a wave of introspection and change within businesses and organizations across the country, following the Black Lives Matter protests and the death of George Floyd.

It is important to note that the memo does not specify that hiring decisions will be based solely on gender and skin color, but rather on achieving a more diverse workforce. The memo also does not indicate a shift away from journalism towards activism. The future impact of this initiative on the organization's journalistic approach remains to be seen.

Title: Can a President Pardon Themselves? Giuliani and Legal Experts Debate the Constitutional Question

Article:

In a recent interview, Rudy Giuliani, President Trump's confidante and lead attorney in the ongoing Russian investigation, was asked about the possibility of a sitting president pardoning themselves. Giuliani stated that President Trump "probably" has the power to pardon themselves, but emphasized that Trump has no intention of doing so.

Giuliani further explained, "Pardoning other people is one thing. Pardoning yourself is another." He added that other presidents have pardoned individuals in similar circumstances, but noted the political ramifications of a self-pardon could be challenging.

The question of a president's self-pardoning power is a topic of debate among legal experts. P.S. Ruckman, a political science professor at Rock Valley College in Rockford, Illinois, who runs a blog about presidential pardons, told Bloomberg News, "Literally, yes. He could write his pardon down on a napkin and sign it—that would be a pardon."

However, other legal experts argue that the answer is less clear-cut. Alan Dershowitz, Felix Frankfurter Professor of Law, Emeritus, wrote in an op-ed that the answer is "crystal clear" but remains unknown due to the lack of a definitive answer. He noted that James Madison wrote in the Federalist Papers that no person "is allowed to be a judge in his own case." Dershowitz questioned whether a self-pardon would violate this principle and bestow jurisdiction on a court to invalidate the self-pardon.

Law professor Lawrence Tribe, in a Washington Post op-ed, cited the Office of Legal Counsel's reasoning four days before Richard Nixon resigned, stating that an embattled president cannot pardon themselves. President Trump has maintained his innocence in the Russian collusion "witch hunt," and Mueller has not charged the president with any specific crimes, making the self-pardoning question a hypothetical one at this time.

Title: Vice President Joe Biden's Possible Presidential Campaign: A Look at Recent Developments and Potential Implications

Article:

Speculation surrounding Vice President Joe Biden's potential entry into the 2016 presidential race has intensified following a series of meetings and public appearances in New York last week. According to John Heilemann of Bloomberg, Biden met with top Obama donor Robert Wolf, delivered a speech in support of a minimum wage hike, stood by Attorney General Loretta Lynch during an announcement regarding rape kit testing, and gave an emotional interview with Stephen Colbert.

Columnist David Brooks of The New York Times has suggested that these events have rekindled the prospects of a Biden candidacy. Brooks believes that Biden's personal story of loss and empathy could resonate not only with Democratic voters but also with a broader electorate.

Robert Wolf, a prolific fundraiser for President Barack Obama and a close friend of the Vice President, confirmed a meeting with Biden over the weekend. The topics discussed during their conversation reportedly included the reauthorization of the Export-Import Bank and the nation's crumbling infrastructure, a focus of Wolf's consulting firm, 32 Advisors.

If Biden decides to run, securing the support of a prominent fundraiser like Wolf could provide several benefits. Wolf, who raised over half a million dollars for Obama in both 2008 and 2012, could serve as a significant source of campaign funds. Additionally, Wolf's connections to Wall Street, an area where Biden has few ties, could help establish economic credibility.

However, Biden's potential campaign faces several challenges. He has previously run for president twice and lost both times, and his performance in New Hampshire has been lackluster. Moreover, Biden would miss the first Democratic debate and the Florida Democratic Party convention if he enters the race later.

Another significant challenge is Biden's need to compete with Hillary Clinton for the support of black voters, a demographic he would need to secure the Democratic nomination. Clinton currently enjoys a high approval rating among black voters in South Carolina, a state where Biden is reportedly focusing his efforts.

The question remains whether Biden has the "emotional fuel" to mount a successful campaign. While there appears to be enough support for a challenge, the outcome remains uncertain.

Title: Fact-Checking the Obama and Romney Campaign Ads: A Look at the Bain Capital Issue

Article:

The ongoing political campaign between President Barack Obama and Mitt Romney has seen a series of negative advertisements from both sides, with fact-checkers rendering multiple verdicts on the subjects of Bain Capital, Romney, and outsourcing. This article will focus on the accuracy of the claims made in these ads.

In recent days, the Obama campaign has released a series of ads that have been criticized for their factual inaccuracies. These ads, according to the Chicago Tribune's David Brooks, are not just negative but also factually inaccurate. The Obama campaign has received numerous "Pinocchios" from fact-checkers for misleading, unfair, and untrue commercials based on "no evidence."

In response, the Romney campaign has released a new ad, which, while not a bad offering, is said to only graze the critical point. The ad touches upon the factual inaccuracies in the Obama ads.

The Obama campaign's ads are not just relentlessly negative; they are knowingly and stubbornly factually inaccurate. For instance, in an interview with a Virginia television station WAVY, President Obama stated, "Mr. Romney claims that he's Mr. Fix-it for the economy because of his business experience. And so I think voters entirely legitimately want to know, well what exactly was that business experience?" This statement, according to fact-checkers, is misleading as the Obama campaign is trying to cherry-pick a few Bain Capital flops that occurred after Romney left and attribute them to him.

The issue of Romney's record at Bain Capital is not off-limits, but the Obama campaign is distorting Romney's record by selectively highlighting negative incidents that occurred after Romney left the company. This provides voters with false information and distorts Romney's record.

It is important to note that Romney should "defend what happened at Bain Capital" when he ran it. The Obama attacks make no such distinctions, leading to the poor reviews from fact-checkers.

In a report, CNN highlighted that four separate sources at Bain, including three Democrats, have confirmed what Romney has said, and what all the fact-checkers have found: Romney left Bain in February 1999, just like he's asserted for more than a decade. This information comes in addition to the taxpayer-funded inquiry into this exact subject that Massachusetts Democrats convened in 2002. That commission's conclusion? Romney left Bain in 1999.

In conclusion, the Obama campaign's ads are facing criticism for their factual inaccuracies regarding Mitt Romney's tenure at Bain Capital. The weight of evidence suggests that Romney did indeed end active management of Bain in 1999, as he has asserted for more than a decade. The Obama campaign's ads are distorting Romney's record by selectively highlighting negative incidents that occurred after Romney left the company.

Title: U.S., World Powers, and Iran Nuclear Deal: Israel and Iran React Differently

Article:

Two days after the historic nuclear deal between the U.S., six world powers, and Iran, the focus has shifted to Washington, D.C., as both President Barack Obama and Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu seek to persuade Congress to either accept or reject the agreement.

President Obama stated, "With this deal, we cut off every one of Iran's pathways to a nuclear program, a nuclear weapons program. Iran's nuclear program will be under severe limits for many years." In Israel, Netanyahu launched a U.S. media blitz against the agreement. He criticized the inspection regime, stating, "I think the inspection regime is full of holes because instead of having instant inspections say within 24 hours, Iran has 24 days to open up suspect sites. Twenty-four days! Imagine giving a drug dealer 24 days' notice before you check the premises? This isn't going to work."

Israelis, who are on the front lines of the potential risk, are skeptical of the deal. According to a poll, 74% believe the deal will not prevent Iran from developing a nuclear bomb. An Israeli man told ███ News, "It's a bad deal because sooner or later, it's going to reach us." An Israeli woman expressed her concerns, stating, "The world doesn't realize that the Islamic people, they want to take over the world." An Israeli man also shared his doubts, saying, "Iran is keeping saying that Israel and the States and Europe has to be destroyed and everything has to be Islamic. So, they're going to continue to doing everything."

In Tehran, the people celebrated the deal. However, Iranian-born Middle East expert Menashe Amir expects Iran will cheat on the agreement, which could open the doors for Iranian nuclear scientists. Amir told ███ News, "The fact that the Iranian scientists have the permission to continue their research means that Iran will continue to find better ways of enhancing its nuclear program. After six years or eight years, they will begin in a very fast way to make the bomb."

Amir also anticipates this could lead to a Middle East nuclear arms race. He stated, "We are talking today about a united Arab forces, which will include Saudis, Egyptians, and other countries, and they may make a united cooperation for making the nuclear bomb or having the protection of the Pakistanis who have the first Islamic bomb."

Besides a nuclear arms race, some compare the $150 billion in sanctions relief to Iran, the world's number one state sponsor of terrorism, to a jihadist stimulus bill that will pour fuel on an already burning Middle East fire.

Title: Attorney General Jeff Sessions' Changing Stance on FBI Director James Comey's Firing

Article:

In a surprising turn of events, Attorney General Jeff Sessions, who reportedly recommended the dismissal of former FBI Director James Comey, has publicly defended actions he now cites as reasons for replacing Comey. The memo from Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein outlines the case for firing Comey, focusing on his handling of the investigation into Hillary Clinton's email practices during her tenure as Secretary of State.

Rosenstein criticizes Comey for holding a press conference on July 5, 2016, to explain why he was not recommending criminal charges against the Democratic presidential nominee. He also faults Comey for announcing, in a letter to members of Congress on October 28, 2016, the discovery of another email trove that might include evidence relevant to the Clinton investigation, just 11 days before the election.

Despite these arguments, which Rosenstein presents as compelling, they are no stronger now than they were last July or last October, when Sessions, then an Alabama senator and a leading Trump supporter, publicly expressed support for Comey. In a Fox News interview, Sessions, a former U.S. attorney, described Comey as "a skilled former prosecutor" whom he had respected over the years.

Two days after Comey's press conference, Sessions appeared on Greta Van Susteren's Fox News show and expressed that the Clinton case was a difficult one. He suggested there was enough evidence for at least a misdemeanor charge against Clinton but admitted he had not studied the facts thoroughly. Sessions gave no hint that he disapproved of Comey's press conference, which, as Rosenstein notes, broke with the FBI's usual practice of leaving prosecution decisions to the Justice Department and avoiding the release of derogatory information about people who have been investigated but do not face charges.

Comey has argued that he needed to announce the outcome of the investigation because Attorney General Loretta Lynch had been compromised by her chumminess with the Clintons, as evidenced by a 20-minute conversation with Bill Clinton aboard her plane at a Phoenix airport on June 27, 2016. However, Rosenstein notes that Comey could have asked Lynch to recuse herself from the case and let another Justice Department official announce the outcome rather than taking on that task himself.

Sessions, in interviews last fall, endorsed Comey's defense of the press conference and his decision to follow up with his letter about newly discovered evidence shortly before the election. Now, Sessions says those actions are firing offenses. "Almost everyone agrees that the Director made serious mistakes," Rosenstein writes. However, it is unavailable whether these mistakes were considered as serious by Sessions when they were helping the Trump campaign.

Title: Four GOP States Consider Cancelling 2020 Primaries to Support Trump

Article:

Four Republican states, South Carolina, Nevada, Arizona, and Kansas, are reportedly planning to cancel their 2020 primary contests, according to a report by Politico. Three sources familiar with the matter have confirmed this development.

The move is said to be an attempt by President Donald Trump to consolidate his control over the Republican Party at the state level. Trump is currently facing long-shot primary challenges from former Representative Joe Walsh (R-Ill.) and former Massachusetts Governor Bill Weld.

Politico reached out to the state parties for comment, but no immediate response was available. In statements to Politico, state party officials in Kansas and Nevada suggested that the decision to cancel the primaries and caucuses was made to save costs and allocate the funds to other races.

Nevada Republican Party Chairman Michael McDonald stated, "It would be malpractice on my part to waste money on a caucus to come to the inevitable conclusion that President Trump will be getting all our delegates in Charlotte. We should be spending those funds to get all our candidates across the finish line instead."

Kansas GOP Chairman Michael Kuckelman stated in another statement that his party would have to spend an estimated $250,000 to hold their caucuses.

Incumbent presidents' parties have canceled nominating processes in the past. The Arizona Democratic Party did not hold primaries in 2012 and 1996 when former Presidents Obama and Clinton, respectively, were running for reelection.

South Carolina GOP Chairman Drew McKissick told Politico, "As a general rule, when either party has an incumbent president in the White House, there’s no rationale to hold a primary."

Title: German Police Implement Ethnic Profiling to Reduce Crime Rates

Article:

In an article published by Bloomberg, Leonid Bershidsky discusses the implementation of a new policing model in Germany, which involves a form of ethnic profiling. The model, which screens and detains North African men, was implemented following the 500 sexual assaults committed in Cologne on New Year's Eve in 2015.

According to Bershidsky, the German police are using a form of ethnic profiling, specifically targeting Arabs, although they are technically classified as "Caucasian." The police chief of Cologne, Juergen Mathies, stated that the 2015 New Year's Eve sexual attackers were not "gray-haired older men or blonde, young women."

The article argues that the term "racial profiling" is often misunderstood and that everyone engages in some form of profiling. The author, Professor Walter Williams, defines profiling as "a practice where people use an observable or known physical attribute as a proxy or estimator of some other unobservable or unknown attribute."

The article cites examples of profiling in medical and criminological science, such as doctors taking race, ethnicity, and sex into account when evaluating patients, and Israeli airport security scrutinizing Muslims more closely due to the near-exclusive nature of terrorism being an Islamic phenomenon.

The article also mentions that 83% of those stopped during the New York City's erstwhile stop-and-frisk program were black and Hispanic, and that 96% of all NYC's crime is committed by these groups. The article argues that this is not properly called racism but recognizing statistics.

The article also mentions examples of profiling by liberal figures, such as MSNBC profiling the San Bernardino terrorists as possible pro-lifers and Senator Sherrod Brown's assertion that "white males" are the biggest terrorist threat.

The article concludes by stating that "racial profiling" is a passion-stoking propaganda term and that there is only good profiling and bad profiling. Good profiling considers many factors, such as age, sex, dress, behavior, religion, and ethnicity, in accordance with sound criminological science. Bad profiling is governed by politics and puerile priorities. The article argues that fairness means that all groups overrepresented in a crime category should factor into a relevant profile.

The author, Selwyn Duke, is a conservative media personality whose work has been published on various conservative outlets. The views expressed in the article are the author's own and not the views of the publication.

Title: Senate Tax Reform Bill Differences with House Version and Potential Challenges

Article:

Congressional Republicans are set to vote on their tax reform bill in the House today, following a speech by President Trump on Capitol Hill. However, passing the bill in the Senate may face challenges, as one Republican senator has already announced he will not vote for the bill as it currently stands.

Sen. Thom Tillis (R-N.C.) expressed optimism about reaching a consensus between the two chambers, stating that about 60-70 percent of the base policy has already been agreed upon. Tillis also noted that changes made based on feedback from the business community and economic modeling will further increase the level of commonality.

One key difference between the House and Senate plans is the Senate's call for a one-year delay in phasing in the reduction of the tax rate for businesses. This delay is to make the lower rate permanent under Senate rules. Despite the delay, Tillis asserts that businesses will still receive tax relief in the first year due to expensing and other benefits.

Tillis, who has experience in reducing corporate tax rates, believes that such reductions can significantly boost the economy. He cited North Carolina's transformation from one of the slowest-growing state economies to one of the fastest-growing after reducing the corporate tax rate.

The Senate bill also takes a step toward weakening the Affordable Care Act (Obamacare) by repealing the individual mandate, a move supported by conservatives in both chambers.

On the House side, Majority Leader Kevin McCarthy emphasized the pro-growth nature of the tax reform bill and its benefits for families and churches. The bill includes provisions for saving for future expenses for children and protecting churches from the Johnson Amendment, which forbids non-profit organizations, including churches and ministries, from supporting or opposing political candidates.

Sen. James Lankford is confident that the final bill in both chambers will include a repeal of the Johnson Amendment. He stated, "We feel very good about protecting the free speech rights of every American regardless of their faith, for profit, nonprofit status, whatever it may be. We feel like this is going to be the opportunity to repair this."

However, the massive tax overhaul could face difficulties, as Republican Sen. Ron Johnson has announced he will not support it. GOP senators can only afford two "no" votes for the bill to pass, but they remain optimistic that they will have a bill on the president's desk by the end of this year.

Title: Biden Campaign Acknowledges Warren's Rise in Polls and Debating Skills, but Focuses on Own Strategy

Article:

Joe Biden's campaign team recognizes Warren's debating abilities and her rising popularity in polls, although they are not solely focusing on her, according to advisers and individuals close to the campaign. Biden has faced criticism during the first two debates, a reflection of his current lead in the polls and his campaign's preparation for further attacks from various candidates.

Allies of Biden suggest that he has weathered rough debate performances in the past with minimal impact on his national poll numbers, demonstrating the enduring goodwill he enjoys from the Democratic base.

The campaign team sees several opportunities for Biden to differentiate himself. These opportunities include emphasizing his foreign policy credentials, given his tenure as Vice President and his previous role as Chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, amid foreign policy controversies involving the Trump administration.

Biden's team believes the Democratic electorate is more moderate than some activists suggest, and they welcome debates on issues such as healthcare and social programs. Biden supports a public option but opposes eliminating private insurance, contrasting with Warren's "Medicare for all" proposal.

Allies are eager to strengthen an argument Biden has been previewing: that it is not sufficient to have ambitious plans if those proposals cannot survive the political realities of Washington.

Senator Chris Coons, a Democrat from Delaware, stated, "Lots of other candidates have great plans, they have good policy papers, many of them have, you know, talked about them on college campuses or in the Senate. The difference, I think, is that Joe has decades of actual experience getting things enacted in a bitterly divided and partisan Washington, and I think he can and should point to that."

Warren did not face significant scrutiny from leading contenders in the first two debates. Biden's allies privately hope that Warren will be questioned on the details and practicalities of her proposals by several candidates onstage, given her increased prominence in the race and the potential for attacks.

Warren and Biden have previously clashed, engaging in a dispute over the nation's bankruptcy laws, which culminated in the passage of a bill in 2005 that Biden supported and Warren opposed.

Title: California and Oregon to Allow Pharmacist-Prescribed Birth Control Pills Without Doctor's Prescription

Article:

California and Oregon have become the first states in the nation to allow women to obtain birth control pills and other hormonal contraceptives directly from pharmacists without a doctor's prescription. California officials finalized regulations on a state law passed in 2013, while Oregon's governor, Kate Brown, signed a similar bill into law last week.

The new measures have been welcomed by women's health advocates, who argue that the move removes barriers to women's access to birth control and other reproductive health care. Kathy Kneer, president and CEO of Planned Parenthood Affiliates of California, stated, "We support efforts like these that remove barriers to women gaining access to birth control and other reproductive health care."

The contraceptives will not be available over the counter like common items such as cough drops or antacids. In California, pharmacists can only dispense them after providing a health screening to women and taking their blood pressure. Oregon will also require a health screening, but the state's specific rules have not been developed yet.

The laws differ slightly. California's law has no age restrictions on patients, while minors in Oregon must show proof of prior birth control prescriptions from a physician. Oregon may also require pharmacists to undergo more training than the one-hour education required of California pharmacists, according to Marcus Watt, executive director of the Oregon State Board of Pharmacy.

California's rules are expected to take effect after October 1, and Oregon's law after January 1. Elizabeth Nash, senior state issues associate at the Guttmacher Institute, a reproductive health think tank, said other states could follow California and Oregon's approaches, depending on how they work.

The laws were passed despite partisan debate in Congress over access to birth control. While members of both parties support legislation allowing over-the-counter access, Republican legislation would not require insurers to pay for it. Democrats argue that this would make hormonal contraceptives off-limits to many poor women, and they have introduced a bill that would require insurance coverage of over-the-counter hormonal contraceptives.

California's regulations and Oregon's law do not address insurance coverage of birth control. However, California pharmacists have expressed concerns that insurers may not pay for the time spent screening women and dispensing birth control, as they would for a doctor's visit.

Pharmacists in California are preparing for the new regulations and hoping to resolve the reimbursement issue. The overall expansion of pharmacists' prescribing authority is aimed at relieving the burden on physicians faced with an influx of patients newly insured under the Affordable Care Act.

Ken Thai, part-owner and manager of the El Monte Pharmacy Group with 10 stores in Southern California, expressed excitement about the new regulations. "Medical clinics in the area are overflowing, with long wait times. We're already doing other services like immunizations and cholesterol checks, and our customers already see us as a resource. We're ready for something like this. It's been a long time coming."

Until now, California pharmacists could only provide emergency contraception, also known as the "morning-after pill," without a doctor's prescription. Most major pharmacy chains are expected to participate in offering non-prescription birth control, as they were involved in developing the protocols.

Some patients welcomed the change, such as 26-year-old Anne Wong, who lives in San Francisco. "I think it's really wonderful," she said. "It's a drag to have to go to a clinic and talk to the doctor to get birth control pills – it takes a chunk out of your day."

Wong, who emigrated from Thailand at age 17 with her family, said the new access would help women in her community practice safer sex. "The topic is still taboo," Wong said. "But with the new regulations, 'I could just tell my parents I'm going to a store for something. All I'd need to do is just walk to the Walgreens near my house.'"

Kaiser Health News is an editorially independent program of the Kaiser Family Foundation.

Title: Trump Accuses China of Meddling in U.S. Midterm Elections, Denial from Chinese Foreign Minister

Article:

In a departure from the traditional scripted format of a United Nations Security Council meeting, President Donald Trump accused China of meddling in the upcoming U.S. midterm elections during a meeting on weapons proliferation on Wednesday. Trump stated that China is attempting to interfere in the November elections to counter his administration's aggressive trade policies towards Beijing.

Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi later denied the U.S. accusation of election meddling during the same session. Wang said, "We do not and will not interfere in any countries' domestic affairs."

President Trump did not provide specific details about the alleged meddling, but later indicated that he was referring to China's retaliatory tariffs against U.S. farm products. Trump stated, "You have statements made [by the Chinese] that they were going to hit our farmers, those are my voters."

The White House later confirmed that China is using a "whole-of-government approach" to interfere in the U.S. democratic system, including political, economic, commercial, military, and informational tools. The official stated, "The activities have reached an unacceptable level."

China's tariffs have particularly affected U.S. farm exports, impacting states and districts that voted for Trump in the 2016 election. China also placed a four-page ad in the Des Moines Register last weekend, referring to the soybean dispute as "the fruit of a president's folly."

In addition to the election meddling allegations, Trump used the meeting to level fresh threats against Iran, stating that new U.S. sanctions against Tehran will be in place within weeks, and that more penalties are being prepared to curb its military programs and support for anti-U.S. proxy groups.

However, Trump's criticism of the 2015 nuclear deal found little support in Wednesday's sessions, as European leaders such as French President Emmanuel Macron and British Prime Minister Theresa May joined Chinese and Russian leaders in urging the deal's preservation. Iran was not represented at the morning session, but Iranian President Hassan Rouhani stated that the U.S. pressure campaign was failing and predicted that an isolated Washington would eventually rejoin the pact.

Trump found virtually no support from the 15-nation Security Council to scrap the 2015 nuclear deal. Rouhani also stated, "We do not wish to increase tensions."

Title: Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez and Rep. Liz Cheney Engage in Debate over Comparison of Immigration Detention Centers to Concentration Camps

Article:

In a series of tweets and statements, Representatives Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez (D-N.Y.) and Liz Cheney (R-Wyo.) have engaged in a debate over Ocasio-Cortez's comparison of immigration detention centers along the southern border to concentration camps.

On Monday, Ocasio-Cortez, during an Instagram Live session, stated, "That is exactly what they are: They are concentration camps." She further explained, "I don't use those words lightly... I use that word because that is what an administration that creates concentration camps is."

Republicans, including Cheney, have criticized Ocasio-Cortez's comments, with Cheney stating on Tuesday, "You demean their memory and disgrace yourself with comments like this."

In response, Ocasio-Cortez asked Cheney how she would describe the use of "mass camps of people detained without a trial." Cheney suggested reading testimonies from Holocaust survivors and Elie Wiesel's memoir, "Night."

The back-and-forth on Tuesday echoed a similar exchange in November, when Ocasio-Cortez cited past global refugee crises, including the Holocaust, to defend today's migrants seeking asylum at the US-Mexico border. Sen. Lindsey Graham (R-S.C.) suggested that Ocasio-Cortez visit the Holocaust Museum in DC to better understand the differences between the Holocaust and the current situation at the border.

Notably, the official Twitter account for the Auschwitz Memorial appeared to tweet a veiled line of support for Ocasio-Cortez, stating, "Those who forget the past are condemned to repeat it." The tweet did not directly mention Ocasio-Cortez but was in response to a tweet about the debate between the two representatives.

Title: Unemployment Rate Drops to 7.7 Percent in November, According to BLS

Article:

The United States Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS) has reported a decrease in the unemployment rate from 7.9 percent to 7.7 percent in November. Total nonfarm payroll employment rose by 146,000. The employment increase was observed in retail trade, professional and business services, and healthcare sectors.

Despite Hurricane Sandy making landfall on the Northeast coast on October 29th, causing severe damage in some states, the BLS stated that the storm did not have a significant impact on the new statistics. The BLS survey response rates in the affected states were within normal ranges, and their analysis suggests that Hurricane Sandy did not substantively impact the national employment and unemployment estimates for November. The regional and state estimates will be released on December 21st.

Although the unemployment rate has decreased, the number of unemployed people has remained the same, indicating that more people may have stopped looking for work. The number of long-term unemployed people, those jobless for 27 weeks or more, also remains the same. Many people looking for full-time work are still working part-time jobs.

In November, the number of long-term unemployed (those jobless for 27 weeks or more) was little changed at 4.8 million. These individuals accounted for 40.1 percent of the unemployed. The number of persons employed part-time for economic reasons, at 8.2 million in November, was little changed over the month. These individuals were working part-time because their hours had been cut back or because they were unable to find a full-time job.

Yesterday, Gallup reported their seasonally adjusted numbers for November, which put the unemployment rate at 8.3 percent and underemployment at 17.2 percent.

Title: Report Reveals Release of Over 600 Criminal Immigrants by ICE in 2013

Article:

A government watchdog report obtained by FoxNews.com has revealed that the Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) released more than 600 immigrants with criminal convictions in early 2013, in advance of the "sequester" budget cuts. The report, by the Department of Homeland Security Office of Inspector General, found that ICE indeed was trying to address the budget shortfall when leadership moved to sharply reduce the number of people in the detention centers.

The report, requested by Sens. John McCain (R-Ariz.) and Tom Coburn (R-Okla.), found that ICE released 2,226 immigration detainees between February 9 and March 1, 2013. Of these, 629 had criminal convictions, some of whom had been implicated in serious offenses. The report indicated many should not have been released.

The report described an inconsistent and confusing scramble to make space in the detention centers. Local divisions did not have written guidance on how to "prioritize" the releases, and had "limited access" to legal advice since ICE leadership "did not formally notify ICE attorneys" of the plan. Only one local field office had an attorney on hand to review "each case," according to the report.

Yet, the report noted that many of the illegal immigrants were required by law to be held. Adding to the confusion, ICE leaders did not tell local field offices to track the releases. When they started asking questions, officers had trouble providing the information. In the end, while the agency found officers made "reasonable release decisions" given the time frame, they ended up redetaining dozens of those they had released.

In a written statement, ICE said the reductions in 2013 were "necessary" due to the "high levels of detention at the time, coupled with the looming prospect of sequestration." The agency said the assessments were made by "career law enforcement officials on a case-by-case basis following a careful examination of each detainee's criminal and immigration history." The agency also stated that those released remained in removal proceedings and "continue to be monitored."

The report comes as the agency, along with other federal departments, grapples with the surge of illegal immigrant children crossing the U.S.-Mexico border. The IG report did note the constraints ICE is facing. The agency is required by law to maintain an average daily population of 34,000 detainees, with funding coming from Congress and other sources. However, at the time, the report said, ICE was dealing with an average population of more than 35,000 detainees, facing budget cuts and other fiscal restraints, the agency decided to reduce the number of prisoners.

Title: U.S. Voters Shift Toward Far-Right and Far-Left Candidates in Trade-Exposed Districts

Article:

A new research paper by four leading academic economists suggests that U.S. voters are experiencing an "ideological realignment" in congressional districts most affected by competition from Chinese imports. As factories close, jobs disappear, and local economies struggle, Americans are favoring either conservative Republicans or liberal Democrats over more centrist candidates.

The researchers, including David Autor of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, cross-referenced voting records from the 2002 and 2010 congressional elections with district-by-district patterns of job losses and other economic trends over the same period. In trade-exposed districts already held by Republicans, voters were "substantially more likely" to elect a conservative Republican, according to the research paper. Conversely, trade-exposed districts with Democratic leaders were more likely to elect either a liberal Democrat or a conservative Republican.

In 2001, the year China joined the World Trade Organization, total U.S. manufacturing jobs averaged 16.4 million positions, according to U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics seasonally adjusted data. By 2010, manufacturing jobs fell by nearly 30 percent to 11.5 million positions as competition with China intensified and the 2008 global financial crisis continued to weaken consumer and industrial demand. U.S. manufacturing has since recovered slightly to 12.3 million jobs in 2015, but many towns across the United States remain economically depressed, with boarded-up storefronts, abandoned factories, and shrinking populations.

The researchers attribute this shift in voting patterns to the economic disruption caused by increased competition from China. Voters in these areas are reaching out for candidates who promise to create jobs and stimulate economic growth, they said.

"Exposure to import competition is bad for centrists," Gordon Hanson, a professor at the University of California, San Diego and one of the authors, told the New York Times. David Dorn of the University of Zurich and Kaveh Majlesi of Lund University in Sweden also co-authored the research paper.

The divide has become particularly prominent among unionized workers, who are increasingly inclined to support candidates like Donald Trump and his anti-trade rhetoric, according to a report by ███ last month. Some Democrats and labor officials have expressed concern that Trump could capture a significant segment of the union vote, which is historically a crucial part of the Democratic electoral coalition.

"Donald Trump is tapping into the very real and very understandable anger of working people," Richard Trumka, the head of the AFL-CIO, the nation's largest labor federation, said in a March speech.

Title: Wisconsin Governor Scott Walker Faces Legal Scrutiny Amidst Presidential Campaign

Article:

Wisconsin Governor Scott Walker, a potential Republican presidential candidate, is currently under investigation for allegedly illegally coordinating with conservative groups. The investigation, known as a John Doe probe, began in August of 2012 and is examining possible "illegal campaign coordination between certain special interest groups and the Walker campaign."

The John Doe probe is similar to a grand jury investigation, but it is conducted under strict secrecy orders in front of a judge rather than a jury. The investigation has been a subject of controversy, with some, including the Wall Street Journal editorial page, casting it as an attack on free speech.

In a recent development, a legal civil war has broken out among targets of the John Doe probe, as a conservative group sought to block prosecutors from having settlement talks with Walker's campaign. This has raised concerns among Walker's allies, who view the investigation as a chance to dismantle Wisconsin's perceived "pernicious regulatory machine" that allegedly targets political speech.

Walker's campaign spent $86,000 on legal fees in the second half of 2013, according to campaign filings. The investigation has its roots in an earlier one investigating Walker's previous tenure as Milwaukee County executive, during which three of Walker's close aides were indicted on felony embezzlement charges and charges were brought against a major campaign donor and one of his appointees.

The Wall Street Journal has been vocal in its criticism of the investigation, with the editorial page describing it as a "partisan witch hunt." However, a federal district judge recently rejected a motion to dismiss a federal civil-rights lawsuit against Wisconsin prosecutors who are investigating the political activities of conservative groups (but not liberals).

The investigation and the legal civil war have put Walker in a difficult position. He is reportedly spooked by the probe and would like to put it behind him to focus on his presidential campaign. However, his backers want him to fight the investigation to the fullest extent, potentially putting himself at risk, in order to make a political point.

The outcome of the investigation could have significant implications for Walker's presidential campaign and his political career. The investigation is ongoing, and it remains to be seen how Walker will navigate this legal challenge while pursuing his larger political ambitions.

Title: Midterm Elections: Democrats and Republicans Differ in Senate Race Outlook

Article:

As the midterm elections approach, both the Democratic and Republican parties have expressed optimism about their chances in the upcoming Senate races. According to recent polls, Republican candidates are slightly ahead in top Senate races, raising hopes among Republicans of gaining six seats and full control of Congress.

However, Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer (D-NY) maintains that the Democrats' ground game, focus on economic issues, and quality of candidates will help them retain a Senate majority. Schumer stated on NBC's "Meet the Press" that the Democrats' on-the-ground efforts are so strong that they should "add 2 to 3 points" to their candidate's side in each race.

Republicans, on the other hand, argue that voter intensity is on their side. Senator Rob Portman (R-OH) pointed to early voting in Iowa as evidence, stating that it's "never happened before" and that the polls show this will be a good year for Republicans.

The Republican strategy in the Senate races involves linking Democratic incumbents and challengers to President Obama, who polls poorly in key red states with seats in flux. Senator Joe Manchin III (D-WV) stated on CBS's "Face the Nation" that these people have voted against the president on issues and that he has worked with them.

Both parties have expressed support for their respective leaders, with Schumer backing Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid (D-NV) and Portman supporting Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-KY). Despite some waffling among party colleagues, both leaders have expressed confidence in their ability to lead the Senate if their parties win a majority.

Senator Harry Reid has been criticized for refusing to bring to the floor scores of bills passed by the Republican-led House, leading to perceptions of gridlock in Congress. Senator Rob Portman argued that the only way to get something done is by winning the majority, stating that Washington needs to "get its act together and start passing stuff."

The support for Mitch McConnell contrasts with endorsements for his Democratic opponent, Alison Lundergan Grimes, in a pair of Kentucky's top newspapers. The Lexington Herald-Leader's editorial board was particularly critical, stating that McConnell "has repeatedly hurt the country to advance his political strategy."

Senator Mitch McConnell, a Senate veteran since 1985, can find solace in some of the latest polls, with figures from the CBS News/New York Times Upshot/YouGov Battleground Tracker showing him up by 6 percentage points.

Title: The Impact of Right-Wing Media on Obama's Engagement with Ferguson Crisis

Article:

The ongoing crisis in Ferguson, Missouri, has sparked a wave of commentary urging President Barack Obama to take a more active role in addressing the situation. However, much of this commentary overlooks the role of right-wing media in shaping the political landscape and Obama's engagement with race-related issues.

Throughout his two terms, the right-wing media has consistently employed offensive and racially charged rhetoric towards Obama, often using it as a professional path for success. This rhetoric has not only corroded public debate but also created a heckler's veto, effectively silencing Obama on the topic of race.

Examples of this can be seen in Obama's responses to high-profile race-related incidents, such as the arrest of Henry Louis Gates in 2009 and the death of Trayvon Martin in 2012. In both instances, conservative media responded with race-baiting and personal attacks, labeling Obama as a "racist" or "Race Baiter in Chief."

Moreover, Rush Limbaugh, the most-listened-to radio host in America, has bombarded Obama with racial invective throughout his presidency. Statements such as "If Obama weren't black, he'd be a tour guide in Honolulu" and "Obama is more African in his roots than he is American" are just a few examples of Limbaugh's rhetoric.

Given this history, it is understandable that Obama may hesitate to engage more forcefully with the Ferguson crisis, as doing so could invite a right-wing media backlash that could last for weeks. This backlash could make it difficult to focus on the pressing issue at hand, as has been the case in the past.

It is important to acknowledge the role of right-wing media in shaping the political discourse surrounding race in America. While it is understandable for pundits to yearn for open dialogue and rhetorical leadership from the White House, it is less helpful to ignore the unpleasant realities of partisan politics in the age of Obama. A national conversation about race includes all corners of society, but it is clear that the conservative flank of American politics does not want to have a discussion about race or racism. Instead, they have made it clear that they will attack the president if he tries to heal that wound.

Title: U.S. Congress Cautions Obama on Syrian Intervention as Alleged Chemical Weapons Attack Investigated

Article:

As the Obama administration considers a response to the reported use of chemical weapons by the Syrian government, members of Congress have urged caution and are urging the president to seek authorization before taking military action.

Sen. Bob Corker (R-TN), the top Republican on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, told "Face the Nation" on Sunday that he believes the president will respond soon with military action, but suggested waiting until Congress returns next week to seek its authorization. Corker also suggested a "surgical" response that would not move the U.S. away from its current policy of supporting the Syrian opposition group taking the lead on the ground.

New York Rep. Eliot Engel (D-NY), the top Democrat on the House Foreign Affairs Committee, called the alleged civilian attacks last week "horrific" and urged the U.S. to respond with its NATO allies. "But we have to move, and we have to move now," Engel said.

Their comments come after almost a year of lawmakers pressing Obama to make good on his statement about Syria "crossing a red line" by using chemical weapons. Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel suggested Friday that the Pentagon might move naval forces closer to Syria in preparation for a possible decision by Obama to order military strikes.

However, U.S. defense officials have said the Navy has already sent a fourth warship armed with ballistic missiles into the eastern Mediterranean Sea, with lawmakers suggesting the best strategy now might be using Cruise missiles fired from offshore.

Rhode Island Democratic Sen. Jack Reed, a member of the chamber's Armed Services Committee, told CBS' "Face the Nation" that the U.S. cannot let itself get into a situation in Syria "where this becomes a springboard for a general military option."

The U.S. intelligence community has made an assessment that chemical weapons were likely used based on the reported number of victims, reported symptoms of those who were killed or injured, and witness accounts. The White House also thinks Assad and his forces originally denied United Nations investigators immediate access to the site of the reported attack to give the evidence time to degrade.

The international aid group Doctors Without Borders has tallied 355 deaths from the purported chemical weapons attack on Wednesday, with three hospitals it supports in the eastern Damascus region reporting receiving roughly 3,600 patients with "neurotoxic symptoms" over less than three hours. Syrian state media has accused rebels of using chemical arms against government troops in clashes Saturday near Damascus.

Title: Trump's Reactions to Personal Challenges: A Look at His Behavior Towards the Media and Potential World Leaders

Article:

The recent combative press conference held by Donald Trump, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee, has sparked discussions about how he might handle personal challenges from world leaders, should he become the U.S. president. The incident, which involved Trump's response to questions about his charitable donations to veterans, has raised concerns about his ability to maintain composure and handle criticism from foreign leaders.

During the press conference, Trump lashed out at reporters, calling one from ABC a "sleaze" and complaining that the press was not giving him credit for his generosity. His anger was directed at a controversy that arose in late May when The Washington Post questioned the accuracy of his claims about donations to veterans' groups. The total donated was significantly less than the $6 million Trump had initially stated, and it appeared that Trump himself had not donated anything.

In response to the controversy, Trump provided a detailed breakdown of the donations, stating that his foundation had made many of them, including his own $1 million gift, on May 23, after the Post story was published. Trump continued to berate the media throughout the press conference.

The incident has raised questions about Trump's ability to handle personal challenges from world leaders, given his apparent anger and thin skin when faced with criticism from the U.S. media. Personal relationships are a significant part of geopolitics, and handling them is one of the most important aspects of the presidency.

Historically, blustery leaders like Trump have faced challenges from their foreign counterparts. For example, Soviet leader Nikita Khrushchev hectored new U.S. President John Kennedy in Vienna in 1961, and the rapport between Ronald Reagan and the final Soviet leader, Mikhail Gorbachev, helped ease the end of the Cold War.

Trump's campaign spokeswoman, Katrina Pierson, stated that Trump would not behave towards foreign leaders as he did towards U.S. reporters. Pierson argued that Trump would not talk to a roomful of colleagues that way "because they are not treating him the way the media is doing today."

However, foreign adversaries can be much rougher than the U.S. media, and Trump's problem with foreign leaders is not rooted in belligerence as much as in credulity, according to one critic. Trump seems easy to flatter, and this has been exploited by world leaders such as Vladimir Putin and North Korea's dictator Kim Jong-un.

The Clinton campaign is eager to portray Trump as an unstable entity, and this image fits with their contention that he is too risky to entrust with America's nuclear codes. Clinton has used this image to pivot away from questions about the propriety and legality of her use of a private e-mail server as secretary of State.

Asked about the server in multiple television interviews, Clinton responded with the same line: "I hope voters look at the full picture of everything I've done in my career and the full threat posed by a Donald Trump presidency."

Title: Trump Explores National Emergency Declaration to Secure Border Wall Funding

Article:

As the partial government shutdown enters its third week, the White House is exploring various options to secure funding for the construction of a barrier on the U.S.-Mexico border, including the potential use of the president's emergency powers to bypass Congress altogether.

President Donald Trump stated on Friday, "We can call a national emergency and build it very quickly," and reiterated the sentiment on Sunday. Acting White House Chief of Staff Mick Mulvaney said on CNN's "State of the Union" that Trump had directed every single Cabinet secretary and the Office of Management and Budget to find legal funds that could be used for a border wall.

"Presidents have authority to defend the nation," Mulvaney said, adding that he was personally involved in the search for funds that could be redirected toward a border wall. The government shutdown is tied for the third-longest on record, with no end in sight.

Kim Lane Scheppele, a professor at Princeton University's Center for Human Values, stated that Trump can test whether he has the power to declare a national emergency for this purpose under the National Emergencies Act. The Act allows him to declare a state of emergency without approval from anyone else, but he must then stay within congressionally delegated emergency powers.

The 1976 National Emergencies Act was passed in the post-Watergate, post-Vietnam era to create more structured procedures for the president's use of emergency powers. Under the law, the president must cite the specific emergency powers he is activating under existing statutes. According to the Congressional Research Service, there are hundreds of "provisions of federal law delegating to the executive extraordinary authority in time of national emergency."

One potential avenue for Trump to declare an "immigration emergency" under the Immigration and Nationality Act. An immigration emergency is defined as an "influx of aliens which either is of such magnitude or exhibits such other characteristics that effective administration of the immigration laws of the United States is beyond the existing capabilities" of immigration authorities "in the affected area or areas."

Other factors that determine if an immigration emergency exists include "the likelihood of continued growth in the magnitude of the influx," an "apparent connection between the influx and increases in criminal activity," high "demands on law enforcement agencies," and "other circumstances" defined by the attorney general. Under the law, the attorney general or head of a local government must submit a request to the president describing the immigration emergency and what is needed to address it. The president then determines if an emergency exists and informs the House and Senate Judiciary committees.

An Immigration Emergency Fund exists for that purpose, but the law only approves $20 million annually for the fund, far short of the $5.6 billion Trump is seeking. Another option that could potentially secure a larger chunk of funding for a border barrier would be under laws regarding military spending, which say the secretary of defense can undertake construction projects during a national emergency without authorization. The law says those projects must be "necessary to support such use of the armed forces."

The law also permits the Army's civil works program to build structures necessary for the national defense after the president declares an emergency. The secretary of defense may also reprogram money that had been set aside for military construction projects. A third statute allows for the construction of emergency projects if the secretary of defense determines it "is vital to the national security or to the protection of health, safety, or the quality of the environment," but that authority is capped at $50 million a year.

Rep. Adam Schiff, D-Calif., called Trump's invocation of his emergency powers "really threatening talk" that "he doesn't have the power to execute." "If Harry Truman couldn't nationalize the steel industry during wartime, this president doesn't have the power to declare an emergency and build a multibillion-dollar wall on the border," Schiff told CNN.

However, another Democrat, Rep. Adam Smith of Washington, said Trump did have the authority to declare the national emergency but would face legal challenges. "There is a provision in law that says the president can declare an emergency. It's been done a number of times," Smith told ABC's "This Week" host George Stephanopoulos. "In this case, I think the president would be wide open to a court challenge saying, where is the emergency? You have to establish that in order to do this."

Title: House Republicans Criticize Obama Administration's Handling of Bergdahl Incident, Alleging Lack of Congressional Involvement

Article:

In a classified briefing on Monday, top national security officials presented their case to House lawmakers regarding the Obama administration's decision to trade five Taliban detainees for Army Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl. The briefing followed the administration's first opportunity to justify the controversial trade.

Republican lawmakers emerged from the more than hour-long briefing expressing dissatisfaction, claiming they learned little new information about the incident that had not already been disclosed in the media. A significant point of contention was the administration's decision to inform approximately 80 to 90 executive branch officials in the Pentagon, White House, and intelligence agencies, but not members of Congress, beforehand.

Rep. Greg Walden (R-Ore.) commented, "It strikes me as unfortunate that they could have 80 to 90 people in the administration and not be able to trust a single Republican or Democrat in the House or the Senate."

Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid (D-Nev.) has publicly stated that he was informed the day before the Bergdahl exchange, but administration officials now claim that was not the case. The conflicting public viewpoints are rare between the administration and its chief partner on Capitol Hill.

Former House Homeland Security Committee Chairman Peter King (R-N.Y.) stated that the administration briefers offered few details on who specifically in the Obama administration knew about the swap beforehand but said the officials were in logistical roles. King added that the officials were likely from the State and Defense departments, the National Security Council, and the White House.

Rank-and-file Republicans were frustrated by what they see as more stonewalling by the Obama administration as the White House tries to navigate yet another controversy. "They [administration officials] made abundantly clear from the stage that we received no classified information," said Rep. Michele Bachmann (R-Minn.), a longtime critic of President Barack Obama who also serves on the House Intelligence Committee.

During the briefing, members were shown a "proof of life" video of Bergdahl from January, made by his Taliban captors to prove he was still alive. Bergdahl reportedly told American military officials that he was held in a cage in total darkness for weeks at a time, according to The New York Times.

While expressing sympathy for Bergdahl and his family, Republican lawmakers criticized the swap as improper and possibly illegal, as Obama was supposed to consult with Congress 30 days before making such a move. Some administration officials have privately claimed that if word of the U.S.-Taliban talks leaked, Bergdahl's life would have been in jeopardy.

Rep. Adam Kinzinger (R-Ill.), a major in the Air National Guard who has served in Afghanistan and Iraq, said that the briefers did not address questions about assurances that the Taliban detainees could not return to the battlefield.

Some Democrats sought to defend the White House's handling of the Bergdahl incident, stating they understood why the administration wouldn't share information with Capitol Hill about such a sensitive matter.

Title: Democrats' Chances of Senate Majority Dim as Election Day Approaches

Article:

The prospects of Democrats flipping the Senate and gaining a majority have diminished over the past month, with key races showing a shift towards the Republican Party. To win control of the Senate, Democrats would need a net gain of two seats. Currently, only one Republican-held seat, in Arizona, is considered a 50-50 bet for the party. Three other targets in Texas, Nevada, and Tennessee have moved towards the Republican Party following the confirmation of Justice Brett M. Kavanaugh to the Supreme Court.

James Henson, a pollster with Strategic Research Associates LLC, stated, "The short interval in which there seemed to be some kind of possibility that Democrats could rally in the Senate was probably ill-fated to begin with, and we see less suggestion of that as we get closer to Election Day."

Democrats' prospects are better in the House, where most analysts predict they will win at least the 23 seats needed to flip control. The key House races are playing out in less Republican-friendly territory compared to the Senate. In the Senate, more than two-thirds of the seats up for re-election are held by Democrats, including several seats in states that President Trump carried by at least 20 percentage points.

Sen. Chris Van Hollen of Maryland, chairman of the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee, expressed optimism about turnout but declined to make any predictions about winning a majority. "I am optimistic that we are going to see a big turnout," Mr. Van Hollen said at a forum sponsored by The Washington Post. "I am not going to make any predictions for this reason. It entirely depends on turnout."

The biggest hurdle to Democrats' hopes is North Dakota, where Sen. Heidi Heitkamp trails her Republican challenger, Rep. Kevin Cramer, by 16 points, according to a poll this week. In Texas, Rep. Beto O'Rourke has outperformed early expectations but trails Republican Sen. Ted Cruz in most polling, raising questions about how many more supporters he can find in the Republican-dominated state.

In Missouri, Sen. Claire McCaskill's re-election race against state Attorney General Josh Hawley is so close that she started running a radio ad in which a supporter assures listeners she is "not one of those crazy Democrats." The race for the open seat in Arizona between Reps. Kyrsten Sinema and Martha McSally is still considered a toss-up.

In Nevada, the contest between Sen. Dean Heller and his Democratic challenger, Rep. Jacky Rosen, is also considered a toss-up, with the latest three polls this month showing the Republican with a lead. Early voting in Nevada could bode well for Ms. Rosen, but the chairman of the Clark County Republican Party, Carl Bunce, had a different take, stating, "The current turnout indicates no blue wave of any kind unless Democrats turn out in higher numbers than Republicans on Election Day, which would be against precedent."

Prognosticators also see the Tennessee contest between Rep. Marsha Blackburn and her Democratic challenger, former Gov. Phil Bredesen, as a toss-up, with the latest polls showing a close race. In Indiana, Sen. Joe Donnelly is in a tight race against Republican challenger Mike Braun. In Florida, Sen. Bill Nelson is in a close race against Republican challenger Rick Scott. In Montana, Sen. Jon Tester is in a tight race against Republican challenger Matt Rosendale.

In summary, the chances of Democrats flipping the Senate and gaining a majority have diminished over the past month, with key races showing a shift towards the Republican Party. The prospects are better for Democrats in the House, where most analysts predict they will win at least the 23 seats needed to flip control. The key Senate races are playing out in less Republican-friendly territory compared to the House, with several Democratic incumbents in tight races in Indiana, Florida, Missouri, and Montana. The race for the open seat in Arizona is still considered a toss-up, and the Nevada contest between Sen. Dean Heller and Rep. Jacky Rosen is also considered a toss-up. The race for the open seat in Tennessee is also considered a toss-up, with the latest polls showing a close race.

Title: New Jersey Senator Cory Booker Announces 2020 Presidential Bid

Article:

New Jersey Senator Cory Booker has officially entered the 2020 Democratic presidential race, joining a growing field of candidates aiming to challenge incumbent President Donald Trump. In an email to supporters, Booker pledged to "channel our common pain back into our common purpose."

Booker, who previously served as the mayor of Newark, launched his campaign on the first day of February, which is designated as Black History Month. In a video accompanying his campaign announcement, Booker recounted the racial discrimination faced by his family and spoke about the power of civil rights movements.

"The history of our nation is defined by collective action; by interwoven destinies of slaves and abolitionists; of those born here and those who chose America as home; of those who took up arms to defend our country, and those who linked arms to challenge and change it," Booker said in the video.

Booker, who was elected to the Senate in 2013, is the state's first black senator. He plans to travel to the first caucus state of Iowa the weekend of February 9, followed by early battleground states South Carolina and New Hampshire.

Like some of the other Democratic contenders, Booker has said he will not accept campaign donations from corporate political action committees and lobbyists. He also opposes Super PACs supporting any candidacy.

Since his arrival in the Senate, Booker has been widely viewed as a potential contender for president and was a finalist for Hillary Clinton's vice presidential nominee in 2016. Branding himself as a progressive, Booker has embraced a 'Green New Deal' and supports Medicare-for-All health insurance provisions, comprehensive immigration reform, and criminal justice reform efforts.

However, Booker has faced criticism from left-wingers for strong ties to Wall Street firms and the pharmaceutical industry. A member of the Senate judiciary committee, Booker is known for his fiery questioning of nominees and administration officials in the age of Trump.

On Friday morning, Booker participated in call-in interviews with radio shows popular with African American and Latinx listeners. Later in the morning, he will go on television to be interviewed on the popular daytime chat show The View, which has a majority female viewership. His mother will be sitting in the studio audience.

Title: U.S. Healthcare System: A Comparative Analysis and the Path Forward

Article:

The United States has a complex healthcare delivery system, with a mix of private and government-funded insurance plans. Approximately half of Americans receive their health insurance through their employer or their spouse's employer, while over 40% receive it from the government. The remaining portion is either uninsured or obtains health insurance through the private individual market. The ongoing political debate centers on the role the government should play in the U.S. healthcare system.

The U.S. spends significantly more per person on healthcare than other industrialized countries, with overall medical spending totaling $3.5 trillion or 18% of the national gross domestic product in 2020. This high spending has led to other countries being used as models for solving U.S. healthcare delivery system problems. However, it is important to consider that other countries are often smaller and have more homogeneous populations, and what may work for one society may not be applicable or acceptable in another.

According to a Forbes survey, the U.S. accounts for 38% of life-saving and life-extending medical innovations, compared to an average of 15% in other countries. The U.S. also leads the world in the research and development of pharmaceuticals.

In all other industrialized countries, the demand for healthcare is greater than the money budgeted for it, leading to chronic shortages and strict rationing of healthcare. Rationing can take various forms, such as long wait times, denying elderly access to certain procedures, or prioritizing individuals with political influence.

Canada has a single-payer, nationalized system that is fully funded by taxpayers. In 2018, wait times for specialty care averaged 20 weeks, with 250,000 citizens waiting more than six months for planned treatments within the National Health Service in the past year. Great Britain established a comprehensive government health-care system in 1948, providing every citizen with cradle-to-grave coverage. However, over the past year, about 10% of the population has waited more than six months for planned treatments within the National Health Service, and 36,000 people have waited nine months or more.

Switzerland has a comparatively large private healthcare sector, with patients responsible for 30% of their own healthcare costs. This has led to a degree of healthcare consumerism in Switzerland, and the country has been fairly successful in holding down costs. However, as officials increase the number of benefit mandates required in insurance plans, healthcare costs are rising.

Singapore has a multi-tiered system with different levels of care depending on the patient's ability and willingness to pay more. This is similar to the system in the U.S. before the passage of Medicare and Medicaid.

While universal health insurance coverage is a worthy goal, the critical point is using the best mechanism to allow the greatest number of Americans access to healthcare. Simply having health insurance does not guarantee timely access to healthcare.
