The American experience with the Veterans Administration hospital system, a comprehensive, government-controlled, single-payer healthcare program, reveals unacceptable wait times and inefficiencies.

The U.S. distinguishes itself from other countries by a broader use of free markets. The free market offers the best solution to provide the greatest access to healthcare and to control costs. Eliminating third-party payers, greater use of health savings accounts, price transparency, and health insurance reform would put patients, rather than the government, in charge of their own healthcare.

Dr. Stark, the Health Care Policy Analyst for Washington Policy Center, emphasizes the importance of allowing Americans to make their own healthcare decisions and use their own healthcare dollars. This would give Americans the best chance to access healthcare and exercise their right to do so.

Title: Chris Christie's Bridge Scandal: Paul Begala Suggests Scandal Will Haunt Christie as Bully Narrative Persists

Article:

In a recent analysis, political commentator Paul Begala suggests that the ongoing George Washington Bridge scandal will likely continue to haunt New Jersey Governor Chris Christie due to its alignment with perceptions of him as a bully. Begala argues that Christie's attempt to distance himself from the bully label by declaring, "I am not a bully," during a press conference was not convincing.

The scandal, which involves allegations that Christie's staff and appointees disrupted traffic on the world's busiest bridge as political punishment, presents a difficult choice for Christie, according to Begala. He describes this choice as being between being a "crook" or a "schnook," with a schnook being a victim or a fool. Begala contends that Christie is not convincing in his portrayal of himself as a victim.

Begala points out that the scandal fits the negative narrative that has been built around Christie, who is known for his bold and forceful leadership style. The positive narrative, which portrays Christie as a straight-talking, no-nonsense leader, is also present, but the negative narrative of a bully is just as powerful and true, according to Begala.

The legal and political processes surrounding the scandal are ongoing, with the Democratic majority leader of the State Senate, Loretta Weinberg, stating that she is waiting for the subpoena power to continue and for the whole story of who knew what and when to be revealed. This means that continuing subpoenas could lead to further revelations, and there may also be lawsuits from aggrieved commuters, putting individuals under oath.

Begala also notes that the scandal's proximity to the media epicenter, the East Coast, has helped fuel Christie's celebrity but may also contribute to his downfall. The truth, according to Begala, is that there is not much Christie can do about the three dynamics that are working against him.

In conclusion, Begala suggests that the Chris Christie bridge-closing scandal is unlikely to go away anytime soon and will likely continue to haunt Christie due to its alignment with the negative narrative of him as a bully.

Title: Congress Faces Impasse Over Homeland Security Funding and Immigration Policy

Article:

Congress finds itself in a stalemate as lawmakers return to the Capitol without a clear resolution to the ongoing funding showdown for the Department of Homeland Security (DHS). The impasse persists despite a week-long reprieve following the passage of a last-minute funding extension that avoided a shutdown last weekend.

Speaker John A. Boehner, in an interview on CBS's "Face the Nation," stated that the cause of the impasse is President Obama's overreach, citing the 38 times Mr. Obama unilaterally changed the Affordable Care Act. However, the funding crisis for DHS stems from Mr. Obama's immigration-related actions.

House Republicans faced internal dissent last week over their leadership's strategy, with Speaker Boehner acknowledging disagreements over tactics but asserting unity in the fight against Mr. Obama's immigration actions. Representative Jim Jordan, chairman of the conservative Freedom Caucus, dismissed speculation about the GOP agreeing to Democrats' demands, stating, "That's not going to happen."

With a new deadline approaching, House Republicans aim to pressure Senate Democrats into negotiations for a funding bill that includes anti-amnesty measures. However, Senate Democrats remain adamant about the passage of a "clean" bill, with Senator Dianne Feinstein stating, "We want a clean bill. We have passed, taken votes on a clean bill."

The Senate will vote on Monday to allow a conference committee, which can be blocked by denying the 60 votes needed to consider forming the committee. Senate Democrats have repeatedly vowed not to go to conference to reconcile the House-passed bill with anti-amnesty measures and the Senate-passed bill without policy riders.

Senate Minority Leader Harry Reid has vowed not to engage in conference negotiations, and Senate Republicans have surrendered to demands for a clean bill to end a filibuster of the House-passed legislation. House Majority Leader Kevin McCarthy suggested invoking the "nuclear option" to change the Senate's rules to stop filibusters, a tactic Senate Democrats used when they controlled the chamber.

The standoff between the two parties continues, with no clear resolution in sight, as both sides dig in their heels over the funding for DHS and the future of President Obama's immigration policies.

Title: Congressional Republicans Return to Washington Amidst Town Hall Controversy and Agenda Challenges

Article:

Congressional Republicans returned to Washington on Monday, following a week-long recess marked by contentious town hall meetings that dominated headlines. The return to the nation's capital, however, offers little respite, as members face a daunting to-do list and the looming impact of President Donald Trump's joint congressional address on Tuesday.

Senators are set to continue the arduous task of confirming Trump's Cabinet nominees, with Democrats employing procedural tactics to slow progress. Nonetheless, Republicans are expected to confirm Wilbur Ross as Commerce Secretary, as well as move forward with the nominations of Ryan Zinke at the Interior Department, Ben Carson at the Department of Housing and Urban Development, and Rick Perry at the Energy Department.

Conservatives are also pushing for the repeal and replacement of the Affordable Care Act, a seven-year promise that now appears more precarious due to tense exchanges with constituents and internal GOP disagreements. The repeal effort requires 50 senators, with Vice President Mike Pence acting as a tie-breaker. However, this means Republicans can only afford to lose two lawmakers.

Last week, Alaska Republican Sen. Lisa Murkowski stated in an address to her state legislature that she would not support a plan that repeals Medicaid expansion under Obamacare nor defund Planned Parenthood as part of the repeal. This could pose a problem if the final version of Obamacare repeal resembles a leaked draft released last week.

Alabama Republican Rep. Mo Brooks admitted last week in a local radio interview that the town hall meetings might halt the repeal effort. "I'll tell you, Toni, there are in my opinion a significant number of congressmen who are being impacted by these kinds of protests and their spine is a little bit weak," Brooks said on "The Morning Show with Toni & Gary" on WBHP 800 Alabama radio. "And I do not know if we're going to be able to repeal Obamacare now because these folks who support Obamacare are very active, they're putting pressure on congressmen, and there's not a counter-effort to steel the spine of some of these congressmen in toss-up districts around the country."

The town hall pressure took the form of organized chants of "do your job" or even "ACA," as well as thoughtful but challenging questions from individual voters. One such constituent asked Tennessee Republican Rep. Diane Black a detailed policy question before citing her Christian faith as her reason for supporting Obamacare.

At a town hall in Kentucky, a woman confronted Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell about the high numbers of people on food stamps in Kentucky, the lack of coal jobs, and the lack of health insurance. "If you can answer any of that, I'll sit down and shut up like Elizabeth Warren," the woman said, referencing McConnell's recent use of Senate procedure to stop the Massachusetts Democrat from speaking on the Senate floor.

After a rocky start, Trump is expected to focus his joint congressional address on policy goals, including health care and tax and regulatory reforms, as well as increased military spending. However, even with a White House ally to enact their party's agenda, Trump has proven to be as much a hindrance as a help.

"In many respects, this administration is in disarray, and they've got a lot of work to do," Arizona Republican Sen. John McCain told an audience in Munich last week. Trump's tone and the content of his Tuesday night speech will ultimately set Republicans' agenda for the near future, and could dictate whether they will be forced to answer new concerns from constituents or focus on their own long-standing wish list.

Trump's propensity to get distracted by personal grievances and his administration's sloppy rollout of its immigration executive order—now stalled in the courts—have put Hill Republicans on defense rather than offense. Additionally, right before the recess, senators were briefed by FBI Director James Comey on the ongoing investigation into possible Trump campaign ties to Russia.

Democrats, meanwhile, remain committed to playing defense on the Affordable Care Act and further investigating Trump's ties to Russia. In an interview with ABC's George Stephanopoulos, House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi argued that Trump's former campaign ally and now Attorney General Jeff Sessions needs to recuse himself from overseeing any investigation into Trump's campaign's ties to Russia. Pelosi also argued that Republicans "don't have the votes" to repeal and replace the Affordable Care Act despite their rhetoric.

"They do not have a replacement. What they have put forth and outlined will cost more to consumers. It will cover fewer people. It will give tax breaks to the wealthiest people," Pelosi said on ABC.

Title: White House, Clinton Campaign Address Affordable Care Act After Criticism from Former President Clinton

Article:

Following former President Bill Clinton's criticism of President Obama's Affordable Care Act (ACA) as "the craziest thing in the world," the Obama administration and the Clinton campaign have sought to clarify their stance on the healthcare legislation.

In a news briefing on Tuesday, White House Press Secretary Josh Earnest defended the ACA, acknowledging that there are areas for improvement. "President Obama, with cooperation from Democrats and Republicans in Congress, there are some things that could be done to further strengthen the law," said Earnest. Hillary Clinton, if elected president, has vowed to pursue these improvements, with President Obama's support.

Clinton's criticism of the ACA was made at a rally in Flint, Michigan, on Monday, where he discussed rising insurance premiums under the ACA. "You've got this crazy system where all of a sudden 25 million more people have health care and then the people are out there busting it sometimes 60 hours a week wind up with their premiums doubled and their coverage cut in half," he said.

After the rally, Clinton's aides and campaign walked back his comments, stating that he is a supporter of the ACA but wants to address lingering gaps in the insurance markets.

Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump seized on the opportunity at a rally in Arizona, thanking Clinton for being "honest" about Obamacare. When asked about Clinton's comments during the White House news briefing, Earnest said, "It's not exactly clear to me what argument he was making, and so I'll let him and his team explain that."

Earnest emphasized the benefits of the ACA, including expanded coverage, limited healthcare cost growth, and consumer protections. Angel Urena, Clinton's press secretary, acknowledged that improvement is needed and outlined Hillary Clinton's proposed measures to address these issues.

Hillary Clinton, who was stymied by Congress in the 1990s when attempting to create affordable healthcare, has stated that the current Republican-controlled Congress wants to repeal the ACA altogether, making it impossible for Obama to attempt changes in the law without willing partners on Capitol Hill. Clinton has pledged to "fix what's broken and keep what works" if elected.

Title: Key Republican Figures Criticize Trump's Decision to Withdraw U.S. Troops from Syria

Article:

Peter Bergen, CNN's national security analyst, a vice president at New America, and a professor of practice at Arizona State University, is completing a book about President Trump's national security team and policies. The opinions expressed in this commentary are his own.

The withdrawal of American forces from Syria has drawn criticism from three senior Republicans: Sen. Lindsey Graham, Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, and former UN Ambassador Nikki Haley. The U.S. has been accused by the Kurds of betrayal due to the decision to pull out approximately 1,000 troops from Syria.

The troops in Syria are not on a combat mission but are in an advisory role to prevent the return of ISIS and to provide leverage over events in Syria, a country supported by Russia and Iran. The U.S. withdrawal allows Turkey to carry out military operations against the Syrian Democratic Forces (SDF), a Kurdish-led group that was instrumental in retaking Syria from ISIS. The SDF is considered a terrorist group by Turkey, which has a restive Kurdish minority.

The SDF have lost around 11,000 soldiers fighting ISIS, while the U.S. has had 17 soldiers killed in action in both Syria and Iraq over the past five years. The U.S. has previously withdrawn troops from Syria, which precipitated the resignation of then-Secretary of Defense, James Mattis, who saw the move as an abandonment of American allies on the battlefield.

The U.S. has a history of withdrawing troops from Muslim states, which can lead to the rise of jihadist terrorist groups. After the U.S. pulled out of Iraq, the group that later became ISIS first organized in Syria in 2011, before it invaded Iraq three years later and took over much of the country.

Trump's policy shift on Syria has been criticized for giving America's enemies an early heads-up about U.S. military plans and for potentially allowing ISIS to return. During his presidential campaign, Trump had correctly critiqued the total American troop withdrawal from Iraq under Barack Obama in 2011 as helping pave the way for the rise of ISIS.

The announcement on Syria also underlines the collapse of any kind of deliberative national security process. Trump appears to make unilateral decisions surrounded by a cabinet of yes-men and acolytes because he has chased out advisers like Mattis, former National Security Adviser H.R. McMaster, former Secretary of State Rex Tillerson, and former Chief of Staff John Kelly, all of whom tended to push back against Trump's more ill-advised decisions.

Title: House Judiciary Committee Authorizes Subpoenas for Mueller Report and Associated Materials

Article:

WASHINGTON - The Democratic-led House of Representatives Judiciary Committee has authorized its chairman, Jerrold Nadler, to subpoena Special Counsel Robert Mueller's full report on Russia's role in the 2016 election and related evidence. The move brings the U.S. Congress closer to a potential legal confrontation with President Donald Trump's administration.

The committee voted 24-17, along party lines, to enable Nadler to subpoena the Justice Department for the unredacted Mueller report, all underlying evidence, and documents and testimony from five former Trump aides, including political strategist Steve Bannon. The committee also authorized subpoenas for former White House Counsel Donald McGahn, former Chief of Staff Reince Priebus, former White House Communications Director Hope Hicks, and former White House deputy counsel Ann Donaldson.

Attorney General William Barr, a Trump appointee, issued a four-page summary of Mueller's main conclusions last month, stating that the special counsel did not establish that the Trump campaign conspired with Russia during the election. Barr has pledged to release the nearly 400-page report by mid-April with certain portions blacked out for reasons such as protecting secret grand jury information and intelligence-gathering sources and methods.

The House Judiciary Committee's focus on subpoenas to obtain the Mueller report stems from the belief that Barr would not comply with a Democratic demand to turn over the report unredacted by a Tuesday deadline. Democrats have expressed concern that Barr could use redactions to suppress evidence of potential misconduct by Trump and his campaign.

Nadler stated that he would work with Barr "for a short period of time in the hope that he will reveal to us the entire Mueller report and all the underlying materials." If that does not occur, Nadler added, the committee will issue subpoenas and potentially seek a court order to obtain the grand jury material.

Representative Doug Collins, the committee's top Republican, criticized the Democrats' actions, stating, "This is reckless... It's also confusing since the attorney general is doing exactly what he said he would be doing: making as much of the report public as possible under federal law and departmental policy."

In another development, the Democratic-led House Intelligence Committee, led by Trump critic Adam Schiff, is reportedly seeking an interview with and documents from a top organizer on Trump's inaugural committee. The Wall Street Journal reported this development, citing people familiar with the request, but the report could not be immediately confirmed by the news organization.

Barr's March 24 letter to lawmakers explaining Mueller's "principal conclusions" stated that the special counsel did not exonerate Trump on obstruction of justice. Barr himself subsequently concluded that Mueller's inquiry had not found sufficient evidence to warrant criminal obstruction charges against Trump. Trump has denied collusion with Russia and obstruction of justice, while Moscow has denied election interference.

Democrats have pledged to fight all the way to the U.S. Supreme Court to enforce a subpoena and obtain the full report. "If the department still refuses, then it should be up to a judge - not the president or his political appointee - to decide whether it is appropriate for the committee to review the complete record," Nadler said.

Trump ally Lindsey Graham, Republican chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, wrote on Twitter that the House panel's demand for classified information and grand jury testimony was "dangerous and ridiculous." The Justice Department declined comment, while Priebus, Bannon, McGahn, and their representatives did not immediately respond to requests for comment. Justice Department regulations give the attorney general wide latitude on how much to release from special counsel inquiries. Nadler also stated that he would seek a judge's permission to get access to Mueller's grand jury material, which is protected under federal law.

Title: Violent Protests Disrupt G20 Summit in Hamburg, Germany

Article:

Thousands of anti-globalization protesters disrupted the Group of 20 (G20) summit in Hamburg, Germany on Friday, setting cars on fire and attempting to block leaders' delegations from entering the summit grounds. Authorities reinforced police presence from other cities, but requested additional support after the situation escalated.

On the second day of protests, dozens of police officers formed moving lines in various parts of the city and used water cannons to disperse protesters from city streets. At least 45 demonstrators were arrested, 15 were temporarily detained, and 160 police officers were injured, including three who were hospitalized.

Hamburg's fire department reported that 11 protesters were severely injured and transported to hospitals after falling from a wall during confrontations with police. The fire department also treated 26 people and took 14 of them to the hospital, but the reason for the protesters climbing the wall remains unclear.

Hamburg Police tweeted, "Our fears have been confirmed. Several of my colleagues were injured in yesterday's riots by high velocity projectiles." The city's interior senator, Andy Grote, stated, "We've asked for a few hundred more police officers - they're on the way." Grote described the potential for violence as "shocking."

German police reported that all leaders entered the city's convention center safely. The leaders, including German host Chancellor Angela Merkel, U.S. President Donald Trump, Russian President Vladimir Putin, and many others, were meeting to discuss issues such as international terrorism and climate change.

Germany's Justice Minister Heiko Maas told reporters that the violent protests were a disservice to the overwhelmingly peaceful demonstrators. "Every peaceful protest is welcome," Maas said. "But that is no free pass for unrestrained rampage."

The violence began on Thursday and continued into Friday, with demonstrators breaking windows at the Mongolian consulate and puncturing the tires of a car belonging to the Canadian delegation. Police estimated there were 100,000 people in total at the demonstration on Thursday, with 12,000 participating in the central march. Organizers called off the event once violence broke out.

Police also reported that one of their helicopters almost collided with a rocket flare, and a pilot of a different helicopter suffered eye injuries after a laser was pointed at them.

U.S. President Donald Trump arrived in Hamburg on Thursday following his speech in Warsaw, where he called for defending Western values and rallying against "dire threats" to civilizations. "Just as Poland can not be broken, I declare today for the world to hear that the West will never, ever be broken," Trump said during his speech in Poland. "Our values will prevail, our people will thrive, and our civilization will triumph."

Trump and Merkel met privately after his arrival on Thursday, discussing issues that include North Korea, the situation in the Middle East, the conflict in eastern Ukraine, and "some issues on the G20 agenda." U.S. Secretary of State Rex Tillerson and German Foreign Minister Sigmar Gabriel also participated, according to a German government statement. Trump then had dinner with Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe and South Korean President Moon Jae-in.

On Friday, Trump is scheduled to meet with Russian President Vladimir Putin for about 35 minutes. Trump tweeted early Friday that he is looking forward to his meeting with the Russian president.

Title: Republican Advantage in Senate Elections Shifts in 2016, According to Political Analyst Charlie Cook

 Article:

 Political analyst Charlie Cook, in a report for the National Journal, asserts that the Republican advantage in the Senate elections observed in 2014 is not expected to persist in the 2016 election cycle. The Senate seats that the Republicans won in 2014 were favorable due to seven Democratic senators hailing from states that former presidential candidate Mitt Romney won handily in 2012, an unpopular president to run against, and fewer seats that the Republicans needed to defend.

 In contrast, Republicans will have to defend 24 seats in 2016, while Democrats will only have 10. All 10 Democratic Senate seats are in states that President Barack Obama won in 2012, and seven states that are currently held by Republicans. These states include Florida, Illinois, Iowa, New Hampshire, Ohio, Pennsylvania, and Wisconsin.

 A silver lining for the Republicans is that the Senate seats up for re-election in blue states were not won by Obama by margins as wide as the red states won by Romney, where Democrats were up for re-election in 2014. The reddest state with a Democratic senator up for re-election in 2014 was West Virginia, which Romney won by 27 points in 2012. By contrast, the bluest state up for re-election with a Republican senator is Illinois, which Obama won by 17 points.

 Another silver lining for the GOP is that not all states with Republican senators up for re-election that were won by Obama in 2012 are necessarily competitive. For example, it is very unlikely that Republican Sen. Chuck Grassley will lose in Iowa, even though the president won the Hawkeye State by 6 points in 2012. The competitiveness of the other states will depend on who the Democratic challengers are.

 Democrats and Republicans may break even on open seats up for re-election, with the Democrats having three open seats, two in deep blue states, while the Republicans have two open seats, with only one considered competitive. If Democrats want to reclaim the majority in the Senate, they will need to pick up four seats if a Democrat wins the presidential election, and five if they do not.

Title: National Poll Shows Warren and Biden in Close Race for Democratic Presidential Nomination

Article:

A new national poll on the eve of the fourth-round Democratic presidential primary debate indicates a close race between Sen. Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts and former Vice President Joe Biden for their party's nomination.

According to a Quinnipiac University survey on Monday, Warren stands at 30 percent support among Democratic voters and independents who lean toward the party. Biden, who was the unrivaled front-runner until Warren's surge in the polls over the past couple of months, is at 27 percent. Warren's three-percentage-point advantage is within the survey's margin of error.

The poll is the third conducted by Quinnipiac since late last month showing Warren with a slight edge over Biden. "For Senator Warren, the third straight time essentially tied at the top is the charm," Quinnipiac University Polling Analyst Tim Malloy emphasized. "Her candidacy clearly has staying power going into the debate."

Sen. Bernie Sanders of Vermont stands at 11 percent, with South Bend, Ind., Mayor Pete Buttigieg at 8 percent and Sen. Kamala Harris of California at 4 percent. Sens. Cory Booker of New Jersey and Amy Klobuchar of Minnesota, tech entrepreneur Andrew Yang, and billionaire environmental and progressive advocate Tom Steyer each registered at 2 percent in the poll. The other candidates in the shrinking but still large field of contenders stood at 1 percent or less.

Quinnipiac's survey differs from a Fox News poll released last week that indicated Biden at 32 percent, with Warren ten points back at 22 percent and Sanders at 17 percent. No other candidate cracked double digits in the Fox News survey.

Twelve candidates have qualified for Tuesday's debate, which is set to be held at Otterbein University in Westerville, Ohio. They are, in alphabetical order, Biden, Booker, Buttigieg, former Housing and Urban Development Secretary Julián Castro, Rep. Tulsi Gabbard of Hawaii, Harris, Klobuchar, former Rep. Beto O'Rourke of Texas, Sanders, Steyer, Warren, and Yang.

While national primary horserace polls have garnered significant attention, the battle for the nomination is a fight for the states and their delegates. A new poll in New Hampshire, the state holding the first presidential primary, indicated a three-way tie at the top.

Warren stands at 25 percent support among likely Democratic primary voters in the Granite State in a Boston Herald-Franklin Pierce University survey, with Biden at 24 percent and Sanders at 22 percent. Buttigieg stands at 9 percent, and Harris at 5 percent, with no one else in the field topping 2 percent.

In New Hampshire's Republican presidential contest, President Trump remains the overwhelming favorite against three extreme long-shot primary challengers, but his support has deteriorated from 88 percent a month ago to 71 percent in the survey. One of the primary challengers, former Massachusetts Gov. Bill Weld, saw his support jump from 3 percent in early September to 14 percent in the new survey.

The Boston Herald-Franklin Pierce University poll was conducted Oct. 9-13, with 422 likely Democratic primary voters and 405 likely Republican primary voters in New Hampshire questioned by live telephone operators. The survey's margin of error was plus or minus 4.8 percentage points for Democratic primary questions and plus or minus 4.9 percentage points for GOP primary questions.

The Quinnipiac University poll was conducted October 11-13, with 1,195 self-identified registered voters nationwide questioned by live telephone operators. The survey included 505 Democratic voters and independent voters leaning Democratic with a margin of error of plus or minus 5.3 percentage points.

Title: GOP and Democrats Clash Over ObamaCare Repeal and Replacement Strategy

Article:

The battle for the future of the Affordable Care Act, commonly known as ObamaCare, intensified on Capitol Hill this week as President Obama and Vice President-elect Mike Pence met with their respective congressional allies to discuss strategy for the Republican's repeal push.

While President Obama urged Democrats to "fight" for the Affordable Care Act's survival, Pence assured Republicans that the Donald Trump administration will make the law's demise its "first order of business."

"It was a promise made on the campaign trail," Pence said at a press conference after meeting with House Republicans. "The first order of business is to repeal and replace ObamaCare... People voted for a better health care system, and we owe them that."

Pence sought to reassure supporters jittery about reports that party leaders could delay repeal efforts and that they have no replacement plan. He also said the repeal process would be a "two-track approach," with incoming GOP President Donald Trump using his executive powers, as leaders of the Republican-controlled Congress draft and pass the requisite legislation.

"It will be a legislative and executive action agenda to assure an orderly transition to something better," said Pence, who with Trump takes office on Jan. 20. He also said the incoming White House team is "already working on a series of executive actions."

Sources also told media outlets on Wednesday that Pence said in the meeting that Republicans hope to have a repeal bill on Trump's desk by Feb. 20, one month after the inauguration.

Though Pence boasted Wednesday that Trump could start taking executive action with minutes or hours of being sworn in, he and House Republican leaders were peppered with questions about when the repeal process would be complete and why they don't have an alternative health care plan.

"We have plenty of plans," said House Speaker Paul Ryan, R-Wis. "We don't want to pull the rug out on people. We do not want people to be caught with nothing."

Ending ObamaCare without a substitute plan could result in as many as 20 million Americans losing their health insurance, which would be a political disaster for Republicans.

Obama exited his 90-minute, closed-door meeting without comment but reportedly urged fellow Democrats not to "rescue" Republicans on what he suggested be called "Trumpcare."

New Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer said afterward that Obama and fellow Democrats had a "very inspiring" meeting in which they discussed a strategy to save ObamaCare, then blasted Republicans for their repeal-replace agenda.

"It would make America sick again, lead to chaos instead of affordable care," the New York Democrat said. "They have no idea what to put in place of [ObamaCare]. They talked about repeal, but for five years they have nothing to put in its place."

The visits come on the second day of the new, GOP-led Congress. Trump replacing Obama at the White House in 16 days puts the GOP's longtime goal of annulling much of the 2010 health care overhaul within reach.

Trump, despite his campaign vows to repeal the law, warned his colleagues on Wednesday not to let Democrats off the hook for a program he called a "disaster," while warning them to be careful in their methods.

Those who voted for Trump and other ObamaCare detractors are already concerned about congressional Republican leaders saying after the election that they'll need two to four years to implement a replacement plan.

ObamaCare was created as a way to drive down overall insurance costs by reducing emergency-care visits and other uninsured medical expenses. However, lower-than-projected enrollment among younger, healthy Americans as well as doctors and insurance companies dropping out of the program have contributed to significantly increasing premium costs.

On Tuesday, as the 115th Congress opened, Senate Republicans took the first step toward repealing ObamaCare. Sen. Mike Enzi, R-Wyo., introduced a resolution that begins the process for repeal legislation and calls for two House and two Senate committees to send over a legislative plan by Jan. 27.

"Today, we take the first steps to repair the nation's broken health care system," said Enzi, chairman of the Senate Budget Committee. He and other leaders of the Republican-controlled Congress are relying on a parliamentary maneuver known as "budget reconciliation" to dismantle the law because it avoids a Senate Democrat filibuster and requires only a 51-vote majority for passage in the chamber, not the 60-vote majority.

Republicans have a 52-to-48 member majority in the Senate and a 241-to-194 majority in the House, which requires only a simple majority for passage. Trump has provided few specifics about how he would revamp the nation's $3 trillion-a-year health care system. Steps he and congressional Republicans have mentioned include greater reliance on tax credits to help people afford coverage. And he has talked about keeping such provisions as allowing young adults to stay on their parents' plan and providing access to coverage for Americans with pre-existing medical conditions.

Title: House of Representatives Investigates Potential Lies by President Trump in Mueller Probe

Article:

The House of Representatives is currently investigating whether President Donald Trump may have lied to special counsel Robert Mueller during the Russia probe. In a court hearing on Monday, a House lawyer, representing the House Judiciary Committee, requested files from the special counsel's inquiry, with a focus on the president's statements to Mr. Mueller regarding WikiLeaks.

The primary focus of the Democratic-led inquiry is on alleged abuse of power by Mr. Trump in US-Ukraine relations. However, the impeachment inquiry is also reportedly scrutinizing the president's statements to Mr. Mueller during the investigation into Russian meddling in the 2016 election.

Doug Letter, representing the House Judiciary Committee, spoke to the federal appeals court on Monday, revealing that the impeachment inquiry is also investigating whether Mr. Trump lied to Mr. Mueller during the course of the probe. Mr. Letter has requested the redacted parts of the Mueller report and the full transcripts related to those portions.

During Mr. Mueller's testimony before Congress in July, he was asked whether Mr. Trump's incomplete written responses showed he was not always telling the truth. Mr. Mueller replied, "I would say, generally." It is unclear what exactly Mr. Mueller meant by his response, but Mr. Letter told the court on Monday he believed it meant the president "had been untruthful in some of his answers."

US media report that Mr. Letter may have been referring to whether Mr. Trump lied about contacts with WikiLeaks and knowledge that they were going to publish hacked Democratic emails. Mr. Letter added that evidence from the recent trial of Trump adviser Roger Stone strengthened lawmakers' argument for obtaining the secret material.

Stone, who was convicted last week of lying to Congress about his work with WikiLeaks, had several calls with Mr. Trump during the 2016 election. The president has said he did not know of any contact between his campaign and WikiLeaks and that he did not discuss WikiLeaks with Stone.

A lawyer for the Department of Justice argued that the impeachment inquiry was not a judicial proceeding and thus it was not legal for lawmakers to view classified grand jury material. However, during the impeachment proceedings against President Richard Nixon, a federal judge granted the House access to grand jury materials.

Following Monday's oral arguments, the appeals panel is considering the matter. Ahead of the news of this additional thread in the inquiry, Mr. Trump tweeted that he would "strongly consider" testifying to the impeachment inquiry "in order to get Congress focused again." As he did with the Mueller report, the president has dismissed the impeachment probe as a "witch hunt."

This week, eight individuals are due to testify before House lawmakers as a part of the impeachment proceedings. On Tuesday, Lt. Col. Alexander Vindman, a Ukraine expert on the National Security Council who listened in on Mr. Trump's July call with Ukraine's President Zelensky, will testify. The July call sparked a whistleblower complaint that eventually led to the start of the impeachment inquiry.

Title: Biden Consolidates Lead in Democratic Race as Super Tuesday Sequel Yields Comfortable Wins

Article:

In a continuation of the primary season, six states held Democratic nomination contests on Tuesday, collectively known as the "Super Tuesday Sequel." Former Vice President Joe Biden emerged as the clear winner, taking Mississippi, Missouri, and Michigan. The results from Washington, Idaho, and North Dakota are still pending, and Vermont Senator Bernie Sanders will hope to perform better in those states.

The race appears to be firmly in Biden's control, as he has consolidated his lead following his strong performance. In Michigan, a state that gave Sanders a surprise win in 2016, Biden's victory could mark the beginning of the end for Sanders' campaign.

Exit polls indicate that the difference in Michigan was white voters, union voters, and college graduates. Sanders won all three groups in 2016, but on Tuesday, Biden captured these demographics. He carried college graduates 51-44, whites 51-45, and union members, who made up 30% of the primary electorate, 54-42.

Biden's strong performance among black voters, late-deciders, and those looking for a candidate who can beat Donald Trump contributed to his comfortable win. The ease of the result has raised questions about whether the 2016 Michigan primary was a reflection of Hillary Clinton's weakness rather than Sanders' strength.

In Mississippi, more than 60% of the electorate on primary night was black, according to exit polls. Biden dominated that demographic, winning 86-11. The state's results are significant because they mean Biden will win the lion's share of Mississippi's 36 delegates to the national convention, further extending his delegate lead.

Bernie Sanders performed best with the youth vote, ages 17 to 29, according to exit polls. He carried it 82-15 in Michigan and 76-19 in Missouri, but only lost it by 4% in Mississippi, despite being routed in the state. The problem for Sanders was that the age group averaged only 12.5% of the electorate in those three states, not nearly enough to save the day for Sanders.

While this may be good news in the short term for Biden, it is a flashing warning sign for the general election if he is the nominee. Young voters were a key part of the coalition that delivered the White House to Barack Obama in 2008, as he won them by a record 34% over John McCain. If Biden does not find some way to improve his standing with this age demographic, he may suffer the same fate as Hillary Clinton, who only won the youth vote by 18%.

On Tuesday night, Biden made his pitch to Sanders' voters, perhaps with the autumn campaign in mind. "I want to thank Bernie Sanders and his supporters for their tireless energy and their passion," he said. "We share a common goal, and together we'll defeat Donald Trump."

The epitaph for Sanders' campaign may be that it was premised, in part, on the passion of new young voters who simply did not show up in sufficient numbers at the polling booths. As the primary season continues, the race for the Democratic nomination narrows for Sanders, and the path to victory becomes increasingly improbable.

Title: Migration Trend: Americans Shift from High-Tax States to Low-Tax States

Article:

Over the past decade, approximately 3.5 million Americans have relocated from high-tax states, such as California and those in the Northeast, to low-tax states like Texas and Arizona. This trend is expected to accelerate, according to a report from the American Legislative Exchange Council co-authored by Arthur Laffer and Stephen Moore.

The Republican Party's tax bill, which caps the deduction for state and local taxes (SALT), could reportedly speed up this migration. Laffer and Moore estimate that California and New York will lose around 800,000 residents over the next three years, nearly double the number from the previous three years. Connecticut, New Jersey, and Minnesota combined are projected to lose approximately 500,000 people in the same period.

The authors of the report suggest that as the migration increases, it will boost real-estate values in low-tax states while hurting high-tax states. In states with high income taxes, such as California, New York, Minnesota, and New Jersey, people can currently deduct their state income taxes on their federal return, but the SALT cap will limit this deduction to $10,000 per family.

While 90% of taxpayers are unaffected by the change, high earners in high-tax states will reportedly bear more costs of their state government under the new SALT cap, according to Laffer and Moore. In states like New York, the elimination of full SALT deductibility is expected to cost the state $14.3 billion, according to a report by Fox. New York Governor Andrew Cuomo has referred to the tax bill as an "economic missile."

In contrast, nine states, including Florida, Nevada, Texas, and Washington, impose no tax on earned income. Since 2007, low-tax states like Texas and Florida have gained 1.4 million and 850,000 residents, respectively, from elsewhere in the U.S., according to Laffer and Moore. High-tax states like California and New York combined have lost more than 2.2 million residents during the same period.

Last week, Texas Republican Governor Greg Abbott invited residents of high-tax New Jersey to move to Texas, citing his administration's $4 billion tax cut, as reported by ███. Abbott's invitation followed New Jersey's newly sworn-in Democratic Governor Phil Murphy's budget proposal, which requested a $2.7 billion increase from the prior year's budget, according to the report.

Title: Christ Church Removes Memorial Plaques of George Washington and Robert E. Lee

Article:

Christ Church in Alexandria, Virginia, has announced the removal of memorial plaques dedicated to its former vestryman and the country's first president, George Washington, and Confederate General Robert E. Lee. The decision was made due to the plaques causing discomfort and perceived unwelcoming atmosphere for some visitors.

In a letter to the congregation, church leaders stated that the plaques, which have been on display since 1870, are relics of another era and do not align with the church's motto, "All are welcome—no exceptions." The plaques, located on either side of the altar, will be removed by next summer, with a new location yet to be determined.

The decision has sparked a heated response, with supporters praising the church for its "courageous" stand, while critics have compared the church's leadership to extremist groups such as the Taliban or the Islamic State. The church's Facebook page has become a battleground for the debate.

The plaques, about the size of grave markers, read "In memory of George Washington" and "In memory of Robert Edward Lee." The Washington plaque was bought by the first president when the church opened in 1773, and he was a vestryman and contributor throughout his life. Lee attended Christ Church from age 3, and his daughter, Mary Custis Lee, left the church $10,000 in her will upon her death in 1918, which was used to establish the church's endowment.

The church leaders stated that the lack of information or comment on the two men's lives in the church was part of the problem, as the sanctuary is a worship space, not a museum. The church has small metal markers on the Washington family pew and at the location where Lee was confirmed, but there is no additional context provided.

The church's website promotes itself as "a church where George Washington worshipped" and displays a picture of its famous patron. It is unclear whether the church could divorce itself from Washington entirely, as the website and Washington's historical connection to the church are significant.

In recent years, monuments dedicated to Lee have been under scrutiny, with incidents of violence in Charlottesville this year surrounding a Lee statue that the city is trying to remove. In response, a church Lee attended in Lexington, Virginia, changed its name from R.E. Lee Memorial Church to Grace Episcopal Church. The Washington National Cathedral also removed a stained-glass window with an image of Lee.

Christ Church, however, stated that the two men were inextricably linked in history and had to be considered together, as they were erected together and visually balance each other. In their letter to parishioners, the church's leadership praised Washington as "the visionary who not only refused to be king but also gave up power after eight years, and a symbol of our democracy." Lee was described in less-glowing terms, as a longtime parishioner who for some "symbolizes the attempt to overthrow the Union and to preserve slavery."

The leaders wrote, "Today our country is trying once again to come to grips with the history of slavery and the subsequent disenfranchisement of people of color." Despite his generosity to Christ Church, Washington was a more regular attendant at Pohick Church, which stands south of Mount Vernon. A staffer at Pohick said they have no plans to delete Washington from their church.

Title: Obama Adjusts Economic Turnaround Timeline Amidst Approaching Election

Article:

In a shift from his 2009 statement that a failure to right the economy in three years would mean a "one-term proposition," President Barack Obama has seemingly moved the goalposts for economic recovery. During a campaign trail appearance in Green Bay, Wisconsin, the President stated, "Now, we knew from the beginning that our work would take more than one year, or even one term -- because let's face it, the middle class was getting hammered long before the financial crisis hit."

This potential adjustment in the President's timetable for economic recovery comes a day before the Labor Department is set to release the October jobs report. Last month's survey showed a decrease in the jobless rate, providing seemingly good news for the economy and Obama's re-election campaign. However, some economists have questioned the accuracy of the statistic, and the report being released on Friday is the last major economic survey before Election Day.

President Obama has consistently argued that he needs more time to complete the work he started. In an August 2011 fundraiser, he said, "When I said change we can believe in, I did not say change we can believe in tomorrow."

However, the claim that "we knew from the beginning" it would take more than one term is a departure from what Obama told NBC's Matt Lauer in February 2009. At the time, Obama stated, "A year from now, I think people are going to see that we're starting to make some progress, but there's still going to be some pain out there. If I don't have this done in three years, then there's going to be a one-term proposition."

Romney's campaign spokesman, Ryan Williams, responded to Obama's Green Bay remarks, stating, "Four years ago, President Obama made a series of commitments to the nation and said that he did not deserve a second term if he failed to keep them. Now, faced with a record of broken promises and failed policies, the President is trying to reissue and repackage the same pledges and mislead Americans into believing that the results will somehow be different."

Thursday marked the first day since Super Storm Sandy that both candidates were out on the trail in full force. They bickered over who can claim the mantle of the "change" candidate. Romney's campaign asserts that the former Massachusetts governor is the only one offering "real change." Obama, on the other hand, argues that his opponent is merely offering to return America to the policies of the George W. Bush administration, policies that he claims unfairly favor the wealthy.

The President was campaigning Thursday in Wisconsin, Nevada, and Colorado, while Romney made a three-stop swing through Virginia. Romney's campaign also revealed Thursday that it is planning a rally in Pennsylvania, a state that has backed Democrats in recent presidential races. All four states are important battlegrounds.

Title: UN Arms Trade Treaty: Assessing the Impact on Second Amendment Rights

Article:

The United Nations Arms Trade Treaty (ATT) faced challenges during the month-long conference held in New York City in July, but as noted by Ted Bromund of the Heritage Foundation, the concept of the ATT is not easily discarded. The treaty's proponents, including numerous countries and left-wing nongovernmental organizations, are pushing for its implementation.

One question that has arisen is whether the UN's argument that the ATT will not infringe on Second Amendment rights is honest. Katie, in a recent post, posed this question, and it deserves further scrutiny.

The Obama administration has stated that they will not accept any treaty that infringes on the constitutional rights of U.S. citizens to bear arms. Given President Obama's stance on gun control and his feelings about the right to bear arms, the ATT has become a significant issue.

Contrary to the common belief that a two-thirds majority in the Senate is necessary for UN treaties to take effect, this understanding is too simplistic, as noted by Ted Bromund in a separate article. If the ATT conference produces a treaty that is open for signature, President Obama may sign it immediately. The U.S. will then be under a legal obligation not to defeat the ATT's "object and purpose." The interpretation of this phrase will rest with the State Department's lawyers, whose decisions can not be predicted and are not easily subject to legislative oversight.

Furthermore, Americans should be cautious about the UN's claims that the ATT will not infringe on their Second Amendment rights. A report by the UN Coordinating Action on Small Arms titled "The Impact of Poorly Regulated Arms Transfers on the Work of the UN" recognizes that states have a right to "individual or collective self-defense" and that the ATT does not aim to impede or interfere with the lawful ownership and use of weapons. However, it also states that because of the problem of diversion, or the transfer of weapons to the illicit market, the arms trade must be regulated in ways that would minimize the risk of misuse of legally owned weapons.

The Obama administration has also echoed claims that the ATT will not pose a threat to domestic gun owners. However, a Washington Times editorial sees through this assertion, stating that the agreement's language is broad, vague, and poorly defined, and could be stretched in ways that would pose a threat to the Second Amendment.

In conclusion, the ATT will not prevent violence, terrorism, and intra-state conflicts, as its backers contend. The logistics alone are impossible, and the fact that the Obama administration is agreeing to come together as equals with dictatorial regimes like Iran is unconscionable.

Given the Obama administration's record on honesty and transparency, Americans should approach the administration's assurances about the ATT with skepticism. The soaring gun sales in Obama's first term and the subsequent skyrocketing gun stocks since his reelection may tell you everything you need to know about whether Americans take the administration at their word.

Title: San Francisco Police Department Instructed Officers Not to Use Body-Worn Cameras During Journalist's Home Raid

Article:

A San Francisco Police Department (SFPD) memo obtained by the Reporters Committee for Freedom of the Press reveals that police were instructed not to use body-worn cameras during a high-profile raid of journalist Bryan Carmody's home last year.

In the two-paragraph memo, Lieutenant Pilar Torres states that officers conducting the raid were told not to utilize their department-issued body-worn cameras (BWC) for the operation, as the video footage could compromise the confidential investigation.

Katie Townsend, legal director for the Reporters Committee for Freedom of the Press, commented, "Body-worn cameras are designed to increase police transparency and accountability. The fact that officers were instructed not to use their bodycams during an illegal raid of a journalist's home is deeply troubling."

In an email response to Reporters Committee questions, SFPD spokesman Sgt. Michael Andraychak said the department is not able to provide additional information about the memo "due to pending administrative investigations."

The SFPD raided Carmody's home with search warrants and a sledgehammer on May 10, 2019, about a month after the freelance journalist refused to reveal the source of a leaked police report concerning the death of Jeff Adachi, a longtime San Francisco public defender. Officers seized computers, cameras, and phones from Carmody's home before conducting a separate search of the journalist's office.

All of the search warrants were later deemed illegal under California's "shield law," which protects journalists' confidential sources and materials. In March, San Francisco agreed to pay Carmody $369,000 to settle a claim filed by the journalist.

The incident sparked nationwide outrage, especially among journalists and press freedom advocates. The unexplained presence of the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) at the search, and the fact that agents questioned Carmody about his source, amplified the press freedom concerns in the case.

Last May, the Reporters Committee called for an investigation into the raid. The Reporters Committee and a coalition of 60 media organizations then urged a California court to return Carmody's seized materials. The Reporters Committee, First Amendment Coalition, and Northern California Chapter of the Society of Professional Journalists also sued to unseal Carmody's arrest and search warrant records.

The Reporters Committee has also pursued records related to the FBI's presence during the raid. According to an FBI document obtained through a Freedom of Information Act lawsuit the Reporters Committee filed in September, FBI agents knew Carmody was a journalist when they questioned him. It is unclear whether the FBI followed Justice Department guidelines requiring authorization from the attorney general before questioning a member of the news media.

The Reporters Committee regularly files friend-of-the-court briefs and its attorneys represent journalists and news organizations pro bono in court cases that involve First Amendment freedoms, the newsgathering rights of journalists, and access to public information. Stay up-to-date on their work by signing up for their monthly newsletter and following them on Twitter or Instagram.

Title: Conservative Figures Allegedly Harassed and Attacked by Antifa in Philadelphia

Article:

On August 6, 2018, Turning Point USA founder Charlie Kirk and Communications Director Candace Owens claimed they were harassed and attacked by Antifa during a breakfast outing in a Philadelphia cafe. According to their Twitter posts, the incident occurred shortly after their arrival, with Antifa members reportedly surrounding the establishment and using bullhorns.

Kirk and Owens alleged that they were met with hissing, chanting, and screaming upon leaving the cafe. Kirk also stated that he was doused with water, and the police had to intervene for safety reasons.

In a series of tweets, Owens and Kirk shared their experiences, accusing Antifa of violence and labeling them as an "all-white fascist organization." They also claimed that the police force protecting them was all-black and Hispanic.

Both Kirk and Owens appeared on Hannity, a Fox News program, to discuss the incident on August 6, 2018. In subsequent tweets, Kirk and Owens expressed their views on the incident, criticizing Antifa and suggesting a connection between the incident and a call for confrontation made by Representative Maxine Waters.

It is important to note that the characterization of Antifa as an "all-white" organization is not universally accepted, as the group is known for its anti-fascist and anti-racist ideology. Additionally, the allegations made by Kirk and Owens have not been independently verified, and the specific details of the police force's ethnicity are not publicly available.

This incident is a part of a broader debate surrounding free speech, political violence, and the role of public figures in inciting confrontations. The Turning Point USA and Antifa have been involved in several similar incidents in the past, further fueling the ongoing discourse.

Title: Obama Nominates Jeh Johnson as Homeland Security Secretary

 Article:

 President Barack Obama has announced his intention to nominate Jeh Johnson, former Pentagon attorney, as the next Secretary of Homeland Security. The nomination will be made official at a ceremony on Friday. If confirmed by the Senate, Johnson will replace Janet Napolitano, who left the administration to head the University of California education system.

 Johnson served as the general counsel for the Department of Defense during Obama's first term. During his tenure, he provided legal review and approval for every military operation approved by the President and the Secretary of Defense.

 The nominee is described as a critical member of the President's counterterrorism team and someone who worked closely with Homeland Security officials during his years at the Pentagon. His specialties include cybersecurity, and he played a key role in repealing the Pentagon's "Don't Ask, Don't Tell" policy that banned openly gay servicemembers.

 Johnson also provided legal guidance in the use of unmanned drones against terrorism suspects overseas and in the use of military commissions instead of civilian courts to try suspects. He led a crackdown on unauthorized news leaks at the Defense Department.

 During a speech at Britain's Oxford University last year, Johnson expressed the view that the nation's war on terrorism should not be endless, and the focus should shift to law enforcement and intelligence operations.

 Johnson's nomination could face scrutiny during a Senate confirmation hearing, with potential topics including his role in national security, human rights, and the use of military commissions and drones.

 Elisa Massimino, president of Human Rights First, praised Johnson for grappling with the challenges of protecting national security while respecting human rights and upholding American ideals during his time at the Pentagon.

 However, Sen. Jeff Sessions (R-Ala.) criticized Obama for nominating a "loyalist and fundraiser" to lead what he called a "mismanaged" department. Sessions expressed concern that the department needs a proven manager with strong relevant law enforcement experience, recognized independence and integrity.

 Johnson, a native of Wappingers Falls, N.Y., also served as general counsel to the Air Force during President Clinton's administration.

Title: Budget Battles: A Historical Perspective on the Recurring Fiscal Conflicts in the U.S. Congress

Article:

The United States Congress and the presidency have been embroiled in a series of recurring budget battles, with each new resolution over taxes and spending leading to another round of fighting. The latest fiscal cliff, as some call it, has once again brought the nation's budget process into the spotlight, with the federal government potentially shutting down or failing to raise the debt ceiling in the coming weeks.

One of the main drivers of these budget battles is partisan strategy, as polarization has made almost every issue more contentious on Capitol Hill. In recent years, Republicans have taken the initiative to use the budget as a means to handcuff Democratic presidents.

The strategy has deep roots, dating back to the 1960s when conservative Southern Democrats and Midwestern Republicans focused attention on the rising deficits to force President Lyndon Johnson to accept deep spending cuts. In 1995 and 1996, Republicans shut down the federal government with their push for spending cuts, a tactic they continued to employ throughout President Bill Clinton's term.

Since 2010, a growing number of Republicans have been willing to use aggressive techniques to force President Barack Obama's hand on this issue. They have demonstrated a willingness to shut down the government and threaten not to raise the debt ceiling, which would send the country into default.

While there have been moments when Democrats have challenged Republican presidents, the difference is that they have usually done so symbolically to make a statement about Republican policies, whereas the new generation of Republicans appears willing to follow through on the threat.

Another reason the budgeting process is becoming ever more brutal is because, historically, once legislators break the barrier of using a certain tactic, the practice can become normalized. The best example is the filibuster, which has become a routine weapon in partisan combat since the 1970s.

The budget wars are also fueled by the 24-hour news media, which is constantly in search of dramatic stories to win attention. The budget war offers great fodder, with the possibility of a fiscal cliff providing political junkies a bit of the kind of thrill that "Breaking Bad" fans have felt every time Walter White extricates himself from another bind.

At some point, there will be pressure to reform the process. The latest round of budget battles has led a larger number of Republicans, like Sen. John McCain, to be openly critical of their colleagues and call for a very different approach. As Rep. Peter King, an opponent of the Affordable Care Act, explained, "I still think we should try to repeal the bill. But you repeal it the same way you passed it. You get bills through both houses of Congress, and you get the president to sign it."

Budget reform is possible, and there have been several moments in U.S. history when Congress overhauled the entire budget process. It might be time to start that debate again.

Title: Former CIA Agent Claims Islamic State Cells Present in U.S.

Article:

Former CIA agent Bob Baer has stated that Islamic State (ISIS) cells are present within the United States, with some members having entered the country by crossing the Mexican border. Baer made these comments during an interview with CNN's Jake Tapper on Tuesday.

According to Baer, intelligence agencies are aware of some individuals they suspect of being ISIS members and are working to gather evidence to apprehend them. However, they fear there may be more individuals they are not yet aware of.

ISIS, currently known as the Islamic State, has taken control of large portions of Syria and Iraq, claiming to have established a caliphate from which they plan to wage global jihad. A spokesman recently stated that ISIS intends to raise the Islamic flag in the White House.

On Tuesday, ISIS released a video featuring American journalist Steven Sotloff, marking the second such video in the past two weeks. The group had previously threatened to behead Sotloff if the United States did not cease airstrikes against ISIS in Iraq. American journalist James Foley was beheaded in a previous video.

Baer suggested that the killings of Foley and Sotloff were a response to U.S. airstrikes hindering ISIS' efforts in Iraq. "They have no choice in their minds but to strike back," Baer said.

At least four Americans are publicly known to be held by ISIS, according to Baer, who stated that the group essentially grabbed the first American they could to carry out their grisly actions and release them on video. Baer expects ISIS to continue beheading Western captives as they continue to be hurt by American attacks.

Title: AstraZeneca-Oxford Coronavirus Vaccine Shows Positive Results in Early-Stage Trials

Article:

An experimental vaccine being developed by AstraZeneca and Oxford University against the new coronavirus has shown an immune response in early-stage clinical trials, according to data published on Monday. The vaccine, known as AZD1222, has been described by the World Health Organization's chief scientist as the leading candidate in a global race to halt a pandemic that has killed over 600,000 people.

The vaccine, which has not caused serious side effects and elicited antibody and T-cell immune responses, was developed by Oxford and licensed to AstraZeneca, which has put it into large-scale, late-stage trials to test its efficacy. AstraZeneca has signed agreements with governments worldwide to supply the vaccine should it prove effective and gain regulatory approval. The company has stated it will not seek to profit from the vaccine during the pandemic.

The trial results, published in The Lancet medical journal, showed a stronger immune response in 10 people given an extra dose of the vaccine after 28 days, echoing a trial in pigs. However, the early-stage trial could not determine whether one or two doses would be needed to provide immunity.

AstraZeneca's Chief Executive, Pascal Soriot, stated that the company is on track to produce doses by September, but the availability of the vaccine this year depends on how quickly late-stage trials can be completed, given the dwindling prevalence of the virus in Britain. Late-stage trials are underway in Brazil and South Africa and are due to start in the United States, where prevalence is higher.

The trial included 1,077 healthy adults aged 18-55 years with no history of COVID-19. Researchers said the vaccine caused minor side effects more frequently than a control group, but some of these could be reduced by taking the painkiller paracetamol. The antibody levels generated were "in the region" of those seen in convalescent patients.

AstraZeneca's biopharma chief, Mene Pangalos, stated that the firm was leaning towards a two-dose strategy for later-stage trials, and did not want to risk a single or lower dose that might not work. The trial results do not provide information on the vaccine's efficacy in preventing COVID-19.

Title: Trump's Economic Speech in Detroit: A Blend of Conservative Policies and Populist Agenda

Article:

In a shift from his previous political rhetoric, Donald Trump delivered a policy-focused economic speech in Detroit on Monday, addressing issues of taxes, regulation, and trade. The speech aimed to unite Republicans and provide a more substantial policy agenda, following a week of controversy over his attacks on the family of a slain Muslim American soldier and his resistance to backing top Republicans in their reelection bids.

In the speech, Trump emphasized the need for "only great and well-crafted trade deals where we as a country for once benefit." However, he also appealed to his "America first" philosophy by stating, "Americanism, not globalism, will be our new credo."

The speech was met with 13 interruptions from protesters, but Trump remained calm and delivered a policy agenda that Republicans could potentially rally around. The agenda included:

1. Adopting the House Republican proposal for individual income tax rates, which would lower the top federal rate (currently 39.6 percent) and reduce the number of tax brackets from seven to three – 33 percent, 25 percent, and 12 percent.
2. Reducing the business tax rate from 35 percent to 15 percent.
3. Allowing parents to fully deduct the average cost of child-care spending from their taxes.
4. Tariffs against any countries that "cheat by unfairly subsidizing their goods."

Trump's tax plan is projected to raise more revenue than his earlier proposal, which had been forecast to cost $10 trillion over a decade. However, economist Jared Bernstein, a former member of President Obama's economic team, questions the plan's benefits for average families and sees a significant loophole for the wealthy in Trump's plan for "pass-through" income.

Douglas Holtz-Eakin, president of American Action Forum and the chief economic adviser to GOP presidential nominee John McCain in 2008, calls Trump's tax plan a "peace offering to House Republicans" but also notes Trump's outreach to labor by adopting Democratic positions on trade and infrastructure. Trump's infrastructure plan is said to be double what Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton is proposing.

However, Holtz-Eakin criticizes Trump for his focus on reviving American steel, stating that it is not a forward-looking vision. Economist Donald Grimes from the University of Michigan agrees that infrastructure spending is needed but notes that Trump provided no details and that there are limits to what the federal government can do alone. Grimes also points out that Trump's trade protectionism may not align with economic realities, especially in Detroit, where the economy is not solely manufacturing.

In conclusion, Trump's economic speech in Detroit presented a blend of conservative policies and populist agenda, aiming to solidify the Republican base and counter the narrative that he lacks substance. However, the specifics of his plans, particularly regarding infrastructure and trade, remain to be seen.

Title: One Federal Employee Lost Job Due to Sequestration, According to Government Audit

Article:

A government audit conducted by the Government Accountability Office (GAO) has revealed that only one employee in the entire federal government lost a job due to sequestration. The audit, released last month, found the only permanent cut came at the U.S. Parole Commission, which eliminated one position.

Sen. Tom Coburn, an Oklahoma Republican, commented on the audit's findings on Wednesday, stating that the audit shows the concerns over sequestration's impact on jobs were overblown.

"Despite relentless warnings about the dire consequences of sequestration's budget cuts, it appears sequestration resulted in only one layoff," he said. "While that's good news for federal employees and other workers, it is devastating to the credibility of Washington politicians and administration officials who spent months—and millions of dollars—engaging in a coordinated multi-agency cabinet-level public relations campaign to scare the American people."

A year ago, sequestration was a significant part of the political conversation in Washington. The cuts, which kicked in on March 1, 2013, reduced spending at nearly every federal department and agency. President Obama and Democrats on Capitol Hill warned of devastating impacts on government services and a major dent to the economy.

Congress blunted some of the impacts, passing legislation to keep air traffic controllers and meat plant inspectors on the job. However, most agencies ended up coping with the cuts, which ran as high as 7 percent.

The White House famously closed itself to public tours, while other agencies took deeper actions. Seven departments or agencies did furlough employees, but even that was less than a third of government agencies and departments surveyed by the GAO. Instead, those 15 departments and agencies that didn't furlough employees ended up using leftover savings or cutting other programs.

"NASA slowed down development of the program that will allow the U.S. to stop relying on Russia for trips to the International Space Station. At the same time, NASA—like most agencies—did not furlough any employees," Mr. Coburn wrote in a letter to the White House budget office.

He asked Director Sylvia Burwell to explain why some programs were cut but federal employees were spared. The budget office didn't immediately respond to a request for comment Wednesday afternoon.

According to the GAO, nearly every agency or department affected by sequestration canceled or limited bonuses, cut travel and training, and limited overtime. Nearly half of agencies and departments offered employees early retirement or bonus payments to get them to leave early. However, most managed to avoid furloughing or cutting jobs altogether.

Title: Political Analyst Suggests Al Gore as Alternative Presidential Candidate for Democrats

Article:

A political analyst, Sean Illing, from Salon, has proposed Al Gore as a viable alternative for the Democratic Party in the upcoming presidential election. Illing, in an article, outlines ten reasons why he believes Gore could bridge the party's establishment and progressive wings.

According to Illing, Gore, who is not currently in office, has the cachet to unite the two factions of the Democratic Party. He notes that Gore's political life may seem distant, but his activism and business acumen have kept him in the public consciousness.

The proposal has received positive reactions from various media outlets, including Powerline, Newsbusters, the Legal Insurrection blog, and PJ Media, which summarize the trend as "Anybody but Hillary!"

Rumors about Gore's potential presidential bid have circulated for about a year, along with reports that he has become a vegetarian. However, Gore has denied any interest in running for office and has been busy with climate matters and the "Live Earth - Road to Paris" concert, scheduled for September 19, to promote "climate action" with singer Pharrell Williams and other artists.

In a recent interview at an advertising awards symposium in France, Gore declined to back Hillary Clinton for the White House, stating that it was "too early" to weigh in on the matter. This response has sparked renewed speculation about Gore's potential candidacy.

Title: Trump Administration Enforces Church Amendment Against University of Vermont Medical Center Over Abortion Allegations

Article:

The Trump administration is taking action against the University of Vermont Medical Center (UVMC) following a nurse's claim that her supervisors compelled her to participate in an abortion against her will. Jordan Sekulow, an attorney representing the nurse from the American Center for Law & Justice (ACLJ), stated on "Fox & Friends" that President Trump, through the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS), is the first president to enforce the federal law, the Church Amendment, which was passed by Congress in 1973.

On May 9, 2018, the anonymous Catholic nurse filed a conscience and religious discrimination complaint against UVMC, alleging they violated the law by forcing her to assist in an elective abortion despite her conscience-based objection. The nurse believed she was assisting in a miscarriage, but later discovered it was an abortion.

In response to the allegations, HHS's Office of Civil Rights (OCR) has given UVMC, located in Burlington, Vt., 30 days to change its policies. Sekulow claims that UVMC's policy dates back to 2017, when the former CEO of Planned Parenthood New England came in as a new chairman of the Board of Trustees and the medical center started performing elective abortions. Sekulow asserts that the former Planned Parenthood chairman "definitely has an animus to pro-life nurses, medical professionals, even doctors."

UVMC responded Wednesday, stating they have "robust, formal protections that safeguard both our employees' religious, ethical, and cultural beliefs, and our patients' rights to access safe and legal abortion." The medical center added they "do not discriminate against any employees for exercising their rights to opt out of procedures to which they object, including 'termination of pregnancy.'"

Sekulow contends that UVMC is disregarding the nurse's rights by stating, "If we can accommodate you, we will. That's not the federal law that was passed by Congress. That's not what HHS enforces... You must accommodate the objector."

Title: U.S. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo to Meet with Russian Foreign Minister Amidst Venezuela Crisis

Article:

United States Secretary of State Mike Pompeo is set to meet with Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov on Monday afternoon in Finland, as tensions persist over Russia's involvement in propping up Venezuelan dictator Nicolas Maduro.

In a press gaggle on his plane en route to the meeting, Pompeo discussed Maduro's current situation, stating, "We're trying to make sure the Venezuelan people get the elected democracy they deserve. That's our mission." He also emphasized the U.S.'s readiness to assist.

Pompeo further explained, "Maduro has to see that this is falling apart on him. I said earlier today that he still rules, there's no way he can govern. The situation on the ground continues to get worse for the Venezuelan people."

He continued, "This week, while Maduro managed to maintain control over the military in some regards, there were many military who left, a senior intelligence officer departed, a very senior official who had been closely connected to Maduro as well as his predecessor. He has to see how tenuous this is. He was in fact prepared to leave and then ultimately chose not to. He understands that time is limited and I think he's searching for as much leverage as he can get before he ultimately makes his departure. I don't know if that will be next week or a month from now, but the Venezuelan people can see conditions continue to deteriorate, and that means he can't maintain his presence there."

According to Pompeo and other administration officials, Maduro was persuaded by the Russians to remain in the country after being ready to leave permanently for Cuba late last week.

White House National Security Advisor John Bolton stated on Twitter about continued Russian interference, "The United States will not tolerate foreign military interference in the Western Hemisphere. President Trump has made it clear that there will be costs for those who further Maduro's usurpation and repression."

During his time in Finland, Pompeo will also deliver a speech on Arctic policy and meet with several leaders from the Arctic Council.

Title: Obama and Romney Return to Debate Preparations After Al Smith Dinner

Article:

Following a light-hearted evening at the Al Smith dinner, where President Barack Obama and Mitt Romney engaged in friendly banter, the two presidential candidates have returned to their campaign trails, preparing for their third and final debate on Monday in Florida.

At an event at George Mason University on Friday, President Obama continued to make jokes, but they carried a more pointed tone. "Romney is changing up so much and backtracking and side-stepping, we've got to name this condition he's going through," said the president. "I think it's called…'Romnesia,'" he added to cheers and laughter.
