"I'm not a medical doctor, but I do want to go over some of the symptoms with you because I want to make sure nobody else catches it."

After campaigning in Virginia, President Obama will spend the weekend at Camp David preparing for the debate. Meanwhile, Romney headed to Boca Raton, the site of the debate, where he will hold a fundraiser and begin another round of debate preparation.

The debates this year have taken on an outsize importance, and as the race tightens, the stakes for Monday's faceoff could not be higher. Following their first matchup, Mitt Romney received his most significant polling boost all year. And following the second debate, President Obama had his best day of fundraising ever, including the 2008 campaign.

"This race is close," said Albert May, a professor of political communication at George Washington University. "Anything that moves the polls a point or two is going to be important."

Monday's debate will focus on foreign policy, an area of expertise on which the president has traditionally polled better. Last week's debate, however, exposed a chink in the president's record, particularly when it came to his understanding and announcing the causes for the Sept. 11 attack on the U.S. consulate in Benghazi, Libya, that left four Americans dead.

A new report out today suggests that the CIA station chief in Libya reported to Washington within 24 hours of the attack that there was evidence that terrorists were behind the assault. Romney has scored points on foreign policy by criticizing the president for not quickly and categorically ascribing the attack to terrorists.

"Of course the debate is important," said a Romney campaign staffer, unauthorized to speak for attribution. "Given the president's shifting record on Libya, I imagine it will come up in a debate on foreign policy."

"On Monday, the President will discuss how he's kept his promise to the American people to end the war in Iraq in a responsible way, refocus on al-Qaeda, and put forward a plan to end the war in Afghanistan," said an Obama staffer on background. "In contrast, all that Mitt Romney has offered in blunder and bluster. He said he would not move heaven and earth to get bin Laden. He called Russia, rather than al-Qaeda, our number one foe. He has failed to outline a plan to end the war in Afghanistan and even said he would have left tens of thousands of troops in Iraq."

"We need a President who not only keeps us safe in the world, but also understands the need for steady leadership and keeping us out of endless wars. On these points, Mitt Romney has failed," said the Obama staffer. "This debate might not have as much impact as the first debate, largely because they've tested each other. It also might not just be about foreign policy, and it won't be just about Libya. They'll talk about Libya, China, and Russia."

According to a comprehensive Gallup study, only two debates between 1960 and 2004 moved the meter and quantifiably changed the direction of the polls and the outcome of the election. But this year's debates seem to be altering the electoral landscape.

Following the first debate two weeks ago, and a lackluster performance by Obama, Romney saw a sustained bounce in the polls, drawing him close to Obama or putting him ahead of the president nationally, according to a flurry of polls. The Obama campaign was bolstered today by fresh NBC News/Wall Street Journal/Marist polls that found Obama with healthy leads in two key swing states, holding a 51-43 lead over Romney in Iowa and a 51-45 lead in Wisconsin.

The debates matter in another way. President Obama had his best fundraising day ever following last week's debate in New York, according to the AP. The AP also crunched the numbers to reveal the biggest campaign contributors. Both candidates have big-name backers. Hollywood director Jeffrey Katzenberg, Obama's single biggest contributor, gave the campaign $2.5 million. And Sheldon Adelson, who has said he would be willing to give Romney $100 million, cashes in as his biggest supporter with a whopping $34.2 million.

Title: Hispanic Advocacy Group Questions Hillary Clinton's Immigration Stance Following 2007 License Cancellation Incident

Article:

At least one Hispanic advocacy group is questioning Hillary Rodham Clinton's commitment to their stance on immigration, following former New York Governor Eliot Spitzer's confession that he canceled driver's licenses for illegal immigrants in 2007 to support Clinton's presidential campaign.

In an interview with former Obama strategist David Axelrod, Mr. Spitzer revealed that the Clinton campaign had asked him to abandon the proposal to avoid complicating her 2008 presidential campaign, as she had struggled to answer whether she supported the policy during a debate.

Carlos Vargas, co-director of the Dream Action Coalition, a group of illegal immigrant "Dreamers," expressed disappointment, stating, "Dreamers and Latinos are truly disappointed that Hillary Clinton would throw the immigrant community under the bus, especially since she has criticized others for doing the same."

The group noted that Clinton's record is becoming increasingly suspect as she attempts to secure the Democratic presidential nomination once more. Hispanic-rights advocates have been dismayed as they've observed both parties experimenting with legalization and pro-immigrant bills, only to abandon them when the politics become too challenging.

The issue of licenses for illegal immigrants was a contentious political debate in 2007, arising just a few years after the September 11, 2001, hijackers used valid licenses to board the planes they turned into missiles, resulting in the deaths of nearly 3,000 Americans.

Clinton initially avoided taking a clear stance on the issue, appearing to support and oppose it at different times. Eventually, she announced that she would not support states issuing such licenses. However, in her current campaign, Clinton has stated that she would now support such licenses.

Clinton's two major opponents for the Democratic nomination argue they have been consistent on Hispanic-rights issues throughout their careers, taking stands even when they were unpopular. The specific details regarding the Clinton campaign's request to Mr. Spitzer and the implications of this incident are not available in the provided source text.

Title: Sanders Endorses Opponent of DNC Chairwoman, Criticizes DNC Process

Article:

In a move that escalates the ongoing tension between the Democratic National Committee (DNC) and the Bernie Sanders campaign, the Vermont Senator has endorsed the primary opponent of DNC Chairwoman Debbie Wasserman Schultz. In an interview set to air on CNN's "State of the Union," Sanders expressed his support for Tim Canova, a candidate running in Florida's 23rd congressional district.

Sanders stated, "Well, clearly, I favor her opponent. His views are much closer to mine than Debbie Wasserman Schultz's." Canova, who teaches at Nova Southeastern University Shepard Broad College of Law in Fort Lauderdale, was asked in 2011 to serve on Sanders' Wall Street reform advisory panel.

Canova, in response to Sanders' endorsement, accused Wasserman Schultz of ignoring her home district's economic issues. "In her own votes in the House of Representatives, I think she's making the problems worse," Canova told CNN's Fredricka Whitfield. He also expressed doubt that his political rival could heal intra-party rifts created during the primary.

Sanders sent out a fundraising email on behalf of Canova earlier in the day. The email stated, "The political revolution is not just about electing a president, sisters and brothers. We need a Congress with members who believe, like Bernie, that we can not change a corrupt system by taking its money."

In a response to Sanders, Wasserman Schultz insisted she would remain neutral in the Democratic presidential race despite the Vermont senator's endorsement of her primary opponent. "I am so proud to serve the people of Florida's 23rd district and I am confident that they know that I am an effective fighter and advocate on their behalf in Congress," Wasserman Schultz said. "Even though Senator Sanders has endorsed my opponent, I remain, as I have been from the beginning, neutral in the presidential Democratic primary. I look forward to working together with him for Democratic victories in the fall."

The Sanders campaign has long been critical of Wasserman Schultz's performance as head of the DNC, claiming that the DNC has favored Hillary Clinton, Sanders' presidential primary challenger. Sanders and his supporters have complained about the nomination process and ways they believe it has helped Clinton, including debates held on Saturday nights, closed primaries in major states such as New York, and the use of superdelegates—essentially free-agent party and union stalwarts who are overwhelmingly backing Clinton.

Canova has called for greater regulation of Wall Street, writing on his campaign website that "we are now in a new Gilded Age." Like Sanders, he also opposes the Trans-Pacific Partnership trade deal.

While Sanders has a strong ability to raise money and could impact the race, he did not fare well in Wasserman Schultz's congressional district during the March Florida presidential primary, scoring 30.1% of the vote compared with Clinton's 68%.

The ongoing feud between Sanders and Wasserman Schultz has been escalating, with Sanders' campaign manager, Jeff Weaver, slamming Wasserman Schultz after she criticized the behavior of Sanders' supporters at the party's raucous Nevada convention last week. Wasserman Schultz has pushed back against Sanders' accusation that the party had rigged the system against him.

Title: Nikki Haley Makes Humorous Remarks at Al Smith Dinner, Addresses Political Climate

Article:

In a humorous and light-hearted speech at the annual Al Smith dinner in New York City, outgoing U.S. Ambassador to the United Nations Nikki Haley made jabs at President Donald Trump, Kanye West, Attorney General Jeff Sessions, and other political figures. The event, now in its seventh-decade, is known for its speakers poking fun at political figures, including themselves.

Haley, a former governor of South Carolina, joked about her ethnicity and the recent DNA test results of Senator Elizabeth Warren, who claimed Native American heritage. "I get it. You wanted an Indian woman, but Elizabeth Warren failed her DNA test," Haley said. She also added, "When the President found out that I was Indian-American, he asked if I was from the same tribe as Elizabeth Warren."

Haley, a Republican, also made light of her unexpected decision to step down as U.N. ambassador, joking about a rumor that rapper Kanye West had been sworn in as her replacement. "Oh wait, that could really happen," she quipped.

In addition to her ethnicity and political career, Haley touched on the current state of U.S. politics, noting the "toxic political environment" that has led politicians to "describe their opponents as enemies or evil." She emphasized, "In America, our political opponents are not evil."

Haley also made humorous remarks about her personal experiences, such as feeling prepared for being a Republican in New York due to growing up in rural South Carolina, and joked about encountering Attorney General Jeff Sessions on LinkedIn.

The high-powered crowd at the dinner included Governor Andrew Cuomo, New York Mayor Bill de Blasio, former Secretary of State Henry Kissinger, CBS anchor Jeff Glor, and Wall Street financier Stephen Schwarzman. The event raised almost $4 million for Catholic children's charities this year. The dinner honors the late governor of New York and America's first Catholic presidential nominee, Alfred E. Smith.

Title: Vice President Mike Pence Criticizes CNN's Coverage of Border Facilities, Denounces Comparisons to Concentration Camps

Article:

Vice President Mike Pence visited migrant shelters in the McAllen, Texas, area on Friday and subsequently criticized CNN's coverage of his trip on Twitter, labeling the news network as "dishonest."

In a series of tweets, Pence stated, "CNN is so dishonest. Today we took reporters to a detention facility on the border for families and children and all told us they were being treated well."

The vice president's tweets followed CNN's reporting of a large group of crowded migrants, primarily men, who were shown shouting "no shower!" to cameras. During the prime-time show Anderson Cooper 360, Pence's interview with CNN senior White House correspondent Pamela Brown was aired, but the broadcast split the screen, only showing the sizable group of male migrants, while none of the footage of Pence visiting with children was shown, according to Fox News.

Pence also defended U.S. Customs and Border Protection (CBP) agents from the comparisons made by freshman Democrats likening holding centers to concentration camps during the interview with CNN. He asserted, "The Nazis killed people. Our Customs and Border Protection as you heard today are saving lives every day."

In addition, Pence emphasized that the crisis at the southern border is not a "manufactured crisis," but a real issue overwhelming the system. To illustrate this, he and his team also visited an overcrowded facility for adult men, many of whom had been arrested multiple times. These men were in a temporary holding area due to the refusal by Democrats in Congress to fund additional bed space.

Pence expressed disappointment that CNN did not broadcast the full story, focusing on the men in the temporary facility while ignoring the compassionate care being provided to families and children at other facilities. He concluded his tweets by stating, "Our great @CBP agents deserve better and the American people deserve the whole story from CNN!"

Title: Trump's Call for Investigation of Clinton's Email Scandal and Comparison to Executive Power Abuse

Article:

In the aftermath of the recent presidential debate, a heated exchange between Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton regarding Clinton's private email server and emails has sparked controversy and debate. Trump stated that if he wins the election, he would instruct the Attorney General to appoint a special prosecutor to investigate Clinton's situation, citing numerous lies and deception. Clinton responded by commenting that it is good that someone with Trump's "temperament" is not in charge of the law in the United States, and Trump retorted, "Because you'd be in jail."

This exchange has led to discussions about Trump's potential abuse of executive power and comparisons to a banana republic. However, the article argues that the focus on Trump's desire for Clinton's investigation overlooks the real anger over how Clinton seems to have been treated differently by the Department of Justice (DOJ) compared to "normal" Americans.

The article points out that Trump is not suggesting he can send Clinton to a prison cell, but rather that he will investigate her. Trump believes that an investigation will lead to her being held accountable for her actions. The article also notes that Clinton remains unconcerned about the potential seriousness of her private email server scandal.

The article also touches on the case of Jeffrey Hurant, the CEO of gay escort site Rentboy.com, who pleaded guilty to federal charges of promoting prostitution and forfeited $10 million in revenue. The article questions why there is more outrage about Trump wanting to have Clinton investigated by the DOJ than there is about the DOJ's treatment of Hurant and Rentboy.com.

The article also discusses Clinton's desire for a special prosecutor to examine trade deals between U.S. companies and other countries, and questions whether this prosecutor would target countries or American businesses who "take advantage" of sweet deals. The article also mentions Clinton's desire to name Supreme Court justices inclined to strike down the Citizens United decision, and the potential consequences of overturning this decision, including the criminalization of certain types of privately funded political speech.

The article concludes by reminding readers of the DOJ's targeting of speech that questions climate change science or goes after commenters who say unkind things about a drug war-promoting judge. The article suggests that the real outrage should be focused on the government's treatment of ordinary citizens, rather than Trump's call for an investigation of Clinton.

Title: Philadelphia Safe Injection Site Moves Forward Despite Federal Objections

Article:

A Philadelphia nonprofit's plan to open a safe injection site, named Safehouse, has been ruled not to violate federal drug laws by a judge, bringing the United States' first medically supervised heroin consumption facility one step closer to reality. The Justice Department had argued that the proposed site would violate the "crackhouse statute," a decades-old law. However, Judge Gerald Austin McHugh ruled on Wednesday that Safehouse aims to "reduce drug use, not facilitate it."

The Justice Department, in a statement by Deputy Attorney General Jeffrey Rosen, has announced its intention to pursue further judicial review. The department also stated that it would take immediate action against any attempts to open illicit drug injection sites in other jurisdictions while the case is pending.

The Justice Department sued Safehouse in February, around the time it identified a location in Philadelphia's Kensington neighborhood, home to one of the nation's largest open-air drug markets. U.S. Attorney William McSwain argued that Safehouse would be in violation of part of the Controlled Substances Act, passed in the 1980s, that makes it illegal to operate facilities for the purpose of drug use or distribution.

However, many cities and states are already in violation of the statute due to the legal marijuana boom and the proliferation of needle exchanges. Judge McHugh noted that there's no evidence that lawmakers considered safe injection sites when writing the statute, as they weren't popular then.

Safehouse would not supply the drugs. Instead, it would provide a place for people to inject intravenous opioids with clean syringes, with medical personnel standing by, ready to prevent an overdose. Participants could also access social services. This "harm reduction" strategy is favored by advocates and medical professionals, as it can help save the lives of people who aren't yet ready to get off drugs entirely.

The Trump administration has a different view. Last August, Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein argued in an op-ed for The New York Times that safe injection sites would destroy neighborhoods like Kensington. "Injection sites destroy the surrounding community," he wrote. "When drug users flock to a site, drug dealers follow, bringing with them violence and despair, posing a danger to neighbors and law-abiding visitors."

The Justice Department has used the "crackhouse statute" to try to block or delay proposed sites around the country. With the opioid crisis still raging, ten countries—including Canada, Australia, and Norway—have safe injection sites, and several American cities have publicly mulled them, including San Francisco, Seattle, and New York. However, these efforts—including a plan to authorize safe injection sites in California—have been chilled by warnings of legal action from the Trump administration.

"Philadelphia is being devastated. We've lost about three people a day," Ronda Goldfein, president of Safehouse, told NPR Wednesday. "And we say we had to do something better and we couldn't sit back and let that death toll rise. And the court agreed with us."

Title: DNC Hack and Antifa: A Look at Media Bias and Government Bureaucracy

Article:

The narratives surrounding the hack of the Democratic National Committee (DNC) emails and the Antifa movement have raised questions about media bias and government bureaucracy at their worst.

In 2016, U.S. intelligence agencies attributed the hack of DNC email accounts to Russia, leading to the publication of about 20,000 stolen emails on WikiLeaks. However, the finding was reportedly based largely on the DNC's strange outsourcing of the investigation to a private cybersecurity firm.

WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange has maintained that the Russians did not provide him with the DNC emails. When it was discovered that the emails had been compromised, then-DNC chairwoman Debbie Wasserman Schultz refused to allow forensic detectives from the FBI to examine the DNC server, prompting questions about the FBI's acceptance of this refusal.

During the 2016 election, former FBI Director James Comey was put into the role of prosecutor, judge, and jury in the investigation of Hillary Clinton's use of a private email server while she was secretary of state. This proved disastrous, with Comey admitting under oath to deliberately leaking his own notes to the media to prompt the appointment of a special counsel.

Comey's investigation of Clinton showed no prosecutable wrongdoing, a judgment that in normal times would not be the FBI's to make. It has since been disclosed that Comey offered this conclusion before he had even interviewed Clinton, suggesting ethical adjustments may have been made.

Comey was also less than truthful when he testified that there had been no internal FBI communications concerning the infamous meeting between Clinton's husband, former president Bill Clinton, and then-attorney general Loretta Lynch on an airport tarmac. In fact, there was a trail of FBI discussion about that supposedly secret rendezvous.

Before he was fired, President Donald Trump drafted a letter outlining his anger, but it seemed to have little to do with obstruction of justice. Instead, Trump's anguished letter complained about Comey's private assurances that the president was not under FBI investigation, which were offered at about the same time Comey would not confirm that reality to the press.

The media has also faced criticism for its portrayal of the Antifa movement. Antifa rioters in Charlottesville were praised by progressives for violently confronting a few dozen white supremacists, Klansmen, and neo-Nazis. The supremacists were pathetic losers without any public or political support for their odious views, and they were condemned by both political parties. Yet Antifa's use of violence was compared perversely by some progressives to American soldiers storming the beaches on D-Day.

Later, Antifa thuggery in Boston and Berkeley against free speech and against conservative groups without ties to white supremacists confirmed that the movement was fascistic in nature. It was recently disclosed that the FBI and the Department of Homeland Security had warned the Obama administration in 2016 that Antifa was a domestic terrorist organization that aimed to incite violence during street protests. That stark assessment and Antifa's subsequent violence make the recent nonchalance of local police departments with regard to Antifa thuggery seem like an abject dereliction of duty.

Doubts about the official narratives of the DNC leaks and the errant behavior of James Comey, and misinformation about the violent extremists of Antifa, illustrate media bias—not to mention entrenched government bureaucracies that are either incompetent, ethically compromised, or completely politicized.

Title: Secret Service Agents Under Investigation for Alleged Impairment During White House Incident

Article:

Two Secret Service agents, Marc Connolly and George Ogilvie, are under investigation for alleged impairment while on duty, according to a report released by the Department of Homeland Security inspector general on Thursday. The incident occurred on March 4, when the agents, who had spent five hours at an Irish bar and restaurant less than a mile from the White House, allegedly drove into the scene of an unattended package investigation.

The report states that Connolly, the deputy special agent in charge of the president's protective detail, and Ogilvie, an agent, were probably "impaired by alcohol." The inspector general, John Roth, released the report before testifying at a hearing by the House Oversight and Government Reform Committee.

The report details that Ogilvie bought 14 drinks in three hours at the bar. He told investigators he consumed fewer than three drinks all night, and Connolly said he had just two beers. Two other Secret Service employees said they consumed three drinks that Ogilvie bought, and he told investigators he gave away the rest but couldn't remember to whom.

Upon arriving at the White House, Ogilvie drove his government-issued SUV past barriers that other agents had erected around the package they were investigating. His car passed "within inches" of the package, the report said. One officer on the scene, who has more than 25 years of experience, told investigators "he had never seen anything like this."

The report also mentions that the incident is part of a series of embarrassments for the Secret Service, whose main job is to protect the U.S. president. The inspector general's office is investigating two more Secret Service incidents in March alone.

In one case, agents may have used agency computers to access the job application of Jason Chaffetz, now the U.S. House member who leads the committee with oversight responsibility for the service. In the other, a senior manager allegedly sexually assaulted a female subordinate after another farewell bash that involved drinking.

Representatives Chaffetz and Elijah Cummings, the top Democrat on the oversight panel, released a joint statement on Thursday, stating that the report's findings point to the need for a "major cultural overhaul" within the Secret Service.

Secret Service Director Joseph Clancy said in a statement, "Behavior of the type described in the report is unacceptable and will not be tolerated." Connolly and Ogilvie have been placed on administrative leave, and the Secret Service's Office of Integrity has requested "supporting information" behind the inspector general's report. Once that information is reviewed, the service will propose disciplinary actions that the two agents can contest.

Connolly has notified the Secret Service that he plans to retire, according to a government official who asked not to be identified.

Title: Foreign Companies Warn of Intellectual Property Concerns in China as Chinese Industries Grow

Article:

Foreign companies have expressed concerns about the potential theft of intellectual property and pressure tactics used by Chinese partners and officials in various industries, particularly in renewable energy sectors such as wind turbines and solar panels.

Business groups representing these companies claim that Chinese companies leverage corporate ties to coerce foreign partners into disclosing sensitive information. They also allege that Chinese officials have demanded access to technology as part of a review process to ensure product safety for Chinese consumers.

Renewable energy, specifically wind turbines, is one area where China has employed these tactics to foster domestic industries. In 2005, Beijing mandated that 70% of each wind turbine installed in China must be domestically manufactured. Spanish wind turbine leader, Gamesa, trained over 500 Chinese suppliers to manufacture components for its turbines and set up a plant in Tianjin to assemble them. Other multinational wind turbine manufacturers followed suit.

The Obama administration questioned this policy as a violation of World Trade Organization rules, but by then, Chinese state-controlled enterprises had already begun assembling turbines using the same suppliers. China is now the world's largest market for wind turbines, and they are predominantly produced by Chinese companies.

A similar industrial evolution occurred in solar energy soon after. China required that its first big municipal solar project only use solar panels that were at least 80% made in China. Companies rushed to produce in China and share technology. The Chinese government also heavily subsidized the manufacture of solar panels, primarily for export. Chinese companies ended up producing most of the world's solar panels.

Some within the Trump administration fear a similar situation may arise in the automotive industry. Shortly after opening China to foreign auto companies, Chinese officials held a competition among global automakers to determine which would be allowed to enter the market. The competition included a detailed review of each company's offer to transfer technology to a joint venture with a Chinese state-owned partner.

Title: FCC Balances Net Neutrality Demands with Cautious Approach Amidst Presidential Pressure

Article:

The Federal Communications Commission (FCC) is grappling with the delicate issue of net neutrality, as Chairman Tom Wheeler considers a hybrid approach that would regulate the relationships between content companies and Internet service providers, while leaving the consumer side largely untouched. This stance took a turn on Monday, as President Obama strongly endorsed full net neutrality, urging the FCC to reclassify wired and wireless broadband Internet as a "common carrier" service subject to strict government oversight.

Although the FCC operates independently, it remains unclear how the Commission will reconcile the President's strong net neutrality stance with the more cautious plans it has been exploring for several months. In response, Wheeler released a statement on Monday, outlining areas of agreement and disagreement with the President's position.

Both the President and the FCC agree on the importance of an open Internet platform, where no players are favored over others, and Internet companies should not be able to block content or degrade its delivery. However, the FCC appears less enthusiastic about reclassifying Internet providers as "common carriers." This classification would grant the government the power to ensure that companies such as Comcast and Verizon treat all traffic that flows across their networks equally.

Industry groups argue that common-carrier reclassification could stifle innovation, as government regulation might choke out the entrepreneurial spirit that led to the growth of the Internet in the first place. In his statement, Wheeler acknowledged that common-carrier reclassification "brings with it policy issues that run the gamut from privacy to universal service to the ability of federal agencies to protect consumers."

The FCC is also keen on ensuring its case for rule changes is legally sound, following the D.C. Circuit Court's January decision to strike down its 2010 Open Internet Rules due to insufficient authority to impose the demands. Reclassifying broadband providers as common carriers would help establish the FCC's authority, but the Commission would need to prove that this change will benefit consumers and the Internet as a whole.

Wheeler emphasized the need for more time to examine the potential approaches and ensure that any changes can withstand legal challenges. The FCC aims to make a case that the chosen approach will benefit consumers and the Internet as a whole, as it navigates the complex and sensitive issue of net neutrality in the face of presidential pressure.

Title: G7 Foreign Ministers Coordinate Response to Syria Crisis, Aim to Pressure Russia

Article:

Secretary of State Rex Tillerson, along with six other Group of Seven (G7) foreign ministers, is seeking to deliver a "clear and coordinated message" to Russia in response to the U.S.'s actions following a chemical weapons attack in Syria that left numerous casualties. The G7 foreign ministers aim to persuade Russia to cease its support for Syrian President Bashar al-Assad after a tumultuous week that included the nerve gas attack and the U.S.'s airstrikes on a Syrian airbase.

The U.S. received broad support from Europe following the airstrikes. Italian Foreign Minister Angelino Alfano, who is hosting the meeting, stated that the missile strike contributed to a "renewed harmony" between the U.S. and its partners ahead of the first meeting of G7 foreign ministers since President Trump took office.

"We need to remember that not 10 years ago, but 100 or 120 days ago, the concern in Europe was that the United States and the EU were moving apart," Alfano told Sky TG24 Sunday. "I welcome this renewed harmony."

With relations between the U.S. and Europe seemingly improving, there has been no indication that President Vladimir Putin is planning to change his stance on the Assad regime in Syria. Russia and Iran issued a joint statement on Sunday, stating that they would "respond to any aggression" in response to the airstrikes in Syria.

"What America waged in an aggression on Syria is a crossing of red lines," the countries said, according to The Sun. "From now on, we will respond with force to any aggressor or any breach of red lines from whoever it is, and America knows our ability to respond well."

H.R. McMaster, President Trump's national security adviser, stated in an interview on "Fox News Sunday" that Russia should reconsider its support for Assad. McMaster added that Russia will have to decide whether it wants to continue backing a "murderous regime" as Trump weighs the next steps against Syria.

Tillerson is expected to meet with Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov after the G7 meeting. The exact details of the meeting and the discussions that will take place are currently unavailable.

Title: U.S. Elections and Their Impact on Foreign Policy: A Neutral Analysis

Article:

The upcoming U.S. elections are raising questions about the potential impact on foreign policy, as the two major candidates, Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton, present distinct yet similar perspectives from an international standpoint.

In domestic terms, there is a significant difference between the two candidates, with Donald Trump being associated with white nationalist sentiments, as reported in various news outlets. However, from a global perspective, the differences between the two are minimal.

Trump, who has been unpredictable in his campaign, could lead a party that has shown a willingness to consider extreme measures, such as Ted Cruz's proposal to bomb Syria. The possibility of the Republican Party, under Trump's leadership, taking charge raises concerns about the potential consequences.

On the other hand, Hillary Clinton, who has advocated for U.S. intervention in the past, such as her role in pushing President Obama to enter the Libyan operation, is perceived as having a tendency to initiate overseas wars. This tendency, according to some analysts, suggests a potentially dangerous approach to foreign policy.

Therefore, from an external viewpoint, there is a valid reason to be concerned about the foreign policy decisions of either candidate, as both have shown a propensity for interventionist policies. As Medea Benjamin, an American political activist, stated in an interview, whichever candidate wins the presidency, a hawkish approach to foreign policy is likely to prevail in the White House.

Title: GOP Candidates Face Criticism Over Minimum Wage Stances

Article:

In the ongoing debate over the federal minimum wage, Democrats have been pressing Republican candidates and officeholders to take clear positions on the issue this year. Most Republicans have expressed opposition to raising the federal minimum wage above its current level of $7.25 per hour.

Recent surveys indicate that a majority of voters support increasing the federal minimum wage. However, in a speech before the U.S. Chamber of Commerce, New Jersey Governor Chris Christie expressed opposition to raising the minimum wage, stating, "I'm tired of hearing about the minimum wage... I don't think there's a mother or a father sitting around the kitchen table tonight in America saying, ‘You know, honey, if our son or daughter could just make a higher minimum wage, my God, all of our dreams would be realized.'"

Critics argue that Christie's statement overlooks the fact that many workers are forced to take minimum wage jobs due to a dismal labor market. While Christie's argument is that most parents aspire to more for their children, the socially stratified nature of America with limited upward mobility suggests a need for measures to redistribute wealth and opportunity and invest in disadvantaged communities through increased education funding, public works projects, and the like.

Wisconsin Governor Scott Walker also faces criticism for his stance on the minimum wage. Earlier this month, Walker's administration rebuffed a workers' coalition's effort to raise the state's minimum wage in accordance with a state law that calls for the minimum to be a "living wage." The administration responded to their effort by asserting that $7.25 an hour is a living wage, despite MIT calculations indicating that a single parent would need to earn $21.17 an hour to make a living wage in the state capital of Madison.

Walker also stated last week that the minimum wage does not "serve a purpose," and he prefers to help Wisconsinites secure higher-paying jobs rather than raise the minimum wage. However, it is estimated that 500,000 workers in the state would see a raise if the minimum wage went from $7.25 to $10.10 an hour.

The Republican Party's approach to the minimum wage has been criticized for its perceived lack of sensitivity and disregard for basic facts. It is argued that minimum wage hikes do not lead to job losses and that most minimum wage earners are not high school students who just need a "starter wage." However, the GOP's stance on the minimum wage remains largely opposed to raising it above the current federal minimum wage of $7.25 per hour.

Title: President Trump Accuses Democrats of Meddling in Midterm Elections over Russia Investigation

Article:

President Donald Trump accused Democrats on Tuesday of meddling in the upcoming midterm elections by continuing the investigation into Russian interference in the 2016 presidential election. In a series of tweets, the President referred to the 13 investigators working on the special counsel's investigation as "The 13 Angry Democrats (plus people who worked 8 years for Obama)" and claimed they are "meddling" with the midterm elections.

"The 13 Angry Democrats (plus people who worked 8 years for Obama) working on the rigged Russia Witch Hunt, will be MEDDLING with the mid-term elections, especially now that Republicans (stay tough!) are taking the lead in Polls. There was no Collusion, except by the Democrats!" Mr. Trump tweeted.

The President also criticized the Democrats for not investigating Hillary Clinton's campaign, stating, "Why aren't the 13 Angry and heavily conflicted Democrats investigating the totally Crooked Campaign of totally Crooked Hillary Clinton. It's a Rigged Witch Hunt, that's why! Ask them if they enjoyed her after election celebration!"

The special counsel's investigation, which has been underway for just over a year, remains ongoing, and it is unclear when it may conclude. In another tweet, the President expressed his desire to focus his energy on other issues, such as North Korea's nuclear program, trade deals, the Veterans Affairs Choice program, the economy, rebuilding the military, and other matters.

"Sorry, I've got to start focusing my energy on North Korea Nuclear, bad Trade Deals, VA Choice, the Economy, rebuilding the Military, and so much more, and not on the Rigged Russia Witch Hunt that should be investigating Clinton/Russia/FBI/Justice/Obama/Comey/Lynch etc." he tweeted.

Title: Pew Report Reveals Political Polarization in American Attitudes Toward Climate and Energy Issues

Article:

A new report released by the Pew Research Center on Wednesday indicates a significant political polarization in American attitudes toward climate and energy issues. The report, which surveyed 2,002 adults in 2014, found that global warming is one of the issues most sharply divided across party lines, along with other climate and energy issues such as offshore drilling, fracking, and nuclear power.

The report reveals that only 27% of Republicans believe the Earth is warming due to human activity, while 71% of Democrats hold this belief. This trend of political polarization has been developing over the past two decades, with attitudes toward climate and energy issues continuing to diverge despite the science behind these issues remaining consistent.

The report found that party identification was more likely to determine a respondent's stance on these issues than even their level of education or scientific knowledge. However, respondents with a greater understanding of science proved less afraid of scientific advancements and futuristic-sounding technologies. They were more likely to support using animals in scientific research, approve of expanding nuclear power, and consider genetically modified foods safe to eat. They were "especially likely" to approve using bioengineered organs for human transplant.

Politics was not the only factor at play in other science-based issues, such as the safety of eating GMO foods, space travel, animal research, and biomedicine. Respondents were far less likely to have their views determined solely by their political leanings in these cases. Interestingly, in the case of evolution, religion played a central role in determining people's stances. However, those same respondents didn't necessarily use religion to determine their stances on other scientific topics.

The report also revealed a surprising correlation between political parties and government spending on scientific research. The majority of both parties—83% of Democrats and 62% of Republicans—said government investment in scientific research paid off in the long run. This finding suggests a bipartisan agreement on the importance of government investment in scientific research.

Title: Washington Post Places Story on Kavanaugh Coaching Basketball in "Public Safety" Category, Sparks Controversy

The Washington Post published a story on Supreme Court Justice Brett Kavanaugh returning to coach his daughter's basketball team, which was placed under the "public safety" category, sparking controversy among conservatives. The story, which was published over the Thanksgiving holiday weekend, was written by an author who has previously covered Kavanaugh and was automatically defaulted to the public safety category, according to a spokesperson for The Washington Post.

The story, which was not categorized as "local," can still be found on a page cataloging the Post's public safety stories. The placement of the story above a story about a 6-year-old child struck by a bus in Charles County, Md., was criticized by National Republican Senatorial Committee member Logan Dobson, who questioned its placement.

Several Twitter users, including Ashe Schow, Chuck Callesto, Just Jeff, The Daily Wire, and Ellen L. Carmichael, expressed their disapproval of the story's categorization, with some calling it "gutter journalism" and "biased."

Brett Kavanaugh, 53, was confirmed by the Senate mostly along party lines, 51-49, on Oct. 5. Sen. Joe Manchin (D-W.Va.) was the only Democrat to vote to confirm Kavanaugh.

Title: Tom Steyer's $100 Million Climate Change Campaign Targets Key 2016 Races

Article:

California billionaire Tom Steyer has announced plans to spend $100 million on the 2014 midterm elections to make climate change a prominent issue in this year's elections. However, sources familiar with Steyer's plan revealed that he might be willing to invest more than the initial $100 million, with a focus on key battleground states for the 2016 presidential race.

Steyer's strategy involves targeting Senate or gubernatorial contests in Iowa, New Hampshire, Florida, and possibly Pennsylvania. The strategy could position Steyer as a counterweight to big conservative donors like Charles and David Koch. However, the extent to which $100 million will impact the post-Citizens United political landscape, or whether climate change can compete with issues like jobs and the Affordable Care Act on the presidential campaign trail, remains unclear.

Steyer's operation, through his NextGen Climate Action super PAC, aims to influence the debate about climate change in Senate races in Iowa and New Hampshire and the gubernatorial contest in Florida. He may also invest in the governor's race in Pennsylvania, where former Bill Clinton environmental aide Katie McGinty is running against Republican incumbent Tom Corbett.

In addition to the 2016 focus, Steyer's strategy includes targeting states where a candidate who supports action on climate change faces an opponent who denies climate change. This description aligns with the governor's race in Florida and the Senate race in Iowa.

While Republican Governor Rick Scott of Florida has stated that science has not proven that humans are causing climate change, Democratic former Governor Charlie Crist, a potential challenger, has been a vocal critic of the 2010 Gulf of Mexico oil spill and held annual conferences on global warming during his tenure as governor. Scott is reportedly planning to spend up to $100 million for his reelection effort, potentially matching Steyer's entire nationwide campaign.

Florida is a significant example for climate advocates of how sea-level rise can threaten communities. Steyer also plans to target states that are crucial for determining whether Democrats can maintain control of the Senate in 2014, such as Iowa and New Hampshire. Furthermore, he aims to sway governor's races in states where the winner could take action on climate change without waiting for Washington. This could suggest involvement in Pennsylvania to support Katie McGinty or other Democratic gubernatorial candidates.

During a gathering of wealthy climate donors at Steyer's ranch in February, Steyer and his PAC's chief strategist, Chris Lehane, outlined the approach. The event included a briefing on potential climate change effects from Columbia University climate researcher James Hansen, as well as fellow billionaires and some of Steyer's oldest friends from the financial community.

The New York Times previously reported that Steyer aims to spend about $50 million of his own money and raise another $50 million from green-minded donors for the 2014 elections. NextGen officials confirmed these figures but emphasized that $100 million is not the ceiling for what Steyer's PAC may spend this year.

Title: Report Suggests Midlevel Bureaucrats, Not Congress, Initiated $4.2 Billion in Tax Credits to Illegal Immigrants

Article:

A new study by the Center for Immigration Studies, set to be released on Monday, claims that the federal government distributed approximately $4.2 billion in tax credits to illegal immigrants in 2010, a decision that was allegedly made by midlevel bureaucrats and has not received full congressional scrutiny. The report, authored by CIS fellow David North, alleges that the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) issued these funds through the "additional child tax credit" (ACTC) to individuals using an individual taxpayer identification number (ITIN), a common indicator of an illegal immigrant.

The study suggests that the issue has been known for some time, but Mr. North delved into the data to examine the reasons behind this occurrence, stating that the tax credit expanded beyond its initial scope, and midlevel IRS managers manipulated the law, resulting in billions of dollars being paid to illegal immigrants.

According to Mr. North, there is no evidence that the decision to allow illegal immigrants to collect the tax credit was made by top leaders at the IRS, and he asserts that it was not the intent of Congress. "I've been in government, and I know how these things work out. It struck me that [GS-] 15s, 16s, got together at some point and decided this is how we should handle it, and it stuck," Mr. North said.

During the government shutdown, which began on Oct. 1, the IRS was unavailable for comment. In the past, the agency has maintained that it does not have the legal authority to deny illegal immigrants the tax credit and also disputes that it has the legal authority to deny claims without documentation showing that the children actually reside in the U.S.

The ACTC was created to assist those who earn too little to qualify for the full child tax credit. The ACTC is refundable, meaning that even if the taxpayer does not owe income tax, they could still receive a payout from the IRS. This setup, combined with the use of the tax credit by illegal immigrant workers, has led to an increase in fraud, particularly since the number of filers using ITINs has risen from 796,000 in 2005 to 1.5 million in 2008 and 2.3 million in 2010, according to the IRS's official auditor.

The IRS has attempted to limit the issuance of ITINs in an effort to reduce fraudulent tax credit payouts. The numbers are now valid for only five years, and a stricter review of identity documents is required. However, abuses still persist for existing ITINs, Mr. North argues.

Investigators identified one address in Atlanta where 23,994 ITIN-related tax refunds were sent, including 8,393 refunds deposited to a single bank account. Mr. North considered these strong indications of fraud. He also suggested that the IRS should look for cases where an ITIN filer goes from claiming no dependents to claiming four or five dependents the next year.

Mr. North used an auditor's report to identify a town in Delaware and another on Virginia's Eastern Shore with large concentrations of ITIN filers. Frankford, Del., had one address where 627 ITINs were registered, despite the town having a population of just 862. Parksley, Va., had a single address with 100 ITINs registered, in a town of 847 residents. Mr. North visited both towns and found that while Frankford seemed oblivious to the situation, Parksley was different. One tax counselor in town told him she suspected a rival business was responsible for the ITIN applications.

Title: White House and Congressional Leaders Disagree on Impact and Necessity of Federal Spending Cuts

Article:

The White House and Congressional leaders are at odds over the impact of the $85 billion in federal spending cuts, which are now in their second week. Gene Sperling, the White House's top economic adviser, stated on NBC's "Meet the Press" that the cuts will not have a significant immediate impact but will have a "slow grind" effect over the long term.

In contrast, President Obama and his Cabinet have repeatedly warned that the cuts will result in furloughs or pay cuts for middle-class wage-earners such as teachers, Capitol Hill janitors, and air traffic controllers, potentially causing 90-minute delays at major U.S. airports.

Sperling declined to directly address whether the worst-case-scenario rhetoric has hurt the president's credibility on the issue. Instead, he emphasized independent economists' forecasts that the cuts will result in 750,000 fewer jobs and slower economic growth.

Senate Republican Leader Mitch McConnell told CNN's "State of the Union" that the cuts are similar to the average American's pay decrease when the payroll tax holiday expired. The Kentucky Republican argued that the cuts, known as sequester, are a "modest reduction of 2.4 percent in spending over the next six months."

Congress agreed to the sequester in 2011 after failing to agree on more specific reductions to defense and some domestic spending. The cuts were intended to be so drastic that Democrats and Republicans would be forced to compromise before they started.

Sperling rejected several Republican-backed plans and stated that no compromise would be reached unless the party agrees to tax increases. Sen. Kelly Ayotte, R-N.H., responded by stating that Congress agreed to such increases in January "at the president's request" and questioned why Obama and other Democrats will not agree to additional spending cuts.

Ayotte argued for potential pay freezes for federal employees and reforms to the federal food stamps program. However, she also stated she would consider tax reform that comes with entitlement reforms but would not agree to revenue increases to pay for additional government spending.

Earlier on the show, Sperling said the Republican strategy is flawed because the cuts will take resources from several of the party's most valued positions, including national defense and border security. Sperling hinted at Democrats' likely strategy for retaking the House in 2014, stating, "Our hope is as more Republicans start to see this pain in their own districts, they will choose bipartisan compromise over this absolutist position."

Sperling also dismissed a plan backed by at least some Republicans to give the president some flexibility in the cuts. He compared it to saying, "You have to cut off three of your fingers but you can choose which ones."

Sperling also addressed an email sent to Bob Woodward in which he said The Washington Post reporter might "regret" writing a story that said Obama has "moved the goal posts" on sequester. He told ABC that he and Woodward share a mutual respect and he hopes they can "put this behind us."

Sen. Lindsey Graham, R-S.C., told CBS' "Face the Nation" that any tax increases were unacceptable. "I'm not going to do any more small deals," he said. "I'm not going to raise taxes to fix sequestration. We don't need to raise taxes to fund the government."

All of this comes ahead of a new, March 27 deadline that could spell a government shutdown and a debt-ceiling clash coming in May. House Speaker John Boehner said his chamber would move this week to pass a measure to keep government open through Sept. 30. McConnell stated a government shutdown was unlikely to come from his side of Capitol Hill. The White House said it would dodge the shutdown and roll back the cuts, which hit domestic and defense spending in equal share.

Sperling said the White House is committed to trying to find a way that Republicans and Democrats can reach a compromise. The billions in cuts apply to the remainder of fiscal 2013, which ends Sept. 30. But without a deal, they will continue slashing government spending by about $1 trillion more over a 10-year period.

Title: Global Economic Downturn Affects U.S. Job Market, Causes Concern Among Economists

Article:

The U.S. job market experienced a setback in May, with the addition of only 69,000 jobs, according to a report released on Friday. This news, coupled with the ongoing debt crisis in Europe and slowing growth in China and India, has caused global financial markets to falter. The Dow Jones industrial average lost 2.22 percent, or 274.88 points, erasing its gains for the year, and the main index of the German stock market closed down 3.4 percent.

Yields on U.S. and German government bonds dropped as investors sought safety, with the 10-year Treasury yield falling to another record low of 1.46 percent, and the German two-year bond falling below zero. The report has led to increased uncertainty, with manufacturers expressing concern about Europe's economic situation and its potential impact on global growth.

Ellen Zentner, the senior United States economist for Nomura, a financial services firm, stated, "Manufacturers are very concerned about Europe because a blowup in Europe means a global slowdown." She added, "It hasn't translated into layoffs—businesses are just hiring less."

Charles Ingram, vice president for marketing and sales at Eriez Magnetics, which produces industrial equipment, said the company was still hiring and still getting orders, but was closely monitoring the situation. "We're very diverse, so if one or two industrial markets are down, we're O.K.," he said. "But if there's a general recession, that would be a real problem, and that's certainly a possibility."

The jobs report showed gains in health care, transportation and warehousing, and wholesale trade, while construction jobs fell by a seasonally adjusted 28,000. Even some bright spots, like booming auto sales, failed to meet expectations or to bolster manufacturing employment by much—only 12,000 jobs.

Government job reductions also contributed to the slowdown, driven by cutbacks at the local level. Patrick J. O' Keefe, the director of economic research at J. H. Cohn, a consulting firm, said, "It appears to me now that that was a premature call [that the labor market had achieved escape velocity]."

The Federal Reserve could potentially step up its stimulus campaign in response to the slowdown. Several members of the Fed's policy-making committee have recently stated that they were not inclined to change current policy, but that position has always been contingent on continued growth. The economy needs to grow by about 125,000 jobs each month just to maintain the current unemployment rate.

Fears of a global slowdown were also evident in other economic data released on Friday. Cooling exports dampened the nation's major manufacturing index, though it remained in positive territory. This news came on the heels of several worrisome reports, including falling consumer confidence, an uptick in new claims for unemployment benefits, and a downward revision of the country's overall economic growth in the first quarter, to a 1.9 percent annual rate from 2.2 percent.

The jobs report is based on two surveys, one of businesses and the other of households. The household survey showed a net gain of 422,000 in the number of people employed, and also an uptick in the percentage of the working-age population who have jobs. However, David Rosenberg, the chief economist with Gluskin Sheff, an investment firm, said much of that gain was in part-time work, while the number of full-time workers fell.

Some analysts said it was too soon to declare a significant slowdown. The recovery's roller-coaster trajectory may be largely illusory, the product of seasonal adjustment distortions and, this year, the unusually warm winter. Many economists say the weather effect, which caused some growth to occur earlier in the year than it otherwise would have, should be over by now. However, historically, May is the month that is most reduced after a warm winter. Seasonal adjustments were also making the winter look better than it was and the spring look worse.

The number of long-term unemployed, those who have been looking for work for more than half a year, rose by 300,000, even as hundreds of thousands of jobless workers lost their unemployment checks because of cutbacks. The long-term unemployed have the most difficulty finding jobs, and many of them say they have not seen any improvement in the job market.

Glen Barry of Carmel, N.Y., who worked for the government at the county level for 25 years as a computer operator and was laid off in December 2010, said, "Nobody has lists and lists of hundreds of available jobs. A lot of people work a job and a half now. Instead of having four people doing the work, they have two people doing the work."

Title: Trump Announces Continuation of White House Coronavirus Task Force, Shift in Focus

Article:

President Donald Trump announced on Wednesday that the White House Coronavirus Task Force, established in January to coordinate the response to the virus, will continue indefinitely and will shift its focus to reopening the nation and manufacturing vaccines. The announcement came a day after Vice President Mike Pence and other officials stated that the group's work would be transferred to federal agencies as soon as this month.

Trump's latest thinking on the task force drew mixed reactions, with some critics arguing it was too soon to disband the group. However, the president left the composition of the task force and its focus somewhat unclear. Trump suggested that he may remove some members and add others, but did not specify who he had in mind. He stated that the group would focus more on "safety" and reopening the economy, as well as vaccine production.

Speaking during a trip to Arizona on Tuesday, Trump seemed to link a decision to disband the group with his broader desire to reopen the nation and recharge its economy. He suggested that winding down the group signaled a new phase in the government's response to the virus.

"I'm viewing our great citizens of this country to a certain extent and to a large extent as warriors," Trump said when asked about the task force. "Will some people be affected, badly? Yes. But we have to get our country open."

Democrats and other critics blasted Trump's plan to reduce the scope of the task force on Tuesday, especially given the threat that death tolls would rise as states reopen businesses and other parts of their economies. The virus has killed more than 70,000 Americans, according to Johns Hopkins University.

Meanwhile, the number of new daily cases has slowed but remains high. "President Trump waves the white flag of surrender and winds down his ‘ task force,'" said Rep. Lloyd Doggett, D-Texas, chairman of the House Ways and Means Health Subcommittee. "As the death toll soars, it is the task force that gets buried."

Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders, the former Democratic presidential candidate, slammed the decision as a "true American tragedy" and predicted that "thousands will unnecessarily die" because of Trump's "contempt for science."

In other news, Supreme Court Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg was hospitalized for a gallbladder condition and infection. The details of her condition and prognosis are not yet available.

Title: Centrist Libertarian Ticket Gains Traction Among Moderate Republicans

Article:

Sen. Susan Collins of Maine has joined Mitt Romney and Jeb Bush in considering a vote for the Libertarian ticket, led by former New Mexico Governor Gary Johnson and former Massachusetts Governor Bill Weld. This development marks a shift in the political landscape, as the Libertarian ticket, traditionally associated with the rightmost precincts, is gaining traction among moderate Republicans.

The Johnson-Weld campaign has been emphasizing moderation, positioning itself as the "sane" and "responsible" choice, and focusing on problem-solving rather than fear and anger. This approach has resonated with voters in the center, with the Libertarian ticket drawing 8-10 percent in national polls.

The shift in the Libertarian Party's positioning is noteworthy, as it is seldom associated with moderation in U.S. politics. The party is often perceived as a balance wheel against the politics of factional revenge, upholding rights for all and a strong rule of law. In Europe, liberal parties, often seen as the nearest analogue of libertarian, are often perceived as occupying centrist or middle positions between labor or revolutionary parties on the left and blood-and-soil or religious parties on the right.

The emergence of the Libertarian ticket as a moderate force in the U.S. political landscape may not guarantee success as an independent force, given the country's first-past-the-post system. The German Free Democrats, despite an illustrious history, have come on hard times and are now shut out of representation in the Bundestag. Parties with similar traditions have struggled in Sweden, Italy, the United Kingdom, and elsewhere, though they form governments in several other European countries either alone or as part of coalitions.

The development of the Libertarian ticket as a moderate force may have a significant impact on the political landscape, particularly after the November elections. The wider significance may come in how libertarian ideas are regarded by others and in how libertarians regard themselves. The shift in the Libertarian Party's positioning may signal a broader realignment in U.S. politics, with libertarian ideas potentially playing a more significant role in the center of the political spectrum.

Title: U.S. Job Growth Slows, Unemployment Rate Drops, and Wage Growth Remains Modest

Article:

The pace of hiring in the United States is beginning to slow, according to a report released recently. After the longest stretch of uninterrupted job growth on record, many economists anticipate a decrease in the rate of hiring as employers face increasing difficulties in finding new workers. The U.S. economy added 164,000 jobs in April, compared to a monthly average of 191,000 additions over the past year.

The unemployment rate has also decreased, falling to 3.9% in April after remaining at 4.1% for six consecutive months. The decline was partly due to a decrease in the labor force participation rate, a statistic that some economists interpret as a potential sign of decreasing job optimism among the population. However, economists expect the unemployment rate to continue declining in the coming months, with the Federal Reserve forecasting a 3.6% rate for next year.

Wage growth, despite the tightening labor market, remains sluggish. Wages rose 2.6% from a year earlier in April, extending a period of slow growth that has puzzled many policymakers and investors. Although some companies have reported labor shortages and increased hiring costs, this has not yet had a significant impact on overall wage inflation.

The Federal Reserve's monetary policy is unlikely to be significantly affected by these trends, as the report shows the same broad economic trends persist: the economy is generally strong, but inflation does not appear to be escalating out of control. This allows the central bank to raise interest rates next month, as well as consider one or two more increases later in the year, according to economists. Investors see a slightly lower chance of at least four rate increases this year, but the probability remains above where it was a few months ago.

Interpreting market reactions to jobs reports has become increasingly challenging, as the economy enters the later stages of its cycle. The Wall Street Journal Dollar Index, a measure of the U.S. currency's strength, jumped immediately after the jobs report, typically a sign of a strong report. However, benchmark Treasury yields were down, suggesting some investors see weakness in the numbers. This phenomenon has been observed in recent jobs reports, partly because it is becoming more difficult to interpret the numbers as the economy matures.

Title: Bernie Sanders Proposes Expansion of Estate Tax, Countering Senate Republicans' Elimination Efforts

Article:

Bernie Sanders, the Vermont senator and potential 2020 presidential candidate, has unveiled a proposal to significantly expand the estate tax, a levy that has diminished over the years. Simultaneously, Senate Republicans are working to abolish the estate tax entirely.

Sanders' new proposal, titled the "For the 99.8 Percent Act," would leave the majority of estates untaxed while implementing a graduated rate structure for the estates of the extremely wealthy, peaking at a maximum rate of 77 percent. This policy would, in essence, mirror Sen. Elizabeth Warren's wealth tax proposal, although the specific implementation details differ.

Both senators aim to generate revenue from the wealthiest Americans and deter the accumulation of vast dynastic wealth. Their plans share a common goal, yet they pursue different routes. The US tax law previously allowed rich individuals to pass down $5.5 million untaxed to their heirs, but the 2017 Trump tax bill doubled that exemption to $11 million. Earlier this week, Senate Republicans introduced legislation to eliminate the estate tax entirely, allowing billions to pass tax-free from today's rich individuals to their children.

Sanders' 2016 campaign proposed a lower top rate for a similar plan. In the new proposal, Sanders suggests a multi-tiered structure for taxing the largest estates, including:

* A 55 percent bracket on wealth from $50 million to $1 billion
* A 50 percent bracket from $10 million to $50 million
* A 45 percent bracket from $3.5 million to $10 million

The majority of Americans do not inherit nearly that much money, but these relatively high rates would significantly impact the tax liability of the wealthiest American families. For instance, Sanders' staff estimates that Warren Buffett's tax liability would nearly double, from $33 billion to $64 billion.

From a policy perspective, Sanders aims to raise revenue from the biggest winners of the past generation of economic change and break up the large fortunes that allow a small number of very wealthy individuals to exert disproportionate influence over the political system.

Conservatives typically argue against estate taxes, or "death taxes," by citing the supposed problems of family farmers and other owners of illiquid assets. The real policy argument from the right, however, is that wealth taxes are a particularly harmful form of taxation because, over the long term, the accumulation of capital is the key to productivity and economic growth, and taxing wealth discourages that.

Sanders' staff estimates that his proposal would raise about $2.2 trillion in a 10-year window, but the exact nature of the window is uncertain due to the impact of his plan being highly sensitive to the exact timing of the deaths of a relatively small number of ultra-wealthy individuals.

Warren's wealth tax proposal would levy an annual fee of 2 to 3 percent on large fortunes, and her team estimates it will raise $2.7 trillion in a standard Congressional Budget Office 10-year scoring window. These numbers are not exactly the same, but they are broadly similar and reflect the fact that these are essentially two different ways to reach the same goal. Warren's plan, by taxing large fortunes at a slow and steady pace rather than in a single huge spurt when someone dies, has the advantage of being less sensitive to timing issues, while Sanders' proposal may do a better job of tapping directly into the intuition that the government should try to prevent the emergence of an entrenched oligarchy.

On a more substantive level, experts in tax avoidance have, in recent years, tended to favor the wealth tax direction as perhaps easier to enforce. However, under either scheme, the avoidance issue is really going to come down to fussy details that neither senator has yet delved into.

Broadly speaking, the message of these dueling plans is that the left wing of the Democratic Party is eager to tax the rich, but has not yet reached a consensus on exactly how to do it.

Title: Trump Nominates Rick Perry for Energy Secretary, Despite Previous Call to Eliminate Department

Article:

President-elect Donald Trump has reportedly nominated former Texas Governor Rick Perry to serve as secretary of the U.S. Department of Energy. According to CBS News and NBC News, Perry beat out two other contenders for the Cabinet post, Sen. Joe Manchin and Ray Washburne.

On Monday, Perry attended a meeting at Trump Towers but did not take questions from reporters. The Energy Department is the same federal agency Perry once wanted to eliminate. In a Republican presidential primary debate in November 2011, Perry infamously forgot the name of the department when asked which departments he would shut down.

Perry's nomination comes despite his ties to the Dakota Access pipeline battle. He sits on the corporate board for Energy Transfer Partners, the parent company of Dakota Access LLC, which is pushing to build the pipeline. The Obama administration blocked the Dakota Access Pipeline easement through Lake Oahe, but the Trump administration is expected to take a different approach.

The president-elect, who has previously invested in Energy Transfer Partners and supports the pipeline, told Fox News Sunday he would intervene if the conflict isn't resolved by his inauguration.

Title: Parliamentary Crisis and Brexit: A Look at the Current State of Affairs in the U.K.

Article:

The ongoing Brexit process has significantly impacted the functioning of parliamentary democracy in the United Kingdom. This week, British Prime Minister Theresa May submitted her negotiated deal for withdrawal from the European Union to Parliament, a move that has been the focus of her premiership. The deal was rejected by a significant margin, with 432 votes against and 202 in favor.

Historians are finding it challenging to find a parallel example of a government's main legislation being so decisively rejected by Parliament. Typically, losses by 60 or 90 votes would lead to a prime minister's resignation or a no-confidence vote. However, despite the rejection of her government's primary piece of legislation, Theresa May's no-confidence vote was easily won.

The current situation in Westminster is complex, with two interconnected crises at play. The first is a crisis of responsibility in Parliament, as Theresa May's deal may not align with the hard Brexiteers' desires, but they lack the votes or the courage to oust May and face parliamentary and public scrutiny of their Brexit plans. They also do not have the votes in Parliament to pass their preferred terms.

The second crisis stems from the unique nature of the U.K. system, where Parliament is supposed to be sovereign. However, Brexit was decided by a national referendum, going against the media and parliamentary consensus. This has led to a situation where many Tory and Labour MPs, who campaigned on election manifestos committing to delivering Brexit, are against the project altogether. They hope to demonstrate that Brexit is harmful or "impossible" in some way, hoping that the passage of time will increase an ascendant majority for Remain.

The rejection of May's deal increases the likelihood of a no-deal Brexit at the end of March or the possibility of Parliament delaying or cancelling Brexit altogether, potentially leading to another national referendum on the issue. The U.K. government and Parliament are currently grappling with the implications of this unprecedented situation, and a solution to these twin crises is not yet in sight.

Parliament has expressed its confidence in May's leadership, but the vote was largely symbolic, as the government lacks a working political majority willing to stand behind any Brexit deal. The U.K. must either Leave or Remain, and it is up to Parliament to decide when and how.

Title: Rep. Paul Ryan Distances Himself from Government Shutdown Tactics for Obamacare Repeal

Article:

Rep. Paul Ryan (R-WI) has distanced himself from the idea of shutting down the government as a means to force the repeal of President Obama's health-care law, a tactic some Republicans, such as Sen. Ted Cruz (R-TX), have advocated. In an interview on CBS's "Face the Nation," Ryan stated that he is not in favor of a government shutdown as a strategy to achieve this goal.

The debate over the potential government shutdown is notable due to the Democrats' unwillingness to repeal the Affordable Care Act, a position that is unlikely to change. Furthermore, the Republican Party lacks the political leverage to compel Democrats to repeal the law. A government shutdown will not defund Obamacare, nor is it likely to alter public opinion about it.

Despite these realities, many Republicans remain undeterred, and for good reason. The current discussion of a government shutdown to defund Obamacare highlights a shift in the character of Capitol Hill. The legislative process has traditionally been focused on numbers, with the most significant numbers being vote counts. Party leaders, such as House Speaker John Boehner (R-OH) and Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-KY), are among those who still adhere to these rules.

However, a new breed of legislator prioritizes a different number: ideology. Senator Cruz hinted at this new political calculus in his remarks about repealing Obamacare at Young Americans for Liberty in Arlington, VA, on Wednesday. "Right now, we don't have the votes... I'm going to be perfectly candid, we can't win this fight," Cruz told the 300 libertarian students. "The only people who can win this fight are you. The only way we win this fight is if the American people rise up in overwhelming numbers and demand our elected officials to do the right thing and stand for principle."

Demographics suggest that Young Americans for Liberty and like-minded voters may not have the numbers to make a repeal feasible. However, they can significantly influence the selection of the next Republican candidate for Congress during the 2014 primaries. This demographic shift is the math that fuels Cruz, or at least ensures that his shutdown-the-government views must be taken seriously by the Republican establishment.

The political polarization of America, particularly among Republicans, has replaced the old vote-counting mindset with an ideological one, where legislators prioritize standing firm for their constituents' demands, even if that is at odds with legislative realities. Cruz and his allies are seeking any legislative means available to achieve what their constituents want: the end of Obamacare. The fact that there are no viable legislative means at their disposal is less important than the attempt, as in their states, the Republican primaries virtually decide the winner, and failure in a noble cause is seen as better than accession to a hated one.

Rep. Paul Ryan, who holds views on strict financial austerity that elicit cheers from the ideologues, finds himself in a delicate position. He is also part of the old school, using his position as House Budget Committee chairman as a bully pulpit from which to move the Congress rightward and toward greater acceptance of his ideas on entitlement reform. He is an ideologue with real power, and therefore must tread carefully or risk losing either his clout or his aura.

The current political climate in Washington, D.C., is uncertain, with no clear direction as to how this situation will unfold. Tea party Republicans in the House brought the nation to the brink of a debt crisis in 2011 and feel they have only the sequester to show for it. For legislators who sought major entitlement reform, that is a disappointing return. The House's 40 failed attempts to kill Obamacare underscore the stakes as Republicans see it. If, instead of entitlement reform, America simply gets another entitlement, the die will be cast, and America will be put on the path to becoming another Greece, living beyond its means due to programs imposed upon the people by a massive and expanding government. Liberty will be dead, and the economy will not be far behind.

Title: Secretary Kerry Discusses U.S.-Russia Relations and Syria Conflict at Indiana University

Article:

Secretary of State John Kerry addressed a packed auditorium at Indiana University on Thursday, where he was speaking at the opening of a school of international studies. In his speech, Kerry referenced his 2004 presidential campaign, joking about his loss in Indiana.

Kerry's visit focused on promoting the Obama administration's recent international agreements, including deals on Pacific trade and Iran's nuclear program. However, he also addressed darker issues, such as Russia's intervention in Syria's civil war. Russian warplanes have been supporting President Bashar Assad's government for the third week, according to the Ministry of Defense, targeting what they claim are "terrorist targets."

The U.S. has been struggling to find forces to oppose Assad and the Islamic State. After his speech, Kerry sat down with NPR's Steve Inskeep, discussing the challenge of convincing Russian President Vladimir Putin to target only Islamic extremists, not the Syrian rebels who oppose Assad.
