"If they're supporting Assad, they're going to attract great difficulties for themselves and for any hope of a unified, secular Syria," Kerry said. "Putin does not have a simple, easy track here," he added. "This is not a situation where he's just moved in and taken over and everybody says, 'Oh, wow, he's doing something we couldn't.' No, he's not. He is not going to be able to stop the war by being there."

Regarding the U.S.'s efforts to help U.S.-backed Syrians under attack by Russian aircraft, Kerry stated, "We are now having that discussion with the Russians right now. I talked to my counterpart today, to [Foreign Minister] Sergey Lavrov. We raised the issue of this 'deconfliction' process. We're very near coming to an agreement on exactly how that will work, and my hope is that it will lead to a broader set of understandings about where the targeting ought to be and what is truly helpful and what is not."

When asked about the goals of the "deconfliction" talks with Lavrov and whether they would go beyond keeping U.S. and Russian warplanes out of conflict with each other, Kerry responded, "That's the immediate, that's the short-term, de minimus deconfliction, but it is possible that if you have adequate cooperation on the early steps of this horrible word 'deconfliction,' then it may be possible to actually engage in a broader conversation about how ISIL is going to be defeated, and who will bear what responsibility."

Kerry concluded by expressing uncertainty about Russia's full strategy in Syria, stating, "It remains to be seen what their full strategy is in Syria.... If Russia is there to go after ISIL, and to in fact help prevent the takeover of the country and to secure a political track that could result in the end of the war, that could be positive. If Russia is there to uphold Assad, and fake it with respect to the extremists and terrorists, that's a serious problem." He also emphasized the need for nonviolence in the region, particularly from the Palestinians and their leadership.

Title: Trump Announces Final Five Supreme Court Nominees Ahead of July 9th Announcement

Article:

President Trump has revealed that he will announce his pick to replace retiring Justice Anthony Kennedy on July 9th, with two women among the five finalists. The age of the finalists averages 48 years old, and their conservative backgrounds are undisputed. The president did not disclose the names of the finalists, but several legal analysts, sitting jurists, and confidential sources have identified the following as the "final five" for the high court:

1. Amy Coney Barrett, 46, of the U.S. Court of Appeals (7th Circuit). A former editor of the Notre Dame Law Review and law professor at Notre Dame, Barrett was also a clerk for the late Justice Antonin Scalia. During her appointment by Trump to the Court of Appeals in 2017, she faced scrutiny from Sen. Diane Feinstein (D-Calif.) regarding her Catholic faith and its potential impact on her rulings. Barrett responded, "It's never appropriate for a judge to impose that judge's personal convictions, whether they arise from faith or anywhere else, on the law."

2. Joan Larsen, 49, of the U.S. Court of Appeals (6th Circuit). A graduate of the Northwestern University School of Law, Larsen has had a rapid legal career, serving as Deputy assistant attorney general under George W. Bush, justice of the Michigan Supreme Court from 2015 to 2017, and U.S. appellate judge for the past two years. A member of the Federalist Society, Larsen is also a former law clerk for the late Justice Scalia.

3. Brett Kavanaugh, 52, of the D.C. Court of Appeals. Kavanaugh is a favorite of Washington, D.C. legal conservatives, particularly those who began their careers in the Reagan administration. A Yale Law School graduate, he clerked for Supreme Court Justice Anthony Kennedy. His judicial record is considered more conservative than his mentor, and he played a significant role in the impeachment of Bill Clinton by the U.S. House of Representatives in 1998. He was later appointed to the federal Appeals Court by President George W. Bush. In the Trump administration, Kavanaugh's biggest booster is White House counsel Don McGahn.

4. Mike Lee, 47, Republican U.S. senator from Utah. Trump has mentioned Lee as a potential high court appointee, calling him an "outstanding talent." Raised in law (his father, Rex Lee, was President Ronald Reagan's solicitor general, and his brother, Tom Lee, is a justice of the Utah Supreme Court), Lee clerked for Samuel Alito when the justice was an appellate judge. He also served as general counsel to former Utah Gov. Jon Huntsman (now U.S. ambassador to Russia). Considered one of the most conservative of Senate Republicans, Lee would be the first sitting senator to be appointed to the high court since Harold Burton (Republican senator from Ohio) was named by Harry Truman in 1945, and the first Mormon to sit on the Supreme Court.

5. Amul Thapar, 49, of the U.S. Court of Appeals (6th Circuit). Thapar would be the first Indian-American to sit on the high court. A U.C. Berkeley School of Law graduate, Thapar is a protégé of Senate Republican Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.) and has moved from being U.S. attorney for the Eastern District of Kentucky, U.S. District judge from 2008 to 2015, and since last year, an appellate judge. As a minority, court-watchers say, he might be an attractive prospect for some Democrats in the Senate to support. McConnell and UN Ambassador Nikki Haley have reportedly weighed in with the White House on his behalf.

John Gizzi, chief political columnist and White House correspondent for ███, has reported on these potential nominees. For more of his reports, visit [Go Here Now].

Title: Biden Reverses Position, Says He Would Comply with Subpoena for Impeachment Trial Testimony

Article:

Former Vice President Joe Biden has reversed his earlier position and stated that he would comply with a congressional subpoena to testify in President Donald Trump's impeachment trial. In a town hall in Fairfield, Iowa, Biden clarified his stance, stating, "I would obey any subpoena that was sent to me."

This change in position marks one of the most significant and swift reversals by a candidate in the Democratic primary, according to the New York Times. The reversal came after a day in which the issue dominated his campaign, following his statement to the Des Moines Register's editorial board on Friday that he would defy a Senate subpoena.

In a series of tweets on Saturday, Biden emphasized his history of cooperating with legitimate congressional oversight requests. However, he also stated that he would not pretend there is any legal basis for Republican subpoenas for his testimony in the impeachment trial.

When asked by reporters after an event in Iowa, Biden asserted that, since he has no first-hand knowledge of the events surrounding Trump's impeachment, there would be no basis upon which to call him as a witness. He also stated that he would "honor whatever the Congress in fact legitimately asked me to do."

When asked about the possibility of challenging a subpoena in court, Biden said it was too early to say. "The answer is, I don't think that's going to happen to begin with. Let's cross that bridge when it comes," he said, adding, "I would in fact abide by whatever was legally required of me. I always have."

Senator Elizabeth Warren also weighed in on the issue, stating that Biden should comply with anything that the Senate issues lawfully. Warren emphasized that the focus should be on Trump and his actions.

"Donald Trump is being impeached for abuse of power, and that's where our focus should be. Shame on him for trying to switch the focus over to something else," Warren told reporters in Iowa. "Joe Biden has said that he has always abided by every lawful order, and if there's a lawful order for a subpoena, then I assume he would follow it."

Title: Anonymous Donors Fuel Political Advertising Through "Social Welfare" Organizations in 2012 Presidential Campaign

Article:

In the 2012 presidential campaign, some of the heaviest advertisers are groups financed by anonymous donors, classified as "social welfare" organizations rather than political committees. Peter Overby, NPR's money and politics correspondent, reports that one such group, Crossroads GPS, is spending significantly on high-profile ads and is rivaling the campaigns themselves in ad spending.

Four months before the election, the top three advertisers are President Obama's re-election campaign ($40 million), Mitt Romney's campaign ($32 million), and Crossroads GPS, which has spent $29 million so far. Crossroads GPS, classified as a "social welfare" organization for federal tax purposes, is one of the groups looming large in the campaign's ad spending.

According to Overby, officially, social welfare organizations are classified under Section 501 (c) (4) of the tax code, which means they perform some kind of public or community benefit. They include groups like local volunteer fire departments, Rotary International, and the League of Women Voters. However, these organizations do not have to disclose their donors, creating a gray area where election law meets tax law.

Crossroads GPS, led by Republican strategist Karl Rove, has run ads in Virginia criticizing the policies of President Obama and Democratic Senate candidate Tim Kaine. Rove recently explained to Fox News why the group can call itself a "social welfare" organization: "It's a social welfare organization because it spends the vast preponderance of its money in furtherance of its social welfare goals. It's an issues advocacy group."

Crossroads GPS, formed in 2010, shortly after the Supreme Court's Citizens United ruling that loosened some campaign finance regulations, has raised $77 million in its first two years in existence. Overby reports that 90 percent of that came from at most 24 donors, making the "social welfare" organization approach appealing due to its anonymity.

"This is what makes the social welfare organization approach so appealing," Overby explains. "You've got a couple dozen people who are able to play this incredibly powerful role in the election. It's anonymous. Nobody will ever know who they are. Not their business competitors. Not their political rivals. And not the voters."

Title: U.S. Reiterates No-Weapons Policy for Ukraine as Obama Meets with President-elect Poroshenko

Article:

President Barack Obama met with Ukraine's president-elect, Petro Poroshenko, for the first time on Wednesday, with the U.S. continuing to rule out providing weapons to help Ukraine fight against pro-Russian insurgents. Poroshenko, who will be sworn in on Saturday, has stated that he will ask for U.S. assistance, including training, advice to modernize Ukraine's military, and a grant of military equipment.

State Department spokeswoman Jen Psaki reiterated this week that "we'll continue to review their requests," but that the U.S. policy has not changed regarding lethal weapons. When asked by a reporter about providing such aid, Obama pointed out that during the Crimea crisis, the U.S. provided non-lethal assistance.

While Russian activity will be a prime topic of their meeting, Obama and Poroshenko will also discuss energy supplies for Ukraine and efforts to rebuild its economy. "We're going to spend a lot of time on the economics of Ukraine," Obama said.

Obama used his visit to Poland, a crossroads of the old Cold War, to intensify a new-style standoff with Russia over Ukraine. In meetings with Polish and Eastern European leaders, Obama unveiled a $1 billion plan to bolster security for NATO allies and warned Russia that further aggression in Ukraine will bring more sanctions.

Under the $1 billion plan, more U.S. troops would be rotated throughout Europe, with more land, sea, and air military exercises and training missions throughout the continent. Assistance would also be available for non-NATO nations on Russia's border, including Ukraine, Georgia, and Moldova.

Russian activity in Ukraine will also be the major topic when Obama attends the G-7 summit Wednesday and Thursday in Brussels. The president's trip wraps up Friday in Normandy, France, with a commemoration of the 70th anniversary of the D-Day landings. The ceremonies feature a number of world leaders, including Russian President Vladimir Putin, who has clashed with Obama over Ukraine.

Obama and Putin do not have a formal meeting scheduled, but Obama said he is sure he will bump into his Russian counterpart. He called on Putin to encourage violent separatists in eastern Ukraine to "stand down." The president said that "responsible behavior by the Russians" could help rebuild American-Russian relations that have been "shattered by Russia's annexation of the Crimea region of Ukraine."

"But," Obama added, "I think it is fair to say that rebuilding that trust will take quite some time." Obama also said that "further Russian provocation will be met with further costs for Russia, including, if necessary, additional sanctions."

Obama stopped in Poland to help commemorate the 25th anniversary of the nation's first free elections as the Soviet Union and the Cold War collapsed—making Poland a perfect place for Obama to talk about national self-determination in the wake of the Ukraine crisis. World War II began after Germany invaded Poland in 1939, yet the Poles wound up as Soviet vassals. Poland played a major role in breaking up the Soviet Union after the birth of the Solidarity labor movement led by dock worker Lech Walesa.

Since it gained independence in 1989, Poland has been a particularly popular stop for presidents in the post-Cold War era—though Obama does have his share of local critics. Walesa himself, a former president of Poland, told a Polish television network last week that Obama has not been robust enough in the Ukraine crisis.

"The superpower has not been up to the job," Walesa said, "and therefore the world is at a dangerous point and maybe it really is the case that lots of bad things are happening in the world because there is no leadership."

Title: Uzbek Immigrant's Entry into U.S. through Diversity Visa Program Sparks Debate on Immigration Policy

Article:

The individual allegedly responsible for the deadly truck attack in New York City on Tuesday, identified as Sayfullo Saipov, entered the United States seven years ago through the Diversity Visa Program. This detail has become significant as President Trump proposes revisions to his "extreme vetting" program in response to the incident.

The Diversity Visa Program, a State Department program that offers a lottery for individuals from countries with low rates of immigration to the U.S., has been a point of contention following the attack. President Trump tweeted early Wednesday, "The terrorist came into our country through what is called the 'Diversity Visa Lottery Program,' a Chuck Schumer beauty. I want merit-based, not more Democrat Lottery Systems. We are fighting hard for Merit Based immigration, no more Democrat Lottery Systems. We must get MUCH tougher (and smarter)."

The DV program makes up to 50,000 immigrant visas available annually, according to the U.S. Citizen and Immigration Services website. Applicants must prove they have a clean criminal record, have a high school diploma or its equivalent, or have at least two years of work experience within the past five years to qualify.

The program was initially introduced in 1990 by Sen. Chuck Schumer, D-N.Y., as part of a bill. Schumer's measure to make a set number of visas available to "diversity immigrants" from certain countries was absorbed into a larger House immigration bill, which was sponsored by Schumer and 31 others, including several Republicans. The program has been a subject of debate in Congress several times, most recently with the Reforming American Immigration for a Strong Economy (RAISE) Act, which called for its elimination.

Senator Tom Cotton, R-Ark., sponsored the RAISE Act, and the Trump White House expressed support for the bill, calling the DV program "outdated" and stating that it "serves questionable economic and humanitarian interests."

In response to Trump's comments, Sen. Schumer called on the president to rescind proposed cuts to "vital anti-terrorism funding" in his budget. "I have always believed and continue to believe that immigration is good for America," Schumer said in a statement. "President Trump, instead of politicizing and dividing America, which he always seems to do at times of national tragedy, should be focusing on the real solution - anti-terrorism funding - which he proposed cutting in his most recent budget."

Following the attack, Schumer kept his post-attack comments to praise of the NYPD. "Thanks NYPD for rapidly responding to tragic situation downtown. Worried & saddened to hear about injuries & loss of life," he said on Twitter.

The details of Sayfullo Saipov's travel to America and his involvement in the attack are still under investigation.

Title: The Comparative Privacy Concerns of Facebook and the IRS

Article:

In the ongoing debate about Facebook's collection of personal information from users, it is worth noting that another entity, the Internal Revenue Service (IRS), is currently handling sensitive financial details from individuals, details that are not voluntarily surrendered. Unlike Facebook, users have no choice but to provide this information to the IRS.

While Facebook's data collection practices, which involved third-party apps compiling detailed user profiles until 2015, were criticized for being intrusive, the information was based on data voluntarily shared through a service that users were not compelled to use. Those uncomfortable with Facebook's policies can choose to close their account or provide false information.

In contrast, individuals cannot avoid providing the IRS with details of their finances, businesses, properties, and families. The tax agency can impose penalties for failing to file a tax return or for failing to pay taxes by the deadline.

Notable examples of the IRS's handling of personal data include Boris Johnson, the former mayor of London, who was slapped with a substantial tax bill by the U.S. IRS due to his American birth, despite leaving the country by the age of 5. To avoid potential arrest upon returning to the U.S., Johnson paid the bill and renounced his American citizenship.

The purposes to which the IRS puts the extracted data are more concerning, as well. The IRS has a history of using the information for questionable purposes, carelessly storing data, leaking information through various channels, and hiring employees with questionable backgrounds.

In 2021, for instance, former IRS agent Ryan Payne pleaded guilty to using other people's Social Security numbers, information acquired during business audits, while applying for a loan and a bank account. Della Ornelas and Randall Ruff, who shared a long-term interest in combining tax collection with fraud, also had careers at the IRS, married, and eventually served prison time.

In February, the Treasury Inspector General for Tax Administration expressed puzzlement in a report about the issuance of more than $1.7 million in awards to 1,962 IRS employees who had a disciplinary or adverse action, with some employees having serious misconduct such as unauthorized access to tax return information, substance abuse, and sexual misconduct.

Additionally, hackers have stolen over 700,000 Social Security numbers and other sensitive records from IRS computers in the past couple of years. Unlike the Facebook data, which contained information about preferences and beliefs that people voluntarily shared, the IRS data included information that few people would willingly provide without the threat of fines, penalties, and imprisonment.

Breaches of IRS data can have severe consequences. In 2020, hackers extracted information on nearly 100,000 college students from the IRS Data Retrieval Tool, allowing them to steal upwards of $30 million. Victims of this breach remain at risk of ongoing identity theft due to the sensitive nature of the information the tax agency requires.

In 2013, the IRS paid out $5.8 billion in bogus refunds as a result of identity theft. The IRS is, therefore, a significant repository of sensitive information and, apparently, a less-than-ideal guardian of that data.

As users contemplate the potential uses of their pictures and posts on social media, a logical reaction when filing required information for tax day with the IRS is less annoyance and more a healthy dose of fear.

Title: Early Voting Begins in Iowa, Democrats Seem to Dominate

Article:

Early in-person voting has commenced in Iowa, marking the first swing state to open polling sites. Residents can now vote in person at their local county auditor's offices or by mail, with some areas offering additional satellite locations. In Des Moines, a line of voters extended down the block at the Polk County Auditor's office on Thursday morning.

Peter Clay, a 62-year-old supporter of President Obama, was among the early voters. He has volunteered for the campaign on his days off from his job as a zookeeper. "It's important to have a lot of folks showing up today because it shows there's passion and energy in this campaign," Clay said. "This is our first chance to show how much we care about the outcome and to demonstrate we want this president in office for another four years."

Democrats appeared to dominate in Johnson County, where polls opened in Iowa City. Victoria Walton, a librarian in Iowa City and an Obama supporter, said she had no reason to delay her vote until Election Day. "I'm very concerned about the election, and I wanted to place my vote as soon as possible," she said. "I've already decided, and the debates are not going to change my mind in any way. I've been listening carefully and thinking about this a long time."

Aleta Alexander, a 63-year-old voter from Waterloo in eastern Iowa, was among several voters who said they were volunteering for the Obama campaign. "I voted for him in 2008 because I thought for sure he was the president that was for all the people—not just blacks for whites or whatever but for everybody," she said. "And I still believe that. So that's why I'm voting for him again."

While there were Romney supporters, they were harder to find. Virginia Sourbeer, a retired state legislative staffer and former teacher from Des Moines, described herself as socially moderate. However, she said she was worried about the federal budget and spending in programs like Medicare and Social Security. Sourbeer said she trusted Romney more when it came to the economy. "I just think that his background, for one thing, and his record in Massachusetts, that he dealt with difficult economic times there, that he'll deal with the issue," she said. "Because we've had somebody who will not deal with the issue the last four years."

The Republican National Committee's Iowa spokesman, Tom Szold, said Republicans had intentionally held off on most efforts to promote absentee voting until this week. He said they believed Romney voters would show up on Election Day if not before. "It's common knowledge that the Democrats are ahead of us in this," he said. "They start much earlier and they focus largely on their base. And we think that's because they're basically worried that their base is not going to turn out on Election Day."

However, Erin Seidler, President Obama's campaign spokeswoman in Iowa, said promoting early voting made sense. "We have 40 days to vote in Iowa. Why you would let any one of those days go by without getting folks to the polls is surprising to me," Seidler said. The Obama campaign has pushed early voting across the country, urging Iowans in particular to "Be the First" to vote for the president.

Democrats have requested the overwhelming majority of absentee ballots in Iowa. However, Republicans have an 18,000-person lead in voter registration. Polk County Auditor Jamie Fitzgerald said Democrats have a longer track record of working to get out the early vote. "Recently Republicans have started doing it," he said. "So the numbers are going to come a little bit closer. But the Democrats have been known for a lot of shoe leather, and working early."

Iowa is among more than 30 states that allow early voting. This report includes contributions from Clay Masters, Pat Blank, and Dean Borg of Iowa Public Radio, and Omaha Public Radio's Katie Knapp Schubert.

Title: Hillary Clinton Concedes Presidential Election to Donald Trump, Vows to Respect Result

Article:

Hillary Clinton conceded the 2016 presidential election to Republican candidate Donald Trump on Wednesday, acknowledging the deep discontent among voters and expressing her disappointment. In a speech at the New Yorker hotel, Clinton, who became the first female presidential nominee for a major party, admitted that her political career may have ended with a dramatic thud rather than the glass-ceiling-shattering win she anticipated.

Clinton's defeat marked a significant shift in American politics, erasing the hope for a Democratic dynasty in the White House. The election results highlighted deep divisions within the nation and revealed the flawed nature of Clinton as a candidate.

In her concession speech, Clinton expressed empathy for her supporters, stating, "I know how disappointed you feel because I feel it too. And so do tens of millions of Americans who invested their hopes and dreams in this effort." She emphasized the importance of respecting the election result and giving Trump a chance to lead.

Clinton's future is uncertain, as she faces ongoing scrutiny over her handling of classified information and questions about corruption within the Clinton Foundation. The State Department is still under court order to continue releasing emails from her private server during her tenure as secretary of state, and watchdog groups plan to continue pushing for more disclosures.

The FBI investigation into pay-for-play accusations involving Clinton's State Department and Clinton Foundation ensures that corruption allegations will not disappear with the end of the presidential race.

Political analysts attribute Clinton's election loss to her being the wrong candidate at the wrong time, as well as the strength of Republican enthusiasm at the state and gubernatorial levels. Lara Brown, an associate professor of political management at George Washington University, stated, "To not recognize the fact that this change election has been brewing is to miss the fact that the Republicans wiped the floor with the Democrats in 2010 and 2014, and to miss the fact that Republicans had been growing in strength across the states throughout Obama's tenure."

Clinton's candidacy was also marred by deep questions about her honesty and trustworthiness, largely due to her private email server and admitted carelessness with classified information. The FBI cleared Clinton of criminal wrongdoing, but critics argue that the investigation cemented the notion that she was a political elitist held to a different standard than other Americans.

Tom Fitton, president of the watchdog group Judicial Watch, stated, "The corruption of Hillary Clinton was resoundingly rejected, and the frustration the American people felt was that she wasn't being held accountable." Fitton believes the incoming Trump administration should appoint a special prosecutor to renew a federal investigation into Clinton.

Beyond the political and legal questions, Clinton's electoral defeat was a personal setback. Her attempts to break the glass ceiling of American politics have been thwarted twice, first by Barack Obama in the 2008 Democratic primary and then by Trump in 2016. Clinton addressed this painful failure in her concession speech and encouraged young women not to be discouraged.

"To all the women, and especially the young women who put their faith in this campaign and in me, I want you to know that nothing has made me prouder than to be your champion," she said. "I know we have still not shattered that highest and hardest glass ceiling, but someday someone will, and hopefully sooner than we may think right now."

Title: Trump Signs Executive Order Promoting and Protecting Religious Liberty

Article:

President Donald Trump signed an executive order on Thursday, marking the National Day of Prayer, aimed at promoting and protecting religious liberty. The event, held in the Rose Garden, brought together evangelicals, Catholics, Jews, and others for a first-of-its-kind gathering.

The executive order reaffirms the government's commitment to upholding religious freedom laws and includes several key provisions. It directs the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) to stop enforcing the Johnson Amendment, which prohibits churches and other non-profits from endorsing political candidates. Additionally, it protects the conscience of employers who do not wish to provide contraception and abortion-inducing drugs in their insurance plans, as mandated by the Affordable Care Act.

The order has received mixed reactions from faith leaders. While some, like Ryan T. Anderson, a senior research fellow at The Heritage Foundation, view it as an important first step, others, such as Sen. James Lankford and the Alliance Defending Freedom, have expressed disappointment due to the order's lack of detail and the perceived need for more robust legislative action.

Critics on the left argue that the order could lead to discrimination against gays, same-sex couples, and women. The American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU) initially threatened to sue the administration but later announced it had decided against it.

The executive order's impact and effectiveness remain to be seen, with some faith leaders viewing it as a step in the right direction in combating the hostility Christians have faced under previous administrations. Franklin Graham, for example, expressed gratitude for a president who is concerned about religious liberty and is not afraid to mention Jesus Christ.

Title: NRA Faces $100 Million in Legal Costs, According to Secret Recording

Article:

The National Rifle Association (NRA) has reportedly incurred $100 million in legal costs due to ongoing investigations and internal turmoil, according to a secret recording of the organization's board meeting obtained by NPR. The recording, from a January 2020 meeting, reveals NRA CEO Wayne LaPierre's criticism of investigations by the New York and Washington, D.C. attorneys general, and his disclosure of $80 million in cuts to the NRA's budget to stay afloat.

In the recording, LaPierre, who is the CEO and executive vice president of the gun rights group, stated, "The cost that we bore was probably about a hundred-million-dollar hit in lost revenue and real cost to this association in 2018 and 2019." He further explained, "I mean, that's huge."

These figures, not previously reported, represent the first time LaPierre has quantified the financial impact of the ongoing legal battles. For context, the NRA and its affiliates raised more than $412 million and spent more than $423 million in 2018, the last year for which there is public reporting.

To weather the financial storm, LaPierre stated that he had reduced the size of the organization's budget by $80 million. "What we did in order to survive and adjust is we took in 2019 and 2020... about $80 million in real costs out of the NRA budget," LaPierre said. "I mean, we kinda reframed this entire association. We took it down to the studs."

Although the NRA has maintained its membership level, LaPierre acknowledged that there is still much to be done. "We're not out of the woods yet. We still got ta wrestle with this financial situation," he said.

LaPierre also criticized the attorneys general of New York and D.C., comparing their investigations to oppressive tactics from autocratic regimes. "I've never seen anything like that in the United States of America, to tell you the truth. I mean, that is Cuba, that is communist China, that is Venezuela, it's Russia," LaPierre said.

The offices of the D.C. and New York attorneys general declined to comment.

The recording was made during an NRA board meeting in Virginia in January, with board members, NRA staff, and a few dozen NRA members in attendance. Ron Carter, the vice president of Save the Second, an organization of NRA members advocating for financial reform and accountability within the National Rifle Association, was present.

"The repeated statement from LaPierre about the $100 million cost to the NRA should have come with an apology for having manifested the situation," Carter told NPR. "The lack of accountability is troubling for many members."

Save the Second is not associated with the recording obtained by NPR. The National Rifle Association did not return a request for comment.

The NRA announced layoffs and pay cuts in late March, blaming the coronavirus crisis for these measures. The coronavirus crisis also prompted the cancellation of the group's annual convention, which had been scheduled to take place this past weekend.

While the coronavirus crisis has undoubtedly affected the organization's finances, the tape of LaPierre from January indicates that many of the organization's financial cuts were underway well before the emergence of the public health crisis. Legal costs remain a heavy burden on the organization, with the ongoing litigation between the NRA and Ackerman McQueen, its former public relations firm, indicating that the firm believes the NRA has paid its outside legal counsel "over $54 million" in the last two years.

Title: Republican Proposal to Split 9th Circuit Court of Appeals Gains Momentum

Article:

Republican Senators Jeff Flake and John McCain of Arizona have introduced legislation to divide the 9th Circuit Court of Appeals, aiming to create a new 12th Circuit. The proposed legislation, if successful, would remove six states from the San Francisco-based court circuit, leaving only California, Oregon, Hawaii, and two island districts within its jurisdiction.

The proposed legislation, which was introduced last month, argues that the 9th Circuit is too large, too liberal, and too slow in resolving cases. According to Sen. Flake, the court currently represents 20% of the U.S. population and has 40% of the land mass within its jurisdiction, making it "too big." He stated that it typically takes the court 15 months to hand down a decision.

The 9th Circuit has been a target of criticism from conservatives for years, often being referred to as the "Nutty 9th" or the "9th Circus." The court's reputation as one of the most liberal in the country is largely due to its judicial makeup, with 18 of its 25 active judges having been appointed by Democrats. Former President George W. Bush appointed six justices, while former President Barack Obama appointed seven.

Under Flake's bill, the new circuit would cover Nevada, Washington, Idaho, Montana, Arizona, and Alaska, leaving the 9th with three Pacific states as well as the Northern Mariana Islands and Guam. A separate House version introduced by Rep. Andy Biggs and four other Arizona Republicans would leave Washington state in the 9th Circuit.

Efforts to split the circuit go back to 1941, but carving up the large circuit is not without precedent. In 1929, Congress split the 8th Circuit to accommodate a population boom and increased caseloads.

Democratic strategist Joe Lestingi pushed back on accusations that the court leans left, stating, "We don't complain about courts being too conservative. The truth is... the liberal side of that court provides the conflict we need to settle our most basic disagreements." He added that the 9th Circuit's track record of rulings being overturned by the U.S. Supreme Court is part of the judicial process.

In 1998, Congress appointed a commission to reexamine the federal appeals courts' structure, which ultimately recommended against splitting the 9th Circuit. However, the possibility of carving up the large circuit is not out of the realm of possibility.

Title: Rep. Rashida Tlaib Meets with Controversial Pro-Palestinian Organization

Article:

Rep. Rashida Tlaib (D-MI) has been criticized for meeting with the Palestine Youth Movement (PYM), a pro-Palestinian organization that has been associated with violent rhetoric and support for terrorism against Israel. The meeting took place during the Arab Texas Festival in Dallas.

The PYM organization has a history of anti-Israel activity, including a 2018 event in San Francisco where attendees called for the kidnapping of Israeli soldiers. In Facebook postings, the organization has memorialized individuals involved in terrorist attacks against Israel, with at least three of those honored being known operatives of the Hamas terror group.

In addition, PYM has been involved in campus events, such as one at the University of California, Los Angeles, where attendees chanted "long live the intifada," a phrase often used by those advocating armed resistance against Israel.

In July 2019, a PYM event in Toronto, Canada, was canceled after it was revealed that the group had hosted an event with a member of the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine (PFLP), a group that has committed terror attacks on Israel. In response to the event's cancellation, PYM blamed "Zionist organizations" for the campaign against it.

Tlaib's interaction with the group is the latest in a series of meetings with anti-Israel groups and supporters of the Boycott, Divestment, and Sanctions (BDS) movement that Tlaib has held. Tlaib and her freshman colleague Rep. Ilhan Omar (D-MN) have also faced criticism for attempting to organize a trip to Israel sponsored by an organization called Miftah, which has praised supporters of terrorism and promoted anti-Semitic conspiracy theories.

Title: Rep. Mark Amodei Supports Impeachment Inquiry, Holds Judgment on Impeachment of President Trump

Article:

Rep. Mark Amodei (R-NV) has expressed his support for the ongoing impeachment inquiry into President Donald Trump, but has not indicated his stance on impeaching the president, according to a report by The Nevada Independent.

During a conference call with reporters on Friday, Amodei stated, "Let's put it through the process and see what happens. I'm a big fan of oversight, so let the committees get to work and see where it goes." He added, "Using government agencies to, if it's proven, to put your finger on the scale of an election, I don't think that's right. If it turns out that it's something along those lines, then there's a problem."

Following The Nevada Independent's publication of their article, Amodei released a statement reiterating his support for the impeachment inquiry but not necessarily impeachment itself. He stated that his position mirrored that of Sen. Catherine Cortez-Masto (D-NV).

Sen. Cortez-Masto told KTVN-TV, "I think from all of that information, we have to follow the facts and figure out what happened here."

In response to a Nevada Independent reporter's article, Amodei clarified that the statement, "Rep. Mark Amodei supports the House's inquiry into whether President Donald Trump should be impeached, but is withholding judgment on whether Trump has crossed the legal line," is accurate in the sense that both the House and Senate have unanimously supported a resolution expressing the sense of Congress that the whistleblower complaint received on August 12, 2019, should be transmitted to the relevant committees. However, Amodei emphasized that he did not indicate support for impeachment and instead stressed his agreement with Sen. Cortez-Masto's statement.

Amodei further stated that anyone who reads the article and believes there is a vote to convict before the process has played out is in individual fantasy. He expressed a desire to know the facts of what took place between President Trump and Ukrainian President Zelensky.

"I think that's why we have the committee process. I won't attribute what was in the president's mind. That wasn't a great way to express concern about it. Part of what the committees will do is try to find some context for that and then based on what a fair reading of the context is, they'll go forward from there," Amodei told The Nevada Independent. "I don't care if it was a partisan spy or not. The only thing I get a vote on is, if it comes to the House floor... do I think that there is evidence there that is credible, that says he broke a specific law?"

Title: FISA Documents Reveal Steele Dossier as Major Component of Carter Page Surveillance Warrant

Article:

The Department of Justice has released documents detailing the government's justification for the FISA surveillance warrant against Carter Page, a former campaign adviser to then-candidate Donald Trump. The materials include an October 2016 application to the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court to wiretap Page, as well as several renewal applications.

The heavily redacted documents show that the infamous and unverified Steele Dossier was a major component of the 2016 surveillance warrant. The dossier, which was opposition research funded by the Democratic National Committee (DNC) and Hillary Clinton campaign, contains salacious allegations against Trump. It was also a major component used to justify subsequent renewals.

The visible sections of the released FISA documents do not indicate the dossier was ever verified. Instead, the FBI claimed that Steele was “reliable” based on his previous work. The FISA records also reveal that a September 2016 Yahoo News article by Michael Isikoff was a significant part of the government's warrant application.

However, London court records show that Steele briefed Yahoo News and other reporters in the fall of 2016 at the direction of Fusion GPS, the opposition research firm behind the Steele Dossier. The newly released FISA warrant application, however, seems to indicate the Yahoo News article was an independent piece of corroborating information that justified the surveillance of Carter Page. Republicans question whether the story is an example of circular reporting that merely repeated information from Fusion GPS, the opposition research firm that commissioned former British spy Christopher Steele to compile the dossier.

Based on what is visible, the dossier is not described to the FISA court as a political document, as the Democrats have asserted; in fact, the FBI speculates to the FISA court that it was commissioned to damage Candidate 1, who is Donald Trump. Page's denials of the Yahoo News reporting were included in the early renewals to the FISA application. The last renewal in late Spring 2017 is particularly important, as by that point, the FBI had dumped Steele as a source after he misled them over his media contacts.

One of the documents reads: “The FBI speculates to the FISA court that the U.S. person was likely looking for information that could be used to discredit candidate 1’s campaign.” ███ believes that the U.S. person is Glenn Simpson, co-founder of Fusion GPS.

The unredacted FISA materials also contain only limited references to ex-Trump adviser George Papadopoulos. Media reports had speculated that Papadopoulos' 2016 meeting in London with a professor who had ties to Russia was a key justification for the FISA-authorized surveillance of Page. Papadopoulos has since pleaded guilty to lying to federal investigators in Special Counsel Robert Mueller's probe.

Critics have charged that Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein, who signed off on the FISA application renewals, should not have approved them without more reliable intelligence.

Reacting to the document release, Page told ███, "I'm having trouble finding any small bit of this document that rises above complete ignorance and/or insanity." President Trump also weighed in on Twitter Sunday, calling the situation a "scam."

"Looking more & more like the Trump Campaign for President was illegally being spied upon (surveillance) for the political gain of Crooked Hillary Clinton and the DNC," Trump wrote. "Ask her how that worked out - she did better with Crazy Bernie. Republicans must get tough now. An illegal Scam!"

The surveillance of Page became a contentious matter between Republican and Democratic lawmakers earlier this year. Republicans alleged the FBI had abused its surveillance powers and improperly obtained the warrant, a charge that Democrats rebutted as both sides characterized the documents in different ways. The documents, meanwhile, remained out of public view.

House Democrats were quick to say that the documents bolstered their arguments. "For more than a year, House Republicans have bullied the Department of Justice and FBI to release highly sensitive documents to derail the Special Counsel's and other legitimate national security investigations and cover for the President," House Democratic leader Nancy Pelosi said in a statement. "For the sake of our national security and our democracy, these vital investigations must be allowed to continue unhindered by Republican interference. The GOP must cease their attacks on our law enforcement and intelligence communities, and finally decide where their loyalty lies."

U.S. Rep. Adam Schiff, the California Democrat who is the ranking member of the House Intelligence Committee, said the documents underscore the "legitimate concern" the FBI had about Page's activities. Yet Schiff said the materials should not have been released during an ongoing investigation because of national security.

Schiff blamed Trump for making public the House Republicans' initial memo about the FISA applications, a move by Trump that the congressman called "nakedly political and self-interested, and designed to to interfere with the Special Counsel's investigation."

Earlier this year, GOP members of the House Intelligence Committee voted to release a memo claiming the DOJ abused the FISA warrant process in order to hurt Trump's presidential campaign, claiming the warrant against Page was based in significant part on the Steele Dossier. Trump declassified the memo over the objections of the FBI, which warned that the document contained “material omissions of fact that fundamentally impact the memo’s accuracy,” the Hill report said. ███'s Gregg Re and the Associated Press contributed to this story.

Title: Senator Sherrod Brown Faces Sexual Harassment Allegation, Prepares Legal Action Against Republican Challenger Jim Renacci

Article:

Democratic Senator Sherrod Brown is preparing to take legal action against his Republican challenger, Rep. Jim Renacci, following Renacci's release of a statement Thursday evening accusing Brown of sexual harassment from 30 years ago.

In a lengthy statement by attorney Laura Mills, a "very credible" and "professional" unnamed woman alleged that Brown made an "unexpected, uninvited, unwanted, and sudden advance, roughly pushing her up against a wall" in the late 1980s. The statement did not provide details about when or where the incident allegedly occurred or the events leading up to that point. The two reportedly met through the course of her work.

The woman chose not to report the incident because it stopped in that moment, according to the statement. Ms. Mills is a former business partner and political donor of Mr. Renacci, according to Cleveland.com.

On Wednesday, Renacci told the Cincinnati Enquirer that he had heard from "multiple women" with abuse allegations against Brown.

In response, Brown issued a cease and desist letter to Renacci, demanding he stop "making unsubstantiated and false claims about something that never happened," or else he would face "legal ramifications." Campaign spokesman Preston Maddock said in a statement, "Pure and simple this is character assassination by a failed and desperate candidate who every day reaches new lows. This will not be tolerated, all legal means will be pursued against Jim Renacci."

Renacci has used Brown's contentious 1986 divorce and separate uncorroborated allegations of abuse as a way to paint Brown as hypocritical for voting "no" on confirming Supreme Court Justice Brett M. Kavanaugh, who faced his own allegations of sexual misconduct.

Renacci said in a statement Thursday that this new allegation raises "even more questions and alarm over Mr. Brown's conduct toward women."

According to the Real Clear Politics average of polls, Brown leads Renacci by 16 points in the Ohio Senate race.

Title: Trump Pardons Lewis "Scooter" Libby, Convicted of Lying Under Oath in 2007

Article:

President Donald Trump has reportedly signed off on a pardon for Lewis "Scooter" Libby, who was convicted of lying under oath in 2007 in connection with the leak of CIA operative Valerie Plame's identity. The pardon, which has been in consideration for several months, was announced on Thursday evening, according to sources speaking to ABC News.

Libby, who served as Chief of Staff to former Vice President Dick Cheney, was found guilty of obstructing justice and making false statements to a grand jury investigating the unauthorized disclosure of Plame's identity. The revelation of Plame's identity put her life at risk and was allegedly orchestrated as a form of retaliation against her husband, Joseph Wilson, who had publicly disputed claims that were used to justify the Iraq War.

In the aftermath of Libby's conviction, there was significant support from the right for then-President George W. Bush to pardon Libby, with the term "witch hunt" being widely used to describe the prosecution of Libby for the release of classified information and lying to a grand jury. However, Bush ultimately commuted Libby's sentence, allowing him to avoid prison but leaving his conviction in place.

Now, Trump is granting a pardon to Libby, reaching back over a decade for this action. While it has been reported that the pardon has been on Trump's mind for months, the timing and the choice of Libby as the recipient of the pardon have raised questions.

In recent years, several individuals connected to the Trump administration have been charged and pleaded guilty to making false statements in connection with the ongoing investigation into potential ties between the Trump campaign and Russia. Michael Flynn, Rick Gates, and George Papadopoulos have all pleaded guilty to making false statements and agreed to cooperate with Special Counsel Robert Mueller. Alex Van der Zwaan, the first person sentenced in connection with the Trump–Russia investigation, is currently serving time for making false statements. Before Van der Zwaan's sentencing, Mueller made it clear that he wanted jail time for the Dutch lawyer, emphasizing that knowingly making a false statement to an investigator is a crime with consequences.

With the pardon of Libby, Trump appears to be sending a message that lying under oath is not a significant offense, as he has the power to pardon anyone.

Title: Trump Associates Face Growing Legal Fees Amid Investigations

Article:

Roger Stone, a confidant of President Donald Trump, has stated that legal fees related to ongoing lawsuits and congressional inquiries will cost him at least half a million dollars. Stone has set up a legal defense fund at WhoframedRogerStone.com to help offset these costs.

Former National Security Adviser Michael Flynn has also established a website to help pay off his legal fees, as the financial burden of probes into Russia's alleged election interference grows for Trump associates.

Stone is being sued by Project Democracy, a group run by former Obama administration lawyers, for alleged involvement in the release of emails from Democratic Party officials. Stone anticipates that this lawsuit will cost more than the preparation for an upcoming hearing before the House Intelligence Committee on Sept. 26 and potential testimony before the Senate Intelligence Committee.

Stone told TheDC that he has spent around $100,000 to dismiss the lawsuit from Project Democracy. Stone and others in Trump's orbit are not the only ones facing burdensome legal fees.

Reuters reported Tuesday that President Trump is using donations to his campaign and the Republican National Committee to pay off some of his legal fees, a legal procedure. An RNC spokesman told Reuters that the party covered a little over $230,000 in legal fees for the president.

The Daily Beast also reported Monday that Flynn's legal fees are estimated to exceed $1 million. The details of the ongoing investigations and the specific allegations against Stone and Flynn were not available in the provided text.

Title: Progressive Groups Oppose Grand Bargain, Risking Economic Stability and Retirement Entitlements

Article:

A group of progressive organizations, led by AFL-CIO President Richard Trumka, has expressed opposition to a grand bargain budget agreement in the upcoming lame duck Congress. In an op-ed published in the ███ newspaper, Trumka argued against any fixes to Social Security and Medicare as part of the agreement.

The opposition to a grand bargain could potentially harm the economy, negatively impact the middle class, and put retirement entitlements at risk. For nearly a century, progressives have worked to establish a secure and comprehensive safety net. With the passage of the Affordable Care Act in 2010, this mission is largely accomplished.

As the nation approaches its most significant demographic aging period, the challenge is to maintain the safety net. A responsible approach to fixing the safety net requires a balance of measures that ensure the programs' health and solvency, including new revenue, modest reductions in benefits for some recipients, and a commitment to not raising payroll taxes for working-class people in the future.

The authors of the op-ed argue that over the past five decades, the top two progressive economic priorities have been on a collision course: public investments in people and jobs versus the safety net. In the 1960s, federal investments in infrastructure, education, research, and other areas outstripped spending on major entitlement programs by a ratio of 3 to 1. By 2012, the ratio was reversed, with the U.S. spending $3 on major entitlement programs for every dollar spent on creating economic growth through public investments. By 2022, the ratio will be 6 to 1. The authors contend that this trend line must change to create the economic growth and middle-class opportunities desired.

Title: Trump Criticizes Bipartisan Immigration Proposal, Calls It "Horrible" on Border Security and "Weak" on Legal Immigration Reforms

Article:

WASHINGTON - President Donald Trump on Wednesday expressed opposition to a proposed bipartisan immigration deal, labeling it as "horrible" on U.S. border security and "very, very weak" on reforms for the legal immigration system. The Senate proposal, aimed at addressing the demands for protections for young adults brought to the United States illegally as children and dubbed "Dreamers," fell short of what most Republicans believe is necessary, according to the president.

In an interview with a news agency, Trump stated, "It's the opposite of what I campaigned for." The plan, presented to Trump last week by Republican Senator Lindsey Graham and Democratic Senator Dick Durbin, was not detailed in the report.

Last week, Trump drew international condemnation after reports emerged that he had questioned the value of taking immigrants from Africa and the Caribbean nation of Haiti during a closed-door meeting with lawmakers at the White House last Thursday, referring to them as "shithole" countries. Trump has since denied using that term.

In the interview on Wednesday, Trump declined to specify the words he used during the meeting, stating, "I'm not going to get into what I said, but I will tell you, it was a tough meeting."

Many Democrats have said they will not vote for spending legislation to keep the federal government funded past a Friday deadline without an immigration deal, and Republicans will need at least some Democratic votes to pass the funding extension in the Senate. Trump said a deal on immigration is still possible, stating, "Time is running out."

Democrats said the negotiated plan addressed Trump's priorities, including $2.7 billion for additional border security funding. However, the proposal was criticized for not providing enough funding for the wall Trump has promised to build on the U.S.-Mexican border, a project opposed by Democrats.

The proposal was also criticized for being "very, very weak" on curbing visas for extended family members of immigrants and failing to end a diversity visa lottery program. Trump stated, "Lindsey - he meant well - but I said, 'Well, how many Republicans agree with this?'"

Trump blamed Senator Durbin for leaking the language he used in the meeting, a disclosure that prompted critics to denounce Trump as a racist, an accusation he denied. Trump campaigned for president in 2016 promising a hard line on immigration, including deporting all of the roughly 11 million illegal immigrants already in the country and a "total and complete shutdown" of the entry of Muslims into the United States. As president, he has signed three orders banning entry of most people from several Muslim-majority countries as well as rescinding the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program.

Title: Koch Network Launches New Super PAC Ahead of Midterm Elections

Article:

The Koch network, a powerful donor group associated with free-market billionaire Charles Koch, has launched a new super PAC, Americans for Prosperity Action, on Monday. This move bolsters the network's political influence ahead of the upcoming midterm elections in November.

The Americans for Prosperity Action super PAC allows the network to directly advocate for voters to support or oppose specific candidates. The new super PAC is an extension of Koch's long-standing grassroots wing, Americans for Prosperity, which operates in 36 states. However, the Americans for Prosperity group, being a nonprofit, faces restrictions on its political activity.

Super PACs, unlike nonprofits, can raise and spend unlimited amounts of money to influence candidate elections, as long as they do not coordinate their spending decisions with the politicians they support.

The launch of the new super PAC follows tensions between Koch officials and President Donald Trump over trade and immigration policies. Koch's aides have criticized Trump's trade policies with China and other countries, labeling them as protectionist, which they argue will harm American businesses and consumers.

The rift between the two parties widened when the Republican National Committee warned Republican donors and GOP candidates using the Koch network's in-house data program to reach voters to avoid the Koch network and its political operation.

In a statement about the new super PAC, Koch officials stated they are "committed to working with anyone to advance positive policies." The Koch network has not yet disclosed the amount they will spend through the new political committee, but they previously indicated they were likely to expend up to $400 million over the two-year election cycle to aid candidates and advance free-market policies.

Republicans are currently fighting to maintain their majority in the U.S. House of Representatives, where Democrats need to flip 23 seats to seize the chamber. Further information regarding the Koch network's involvement in specific races is unavailable at this time.

Title: Supreme Court's Decision on Asylum Policy Sparks Controversy, Concerns for Asylum Seekers

Article:

The Supreme Court's decision to allow the implementation of a new asylum policy, which restricts asylum seekers from entering the United States at any point along the border, has sparked controversy and concerns among the left. Critics argue that the policy has questionable legal standing and could harm asylum seekers.

The policy, which is part of President Donald Trump's immigration agenda, has been met with opposition due to its potential violation of international humanitarian law and the United States' historical debt to Central America. The policy, they argue, disregards the legal rights of asylum seekers and ignores the country's responsibility to provide humanitarian aid.

Under U.S. law, individuals can seek asylum at any point along the border. However, it is unclear whether the Trump administration has the legal authority to enact the new policy, which is part of the ongoing legal challenge.

The Supreme Court's decision to allow the policy's implementation has been criticized for disregarding the health, safety, and legal rights of asylum seekers. The decision is seen as part of a troubling pattern of deference to the Trump administration's wishes.

The implementation of the policy is expected to push more asylum seekers into Mexico, a country that is ill-equipped to offer humanitarian aid. Asylum seekers in Mexico face dangers such as kidnapping, sexual assault, overcrowded shelters, and slim employment prospects. They also have difficulty finding lawyers, which significantly decreases their chances of having their asylum cases approved.

Mexico does not have the infrastructure to absorb tens of thousands of asylum seekers, nor does it have a legally robust asylum process. Individuals fleeing persecution in Central America, for example, on account of sexual orientation, are not likely to find protection in Mexico. The U.S. regularly accepts asylum seekers from Mexico who have suffered from the same kinds of persecution.

The Supreme Court's decision was both premature and unnecessary, according to critics, and is part of a troubling pattern of deference to the Trump administration's wishes. The decision was made before the lower courts had a chance to fully consider the case, and it is seen as a departure from the Court's traditional approach to emergency action.

The increase in nationwide injunctions issued by district judges has been cited as a common response to the Court's aggressiveness. However, many emergency stays have been issued in cases where no nationwide injunction is at stake, or in more or less routine disputes over information the government must provide when it is sued.

In the absence of an explicit quid pro quo over restarting aid, the context and circumstances are what will become the focus of the investigation. There is enough here to support impeachment, but whether it is also enough to convince Republicans and lead to removal is another matter.

Title: "Cost and Efficiency Concerns Raised in Debate Over 'Medicare for All' Healthcare System"

Article:

The proposal for a universal "Medicare for All" healthcare system, a popular topic among progressive Democrats, has been met with criticism, particularly in terms of cost and efficiency. In an op-ed published in The Wall Street Journal, Scott W. Atlas of the Hoover Institution argues that the cost of implementing such a system would be prohibitive.

For instance, the estimated cost for single-payer healthcare in California alone is approximately $400 billion annually, more than twice the state's current annual budget. Nationwide, the cost of "Medicare for All" over its first decade is estimated to exceed $32 trillion. Doubling federal income and corporate taxes would not be sufficient to cover these costs, and further restrictions on health-care access could result.

In 2017, a single-payer bill passed by New York's state assembly would have cost $173 billion annually, significantly more than the state's current annual revenue. Even when factoring in savings from eliminated insurance premiums and co-payments, the revenue would not be sufficient to cover the costs.

In 2014, Vermont had to abandon plans for a single-payer system due to the estimated $2.5 billion annual cost, almost double the state's current budget, and the requirement for an 11.5 percent payroll tax increase and a 9 percent income tax increase.

Cost is not the only concern. Atlas points to waiting times in countries with single-payer systems, such as the United Kingdom and Canada, where long wait times for medical appointments and treatments are common. In contrast, wait lists are not a significant issue in the United States.

Additionally, Atlas argues that single-payer systems impose long delays in the debut of new drugs for cancer and other serious diseases. For example, in 2011, the Food and Drug Administration approved 32 new cancer drugs in a decade, while the European Medicines Agency approved 26. All 23 drugs approved by both Europe and the U.S. were available to American patients first.

Proponents of Medicare for All often argue that they do not want to fully nationalize healthcare, as Canada has done. Atlas counters that the poor and middle class would suffer the most under a single-payer system, as they would be unable to circumvent the system. He also notes that countries with the most experience with single-payer systems, such as Sweden and Denmark, are moving toward private provision of healthcare.

Atlas suggests that the United States' healthcare system is flawed due to a lack of market-based solutions. He proposes ways to address issues such as pre-existing conditions, drug trials, and licensing of healthcare professionals without causing costs to spiral out of control.

Given the Republican Party's reluctance to engage in healthcare policy following the passage of Obamacare, it seems unlikely that market-friendly solutions will be implemented any time soon. If "Medicare for All" is adopted, the cost would be substantial, not just in terms of taxes, but also in terms of potential restrictions on healthcare access and delays in treatment.

Title: Major Companies Under Scrutiny for Advertising on Russian Social Media Platform Known for White Supremacist Content

Article:

Over 100 companies, including Coca-Cola, Pepsi, Adidas, and Reebok, have announced a boycott of Facebook in protest of divisive political speech. This move coincides with a public pressure campaign led by Joe Biden and other top Democrats to press Facebook to enforce stricter control over President Trump's postings. However, many of these companies, such as Coca-Cola, Pepsi, Adidas, and Reebok, have been regular advertisers on VK, a popular Russian media website known for its laissez-faire attitude toward online hate speech and a haven for white supremacists and neo-Nazis, who have been banned from Facebook.

VK's popularity among white supremacists and neo-Nazis has been documented for years by media outlets and watchdog groups. Despite this, the companies that joined the Facebook ad boycott continue to market their products and brands on their VK pages, including Starbucks, Ford, Unilever, Colgate, Vans, The North Face, and Patagonia. On July 2, Colgate ran a promotion on VK offering prizes to members who purchased its products and used the VK app to scan the product code.

Coca-Cola has run advertising campaigns on VK, including a controversial 2016 ad in which the company included the disputed territories of Crimea and the Kuril Islands on a map of Russia. Pepsi has also been an advertiser on the site and reportedly collaborated with VK on a payment app in 2018. Both still have an active presence on the platform.

None of the companies responded to inquiries about whether they would stop marketing on VK. Starbucks told the ███ that its temporary pause in advertising "applies to all social media platforms." Microsoft, Honda, Reebok, Vans, Patagonia, Colgate, The North Face, Unilever, Pepsi, and Coca-Cola did not respond to request for comment.

The Anti-Defamation League said VK has become "an international hub for white supremacists" who have been kicked off mainstream U.S. social media websites such as Facebook. Although VK has taken some recent steps to crack down on hate groups, organizations like the National Socialist Movement and the Ku Klux Klan still maintain an active presence on the website. Last month, Focus magazine reported the far-right Russian Imperial Movement, a U.S.-designated terrorist organization, has been holding paramilitary training sessions for foreign white supremacist groups this summer, which are bookable over VK.

VK also complies with Russian laws against "gay propaganda," which prohibit content that is considered supportive of same-sex relationships. Several gay-rights groups were barred from the website last October after a judge ruled that their posts violated the law.

Title: U.S. Coronavirus Death Toll Surpasses 9/11 Toll

Article:

The death toll from the coronavirus pandemic in the United States has surpassed the number of people killed in the September 11, 2001, terror attacks. As of March 30, the virus's death toll in the U.S. exceeded 3,100, surpassing the 2,977 victims who were killed in the World Trade Center, the Pentagon, and four hijacked planes on September 11.

While the virus is incomparable to the sudden deaths on American soil in a terrorist attack, its slow-moving toll on civilian lives promises to upend American society in peacetime as only terror has done. The number of confirmed cases is still rising rapidly, meaning many more people will likely die from COVID-19 in the weeks and months ahead.

The impact of September 11 went far beyond its initial death toll. Thousands of people were injured in the attacks, and thousands more died of diseases caused by exposure to toxic substances in the aftermath of the rubble of the Twin Towers. Its economic impact was similarly grim: In the three months following the attack, New York City's economy lost 143,000 jobs each month and $2.8 billion in wages, according to a New York Times report from 2004.

The coronavirus's effects will be far-reaching, as well. An estimated 160,000 people have been infected with the coronavirus in the United States, resulting in more than 20,000 hospitalizations and placing an unprecedented strain on the nation's health care system. In addition, more than 3 million people have filed for unemployment due to the shuttering of non-essential businesses across the country. As the economy stumbled, the Congress passed a $2.2 trillion stimulus package—the largest of its kind in modern history.

Title: New Jersey Governor Chris Christie's Approval Ratings Skyrocket Following Sandy Response

Article:

In the aftermath of Superstorm Sandy, New Jersey Governor Chris Christie's approval ratings have surged significantly, according to three consecutive surveys over the past 24 hours. The Quinnipiac University poll, released Tuesday morning, indicates that 72% of Garden State voters approve of Christie's job performance, a 16-point increase since before the storm hit the state in late October.

On Monday, Christie announced his intention to seek a second term as New Jersey governor. The day prior, a Fairleigh Dickinson University survey showed his approval rating at 77%, a 21-point increase since late October. A new Rutgers-Eagleton survey also reported a 19-point jump in Christie's favorable impression, with 67% of respondents viewing him favorably.

In his re-election bid announcement, Christie emphasized his commitment to leading New Jersey through the storm's aftermath and the subsequent rebuilding and restoration process. "The public needs to know that I'm in this for the long haul. The person who has helped to lead them through the initial crisis wants to be here to lead them through the rebuilding and restoration of our state," he said at a news conference.

According to the Rutgers-Eagleton poll, 59% of New Jersey registered voters support a second term for Christie, while 32% oppose his re-election. In both the Quinnipiac and Fairleigh Dickinson polls, a significant factor in the increase in Christie's overall approval rating was a substantial rise in support from Democrats.

Maurice Carroll, director of the Quinnipiac University Polling Institute, commented, "Gov. Chris Christie never looked more like a 'Jersey Guy' than when he stood on the Seaside boardwalk after Sandy, and, just about unanimously, his New Jersey neighbors – Republicans, Democrats, Independents – applauded."

During the 2012 presidential campaign, Christie served as a top surrogate for Mitt Romney and was considered a potential running mate for the GOP nominee. However, he faced criticism from some Republicans following Romney's loss for his appearance with President Barack Obama in New Jersey during the storm's aftermath and his praise of the president and the federal government's assistance to New Jersey immediately after the storm.

The Quinnipiac poll indicates that the vast majority of New Jersey voters, including two-thirds of Republicans, view the GOP criticism of Christie as "nonsense."

The news of Christie's re-election bid was widely expected. Much of the electoral speculation in New Jersey now centers on which Democrat will challenge Christie in the fall, with much of the focus on two-term Newark Mayor Cory Booker, who is seen as a rising star in the Democratic Party. Newark's Democratic mayor said in mid-November his decision on running for governor has been delayed due to Sandy.

Other potential candidates include state Sen. Richard Codey, who served as governor for 14 months following the November 2004 resignation of then–Gov. Jim McGreevey, as well as State Sen. Barbara Buono and Assembly member Lou Greenwald.

According to the Rutgers-Eagleton poll, Christie has large leads over all of his potential Democratic challengers in hypothetical 2013 general election matchups.

New Jersey and Virginia are the only two states to hold gubernatorial contests in the year after a presidential election. Because they are the only contests in the election cycle, they often receive outsized attention.

The Quinnipiac University poll was conducted November 19-25, with 1,664 New Jersey registered voters questioned by telephone. The survey's overall sampling error is plus or minus 2.4 percentage points. The Rutgers-Eagleton poll was conducted November 14-17, with 1,108 New Jersey registered voters questioned by telephone. The survey's overall sampling error is plus or minus 2.9 percentage points.

Title: House Declines to Consider New Senate GOP Bill on National Emergencies Act

Article:

Speaker of the House Nancy Pelosi announced on Wednesday that the House would not take up a new Senate Republican bill aimed at curbing the National Emergencies Act. Pelosi stated that the goal was to constrain President Trump, not to address broader presidential powers issues.

Pelosi's comments came in response to a new bill by Sen. Mike Lee that would, in the future, limit a president's powers under the 1976 Emergencies Act. The bill would not apply retroactively to President Trump's recent border emergency declaration or to the more than two dozen other emergencies still in effect from previous presidents.

Democrats argue that the GOP is using the Lee bill as political cover to support President Trump's wall declaration, while also preventing future presidential power abuses. Senators face a showdown vote on Thursday on the wall declaration.

The House has already passed a resolution to overturn the declaration, and it appears that enough Republicans and Democrats in the Senate will approve it as well. However, President Trump has vowed to veto the bill, and there is not enough support currently to override him.

Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell told reporters on Tuesday that Republicans do not question President Trump's powers, but they have misgivings about his decision to divert funds from the Pentagon for additional border wall construction.

The president is invoking the National Emergencies Act, a post-Watergate piece of legislation that grants the Executive Branch strong powers to rearrange funds if the president declares an emergency is ongoing. In this case, President Trump plans to take more than $6 billion from the Defense Department for wall-building.

Senate Majority Leader McConnell stated, "I think most of my members now believe this is not a constitutional issue, but rather this grant of authority to any president, not just this one, but any president, was too broad back in the 1970s when it was passed."

His Democratic counterpart, Sen. Charles E. Schumer, said Republicans have long complained about an overbearing Executive Branch. This, he said, is their chance to reel it in.

"The vote tomorrow boils down to something very simply for our Republican friends: Do you believe in the Constitution and conservative principles?" Mr. Schumer said.

However, Republicans argue that Democrats are being hypocritical, as they did not object when President Obama claimed executive powers to create the DACA deportation amnesty, and Democrats also voted for border fencing in the past.

Title: Vice Presidential Debate Moderator Faces Criticism for Question Delivery

Article:

Tuesday's Vice Presidential debate, moderated by Elaine Quijano, was met with criticism for its disjointed and unfocused nature. The conversation often meandered, with the candidates speaking past each other rather than engaging in substantive discussion.

Quijano, the debate's moderator, faced criticism for her handling of the debate. David Axelrod, CNN's senior political commentator, observed on Twitter that Quijano seemed "intent on running through her questions, even when significant exchanges are happening."

One notable example occurred when Quijano switched topics as Sen. Tim Kaine was pressing Gov. Mike Pence to explain why he had not defended his running mate Donald Trump on six different issues. Instead of allowing what may have been a revealing conversation to continue, she moved the discussion along.

Jeffrey Goldberg, the Atlantic's national correspondent, tweeted shortly after that moment, "Elaine Quijano should occasionally go where the debate is going, and not stop these interesting arguments."

Kenneth Li, the managing editor at Newsweek, asked, "Why change the topic at the best moment?"

At other times, Quijano seemed powerless to stop the candidates from bickering with each other. She was even forced to reprimand both candidates at one point, telling them, "Gentlemen, the people at home can not understand you when you speak over each other."

On at least one occasion, Quijano was similarly powerless in getting the candidates to address her question. "I'll remind you both, the topic was North Korea," she told the candidates as they attacked one another over the Clinton and Trump foundations.

Quijano had an extremely challenging task, as there is only one vice presidential debate, and the format required her to address nine topics in just 90 minutes. Moreover, both candidates were more interested in attacking each other's running mates than answering the questions at hand. They also had two different styles, which made moderation difficult: Kaine was notably aggressive and interrupted Pence frequently, while Pence cast a more thoughtful, reflective posture.

However, Quijano's performance served as a reminder that debates are not scripted events, and they require moderators who can be fluid and adapt to the direction the candidates choose to take the discussion.

Title: Senate Republicans to Cede Control to Democrats Over Weekend Amid Ongoing Filibuster Dispute

Article:

Senate Republicans are reportedly planning to cede control of the chamber to Democrats over the weekend, as a result of the ongoing dispute over filibuster changes on nominations.
