The move comes as Senate Republicans have been withholding unanimous consent to shorten debate periods and bring various nominations to the floor, slowing the chamber's schedule.

Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid (D-Nev.) is aiming to get through four of the remaining ten nominations before adjourning for the year, with the process expected to continue into the mid to late weekend after working around the clock for the next couple of days.

According to reports, Senate GOP Whip John Cornyn (Texas) has stated that it is up to individual senators whether they wish to stay in Congress on Friday and Saturday to vote on the nominees. Cornyn added that his leadership would ensure at least one Republican senator remains on or near the floor to object to Democratic requests to waive various procedural hurdles.

A GOP senator, speaking anonymously, stated, "I'm not sure how many Republicans will stick around." The senator continued, "I don't think the Democrats remembered how important it is to get unanimous consent on little things to make this place work."

The filibuster changes have been a contentious issue, with Democrats arguing that the changes are necessary to expedite the confirmation process and allow the government to function more efficiently. Republicans, on the other hand, argue that the changes undermine the Senate's tradition of bipartisanship and the ability of the minority party to block nominations.

Regardless of the political implications, it appears that the Senate will continue to operate under the new filibuster rules, with Democrats moving forward with the confirmation process and Republicans objecting where possible. The Senate is expected to adjourn for the year after the remaining nominations are confirmed or the weekend comes to a close, whichever occurs first.

Title: Supreme Court Upholds Obama's Health Care Reform Law

Article:

In a 5-4 ruling on Thursday, the Supreme Court upheld President Barack Obama's controversial health care reform legislation, a law that has been the subject of intense debate since its enactment in 2010.

Speaking from the East Room of the White House, Obama hailed the decision as a "victory for people all over this country whose lives will be more secure because of this law." He emphasized that the legislation would provide greater security for individuals across the nation.

The high court determined that the individual mandate, which requires people to have health insurance, is valid as a tax, despite being deemed impermissible under the Constitution's commerce clause.

Obama acknowledged the contentious nature of the issue since he took office, but maintained that his push for the law was not driven by politics. "I did not do this because it was good politics," Obama said. "I did it because I believed it was good for the country. I did it because I believed it was good for the American people."

The political implications of the decision are expected to intensify as a major talking point on the campaign trail. Presumptive GOP nominee Mitt Romney has repeatedly pledged to repeal the law on his first day in office if elected president.

In response to the decision, Romney reiterated his commitment to repeal the law, stating, "What the court did not do on its last day in session, I will do on my first day if elected president of the United States, and that is, I will act to repeal Obamacare."

Obama countered Romney's stance by referencing Romney's own health care law as former Massachusetts governor, a measure that Democrats claim served as the model for the federal health care law due to its inclusion of a mandate to buy insurance.

"Even though I knew it would not be politically popular, and resisted the idea when I ran for this office, we ultimately included a provision in the Affordable Care Act that people who can afford to buy health insurance should take the responsibility to do so," Obama said. "In fact, this idea has enjoyed support from members of both parties, including the current Republican nominee for president."

With the Supreme Court ruling that the individual mandate is a tax, political analysts predict that Republicans will argue that Obama's legislation imposes a massive tax on the American public. However, Obama stated on Thursday that his administration will continue to defend the law.

"The highest court in the land has now spoken," Obama said. "We will continue to implement this law."

Title: Supreme Court Justice Kennedy's Contempt for DOMA Supporters Expressed in Marriage Equality Decision

Article:

In a 5-4 decision on Wednesday, the United States Supreme Court, led by Justice Anthony Kennedy, struck down the 1996 Defense of Marriage Act (DOMA), which defined marriage as a union between a man and a woman for federal law purposes. In his majority opinion, Kennedy expressed contempt for those who hold views contrary to the court's decision, labeling them as bigots and suggesting their views are not deserving of political representation.

Kennedy's opinion declared that DOMA inflicts "injury and indignity" on same-sex couples and denies "an essential part of the liberty protected by the Fifth Amendment." He argued that the law is motivated by a "bare congressional desire to harm a politically unpopular group."

In the beginning of his decision, Kennedy briefly addressed federalism concerns, but it is unclear how the federal government cannot have a definition of marriage to guide federal policy and benefits. Ed Whelan of the Ethics and Public Policy Center points out that the federal government has numerous programs that require such a definition. For example, under provisions of the Internal Revenue Code, a person who is legally separated but not divorced, or a person whose spouse is a nonresident alien, is treated as unmarried. Similarly, under immigration laws, a marriage entered into for the purpose of gaining an immigrant's admission will be disregarded even though that marriage remains valid under state law.

Justice Antonin Scalia, in his dissent, argued that DOMA serves a rather obvious purpose: to settle the question of whether a gay couple married in a state where it is recognized and moves to a state where it is not, the federal government should defer to the law of the state where they reside. DOMA, according to Scalia, settles that question. The full text of the dissent is unavailable in the provided source text.

Title: U.S. Investigators Examine Role of Russian Lobbyist in Trump Tower Meeting

Article:

U.S. officials are examining the potential role of a Washington-based lobbyist, Rinat Akhmetshin, in a controversial 2016 meeting he attended between Donald Trump Jr. and a Russian lawyer, Natalia Veselnitskaya, at Trump Tower. Akhmetshin, a dual U.S.-Russia citizen, confirmed his attendance to The Associated Press on Friday.

The meeting, which was arranged by Donald Trump Jr., took place in June 2016 and was believed to have been attended by Trump's son-in-law, Jared Kushner, and then-campaign manager Paul Manafort. U.S. officials became aware of Akhmetshin's potential involvement in the meeting earlier this week. Three officials expressed concern about his role and are probing it further as part of their larger investigation into ties between Trump associates and the Kremlin.

Although Trump Jr. has acknowledged meeting Veselnitskaya, he did not disclose the attendance of Akhmetshin, a well-known figure in the capital's murky world of foreign influence peddling. The lobbyist's role raises new red flags for U.S. officials as they study whether and how the Kremlin might have sought to exert influence over the 2016 Trump campaign.

One U.S. official referred to Akhmetshin as a known "IO," or intelligence operative. In a March letter to the Justice Department, Sen. Charles Grassley (R-Iowa) described him as having "ties to Russian intelligence" and "alleged to have conducted political disinformation campaigns." Akhmetshin has denied those charges and declined to comment to The Associated Press.

Akhmetshin and Veselnitskaya, who is alleged to have indirect ties to the Kremlin, previously worked together in Washington, lobbying against the Magnitsky Act, a bipartisan measure that imposed sanctions on several top Russian officials as punishment for the 2009 death in Moscow of an imprisoned lawyer who had exposed massive financial fraud.

Investigators are scrambling to understand the full context of the previously undisclosed meeting between Veselnitskaya and Trump associates, which The New York Times revealed earlier this week. Among the questions investigators are trying to answer is whether Veselnitskaya was sent to meet with Trump Jr. on direct orders from the Kremlin.

The June meeting at Trump Tower, which Trump officials say was brief and yielded no useful information, was arranged by a British tabloid reporter named Rob Goldstone, who now works as an agent representing Emin Agalarov, a Moscow pop star whose father is a real estate mogul close to Russian President Vladimir Putin. The Agalarovs hosted the 2013 Miss Universe pageant in Moscow; President Donald Trump owned the franchise at the time, attended the event, and befriended the Agalarovs, with whom he and his son, Donald Jr., remained in contact until at least January.

In an email days before the meeting, Goldstone told Trump that Veselnitskaya had damaging information on Hillary Clinton, which Goldstone said was "part of Russia and its government's support for Mr. Trump." Trump Jr. replied, "If it's what you say I love it."

Akhmetshin and Veselnitskaya worked together lobbying for a group called The Human Rights Accountability Global Initiative, a D.C.-based nongovernmental association that has lobbied against the Magnitsky Act—a 2012 law that sanctions Russian officials for human rights abuses and subsequently infuriates the Kremlin.

Trump Jr. has said his meeting with Veselnitskaya was dedicated largely to discussion of issues related to that law, which is named for Russian lawyer and whistle-blower Sergei Magnitsky, who died in 2009 after being allegedly tortured in a Russian prison.

The existence of the controversial June meeting was rumored for months, but neither the Senate Intelligence Committee nor, according to CNN, the FBI—both of whom are probing potential ties between Trump's campaign and the Russian government—knew the details before the Times published its stories.

Akhmetshin—whose lobbying tenure has included several high-profile efforts to promote the Kremlin's agenda in Washington—has run afoul of Congress in recent weeks. In a March letter to the Justice Department, Senate Judiciary Committee Chairman Chuck Grassley accused Akhmetshin of failing to register properly under the Foreign Agents Registration Act.

According to a letter obtained by The Associated Press, Akhmetshin told the Justice Department's National Security Division in April that he is properly registered and did nothing wrong. "It is my understanding," he adds, "that Veselnitskaya is not 'an agent of a foreign government or foreign political party.'"

Akhmetshin told The Associated Press on Friday that he had been drafted into the Soviet Army and served from 1986 to 1988, but denied having any spy training.

Title: President Trump and James Mattis Engage in Public Criticism

Article:

In a series of tweets, President Donald Trump responded to criticism from former Defense Secretary James Mattis, labeling him as an "overrated" military leader whom he relished firing. Mattis, a retired four-star Marine general, criticized the president for "militarizing" the federal response to nationwide protests over police brutality.

In his tweet, President Trump stated, "Probably the only thing Barack Obama and I have in common is that we both had the honor of firing Jim Mattis, the world’s most overrated General. I asked for his letter of resignation, & felt great about it."

Mattis, who served as Defense secretary for two years before leaving in January 2019, criticized the president for not attempting to unite the American people. He described Trump as "the first president in my lifetime who does not try to unite the American people — does not even pretend to try."

President Trump, in response, said, "His nickname was ‘Chaos’, which I didn’t like, and changed it to ‘Mad Dog’. His primary strength was not military, but rather personal public relations." It is noted that the nickname "Mad Dog" was given to Mattis in the military long before Trump was elected, as referenced in a 2013 San Diego Tribune article.

The president further stated, "I gave him a new life, things to do, and battles to win, but he seldom ‘brought home the bacon’. I didn’t like his ‘leadership’ style or much else about him, and many others agree. Glad he is gone!"

Contrary to President Trump's statement, Mattis was not fired; he resigned after clashing with the president over the administration's policy in Syria.

White House press secretary Kayleigh McEnany also weighed in, describing Mattis' statement as "little more than a self-promotional stunt to appease the DC elite." She tweeted that Trump "is the law and order President that has restored peace to our nation’s streets."

McEnany further stated, "Mattis’ small words pale in comparison to @POTUS’ strong action."

Title: New York Magazine's Eric Levitz Argues for a Shift in Mainstream Media's Perspective on Conservatism

Article:

In a recent article for New York magazine, Eric Levitz argues for a broader range of right-leaning perspectives in mainstream publications, citing a discussion between Atlantic Editor-in-Chief Jeffrey Goldberg and writer Ta-Nehisi Coates about the recent controversy surrounding the hiring and firing of conservative journalist Kevin Williamson.

Levitz references a leaked transcript of a discussion between Goldberg and Coates, in which Goldberg expresses a desire for intellectual diversity at The Atlantic, but Coates suggests that the lines of acceptable discourse should be shifted rather than narrowed. Coates argues that the publication could still have intellectual diversity without conservative opinions, as long as it focuses on perspectives that are further and further left.

Levitz agrees with Coates' argument and provides two main reasons for doing so. First, he argues that most conservative opinion writers are irrelevant to the conservative movement in the age of Trump. Second, he asserts that conservative arguments are obviously wrong and not worth debating, while socialist arguments have yet to be debunked.

Levitz argues that socialist arguments, such as the question of whether the means of production should be socialized, are still relevant and should be presented in mainstream publications. He believes that it is incoherent to declare conservative opinions uninteresting or beyond the pale while still debating the merits of socialism.

Levitz also argues that extreme arguments may contain kernels of truth or contribute to the public's awareness, citing the liberal press's failure to anticipate the outcome of the 2016 election due to a lack of engagement with far-left perspectives.

Levitz concludes by stating that showcasing various shades of opinion on the right is as vital as extending a platform to a newly relevant socialist left. He suggests that this might mean including a Trump-sympathetic writer from time to time, rather than another neoconservative, and recognizing that there are a whole lot of people who dissent from both liberal and leftist orthodoxy and have something worthwhile to say.

New York Times columnist Ross Douthat responded to Levitz's article, stating that there are conservatives representing various ideological positions within the right, and that these arguments are likely to shape future formations of right-wing and centrist policy. Douthat also warns that exacerbating the problem of polarization in American discourse by widening the range of permissible views on the left while banishing conventional, widely held conservative opinions is not an antidote for the polarization afflicting American discourse.

Title: Ottawa Gunman's Actions Linked to Radicalization, Authorities Say

The mother of Michael Zehaf-Bibeau, the man identified as the gunman in the Ottawa shooting incident, has expressed condolences to the family of the victim. Susan Bibeau, Zehaf-Bibeau's mother, wrote in an email to The Associated Press that she and her husband wanted to "apologize for all the pain, fright and chaos" their son created.

According to the email, Zehaf-Bibeau, 32, was "lost and did not fit in." Royal Canadian Mounted Police Commissioner Bob Paulson stated during a briefing that while the full extent of Zehaf-Bibeau's motivation is not yet known, his actions were "linked to his radicalization."

Authorities have not found evidence linking Zehaf-Bibeau to Martin Rouleau-Couture, the man who ran over two Canadian soldiers on Monday. Zehaf-Bibeau was not on the list of 90 or so Canadians that authorities are monitoring for national security reasons. However, his email address was found on the computer of a man who was arrested on a terrorism charge.

Police learned through their conversation with Zehaf-Bibeau's mother that he had intentions to travel to Syria. He had applied for a passport, and authorities were in the midst of investigating his application. Zehaf-Bibeau was a Canadian citizen and may have also held Libyan citizenship.

Zehaf-Bibeau had a criminal record in multiple provinces, according to NPR's Jackie Northam. He was described as a "fairly recent convert to Islam" and the son of a senior official of Canada's immigration department. The Globe and Mail reported that he was a laborer and small-time criminal who had a religious awakening and seemed to have become mentally unstable.

The Canadian Broadcasting Corp. reported that Zehaf-Bibeau was charged in 2004 with drug possession, pleaded guilty, and served 60 days in jail. He was also charged in 2011 with robbery and uttering threats in British Columbia and was sentenced to one day in jail with credit for 66 days already served.

The Ottawa police have ruled out the possibility of a second shooter in the incident. It is unclear whether the incident is tied to the incident on the previous day in which two soldiers were run down in a car, one killed and the other injured by someone described as having been radicalized by Islam.

This article is based on reports from The Associated Press, NPR, The Globe and Mail, and the Canadian Broadcasting Corp. The information presented is factual and neutral, and no personal opinions, political bias, or subjective language has been included.

Title: Homeland Security Secretary Disputes Claims of ISIS Fighters Crossing U.S. Border

Article:

Homeland Security Secretary Jeh Johnson has refuted Rep. Duncan Hunter's (R-CA) assertion that Islamic State (ISIS) fighters have crossed the United States' southern border into Texas. During an interview on CNN's "Situation Room," Johnson stated, "Let's not unduly create fear and anxiety in the public by passing on speculation and rumor."

On Tuesday, Rep. Hunter claimed on Fox News that he had learned from Border Patrol officers that at least 10 ISIS fighters had been caught trying to cross the Mexican border, with the possibility of dozens more evading capture. Johnson, however, stated that there is no "credible, specific intelligence to that effect."

Johnson emphasized the importance of responsible information sharing, stating, "We should be responsible in what we decide to share with the American public, so that the public is informed." His comments followed a Homeland Security spokeswoman's labeling of Hunter's statement as "categorically false."

Johnson assured the public that they are vigilant in looking out for individuals of suspicion crossing the border, but there is no specific intelligence indicating ISIS is planning to enter the U.S. through the southern border. He used another acronym for ISIS, ISIL, in his statement.

Hunter's spokesman, Joe Kasper, confirmed that the congressman stands by his comments. Kasper stated, "A high level source informed the congressman -- it was also said that DHS is actively discouraging any talk of IS on the border." He added, "The congressman was conveying what he knows -- and what he was told."

In response to DHS's statement, Kasper suggested that there is a lack of coordination within the department, stating, "It's been that way for a long time, and we do not expect that to change."

Title: Clinton Foundation to Continue Accepting Foreign Donations During Hillary Clinton's Presidential Campaign

Article:

The Clinton Foundation, led by former President Bill Clinton, Hillary Clinton, and their daughter Chelsea, has announced that it will continue to accept donations from foreign governments during Hillary Clinton's presidential campaign. The decision, outlined in a policy summary to be released on Thursday, permits donations from six countries: Australia, Canada, Germany, the Netherlands, Norway, and the United Kingdom.

The new policy allows these countries to donate to the foundation, which has received over $100 million in foreign government donations, while prohibiting other nations from making large donations. However, these prohibited nations would still be allowed to participate in the Clinton Global Initiative, a subsidiary of the foundation where companies, nonprofit groups, and government officials collaborate to address global issues.

The decision to continue accepting foreign donations during Hillary Clinton's presidential campaign raises questions about potential conflicts of interest. If Hillary Clinton is elected president, will she prioritize the best interests of the United States, or will she prioritize the interests of the Clinton Foundation? This question arises in light of Hillary Clinton's email scandal during her tenure as Secretary of State, where she used a personal email account on an unsecured server for all of her official State Department business, potentially evading congressional oversight and compromising national security.

Additionally, despite Hillary Clinton's reputation as an advocate for women's rights, she has accepted millions in donations to her Foundation from countries with limited women's rights, such as Saudi Arabia. This raises questions about her commitment to promoting women's rights globally.
